site_title: New York celebrates 2015 with Taylor Swift and a big ball
summary: Hundreds of thousands of people gathered in New York's Times Square on New Year's Eve to celebrate the start of 2015. Taylor Swift was the headlining musical act, performing alongside Idina Menzel. The event featured a 12,000-pound crystal ball with 32,000 LED lights and 2,688 Waterford crystals, which was dropped to mark the final minute of 2014. The celebration was attended by nearly a million people, with an estimated 200 million Americans tuning in on TV and one billion more worldwide.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group has secured an S$128 million contract from the Housing Development Board for a Sembawang residential project. The 36-month construction period will involve six blocks of residential buildings and commercial facilities. Meanwhile, Second Chance Properties reported a 56% drop in Q1 net profit to S$1.7 million, with revenues falling 4% to S$8.84 million. The company's shares closed unchanged at S$0.445.

site_title: Sony's 'Interview' lands on pay TV and in 580 theaters
summary: Sony's comedy film "The Interview" is now available through US pay TV operators, nearly doubling the number of independent theaters showing the movie. The film, which was canceled on Christmas Day due to hacking threats, earned $15 million in four days and was added to Apple's iTunes store. It will also be sold through Vudu and Sony's PlayStation Network. The limited theatrical release brought in $2.8 million at the box office, with Sony aiming to recoup its $44 million production budget and $30-40 million in marketing costs.

site_title: China to better handle property in crime cases
summary: China's leading reform group approved measures to better handle properties involved in crimes, aiming to improve judicial justice and increase the credibility of the judicial system. The measures, approved by President Xi Jinping, include strengthening cooperation among departments and exploring a central platform to share information about properties involved in crimes. The move comes after recent judicial injustices involving properties in crime cases, with officials warned not to interfere in the handling of such properties.

site_title: US: Wall Street lower but finishes year with solid gains
summary: US stocks closed lower on New Year's Eve, but finished the year with solid gains, notching a sixth straight annual increase. The Dow rose 7.5% and the Nasdaq 13.4%, with Southwest Airlines Co being the best-performing S&P component at 124.6% gain. Despite headwinds, the S&P 500 finished the year up 11.4% and closed out a third straight year of double-digit gains.

site_title: US: Markets close Thursday for New Year's holiday
summary: The US stock and bond markets will be closed on Thursday for the New Year's holiday and will reopen on Friday with a normal schedule.

site_title: Snapchat plans global view of new year joy
summary: Snapchat plans a global 24-hour New Year's Eve countdown, featuring photos and videos from users at celebrations in Dubai, New York City, St Petersburg, and other locations worldwide. The app will stitch together the content to create a documentary-like view of how people are experiencing New Year's Eve, with the story disappearing after 24 hours. This initiative showcases Snapchat's growing prominence among teenagers and young adults, with 25.3 million unique US visitors, and its evolution into a mobile broadcasting service.

site_title: Search for missing AirAsia black box recorders could 'take a week'
summary: Indonesia's AirAsia search for the missing black box recorders of Flight QZ8501, which crashed on January 1, 2015, killing 162 people, may take a week due to poor weather and heavy seas. Divers were unable to resume full-scale operations on Thursday, and investigators believe the plane went into a stall while climbing to avoid a storm. At least seven bodies have been recovered, and relatives are being identified through DNA analysis. The cause of the crash remains unclear, with theories including an aerodynamic stall and a possible technical issue.

site_title: Surprise absence of late push; STI up 6.3% for 2014
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended 2014 with a 6.3% gain, despite a lack of retail interest and a shortened trading session. The index rose 198 points to 3,365.15, with semiconductor firm STATS ChipPAC being a notable mover. A consortium led by China's Jiangsu Changjiang Electronics Technology announced a pre-conditional voluntary general offer for STATS ChipPAC. Analysts at OCBC Investment Research and Phillip Futures predict a challenging year ahead for the STI, citing economic slowdowns in China and Japan, and a potential decline in oil prices.

site_title: Bond market did unexpectedly well for 2014
summary: The global bond market had a strong year in 2014, with an average total return of 7.6% due to cautious investing and low interest rates. Government securities, particularly US Treasuries and German bunds, led the gains. Despite a weak global economy and inflation, investors flocked to safest assets, and the average yield on bonds fell to a record low of 1.5% in October. The US central bank remained patient on raising interest rates, while the ECB flooded its financial system with cash to revive economic growth.

site_title: Morgan Stanley close to resolving bond probe
summary: Morgan Stanley is in talks to resolve an investigation into the bank's creation and sale of mortgage-backed bonds, a key issue tied to the 2008 financial crisis. An agreement could be reached within the first few months of 2015, with a possible settlement amount unclear. The investigation focuses on the bank's actions in the mortgage market, which contributed to the financial crisis. A resolution would bring closure to the probe, which is part of a larger wave of Wall Street cases stemming from the crisis. Details of the settlement remain unknown.

site_title: Relief and hesitation mark Lithuania's entry into eurozone
summary: Lithuania officially joins the eurozone on Thursday, adopting the currency after years of economic turmoil and a significant impact from Russia's economic sanctions. The move aims to grease commerce, eliminate money-changing costs, and develop new markets. Analysts argue that the euro will provide geopolitical security, but many Lithuanians remain skeptical, citing concerns about higher prices and stability. The country's current currency, the litas, has been pegged to the euro for over a decade, and joining the eurozone will eliminate administrative burdens and costs. The transition is expected to cost 600 million euros through 2020.

site_title: Climate change for Statoil, pride of Norway
summary: Statoil, Norway's state-controlled oil company, faces increasing pressure from the public and parliament. The company reported its first quarterly loss since 2001 due to collapsing oil prices and postponed a Canadian tar sands project for at least three years. Statoil also cut 1,000 jobs and announced disappointing results from its drilling program. The company's struggles highlight the challenges of the oil industry under climate change pressures.

site_title: Kim says open to 'highest-level' talks with South
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un said he is open to "highest-level" talks with South Korea, calling for a "big change" in strained relations between the two countries. This comes after a traditional New Year message broadcast live on state television, where Kim emphasized the need for improvement in cross-border ties. The offer is seen as a significant development in efforts to ease tensions between the two Koreas, which remain technically at war.

site_title: Body with life jacket on raises questions
summary: Rescuers believe they have found the wreckage of the crashed AirAsia plane on the ocean floor near where debris and bodies were recovered. A body recovered with a life jacket raises questions about the disaster's unfolding, as the aircraft was intact when it hit the water, supporting a theory of an aerodynamic stall. The pilots did not issue a distress signal, despite having time to prepare, and no survivors have been found. The search operation, involving 30 ships and 21 aircraft, continues with efforts to locate the black box flight data and cockpit voice recorder.

site_title: Web retailers reap rewards of pre-holiday planning
summary: US web retailers experienced record-breaking sales this holiday season, driven by early promotions and improved delivery systems. Online shopping is expected to rise 16% to $61 billion, boosted by lower unemployment rates, higher consumer confidence, and lower oil prices. This surge in sales benefits retailers, offsetting the impact of tariffs and shipping snags in previous years.

site_title: Jones the Grocer in S'pore unfazed by Aussie woes
summary: Jones the Grocer, a food chain majority-owned by L Capital Asia, has not been affected by its Australian operations' restructuring. Despite its Australian business going bust, the Singapore operations are expected to remain fine, according to L Capital Asia chairman Ravi Thakran. The Australian operations' issues with internal management and debt may be less than tens of millions, with L Capital Asia seeking to take control and restructure the business.

site_title: Aftertaste of larceny at fabled French Laundry
summary: A break-in at The French Laundry in Napa Valley drained the restaurant of a small fortune in fine wines, with losses estimated at over $300,000. The theft included 40-50 bottles of Domaine de la Romanee-Conti and cult American wines. The restaurant's chef reported the incident on Twitter, while The Los Angeles Times estimated the total loss at $300,000.

site_title: Minimum wage in half of all US states to go up in the new year
summary: The minimum wage in 20 US states will increase in 2015, with 9 states raising pay due to inflation indexing. The increases range from $0.15 to $0.90 per hour. The changes were approved at the state level, while a federal nationwide rise remains pending in Congress.

site_title: Oil ends on a low after halving in 2014 as Opec stands aside
summary: Oil prices fell to a 5-1/2-year low, ending with their second-biggest annual decline, as a global glut and expanding US shale output pressured prices. Despite a weekly US data showing crude oil stockpiles fell more than expected, inventories at the Cushing oil hub grew, keeping prices depressed. Opec maintained output levels, contributing to the decline, which was also influenced by diminishing demand growth from China.

site_title: Keppel wins another FLNG vessel conversion deal
summary: Keppel Corporation's Keppel Shipyard secured a US$705 million contract to convert a Moss LNG carrier into a floating liquefaction (FLNG) vessel for Golar LNG. This marks the yard's second FLNG vessel conversion deal with Golar. Engineering firm Black & Veatch will provide design and procurement support services for the topsides and leverage its technology for the liquefaction process. The project is valued at approximately US$705 million.

site_title: Update: Poor weather, rising seas frustrate efforts to reach suspected AirAsia plane wreck
summary: Search teams for the sunken AirAsia jet struggled to resume full-scale operations after a brief window of fine weather closed, with rising seas hindering efforts. The suspected fuselage of the Airbus A320-200, carrying 162 people, was detected 30-50 meters deep. Divers were on standby, but no "pings" from the black boxes had been detected. The search will continue in the sea, while air searches are limited due to deteriorating weather conditions.

site_title: US drone rules remain in the hangar in 2014
summary: The US missed a year-end deadline to publish new drone rules, delaying commercial drone flights. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) submitted a draft to the White House in October 2014, but the Office of Management and Budget has yet to release it. The rules, expected to take at least a year to implement, address issues such as licensing, flight safety, and state regulation. Analysts estimate the rules will be subject to public comment and may include a "pre-emption clause" to assert FAA control over state and local drone laws.

site_title: China slowdown deepens with dip in factory activity in Dec
summary: China's factory sector activity shrank for the first time in seven months in December, according to a private survey, deepening the country's economic slowdown. This move fuels debate on whether Beijing should roll out more support measures or fast-track market reforms to stimulate demand. The weak performance adds to pressure on policymakers to address the economic slowdown, which is expected to slow China's GDP growth.

site_title: South Korea Dec exports at 3-month high, beat expectations
summary: South Korea's exports rose 3.7% to a three-month high in December, beating expectations, with shipments reaching $49.74 billion. This marks the fastest growth since September. Despite this, analysts warn that sluggish demand in Europe and China could lead to erratic exports in the new year. The country's trade surplus increased to $5.78 billion, with electronics goods accounting for over one-fifth of total exports.

images.alt_text: South Korean exports rose to a three-month high in December and far outperformed market expectations, data showed on Thursday, good news for policymakers struggling to find a spark for the sluggish economic recovery.

site_title: UK retailers upbeat about prospects for 2015: industry survey
summary: British retailers are optimistic about 2015 prospects, with 76% expecting sales to improve, 78% planning to hire more staff, and 67% increasing investment levels. Weak consumer demand and high business rates tax remain major concerns. The retail industry aims to drive growth through investments and job creation, but solutions to business rates are needed. This follows a weaker-than-expected economic recovery in 2014 and easing consumer confidence.

site_title: Dispute on carmakers' forced quotas escalates
summary: Foreign carmakers in China are facing a dispute with dealers who claim they were forced to buy excessive stock during a market boom, leading to significant losses. Dealers have complained to the government, and the China Automobile Dealers Association has filed a report against the practice. This move could shift the balance of power between carmakers and dealers, with industry analysts predicting a slowdown in carmakers' expansion plans in China. Carmakers such as Honda, Toyota, and BMW have cut their sales forecasts, citing a normalization of the market.

site_title: Soilbuild Construction bags S$128m HDB contract
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group has secured an S$128 million contract from the Housing Development Board (HDB) to build six 16- to 17-storey residential blocks in Sembawang. The 36-month construction period will not significantly impact the company's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the current financial year. This award brings Soilbuild's total 2014 contracts to eight, with an order book value of S$717.2 million.

site_title: Oil price crash claims first US LNG project casualty
summary: The US liquefied natural gas (LNG) export project by Excelerate Energy, Lavaca Bay in Texas, has been put on hold due to an oil price slump. The project, initially due to begin exports in 2018, was forced to suspend all activities due to uncertainty generated by the steep decrease in oil prices. The move bodes ill for 13 other US LNG projects struggling to sign up international buyers, with only two projects, Sabine Pass and Cameron LNG, having reached a final investment decision.

site_title: E-mail, Internet remain top US workplace tools: study
summary: A Pew Research Center study found that 61% of Americans consider e-mail and the Internet as "very important" tools for productivity at work, with 78% of office workers citing e-mail as a key tool. Despite the rise of social media, e-mail remains the most important tool for workplace communication, with only 4% of respondents saying social networks are important for work. The study also found that 46% of employees believe digital tools make them more productive, and 39% have more flexibility at work due to digital tools.

site_title: Getting one step closer to the chore-free home
summary: In 2014, several robots were introduced in the US, bringing consumers closer to a chore-free home. Notable robots include the Neato Botvac vacuum, Grillbot grill cleaner, Soloshot2 camera system, Litter-Robot cat litter changer, and Robomow RS lawn mower. Other robots debuted in 2014, such as the rockaRoo baby tracker, Scooba 450 floor scrubber, and Droplet automated watering system. These robots aim to simplify household tasks, but some have limitations, such as the Litter-Robot's size and cost. Despite these limitations, the introduction of these robots marks progress towards a future with reduced domestic chores.

site_title: Hong Kong fireworks dazzle as Asia leads global New Year party
summary: Millions around the world celebrated the start of 2015 with fireworks displays, concerts, and light shows. Hong Kong's eight-minute pyrotechnic display lit up Victoria Harbour, while Sydney Harbour in Australia was also treated to a massive fireworks display. Other notable celebrations took place in China, Taiwan, Japan, India, and various European cities, including Berlin, Paris, and London. Meanwhile, some countries, such as Malaysia and Indonesia, held somber New Year's Eve events due to recent tragedies, including the crash of AirAsia Flight QZ8501 and flooding in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: A huge display of fireworks lit up Hong Kong on Thursday, with brilliant bursts of colour over Victoria Harbour as the Chinese city rang in 2015 in spectacular style, launching the party for millions across Asia.

site_title: US, China to intensify talks on investment agreement
summary: The US and China plan to intensify talks on a bilateral investment treaty (BIT) to limit foreign investment in sectors such as telecommunications and soya bean crushing. The treaty, which is due to be finalized by early 2015, aims to increase investment flows between the two countries. China has announced plans for economic reforms to reduce government involvement and restrictions on foreign investment. The US is urging China to eliminate its separate investment laws and apply one law to both domestic and foreign investors, while China has submitted a revised offer to join a global agreement on government contracts.

site_title: Asian stock markets closed
summary: Asian stock markets closed on December 31, 2014, for a public holiday. No relevant information was found in the provided article content.

site_title: Dodging the next big environmental crisis
summary: The rapid advancement of technology poses an environmental crisis. Despite innovations in electric cars, self-driving cars, and biotechnology, the world continues to rely on fossil fuels, plastic waste, and water-intensive farming methods. The construction of coal-fired power plants and fracking operations exacerbate the problem. The author questions how humanity can survive on a planet plagued by environmental degradation and unsustainable practices, especially with the possibility of interplanetary travel and colonization on the horizon.

images.alt_text: It is hard to keep in perspective how fast we are moving, but almost every facet of our lives is changing at warp speed. And not necessarily for the benefit of us all.

site_title: Singapore stocks made more affordable for individuals
summary: Singapore's stock market is making its offerings more accessible to individual investors. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will reduce the standard lot size for equity transactions to 100 shares from 1,000 shares on January 19. This change aims to boost trading volume, which has fallen 37% since the 2008 global financial crisis. The move is expected to make Singapore stocks more affordable for investors, particularly young people opening trading accounts. The bourse seeks to revitalize the market, which has been struggling with low trading volume.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is looking to individual investors to boost South-east Asia's biggest stock market after trading volume this year tumbled the most since the 2008 global financial crisis.

site_title: India to end tax breaks for car-makers
summary: India will not extend tax breaks to carmakers beyond December 31, 2014, due to weak tax receipts in a sluggish economy. The government aims to meet its 4.1% fiscal deficit target. Car sales are expected to miss growth targets, with some manufacturers, like Maruti Suzuki, anticipating temporary price hikes. The government will also end tax breaks on consumer durables. This decision aims to shore up India's finances before the end of the financial year.

site_title: China: Shares end 2014 near five-year high
summary: Chinese shares closed at a near five-year high on the last trading day of 2014, with the Shanghai Composite Index jumping 2.18% to 3,234.68 points. This marks the highest close since January 2010 and a 52.87% surge for the year. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, gaining 1.19% to 1,415.19 points and 33.80% for the year, driven by hopes of monetary easing following weak manufacturing data.

site_title: Ying Li joins China Everbright in Beijing project
summary: Ying Li International Real Estate Limited has agreed to jointly invest in a mixed-use development project in Beijing's Tongzhou District with China Everbright Limited. The project, valued at 7.2 billion yuan, will feature high-rise residential units, office buildings, and retail malls. This marks Ying Li's first project outside of Chongqing and its expansion into first-tier cities in China. The partnership will see Ying Li invest 559 million yuan, with China Everbright contributing the remaining funds.

site_title: China's Huawei 2014 smartphone revenue to rise 30% year-on-year: memo
summary: Huawei's smartphone division reported a 30% year-on-year increase in revenue to $11.8 billion in 2014, with 75 million smartphones shipped, 40% more than the previous year. However, this fell short of the target of 80 million units.

site_title: At least 35 dead, 42 injured in Shanghai New Year's stampede
summary: At least 35 people were killed and 42 injured in a stampede during a New Year's celebration in Shanghai's Bund area, according to Chinese media. The incident occurred in Chen Yi Square, with many of the injured being students, and authorities were working to rescue and aid the wounded. The cause of the stampede was not immediately clear, but it came after authorities cancelled a 3D laser show on the Bund that drew large crowds last year.

site_title: Text of PM Lee's New Year message
summary: PM Lee delivered a New Year message highlighting Singapore's moderately strong economy in 2014, with 2.8% growth and a 10% increase in median incomes over the past five years. Despite weak productivity growth, the government aims to upgrade and become more productive through initiatives such as SkillsFuture and MediShield Life. The government also focuses on creating opportunities for Singaporeans, improving social well-being, and building a better home through infrastructure and Smart Nation initiatives. PM Lee emphasized the importance of stability, safety, and security for a prosperous future, and urged Singaporeans to unite and work together to achieve their aspirations.

site_title: Business lending hits single-digit growth in Nov
summary: Singapore's business lending showed a 0.6% increase in November, its first growth in two months, but still at a single-digit rate compared to a year ago. Consumer loans also rose 0.6% in November, with growth in housing loans easing. The Monetary Authority of Singapore forecasts bank loans to stabilize at a single-digit year-on-year growth basis for the next few months. Overall, business loans grew 9.2% in November, while consumer loans reached a seven-year low.

images.alt_text: KEY SECTOR: Construction loans - the largest of all business loans - were up 1.6 per cent at S$103 billion in November, although the gain was still weaker compared to 2.5 per cent seen in October.

site_title: Argentina's debt crisis seen rumbling on until 2015 election
summary: Argentina is unlikely to resolve its debt crisis until 2015, when its next president takes office, rather than January as hoped. The country is locked in a standoff with US hedge funds over $1.3 billion in unpaid debt, with Argentina insisting on reduced payments. The economic stagnation has deterred investment, with trade and currency controls exacerbating the issue. The US court order demands full repayment of the debt, including interest, but a resolution is not expected until after the 2015 presidential election.

site_title: Ebola spreads in Sierra Leone as global cases top 20,000: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) reports that Ebola has spread to over 20,000 known cases globally, with 7,905 deaths, mostly in West Africa. Sierra Leone accounts for 337 of the 476 new cases since December 24, while neighboring Guinea saw a rise in cases for the second week. A nurse in Britain has been diagnosed with Ebola after returning from Sierra Leone, and the epidemic is expected to last until the end of 2015.

site_title: There is no cure for a hangover
summary: There is no cure for hangovers, despite various products and remedies available. According to George Koob, director of the National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, excessive drinking causes hangovers, not a hangover itself. Products such as tablets, drinks, and intravenous infusions can relieve symptoms, but there is no medication that can cure a hangover. Researchers have found some beverages, like lemon-lime soda, to be effective in reducing hangover duration, but a cure remains elusive.

site_title: Goldman tops UK banker pay with £3m awarded for 2013
summary: Goldman Sachs paid its top 121 London bankers an average of £3 million (S$6.2 million) in 2013, significantly higher than other leading banks. The US investment bank awarded staff US$193.6 million in 2013 and 2.1 million restricted stock units (RSUs) worth US$377 million. This payout surpasses those of other major banks, highlighting Goldman's commitment to rewarding high-performing staff.

site_title: Greek ferry tragedy turns into murder mystery
summary: A Greek ferry, the Norman Atlantic, caught fire in the Adriatic, killing 10 people and leaving 12 unaccounted for. The ship's owner, captain, and crew may face a manslaughter probe after discrepancies were found in the passenger list, with some stowaways believed to be among those rescued. The fire's rapid spread and lack of preparedness by the crew have raised questions about safety systems on board, with a Dec 19 safety inspection highlighting several deficiencies that were not adequately addressed.

images.alt_text: UNEXPLAINED BLAZE: It is not known why the fire on the ferry gained such force so quickly and why it was not contained in the area where it started.

site_title: AirAsia relatives 'surrender' to fate of loved ones
summary: Dozens of grieving relatives of victims of AirAsia Flight QZ8501 gathered for a mass at a crisis center in Surabaya, Indonesia, to come to terms with the loss of their loved ones. The relatives, many of whom had lost family members, sang hymns and prayed, with some breaking down in tears. They appeared resigned to the fact that their loved ones were dead, with some preparing funerals and others awaiting news about efforts to retrieve more bodies. Police and medical teams were also preparing for the grim task of handling and identifying the bodies, with DNA samples and medical records being collected.

site_title: Fed forecasting tool calls for immediate rate hike, Plosser says
summary: The Federal Reserve's forecasting tool recommends an immediate interest rate hike to 0.5% by the fourth quarter of 2014, and to 1.1% by the second quarter of 2015, citing an improving US economy. This contradicts the Fed's core officials, who predict a mid-2015 hike and a 1% federal funds rate by year-end. Philadelphia Fed President Charles Plosser co-authored the research, which also suggests a more aggressive tightening cycle than predicted.

site_title: Consumer confidence up in Dec on job gains
summary: US consumer confidence rose in December, increasing to 92.6 from 91 in November, the highest level in almost seven years, according to the Conference Board. The improvement was driven by job gains and declining petrol prices. This increase in consumer confidence is a positive sign for the US economy, suggesting a stronger outlook for the coming months.

site_title: Improved weather raises hopes that divers can reach suspected AirAsia plane wreck
summary: A break in bad weather on Thursday raised hopes that divers can investigate the suspected sunken wreck of an AirAsia plane off Borneo, where 162 people are believed to have died. The Airbus A320-200 crashed on Sunday while trying to climb above stormy weather, and its black box flight data and cockpit voice recorder are crucial to solving the mystery. Rough seas had prevented divers from investigating the wreck, but improved weather conditions are expected to allow for a stepped-up search effort.

images.alt_text: A break in bad weather on Thursday raised hopes that divers would be able to investigate what is believed to be the sunken wreck of an AirAsia jet off Borneo and retrieve the plane's black box that should explain the cause of the crash.

site_title: Indonesia to scrap gasoline subsidy from Jan 1 and float prices
summary: Indonesia will scrap gasoline subsidies starting January 1, linking retail prices to international oil markets. The country will stop subsidizing gasoline prices, but diesel will remain subsidized with a capped liability of $1.4 billion. This move aims to reduce the country's reliance on oil price fluctuations and free up funds for other priorities, with analysts predicting a reduction in the subsidy burden from 13% to 1% of total expenditure.

site_title: New Delhi sets new rules for Uber, other taxi operators
summary: New Delhi has introduced rules for Uber and other taxi operators, requiring them to install panic buttons, use clean fuels, and track vehicles. The move follows an incident where a driver for Uber allegedly raped a passenger, reigniting concerns over women's safety in India. The Delhi government has also ordered the impounding of 93 taxis, including those of Uber, for abusing exemptions to use national-permit cars. Uber has expressed disagreement with the guidelines, stating that regulations do not apply to its "disruptive technology company" model.

site_title: Japan to trim new bond issuances to below 38t yen
summary: Japan plans to issue less than 38 trillion yen ($420 billion) in new bonds in the next fiscal year, cutting fresh issuances by more than three trillion yen. This is due to rises in tax revenues following a sales tax hike. The move aims to reduce the country's reliance on borrowing, as its debt level is more than double the size of the economy. The government's total spending is expected to top 96 trillion yen for the first year, with spending on social security and defense expected to increase.

site_title: Ascendas to invest US$95m in Indian property developer
summary: Singapore's Ascendas India Trust is investing US$95 million in Indian property developer Paranjape Schemes over two years. The investment will be made through debentures and a stake in a commercial project in Pune. This move follows a revival in India's commercial real estate space, encouraged by the Narendra Modi-led government's efforts to list Real Estate Investment Trusts. Foreign investors, including Blackstone Group and Goldman Sachs, have invested US$1.5 billion in India's real estate sector, with about a third in commercial properties.

site_title: Samsung unveils new TV platform to cut Google reliance
summary: Samsung Electronics has announced the release of new smart TVs with its Tizen operating system, aiming to reduce its reliance on Google. The new platform will power all of Samsung's web-connected TV sets, with the first Tizen smart TVs set to debut at the Las Vegas consumer electronics fair. This move is seen as a strategic step towards creating a more intelligent and integrated system, according to Samsung executive vice president Lee Won-Jin.

site_title: Indonesia says one body from AirAsia plane was wearing life jacket
summary: Indonesia's search and rescue agency recovered four bodies from the crashed AirAsia plane on December 31, 2014. One of the bodies was found wearing a life jacket.

site_title: US home prices rising at slower rate
summary: US home prices rose 4.5% in the year ended in October, the smallest gain in two years, according to the S&P/Case-Shiller index. This slower pace puts the market on better footing for 2015. Nationally, prices rose 4.6%, with some cities starting to show reacceleration, setting the stage for faster price growth in 2015. Economists' median projection calls for a 4.4% advance.

site_title: Bank outperformance and Fed-speak ruled in 2014
summary: In 2014, the Straits Times Index gained 6.25% due to strong outperformance by Singapore's three major banks and the US Federal Reserve's "Fed-speak," which reassured markets of a "considerable time" before interest rate hikes. This led to Wall Street indices setting all-time highs, and global stocks remained buoyant despite overseas turmoil and liquidity concerns. Central banks also pledged quantitative easing to revive their economies. The year's low-volatility environment was marked by retail investors' reduced presence in the market, following the 2013 penny stock crash.

site_title: Indonesia to cap, scrap fuel subsidies
summary: Indonesia will cap the diesel subsidy at 1,000 rupiah ($0.11) per liter and scrap the petrol subsidy, effective January 1, as part of President Joko Widodo's efforts to reform the country's decades-old energy subsidy system. The changes aim to free up budget funds for development spending and reduce energy imports. The new system will be based on international prices, with diesel and petrol prices set at 7,250 and 7,600 rupiah per liter, respectively. The move is seen as a significant step towards a market-based price mechanism, with economists praising the government's decision.

site_title: China eases rules for overseas listed firms to send FX home
summary: China has eased rules for overseas listed firms to send foreign exchange back home, allowing them to remit funds without approval. The move is seen as a step toward relaxing capital flows, as previously companies had to submit formal applications and win regulatory approval. The change, effective immediately, requires only registration with foreign exchange authorities. The move aims to increase foreign investment in China and reduce restrictions on yuan conversion.

site_title: China details fiscal reform plans to improve budget management
summary: China has published plans to reform its fiscal reporting system, shifting from a cash management system to an accrual accounting model. The goal is to improve budget management and reallocate spending obligations from local governments to the central government. The reforms aim to increase transparency and accuracy in budgeting processes. China plans to establish a commission to set standards and implement the new system by 2020, with trial compilations starting in 2016 and 2020. The reforms are part of efforts to address massive local government debts and ensure sustainable fiscal policies.

site_title: Farewell to 'golden era' of China's property sector
summary: China's property sector is experiencing a slowdown, marking the end of the "golden era" of rapid growth. Housing prices have fallen in 67 out of 70 cities, with property investment also cooling. The sector's impact on China's economy is expected to slow GDP growth by 1% in 2014 and 0.3% in 2015. Young people like Lyu Haoran, who face unaffordable prices, are shifting their priorities away from home ownership. The Chinese government has introduced measures to stimulate the sector, but oversupply and cooling demand are hindering efforts.

site_title: RBI rate cuts will extend gains in India bonds in 2015: poll
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is set to cut its repurchase rate by 75 basis points to 7.25% in 2015, the biggest annual reduction since 2009, according to a Bloomberg survey. This is expected to extend gains in India's bonds, with yields on 10-year sovereign notes predicted to drop 48 basis points to 7.4% by December 2015, a level last seen in June 2013. Global funds have already bought a record $26.4 billion of rupee debt in 2014, driven by optimism over Prime Minister Narendra Modi's economic reforms.

site_title: Singapore's economy grew 2.8% in 2014
summary: Singapore's economy grew 2.8% in 2014, but productivity remained weak for the third consecutive year, with a 0.5% decline in the first three quarters. Despite this, real median incomes rose 10% over the last five years. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized that economic growth remains crucial for creating jobs and investing in the nation's future, but acknowledged that growth will slow down.

site_title: Wall Street ponders next year after big gains in 2014
summary: US equity markets closed near all-time highs in 2014, with the S&P 500 gaining 11.39% to 2,058.90, the Dow Jones rising 7.52% to 17,823.07, and the Nasdaq Composite climbing 13.40% to 4,736.05. Analysts attribute the gains to improving economic data and investor-friendly monetary policy, despite concerns over weak growth in Europe and emerging economies. Many predict the market will continue to rise, albeit at a modest pace, with some analysts warning of potential volatility and a correction due to the impact of sharply lower oil prices and a higher dollar.

site_title: US easing of light crude export ban to put pressure on Asian producers
summary: The US has formally approved easing a 40-year-old ban on exporting most domestic crude oil, which will increase ultra-light shale oil supplies into global markets. The move is expected to put pressure on Asian producers, particularly in Malaysia, where declining revenues from falling energy prices and weakening currencies could exacerbate debt issues. US exports are likely to go to Europe due to high freight costs, but will still impact Asian markets, triggering price competition and potential project cancellations. Oil prices are expected to fall further in 2015, with some forecasts reaching as low as $40 a barrel.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end lower
summary: Singapore shares ended lower on December 31, 2014, with the Straits Times Index slipping 0.96 points to 3,365.15. Trading volume was 587.7 million shares valued at S$514 million.

site_title: Bad weather hampers recovery of bodies from AirAsia flight
summary: Indonesian authorities are struggling to recover bodies from the crash site of AirAsia Flight QZ8501 due to bad weather. Rough conditions have hindered helicopter operations, and officials have taken DNA from 30 family members to aid in identification. So far, seven bodies have been recovered, and debris found includes an exit door and a blue suitcase. The search is focusing on the seabed where a "shadow" believed to be the missing plane was spotted. The cause of the crash is still unknown, with the pilot's last communication showing he wanted to change course to avoid a storm system.

site_title: After 2014's party, investors in US stock market may face a hangover
summary: US stock market investors may face a hangover in 2015 after a nearly 50% gain in 2014, driven by improved economic growth and the Federal Reserve's accommodative policies. However, the S&P 500's forward price-to-earnings multiple is at 17, exceeding the 15-year average, and earnings growth estimates for 2015 are in the mid-single digits. The Fed's potential interest rate hike and a strong dollar may offset the effects of lower oil prices on corporate profits.

site_title: Sydney spectacular to set off global New Year celebrations
summary: Sydney is set to lead global New Year's celebrations with a spectacular fireworks display over Sydney Harbour, defying terrorist fears after a deadly siege in the city just before Christmas. Millions worldwide will watch as the clock ticks past midnight, with major events planned in Hong Kong, London, New York, and Rio. The Sydney Harbour fireworks display will be attended by 1.6 million people, with tributes planned for the two hostages who died during the siege. Despite heightened security concerns, the city's Lord Mayor says the event will be safe.

site_title: AirAsia victim with life jacket raises questions about plane's last moments
summary: A body recovered from the crashed AirAsia plane was wearing a life jacket, raising questions about the plane's last moments. Rescuers believe they have found the plane on the ocean floor, and seven bodies have been recovered, some fully clothed, suggesting the aircraft was intact when it hit the water. The fact that one person put on a life jacket before the aircraft sank implies that those on board had time to react before the plane hit the water, contradicting the lack of a distress signal. The search and rescue operation continues, with authorities focusing on retrieving bodies and investigating the cause of the crash.

site_title: Keppel in second FLNG deal worth US$705 million with Norway's Golar LNG
summary: Keppel Corporation's subsidiary, Keppel Shipyard, has secured a US$705 million contract with Norway's Golar LNG to convert an LNG carrier into a floating liquefaction (FLNG) vessel. This is Keppel's second FLNG deal, with the first contract also awarded in July. The project is expected to start construction in November 2015 and take 33 months to complete. FLNG technology is gaining traction among oil companies, allowing for timely and cost-efficient natural gas supplies to market. The contract marks the exercise of an option awarded to Keppel in July.

site_title: Greenspan sounds note of caution on US economy
summary: Former Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan expressed caution on the US economy, stating it's "doing better than anybody else, but we're still not doing all that well." Greenspan believes the economy won't fully recover until American companies invest more in productive assets and the housing market bounces back. He forecasts growth to dip below a 3% annual rate in the fourth quarter of 2014. This prediction aligns with a Bloomberg survey of economists.

site_title: Vietnam's economy expands 5.98% in 2014
summary: Vietnam's economy expanded 5.98% in 2014, the highest growth rate in three years, despite challenges such as a banking crisis and anti-China riots. The country's inflation slowed to 4.09% from 6.04% in 2013. The government is targeting 6.2% economic growth in 2015. The growth is seen as a positive sign, but Vietnam still struggles with bad debts, weak competitiveness, and inefficient production. The central bank devalued the dong to boost exports after the riots.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's economy grew 5.98 per cent in 2014, the highest for three years, despite a festering banking crisis and damaging anti-China riots, authorities said Wednesday.

site_title: China's 2 trainmakers surge on merger plan
summary: China's two largest trainmakers, CSR Corp and China CNR Corp, plan to combine through a share swap, boosting exports of high-speed rail technology. CSR Corp will issue 1.1 new shares for each CNR share held, with CNR rising 43% and CSR soaring 34%. The move aims to compete with Siemens AG and Alstom SA in constrained markets, targeting emerging markets and high-profile projects. The proposal has been approved by CNR's board, with a conversion price of 6.19 yuan per share or HK$8.05 for CNR's Hong Kong-listed shares.

site_title: UK wage rises slow with job market slack
summary: UK wage growth is expected to be "very modest" in 2015, with nominal earnings growth ranging from 1% to 2% next year. This is due to a sufficient job market supply and slowing inflation, which limits the pressure to raise interest rates. The Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development states that labour-market pressures are insufficient to push wage increases above their current range, and falling inflation may remove any temptation for employers to offer higher pay increases.

site_title: Oil prices down in thin pre-holiday trade
summary: Oil prices fell 63 cents to $53.49 for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate and 91 cents to $56.99 for Brent crude in thin pre-holiday trade on December 31. Analysts predict a rebound in prices in 2015, driven by expected US crude reserve dips and potential stimulus measures in major economies. Oil prices have tumbled 50% since June due to slowing growth in China and emerging markets, as well as Opec's decision to maintain output levels. A rebound in prices is expected if demand improves in countries such as China, Japan, and the eurozone.

site_title: Japan PM Abe pledges reforms to boost economy
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has pledged to carry out crucial structural reforms this year to boost the economy, while stressing Japan's pacifist stance. Abe, who won a landslide election, aims to deliver economic recovery to every corner of the nation through measures such as deregulation in the energy and farm sectors. His reforms, dubbed "Abenomics," are seen as the most drastic since the end of World War II, with a focus on freeing up the labor market and tackling an inefficient agricultural sector.

site_title: China home prices fall faster in December
summary: China's housing prices dropped 0.44% in December, the eighth consecutive month of decline, with the average price of a new home falling to 10,542 yuan (US$1,700) per square meter. On a year-on-year basis, prices fell 2.69%, accelerating from November's 1.57% decline. The top 10 cities saw a 0.61% drop in prices, with only Beijing, Shanghai, and Shenzhen experiencing annual price increases. Experts predict ongoing inventory pressures and downward pressure on house prices in 2015.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.8 points to close at 1,768.63 on December 31, 2014, with 616.55 million lots valued at RM570.16 million traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 315-296.

site_title: Australia bans commercial sunbeds over cancer fears
summary: Australia is set to ban commercial sunbeds from January 1, joining Brazil as the second nation to restrict artificial tanning, citing a direct link between sunbed use and skin cancer. The ban comes after a majority of Australians, including 6,300 people surveyed, supported the move. The country already has one of the highest rates of skin cancer in the world, with the Cancer Council warning that two-thirds of Australians will be diagnosed with skin cancer by age 70.

site_title: Crowded skies in Southeast Asia put pressure on pilots, air traffic control
summary: Southeast Asia's rapidly growing air travel industry is putting pressure on outdated air traffic control systems and pilots, who must take risky unilateral actions to navigate volatile weather conditions. With a high volume of flights and limited air traffic control infrastructure, pilots often face a high-risk challenge of declaring emergencies without permission. The region's airlines are investing heavily in new planes, but infrastructure upgrades are also needed to ensure safe air travel. The Association of Asia Pacific Airlines has highlighted the need for investment in related infrastructure, such as airport terminals and air navigation services.

site_title: HK culls 15,000 chickens on H7N9 fears
summary: Hong Kong has begun culling 15,000 chickens after detecting the H7N9 bird flu virus in a batch imported from China's Huizhou. The virus was found in 120 chickens, prompting authorities to slaughter the birds to prevent the spread of the disease. This move comes after a woman in Hong Kong was hospitalized with the virus. The city's health minister has confirmed that the chickens carry the H7N9 virus, and the culling is expected to continue.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close up 1.3% in 2014
summary: Hong Kong shares closed up 1.3% on December 31, 2014, marking the widest performance gap versus mainland indexes since 2007. The Hang Seng index rose 0.4% to 23,605.04 points, while the China Enterprises Index gained 1.2%. The China Enterprises Index rose 11% for the year, driven by mainland market rallies. Notable gains included Peacemap Holdings, China Resources and Transportation Group, and Bank Of China.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release. Meanwhile, CGSIC downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to expected earnings growth slowdown in H2. OCBC CEO Helen Wong is set to retire, with Tan Teck Long named her successor. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to $3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Tesla marked its formal India entry with a launch event in Mumbai. Citigroup set a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. Analysts are positive on SGX earnings, raising target prices.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: Singapore stocks experience a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the market showing resilience. Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow in H2, prompting CGS-I's downgrade to 'hold'. OCBC's CEO, Helen Wong, will retire, and Tan Teck Long will take over. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rises 30.5% to $3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Tesla marks its formal India entry with a Mumbai launch event, and Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index.

site_title: Second Chance Properties Q1 net profit plunges 55.8%
summary: Second Chance Properties reported a 55.8% plunge in Q1 net profit to S$1.7 million, mainly due to revenue decline from closed apparel retail outlets and expenses from acquiring properties in Malaysia. Revenues also fell 4% to S$8.84 million. The company attributed the decline to the closure of six outlets in Singapore and Malaysia, as well as increased expenses.

site_title: Indonesia vows 'all-out effort' in search for AirAsia victims
summary: Indonesian rescuers are making an "all-out effort" to search for AirAsia Flight QZ8501 victims, with improved weather conditions. Seven bodies have been retrieved from the Airbus A320-200, which crashed Sunday in the sea near Borneo, carrying 162 people. International investigators, including French and Singapore experts, are joining the search to locate the wreckage and retrieve black boxes. Police have taken DNA samples from relatives to aid in identification, with four bodies transferred to land and two more to Surabaya for examination.

site_title: US clearing path for shale oil to be exported
summary: The US government has cleared the way for the export of ultra-light shale oil, a 40-year-old ban on exports of most domestic crude, allowing some companies to sell lightly treated condensate abroad. The Bureau of Industry and Security has granted permission to "some" companies to export ultra-light crude, a move expected to unleash a wave of US shale oil onto global markets. The decision comes after months of growing pressure and follows a year of uncertainty over the ban's implications for the booming US shale oil production.

site_title: Indonesia says finds large dark object presumed to be AirAsia jet
summary: Indonesia's search and rescue agency confirmed a large, dark object under the sea, presumed to be the missing AirAsia plane, following a sonar image. The object is 30-50 meters underwater and crews are ready to collect and identify bodies. The official hopes it's the plane to facilitate a quick evacuation, bringing closure to the families of the missing passengers.

images.alt_text: A sonar image showing a large, dark object under the sea was presumed to be the missing AirAsia plane, an official with Indonesia's search and rescue agency said on Wednesday.

site_title: Swiber shares tumble on news of proposed rights issue
summary: Swiber Holdings' share price dropped 10% on Wednesday after announcing a proposed rights issue to raise S$45.9 million, with the issue price at a 49.2% discount to its last traded share price. The company plans to use the funds for working capital, despite a 54% decline in its share price in 2014 and a net loss of US$22.9 million in the third quarter. Major shareholders have subscribed for an aggregate of up to 152.8 million rights shares, but analysts have downgraded the company to a "sell" rating, citing concerns over the group's debt and earnings growth.

site_title: US expresses concern over detained Cuba dissidents
summary: The US expressed concern over the detention of several Cuban dissidents, with 10 people confirmed arrested or under house arrest. The detentions contradict the US's efforts to normalize relations with Havana, which ended 50 years of hostility. The US State Department condemned the Cuban government's use of arbitrary detention and violence to silence critics, and urged the government to respect internationally recognized human rights and freedoms of expression and peaceful assembly. The move is likely to revive criticism from those who disapprove of the US-Cuba rapprochement.

site_title: Inflation in S Korea falls to its lowest since 1999
summary: South Korea's inflation rate has fallen to its lowest since 1999, with December's consumer price index rising 0.8% from a year earlier. This decrease is attributed to low energy prices and sluggish domestic consumption growth. Economists expect the inflation rate to rise to around 2% by the end of 2015, but some analysts argue that the Bank of Korea has more room to cut interest rates to aid the economic recovery. The central bank's next policy meeting is scheduled for January 15, and Governor Lee Ju-yeol has expressed caution against cutting interest rates solely due to low inflation.

site_title: China firms fined record US$26m for polluting river
summary: Six Chinese companies have been fined a record US$26 million for polluting two rivers with 25,000 tonnes of waste chemicals. The firms, in Taizhou, Jiangsu province, were ordered to pay 160 million yuan (US$26 million) in fines for discharging waste hydrochloric acid into the rivers. The case is the largest environmental public interest litigation in China, and 14 people involved were sentenced to prison terms of two to five years for causing environmental pollution.

site_title: Indonesian sonar shows suspected body of AirAsia plane on sea bed - WSJ
summary: Indonesia's search-and-rescue agency says a sonar image may show the body of the missing AirAsia jet, Flight QZ8501, at the bottom of the Java Sea. The plane vanished on Sunday with 162 people on board during a flight from Surabaya to Singapore. The sonar image, taken 24-30 meters below the surface, appears to show an airplane upside down. The agency has not confirmed the image as the missing plane, but it is being investigated further.

images.alt_text: INDONESIA'S search-and-rescue agency has obtained a sonar image it says may be the body of the missing AirAsia jet at the bottom of the Java Sea, the Wall Street Journal said on Wednesday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FBMKLCI down 6.16 points to 1759.76. Volume was 17.5 million lots valued at RM$7.5 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 50 to 45.

site_title: Bad weather hinders search for victims in AirAsia crash
summary: AirAsia's Airbus A320-200 crashed into the sea on December 28, 2014, en route from Surabaya to Singapore, with over 162 people on board. Bad weather has hindered the search for victims, forcing officials to suspend aerial missions. Heavy rain and low visibility have scattered bodies and debris, with 7 bodies recovered so far, including 2 flown to Surabaya for identification. The search area has been narrowed to 120 square nautical miles, with 22 ships continuing to hunt for the remaining victims and the plane's black box.

site_title: China funds reduce equity allocations as markets rally
summary: China-based fund managers have reduced their suggested equity weightings to 85.9% due to concerns about the surge in mainland stock markets, which have jumped 20% over the past month. The suggested cash allocation increased to 9% and bond weightings remained flat at 5.1%. Economists expect more policy easing to avoid a slowdown, and some fund managers predict the Shanghai Composite Index may gain little additional ground or pull back slightly in the next three months. The main stock indexes have gained nearly 50% for the year, making them the best performers globally.

site_title: Singapore oil & gas sector may rebound later in 2015
summary: Singapore's oil and gas sector is seen as a potential buying opportunity in 2015, despite low oil prices, as analysts expect a rebound when oil prices recover. The sector's value rose 6.5% in 2014, driven by takeover activity, with companies like Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine being targeted. Analysts expect the Straits Times Index (STI) to rise between 3,200 to 3,500 points in 2015, with some predicting a 5% to 10% gain. However, others remain cautious, citing concerns over US interest rate hikes and the impact on the sector.

site_title: China service sector growth picks up in December
summary: China's services sector growth improved in December, with the non-manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 54.1 from 53.9 in November. This helped offset weakness in the manufacturing sector, which showed slower growth as expected. However, analysts expect the fourth-quarter economic growth to slow, potentially undershooting the government's 7.5% target and marking the weakest expansion in 24 years.

images.alt_text: Growth in China's services sector picked up slightly in December, a government study showed on Thursday, helping to offset further weakness in manufacturing which is weighing on the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Schroder, Lloyd's Asia, Twitter sign up at CapitaGreen (Amended)
summary: Lloyd's Asia, Schroder, and Twitter have signed leases for office spaces at CapitaGreen, with Lloyd's Asia occupying about 75,000 sq ft and Schroder taking about 44,000 sq ft. Ace Insurance is reportedly signing up for 38,000 sq ft, while Twitter has secured 22,000 sq ft. The leasing activity contributes to the bulk of leasing activity in Q4 2014, with gross effective monthly rentals expected to increase to S$12-14 psf per month.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Public scorn greets LG and Samsung's storm in a washing drum
summary: South Korea's top technology firms, Samsung and LG, are facing public scorn over a dispute involving damaged washing machines. The dispute began in September when Samsung accused LG of damaging its machines in Germany, leading to a mediation and LG's agreement to pay for the damage. However, LG responded with accusations of Samsung's poor build quality, prompting a raid on LG offices and a travel ban on its head of household appliances. Experts say the dispute is a petty and juvenile act, with both companies unlikely to gain from the public backlash.

site_title: Tokyo, Seoul: Markets closed
summary: Financial markets in Tokyo, Seoul, and several Southeast Asian countries will be closed on Wednesday for public holidays. No significant market events or announcements are reported in the provided articles, suggesting no major market fluctuations or news on December 30, 2014.

site_title: Economy grew 2.8% in 2014: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's economy grew 2.8% in 2014, despite a 0.5% decline in productivity in the first nine months. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for "productivity-driven growth" to sustain rising incomes. Real median incomes rose 10% over the past five years, and the government aims to create more opportunities through investments in education and social welfare programs. Lee highlighted the importance of sustainable growth, stating it's crucial for creating good jobs and improving social well-being.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.35 points to 3,365.76. Volume was 47.3 million shares valued at S$89.7 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 46 to 38. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with stocks to watch including Singtel, Sinarmas Land, and PSC.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open marginally lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened marginally lower on the last day of trade for the year, extending the previous day's losses, amid fears over Greece's political crisis. The Hang Seng Index dropped 20.29 points to 23,480.81. This follows sell-offs in New York and Europe.

site_title: Hong Kong culls chickens, suspends imports after H7 bird flu found
summary: Hong Kong authorities have begun culling 15,000 chickens and suspended live poultry imports from mainland China for 21 days after discovering the H7 bird flu strain in a batch of imported chickens from Guangdong province. The wholesale poultry market has also been closed for cleaning and disinfection. This move comes after a woman fell critically ill with the H7N9 strain of bird flu, prompting concerns about the spread of the virus. Hong Kong authorities will also inspect and collect samples from live chicken farms to ensure they are not affected.

site_title: China-made regional jet gets CAAC certification
summary: China's first domestically produced regional jet, the ARJ21-700, has been certified by the Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) after a series of examinations using the country's airworthiness standards. The certification marks a significant milestone in China's plane manufacturing sector and demonstrates the country's independently developed and manufactured planes have met safe flying conditions. The ARJ21 has undergone over 5,000 hours of test flights and has 78-90 seats in various configurations, with an economic life of 60,000 flying hours or 20 calendar years.

images.alt_text: SET TO ENTER MARKET: The ARJ21, which has 78 seats in a dual-class configuration and 90 seats in a full economy class configuration, currently has 278 orders.

site_title: Jones the Grocer's Singapore stores not hit by restructuring of Australian ops: executive
summary: Jones the Grocer's Singapore operations remain unaffected by the restructuring of its Australian operations, according to L Capital Asia executive Ravi Thakran. The Singapore business will "be fine" with a good prognosis, despite the Australian company's collapse due to internal management issues and potentially less debt than tens of millions. The Australian operations, which include four stores in Melbourne and Sydney, have been handed over to PKF Lawler for insolvency cases.

site_title: Beijing's contemporary art scene gaining in popularity
summary: Beijing's contemporary art scene is gaining popularity, with recent events held at the Opposite House Hotel showcasing local and international artists. The events, organized by Surge Art, have seen reasonable turnout despite comparisons to a larger party held the previous Friday night. This growing interest in contemporary art suggests a shift in Beijing's cultural landscape, with the city emerging as a hub for artistic expression and innovation.

site_title: Six out of 10 owners in Singapore still live in their first HDB flat: Khaw Boon Wan
summary: Minister for National Development Khaw Boon Wan revealed that 61% of HDB flat owners in Singapore still reside in their first flat, a remarkably high percentage. This is attributed to the success of the "Home Ownership for the People Scheme" which has enabled Singaporeans to build deep community ties and lasting memories. The highest percentages are found in estates like Tanjong Pagar (77%), Marine Parade (74%), and Bukit Timah/Geylang (67%). The scheme has contributed to Singapore's reputation for public housing, with over 80% of residents living in HDB flats.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: KAL chief's daughter apologises for 'revenge' message
summary: The second daughter of Korean Air's CEO, Cho Hyun-Min, apologized for a "revenge" message sent to her sister, Cho Hyun-Ah, who was arrested for delaying a flight with a tantrum over snacks. The message, sent on Dec 17, read "I will certainly take revenge!" after Cho Hyun-Ah was summoned by prosecutors. Cho Hyun-Ah was formally arrested on charges including aviation safety law, coercion, and interference in duty. The apology comes after prosecutors revealed the contents of the message.

site_title: China steel mills start taking the high road
summary: China's state-owned steel mills are shifting their focus due to the country's slowing economy and increasing competition. Hebei Iron & Steel Co Ltd, China's largest steelmaker, plans to export 11% of its annual production to South Africa and other countries by 2023. Despite concerns over demand, the move aims to reduce pollution and increase revenue. This strategy is part of a broader effort to revamp the country's industrial sector and address environmental concerns.

site_title: US opens door to oil exports after year of pressure
summary: The US has lifted restrictions on exporting most domestic crude oil after a year of pressure, allowing some companies to sell lightly treated condensate abroad. The Bureau of Industry and Security granted permission to "some" companies to export ultra-light shale oil, and released guidance to clarify what kind of oil is allowed under the ban. The move is expected to unleash a wave of ultra-light shale oil onto global markets, where it can fetch a premium of $10 a barrel or more.

site_title: South Korean inflation slows in December
summary: South Korea's inflation rate slowed to 0.8% in December, its lowest point in 14 months, due to plummeting oil prices. This marks the lowest gain since October 2013. Consumer prices for 2014 rose 1.3%, below the central Bank of Korea's target of 2.5-3.5%. The core consumer price index remained unchanged from the previous month. The slow inflation rate raises concerns about deflation despite the central bank's interest rate cut.

site_title: Asia closing the year on a cautious note
summary: Asian markets closed cautiously on December 31, 2014, amid concerns over Greece's euro zone future and the US dollar's recent gains. The euro fell as European bond yields hit historic lows, while the yen strengthened against the dollar. China's CSI300 index ended the year with a 48% gain, largely driven by policy stimulus hopes. The Nikkei rose 7.1% for the year, and the MSCI Asia-Pacific index ended almost unchanged, mirroring its start to the year.

site_title: Divers set to search for AirAsia wreckage after debris, bodies found
summary: Indonesian divers and ships began searching for the wreckage of AirAsia Flight QZ8501 on Wednesday, after debris and bodies were found in shallow waters off the coast of Borneo. The Airbus A320-200, carrying 162 people, lost contact with air traffic control during bad weather and crashed into the Java Sea. No survivors have been found, and Indonesian President Joko Widodo has announced an immediate advance of money to the families. The search effort involves dozens of Indonesian navy divers, ships, and aircraft from several countries, including the US, Australia, and Singapore, which are seeking the black boxes and wreckage.

site_title: Ying Li expands into Beijing with 559 million yuan investment
summary: Ying Li International Real Estate has invested 559 million yuan (S$119 million) in the Shanghai Zhao Li Investment Centre LLP to partner with China Everbright Limited on the Beijing Tongzhou Project, a development of apartments, office buildings, and retail malls. The project is expected to start pre-sales in 2015 with a total investment of 7.2 billion yuan. This marks Ying Li's expansion into first-tier cities outside of Chongqing, China, for the first time.

site_title: Australia: Shares barely up in 2014
summary: Australian shares are expected to close the year 2014 with a 1% gain, lower than the 15% advances in 2012 and 2013. Weak commodity prices, particularly a 12-13% drop in energy and materials, have impacted the market. The S&P/ASX 200 index was up 3.3 points at 5419.9 at 0045 GMT on New Year's Eve, with investors focusing on celebrations. The market's performance in 2015 may be influenced by the ongoing decline in commodity prices.

images.alt_text: Australian shares looked set to end 2014 with a scant gain well below the past two years' robust advances, and weak commodity prices could impact how the market performs in 2015.

site_title: China's Fosun to buy Meadowbrook Insurance for about US$433m
summary: Chinese conglomerate Fosun International Ltd will acquire Meadowbrook Insurance Group for approximately $433 million, entering the US property and casualty insurance market. The deal represents a 24% premium over Meadowbrook's closing price on Dec 29 and is expected to close in the second half of 2015. Meadowbrook will maintain its headquarters in Michigan and operate under the Meadowbrook brand name. The transaction aims to establish Fosun's presence in the US insurance market, with Chairman Guo Guangchang stating it allows Fosun to enter a "important US P&C market".

site_title: Bank lending in Singapore up 0.6% in November after two months of no growth
summary: Bank lending in Singapore increased 0.6% in November, following two months of no growth, according to data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Loans rose to S$608 billion, driven by a 0.8% increase in business loans to S$373 billion. This contrasts with a 0.3% contraction in October. The growth in lending marks a reversal of the previous two months, which saw stagnant growth.

images.alt_text: BANK lending rose 0.6 per cent in November, following two straight months of no growth, data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore showed on Wednesday.

site_title: China to ease curbs on banks' yuan trading, simplify regulations
summary: China is relaxing restrictions on banks' yuan trading, starting in 2015, with new rules replacing daily caps on foreign exchange positions with weekly limits and establishing unified standards for total foreign exchange positions. The changes aim to simplify regulations and liberalize banks' forex trading practices, amid a weakening yuan and bearish market pressure. The new rules apply to banks with less than $100 million in forex settlement business, with varying limits on total positions and short positions based on the bank's size and business volume.

site_title: Fees, expenses for Detroit bankruptcy hit nearly US$178 million
summary: Detroit's historic bankruptcy cost the city nearly US$178 million in fees and expenses, exceeding its budgeted amount. Jones Day, the lead law firm, billed US$57.9 million, while the city paid US$165 million out of its general fund budget. The city's bankruptcy plan aimed to adjust US$18 billion of debt and obligations. US Bankruptcy Judge Steven Rhodes ordered the city to disclose fees and expenses, which were subject to mediation and ultimately reached fee deals subject to his approval.

site_title: Hopefully, 2015 will not be the year of The Great Payback
summary: The article discusses the potential lack of a "Great Rotation" in the stock market, as predicted by experts, and instead predicts a "Great Divergence" due to central banks' continued use of quantitative easing. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates in June, potentially affecting stock performance. However, the article raises concerns about the sustainability of prolonged quantitative easing and the potential for a "Great Payback" if economic growth does not materialize.

images.alt_text: From 2007 until 2013, equity markets were said to have been buoyed by a "Great Flotation", pushed higher by the tidal wave of liquidity unleased by the US Federal Reserve under various guises that started with TARP (Troubled Asset Relief Programme) and ended with QE3 (quantitative easing).

site_title: China Dec HSBC factory PMI contracts to 7-month low
summary: China's factory sector activity contracted to a 7-month low in December, with the HSBC/Markit Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 49.6, just below the 50.0 level separating growth from contraction. New orders contracted for the first time since April, while output prices declined for the fifth consecutive month. Employment weakened for the 14th month, and the central bank's recent easing moves are seen as insufficient to stimulate demand, raising concerns about the country's economic growth, expected to slow to a 24-year low of 7.4% this year.

site_title: "MH370" ranks as the top Google search topic in Singapore this year
summary: The mysterious disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 was the top Google search topic in Singapore this year, with over 200 million searches made since its disappearance in March. The next top search items were the World Cup 2014, iPhone 6, and MH17, the second Malaysia Airlines plane to be shot down over Ukraine. Google reported that Singaporeans also searched for food, entertainment, and fitness-related topics, with recipes and running events being popular searches.

site_title: US: Stocks follow European equities lower
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, following European markets lower, amid concerns over Greece's potential departure from the eurozone. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 55.16 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index declined 10.22 and 29.47 points, respectively. US consumer confidence rose, but home-price increases were modest. Analysts attributed the market's volatility to limited trade ahead of the New Year's holiday and lack of a specific driving theme.

site_title: China daily blames Google for Beijing's blocking of Gmail
summary: China's state-run media, the Global Times, blames Google for the shutdown of its Gmail service in Beijing, citing the company's unwillingness to obey Chinese law. The Global Times claims Google values its autonomy over complying with Chinese regulations, leading to a conflict. This move comes after the last easy way to access Gmail was blocked, effectively cutting off users' access to the service.

site_title: Glasgow nurse first to be diagnosed with Ebola in the UK
summary: A Glasgow nurse became the first person diagnosed with Ebola in the UK after returning from Sierra Leone, prompting a specialist treatment at London's Royal Free Hospital. The patient, a healthcare worker, received treatment in an isolation unit after feeling unwell upon her return to Scotland. Public health officials assured that the risk of transmission to others was extremely low, citing the patient's early stage of illness and lack of symptoms consistent with Ebola transmission.

site_title: US oil drillers idle the most rigs in two years as crude sinks
summary: US oil drillers have idled the most rigs since 2012, with 37 rigs declining in the week ended Dec 26, bringing the total to 1,499. This decline is attributed to the lowest crude prices in five years, with global prices dropping by $55-a-barrel since June. Domestic oil production continues to surge, reaching 9.14 million barrels a day in the week ended Dec 12, despite the declining rig count.

site_title: Oil prices edge higher from 5-year low
summary: US benchmark West Texas Intermediate oil prices rose 51 US cents to $54.12 a barrel, while European benchmark Brent oil rose 2 cents to $57.90 a barrel. Despite the modest gain, analysts say the market remains focused on excess supply and weak demand. Crude prices have fallen 50% since June, following OPEC's decision not to cut output in response to lower prices. Analyst Gene McGillian says the market is trying to adjust to the policy change, but prices are expected to continue marching lower due to limited fuel demand.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose modestly from a five-year low on Tuesday, but analysts said market sentiment remains focused on excess supply and weak demand.

site_title: Oil price crash claims first US LNG project casualty
summary: US liquefied natural gas (LNG) project developer Excelerate Energy has put its 8 million tonne per annum export terminal project on hold due to an oil price slump. The project, initially due to begin exports in 2018, has become the first casualty of the economic downturn threatening US LNG export projects. The decline in oil prices has made US LNG uncompetitive with supplies from other countries, with the US LNG price linked to Henry Hub gas prices now surpassing those from Qatar and Australia. Thirteen other US LNG projects are also struggling to secure international buyers.

site_title: Norway-bound Air France returns to Paris after captain falls ill
summary: Air France flight AF1746, en route from Paris to Stavanger, Norway, returned to Paris after the captain fell ill mid-flight. The captain experienced a pain in his thorax and opted not to continue the flight. The plane landed at Charles de Gaulle airport at 8:10 pm local time, 37 minutes after takeoff. The captain was immediately attended to by medics upon arrival, and the co-pilot handled the landing. The crew made the decision to return to Paris due to the medical emergency.

site_title: Hangover cure is elusive but symptom relief fizzles and flows
summary: Revelers in the US are seeking relief from hangovers on New Year's Day, but a cure remains elusive. Dr. George Koob, director of the National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, states there are no hangover cures and no medications can effectively treat the symptoms of excessive drinking, which include headaches, nausea, and fatigue. While moderate drinking may have health benefits, hangovers are a symptom of excessive drinking.

site_title: Investors eye 2015 with big appetite for hedge funds: report
summary: Wealthy investors are expected to invest at least $90 billion in hedge funds next year, despite lackluster returns this year. Fresh demand from pension funds, endowments, and insurers will drive the flows, with eVestment predicting between $90 billion and $110 billion in asset inflows. Hedge funds manage $3 trillion in assets and took in $112 billion in new money this year, with multi-strategy funds expected to attract more new money next year due to their diversity.

site_title: Sports scandals leave cloud over memorable 2014
summary: In 2014, sports scandals marred memorable events, overshadowing achievements. The FIFA World Cup in Brazil saw Germany win the title, while the US team faced criticism for its handling of corruption allegations. The 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, were marked by controversy over human rights and doping allegations. Meanwhile, major sporting events were also marred by scandals, including racism in the NBA and MLB, and doping in cricket. Notable athletes like Serena Williams, Lewis Hamilton, and Rory McIlroy achieved success, but the year's sports landscape was dominated by scandals and controversy.

site_title: US expects China investment treaty talks to intensify
