summary: The US expects intensified negotiations with China on a bilateral investment treaty (BIT) to boost business between the two countries. The US has expressed cautious optimism over China's economic reforms, but urges Beijing to move more swiftly on implementation. Key areas of contention include restrictions on foreign investment, intellectual property rights, and market access barriers. The US wants China to allow its government offices to buy more US goods and services, and to reduce discriminatory practices against foreign companies. The US-China BIT talks are due to exchange offers detailing restricted industries by early 2015.

site_title: Government trims confirmed-list industrial land sales for H1 2015
summary: The Singapore government has trimmed confirmed-list industrial land sales for the first half of 2015, offering nine sites totaling 6.46 hectares. This move aims to moderate prices and rentals, which have risen by 16% and 8% per annum in the last four years. The strategy is seen as effective, with 2.6 million square meters of industrial space expected to be ready in 2015 and another 1.9 million sq m in 2016. The government has also released more sites under one hectare and with shorter tenures to make it more affordable for end-users.

site_title: UK house price gain slowest in over a year
summary: UK house prices rose 7.2% in the year to December, the slowest annual increase since November 2013, according to a Nationwide survey. This marks the fourth consecutive month of slowing growth. Economists had expected a 7.5% increase. Despite this, Nationwide predicts the market will recover in 2015 if the economy improves as expected.

site_title: Walgreens shareholders okay takeover of Alliance Boots
summary: Walgreens shareholders approved a $16 billion takeover of Alliance Boots, creating a global pharmacy leader. The deal, which was initially announced in 2012, will combine the two companies into Walgreens Boots Alliance, Inc. The new company will have over 11,000 stores in 10 countries and will be headquartered in Deerfield, Illinois. Stefano Pessina will lead the company as acting CEO, and Greg Wasson will step down shortly after the deal closes.

site_title: Tokyo stocks have nowhere to go but up in 2015: analysts
summary: Tokyo stocks are expected to rise in 2015 due to the Bank of Japan's monetary stimulus and corporate profits. The Nikkei 225 index rose 8% in 2014, its highest level in over seven years, despite a brief setback due to Ebola concerns. Analysts predict further significant gains in the new year.

site_title: Italy's economic slowdown has ended, says minister
summary: Italy's economic slowdown has ended, according to Economy Minister Pier Carlo Padoan. After three years of recession, employment is starting to grow again, boosting consumer and business confidence. The government forecasts a 0.3% economic output fall in 2014, followed by a 0.6% rise in 2015. To boost growth, the government plans to approve measures to support small companies, reduce regulatory risk, and encourage private investment. Italy will proceed with plans to sell state-owned companies and public assets in 2015, aiming to raise funds and cut its debt.

site_title: Airline, travel site sue over 'hacked' airfares
summary: United Airlines and Orbitz have sued Aktarer Zaman, founder of Skiplagged.com, for allegedly promoting a technique to get discounted airfares by skipping the final leg of a flight. Skiplagged, launched last year, enabled travelers to find cheaper fares. The lawsuit, filed in Illinois federal court, claims Zaman's promotion was illegal. Skiplagged.com operates by exploiting loopholes in airline pricing systems, sparking debate over the ethics of such practices.

site_title: Japan social network firm finds mobile gaming success
summary: Japan's social network firm Mixi has reversed its fortunes by successfully transitioning into mobile video gaming with its hit game Monster Strike. The game, released in 2013, has been downloaded over 20 million times and earns Mixi around $2 million daily in revenue. After a year of decline, Mixi has regained investors' trust and its stock market valuation has more than doubled. The company's new focus on gaming has also led to the development of a new app, allowing users to play with friends over Bluetooth or Line.

site_title: US suspects North Korea "had help" in cyber attack on Sony Pictures: source
summary: US investigators suspect North Korea hired hackers from outside the country to help with the massive cyber attack on Sony Pictures in December 2014. North Korea lacks the capability to conduct the attack alone, and US officials are looking into the possibility of Pyongyang contracting out some of the cyber work. The FBI still stands by its previous statement that North Korea is responsible for the attack, but some experts question the government's conclusion, citing linguistic analysis suggesting the hackers may be from Russia.

site_title: Ukraine expects loan disbursement after IMF visit, hopes for more
summary: Ukraine expects the IMF to disburse new and overdue loans totaling over $4 billion after a visit next month, with a potential $17 billion bailout program expansion. The country's economy, heavily impacted by a separatist war and energy imports from Russia, has received $4.6 billion in aid under the IMF-led program. Ukraine hopes to implement reforms to secure further financial assistance, but the IMF and Western backers have expressed concerns about the country's ability to meet its commitments. The government aims to restore its foreign currency reserves to a healthy level, currently at $10 billion.

site_title: Agonising wait for Schumachers and Bianchis
summary: Formula One legend Michael Schumacher has entered his second year battling back from a horrific ski accident in 2013, with his condition remaining a closely-guarded secret. Meanwhile, 25-year-old Jules Bianchi's recent accident on the track has heightened anxiety in the racing world. Schumacher made headlines in 2013 with a critical brain injury after hitting a rock while skiing off-piste in the French Alps, and his recovery has been marked by a reclusive lifestyle in his Swiss home. The racing community remains anxious about his progress and the future of the sport.

site_title: It's only getting better
summary: Advances in science and medicine have led to significant improvements in global health, with major declines in infectious diseases such as TB and polio. The number of deaths from crimes and wars has also decreased, with the US experiencing a drop in crime rates. Despite regional conflicts and global tensions, effective management by world leaders has prevented global military confrontations. Globalization has continued, with the American economy recovering and European trade agreements being negotiated. However, challenges remain, including climate change and environmental problems, as well as corruption and instability in some regions.

images.alt_text: An Indian tuberculosis patient sitting with his brother at the Rajan Babu Tuberculosis Hospital in New Delhi.

site_title: US airports modernising dining options with fresh-from-the-farm fare
summary: US airports are modernizing their dining options with fresh, local produce and meat from farm-to-table restaurants, led by well-known chefs. Many airports, such as Newark Liberty International and JFK, are requiring chefs to shop at greenmarkets three times a week. This shift has been welcomed by travelers, who can now enjoy healthier options like salads and sandwiches. The farm-to-table movement is also benefiting small-scale farmers, who are finding new markets and increasing their income. This trend is seen as a potential solution to the predicted 25% decline in farm income in the US this year.

site_title: Goldman tops UK banker pay with US$4.7m awarded for 2013
summary: Goldman Sachs topped UK bankers with an average payout of $4.7 million in 2013, exceeding other leading banks. The US investment bank paid its top 121 London bankers 3 million pounds (US$4.7 million) on average, with senior staff receiving more than five times the fixed pay in variable pay. The payouts, combined with 2.1 million restricted stock units worth US$377 million, totaled US$193.6 million in 2013. This far exceeded the average annual pay in Britain, with 2,600 employees at British banks or working in London receiving over 3.4 billion pounds in 2013.

site_title: Ang Mo Kio: A pilot walking, cycling town
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) and Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) have announced plans to transform Ang Mo Kio into a pedestrian and cyclist-friendly town by 2018. Key features include a weather-proof walking and cycling path under the MRT viaduct, elevated paths for pedestrians and cyclists, bicycle parking, and safer bus stops and road crossings. The pilot project aims to enhance the travel experience for commuters and support Singapore's vision of a "Car-Lite Singapore" with a sustainable and liveable environment.

site_title: China launches cyber claim to islands in Japan dispute
summary: China has launched a website, www.diaoyudao.org.cn, to assert sovereignty over the disputed Senkaku Islands in the East China Sea, which are claimed by Japan. The website features historical documents and maps, and will soon be available in seven languages, including Japanese. China's National Marine Data and Information Service unveiled the website, which includes a timeline dating back to 1403, the year Beijing claims the islands' Mandarin name first appeared in writings. This move comes after Japan nationalized some of the islands and despite a recent meeting between Chinese and Japanese leaders.

site_title: Plane debris found, some bodies retrieved
summary: Indonesian search crews recovered debris and bodies from the AirAsia airliner that went missing on December 28 with 162 people on board. The plane's emergency door and parts resembling plane components were found, along with two female and one male body. Aviation expert Paul Hayes stated that the bodies did not have life jackets, indicating it wasn't a controlled ditching. The investigation continues to determine the cause of the crash, with a focus on finding the voice and data recorders.

site_title: Smooth crossover to Euro VI diesel standard expected in 2018
summary: Singapore is set to transition to the Euro VI diesel-emission standard on January 1, 2018, which aims to reduce pollutants such as fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and nitrogen oxides (NOx) from diesel vehicles. The standard will be accepted by the National Environment Agency (NEA) for vehicles meeting Japanese emission standards, including Nissan and Honda models. However, some Japanese manufacturers, such as Honda, may not offer Euro VI-compliant diesel models due to limited availability of Euro IV-compliant vehicles. The Motor Traders Association of Singapore has successfully lobbied for the dual standard.

site_title: US ETF tracking China stocks posts record inflows
summary: US investors added $34.6 million to the Deutsche X-trackers Harvest CSI 300 China A-Shares ETF for the eighth consecutive week, amid speculation that China's easing monetary policies will extend equity gains. The Shanghai Composite Index surged 49% in 2014, with authorities announcing a change in deposit calculation that could boost lending capacity for Chinese banks. Foreign investors, unable to invest directly in mainland China, are using the ETF to chase the rally, with the benchmark gauge reaching a five-year high.

site_title: Bric investment theme loses appeal as outlook for the four economies diverges
summary: The Bric grouping of Brazil, Russia, India, and China has seen a significant divergence in their economies, with Chinese and Indian benchmark equity indexes surging 40% this year, while Russian and Brazilian gauges have dropped 4.2%. This annual divergence is the largest since 2001, with Chinese and Indian equities' combined market capitalization surpassing Russia and Brazil's by $5.2 trillion. The divergence highlights a growing disparity in the economic outlook of these nations.

site_title: US carmakers feeling optimistic after industry's rebound in 2014
summary: US car sales rebounded in 2014, with a 6% increase and over 16 million vehicles sold, the most since 2006. Petrol prices' decline and improved economic conditions contributed to the growth. Innovative upgrades, such as aluminum frames in Ford F-150 pickup trucks and Apple CarPlay, were also notable. However, 2014 was also marked by a record 50 million car recalls, resulting in dozens of deaths and millions of faulty cars remaining on the road. Analysts predict continued growth in 2015, but warn of increased competition and potential slowing sales growth.

site_title: America is still in the race
summary: The US economy has narrowed its gap with China's, according to China's revised GDP figures, which now stand at $9.6 trillion. Despite this, the US economy remains larger, estimated at $16.7 trillion. Analysts have long argued that the US is in relative decline, citing factors such as dysfunctional governance and a shrinking workforce. However, President Barack Obama has taken steps to boost the economy, including job creation and environmental initiatives. Some experts argue that the US has the capacity to innovate and develop institutions, making it well-positioned to compete with China and other emerging economies.

site_title: South America seeks new sources of growth
summary: South American governments face stagnant economies as the commodity boom comes to an end. Venezuela's president calls for budget cuts due to plummeting oil prices, while Peru relaxes environmental regulations to boost mining production. Brazil's new Cabinet aims to cut spending and eliminate tax breaks to shore up government finances. The region, which was transformed by sustained economic growth and poverty reductions for a decade, now seeks new sources of growth to replace declining commodity prices.

site_title: Greece back on investors' radar screen
summary: Greece's political uncertainty has returned to investors' radar, leading to a sell-off in regional stocks. The country's parliament failed to secure the required votes for a new president, paving the way for early parliamentary elections, likely on January 25. This is expected to lead to a shift in Greek policies, potentially reversing austerity measures and restructuring the country's debt. The Syriza party is likely to win the elections, and European leaders are warning of the possible consequences of this shift, with some expressing concerns about the impact on the eurozone economy.

site_title: Slimming specialist forks out $32m for 4-storey industrial building
summary: A four-storey industrial building at 243 Alexandra Road in Singapore has been sold for S$32 million to Bottomslim New York, a slimming specialist. The property, with a 2.5 plot ratio, can be redeveloped into a six-storey building. Located near Redhill MRT Station, it is zoned for Business 1 use and has a potential gross floor area of around 36,000 sq ft. This is the third time the property has changed hands in four years, following previous sales by the Le Mercier family and Cheong Sim Lam in 2011 and 2012, respectively.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Thailand private consumption flat in November
summary: Thailand's private consumption remained flat in November, with the economy growing only 0.2% in the first nine months of the year. Private investment rose 1.4% on the month, but was down 0.4% on the year. The Bank of Thailand cut its 2014 economic growth forecast to 0.8% and 2015 growth estimate to 4% due to weak exports and slow public spending. The junta maintains that 2015 growth will be 4.5%, but experts expect the economy to remain subdued due to high household debt and soft demand from major markets.

site_title: Greece may be leading indicator, not exception
summary: Greece's failure to agree on its president will lead to new elections, potentially bringing left-wing Syriza to power, which may put Athens at odds with European creditors. A Syriza-led government may lack bargaining power, but a haggling period between Greece and eurozone governments is more likely, causing sustained political uncertainty and economic suffering. The ECB's plans to buy sovereign debt may be derailed, and investor confidence could be weakened, with Greece becoming a leading indicator of Europe's recovery issues.

site_title: 2014 ends with uneasy truce in East Asia
summary: An uneasy truce settled over East Asia as 2014 drew to a close, with Japan, China, and South Korea avoiding provocative acts and tensions. China's rise as a superpower has led to Japan's adjustment to a new post-war order, with both nations building up their military and economic power. The region's "balance of terror" has shifted, with Japan avoiding visits to Tokyo's Yasukuni Shrine and China consolidating its power. This cautious approach offers breathing space for wiser counsels to prevail, but the underlying tensions remain, and the potential for conflict remains.

site_title: Macau increases scrutiny of high rollers' agents
summary: Macau's gaming regulator tightened scrutiny of high rollers' agents, requiring junket operators to submit documents on their agents' criminal records. This move comes after Chinese President Xi Jinping urged the Macau government to strengthen supervision of the gambling industry, which relies on high rollers for two-thirds of its revenue. The regulator is seeking to curb money flows and remove the negative impression of the industry, as Xi has called for the city to diversify its economy and turn into a world tourism and leisure centre.

site_title: Sengkang EC tender closing postponed
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has postponed the tender closing for an executive condo (EC) development site in Sengkang East to January 20, 2015, to allow bidders to study the additional requirement for 88 bicycle parking spaces. The Land Transport Authority's (LTA) new condition aims to encourage cycling as a mode of transportation. The successful tenderer will need to provide the minimum required spaces, with any additional provision subject to evaluation and potential gross floor area (GFA) exemption.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Gun smuggling on Delta flights shows up security
summary: A former Delta Air Lines employee and a baggage handler at Atlanta Airport have been charged with smuggling 153 firearms, including an AK-47 assault weapon, on 17 Delta flights between Atlanta and New York. The suspect, Mark Henry, received the guns from an accomplice, Eugene Harvey, who had access to secure areas of the airport. Despite Henry passing through regular airport security checkpoints, he was able to carry the guns onto the plane in his backpack. The case highlights major deficiencies in airport security, with employees with access to secure areas not being as closely screened as passengers.

site_title: European startups finding it harder than US counterparts to raise funds
summary: European startups are struggling to raise funds compared to their US counterparts, with tech companies in Silicon Valley securing $22 billion in 2014, more than double the amount raised by European companies. In a dollar-for-dollar comparison, New York outperforms European rivals, with London and Berlin tech companies raising $1.4 billion and $1.1 billion respectively in 2014. Despite this, Berlin saw a 140% increase in venture capital investment, while London startups raised roughly double the amount they did in 2013, with notable funding for peer-to-peer lending company Funding Circle and online fashion company FarFetch.

site_title: US high-speed rail plans may ride on Texas express
summary: A Texas-based company, Texas Central Railway, plans to build a high-speed rail line between Dallas and Houston, with service expected to begin in 2021. The $10 billion project will use private investment and Japan's bullet train technology, with travel times under 90 minutes. Proponents argue that high-speed rail is environmentally friendly and could jumpstart other US projects. However, some skeptics question the project's viability due to lack of government involvement and the need for significant subsidies, a challenge that has hindered similar projects in the US.

site_title: The case against persistent global imbalances
summary: A professor warns that persistent global imbalances could trigger a new financial meltdown if left unchecked. He cites 10 confidence-denting events starting in 2014 that, if combined, could lead to a 75-85% probability of a dire outcome. The events include natural disasters, geopolitical conflicts, and economic downturns. The professor advises governments, corporations, and investors to recalibrate their thinking and response calculus to mitigate the risk of a global financial crisis.

site_title: Rent payments up US$20.6b in US as home ownership falls
summary: US renters paid a record $441 billion for apartments and houses in 2014, a $20.6 billion increase, as fewer Americans owned their homes. Rental households grew by 2% nationally, with the New York metropolitan area seeing a 63,000 increase to 3.4 million residents. Landlords raised leasing charges due to tight inventories, contributing to the rent increase.

site_title: Why commodity prices are down in US but up in Europe
summary: Commodity prices have declined in the US but risen in Europe in 2014, defying expectations. The global economic slowdown and diminishing demand for energy, minerals, and agricultural products are cited as contributing factors. However, the US is a notable exception, with the American expansion showing strong growth despite falling commodity prices. Monetary policy is also a key factor, with anticipated interest rate hikes in the US and expansionary monetary policies in Europe. The dollar's appreciation against the euro and yen is attributed to the end of quantitative easing in the US, which has shifted speculative attention to higher interest rates in 2015, bringing forward the expected price decrease.

images.alt_text: High rates also decrease firms' desire to carry inventories. Think of oil held in tanks.

site_title: China's Jiangsu Changjiang to spearhead US$780m bid for STATS ChipPAC
summary: JCET, a Chinese electronics packaging service provider, has formed a consortium to make a US$780 million takeover bid for STATS ChipPAC, a Singapore-listed semiconductor testing and assembly services provider. The offer is conditional on pre-conditions being met and is valued at S$0.466 per share, a 1.3% premium to STATS ChipPAC's last traded price. The bid aims to take STATS ChipPAC private. The company also plans to distribute its Taiwan subsidiaries and offer US$200 million in perpetual securities to its shareholders.

site_title: QZ8501 caps grim year for airline industry
summary: AirAsia's Indonesia-bound Flight QZ8501 vanished on December 28, 2014, with 162 people on board, in the Java Sea. The incident marks a grim year for the airline industry, following the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines' MH370 in March and MH17 in July. Despite the tragedies, the industry is expected to see a record profit of $19.9 billion in 2014, with Asia-Pacific carriers projected to be the second-best performers. However, the industry faces challenges, including the need for improved tracking capabilities and better communication for aircraft over conflict zones.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
FRAUGHT with tragedies, 2014 has been a year that the aviation industry will likely close the door on with relief.

site_title: As 'Interview' takes streaming plunge, Hollywood tests waters
summary: Hollywood's test of same-day streaming of "The Interview" has shown promising results, with consumers paying $15 million in four days. The success may encourage studios to shorten the theatrical window, with analysts predicting changes in the industry's distribution strategy. However, close ties between theaters and studios and the importance of theaters for revenue generation may slow the adoption of same-day distribution. Experts suggest that consumers' expectations will play a key role in shaping the industry's future, with potential changes to the theatrical window and increased emphasis on online releases.

site_title: Among Cuba's vintage cars, the truly valuable are elusive
summary: US-Cuba diplomatic ties have been restored, and economic sanctions are expected to be lifted, allowing for increased access to US markets for Cuba's vintage cars. However, finding valuable collectible cars is challenging due to the country's chronic shortages and the US embargo. Most vintage cars have been heavily modified with makeshift parts, and original parts are scarce. Even if the embargo is lifted, US collectors may need to temper their expectations, as Cuba's 2010 law prohibits cars from being taken off the island, and many are in poor condition.

site_title: Japan cuts corporate taxes to spur economic growth
summary: Japan's ruling coalition has approved a tax reform plan cutting corporate taxes by 2.51 percentage points to 32.1% from April, with further reductions planned in coming years to boost profitability and economic growth. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aims to increase wages, consumption, and corporate investment. The plan is estimated to cost around 400 billion yen over the next two fiscal years, and will be budget-neutral in the third year, with a further increase in the consumption tax to 10% from 2017.

site_title: Deloitte suggests refinements to PIC scheme in Budget 2015 wishlist (Amended)
summary: Deloitte recommends refinements to Singapore's Productivity & Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme, including having the Economic Development Board (EDB) assess R&D project proposals instead of IRAS. The firm also suggests combining PIC cash payouts and raising the payout cap to S$100,000 per year. Additionally, Deloitte recommends increasing the partial tax exemption for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) from S$300,000 to S$600,000 to lower their effective tax rate.

site_title: Low valuations spell consolidation for O&M sector
summary: Low oil prices have led to a significant decline in the offshore and marine (O&M) sector, with market capitalization falling 15.7% in November. Despite investors' recent run on O&M stocks, analysts rule out a dramatic recovery in 2015, instead expecting a period of consolidation. Fund-raising, takeovers, and privatization are expected to shape the industry's landscape, as companies seek to adapt to the low oil price environment. A prolonged downturn is anticipated, with the O&M sector likely to experience further challenges in the coming year.

site_title: Fresh reminder from another disaster at sea
summary: A recent ferry fire in the Adriatic and the Norman Atlantic incident have highlighted the need for improved passenger ship safety and evacuation procedures. The incidents come after the 2014 AirAsia disaster and the tragic sinking of the South Korean Sewol, resulting in 304 lives lost. The shipping industry must re-examine its approach to quickly and safely evacuating large numbers of people from passenger ships, including ro-ro and cruise liners. Priorities should be focused on passenger safety and evacuation procedures in 2015.

site_title: Singapore brokers to disclose trading curbs from Dec 31
summary: Singapore brokers will disclose trading restrictions starting Dec 31, as part of industry guidelines developed by the Securities Association of Singapore (SAS) to enhance transparency. The move follows the 2013 penny stock sell-off and a consultation between the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Singapore Exchange. Each of the nine SAS member houses will announce the restrictions on their websites, providing more information to traders. The goal is to increase transparency and fairness in trading practices.

site_title: Electricity tariffs to fall 8% in Q1 2015
summary: Electricity tariffs in Singapore are set to fall 8% in Q1 2015, with households seeing a reduction of 23.29 cents per kWh from 25.28 cents. The decrease is attributed to a 16.4% drop in natural gas prices, which make up half of the tariff. The lower tariff will result in a S$7.93 decrease in the average monthly bill for a four-room-flat household. Industry regulators and economists note that the impact on inflation will be minimal, as electricity costs only account for 2% of the consumer price index.

site_title: Disaster rekindles pain of MH370
summary: Relatives of passengers on missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 expressed renewed pain and desperation after the disappearance of AirAsia flight QZ8501 in Indonesia. The loss of two-thirds of the 239 people on MH370, including Chinese citizens, has sparked a sense of solidarity among families. Authorities found wreckage and bodies of QZ8501 in the sea, providing some solace to victims' families. The disappearance of QZ8501 has reignited the pain of MH370's relatives, who have been seeking answers for nine months.

site_title: Cuba's artists await a flood of travellers
summary: Cuban artists are poised for a surge in international recognition as US President Barack Obama's decision to loosen the economic embargo creates a new pipeline of art lovers. Wealthy collectors and institutions, including the Bronx Museum of the Arts and the Museum of Modern Art, are flocking to Cuba to visit galleries and studios. Artists like Kadir Lopez and Carlos Garaicoa are seeing a significant increase in interest, with prices ranging from $1,500 to $15,000. However, some worry that the sudden influx of collectors may lead to a decrease in quality, with Roberto Diago citing concerns that artists may produce work in anticipation of a boom.

site_title: Oil still the main drag as commodity benchmarks take further hits
summary: Oil prices continue to plummet, with Brent trading at a 5-and-a-half year low of US$57, due to a global supply glut. The Credit Suisse Commodity Benchmark Index has tumbled 25% for the year, with other commodities like copper and iron ore also suffering losses. Analysts predict oil prices will take time to recover, with a possible rebound in late 2015. Meanwhile, precious metals like palladium and platinum are expected to outperform the sector, while agricultural commodities like corn and soybeans are expected to see moderate price support.

site_title: Brokers to disclose trading curb details from Dec 31
summary: Singapore brokers will disclose trading restrictions on their websites starting December 31, following a consultation with the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Singapore Exchange. The Securities Association of Singapore (SAS) will provide links to each member firm's website, allowing investors to access the information. The move aims to increase transparency and address concerns about "information asymmetry" in the market.

site_title: Shipping needs a tech revolution
summary: The global shipping industry is at a crossroads, with its environmental performance under increasing scrutiny. Stricter regulations aim to reduce harmful emissions and greenhouse gas emissions, requiring significant investment in new technologies and fuels. While the industry is taking steps to address these challenges, a "radical rethink" is needed to balance economic growth with environmental sustainability. A technological revolution is proposed, involving the central collection of voyage information and data to enhance performance, optimize routes, and leverage existing technologies. This could lead to greater efficiencies, improved environmental performance, and economic benefits for shipowners.

site_title: Jaitley denies putting pressure on RBI to cut rates
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley denied putting pressure on the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) to cut interest rates, after his comment that high capital costs are stifling investment sparked market volatility. Jaitley claimed his remarks were about discussing the manufacturing sector, not pressuring RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan. Benchmark bond yields fell, and economists expect the RBI to lower rates in February or April if inflation remains tame.

site_title: Contemporary art scene sizzles in Shanghai with Power Station
summary: The Power Station of Art, China's first state-owned contemporary art museum, has found its footing in the contemporary art scene in Shanghai. Two years after its debut, the museum has hosted successful exhibitions, including the 10th Shanghai Biennale, which has been well-received by critics and the public. The Power Station has developed educational outreach and training for emerging curators, but still faces challenges in building a strong vision for Chinese contemporary art and navigating censorship. The museum's director aims to shift attention from politics to individual art value and secure private funding to support operations.

site_title: New Lakeside rapped for breach of rules, governance failure
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reprimanded New Lakeside Holdings, now known as Zhongxin Fruit & Juice, and its former director Go Twan Heng, and CFO Oh Gim Teck, for breaching listing rules and corporate governance failures. A 2010 audit review found the company failed to disclose material information, leading to breaches of SGX listing manual rules. The company's former executives are accused of failing to act in shareholders' interests and safeguarding the company's interests. SGX has advised companies to consult the exchange before appointing these individuals as directors or management members.

site_title: Former China president Hu approved graft probe against aide: sources
summary: Former Chinese President Hu Jintao approved a graft probe against former senior aide Ling Jihua, who is suspected of trying to cover up his son's death in a luxury sports car crash. The probe, announced last week, is part of President Xi Jinping's crackdown on official corruption. Hu signed off on the investigation, showing that internal Communist Party harmony and respect for elders still holds sway under Xi's leadership. Ling was demoted in 2012 after his son's fatal crash and is now suspected of unilaterally mobilizing the party's Central Bodyguards Bureau to cover up the incident.

site_title: Airbus says to work with investigators on AirAsia crash investigation
summary: Airbus will collaborate with Indonesian investigators to determine the cause of the AirAsia crash, which occurred on December 28, 2014, when Flight QZ8501 lost contact while flying between Indonesia and Singapore. The Airbus A320-200 was located off the coast of Borneo, and wreckage and bodies have been recovered. The investigation, led by the Indonesian National Transportation Safety Committee, aims to establish the cause of the tragic accident with the assistance of international agencies.

site_title: Coffee snaps its rising streak as rain revives supply and prices slide
summary: Coffee prices have fallen 13% in the past two months due to heavy rainfall in Brazil, the world's top coffee grower, reviving parched trees and increasing supply. The 2015 crop is expected to be 25% larger than forecast, with farmers exporting more as the Brazilian currency weakens. Hedge funds have cut their bullish bets on prices by 35% since mid-October, predicting prices may drop further by April to $1.50 a pound. Global demand remains high, but supplies are increasing, leading to a surplus for a fifth straight season.

images.alt_text: With the harvest still months away, there's still a risk to supply. Citigroup Inc predicts coffee will average US$2.15 in the first quarter.

site_title: Small US firms may struggle with new UPS, FedEx prices
summary: US parcel delivery firms UPS and FedEx are introducing new pricing systems that charge by dimensional weight, rather than just weight, starting January 5. This change is expected to increase shipping costs for small firms by up to 50% and may lead some to switch to the US Postal Service (USPS). Online retailers like Amazon are expected to adapt, but smaller companies may struggle to adjust, with one firm estimating it will pay 36% more for shipping.

site_title: AirAsia jets in fresh incidents in Thailand and Philippines
summary: AirAsia experienced two incidents on December 30, 2014. An AirAsia flight from Bangkok to Khon Kaen in Thailand turned back to the capital due to a minor irregularity in the storage compartment, but resumed service after a detailed inspection. Later, an AirAsia jet in the Philippines skidded off the runway on arrival at Kalibo airport, causing no injuries but shutting the airport. Both incidents were resolved without technical issues, and flights continued as scheduled.

images.alt_text: AN AirAsia flight bound for north-east Thailand turned back to the capital Bangkok shortly after takeoff Tuesday when pilots detected an "irregularity" in the storage compartment, airline officials said.

site_title: When planes crash at sea
summary: Debris and bodies from the AirAsia Airbus jetliner have been located in the Java Sea off Indonesia, but finding and recovering the aircraft could take time and cost millions of dollars. This incident follows similar crashes at sea, including the still-undiscovered Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 and the 2009 Air France flight AF447. The recovery of the AirAsia flight will benefit from its shallow water crash site and the use of advanced devices such as satellites, robots, and underwater drones.

site_title: US in-store pickup of online purchases does not save much time: study
summary: A study by StellaService found that in-store pickup of online purchases by major US retailers like Target and Toys "R" Us saves little to no time, with an average of 96 seconds saved. Shoppers spent an average of 5 minutes and 24 seconds in stores when picking up orders, and those who did not use the service spent an average of 7 minutes. Retailers have varying approaches to in-store pickup, with some saving as little as 30 seconds and others taking up to 8 minutes.

site_title: Email, Internet remain top workplace tools: study
summary: A US study by the Pew Research Center found that 61% of Americans consider email "very important" for work productivity, and 54% for the Internet. This preference is consistent across all workers, with higher figures for office-based workers. Landlines remain preferred over cellphones for office use, highlighting a preference for traditional tools in the workplace.

site_title: Hotdog cart-turned-burger chain files for IPO
summary: Shake Shack Inc., a burger chain that started as a hotdog cart in New York, is going public with an initial public offering (IPO) filing. The company, founded by restaurateur Danny Meyer, has over 63 outlets in 30-plus cities and aims for a US$1 billion valuation. Despite a 41% sales increase, net income fell due to rising expenses, and the company's growth rate and profitability are slowing. Shake Shack plans to open 10 new stores annually and expand globally, but faces challenges from sanctions and volatility in the Middle East.

images.alt_text: An instant success at the beginning, Shake Shack is aiming for a US$1 billion valuation in the IPO. It plans to open 10 new company-operated stores in the US each year starting in 2015.

site_title: AirAsia crash probe focuses on timing of request to climb, weather
summary: Indonesia's investigation into the AirAsia Flight QZ8501 crash is focusing on the timing of the pilot's request to climb to avoid bad weather, as a possible factor behind the tragedy. The crew asked to ascend 36 minutes after takeoff, but there was no response from the cockpit. Investigators are examining the role of storms in the area, as well as the crew's decision-making process, and are reviewing data from radar, weather reports, and communication records. The investigation, led by Indonesia's National Transportation Safety Committee, has yet to determine the cause of the crash, which killed all 162 people on board.

site_title: World's wealthiest add US$92b in 2014
summary: The world's 400 wealthiest billionaires added US$92 billion to their collective fortune in 2014, increasing their net worth to US$4.1 trillion. Jack Ma, Warren Buffett, and Mark Zuckerberg were among the biggest gainers, with Ma's US$25.1 billion increase propelled by Alibaba's 56% surge in shares. Bill Gates remained the world's richest person with a US$87.6 billion fortune. However, Russian billionaires suffered significant losses due to the country's economic downturn and sanctions. The decline in oil prices also affected billionaires like Sheldon Adelson and Jeffrey Bezos.

site_title: Yen surges amid end-of-year investor nerves
summary: The yen surged against the US dollar and euro on December 30 as investors sought the traditional safety of the Japanese currency amid end-of-year economic risks. The euro fell to a 29-month low, while the dollar declined 0.3% against a basket of currencies. The yen rose 1% to 119.56 per dollar, knocking the dollar off an 8.5-year high. Investors are concerned about global economic growth, deflation, and the risk of Greece leaving the eurozone, driving more dollar weakness and yen strength in 2015.

images.alt_text: The yen gained sharply against the US dollar and euro on Tuesday as investors sought the traditional safety of the Japanese currency amid end-of-year nerves over looming economic risks.

site_title: Opec oil output hits six-month low in December on Libya
summary: OPEC's oil output fell to a six-month low in December, dropping 270,000 barrels per day, due to Libyan turmoil, despite a record Iraqi southern export increase and stable Saudi production. This move offsets the market's concerns about a potential supply cut. Analysts attribute the decline to Libyan output, which has been decreasing since a Vienna meeting last month, and warn of an overhang in supply balances for next year.

site_title: Palm oil and rubber prices rise as floods in M'sia, Thailand hit supplies
summary: Malaysia and Thailand experienced severe flooding, disrupting palm oil and rubber supplies. Floods in the two countries are expected to drop rubber output by at least 30% and palm oil production by 30-11% this month. The floods may exacerbate the decline in palm oil output, which is typically lower in the first quarter. Heavy rain is forecasted to continue, further disrupting supplies.

site_title: SGX reprimands New Lakeside Holdings for breaching listing rules, corporate governance failings

site_title: US: Stocks dip as Greece uncertainty weighs
summary: US stocks fell slightly in early trade on Tuesday, dipping with European markets due to Greece's snap election and uncertainty over potential anti-austerity policies. site_title: Matex International eyeing coal assets in proposed reverse takeover deal

summary: Chinese state-run media blames Google for the shutdown of its Gmail service, citing the company's unwillingness to obey Chinese law. The shutdown may boost a rival email service run by Netease, with new users signing up at a rate three to four times normal.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end lower

summary: US single-family home prices increased 4.5% in October from the prior year, slowing less than forecast. site_title: Greek polls to 'determine whether Greece stays in Europe': PM

The election has rattled markets and could lead to a new government, potentially affecting Greece's bailout payments and economic reforms.

site_title: Indonesia search chief says three bodies retrieved in AirAsia hunt
summary: Indonesia's National Search and Rescue Agency chief Bambang Soelistyo said three bodies have been recovered in the search for the AirAsia plane that crashed in the Java Sea on Sunday, with two females and one male. site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Tuesday, closing at 1,766.83 after a 1.58-point drop. The index saw 1.34 billion lots traded, with 382 gains and 402 losses.

site_title: Taiwan says Xiaomi, other smartphone brands don't breach privacy rules

site_title: Fourth ST Marine senior exec charged in corruption scandal

site_title: Korean Air heiress arrested for 'nut rage'
summary: Korean Air heiress Cho Hyun-Ah was arrested for delaying a flight after a tantrum over snacks, known as the "nut rage" incident. She was accused of forcing the chief purser off the plane and compelling it to return to the gate. Cho, 40, was charged with aviation safety law violation, coercion, and interference in duty duties. An unidentified executive was also arrested for destroying evidence. Cho has resigned and apologized, while the transport ministry plans to sanction the airline with a flight ban or fines up to $2 million.

site_title: Dozens die as Malaysia, Thailand, Philippines battered by storms
summary: Malaysia, southern Thailand, and parts of the Philippines have been hit by heavy rain and flash floods, killing dozens. In Malaysia, nearly a quarter of a million people were forced from their homes due to the worst flooding in a decade, with 21 deaths reported. In southern Thailand, 15 people have been killed. The government's response has been criticized for being slow.

site_title: AirAsia jets in fresh incidents in Thailand and Philippines
summary: AirAsia jets experienced two incidents on Tuesday, one in Thailand and the other in the Philippines. Both incidents were deemed safe and no passengers were injured.

site_title: Ukraine economy shrank 7.5% in 'worst year since WWII'
summary: Ukraine's economy shrank 7.5% in 2014, the largest contraction since World War II, due to the ongoing conflict and currency devaluation. Inflation soared to 21% by the end of November. The country's reserves more than halved in 2014, and the hryvnia currency depreciated by 50% against the US dollar.

site_title: Asia fuel oil: 380-cst bunker plunges to over 5-1/2 year low on weak crude
summary: The 380-cst bunker fuel in Asia plummeted to a 5-1/2 year low on Tuesday, reaching $305 a tonne, due to a weak crude market. The decline was attributed to a sliding crude market, erasing earlier gains.

site_title: ECB may roll out heavy artillery against deflation in 2015
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to roll out "heavy artillery" against deflation in 2015, with analysts predicting the possibility of "quantitative easing" (QE) to boost eurozone inflation. Despite concerns from critics, including Bundesbank president Jens Weidmann, ECB chief Mario Draghi has stated that a QE program could be designed to win consensus on the governing council. The ECB has already implemented various measures to combat deflation, including cutting interest rates and making cheap loans available to banks, but inflation remains alarmingly low at 0.3%.

images.alt_text: So far, the ECB has rolled out a wide range of measures to try and get eurozone inflation back up to the level of 2 per cent.

site_title: AirAsia disaster rekindles pain for MH370 relatives
summary: Tearful relatives of those on board missing Malaysia Airlines flights MH370 and QZ8501 expressed deep pain and desperation after the AirAsia disaster in Indonesia, nine months into their nightmare. site_title: Plans to make Ang Mo Kio a pedestrian, cyclist-friendly town (Amended)
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) and Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) have announced plans to transform Ang Mo Kio into a pedestrian and cyclist-friendly town. site_title: Update: Bodies, debris found as AirAsia plane believed found in sea
summary: A missing AirAsia passenger plane, Flight QZ8501, believed to have crashed in the Java Sea off Indonesia, has been located. site_title: Indonesia recovers 40 bodies at sea from missing AirAsia jet: navy
summary: Indonesia's navy has recovered 40 bodies at sea from the missing AirAsia jet that went missing on Sunday. The recovery effort is part of an ongoing search and rescue operation. No further information on the cause of the crash or the number of people on board is available.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares shed 1.14%

site_title: Indonesia finds bodies, debris in search for missing jet: official

site_title: AirAsia boss says 'my heart is filled with sadness'
summary: AirAsia CEO Tony Fernandes expressed grief and condolences to the families of the 162 passengers and crew on board Flight QZ8501, which crashed in the sea on Sunday. The incident marks a tragic loss of life, and Fernandes' words convey his sorrow and support for the affected families.

site_title: Global markets: Year-end caution subdues shares, lifts yen
summary: Global markets experienced a wave of risk aversion on Tuesday, driven by concerns over Greece's future in the euro and end-of-year caution. site_title: Oil hits 5-1/2-year low under US$57 on supply glut
summary: Brent crude oil fell to a 5-1/2-year low of $56.74 a barrel, its lowest since May 2009, due to a global supply glut. site_title: Eurozone loans to private sector still contracting: ECB
summary: The European Central Bank reported that loans to the private sector in the euro area declined by 0.9% in November compared to the same month in 2013, a slightly lower rate than the drop of 1.1% in October. site_title: Bodies, debris from missing AirAsia plane pulled from sea off Indonesia
summary: Indonesian rescuers pulled 40 bodies and wreckage from the sea off Borneo, ending the search for AirAsia Flight QZ8501, which lost contact on Sunday during bad weather. site_title: Singapore offering land totalling 14 ha for industrial use

site_title: Body found in sea search for AirAsia: Indonesian search and rescue
summary: A body was found in the sea during the search for missing AirAsia flight QZ8501, according to Indonesia's National Search and Rescue Agency chief. site_title: Joyas says unaware of information to explain heavy trading

site_title: AirAsia plane crash caps disastrous 2014 for aviation
summary: A disastrous 2014 for aviation saw multiple high-profile plane crashes, including Malaysia Airlines' MH370 and MH17, and AirAsia's recent incident. site_title: Rebates worth S$100 million to be doled out in January to Singaporean HDB households
