However, Bundesbank president Jens Weidmann and German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble have expressed concerns about the policy, citing the need for structural reforms to address underlying economic issues.

site_title: Debris is 'from AirAsia plane': Indonesian civil aviation chief
summary: Indonesian Director General of Civil Aviation Djoko Murjatmodjo confirmed that debris spotted during an aerial search for AirAsia flight QZ8501 is from the missing plane. The debris, including a passenger door and cargo door, was found 100 miles southwest of Pangkalan Bun in Central Kalimantan. The discovery marks a significant development in the search efforts for the missing aircraft, which disappeared on Sunday with 162 people on board.

site_title: UK annual house price growth slows for a 4th month: Nationwide
summary: UK annual house price growth slowed for a fourth consecutive month in December, rising 7.2% compared to a year earlier, according to Nationwide. This follows a 8.5% increase in November. Economists had forecast a 7.5% growth rate. Month-over-month growth slowed to 0.2% from 0.3% in November.

site_title: In-store pickup does not save US shoppers much time: study
summary: A study by StellaService found that in-store pickup for online purchases at US retailers like Target and Toys 'R Us saves shoppers an average of just 96 seconds compared to searching for items on their own. Shoppers spent an average of 5 minutes and 24 seconds in stores when trying to pick up their online orders, with some retailers having no uniform approach to the service. The study suggests that in-store pickup is not significantly time-saving, despite retailers investing tens of millions of dollars in the initiative.

images.alt_text: Major US retailers including Target Corp and Toys 'R Us have begun allowing shoppers to collect online purchases at their brick-and-mortar stores, but a study shows the option often saves little, if any, time over in-store shopping.

site_title: As oil falls, Russia choked by military, social spending
summary: Russian authorities face unpalatable options to keep the economy afloat amid a crisis brought on by diving oil markets and Western sanctions. The government must limit military spending to prevent a state deficit from running out of control, or risk raising taxes, increasing the pension age, or printing money. Without radical action, officials fear a deficit of 4 trillion roubles (US$71 billion) by 2016, and the Reserve Fund will be depleted within 18 months. Sanctions have deepened the problems, with foreign investment down sharply and privatisation plans on hold.

site_title: Update: Items resembling slide, plane door seen in AirAsia QZ8501 search
summary: AirAsia QZ8501, a plane carrying 162 people, disappeared over the Java Sea on Sunday. An aerial search has found items resembling an emergency slide, plane door, and other objects in the sea. Indonesian officials spotted 10 big objects and many more small white-coloured objects, 10km from the last known location of the plane. The cause of the disappearance remains unclear, with officials expressing hope that the found objects are from the plane. The search continues in waters around the islands of Bangka and Belitung.

site_title: Asia to test bond record again in 2015
summary: Asian countries are expected to issue a record-breaking amount of international bonds in 2015, with China alone potentially accounting for half of all Asia G3 volumes. Chinese companies such as Alibaba and Bank of China have driven the country's offshore bond issuance to nearly double to over $70 billion this year, with more issuers expected to follow in 2015. India and Indonesia are also forecast to increase their issuance, with Indian banks potentially raising AT1s offshore as early as the second quarter. Despite falling oil prices and global market volatility, bankers believe Asian credit profiles remain stronger, driving investor appetite.

site_title: Red and white debris sighted off Kalimantan is probably from AirAsia jet: official
summary: Red and white debris spotted off Indonesia's Kalimantan coast is likely from the missing AirAsia jet, according to a transportation ministry official. The Airbus A320-200 carrying 162 people disappeared on Sunday while flying from Surabaya to Singapore. The debris, described as red and white, matches the aircraft's color scheme and is believed to be part of the body of the plane. The official is checking the debris to confirm its origin, but it is probable that it is from the missing jet.

site_title: Refine PIC in Budget 2015 to help SMEs restructure: Deloitte (Amended)
summary: Deloitte Singapore has proposed amendments to the 2015 Budget to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) restructure. The accounting firm recommends improving the Productivity & Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme by combining cash payouts across assessment years and increasing the payout cap. Additionally, Deloitte suggests introducing a new scheme to reward innovative activities not deemed research and development. The firm also proposes increasing the partial tax exemption from S$300,000 to S$600,000, reducing the effective tax rate for SMEs to 8.4%. This would help SMEs operate more effectively and drive growth for the Singapore economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.34% at the open on Tuesday, following a record close for the S&P 500 on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index added 79.95 points to 23,853.13. The rally comes as investors wind down for the end of the year, brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Equity analysts keep positive outlook for energy firms active in Asia
summary: Equity analysts remain optimistic about energy firms in Asia, despite oil prices halving this year and costs remaining high. Share prices of firms involved in Asian energy projects have dropped 10-50% since June, but 90% of analysts recommend a "strong buy", "buy", or "hold". Large energy firms like ExxonMobil and Chevron have more positive analyst views than smaller peers. Credit analysts, however, have lowered their outlook more aggressively, citing negative discretionary cash flows at companies involved in Southeast Asian LNG projects.

site_title: Seoul: Shares down 4.8% for the year; won in biggest annual fall since 2008
summary: South Korean shares ended the year with a 4.8% decline, marking the first annual decline since 2011. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) fell 0.64% to close at 1,915.59 points. The won depreciated 4% against the dollar, its largest annual fall since 2008, due to renewed weakness in the Japanese yen and concerns over market intervention. The market will close on Wednesday and Thursday before reopening on Friday, January 2.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened flat on Tuesday, with the FBMKLCI index rising 0.93 points to 1,769.34. A total of 157 million lots were traded, valued at RM$73.3 million, but losers outnumbered gainers 117 to 110.

site_title: Indonesian TV shows objects in Java Sea, may be AirAsia jet debris
summary: Indonesian authorities have stepped up the search for an AirAsia plane carrying 162 people presumed to have crashed in the Java Sea. Television footage showed objects that could be debris from the jet, prompting the expansion of the search area. The search will be assisted by a US warship and smaller islands and coastal land on Indonesian Borneo. Authorities have not yet confirmed the plane's wreckage, but the search operation is ongoing.

images.alt_text: Countries around Asia on Tuesday stepped up the search for an AirAsia plane carrying 162 people that is presumed to have crashed in shallow waters off Indonesia, as television showed pictures of objects that could be debris from the jet.

site_title: AirAsia disappearance fuels calls for real-time tracking
summary: AirAsia disappearance fuels calls for real-time tracking of aircraft. The incident, similar to Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, has prompted industry insiders to prioritize satellite tracking and live-streaming of black box data. The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) has agreed to mandate real-time tracking following the 370 incident, but the call for action has become more insistent with another passenger plane lost. Industry experts emphasize the need for real-time tracking to improve safety and prevent similar incidents.

site_title: Lorenzo proposes S$9.1 million rights issue, negotiates JV with acquisition party
summary: LORENZO International proposes a S$9.1 million rights issue, offering up to 130 million new shares at S$0.07 each. The company also negotiates a S$124 million joint venture with Gene ID Party, a clinical laboratory specializing in DNA sequencing. Lorenzo will contribute up to S$24 million, with Gene ID Party contributing laboratory services and an imaging center in Singapore. The joint venture aims to establish an Asia-wide rights to Gene ID.

site_title: Items resembling slide, plane door seen in AirAsia search
summary: Indonesian authorities have spotted items resembling an emergency slide, plane door, and other objects during an aerial search for the missing AirAsia plane QZ8501. The items were seen during a search flight, and officials reported spotting about 10 large objects and many more small white-colored objects. The search operation is ongoing, with the goal of locating the missing aircraft, which was carrying 162 people.

site_title: Italian navy says ten dead in ferry fire disaster
summary: The Italian navy reported that the death toll from a fire on board the car ferry Norman Atlantic has risen to ten. The updated figure follows an announcement that over 40 unaccounted passengers were on the boat, with uncertainty surrounding the accuracy of the manifest lists.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ASTI Holdings, KrisEnergy, Lian Beng, KSH, KOP
summary: ASTI Holdings sold its 24.23% stake in APSI Group for S$8.9 million. KrisEnergy received approval from the Indonesian government to develop the Lengo gas field in offshore East Java. Lian Beng Group, KSH Holdings, KOP, and Centurion Global sold their shareholdings in Epic Land for S$16.7 million.

site_title: Indonesia expands search for missing AirAsia jet, U.S. sends warship
summary: Indonesia has expanded the search for the missing AirAsia jet carrying 162 people, presumed to have crashed in shallow waters off the Indonesian coast. The US has sent a warship, the USS Sampson, to assist in the search. The search area has been expanded to 10,000 square nautical miles, and officials are scouring islands and land in the area. No confirmed signs of wreckage have been found, and the incident remains an unexplained accident. The plane, an Airbus A320-200, lost radar contact in poor weather on Sunday, and investigators are examining passenger and crew lists for clues.

site_title: Japan ruling coalition pledges corporate tax cuts: plan draft
summary: Japan's ruling coalition has approved a tax reform plan that cuts the corporate tax rate from 34.6% to 32.1% effective April, aiming to boost profitability and economic growth. The plan also ponders further reductions to below 30% in coming years. This move follows a US$29 billion stimulus package and aims to encourage companies to raise wages, stimulating consumer spending. The plan is part of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" stimulus policies, which have been bolstered by his ruling coalition's majority in snap elections.

site_title: Singapore to adopt Euro VI emission standard for new diesel vehicles from 2018
summary: Singapore to adopt Euro VI emission standard for new diesel vehicles starting from 2018, set by the European Union, to reduce fine particulate matter and nitrogen oxide emissions. The National Environment Agency has given the motoring industry sufficient lead time to adapt, consulting since 2014. This move aims to improve air quality and public health.

site_title: Asian shares slip, euro hit by Greece fears
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday, following a previous day's gains, due to concerns over Greece's economic crisis and its potential impact on the eurozone. The euro fell against the dollar, reaching levels not seen since 2012. The S&P 500 marked a record close, while oil prices remained near five-year lows. Analysts attributed the sell-off to thin volumes and worries about global economic growth. Greek Prime Minister Antonio Samaras announced a general election for January 25, raising concerns about the Syriza party's potential to roll back austerity measures, further weakening the eurozone economy.

site_title: S.Korea Nov factory output rise most in 4 months vs Oct
summary: South Korea's industrial output rose 1.3% in November, the largest increase in four months, beating market expectations. This follows a revised 1.7% fall in October. On a year-on-year basis, output slipped 3.4% in November. The service sector also saw a 0.3% decline in November, after a 0.8% rise in October. The data suggests a slight improvement in the country's manufacturing sector, but overall output remains down from the previous year.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.20% lower on the final day of 2014 trading, falling 35.33 points to 17,694.51. Japanese shares declined on Monday due to concerns over a possible Ebola virus outbreak in Tokyo. The market is expected to close the year with a lower tone, following a 0.20% drop on Monday.

site_title: Second ex-president of ST Marine charged with graft
summary: A second ex-president of Singapore Technologies Marine Ltd (ST Marine) has been charged with graft. See Leong Teck, 64, faces seven counts under the Prevention of Corruption Act for conspiring with four former colleagues to bribe agents of ST Marine's customers between 2004 and 2010. The bribes amount to over S$556,000. This is part of a corruption scandal that has implicated six former high-level executives, including Mok Kim Whang, Patrick Lee Swee Ching, and Ong Teck Liam.

site_title: Major organisational changes for ECB in 2015
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) will undergo significant changes in 2015, including a new voting system and policy meeting schedule. With Lithuania joining the eurozone, the council will adopt a rotating vote system, where the five largest economies will share four votes and the remaining 14 countries will share 11 votes. The governing council will also meet every six weeks, starting from January 1. Additionally, the ECB will publish minutes of its closed-door debates to increase transparency, and its new headquarters in Frankfurt will be officially inaugurated on March 18.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index up 0.72 points to 3,367.50. The market saw 111 million shares traded at S$82 million, with 85 gainers and 62 losers. This is part of a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, following recent positive sentiments despite US trade uncertainty.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE share prices opened flat on Tuesday with the Straits Times Index up 0.72 points to 3,367.50.

site_title: US fines Japanese shipper NYK for price fixing
summary: The US Department of Justice fined Japanese shipping company NYK $59.4 million for conspiring with other companies to fix the prices of transporting cars to and from the US from 1997-2012. NYK agreed to plead guilty to a felony charge and pay the fine, following similar pleas from two other unnamed companies. The Justice Department aims to restore competition in the ocean shipping industry to benefit US consumers, with an ongoing investigation.

site_title: Singapore Q4 annual GDP growth seen slowing to 2%: Reuters poll
summary: Singapore's annual economic growth is expected to slow to 2.0% in the fourth quarter, according to a Reuters poll. Manufacturing output in November fell 2.8% from a year ago, the largest year-on-year decline since June 2013. The slowdown is attributed to an uneven global recovery and lacklustre exports, as well as the government's push to reduce reliance on overseas workers, leading to a tight labour market and wage pressures. The advance estimate of fourth-quarter GDP will be released on January 2.

site_title: ASTI sells stake in semicon packaging technology firm for S$8.9 million
summary: ASTI Holdings, a semiconductor-equipment maker, sold its 24.23% stake in APSI Group for S$8.9 million. APSI Group, a packaging technology firm, is controlled by J C Investment, which holds 53.73% of the company. The sale is expected to be completed by February 27, 2015, and the proceeds will be used for general working capital purposes.

site_title: Oil trades near five-year low
summary: Oil prices traded near five-year lows on December 30, 2014, due to rising US production and a global supply glut. West Texas Intermediate fell to $53.12 and Brent crude to $57.33. Analysts predict further bearishness in the market, citing concerns about US production and potential downward pressure from a Greek political crisis and poor economic data. Oil has shed about half its value since June, attributed to slowing growth in China and emerging-market economies.

images.alt_text: Oil prices traded near five-year lows in thin year-end trade Tuesday, as analysts predicted further bearishness in the market owing to rising US production despite a global supply glut.

site_title: SP Services lowers electricity tariffs in Singapore for Q1 2015
summary: SP Services in Singapore lowered electricity tariffs for Q1 2015, with an average decrease of 8% or 1.99 Singapore cents per kWh, primarily due to a 16.4% drop in fuel costs. The new tariff for households will be 23.29 cents per kWh, resulting in a S$7.93 decrease in the average monthly electricity bill for four-room HDB flats. The tariff reduction is based on quarterly reviews by SP Services in accordance with guidelines set by the Energy Market Authority.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

SP Services said on Tuesday that electricity tariffs for the period from Jan 1 to March 31, 2015, will decrease by an average of 8 per cent, or 1.99 Singapore cents per kWh, compared to the previous quarter.

site_title: U.S. suspects North Korea had help attacking Sony Pictures: source
summary: US investigators believe North Korea likely hired outside hackers to help with the massive cyberattack on Sony Pictures, due to the company's lack of capability to conduct the sophisticated campaign alone. The FBI still stands by its statement that North Korea is responsible for the attack, but some security experts question this assertion, suggesting alternative theories such as Russian involvement or a Sony insider. North Korea has denied responsibility and vowed retaliation if the US takes action.

site_title: Australia: Weak commodities pummel shares
summary: Australia's shares retreated 0.4% on Tuesday due to weak commodity prices, with iron ore and oil tumbling 50% and 5-year lows respectively. Miners Fortescue Metals Group, BHP Billiton, and Rio Tinto fell over 1%. Financials, however, remained stable, with the "Big Four" banks rising 0.2%. New Zealand's NZX50 index reached a lifetime high, driven by Diligent's 6% surge.

images.alt_text: Australian shares retreated on Tuesday as commodity prices fell, while New Zealand stocks set a fresh record high.

site_title: Putin not "so smart", says Obama
summary: US President Barack Obama says Russian President Vladimir Putin is not as "smart" as previously thought, as sanctions against Russia for its actions in Ukraine prove successful. The sanctions, combined with declining oil prices, have validated the US-led approach and shown the Russian economy's vulnerability. Obama attributes Russia's economic struggles to its reliance on oil, whereas the US has a dynamic and vital economy.

site_title: 'Grexit' spectre returns, but eurozone safer: analysts
summary: Greece's decision to hold early elections has reignited fears of a possible "Grexit," but analysts say the eurozone is safer due to steps taken after the 2012 financial crisis. The uncertainty may boost anti-austerity parties across Europe, including in Spain, and pose a risk of political contagion. However, the European Union's 500 billion firewall and the European Central Bank's efforts to contain the crisis reduce the risk of a Greek exit spreading to the rest of the eurozone. Analysts caution that a Greek exit could still have broader geopolitical implications.

site_title: Critics ask how AirAsia jetliner went missing in age of GPS
summary: AirAsia Flight QZ8501, carrying 162 people, went missing in the Java Sea on December 28, 2014, despite the presence of satellites and webcams monitoring society. The aircraft was equipped with a flight-tracking system, but rescuers were unable to locate wreckage for two days. Critics blame the lack of full deployment of tracking systems, citing industry reluctance to incur costs and disagreements over standards. Advocacy groups call for regulators to require better tracking, with some predicting a solution may take at least a decade.

site_title: India's Modi says will change rules, laws for manufacturing
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced plans to change rules and laws to speed up manufacturing under the "Make in India" program, despite opposition from politicians. The government passed an emergency executive order to ease land acquisition rules, a move aimed at addressing delays in industrial projects worth up to $300 billion. Modi vowed to change the government's culture from "ABCD" to "ROAD," emphasizing responsibility, ownership, and accountability. This move aims to improve India's ranking in the World Bank's ease of doing business rankings, currently at 142.

site_title: South Korea Nov current account surplus at 7-mth high
summary: South Korea's current account surplus reached a seven-month high of $9.73 billion in November, driven by a 0.8% increase in exports to $49.60 billion and a 1.6% decline in imports to $41.19 billion. The goods account surplus expanded to $8.41 billion, while the financial account saw a net outflow of $9.92 billion. This is the largest surplus since April, when it reached a record high of $9.81 billion.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit lost S$3.3m in property deal
summary: Parkway Life Reit has reportedly lost S$3.3 million in a property deal after selling seven nursing homes in Japan for S$88.3 million. However, a closer examination of the sale price reveals that the actual cost of the nursing homes, adjusted for depreciation, was S$91.6 million. This discrepancy arises from the yen's depreciation against the Singapore dollar since the nursing homes were purchased between 2009 and 2012.

site_title: Oil prices fall more than US$1, dropping to five-year lows
summary: Crude oil prices dropped more than $1 a barrel, reaching five-year lows, as fears of global oversupply outweighed concerns about output curtailment from Opec producers. The global benchmark Brent crude settled at $57.88, down $1.57, while US crude settled at $53.61, down $1.12. The market's concerns about oversupply were reinforced by the damage to Libya's oil infrastructure, with oil production expected to remain robust despite a dip in US drilling rigs.

site_title: S Korea banks to gain from move to ease regulation
summary: South Korea's banks are poised to benefit from a move to ease heavy-handed regulation, which has limited their ability to charge rates and offer products based on market demand. The current regulatory environment has hindered banks' ability to adapt to a slowing economy and low interest rates, leading to poor returns on equity. The new head of the Financial Supervisory Service has pledged to consider ways to give banks more freedom to operate, potentially leading to increased competitiveness and profitability.

site_title: China looking at deal with US to recover ill-gotten assets
summary: China is reportedly negotiating a deal with the US to recover ill-gotten assets seized by corrupt officials abroad. The agreement, part of China's anti-graft efforts, aims to target assets in the US, Canada, and Australia, where corrupt officials have hidden their illicit gains. China's central bank is in talks with the US Treasury Department's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, while similar deals are being finalized with Canada and Australia. The agreement would allow China to share intelligence and coordinate investigations with US and Australian authorities to freeze and confiscate assets.

site_title: Pinterest to start selling advertisements on Jan 1
summary: Pinterest plans to start selling advertisements on its site starting January 1, marking the company's first major step towards building a scalable business. The ads, called Promoted Pins, will be similar in style to existing content and will be targeted to users based on their interests, location, and other factors. Early results show that 30% more users will see the ads after they are shared by others. This move aims to compete with major platforms like Google, Twitter, and Facebook, and Pinterest believes its unique service, which focuses on users' aspirations and interests, will set it apart.

site_title: City fears home price rise as Google plans campus
summary: Google plans to build a four-acre campus in Boulder, Colorado, which could quintuple its local workforce to 1,500 people. The move has sparked concerns among locals that it will drive up housing prices, pricing out lower and middle-income residents, and alter the city's character. While Google has offered benefits such as bike and pedestrian paths, public transit access, and local food sourcing, some residents fear the company's campus will create a "dead zone" for pedestrian and retail activity, ultimately changing the city's feel.

site_title: Britain eyed China trade after Hong Kong deal: files
summary: Britain sought stronger economic ties with China before the 1984 agreement that would hand Hong Kong to China, according to secret documents released by the National Archives in London. Officials discussed how to make the case for British business in China and assured China's leader Deng Xiaoping that the UK would not exploit Hong Kong's interests. The Joint Declaration was signed in December 1984, agreeing to hand Hong Kong to China in 1997. Business deals, including a nuclear power station development, were discussed during Thatcher's trip to Beijing. China's commitment to the agreement was reaffirmed by Deng.

site_title: Greek move to hold elections hurts euro
summary: Greece's move to hold new parliamentary elections sent the euro to a fresh multi-year low against the dollar, as concerns spread of a possible poll victory by the leftist Syriza party. The euro dropped to $1.2153, its lowest level since mid-2012, amidst worries of a possible roll back of austerity measures. Market analysts predict a 30% risk of a new deep crisis in Greece, but believe it would not have a systemic impact on the eurozone economy. The dollar is expected to gain further this week if US consumer confidence and manufacturing readings come in strong.

site_title: Ebola returns to Europe with first case diagnosed in Britain
summary: A healthcare worker in Scotland, recently returned from Sierra Leone, was diagnosed with Ebola on Monday, marking the first case of the virus in Britain. The patient, a female health worker, is in a stable condition in hospital and is being treated for the highly infectious disease. All possible contacts are being investigated, but the risk to others is considered extremely low due to early diagnosis. The patient was screened before returning to Scotland and was not showing symptoms when she arrived.

images.alt_text: A healthcare worker recently back from Sierra Leone was diagnosed with Ebola on Monday by doctors in Scotland's largest city, the first diagnosis of the deadly virus in Britain during the current outbreak.

site_title: No respite for rand despite worst streak since 2001
summary: South Africa's rand is facing a fifth year of declines, its worst performance since the 2001 recession, due to budget and current account deficits, rising government debt, and periodic power shortages. The rand is also under pressure from a potential US interest rate hike and rising dollar value. Economists predict a 25 basis-point interest rate increase in September and another by the end of the year, with the currency forecast to weaken to 12 per dollar in the first quarter.

site_title: 'The Wolf of Wall Street' tops 2014 illegal downloads
summary: "The Wolf of Wall Street" was the most illegally downloaded film in 2014, with over 30 million pirated copies, followed closely by "Frozen" with 29.9 million downloads. Other popularly pirated films included "RoboCop," "Gravity," "Thor: The Dark World," and "12 Years a Slave." These figures were compiled by piracy tracker Excipio and reflect the most pirated movies of 2014, with a total of over 150 million downloads.

site_title: Indonesia asks for US help in missing jet search
summary: Indonesia has requested US assistance in searching for a missing AirAsia jetliner, QZ8501, which vanished over the Java Sea on Sunday with 162 people on board. The US State Department is reviewing the request, which could include military or other detection capabilities. No Americans were on the flight. Dozens of planes and ships are already searching for the plane, with Australia, Malaysia, and Singapore joining the Indonesia-led effort. Relatives of the passengers are anxiously awaiting news, amid fears the aircraft may have crashed into the sea.

site_title: Forecasters warn of disastrous year ahead for US government bonds
summary: US government bonds are expected to experience a disastrous year in 2015, with forecasters predicting a significant rise in Treasury yields. Analysts, including Chris Rupkey, expect 10-year yields to reach 3.4% by the end of 2015, with the median forecast calling for a 0.75 percentage point increase. This would be the most aggressive calls since 2009, when yields rose by over a percentage point. The strong US economy, low unemployment, and potential for a rate hike by the Fed have led to renewed confidence that Treasuries are due for a sell-off.

site_title: M1, Rakuten form e-commerce tie-up
summary: M1, a Singaporean telecommunications company, has formed a partnership with Rakuten Singapore to facilitate e-commerce for local businesses. As part of the collaboration, M1's corporate clients will receive a three-month subscription waiver for launching their e-commerce business on Rakuten's online marketplace. The partnership aims to enable local merchants to capitalize on Singapore's growing e-commerce market, which is expected to reach S$4.4 billion in 2015.

site_title: Canadian oil surge to US Gulf Coast puts Mexico on defensive
summary: Canada's heavy crude oil is surging to the US Gulf Coast, with the Seaway Twin pipeline set to double its shipments to 400,000 barrels per day starting in January. This influx of heavy Canadian crude is expected to put Mexico on the defensive, as state-owned Petroleos Mexicanos widens its discount for US buyers. US refineries, such as Valero Energy and Marathon Petroleum, are poised to gain from the Canadian supply, while Latin American countries may re-export their crudes to Europe if they can't find a home on the Gulf Coast.

site_title: Subway probes China reports of doctored labels
summary: Subway is investigating reports from China that workers at a Beijing outlet allegedly doctored food labels and used expired produce. The claims, made by Chinese media, suggest workers altered dates on meat, drink, and vegetable products to extend their use. A Subway spokeswoman in Shanghai confirmed the probe, but no further details were provided.

site_title: Seven dead as rescued passengers recount ordeal on blaze-hit ferry
summary: Seven people died in a fire on a Greek-Italian car ferry, Norman Atlantic, after it caught fire in the Adriatic Sea on Sunday. The ferry, carrying 478 passengers and crew, was rescued after a 24-hour evacuation operation. Survivors described a terrifying ordeal, citing panic and a lack of preparedness from the crew. An investigation has been launched to determine if negligence contributed to the disaster, with the Italian owner cooperating fully. The ship's steering system was damaged in the fire, causing it to drift in high seas before being towed to port.

site_title: Missing jet puts Indonesia aviation safety back in focus
summary: An Indonesia AirAsia passenger jet with 162 people on board is presumed to have crashed into the Java Sea, raising concerns over the country's aviation safety record. The incident puts renewed scrutiny on Indonesia's regulation of airlines, which remains on the European Union's aviation blacklist. Transport Minister Ignasius Jonan announced a review of Indonesia AirAsia's operations to ensure safety improvements. The disappearance comes at a sensitive time for Indonesia's aviation authorities, which are working to improve the country's safety reputation to match its growing airline industry.

site_title: Analysts still optimistic about Sony revival despite its troubles with The Interview
summary: Sony Corp has seen a 43% rally in shares despite forecasting a loss of 230 billion yen for the fiscal year ending March 2015. Analysts remain optimistic, with 65% having buy ratings, due to strong sales of the PlayStation 4 franchise, image sensors, and a weaker yen. The company's film business, however, has been marred by a hacking scandal and the release of the satirical film "The Interview." Analysts predict Sony's earnings will improve in the next fiscal year, with some forecasting net income of 201 billion yen by 2016.

site_title: India's banking system vulnerable to financial contagion
summary: India's banking system is vulnerable to financial contagion due to close ties between top five most connected lenders, which could lead to a 50% wipeout of Tier I capital in a severe stress scenario. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) warned of this risk in its semi-annual financial stability report, citing potential failure by a bank and its exposure to money markets. The RBI also highlighted risks from non-banking financial firms, known as shadow banking, worth $190 billion in India.

site_title: Snap poll in Greece after failure to choose president
summary: Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaras called for a snap poll on January 25, which could bring a radical anti-austerity party to power. The election follows parliament's failure for a third time to elect a president, further rattling global financial markets. Samaras believes voters will choose to stay on the path of fiscal reform, despite dire Greek finances and the potential for a new crisis. Stocks in Athens tumbled in response, with analysts warning of the makings of a new Greek crisis.

site_title: Completed shoebox units lead price falls this year
summary: Singapore's completed shoebox units, which are small apartments up to 506 sq ft, saw a 4.4% drop in price index from December 2013, according to the National University of Singapore's Nov flash estimate. This decline is expected to put pressure on rents and prices as more units are completed, with property consultants warning of increased competition for tenants and downward adjustments to attract or retain renters. The total stock of completed shoebox units is projected to increase to around 11,000 units by the end of 2015, further exacerbating the issue.

site_title: A sobering 2015 awaits Malaysia, post-annus horribilis
summary: Malaysia is expected to face a challenging 2015, following a disastrous 2014 marked by a missing AirAsia flight, oil price plunges, and severe floods. The country's economy, heavily reliant on oil revenue, is projected to suffer a fiscal deficit of 3.1-3.5% of GDP due to the drop in oil prices. However, the government can mitigate this by implementing cost-cutting measures, reconsidering fiscal policies, and leveraging new revenue streams, such as the upcoming goods and services tax.

site_title: Search efforts: S'pore extends more help
summary: Singapore has extended assistance to Indonesia's search efforts for the missing AirAsia Indonesia flight QZ8501, which went missing on December 28. The city-state has sent two teams of specialists and two sets of underwater locator beacon detectors to aid the search. AirAsia has also arranged for 11 next-of-kin to fly to Indonesia. Singapore's Air Force and Navy have joined the search operations, and the city-state has offered additional equipment. The incident is the latest tragedy for the aviation industry in 2014, which has claimed 762 lives in accidents.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Japanese firms' tight-fisted attitude on wages could backfire, say analysts
summary: Japanese firms are unlikely to raise basic wages next year, contradicting Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's pleas to boost consumption and combat deflation. According to a Reuters survey, only 9% of leading Japanese companies plan to increase wages, which would damage the Bank of Japan's policies and Abe's credibility. Analysts warn that this could lead to deep disappointment and betrayal among workers, while others predict an unprecedented merger wave as small firms struggle to retain staff due to labor shortages.

site_title: Surge in Vancouver's housing prices deters young professionals
summary: Vancouver's housing prices have surged nearly 30% in five years, making it difficult for young professionals to afford homes. The city's median detached home price has reached $2.6 million, forcing many to leave the city for nearby suburbs or other provinces. This trend is eroding Vancouver's working-age demographic and making it challenging for companies to attract and retain talent. Experts warn that the high cost of living is a major concern, particularly for those starting families, and could impact the city's economic growth.

site_title: Oscars prove a tender trap for some
summary: The Oscars have become a tender trap for some nominees, particularly those from diverse backgrounds who may not fit the typical Hollywood mold. While the Academy has made efforts to increase diversity among nominees, the film industry still struggles to provide opportunities for many performers. Talent is often prioritized over usefulness, and the Oscar spotlight can lead to a comedown in career prospects. Nominees have spoken about the pain of watching their careers stall after the awards season, with some finding success in TV work or independent films.

site_title: Uganda moves into the world of chocolate
summary: Uganda has entered the chocolate industry with startup Pink Food Industries, which produces products from locally grown cocoa. The company's executive director, Felix Okuye, says the reaction to the chocolate was overwhelmingly positive, with the farm manager's reaction described as "amazing." This marks a new venture for Uganda, as the country begins to capitalize on its cocoa production.

site_title: Ukraine adopts IMF-backed budget after lengthy debate
summary: Ukraine's Parliament adopted an IMF-backed austerity budget, increasing import prices and reducing social spending to balance the books. The budget, which was passed with a 4.15am vote, includes measures to boost employment and simplify life for small businesses, but has been met with criticism from the public. The budget aims to slash the budget deficit to 3.7% and kickstart growth in 2016, with the IMF approving a $17.1 billion two-year loan.

site_title: PM: Michael Fam a rare and selfless individual
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong paid tribute to late businessman Michael Fam, describing him as a "rare and selfless individual" who contributed to Singapore's development. Fam, who died at 87, held leadership positions in several companies and served in public roles, including chairman of the Mass Rapid Transit Corporation and the Housing and Development Board. Under his leadership, public housing doubled in stock and HDB improved its planning and design concepts.

site_title: Jamie Oliver said no to being a hobbit
summary: Jamie Oliver revealed on his show that he was offered to play a hobbit in the Lord of the Rings film in exchange for cooking director Peter Jackson a birthday meal. Oliver was working at the time and couldn't accept the offer. He jokingly expressed his desire to take the costume home and make love to his wife. Oliver declined the opportunity, prioritizing his work commitments.

site_title: Tax-time crunch: Tips to boost your tax savings
summary: As a sole proprietor in Singapore, business owners are considered a single entity for tax purposes, requiring additional taxes and reporting. They can claim tax deductions for qualifying business expenses, but must maintain accurate records and comply with tax reporting requirements. Key deductions include business travel expenses, professional fees, and interest on business loans used for business purposes. The Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme is also available, allowing businesses to claim enhanced tax deductions or cash payouts for qualifying activities. Self-employed individuals must file tax returns by April 15 and keep proper documentation to ensure compliance with the law.

site_title: No sign of plane after second day of search
summary: An AirAsia passenger jet with 162 people on board likely crashed into the Java Sea after failing to make contact with air traffic control during a routine flight from Surabaya, Indonesia to Singapore. Despite a massive search operation involving 15 ships and 30 aircraft from Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, and Australia, no signs of the plane have been found. The search area has been widened to over 11,000 square nautical miles, and authorities suspect the plane is underwater with no signal detected from the emergency transmitter.

site_title: Scrabbling for a place at the AIIB table
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) is facing challenges in its development due to fundamental differences in its governance structure, ownership, and role in the region. China, as the leading shareholder, has proposed a governance structure that may restrict the bank's ability to become a global multilateral development bank. The bank's president, Jin Liqun, has emphasized the importance of incorporating international "best practices" and "safeguards" into its projects, but critics argue that the bank's approach may undermine the effectiveness of its projects. China's financial independence and significant foreign exchange reserves have also raised concerns about the bank's ability to operate independently.

images.alt_text: A total of 21 countries have signed an MOU expressing interest in joining the AIIB. China has given others until the end of March 2015 to decide whether or not they wish to join.

site_title: Cyberattacks seen getting more sophisticated
summary: A recent string of high-profile cyberattacks, including a hacking incident on PlayStation and Xbox, has highlighted the growing sophistication of cyber threats. Hackers are expected to raise their game in 2015, with predicted methods including malvertising and Advanced Persistent Threats (APT). The rise of cloud computing, Big Data, and the Internet of Things (IoT) is also expected to increase the vulnerability of digital systems. Security experts warn that targeted attacks will become more frequent and lucrative, with hackers seeking sensitive information and financial gain.

images.alt_text: A Sony PlayStation 4 booth at the Paris Games Week in October. The online gaming sites of PlayStation and Microsoft's Xbox were hacked into on Dec 25. Usernames, passwords and card details were stolen.

site_title: Calibrating the US airport safety net every morning
summary: TSA officers at Reagan National Airport began preparing security lanes at 2:30am, a half-hour earlier than usual, to accommodate the expected 30,000 passengers on a busy Christmas Day. The team calibrates the equipment, including metal detectors and X-ray machines, using props such as a gun-shaped object and a leg brace filled with materials. The automatic target recognition machines and explosives trace detectors are also tested to ensure they are functioning properly. The checkpoint is staffed by nine officers per lane, and the first flight departs at 5:45am, with 897 more passengers to be screened before 6am.

site_title: Gmail blocked in China; critics blame Great Firewall
summary: Google's Gmail has been blocked in China, with anti-censorship advocates blaming the Great Firewall. The blockage, which began on Friday, has disrupted Gmail's traffic from China, according to Google's Transparency Report. The move is seen as an attempt to further eliminate Google's presence in China and weaken its market overseas. China maintains tight control over the internet, and the blockage is the latest in a series of disruptions to foreign online services like Google.

images.alt_text: GOOGLE Inc's Gmail has been blocked in China after months of disruptions to the world's biggest e-mail service, with anti-censorship advocates suggesting the Great Firewall was to blame.

site_title: America must rise from wars again
summary: The US, which emerged as a global economic power after World War I, must now confront new multiple hegemonies from rival world powers, including China and India. The Great War led to the US replacing London as the global financial capital, allowing the US to aggressively pursue global economic ambition through diplomatic and military interventions. However, US wars in Vietnam and Iraq caused significant economic losses, undermining the country's economic stability. President Woodrow Wilson's predictions of US leadership and direction after the war were largely correct, with the US becoming a dominant economic power by 1929.

images.alt_text: The Great War created an opportunity for the US to replace British domination in global finance and trade, and led to New York replacing London as the global financial capital.

site_title: Keppel among three O&M firms unveiling deals
summary: Three Singapore Exchange-listed offshore and marine (O&M) companies, Keppel Corporation, Nam Cheong, and Otto Marine, announced substantial deals despite declining oil prices. Keppel AmFELS won a US$100 million contract to build a land drilling rig, while Nam Cheong sold two vessels worth approximately US$45 million. Otto Marine's shipyard division sold an AHTS vessel for US$100 million. These deals demonstrate the sector's growth potential and resilience to the oil price rout.

site_title: India refiners enjoying a boom from oil price slump
summary: India's state-owned refiners, Indian Oil, Bharat Petroleum, and Hindustan Petroleum, have seen significant share gains due to the oil price slump, with shares increasing by 53-131% over the past year. The companies can now profit from fuel sales after the government deregulated the market, allowing them to sell petroleum products at market rates. This move has outpaced the rest of the industry, including China Petroleum & Chemical Corp and Phillips 66. However, some investors warn that the gains may be short-lived, as the companies' profits depend on government policy and oil prices may rise in the future.

site_title: Infratil, NZ fund buying RetireAustralia
summary: Infratil and New Zealand's sovereign wealth fund are buying retirement village operator RetireAustralia for A$640 million. The companies will each pay A$215 million for 50% stakes in the takeover consortium. The acquisition is driven by Australia's growing older population, with the number of people aged over 85 forecast to grow at 4.7% annually until 2044. RetireAustralia, the country's largest private retirement property company, operates 3,700 properties in 28 villages across New South Wales, Queensland, and South Australia.

site_title: Global investors losing confidence in Abenomics
summary: Global investors are losing confidence in Japan's Abenomics, with foreign investment in Japanese stocks down 94% this year, the lowest annual amount since the 2008 global financial crisis. The decline follows a record figure last year, after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's tax increase in April sent Japan into recession. Fund managers say Abe needs to enact structural changes to lure investors back, moving beyond short-term stimulus. Foreign investors are net sellers for a fourth straight year, while domestic policy changes are filling the gap with state and pension-fund cash.

site_title: Single-digit fall in HDB prices next year a good thing: Khaw
summary: Singapore's public housing resale prices are expected to experience a single-digit fall in 2015, considered manageable and a balance between affordability and preserving asset values. The Housing & Development Board (HDB) aims to launch 16,900 new flats next year, down from 22,400, to moderate price declines. The total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) framework, which caps borrowers' debt repayments at 60% of income, will remain unchanged. Some temporary property cooling measures may be lifted, but the review of loan-to-valuation limits will be considered based on market conditions.

site_title: Novo Nordisk board looking for new CEO
summary: Novo Nordisk's board is searching for a new CEO to replace Lars Rebien Soerensen, who led the Danish company to a strong stock market performance over 14 years. Soerensen, 60, will likely step down as soon as a new leader is identified, possibly as early as next year. The company promoted Kaare Schultz, chief operating officer, to president in January, which may signal a transition. Analysts say the change is a normal move and the company's strategy is not complicated, allowing for a smooth transition.

site_title: Proposed disposal of Epic Land's subsidiary for S$16.7m
summary: Epic Land, a real estate investment holding consortium, has proposed disposing of its wholly owned subsidiary for S$16.7 million. The deal was made on a willing-buyer-willing-seller basis, considering the shareholders' loan, property costs, and market conditions. The disposal will not impact the net earnings per share or net tangible assets per share of the group for the current financial year. The subsidiary, Epic Land (19-2), was incorporated in May this year and has an unaudited net liability value of approximately S$86,593.46 as of December 26, 2014.

site_title: Oil price rises to US$60 on concern over Libya supply
summary: Brent crude oil prices rose to US$60 per barrel on Monday, driven by concerns over a disruption to Libya's oil exports due to a fire at one of its main terminals. The fire destroyed 800,000 barrels of crude, equivalent to two days of Libya's output. Despite the supply disruption, global supply remains abundant, keeping prices nearly 50% off their peak for the year. Analysts attribute the price increase to limited liquidity and sparse trade, with investors away for the festive period.

site_title: Russian banks eye syariah financing as crisis looms
summary: Russian banks are exploring syariah financing as the country faces a recession due to international sanctions and a slump in oil prices. Vnesheconombank, Russia's state development bank, is seeking advice on selling its first Islamic bonds. The move comes as the nation's currency weakened to an all-time low and banks face high interest rates. The central bank is considering legislation for Islamic finance, and lawmakers have allowed the Deposit Insurance Agency to buy stakes in banks to keep the system stable. Russia's economy is expected to contract next year, with growth unlikely for four consecutive quarters.

site_title: New beginnings for Yale's iconic library, thanks to US$20m donation
summary: Yale University's iconic Sterling Memorial Library has undergone a $20 million restoration, thanks to a donation from Richard Gilder. The renovation transformed the entrance hall, known as the nave, into a popular study lounge, complete with stained-glass ceilings, gilded details, and comfortable seating areas. The changes aimed to create a sense of belonging among students, rather than a traditional cathedral. The library's original liturgical elements, such as confessionals and a circulation desk resembling an altar, have largely been lost, but their symbolic significance remains.

site_title: Advertisers give BT website top marks
summary: Advertisers rank BT website as top business and finance site, beating The Edge Media Group's site. The Business Times website was redesigned with a responsive layout, making it easily readable on various devices. Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) owns The Business Times and saw its other websites perform well in the survey, with AsiaOne ranking first in the news category and Channel NewsAsia ranking second. The rankings are based on a survey of 700 advertising professionals polled by Marketing's research arm.

site_title: Navigating the franchise roadmap to take Singapore brands overseas
summary: Singaporean franchises are expanding globally, with companies like Dapur Penyet successfully franchising their brands in countries such as Brunei, Indonesia, and Malaysia. To navigate international franchising, businesses must choose the right franchise model, considering factors like market stability, regulatory requirements, and the ability to protect intellectual property rights. A master franchise model is often effective, but careful screening of franchisees is crucial to mitigate risks in unfamiliar environments. Understanding the local business environment and adapting to local regulations are key to achieving success in international franchising.

site_title: Italy coastguard says stricken ferry now evacuated, death toll 7
summary: A ferry caught fire off Greece's coast, killing 7 people. The Norman Atlantic, carrying 478 passengers and 200 vehicles, was chartered by Anek Lines. Italian and Greek helicopter crews airlifted passengers since Sunday afternoon. The Italian captain was the last to leave the ship. The evacuation is now complete, with two more corpses found.

site_title: Japanese banks face different kind of stress test
summary: Japanese banks are facing a unique stress test due to ultra-low interest rates, which may be stifling smaller banks' ability to earn. The Financial Services Agency (FSA) is conducting the test, concerned that regional lenders are struggling with low deposit rates and shrinking loan demand. This is a result of the Bank of Japan's monetary stimulus, which has kept interest rates near a record low. The FSA is urging regional banks to consolidate or seek customers abroad, with some banks considering mergers to spur consolidation.

site_title: India approves emergency orders to ease land acquisition rules
summary: The Indian government passed an ordinance to ease land acquisition rules, allowing projects worth nearly $300 billion to move forward. The ordinance relaxes requirements for land acquisition, allowing projects in sectors such as power, housing, and defense to bypass social impact studies and public hearings. However, compensation to landholders will remain at four times the market price. The move aims to kick-start stalled projects, but analysts warn that reform through ordinances may not be perceived as a stable solution by investors seeking secure property rights.

site_title: Xi calls for more 'guidance' on varsity campuses
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has called for more "ideological guidance" on university campuses, urging the study of Marxism, amid tightened controls on Western ideology. This move is part of Xi's conservative agenda, following increased restrictions on media, dissidents, and the internet. The comments come as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Mr Xi's conservative agenda rears its head amid tightening controls over the media and dissidents.

site_title: Russia economy in first contraction since 2009
summary: Russia's economy contracted 0.5% in November, its first decline since 2009, due to a sharp slowdown in manufacturing and investment amid the rouble's worst rout in a decade. The decline is attributed to low oil prices and sanctions, which have severely reduced borrowing abroad. The economy is expected to contract about 4% next year, with inflation likely to rise due to the rouble's weakness. The government has introduced informal capital controls and raised interest rates to stabilize the currency.

site_title: Global iron-ore slump fails to end glut as mines expand
summary: Global iron-ore prices have plummeted 65% from a record in 2011, but the glut persists due to expanded mine capacity. China, the world's second-largest economy, continues to absorb excess supply, leading to a projected 300 million-tonne surplus by 2017. Despite high costs, many producers remain profitable, with over 80% of global production generating income. Companies like Gina Rinehart's Roy Hill mine continue to expand, with plans to ship 55 million tonnes of ore annually, and some mines in China may "hang on" above $60 to preserve jobs.

site_title: China settlement of antitrust probe may be start of Qualcomm's woes
summary: China's settlement of Qualcomm's antitrust probe may intensify global scrutiny of the company's patent licensing business, potentially weakening its worldwide contracts with smartphone makers like Apple and Samsung. A record-breaking fine and changes to royalty rates in China could lead to increased pressure from regulators in Europe and the US. Qualcomm's highly profitable patent licensing business, which earned over half of its global revenue in China, could be impacted by the deal, and its relationships with major global players may be affected.

site_title: The allure of brands with an aura of authenticity
summary: US entrepreneurs are shifting focus from just selling products to selling values, with authenticity being a key factor. Companies like Zady and Tito's Handmade Vodka emphasize heritage, sincerity, and commitment to quality to create an aura of authenticity. Research shows that consumers value products made in original factories, with heritage playing a significant role in brand authenticity. Transparency in supply chains is also becoming increasingly important, with Patagonia's Footprint Chronicles serving as an example. The desire for authenticity is driving sales, with companies like Zady selling out of their first product run in just 24 hours.

site_title: AirAsia shares retreat as search for jet continues
summary: AirAsia shares fell 8.5% to RM2.69 as the search for its missing Airbus A320-200 continued after the crash of Flight QZ8501 into the Java Sea on Sunday, killing 162 people. Despite AirAsia's strong safety record, investors are spooked by the loss, which may lead to the airline offering lower fares. Analysts predict a knee-jerk reaction, but also see fundamentals remaining intact, with some maintaining target prices of RM3.25-3.47. The airline's cost base is expected to ease with lower jet fuel prices, but a weaker ringgit and US dollar will exert pressure on profitability.

site_title: Banks help STI make 8th straight gain
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 14.01 points to 3,367.69, its eighth consecutive gain, with banks and the Jardine group driving the increase. The index has risen 152 points or 4.7% in the past eight sessions and is up 6.3% for the year. Analysts predict the Asean4 markets, including Singapore, will underperform the Asia Pacific ex-Japan in 2015, with Morgan Stanley favoring the Philippines and Singapore.

site_title: Yet another Bush presidential candidate in 2016?
summary: A potential Jeb Bush candidacy in the 2016 US presidential election could lead to a rematch between a Clinton and a Bush, mirroring the 1992 presidential race. Jeb's background as a governor of Florida, a "purple" state, and his ability to appeal to diverse demographics, including Hispanic voters, make him a contender. However, his support for immigration reform and moderate positions may make it difficult for him to secure the Republican nomination. Other potential candidates, such as Mitt Romney and Chris Christie, also have a chance but face their own challenges. The Republican establishment is considering Jeb as a potential candidate to counter Hillary Clinton's expected nomination.

site_title: Plan to develop former Clark Air Base draws interest from local, Asian developers
summary: The Philippines plans to develop the former Clark Air Base into an alternative urban center to alleviate congestion in Manila. Foreign developers, including Taiwan's Farglory Land Development Co and Japan's Sumitomo Corp, are showing interest in the project. The 9,450-hectare site will be developed into a mix of housing, shops, and manufacturing facilities, generating about $36 billion in economic activity over 30 years and creating one million jobs. Local developers such as Ayala Land Inc and Century Properties Group Inc are also in talks with the government.

site_title: German companies cancel, delay investments in Russia
summary: German companies are canceling and delaying investments in Russia due to the conflict in Ukraine, with over one-third of companies with operations in Russia likely to cancel investment projects. The conflict has led to increased hostility towards foreign investors, with Allianz stopping auto insurance sales in Russia and Fresenius canceling a joint venture. Exports to Russia have fallen 22% and Germany is expected to grow 1% in 2015, while Russia is forecast to suffer a recession. The uncertainty has complicated Chancellor Angela Merkel's efforts to use Germany's close ties with Russia as leverage to fashion a solution to the crisis.

site_title: Greece set for early election after failure to choose president
summary: Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaras called for an early election on January 25 after parliament failed to elect a president for the third time, potentially bringing a radical anti-austerity party to power. The announcement led to a 11% drop in Greek stocks, with fears of Syriza's economic reforms undoing Greece's economic progress. The European Union and International Monetary Fund have overseen massive bailouts worth €240 billion, but the economy still struggles to recover after six years of contraction.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Parkway Life Reit divested seven Japanese nursing homes for S$88.3 million, expecting a gain of S$12.3 million. This sale will be used for further yield-accretive acquisitions. CIMB Research maintains an Add rating, expecting the divestment to be a temporary drop in FY15-16 DPU and target price. Viva Industrial Trust is seen as attractive with a high yield and potential for asset enhancement. Singapore Airlines' joint venture Vistara is expected to incur significant costs, likely leading to a net loss for the first year of operations.

site_title: S Korea Nov department store sales fall most in two years
summary: South Korea's top department store sales plummeted 6.5% in November, the largest decline in nearly two years, according to official data. This marks the third consecutive month of sales drops, raising concerns about the country's economy. Quarterly economic growth quickened to 0.9% in July-September, but the decline in department store sales adds to doubts about growth prospects. The decline in sales also affects major discount store chains, which saw a 4.7% drop in November.

site_title: Billionaire investor Yuri Milner sees Xiaomi reaching US$100b
summary: Billionaire investor Yuri Milner predicts Xiaomi's valuation to reach $100 billion, citing the company's rapid growth and potential to rival Facebook and Alibaba. Xiaomi's latest $1.1 billion funding round valued the company at $45 billion, with Milner citing the company's "unprecedented speed of growth" and "significant potential" to become a global consumer brand. The company plans to expand into new markets and unveil new products, including a flagship product, in the coming months.

site_title: SGX to upgrade derivatives trading platform
summary: SGX, Singapore's stock exchange, plans to upgrade its derivatives trading and clearing platforms to accommodate growing demand. The upgraded platforms, SGX Titan, will utilize Nasdaq technology and strengthen risk controls and system safeguards. The rollout is expected by the end of 2016. Following recent market disruptions, SGX aims to provide better solutions to meet evolving needs. The upgrades follow a partnership with Nasdaq Technology to support and maintain the systems.

site_title: SMEs see lower growth momentum in H1 2015
summary: Singaporean SMEs have reported lower growth momentum in the first half of 2015, with the construction sector experiencing the largest decline. The SBF-DP SME Index fell to 54.4 from 55.5, indicating a more conservative outlook. This drop is attributed to a score of 54.2 in the construction/engineering sector, down from 56.0 previously, as confidence in this sector is at its lowest.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Stop tightening the screws
summary: The US economy has seen a recent improvement, contrary to the narrative that President Obama's policies were causing a downturn. The private sector has added 6.7 million jobs since his presidency, while corporate profits and stock prices have soared. However, the alleged faults of "Obamanomics" were not due to the pain in the economy, but rather from public-sector austerity. The easing of this austerity is now allowing the economy to recover. The author is optimistic about 2015 and beyond, as long as the US avoids further self-inflicted damage.

site_title: Marine firm penalised for replacing local with foreign workers
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Manpower has penalized Prime Gold International Pte Ltd for retrenching Singaporean workers and replacing them with foreign employees. As a result, the company will be banned from hiring new foreign employees on all types of employment passes for two years. This marks the first time the ministry has taken such action against a Singapore company.

site_title: Indonesia fears missing jet 'at bottom of sea'
summary: A missing AirAsia plane with 162 people on board is feared to be at the bottom of the sea in the Java Sea. The Airbus A320-200 lost contact on Sunday while flying from Surabaya to Singapore due to stormy weather. International search planes and ships, including those from Australia, Singapore, and Malaysia, are scouring the area for possible clues. Indonesian officials believe the plane is likely at the bottom of the sea, with an object spotted at sea not from the plane. Relatives of the passengers are anxiously waiting for news, while the government vows not to give up the search.

site_title: US financial startups aim to court anti-finance crowd
summary: US financial startups aim to disrupt the traditional brokerage industry by offering fee-free or low-cost services to younger and middle-class Americans. Aspiration, a wealth manager, and Robinhood, a brokerage firm, are among the new entrants that have raised millions of dollars from venture capitalists. These startups aim to challenge the Wall Street establishment and capitalize on the public's distrust of traditional financial institutions. However, their viability is uncertain, and some analysts question whether they can turn a profit without sacrificing quality of service.

images.alt_text: "There's room for an investment firm with a conscience, at a time when Wall Street is facing this enormous level of distrust," said Aspiration's Mr Cherny.

site_title: Greece set for early elections after failure to choose president
summary: Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaras called for an early election on January 25 after parliament failed to elect a president for the third time, with radical anti-austerity party Syriza likely to gain power. The election could further destabilize Greece's economy and financial markets, which have struggled to recover from a debt crisis. European leaders have warned against abandoning economic reforms, while Syriza's leader Alexis Tsipras vowed to end austerity measures.

site_title: AirAsia has little margin for error in crisis over missing jet
summary: AirAsia faces significant challenges after its Indonesia AirAsia flight with 162 on board went missing, presumed crashed off the Indonesian coast. The airline operates on thin margins, with affiliates in Thailand and the Philippines posting losses, and its Indonesian unit barely breaking even. A decline in passenger traffic could result in a 13% reduction in AirAsia's 2015 net profit, according to analysts. The incident may deter short-term travel, but AirAsia's strong safety record and commercial offerings could limit the impact.

site_title: Taiwan pilots in fatal crash couldn't find runway: report
summary: A fatal TransAsia Airways Corp flight crashed on Taiwan's Penghu islands on July 23, killing 48 people. The pilots couldn't find the runway seconds before the crash, with the captain asking "Have you seen the runway?" and receiving a "no" response from the first officer. The aircraft hit houses near the runway, with 10 survivors. The accident report doesn't draw conclusions or assign blame, with a draft assessment expected in June and a final report in October. Weather conditions and air traffic control issues contributed to the crash.

site_title: Proposed disposal of Epic Land unit for S$16.7m
summary: Epic Land, a real estate investment holding consortium, has proposed disposing of its unit for S$16.7 million. The sale and purchase agreement was executed by Lian Beng Group, KSH Holdings, KOP, and Centurion Global. The disposal comes less than eight months after Epic Land's incorporation, with no valuation commissioned. As of Dec 26, 2014, Epic Land's unaudited net liability value was approximately S$86,593.46. The proposed disposal is expected to have no material impact on the group's net earnings per share or net tangible assets per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Update: Oil rises to US$60 per barrel, Libya fire supports
summary: Brent crude oil rose to $60 per barrel, supported by concerns over Libya's oil output, which has been reduced to 128,000 barrels a day due to fighting and port blockades. Despite this, a global supply glut kept prices nearly 50% off their year-high. Oil prices also received support from China and Japan's plans to boost their economies.

site_title: American Apparel urged to "explore options"
summary: American Apparel's board received a letter from British buyout firm Lion Capital urging the company to explore strategic options, including a sale. Lion Capital, which has warrants to purchase up to 12% of the retailer, also nominated Lyndon Lea, one of its founders, to the board of directors. The move comes as American Apparel faces debt issues and investigations into former CEO Dov Charney's conduct. The company's board is reviewing the letter and considering forming a special committee to evaluate options.

site_title: EU says Greece must commit to Europe, back reforms
summary: European Economic Affairs Commissioner Pierre Moscovici stated that Greece must commit to Europe and support growth-friendly reforms to thrive in the euro area. This comes after Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaras announced an early general election following parliament's rejection of his candidate for president, which may throw the country's international bailout into doubt.

site_title: Euro zone rattled as Greece braces for elections
summary: Greece's parliament rejected the government's presidential candidate, forcing Prime Minister Antonis Samaras to call a national election in late January or early February. The anti-EU/IMF bailout rival Syriza party is expected to win, leading to uncertainty about Greece's future in the euro zone. European markets tumbled, with stocks in Athens plummeting 11% and yields on Greek bonds spiking sharply. The euro remained relatively stable, while the dollar rose against the yen, amidst a global economic slowdown and other market fluctuations.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower after recent rally
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, following a recent rally that took major indexes to record highs. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.71 points, or 0.07%, to 18,041, while the S&P 500 lost 1.07 points, or 0.05%, to 2,087.7, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 5.21 points, or 0.11%, to 4,801.65. Investors found few reasons to push shares higher, despite some stocks in the healthcare and mining sectors performing well.

site_title: Euro holds ground near 28-month low vs US$
summary: The euro held steady near a 28-month low against the US dollar on Monday, despite renewed uncertainty in Greece following a failed attempt to elect a new president. Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaras proposed an early national election, which could lead to a government led by the leftist Syriza party, potentially derailing Greece's bailout program. The euro edged up 0.2% to trade at US$1.2200, while the safe-haven German equivalent hit a record low of 0.564%.

images.alt_text: The euro held its ground on Monday in the face of renewed nerves over Greece prompted by a failed attempt to elect a new president, leaving the country facing an early national election which could derail its bailout programme.

site_title: KrisEnergy gets nod for Indonesia gas project
summary: KrisEnergy, a Singapore-based oil and gas company, has received approval from the Indonesian government to develop the Lengo gas field in the Bulu production sharing contract. The project, which will produce approximately 70 million cubic feet of gas per day, is KrisEnergy's first as an operator in Indonesia. The company plans to pursue formal negotiations for gas sales agreements with potential offtakers before making a final investment decision. This development is expected to contribute to KrisEnergy's balanced mix of gas and oil production, with a focus on hedging against oil price volatility.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended higher on Monday, closing at 1,768.41 after adding 3.97 points. The index saw 1.25 billion lots valued at RM1.33 billion traded, with 343 gains and 376 losses.

site_title: Cosby team's strategy: Hush accusers, smear their reputation, blast the media
summary: Bill Cosby's defense team has employed a strategy of silencing accusers, smearing their reputations, and attacking the media, which may have contributed to the recent surge of accusations against him. The team has a history of using aggressive tactics, including threatening defamation lawsuits, spreading "damaging information" about accusers, and playing on the media's desire for sensational stories. Critics argue that this approach can be counterproductive, as it can further damage Cosby's reputation and undermine the credibility of his accusers. The team's strategy has been led by lawyers and agents who have a reputation for being ruthless in defending their clients.

images.alt_text: Ms Green watching via video link as her attorney speaks; she had filed a defamation suit against Cosby on Dec 10, saying that the denials by his team basically branded her a liar

site_title: Asia-pacific crude: Weak demand pressures market
summary: The Asia-Pacific crude market experienced pressure on Monday due to weak demand, with several cargoes from February being left overhanging the market. Refiners showed little interest in purchasing February barrels, with Petronas failing to award a tender and instead selling through private negotiations. The premium for Labuan, a Malaysian crude grade, fell to US$5 a barrel against dated Brent, down from US$5.50 last month. Brent crude prices remain stable at around US$60 a barrel, down 48% since June.

site_title: SingTel carrying out trial of Ericsson's Radio Dot System
summary: Singtel is conducting a trial of Ericsson's Radio Dot System at Changi Business Park to improve in-building mobile broadband experience in Singapore. The trial aims to extend SingTel's Long-Term Evolution (LTE) and 3G network coverage into enterprise buildings and public venues. The Radio Dot System delivers mobile broadband access with an antenna element, designed to suit various Singaporean buildings. The trial is part of Ericsson's efforts to address growing mobile data usage, with mobile data traffic expected to grow by a factor of 17 over the next five years.

site_title: Euro wobbles before Athens vote, Greek shares tumble
summary: Greek parliament prepares for a final round of presidential voting, which could lead to snap elections and potentially derail Greece's future in the euro if Prime Minister Antonis Samaras fails to secure enough support. European shares plummet 8% in Athens and the euro nears a two-year low against the dollar. Investors are uncertain about the outcome, which could impact the eurozone and global markets.

site_title: BT website tops advertiser poll in business and finance category
summary: The Business Times' website ranked as the top advertiser's preferred website in the business and finance category in a survey by Marketing magazine, which polled 700 industry professionals. SPH also took top positions in the news category and its publications in men, women, and technology categories. The Straits Times' website took third place in the news category, while AsiaOne ranked first.

site_title: In brief
summary: Hitachi Ltd plans to acquire Singapore engineering company Aqua Works and Engineering Pte Ltd for an undisclosed price. Aqua Works specializes in water-related installations and made S$9.07 million in sales in 2013. The acquisition aims to combine Aqua Works' water features with Hitachi's reverse osmosis membrane systems and leverage Aqua Works' customer base in South-east Asia. The purchase is expected to be completed by end-January 2015.

site_title: Michael Fam was a rare and selfless individual: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong described Michael Fam as a "rare and selfless individual" who contributed significantly to the country. Fam, who passed away at 87, held leadership positions in prominent companies such as F&N Group, SIA, and SPH. His commitment to public service was notable, and his legacy will be remembered.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: China's Shenzhen latest city to restrict car sales
summary: China's southern city of Shenzhen has restricted new car sales, capping the number at 100,000 per year. This move follows Shanghai and Beijing, and is part of a nationwide effort to combat smog and traffic congestion. The measure is expected to impact the already slowing Chinese auto market, putting pressure on carmakers like General Motors and Volkswagen to expand in western cities.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares rose on Monday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 14.01 points to 3,367.69. 890.7 million shares valued at S$579.7 million were traded, with 228 gains and 172 losses. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains, ahead of the release of GDP data.

site_title: Gallant Venture disposes of Starhome for US$20.5m
summary: Gallant Venture has disposed of its 100% equity interest in Starhome Limited to Segovia Global Limited for US$20.5 million. The disposal, performed through a subsidiary, will not significantly impact Gallant Venture's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the current financial year.
