Gallant Venture operates in four key business segments, with total assets of S$2.6 billion, and is majority-owned by Indonesia's Salim Group. The company's counter closed at S$0.245 after jumping 2.08% on the news.

site_title: Singapore's manpower ministry penalises firm for replacing local with foreign workers
summary: The Singaporean Ministry of Manpower has penalized Prime Gold International Pte Ltd for retrenching 13 local workers and replacing them with foreign workers, in violation of the Fair Consideration Framework. The company was found to have breached the framework despite claiming the retrenchments were due to job redundancy and poor work performance. Prime Gold's privileges to issue work passes have been curbed for two years. This is the first time the ministry has taken action against a company for discriminatory practices against local workers.

site_title: Update: China's Xiaomi raises US$1.1b from investors at US$45b valuation
summary: China's Xiaomi Inc has raised $1.1 billion in funding, valuing the company at $45 billion. Investors include All-Stars Investment, DST Global, and Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC. This round of funding solidifies Xiaomi's status as one of the world's most valuable private technology companies, surpassing Lenovo's market capitalization. Despite intellectual property challenges, Xiaomi's valuation reflects investors' confidence in its growth potential as a global powerhouse. The company has been investing in other manufacturers to build an ecosystem of Internet-connected devices.

site_title: Oil prices rise on violence in Libya
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia on Monday due to concerns about supply disruptions in Libya. Violence between forces loyal to the internationally recognized government and Islamist militias has affected crude oil flows, with oil production dropping to fewer than 350,000 barrels per day. The conflict, which began on December 13, has resulted in the destruction of seven oil storage tanks at the Al-Sidra export terminal. Analysts expect oil prices to remain range-bound ahead of the New Year holiday.

site_title: India clears order to ease land acquisitions in reforms push
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi has passed an executive order to ease land-acquisition rules for stalled projects worth over $300 billion, including power, housing, and defence sectors. The order exempts 80% of affected landowners from consent and social impact studies, but maintains four times market compensation for landholders. The move aims to kick-start stalled projects, with Finance Minister Arun Jaitley stating that governments must act with determination. Analysts see this as an important step to signal the government's commitment to reforms, but also note that ordinances may not provide secure property rights for investors.

site_title: Object spotted in sea not from AirAsia plane: Indonesian VP
summary: Indonesia's vice president, Jusuf Kalla, said an object spotted in the sea during a search for the missing AirAsia plane was not from the aircraft. The search, involving 15 ships and 30 aircraft, is now focused on a patch of oil spotted off Belitung island. The location is a shipping line, and authorities are investigating whether the oil is from the AirAsia plane or a vessel. Australia, Singapore, and Malaysia are assisting in the search, which is ongoing in bad weather.

images.alt_text: An object spotted during a sea search for an AirAsia plane was not from the aircraft, Indonesia's vice president said on Monday, after reports that an Australian surveillance aircraft had found something.

site_title: Family of 10 misses ill-fated AirAsia flight
summary: A family of 10 from Indonesia narrowly escaped when they arrived too late to catch AirAsia Flight QZ8501, which crashed shortly after take-off en route to Singapore on December 28, 2014. The family had been rescheduled to an earlier flight and arrived at the airport just as the news of the crash was being announced, leading them to cancel their flights. They expressed shock and relief at their close call, and Christianawati said she would switch to Garuda Indonesia due to shaken confidence in AirAsia.

site_title: Russian economy shrinks for first time since 2009
summary: Russia's economy shrank 0.5% in November for the first time since 2009, according to the government. The decline was attributed to a slowdown in sectors such as services, agriculture, and construction, exacerbated by sliding oil prices and Western sanctions over Ukraine. This marks a reversal of the country's economic growth trend, which had been steadily increasing since 2009.

images.alt_text: Russia's economy shrank in November for the first time in five years, the government said on Monday, as sliding oil prices and Western sanctions over Ukraine take their toll.

site_title: Indonesia says missing AirAsia plane could be at "bottom of sea"
summary: A missing AirAsia plane carrying 162 people is presumed to have crashed off the Indonesian coast, with authorities expecting it to be at the bottom of the sea. The plane, an Airbus A320-200, disappeared on Sunday after its pilot failed to get permission to fly higher to avoid bad weather. The Indonesian search and rescue agency has received radar data and is waiting for debris to be found before starting an investigation into the cause. The plane was traveling from Surabaya to Singapore with passengers from Indonesia, South Korea, Singapore, Malaysia, and Britain on board.

site_title: Oil rises to US$60 per barrel, Libya fire supports
summary: Oil prices rose to US$60 per barrel on Monday, driven by concerns about a fire at a Libyan export terminal that destroyed 800,000 barrels of crude. The incident reduced Libya's daily output, but the global supply glut kept prices nearly 50% off their peak for the year. Analysts say the tension in Libya is not enough to significantly impact oil prices, with the global supply overhang remaining a major factor.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.82% on Monday, following a record close on Wall Street and easing measures from Chinese authorities. The Hang Seng Index rose 423.84 points to 23,773.18 on HK$80.42 billion in turnover. Mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index added 0.33%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 1.46%. The gains followed a record close on Wall Street and are seen as a positive sign for the region's markets.

site_title: China offers to sign FTA with Bangladesh
summary: China has offered to sign a free trade agreement with Bangladesh to narrow the country's growing trade gap. The proposal was made during talks between Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi and Bangladeshi Foreign Minister Abul Hassan Mahmood Ali. The deal, if signed, could boost Bangladesh's garment exports to China, worth over $300 billion, and potentially "massively boost" the country's exports to the world's second-largest economy. Bangladesh is a signatory to several multilateral free trade agreements but has yet to sign a bilateral FTA.

site_title: Singapore's JTC launches industrial site at Tuas South Street 7 for sale
summary: Singapore's JTC Corporation has launched a 0.5 ha industrial site at Tuas South Street 7 for sale by public tender under the 2014 Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) Programme. The site, zoned for Business-2 development, has a minimum bid price of S$4.2 million and a tenure of 20 years 4 months. Industrialists can apply for the site before the tender closes on Feb 9, 2015.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Subway investigates China media reports of doctored expiry dates
summary: Subway is investigating reports from China that workers at a Beijing outlet allegedly doctored food labels and used produce beyond its expiry date. The incident, which was first reported by Chinese media, has raised concerns about food quality and safety in China's supply chains. Subway has sent teams to inspect its franchises and given staff training on food safety, but no conclusions have been reached. The incident highlights the challenges faced by firms in controlling food quality and safety in China, following previous scandals involving McDonald's and Yum Brands.

images.alt_text: US fast-food chain Subway is investigating media reports in China that workers at an outlet in Beijing doctored food labels and used produce beyond its expiry date, a Shanghai-based spokeswoman for the firm said on Monday.

site_title: AirAsia shares hit in Malaysia after jet loss
summary: AirAsia shares plummeted 8.50% in Kuala Lumpur after one of its jets, carrying 162 people, disappeared over the Java Sea. The incident, which is likely at the bottom of the sea, has not significantly impacted the airline's business model, according to analysts. Despite the loss, investor confidence in AirAsia is expected to return quickly, with the airline's CEO, Tony Fernandes, having successfully transformed the carrier into Asia's most successful budget airline. The incident is seen as having minimal impact on AirAsia's load factor and bottom line.

site_title: Another Malaysia-linked plane disappearance spooks air travellers
summary: A Malaysia-linked plane disappearance has sparked concerns among air travelers in the region, following a string of incidents involving Malaysian carriers. Flight QZ8501, operated by Indonesia AirAsia, vanished on Sunday with 162 people on board, presumed to have crashed at sea. The incident has further dented confidence in Malaysia's aviation industry, mirroring the earlier disappearance of MH370 and MH17. AirAsia shares plummeted 8.5% and Malaysia Airlines' passenger numbers dropped 14% year-on-year, raising concerns about the impact on the country's tourism industry.

site_title: Singapore ready to deploy specialists to assist in search of missing AirAsia plane
summary: Singapore has accepted Indonesia's request for assistance in locating the flight data recorders of the missing AirAsia plane QZ8501. Two teams of specialists from Singapore's Air Accident Investigation Bureau and their equipment, including underwater locator beacon detectors, are ready to be deployed pending Indonesian authorities' activation. This move comes after Indonesia accepted Singapore's offer of assistance, marking a significant step in the search and rescue efforts for the missing aircraft.

site_title: India banking system vulnerable to financial contagion: central bank
summary: India's banking system is vulnerable to financial contagion due to close ties between lenders, according to the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). A severe stress scenario could wipe out nearly 50% of Tier I capital in the banking system if trouble arises at one of the top five most connected lenders. The RBI also warns that non-banking financial firms (NBFC) pose a risk to the banking system, and promoters pledging company shares to get loans need closer examination. The RBI expects consumer price inflation to remain around 6% and the economy to grow 5.5% in the fiscal year ending March.

site_title: India's GDP growth expected to be "much better" in 2015/16: Jaitley
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley predicted the country's GDP growth to be "much better" in the 2015/16 fiscal year, surpassing the current year's growth of 5.5%. The country's economy has been recovering from its worst slowdown since the 1980s, with two consecutive years of below 5% growth.

site_title: SingTel, Ericsson in radio dot system trial for in-building mobile broadband coverage
summary: SingTel is conducting a trial of Ericsson's Radio Dot System to improve in-building mobile broadband coverage in Singapore. The trial, at Changi Business Park, aims to extend SingTel's Long-Term Evolution (LTE) and 3G network coverage into enterprise buildings and public places. The Radio Dot System features an antenna element that delivers mobile broadband access to users, promising to "vastly improve" the in-building mobile broadband experience.

site_title: China's Xiaomi raises US$1.1b from investors at US$45b valuation
summary: China's Xiaomi Inc has raised US$1.1 billion in funding at a valuation of US$45 billion, according to CEO Lei Jun. The investors include private equity funds and sovereign wealth funds such as All-Stars Investment, DST Global, and Singapore's GIC. This funding round is Xiaomi's latest in a series of investments that have helped the company become one of the world's fastest-growing smartphone makers. The valuation represents a significant increase from Xiaomi's previous valuation of US$10 billion in 2014.

site_title: Stakes high for Indonesia as aviation safety in spotlight again
summary: Indonesia is reeling from the disappearance of an Indonesia AirAsia passenger jet, which is presumed to have crashed into the Java Sea on a flight from Surabaya to Singapore. The incident puts scrutiny on the country's aviation authorities, which are already under pressure to improve Indonesia's safety reputation. A review of Indonesia AirAsia's operations has been announced, and the country is expected to lead the investigation into the disappearance. Despite recent improvements, Indonesia's air safety record remains patchy, with 13 serious incidents since 2010, including the fatal Adam Air Boeing 737-400 crash in 2007.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 0.50% down
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.50% lower on Monday, reversing early gains driven by a weaker yen and a record close on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index ended at 17,729.84, while the Topix index fell to 1,424.67.

site_title: Google's Gmail blocked in China, Great Firewall suspected
summary: Google's Gmail service was blocked in China after months of disruptions, with the Great Firewall suspected of being responsible. The blockage began on Friday and was still in effect on Monday, according to GreatFire.org, a China-based freedom of speech advocacy group. Google's Transparency Report showed a sharp drop-off in traffic to Gmail from China, and the service is now inaccessible to users. The blockage is seen as an attempt to further restrict Google's presence in China and weaken its market overseas.

site_title: Thai Nov factory output shrinks more than expected, drops for a 20th month
summary: Thai factory output declined 3.5% in November, marking the 20th consecutive month of decline, due to weak exports. Industrial goods, which account for two-thirds of total Thai exports, fell 14% from a year earlier. Exports dropped 1% in November, contradicting forecasts of a 3.6% gain. The central bank expects exports to contract 0.5% this year and only grow 1% in 2015, reducing Thailand's economic growth to 0.8% this year.

site_title: Allianz is lead reinsurer to missing AirAsia plane
summary: Allianz is the lead reinsurer for the missing AirAsia plane, with its division, Allianz Global Corporate & Specialty UK (AGCS), covering aviation hull and liability insurance. This is the same division that provided insurance for Malaysia Airlines after two of its aircrafts were lost earlier in the year. The AirAsia plane, carrying 162 people, is presumed to have crashed off the Indonesian coast.

site_title: Single-digit fall in Singapore HDB resale prices next year still manageable: Khaw Boon Wan
summary: Singapore's HDB resale prices are expected to fall by a single-digit amount next year, which Minister for National Development Khaw Boon Wan considers manageable and a "very good development." This comes after a 6.1% year-on-year decline in HDB resale prices as of Q3 2014. Khaw believes a soft downward adjustment is healthy and not painful, unlike drastic corrections which can be due to external events. He also hinted that some cooling measures are temporary, and the framework for debt servicing ratio is a good one.

site_title: M1 and Rakuten in e-commerce tie-up
summary: M1 and Rakuten Singapore have formed a tie-up, allowing M1's corporate clients to launch e-commerce businesses on Rakuten's online shopping marketplace with a three-month subscription waiver. The deal provides merchants with e-commerce consultants for online business strategy, implementation, sales, and marketing. This partnership aims to help companies capitalize on the growing demand for online shopping without significant investment in technical or human resources.

images.alt_text: AS online shopping booms, M1 and Rakuten Singapore are pairing up in a deal that is the first of its kind between the Japanese e-commerce firm and a local company.

site_title: SCCCI monitoring compliance costs weighing on Singapore SMEs
summary: The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce & Industry (SCCCI) is monitoring compliance costs affecting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Regulatory requirements, such as the proposed tobacco display ban and changes to the Singapore Civil Defence Force's permit policies, are adding to existing high business costs. The SCCCI has organized briefing sessions to inform its trade association members and affected businesses about these changes and potential implementation issues. The chamber is urging policymakers to consider the impact of compliance costs on SMEs.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall on ex-dividend; won flat
summary: South Korean shares fell 1% on Monday, closing at 1,927.86 points, as they went ex-dividend. The won remained nearly unchanged. Regional peers outperformed, and trading was thin as investors squared out positions ahead of the year-end.

site_title: Italy says 265 rescued from ferry, more than 200 still stranded
summary: Rescue teams in Italy have pulled 265 people from a fire-stricken ferry off the coast of Greece, with over 200 still stranded on board. The Norman Atlantic caught fire on Sunday while sailing from Greece to Italy, with one confirmed death and four reported injuries. A medical team and flight operator are on the vessel to assist the remaining passengers and crew. The rescue operation, coordinated from an Italian navy ship, has been slowed by bad weather and rough seas, with several passengers flown to southern Italy for treatment.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei reverses, drops over 1% on suspected Ebola case
summary: Japan's Nikkei average dropped over 1.5% on Monday after a man suspected of having contracted Ebola returned to the country. The benchmark fell to 17,525 points before rising slightly. Test results are expected on Tuesday, which would be the first diagnosis of Ebola in Japan. The decline follows a 0.4% gain in the morning session.

site_title: Thai Finance Ministry cuts 2014 GDP forecast to 1%
summary: Thailand's Finance Ministry has revised its 2014 GDP forecast to 1% growth, down from 1.4% in October. This is in line with the ministry's earlier prediction. For 2015, the ministry expects 4% growth, unchanged from the previous estimate. Exports are also expected to grow 3.5% next year, after a weak performance in 2014. The central bank had previously lowered its 2014 GDP forecast to 0.8% and 2015 estimate to 4.0%.

images.alt_text: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 1 per cent this year and exports should not contract, a senior official from the Finance Ministry said on Monday.

site_title: Australia: Shares rally to 7-week high, New Zealand hits fresh record
summary: Australian shares reached a 7-week high, rising 1.5% to 5,473.8 on the S&P/ASX 200 index, while New Zealand stocks set a fresh record high at 5,592.3 on the NZX 50 index. These gains come ahead of the 2014 year-end, with both countries' benchmarks poised for over 2% gains. The markets' resilience is attributed to the ongoing rally, despite global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Philippines posts Nov budget surplus, weak govt spending drags on economy
summary: The Philippines posted its fourth monthly budget surplus in November with 6.8 billion pesos (S$201 million), driven by weak government spending. Expenditures contracted 8% while revenue dropped 4%, indicating weak economic activity in the last quarter. This is a bad sign for the economy, which slowed dramatically in the third quarter due to lack of fiscal stimulus. The budget surplus is a concern for policymakers, highlighting the need for fiscal stimulus to boost economic growth.

site_title: Indonesian rescue agency says AirAsia plane believed to have crashed in sea
summary: An AirAsia plane carrying 162 people is believed to have crashed into the Java Sea after failing to gain permission to alter course to avoid a storm. The plane went missing on Sunday during a flight from Surabaya to Singapore. Indonesian search and rescue officials estimate the plane's likely location to be in the water, pending further evaluation.

site_title: Russian factory activity shrinks in Dec for first time in 6 months: PMI
summary: Russia's manufacturing sector shrank in December for the first time in six months, with the HSBC purchasing managers' index falling to 48.9, below the 50 mark. The sector was hurt by a decline in new orders and a rise in inflationary pressure due to the rouble's fall in value. Output prices rose at the fastest rate since 2003, and input prices rose at the strongest rate in 16 years. The decline is attributed to financing difficulties and doubts over the rouble's exchange rate, and inflation risks are expected to escalate in 2015.

site_title: Prices of small apartments in Singapore fall 1.9 per cent in November: NUS index
summary: Singapore's completed non-landed private homes saw a 0.3% dip in prices in November, according to the National University of Singapore's Overall Singapore Residential Price Index. The sub-index for Central Region fell 0.5%, while Non-Central Region remained flat. Small apartments islandwide declined 1.9%. The revised October index showed a 0.4% increase, with Central Region rising 0.5% and Non-Central Region edging up 0.4%.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

PRICES of completed non-landed private homes in Singapore dipped 0.3 per cent in November over October based on flash estimates from the National University of Singapore for its Overall Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI) released on Monday.

site_title: Missing AirAsia plane no MH370 mystery: Australian PM
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott says the disappearance of an AirAsia plane, MHQZ8501, is not a mystery like the disappearance of MH370, which vanished in 2014 with 239 people on board. The AirAsia plane was on a routine flight from Indonesia to Singapore when it disappeared in bad weather, killing all 162 people on board. Abbott notes the plane's route and weather conditions are different from MH370, and an intense search is underway in the Java Sea. Experts say it's unlikely the plane was hijacked, and Abbott calls for improved tracking systems to prevent similar incidents.

site_title: Singapore SMEs cite lower growth momentum for H1 2015
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) report a lower growth momentum and conservative outlook for the first half of 2015, citing weaker market sentiment and domestic pressures. The SBF-DP SME Index fell 2.0% to 54.4, indicating a positive outlook for the next six months. The index is based on 3,600 interviews with SME owners and managers, covering various sectors including business services, commerce, and manufacturing. This decline suggests a more cautious approach by SMEs amidst an uneven global economy.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Japan's regional banks face stress test for ultra-low rates
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency has begun stress tests on regional banks to assess their earnings under ultra-low interest rates. The tests aim to determine how much regional lenders' earnings would decline if 10-year Japanese government bond yields remain near record lows. Concerned about the gap between deposit and loan interest rates, the FSA is urging regional banks to consolidate or seek customers abroad. The tests are part of Japan's efforts to address the risks of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's loose monetary policy, which has kept interest rates exceptionally low for a prolonged period.

site_title: Thousands flee as floods hit southern Philippines
summary: Thousands of people in the southern Philippines have been evacuated due to flooding caused by tropical storm Seniang, which brought strong winds and heavy rains. Over 4,000 people were moved to temporary shelters, with reports of floodwaters as deep as 1.5 meters and fallen trees. The storm is forecast to bring heavy to intense rains within its 300-kilometre diameter, with no immediate reports of casualties. The region is prone to flooding, with the Philippines experiencing about 20 storms every year.

site_title: Singapore to scale back pace of HDB construction in 2015: Khaw Boon Wan
summary: Singapore plans to scale back its public housing construction pace in 2015, targeting 26,000 HDB flats, down from 28,000 this year. Minister Khaw Boon Wan notes that 2014 marked a shift in the housing market from a seller's to a buyer's market, with prices moderating. Despite scaling back construction, the government aims to refine policies to meet diverse housing needs, with iconic projects like Waterway Terraces and SkyTerrace@Dawson included in the 2015 pipeline.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Indonesia transport minister says will review AirAsia operations
summary: Indonesia's transport minister announced a review of AirAsia's operations following the disappearance of a plane carrying 162 people on Sunday. The Airbus A320-200 was en route from Surabaya to Singapore due to stormy weather. This is the third crisis for a Malaysian carrier this year. AirAsia said the missing jet last underwent maintenance on November 16, and the company has never suffered a fatal accident. The review aims to ensure AirAsia's activities are better in the future.

site_title: German minimum wage rings in Happy New Year for millions
summary: Germany's national minimum wage of 8.50 euros per hour comes into effect on January 1, affecting around 3.7 million people, including bakery worker Jessica Arendt. The move is seen as a victory for Chancellor Angela Merkel's coalition partners, the Social Democrats, who pushed for the minimum wage to help Germany's growing working poor. However, business owners like bakery chain owner Mathias Moebius predict price rises, which could offset the benefits for low-wage earners, with some economists warning of job cuts and reduced investment.

site_title: China looking at deal with US to recover dirty assets
summary: China is reportedly in talks with the US to sign an agreement targeting assets illegally taken out of China by corrupt officials, as part of its anti-graft battle. The deal aims to recover ill-gotten assets held in the US, following similar agreements with Canada and Australia. China has vowed to pursue a global "Fox Hunt" to track down corrupt officials and business executives, despite concerns over the integrity of its judicial system and treatment of prisoners. The US and other countries have been reluctant to sign extradition deals with China due to these concerns.

site_title: China offers help in search for missing AirAsia flight: FM
summary: China has offered to send aircraft and ships to help in the search for the missing AirAsia flight QZ8501, which disappeared on December 28, 2014, while en route from Indonesia to Singapore. The Foreign Ministry stated that China is "deeply concerned" about the safety of the 162 people on board and will provide aid according to Indonesia's needs. No Chinese citizens were found on the plane, but the offer comes amid concerns about China's response to the previous disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, which had 152 Chinese citizens on board.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 1.48% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 1.48% higher on Monday, following a record close on Wall Street. The benchmark Hang Seng Index rose 345.19 points to 23,694.53, driven by news that China unveiled measures to boost the economy. This positive sentiment was also influenced by the US and European markets, which reached fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares jumped 1.48 per cent at the open Monday as investors returned from the Christmas break to another record close on Wall Street and news that China had unveiled fresh measures to boost the economy.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall on ex-dividend, won little changed
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.4% on Monday, going ex-dividend, as investors took a break ahead of the holiday season. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) dropped to 1,940.41 points, with 14 of 17 industry sub-indices in negative territory. Samsung SDS rose 4.2% after being added to the KOSPI 200 index, while airline shares gained due to lower jet fuel costs. The won remained nearly flat, trading at 1,099.0 to the dollar.

site_title: a-iTrust to buy BlueRidge Phase II in Pune, India
summary: ASCENDAS Property Fund Trustee has agreed to buy BlueRidge Phase II in Pune, India for approximately S$133 million (6,404.6 million rupees). The acquisition is expected to enhance earnings for unitholders and mark a-iTrust's entry into the Pune market. Construction of the 1.5 million square feet IT special economic zone is expected to be completed by mid-2015. The deal will scale up a-iTrust's operations to 9 million sq ft.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Singapore share prices opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 6.43 points to 3,360.11. The rally comes ahead of GDP data, with gainers outnumbering losers 76 to 36. Volume reached 32.6 million shares worth S$19.2 million.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE share prices opened higher on Monday with the Straits Times Index up 6.43 points to 3,360.11.

site_title: Singapore Exchange to upgrade derivatives trading and clearing platforms
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to upgrade its derivatives trading and clearing platforms, SGX TITAN, to strengthen risk controls and system safeguards. The upgrade, expected to be completed by the end of 2016, aims to enable 24-hour trading and clearing. Additionally, SGX will continue to work with Nasdaq for an additional six years to support its securities and derivatives markets. The upgrade is seen as a positive development for SGX, with analysts expecting the company's earnings to benefit from increased volatility.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE Exchange (SGX) said on Monday it will upgrade its derivatives trading and clearing platforms.

site_title: Asian shares mostly up after Christmas break
summary: Asian markets rose on the first full day of trade after the Christmas break, boosted by Chinese easing measures and US economic growth. Tokyo added 0.31%, Hong Kong jumped 1.48%, and Shanghai rallied 1.26%. AirAsia shares fell 7.5% after a plane went missing with 162 people on board. Oil prices rose following violence in Libya. The US economy's 5% growth in July-September also contributed to the rally, with the Dow and S&P 500 hitting new records.

site_title: Hot stock: Shares of Nam Cheong gain on contract wins
summary: Nam Cheong's shares rose 3.33% on Monday after securing two vessel sale contracts worth US$45 million. The contracts, with one from Vroon BV in the Netherlands and another from E A Temile Development Company in Nigeria, are expected to positively impact earnings for the 2014 and 2015 financial years. This brings Nam Cheong's order book to RM1.7 billion.

site_title: Twitter sees limited blackout
summary: Twitter experienced a partial outage on Sunday, affecting users on Android and iPhone smartphones, as well as the computer application TweetDeck. The issue, which Twitter described as "technical," was resolved shortly after the company acknowledged the problem. The outage comes after a sophisticated hacking attack on Sony, blamed on North Korea, and raises concerns about the security of social media platforms. Twitter has 284 million active users and did not specify the cause of the outage.

site_title: Hot stock: Shares of Otto Marine gain on vessel sale
summary: Otto Marine's shares rose 4.4% after selling an Anchor Handling Tug Supply Vessel (AHTS) to a third party for $100 million. The vessel, under construction in Indonesia, is expected to be completed in Q2 2015 and will be chartered for 8 years. The sale is expected to positively impact the company's net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the 2014 financial year.

site_title: Asia follows Wall St up, euro wobbles before Greek vote
summary: Asian stocks rose Monday, following Wall Street gains, while the euro hovered near 28-month lows due to Greek parliamentary uncertainty. Greece's leading coalition faces a vote that could lead to snap elections, potentially bringing leftwing Syriza to power and derailing an international bailout. The euro's value may fluctuate depending on the outcome, with potential relief if the coalition secures 180 votes to elect a president.

site_title: AirAsia shares fall 11.6% after plane goes missing
summary: AirAsia shares plummet 11.6% after one of its planes, QZ8501, went missing in bad weather en route to Singapore from Surabaya, Indonesia. The airline's stock hit its lowest point since Nov 28, despite a 21.4% gain this year. Indonesia resumed its search for the missing jetliner at first light on Monday. The incident is the first major accident for the AirAsia group since its Malaysian operations began in 2002.

site_title: Aviation's deadly 2014, yet safety record improving
summary: The year 2014 saw a significant increase in aviation fatalities, with 762 people losing their lives in seven fatal accidents, including the disappearance of Indonesia AirAsia Flight QZ8501. However, despite these tragedies, the industry's overall safety record is improving, with a record-low number of crashes and a hull loss rate of 0.22 per million flights. This is attributed to advancements in aircraft design, training, and infrastructure, with the International Air Transport Association (IATA) noting that 2014 was among the safest years on record.

site_title: Australia joins hunt for missing AirAsia flight
summary: Australia has joined the search for the missing AirAsia flight with 162 people on board, which disappeared in bad weather en route to Singapore. A Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) aircraft took off from Darwin to assist the Indonesia-led operation in the Java Sea. Australia's Prime Minister Tony Abbott pledged to help Indonesia in the search, offering assistance and promising to do "whatever we humanly could to assist." This is Australia's second major search operation, following the ongoing search for Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, which disappeared in March with 239 people on board.

site_title: Hitachi buys Singapore water installation firm
summary: Hitachi Ltd plans to acquire Aqua Works and Engineering Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based water installation firm, to combine Aqua Works' water features with Hitachi's reverse osmosis membrane systems. The purchase price was not disclosed, but Aqua Works generated S$9.07 million in sales in 2013. The acquisition is expected to be completed by the end of January 2015.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 6.79 points to 1,757.65. The index saw 229 million lots traded worth RM187.9 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 215 to 108.

site_title: Update: Indonesia searches Java Sea for missing AirAsia plane, relatives wait
summary: Indonesia launched a search operation in the Java Sea on Monday for the missing AirAsia plane carrying 162 people, which disappeared five minutes after requesting a change of course to avoid a storm cell on its flight from Surabaya to Singapore. The aircraft, an Airbus A320-200, lost contact with air traffic control at 6:17 am on Sunday. Two C-130 Hercules planes and naval vessels from Singapore, Malaysia, Australia, the US, Britain, South Korea, and India are participating in the search efforts. The incident marks the biggest challenge for AirAsia, which has not suffered a crash since its Malaysian budget operations began in 2002.

site_title: Indonesia resumes search for missing AirAsia plane
summary: Indonesia has resumed the search for the missing AirAsia plane with 162 people on board, which disappeared in the Java Sea due to stormy weather. The search operation began at dawn on Monday, with four aircraft and vessels from Malaysia and Singapore participating. The plane was en route from Surabaya to Singapore when it changed its flight plan. The search team hopes to locate the plane soon, with assistance from various search and rescue offices and vessels from neighboring countries.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 0.53%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.53% higher on Monday, driven by a weaker yen and fresh record highs on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 93.87 points to 17,912.83, supported by solid year-end momentum and optimism over the US economy. A weak yen makes Japanese exporters more competitive abroad, while US data indicate an ideal, moderately recovering economy with no near-term interest rate increase.

site_title: China's economy expected to grow by 7% in 2015: state think-tank
summary: China's economy is expected to grow by 7% in 2015, slightly lower than the forecast of 7.3% this year, due to global economic weakness. The State Information Centre attributes the slowdown to a gradual trend of economic growth. Consumer price index is expected to increase less than 2% in 2015, while exports are forecast to grow 7% from 6% this year. The report also notes that the global economy may recover slightly in 2015, but fully recovering from the global financial crisis is unlikely.

site_title: Keppel's US unit wins rig contract worth more than US$100m
summary: Keppel's US unit, KEPPEL AmFELS LLC, has won a contract worth over US$100 million to build a massive land drilling rig for a major operator, scheduled for delivery in mid-2016. The contract will be undertaken by Keppel AmFELS, with no expected impact on Keppel Corporation Limited's financials for the current year.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: 'The Interview' generated US$15m in four days with 2m downloads: Sony
summary: Sony's "The Interview" generated over $15 million in its first four days of release, with 2 million downloads, making it the No 1 online movie ever released by Sony Pictures. The film, which was criticized by North Korea and triggered a cyberattack, has broken box office records.

site_title: Indonesia set to resume search for missing AirAsia plane, relatives wait
summary: Indonesia is set to resume the search for the missing AirAsia plane carrying 162 people that vanished on Sunday after the pilot requested a change in course to avoid bad weather. The Airbus A320-200 plane was about halfway between Surabaya and Singapore when it lost contact with air traffic control. Relatives of passengers are waiting anxiously for news, with the Indonesian government cooperating with international authorities to determine the cause of the incident.

site_title: Otto Marine sells vessel for US$100m
summary: Otto Marine Limited sold its Norwegian-designed Anchor Handling Tug Supply Vessel (AHTS) to an unrelated third party for US$100 million. The vessel, under construction in Batam, Indonesia, is expected to be completed in the second quarter of 2015. The sale is expected to positively contribute to the group's net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the 2014 financial year.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Nam Cheong secures deals for two vessels worth US$45m
summary: Nam Cheong Limited secured sale contracts for two vessels worth approximately US$45 million. The deals include a 6,000 bhp Anchor Handling Towing Supply vessel to a Netherlands-based customer and a 5,000 dead weight tonne Platform Supply Vessel to a Nigerian customer. The contracts are expected to positively contribute to the group's earnings for the financial years 2014 and 2015, increasing its order book to RM1.7 billion.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Regulators find it difficult to make clearing houses stronger: bankers
summary: Regulators face challenges in strengthening clearing houses, which are crucial in preventing financial crises by guaranteeing derivatives trades. Despite efforts to make them more robust, concerns remain about their capital levels and risk management. The global financial crisis highlighted the importance of clearing houses, but regulators are finding it difficult to craft standardized rules and stress tests for these institutions. An international panel is working on developing standardized stress tests, but a global plan to replace clearing houses is still in the works.

site_title: China's CITIC Securities says plans up to 1.5b new H-share issue
summary: China's CITIC Securities plans a new public issue of up to 1.5 billion Hong Kong-listed H-shares to supplement capital and expand businesses, including margin trading in China's mainland. The issue, pending shareholder and regulatory approval, could raise up to HK$41.6 billion (US$5.36 billion) based on the current H-share price of HK$27.75.

images.alt_text: Chinese biggest stock brokerage CITIC Securities said it plans a new public issue of up to 1.5 billion Hong Kong-listed H-shares to supplement capital to help expand businesses including margin trading in China's mainland.

site_title: MF Global settles suit over 2011 losses
summary: MF Global Holdings Ltd settled a US government lawsuit for $1.2 billion in restitution and a $100 million fine for customer losses tied to the company's 2011 collapse. The US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) accused MF Global of failing to properly supervise employees, making false statements, and improper investments. The settlement, approved by US District Judge Victor Marrero, guarantees payment of the brokerage unit's obligations and allows customers to receive most of their owed restitution. The CFTC will continue its litigation against former CEO Jon Corzine and Edith O'Brien.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise in thin trade, NZ index hits record high
summary: Australian shares rose 1% on Monday, led by gains in mining, energy, and telecommunications, while New Zealand stocks reached record highs. Trading volume was thin due to holiday time, and the market will be closed on Thursday. Key gainers included Fortescue Metals Group, BHP Billiton, and Rio Tinto, despite a decline in iron ore prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached a seven-week peak of 5,450, and the real estate sector index lost 0.5%.

site_title: AirAsia's 4th update on QZ8501
summary: AirAsia Indonesia released its 4th update on flight QZ8501, which crashed on December 28, 2014. The airline's CEO, Sunu Widyatmoko, expressed shock and sadness, while reaffirming the company's commitment to assisting families of passengers and crew. Search and rescue operations are ongoing, with AirAsia cooperating fully with authorities. The aircraft, an Airbus A320-200, was carrying 155 people, including 137 adults, 17 children, and 1 infant, with 2 pilots and 4 cabin crew on board. An emergency call center and briefing centers have been set up for families in Surabaya and Singapore.

site_title: South Korea Jan business sentiment climbs to 10-mth high
summary: South Korea's manufacturing business sentiment index rose to a 10-month high in January, driven by improved sentiment among exporters. The index, which measures companies' confidence in the coming month, increased to 81, its highest level since March. The Bank of Korea surveyed over 1,400 companies and found that exporters' expectations jumped 11 points, while non-exporters' expectations dropped 3 points. This marks a significant improvement from the previous quarter, but the economy's recovery may be slowing, with exports remaining a dominant growth driver.

site_title: Wall Street: Big questions for markets for 2015
summary: Wall Street experienced a relatively calm year in 2014, but with notable exceptions. The biotech and social media sectors saw significant downturns, and oil prices plummeted. Notable events included Cynk Technology's brief valuation of $6 billion and the Herzfeld Caribbean Basin Fund's record trading activity in December. Strategists predict watching for unusual market movements in 2015, including the impact of the US presidential election and potential trade tensions between the US and EU.

images.alt_text: Wall Street was generally calmer in 2014 than in previous years, but that doesn't mean the stock market was devoid of drama.

site_title: Sony says PlayStation still has problems, gradually coming back online
summary: Sony's PlayStation Network suffered a fourth consecutive day of connection problems due to a hacker attack by the group Lizard Squad. The company stated that service is gradually being restored. The attack follows a similar incident in August, which coincided with a bomb threat against a plane carrying an executive with Sony Online Entertainment. Despite the outage, some gamers reported being able to access the network, while others continued to complain about the issue. The PlayStation Network has been the victim of high-profile security breaches in the past, including a 2011 attack that stole data from 77 million users.

images.alt_text: Sony Corp's PlayStation Network suffered connection problems for a fourth straight day since hackers attacked the video game network, and the company said on Sunday that service was gradually being restored.

site_title: Japanese firms to spurn PM's call for higher wages next year: survey
summary: Japanese firms plan to return excess cash to shareholders rather than spend it on wage rises, contradicting Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's call to lift salaries. Only 6 firms, including Seven & i Holdings Co, said they would boost pay next year, while over 70% plan to use cash reserves on dividends and share buybacks. Abe's economic stimulus policies aim to boost consumption and combat deflation, but employers are hesitant due to concerns about passing on higher costs to consumers.

site_title: Shanghai-Hong Kong stock link hurdles spark derivatives boom
summary: Hong Kong's off-exchange derivatives market is thriving as foreign funds bypass technical and regulatory hurdles to gain exposure to China's record-breaking stocks rally. Despite Beijing's efforts to limit foreign investment through the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect, many US and European funds are using synthetic equity products, such as p-notes and equity swaps, to access China's markets. The market is booming, with some brokers and fund managers reporting that the vast majority of trading is happening in Hong Kong's OTC market, away from regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: South Korea's banks to get a boost from promised lighter regulation
summary: South Korea's banks are expected to benefit from the country's move to ease heavy-handed regulation, which has stifled their ability to charge rates and offer products based on market demand. The regulatory environment has been a major challenge for Korean lenders, with average returns on equity being the worst in Asia and less than half of those in China. The proposed change is seen as a positive development for banks, which are struggling to compete in a slowing economy and low interest rate environment.

site_title: Nurturing talent - 10 years and counting
summary: ChildAid 2014 marked a milestone, raising a record-breaking S$2.33 million for two children's charities over 10 years, totaling S$12.13 million. The concert featured returning musical stars, including Abigail Sin, Janani Sridhar, and Clarence Liew, who got their early starts on the ChildAid stage. The event also supported the BT Budding Artists Fund and ST School Pocket Money Fund, providing music lessons and financial assistance to underprivileged children.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Apple makes 'The Interview' movie available on iTunes
summary: Apple has made the comedy film "The Interview" available for rental or purchase on its iTunes store, four days after competitors. The film, which depicts assassinating North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un, was initially refused by large movie theater chains due to threats of violence from hackers. The movie was shown in 331 independent theaters, generating over $1 million in sales on Christmas Day, but its online revenues are unknown until Sony discloses them. The film's production and marketing costs were estimated at $44 million and $30-40 million, respectively.

site_title: For India's most famous female boxer, a fight against prejudice
summary: Mangte Chungneijang Mary Kom, India's most famous female boxer, has long faced prejudice and bias in the sport, despite her numerous achievements as a five-time world champion and Olympic bronze medalist. Kom, who has remained an outsider in India, has spoken out against bias in judging and has been suspended by the International Boxing Association for unsportsmanlike conduct. Her colleagues, including fellow Manipuri boxer Laishram Sarita Devi, have also faced similar issues, highlighting deeper fissures in the sport. Kom's struggles reflect the broader challenges faced by northeastern Indians in India, who often face discrimination and prejudice.

site_title: Vietnam economic growth quickens in Q4 on exports
summary: Vietnam's economic growth accelerated in Q4 with a 6.96% increase, beating the government's 5.8% target. Exports rose 15% this year, driven by foreign investment and companies like Samsung Electronics and LG Electronics. The central bank lowered interest rates and devalued the dong to boost lending and exports. The economy grew 5.98% for the full year, with inflation easing to 1.84% in December. Analysts attribute the growth to exports and manufacturing, with the government aiming to maintain stability in 2015.

site_title: Hundreds await nighttime rescue, one dead after Italian ferry catches fire
summary: A ferry carrying 478 passengers caught fire off the coast of Greece, resulting in one death. The Italian navy and coastguards battled to rescue nearly 300 passengers trapped on the burning vessel, with 190 evacuated by late evening. Rescuers faced strong winds and choppy waters, and passengers described desperate scenes as they pleaded for help. The cause of the fire remains unclear, but an investigation is underway.

site_title: Race to build on Columbia River could block Pacific oil route
summary: Environmental groups in Vancouver, Washington, are pushing a builder to expedite a $1.3 billion real estate project along the Columbia River, which includes office buildings and 3,300 apartments, to block the construction of a proposed oil terminal. The terminal, which would transfer North Dakota crude to barges, is opposed by local groups citing concerns over spills and derailments. The project is part of a surge in fossil fuel delivery across the Pacific Northwest, with 19 oil trains passing through Washington each week, and could lead to a 137-train-per-week scenario by 2020.

site_title: The forum in review
summary: The Business Times-Citibank Young Investors Forum has wrapped up another year, offering insights on personal finance and investing. A landmark 1996 study found that companies with low accruals outperformed those with large accruals, as large accruals' earnings reversed, sparking a selloff. The forum features step-by-step guides, peer success stories, and answers to investing questions, encouraging readers to invest their time by reading The Business Times every Monday and writing in with questions. The forum will continue to provide valuable information for young investors in the coming year.

site_title: Continued smooth sailing a safe bet for now
summary: Singapore insurers have had a profitable year, with a promising outlook expected to continue. Foreign players, including Nationale Suisse, Etiqa, and Berkshire Hathaway Specialty Insurance, have entered the market, driven by a rising Asian middle class and low penetration. However, a "perfect storm" of tougher rules and increased competition is expected to brew in the coming years.

site_title: Top Japan firms sees yen fall almost done: Reuters survey
summary: Top Japanese firms predict the yen will not decline much further in 2015, forecasting an average low of 125 to the dollar and high of 112, despite Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's easy-money policies. The currency has lost about one-third of its value since Abe took power in 2012. Many firms, including Suntory Holdings and Mitsubishi Chemicals, are bullish on the Tokyo stock market, forecasting a Nikkei stock average of 16,000-20,000 next year.

site_title: Sony restores PS4 service on PlayStation Network
summary: Sony has restored service for the PS4 game console on its PlayStation Network after a three-day outage caused by hackers calling themselves Lizard Squad. The attack, which also targeted Microsoft's Xbox Live, was claimed by Lizard Squad on its Twitter account. The hackers demanded attention by retweeting their statements. The incident occurred on Christmas Day, the same day Sony released the comedy film "The Interview" online, which was also targeted by hackers claiming responsibility for infiltrating Sony Pictures Entertainment's servers.

site_title: MBA programmes strive to adapt to Digital Age
summary: Business schools are adapting to the digital age by incorporating courses in statistics, data science, and A/B testing, reflecting the growing importance of these skills in industries beyond tech. Programs like Cornell Tech's MBA, which combines business and computer science, are being established to train "entrepreneurial, technology product managers" needed across industries. Applications to business graduate schools have declined, while those for computer science and math programs have increased, as talented young people seek education in fields better equipped to address the digital economy's demands.

site_title: 10 dead, 200,000 evacuated in Malaysia floods
summary: Malaysia's severe floods, the worst in decades, have resulted in at least 10 deaths and the evacuation of over 200,000 people. The government has allocated an additional RM500m in aid, following an initial approval of RM50m, to support victims. The floods have also affected parts of Thailand and Sri Lanka.

site_title: Why invest? And how do you do it?
summary: Investors often seek financial freedom and passive income through diversified portfolios. However, they must consider the sustainability of income streams, as companies like Seadrill, which suspended its dividend payouts, demonstrate the risks of high-yield stocks. Income investors may turn to bonds, defensive assets, or global giants like Nestle, Procter & Gamble, and Coca-Cola, which have stable brands and cash flows, to minimize risks. A long-term approach, focusing on reinvested dividends and steady buying, can help secure financial futures despite market fluctuations.

site_title: YouTube goes beyond cat videos with The Interview screening
summary: YouTube successfully debuted Sony's The Interview, a satirical comedy starring Seth Rogen and James Franco, after Google acquired the rights to stream the film. The move marked a high-profile feature film debut on the internet and demonstrated YouTube's ability to sell premium content. Despite hackers linked to North Korea threatening violence, the film was released simultaneously with theaters, generating over $1 million in ticket sales on its first day. The rollout showcased YouTube's growing collection of films and its drive to compete with digital rivals like Netflix.

site_title: So many different cellphone plans, so many confused customers
summary: Wireless phone companies have introduced various contract-free plans, allowing customers to upgrade or share data across multiple devices. However, this competition has created a complex and confusing market, with unique language and requirements in the fine print. Executives acknowledge the industry has "propagated some confusion" and urge consumers to navigate the offers carefully, as deals can change frequently. Industry analysts note that while this increased competition benefits consumers, it requires more work to find the best deals, and the constant changes can be overwhelming.

site_title: Russian airlines face headwinds as rouble falls
summary: Russian airlines face significant financial challenges due to the decline of the rouble, which has fallen 40% against the dollar and euro this year. With jet fuel costs accounting for a quarter of flight costs, airlines are expected to see a boost in earnings, but this is expected to be offset by reduced international traffic and increased costs in foreign currencies. The government has offered loan guarantees and subsidies to support airlines, but experts warn of a "complete upheaval" in the market in 2015, with many airlines expected to lose money or even go bankrupt.

images.alt_text: THEIR international competitors may be cheering tumbling oil prices, but the collapse in the rouble has meant major financial turbulence for Russian airlines which have expenses in foreign currencies.

site_title: Taking heart
summary: A Christmas celebration was held at Parkroyal on Kitchener Road for children aged 7-12 from Thye Hua Kwan's Student Care Centre @ Bukit Panjang. The event included a Boxing Day lunch, Christmas presents, and a Frozen-themed children's corner. TAOBAO Marketplace is encouraging online donations to The Salvation Army's thrift stores until Jan 15, 2015. The Make-A-Wish Foundation received a S$10,000 cheque from Caribbean International, and 50 Make-A-Wish kids went on a special Christmas cruise.

site_title: Academic joins DTZ as head of Singapore research
summary: DTZ has appointed Lee Nai Jia as associate director and head of Singapore research, replacing Lee Lay Keng who left the firm to join Alpha Investment Partners. Dr. Lee, a 38-year-old PhD holder from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, brings expertise in data analytics and GIS, as well as experience in consulting for government agencies. He will focus on understanding globalized real estate markets in Singapore and beyond, and will help the firm innovate its research methodology.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Will gold keep its shine in 2015?
summary: Gold's 2015 direction remains uncertain, with analysts divided on its prospects. A possible hike in US real interest rates could negatively impact the metal, but some predict a rebound in physical demand from China and India, offsetting the negative effects. The Federal Reserve's delay in raising interest rates until mid-2015 may also contribute to a mixed outlook. While some forecasters, such as ABN Amro and UBS Wealth Management, expect lower gold prices, others, like ANZ commodity strategist Victor Thianpiriya, predict a stronger demand for gold from China and India, potentially leading to a recovery.

site_title: Britain to pay off debts incurred in 18th, 19th centuries
summary: The British government plans to pay off debts incurred in the 18th and 19th centuries, including those from the South Sea Bubble and World War I, using record low interest rates. The move aims to close the books on historic debt, which has been passed down through generations, and is seen as a financial manoeuvre. The government will repay £1.9 billion to holders of a 3.5% war loan issued in 1932 and £218 million to "4 per cent consols" issued in 1927.

site_title: UK starts gritting roads as first snow cover hits
summary: The UK starts gritting roads as the first snow cover of winter hits, covering large areas of England and Wales. An army of gritting trucks will spread up to two million tonnes of salt on over 128,750 km of roadways to combat "treacherous" driving conditions. The cost of salting roads is estimated to be £150 million, while the Salt Association warns that delays could cost the economy £2 billion annually.

site_title: Uber broke Indian financial rules: central bank chief
summary: India's central bank chief, Raghuram Rajan, has accused Uber of violating the country's financial regulations by using an overseas payment system. Uber was found to bypass India's two-step authentication system for e-commerce credit card payments. Rajan warned that India will not tolerate such violations "no matter who you are" and urged Uber to conform to banking regulations. Uber later migrated to a new transaction process in India, but the central bank is seeking to establish a new financial framework to keep pace with the country's burgeoning e-commerce sector.

images.alt_text: Mr Rajan said India is seeking to establish a new financial framework to keep pace with its burgeoning e-commerce sector.

site_title: Safeguarding businesses from digital threats
summary: Cyber threats pose a significant risk to businesses in the digital age, with 66% year-on-year increase in detected attacks and $20 million or more losses reported by 40% of respondents in 2014. Companies must adopt a proactive approach to manage cyber risks by reframing their thinking, focusing on strategy, capability, and culture. This includes conducting risk assessments, investing in critical assets, and developing a clear cyber risk strategy backed by necessary resources. A dedicated chief information security officer and employee buy-in are also crucial to the success of any security strategy.

site_title: Panama Canal receives claims for US$737m
summary: The Panama Canal Authority has received claims for US$737 million in cost overruns related to the canal's expansion project. Canal administrator Jorge Quijano stated that the claims will be evaluated, but warned that the issues may be difficult to justify. Excavation work has been halted due to a strike by workers, adding to the project's delays and budget overruns.

site_title: Writers up in arms over Amazon's Kindle Unlimited
summary: Self-published authors are unhappy with Amazon's Kindle Unlimited, a subscription service that offers access to 700,000 books for $9.99 a month. The service's all-you-can-eat model is seen as a threat to writers' earnings, with some experiencing a 75% drop in income after participating. The program requires exclusivity, limiting sales through other platforms, and pays a fluctuating amount per book. Writers fear that not participating will harm their books' promotion, and some are considering forming a union to advocate for better terms.

images.alt_text: Revenue from e-books levelled off in 2013 at US$3 billion after increasing nearly 50 per cent in 2012, according to BookStats. But Kindle Unlimited is making the glut worse, some writers say.

site_title: Riding on Asia's aviation aftermarket
summary: Pratt & Whitney, a global aerospace manufacturer, is expanding its operations in Singapore to capitalize on the growing demand for long-term fleet management services. The company has invested $110 million in new facilities, including a 180,000 square-foot manufacturing plant and a repair and engineering facility. Pratt & Whitney aims to deliver steady cash flow through engine maintenance services, with 80% of its PurePower engine fleet expected to be under fleet management programs by 2017. The company has also partnered with local institutions to address Singapore's tight labor market, with plans to hire 1,200 new staff by 2017.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US oil states brace for fallout from crude's price bust
summary: US oil states, including Texas, Louisiana, Oklahoma, and Alaska, are bracing for layoffs and budget cuts due to falling oil prices. Texas has already lost 2,300 oil and gas jobs, while Louisiana's budget shortfall has increased to $1.4 billion. Alaska's budget deficit has worsened, and Moody's has lowered its credit outlook to negative. Experts say the situation could have been worse if states had diversified their economies, but many are taking steps to mitigate the impact, including reviewing budgets and cutting expenses.

site_title: OUE Lippo to buy 22.97% stake in Gemdale for HK$1.5b
summary: OUE Limited's subsidiary, OUE Lippo, has agreed to buy a 22.97% stake in Hong Kong-listed Gemdale Properties and Investment Corporation Limited for HK$1.5 billion (S$256.4 million). The deal allows OUE Group to gain access to China's real estate market and leverage potential collaborations with GPI, a leading Chinese developer. The subscription price of HK$0.52 represents a discount to GPI's net tangible asset value and a premium to its volume-weighted average price. The deal is expected to enhance OUE Group's long-term shareholder value and explore potential synergies between the two companies.

site_title: HK new home sales seen to reach record proceeds this year
summary: Hong Kong's new home sales are expected to reach record proceeds this year, with estimated full-year sales of HK$175 billion (S$30 billion). This is the highest since 1996, driven by property developers selling new residential projects to raise cash for land. The strong sales are attributed to the city's growing demand for housing and increasing property prices.

site_title: Goldman's bearish call on grains echoed by investors in ETFs
summary: Investors are pulling out of agriculture ETFs despite a four-year high in grain prices, with $85 million withdrawn in the latest quarter. Banks, including Goldman Sachs, predict a short-lived rally, citing growing global harvests and supply imbalances. The Bloomberg Grains Subindex has surged 21% since September, but is still heading for its second straight annual decline. Experts warn of a "sharp decline in agriculture" next year, with prices potentially slumping for the first two-year time since 1999.

images.alt_text: Corn prices have rebounded 30 per cent since reaching a five-year low on Oct 1 amid rising demand for US shipments.

site_title: Ringing in the New Year in London will now come at a cost
summary: London Mayor Boris Johnson has introduced a £10 (S$20) head charge for people wanting to party on the streets along the River Thames for New Year's Eve, limiting entry to 100,000. The move aims to ensure the event remains safe, enjoyable, and sustainable. However, some politicians have warned of potential crowd control issues outside the closed zone, with some partygoers being offered tickets for £50-£200. The mayor's office has urged people without tickets to stay home and watch the celebrations on TV.

images.alt_text: London Mayor Boris Johnson says that the £10 charge will help the cost of policing the event, the highlight of which is a spectacular fireworks display centred on the London Eye.

site_title: PBOC widens deposit base for China banks
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) is set to change rules governing loan-to-deposit ratios at banks starting next year, expanding the base for calculating these ratios and boosting liquidity conditions. The new rules will include savings held by banks for non-deposit-taking financial institutions in banks' deposits, allowing for more liquidity to be available for lending and investment. This move aims to reinvigorate productive business investment without reducing reserve requirement ratios. The change is seen as a way to counter deflationary pressure and sliding industrial activity.

site_title: Mizuho cautious about corporate bond outlook
summary: Mizuho Financial Group, set to become Japan's largest corporate bond underwriter in 2014, is cautious about the outlook for next year due to yields approaching zero percent. This has put off investors, forcing top-rated issuers to offer extra premiums. The Bank of Japan's bond buying has pushed average corporate yields to a record low 0.27 percent, making it difficult for issuers to find mutually acceptable terms. Mizuho predicts that companies will sell more 10-year notes, but sales may cap at current levels due to companies having plentiful cash.

site_title: Greek MPs hold crunch presidential vote to avert snap polls
summary: Greek MPs will hold a presidential vote on Monday to avoid snap polls, which EU and IMF officials fear could be won by the anti-austerity Syriza party, potentially undoing fiscal reforms. Prime Minister Antonis Samaras' government candidate, Stavros Dimas, fell short in the second round and will need 180 votes to pass the final vote. If no president is chosen, a general election will be triggered, which Syriza is likely to win, given recent polls showing the party trailing Samaras' ruling coalition by 3.3%.

site_title: Capturing college students' attention
summary: US universities are transforming the way science is taught, shifting from traditional lecture-based classes to more active and engaging approaches. This change is driven by research showing that students fare better with hands-on learning methods. Despite the benefits, many colleges remain slow to adopt these changes, citing low priority on teaching and faculty resistance. To address this, universities are investing in training for teaching assistants and faculty, and incorporating tools such as group work and problem-solving exercises. The goal is to increase student engagement and improve outcomes, particularly for underrepresented groups.

site_title: Russia will burn through wealth funds in 3 years without cuts, minister warns
summary: Russia's Finance Minister Anton Siluanov warned that the country will exhaust its rainy day funds in three years if the government doesn't change its budget structure. With oil prices near a five-year low, Russia is facing a recession, projected to contract about 4% next year, and a budget deficit of over 3% of output. The country's international reserves have shrunk by about one-fifth this year to $398.9 billion, and policymakers are rolling out measures to ease foreign currency refinancing.

site_title: Soft market ahead for most developers
summary: Singapore's industrial property market is expected to remain soft in 2015 due to a weaker manufacturing outlook and targeted measures to boost supply and curb speculation. Certain high-specification factories, business parks, and warehouses will continue to see strong take-up and stable rents, while multi-user factories and ready-built factories will suffer. A huge supply of 2.6 million square meters of factory space is expected to be completed in 2015, leading to falling rents.

site_title: More of the same enervating and dismal politicking up ahead
summary: Malaysia is expected to face a challenging 2015, with analysts predicting more politicking and racial tensions. Despite the Prime Minister Najib Razak's efforts to defend his policies, critics argue that his administration has failed to address key issues such as corruption and vested interests. The government's decision to retain and strengthen the Sedition Act has also sparked concerns about freedom of speech. Meanwhile, the 1MDB scandal continues to raise questions about the government's handling of public funds. Analysts hope that moderate Malays will speak out to quell discordant voices, but warn that the situation could deteriorate into ethnic or religious tensions.

site_title: Missing AirAsia flight had asked to fly higher to avoid cloud: official
summary: An AirAsia flight went missing on December 28, 2014, between Surabaya, Indonesia, and Singapore. The aircraft was flying at 32,000 feet when it requested to ascend to 38,000 feet to avoid clouds. The plane was last seen near the town of Pontianak, West Kalimantan, on Borneo island.

site_title: Cuban port poised to reap from trade as US eases embargo, normalises relations
summary: Cuba's port of Mariel is poised to reap from the easing of the US embargo and normalization of relations. The US$1 billion port, built by Brazil's Odebrecht, has already employed 2,000 workers and is expected to export goods to the US and Caribbean markets. However, many residents remain skeptical, citing poverty and lack of infrastructure, with only one ship docked at the terminal on Christmas Eve. The new free trade zone, set to be completed in 2015, aims to attract foreign investment and create jobs, but regulatory changes have been slow, hindering progress.

site_title: Directors' buying down in holiday shortened week
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

During the holiday-shortened week of Dec 22-26, directors' buying rebounded with 12 companies recording 14 purchases worth S$3.1 million, while selling recovered with two firms recording two disposals worth S$9.4 million. Keppel Corporation saw intensified buying with buybacks and purchases by Temasek Holdings and directors. Aberdeen Asset Management Plc also reported a significant purchase. Meanwhile, Sarine Technologies and FIL Limited recorded buybacks and acquisitions. Singapore Press Holdings bought back shares for the first time since December 2013. The buying has intensified in shipping, property, and infrastructure firm Keppel Corporation.

site_title: Multi-nation search yields no results so far
summary: A multi-nation search for the missing AirAsia Bhd plane with 155 passengers and crew on board has yielded no results after Day One. The Airbus A320-200 lost contact with airport controllers on Sunday morning while flying from Surabaya to Singapore, with storms and clouds along the flight path. Singapore and other countries are assisting Indonesia in the search, with two Singapore planes set to assist on Monday. The plane's last signal was between Pontianak and Tanjung Pandan islands, and the search will focus on these areas.

site_title: China anti-graft campaign takes its toll in collateral damage
summary: China's anti-graft campaign, led by President Xi Jinping, has taken a toll in collateral damage in the mountainous region of Lüliang, Shanxi province. Seven local party bosses have been stripped of power or jailed, and nine more officials have been detained. The crackdown targets corrupt officials and business leaders who have bought and sold government posts to maintain control of the area's lucrative coal mines. While many residents support the purge, ordinary people are concerned about the impact on jobs and growth. The campaign's emphasis on cleaning up local governments has unsettled the party establishment and its allies in business.

site_title: Sheng Siong signs joint-venture deal to run supermarkets in China
summary: Sheng Siong Group has signed a conditional joint-venture agreement with Kunming LuChen Group Co Ltd to operate supermarkets in China. The proposed JV company will be incorporated with a registered capital of US$10 million, with Sheng Siong holding 60% equity and LuChen holding 30%. The agreement is subject to Chinese authority approval. This partnership aims to expand Sheng Siong's presence in the Chinese market.

site_title: Sheng Siong in deal to run China supermarkets
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a Singapore-listed company, has executed a conditional joint-venture agreement with Kunming LuChen Group Co to operate supermarkets in China. The proposed joint venture will be incorporated in China with a registered capital of US$10 million. Sheng Siong will invest US$6 million for 60% equity interest, while LuChen will provide US$3 million for 30% interest. The agreement is subject to Chinese authorities' approval and is expected to strengthen Sheng Siong's presence in the Chinese market.

images.alt_text: Singapore-listed Sheng Siong Group has executed a conditional joint-venture agreement with Kunming LuChen Group Co to operate supermarkets in China.

site_title: Commercial software used in suspected state-backed hacking
summary: Researchers say a previously undisclosed hacking campaign against military targets in Israel and Europe is likely backed by a country that misused security-testing software to cover its tracks. The campaign used Core Security software, which costs $10,000-$20,000, to enhance its capability. The attackers, possibly Iran, used seven connected attacks since April, including attempts to steal information from Israeli and European defense institutions. The campaign was dubbed "Rocket Kitten" and is the first to use commercial software to attribute the attacks to a specific government.

site_title: Atari nearly introduced the world to fitness gaming 30 years ago
summary: Atari nearly released the Puffer, an exercise bike that allowed players to control a game character by pedaling, in 1984. However, the industry crash led to Atari's bankruptcy and sale. This concept predates popular fitness games like Wii Fit and Dance Dance Revolution. The Puffer's idea of using exercise to control a game was a precursor to modern fitness gaming, but it never reached the market.

site_title: AirAsia faces biggest crisis as jet goes missing
summary: AirAsia, a Southeast Asian airline, faces its biggest crisis after an Airbus 320-200 with 162 people on board went missing during a flight from Surabaya to Singapore. The plane vanished after pilots asked to change course due to bad weather, and authorities called off the search as darkness fell. The airline, which operates over 180 jets and has a virtually unblemished safety record, is owned by Malaysia-based AirAsia Bhd and led by CEO Tony Fernandes. The incident marks a devastating blow to Fernandes, who has been closely identified with the airline's rise to success.

images.alt_text: Mr Fernandes at a news conference at the Juanda International Airport, Surabaya on Sunday. He had earlier tweeted that as group CEO, he will go through the ordeal with his staff.

site_title: AirAsia updates nationality breakdown of those on board missing Flight QZ8501
summary: AirAsia has updated the nationality breakdown of those on board its missing Flight QZ8501, revealing that there was one Singaporean, one Malaysian, one British, three South Koreans, and 149 Indonesians among the 155 passengers and crew members. The airline initially reported 121 Indonesians, with the remaining 34 passengers and crew members from other nationalities.

site_title: Doubts as giant China project's water reaches capital
summary: China's South North Water Diversion Project, a massive $81 billion water transfer system, is set to begin supplying Beijing with 1.05 billion cubic meters of water annually, but critics argue it's only a temporary solution to the city's chronic water shortage. The project, which has taken over a decade to complete, aims to alleviate water scarcity in northern China, but its success is threatened by declining rainfall in the south, and environmentalists say it doesn't address the root causes of the region's water stress.

site_title: Euro's prospects against trading partners unclear
summary: Investors expect the euro to fall against the US dollar, but its prospects against other major trading partners are unclear. The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to ease monetary policy, potentially leading to a euro decline against the US dollar, but its impact on the euro against other currencies, such as the yuan, sterling, and Japanese yen, is uncertain. The euro has already lost 3% against the US dollar since October and is seen as a key factor in the ECB's efforts to combat deflation in the eurozone.

site_title: Dubai Investments plans 10b dirhams of property projects as market recovers
summary: Dubai Investments PJSC plans 10 billion dirhams (S$3.6 billion) of real estate projects over the next five years, benefiting from a resurgent property market in Dubai. The company will start tendering for the 2.5 billion dirham Mirdiff Hills project in the next two months, with no need to borrow funds.
