site_title: Fujian Zhenyun requests trading suspension, citing delay in finalising accounts
summary: Fujian Zhenyun Plastics Industry's stock has been halted from trading due to uncertainties surrounding the company's state of affairs. Operational issues have delayed finalizing accounts, causing its external auditor to postpone the interim audit. The company's independent directors have initiated an internal inquiry and will update shareholders as necessary. The halt comes after the stock last traded at 14.9 Singapore cents on December 23.

site_title: US: Wall St hits records in broad, thinly traded rally
summary: US stocks hit records on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average reaching new highs. The S&P 500 is on track for its 52nd record close of the year, while the Dow is on track for its seventh straight daily gain. The rally is attributed to strong economic data and accommodative measures from central banks, with the Nasdaq biotech index rising 2% despite being down 3.8% for the week. The market's upward bias continues, with all 10 S&P 500 industry sectors higher, but concerns about overbought conditions are growing.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Friday, rising 14.7 points to 1,764.44. A total of 846.49 million lots worth RM870.12 million were traded, with 436 gains and 255 losses.

site_title: Isetan to stop its own retailing operations at Isetan Orchard by Q2 2015
summary: Isetan (Singapore) plans to cease its own retailing operations at Isetan Orchard by Q2 2015, but will continue to lease space to other tenants. The company reported a Q3 2014 loss of S$2.9 million, with revenue increasing 4.4% to S$79.9 million. Isetan will maintain its department store operations at Isetan Scotts Store in Shaw House. The decision follows a challenging retail environment in Singapore, with the company expecting its FY2014 to be unprofitable.

site_title: S$2.58m fraud spread over three years discovered at Swissco
summary: A senior employee at Swissco Holdings misappropriated S$2.58 million over three years through falsified documents, directing payment to her personal and family members' bank accounts. The company has recovered S$900,000 and plans to recover the remainder. Financial losses of S$1.68 million are not expected to impact the company's profit and net tangible assets for the 2014 financial year. Swissco's shares fell 2.8% after the announcement. The company's management filed a police report and launched an investigation into the incident.

site_title: Stamford Land flips New South Wales freehold site for A$51m
summary: Stamford Land has sold its freehold site in New South Wales, Australia for A$51 million. The 10,132 square meter site was acquired for A$23.7 million less than a year ago and has development approval. The sale is expected to result in an after-tax gain of A$15.7 million for the financial year ending March 31, 2015. The disposal is expected to be completed by end-February 2015 and will increase net tangible assets per share and earnings per share by 1.95 Singapore cents.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit sells seven Japan nursing homes for 7.95b yen
summary: PARKWAY Life Reit has sold seven Japan nursing homes for 7.95 billion yen (S$87.3 million), generating an estimated divestment gain of approximately S$12.3 million. The sale price is 28.1% higher than the original purchase price, exceeding the latest independent valuation. This sale will decrease distribution per unit to 10.32 cents and increase net asset value per unit to S$1.65, with the Reit's counter closing unchanged at S$2.37.

site_title: Sony's PlayStation, Micosoft's Xbox offline in 'hacker attack'
summary: Sony's PlayStation and Microsoft's Xbox online gaming networks were disrupted for a second day due to a hacker attack, with hackers claiming responsibility via the Twitter handle "Lizard Squad." The attack, which started on Christmas Day, was seen as a coordinated effort, with Sony's data breach earlier in the month sparking speculation about a potential connection. Analysts believe the hack was likely carried out by amateur hackers seeking to gain notoriety, with a direct link to the Sony Pictures attack unlikely. Both companies are working to restore service.

site_title: US: Stocks rise; Dow up for 7th straight serssion
summary: US stocks rose in opening trade on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 30.89 points (0.17%) to 18,061.10, the S&P 500 gaining 5.70 (0.27%) to 2,087.58, and the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 15.33 (0.32%) to 4,788.80. The gains follow the release of the US economic growth report, which showed the US economy grew 5% in the third quarter. This is the Dow's seventh consecutive day of gains.

site_title: STI up for the 7th consecutive session
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 74 points, or 2.3%, to 3,353.68 for its seventh consecutive session, driven by a rebound in stocks, despite a strengthening US economy and weak oil prices. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate assurances have been the main factor in the S&P 500's 50 all-time highs this year, rather than the US economy's improvement. In Singapore, the market relies on a small number of heavyweights, including banks and blue chips, to move the index, with low investor interest contributing to the low trading volume.

site_title: Deputy head of China business regulator investigated for graft
summary: The deputy head of China's State Administration for Industry and Commerce, Sun Hongzhi, is under investigation for suspected corruption. The ruling Communist Party's anti-graft watchdog is looking into "serious violations of party discipline and law". Sun, who joined the body in 2011, is also involved in anti-trust roles, including questioning Microsoft on the compatibility of its Windows operating system. This investigation follows China's intensified campaign against official corruption since Xi Jinping took office two years ago, with several senior government figures and state company executives in detention.

site_title: Global bank regulator proposes standardised minimum capital measure
summary: The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision has proposed introducing a standardized minimum capital measure to mitigate model risk and ensure comparability of capital outcomes across banks. The measure, based on revised standardised approaches for credit, market and operational risk, aims to reduce reliance on internal models and international credit ratings agencies. Banks will have until March 27 to comment on the proposals, which are part of the Basel III regulations. The move aims to enhance the banking system's resilience and stability.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index down 5.3 points to 3,340.61. The market saw a higher volume of 24.2 million shares worth S$50 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 47 to 38. This follows a 0.4% gain on Thursday, where investors remained optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: China starts building huge new Beijing airport
summary: China has begun construction on a new international passenger airport in Beijing, expected to handle 72 million passengers annually by 2025. The $13 billion project aims to alleviate capacity constraints at the current airport, which is the world's second busiest but also one of the most delayed. The new facility, located in southern Beijing, will be completed in five years and will handle 620,000 flights per year. The airport's construction is part of a growing demand for air travel in China, with the country expected to surpass the US as the world's largest domestic air traffic market by 2023.

site_title: Malaysia's monsoon floods seen crippling December palm supply: industry
summary: Malaysia's severe monsoon flooding has forced over 100,000 people to evacuate, disrupting palm oil production and supply. The floods, affecting key palm-growing areas, will hinder harvesting, transportation, and crushing of fresh palm fruits, leading to tighter supplies of palm oil in December and early 2015. Production is expected to drop 18% from November, with output potentially falling 5% more than usual for December. This is expected to drive up palm oil prices, which have already risen to their highest levels in two months.

site_title: Rouble rebounds sharply from lows as exporters sell dollars
summary: Russia's rouble sharply rebounded to its strongest levels in over three weeks after the government ordered exporters to sell some of their hard currency revenues, citing efforts to halt its slide and bring down inflation. The rouble rose to 52.78 after a hike in interest rates and curbs on grain exports, but signs of economic stress remain, including a central bank rescue of Trust Bank from bankruptcy. Oil prices, which have almost halved from their peak in June, continue to pose a threat to the rouble's recovery, with Standard & Poor's warning of a potential downgrade to junk status.

site_title: China is launching yuan swaps, forwards vs rouble, ringgit, NZ dollar
summary: China is launching yuan swaps and forwards against the Russian rouble, Malaysian ringgit, and New Zealand dollar, starting next week, offering companies a hedging tool amid emerging market currency volatility. The China Foreign Exchange Trade System (CFETS) will start trading with a minimum size of US$10,000 equivalent. This move is part of China's efforts to internationalize the yuan and increase its currency convertibility. The yuan is already traded against major global currencies, and the new swaps and forwards will further enhance its market presence.

site_title: Vietnam's 2014 trade surplus seen at record US$1.98b: newspaper
summary: Vietnam's trade surplus is projected to reach a record US$1.98 billion in 2014, driven by robust exports of US$150.04 billion, up 13% from 2013. Key sectors include telephones, mobile phones, and spare parts, as well as textiles and garment products. Imports are estimated at US$148.06 billion. This marks the third consecutive year of a trade surplus for Vietnam, with the economy expected to expand 5.8% in 2014.

site_title: PBOC mulls easing liquidity requirements at banks: sources
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) is considering easing liquidity requirements at banks by expanding the base for calculating loan-to-deposit ratios. This move, which could boost liquidity conditions, may not require banks to set aside additional reserves. The PBOC weighed the proposal during a meeting with domestic financial institutions, with 24 major financial institutions told that even with interbank deposits included, they may not need to set aside additional reserves. The move aims to reinvigorate productive business investment without a reserve requirement ratio cut.

site_title: Board changes at Competition Commission of Singapore, JTC and Singapore Tourism Board
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS), JTC Corporation (JTC), and Singapore Tourism Board (STB) have announced changes to their boards. At CCS, Aubeck Kam was appointed chairman, replacing Lam Chuan Leong after 10 years. New members include Tan Kok Kiong and Chionh Sze Chyi. JTC appointed Olivier Lim, Guy Harvey-Samuel, and Ng Lang, with Loo Choon Yong re-appointed as chairman. STB re-appointed Mike Barclay, Deborah Ong, Jessica Tan, and Christina Ong. The appointments take effect from January 1.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Shanghai soars despite muted post-Christmas trade in Asia markets
summary: Asian markets were largely flat on Friday due to the Christmas holiday closures, but Shanghai surged to a four-year high, driven by a 2.77% gain in financial stocks. Shanghai's Shanghai Composite Index rose to 3,157.60 on turnover of 488.9 billion yuan, while Tokyo and Seoul edged up 0.06% and 0.08%, respectively. The gains were attributed to a strong performance by financial stocks, despite muted trade in other Asian markets.

site_title: Raffles Education gets Hong Kong nod for spin-off
summary: Raffles Education Corp has obtained an in-principle approval from the Hong Kong Stock Exchange for the proposed listing of its subsidiary Oriental University City Holdings on the Growth Enterprise Market board. This follows a no-objection letter from the Singapore Exchange earlier this month. Formal approval is subject to the completion of documentary requirements and approval for the contents of its prospectus. The proposed spin-off listing involves Oriental University City, which owns and leases educational facilities in China's Hebei province. There is no assurance the listing will proceed.

site_title: Seoul prosecutors raid LG office over washing machine dispute with Samsung: Yonhap
summary: Prosecutors in South Korea raided LG Electronics' headquarters over allegations that the company damaged Samsung Electronics' washing machines at retail stores in Germany. LG has denied any wrongdoing, while Samsung has accused the head of LG's home appliances business of vandalizing its products. The raid is part of a probe into the dispute, which has sparked tensions between the two rival companies. The outcome of the investigation is unclear.

site_title: Dukang Distillers drops plan to set up Taiwan office
summary: Dukang Distillers Holdings has abandoned plans to set up an office in Taiwan, citing China's ongoing anti-corruption campaign and its impact on sales of baijiu. The company will reallocate funds from its Taiwan office to advertising and promotional activities in the Chinese market. Dukang reported a loss of 29.4 million yuan in the first quarter, with revenue almost halving to 207 million yuan. The company's shares rose 1.7% before the announcement, despite being down 63% compared to a year ago.

site_title: Hyundai Motor promotes younger execs, with eye on succession planning
summary: Hyundai Motor promoted two younger executives, Cho Won-hong and Kong Young-woon, to executive vice president, in a move analysts say is part of succession planning. The promotions, at the ages of 50, are seen as paving the way for the eventual leadership of Chung Eui-sun, the heir apparent. Kia Motors also promoted Kim Gyun to executive vice president. These moves are part of a broader trend of injecting younger talent into Korean conglomerates, as they prepare for leadership transitions.

site_title: Record numbers evacuated in Malaysia's worst floods in decades
summary: Malaysia's worst monsoon floods in decades have displaced over 103,000 people across five northern states, surpassing the previous record of 100,000 evacuated in 2008. The floods, caused by extremely high levels of floodwater and bad weather, have made evacuations and food supply transport by helicopters difficult. The worst affected area, northeastern peninsular Malaysia, is regularly hit by flooding, but this year's rains have been particularly bad. The flooding comes as communities in northwestern Malaysia mark the 10th anniversary of the devastating tsunami that hit on December 26, 2004.

images.alt_text: More than 100,000 people have been evacuated from their homes by authorities in five northern states of Malaysia hit by the Southeast Asian' nation's worst monsoon floods in decades.

site_title: Asian shares mixed in muted post-Christmas trade
summary: Asian shares were mixed on Friday due to muted trade across the region, with key bourses closed for the Christmas holidays. Tokyo slipped 0.17%, Shanghai edged up 0.18%, and Seoul rose 0.24%. Japan's industrial output dropped in November, while Chinese market sentiment improved following government support policies. Oil prices rose in Asia due to a surprise attack on Libya's main oil terminals, with West Texas Intermediate rising 28 cents to $56.12.

site_title: China extends high-speed rail network to Xinjiang
summary: China has extended its high-speed rail network to Xinjiang, a remote and poor region in the far west of the country, with a new line connecting Urumqi and Lanzhou. The 1,777-kilometer line reduces travel time between the two cities to under 12 hours and is designed to travel at 250 kilometers per hour. The move is part of China's efforts to boost connectivity and development in the region, which has faced ethnic and religious unrest. The line is the first high-speed railway in China's northwest and is expected to further integrate Xinjiang into the rest of the country.

site_title: Japan Nov jobless rate steady at 3.5%
summary: Japan's jobless rate remained steady at 3.5% in November, according to the internal affairs ministry. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate matched economists' median forecast. The jobs-to-applicants ratio increased to 1.12, the highest since May 1992. New job offers rose 1.2% from October but fell 4.4% from the previous year.

site_title: China a likely factor in North Korea cyber prowess: experts
summary: North Korea's alleged hacking of Sony Pictures has raised questions about its cyber capabilities, with experts suggesting China plays a significant role in facilitating the attack. China's telecommunications giant China Unicom provides and maintains all Internet links with North Korea, and thousands of North Korean hackers operate on Chinese soil. Despite North Korea's limited cyber infrastructure, it has an estimated 6,000 hackers, making it one of the world's top five countries in cyber warfare capability. China has consistently denied any involvement in aiding North Korean hacking, but analysts believe Beijing may have been behind the recent cyber attack against South Korea's nuclear power operator.

site_title: Over 2,500 pre-X'mas flights in the US delayed by fog
summary: Over 2,500 pre-Christmas flights in the US were delayed due to fog, with the majority occurring at New York's LaGuardia Airport. Two planes clipped each other while taxiing, but no passengers or crew were injured. The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating the incident. Disruptions were also seen at Philadelphia International Airport, where over 100 flights were cancelled. The weather was mild, giving fliers a break from frigid conditions typically associated with late-December travel.

site_title: Senior Chinese leader says Vietnam ties need "correct path"
summary: China's senior leader Yu Zhengsheng urged Vietnam to follow a "correct path" in their relations, aiming to improve mutual trust and build consensus amid tensions over the South China Sea. China claims 90% of the sea, while Vietnam and other countries have competing claims. Yu vowed to enhance communication and deal with bilateral ties strategically, following a visit commissioned by President Xi Jinping. Vietnam has been suspicious of China, particularly over the South China Sea, and anti-Chinese violence erupted in May. China seeks to make amends with Vietnam and resolve maritime disputes.

site_title: Brent holds above US$60 in thin Christmas trading
summary: Brent crude prices held above $60 a barrel in early Asian trade on December 26, 2014, driven by strong US economic data and a building supply glut. The US Labor Department reported a fourth consecutive week of falling jobless claims, while the Commerce Department's estimate of US third-quarter economic growth indicated the quickest pace in over a decade. However, a supply glut, indicated by a rise in US crude inventories, capped gains. Prices were trading at $60.40 a barrel at 0240 GMT, up 16 cents.

site_title: UK's Queen Elizabeth urges reconciliation in post-referendum Scotland
summary: Queen Elizabeth II urged reconciliation in post-referendum Scotland, referencing a World War One Christmas truce between British and German soldiers. In her Christmas Day broadcast, she acknowledged the divisions in Scotland following the 55-45 rejection of independence in a September referendum. The queen noted that reconciliation takes time and that peace and goodwill can have lasting power, but also acknowledged that sometimes it seems reconciliation stands little chance in the face of war and discord.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end flat
summary: Tokyo shares ended flat on Friday, edging up 0.06% to 17,818.96, as investors retreated ahead of Christmas. The Nikkei 225 index added 10.21 points, while the Topix index rose 0.44%. The lack of major bourses in operation contributed to the flat trading session.

site_title: Singapore to release advance GDP data on Jan 2
summary: Singapore will release advance GDP data for the fourth quarter and full-year 2014 on January 2. Economists expect a 2.3% year-on-year expansion in the fourth quarter and 3.0% growth for the year. This follows a quarterly survey by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, which showed consensus among economists. The release of advance GDP data is a key indicator of the country's economic performance.

site_title: Sony's 'Interview' draws US moviegoers who trumpet free speech
summary: US moviegoers flocked to theaters to watch "The Interview," a comedy about assassinating North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, on Christmas Day, despite threats of cyberattacks and cancellations. The film's release was backed by US President Barack Obama and Hollywood stars, and patrons praised freedom of expression. The movie drew sell-out crowds and received positive reviews, with many citing the importance of standing up against censorship. Despite North Korea calling it an "act of war," fans described the film as a funny and satirical movie with a message for America's foreign policy.

site_title: IPC Corporation to sell 2 hotels in Sapporo, Japan
summary: IPC Corporation is selling its two hotels in Sapporo, Japan, to GK Sapporo Holdings Tokumei Kumiai for 2.69 billion yen (approximately S$29.61 million). The hotels, nest HOTEL sapporo odori and nest HOTEL sapporo ekimae, will retain the "nest" brand and be managed by Nest Hotel Japan. The sale resulted in a net gain of approximately 950 million yen (approximately S$10.45 million) for IPC Corporation, according to their latest unaudited consolidated financial statements.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Japan industrial production falls 0.6% m-o-m in November
summary: Japan's factory production fell 0.6% in November, contrary to market expectations of a 0.8% rise. This marks the first decline in production after two consecutive months of increases. The Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry attributed the drop to "indecisive" fluctuations in industrial production.

site_title: Los Angeles, Long Beach ports act to reduce cargo pile-ups
summary: Los Angeles and Long Beach ports in Southern California are working to reduce cargo congestion that has slowed US import delivery. The ports, which handle 40% of US imports, have seen a shortage of truck trailers and changes in shipping patterns due to labour slowdowns and vessel-sharing alliances. The ports are seeking an antitrust exemption to work together on solutions, such as a joint repair facility and container arrangement system. This effort aims to alleviate congestion that has disrupted imports and exports with China and other Pacific Rim markets.

site_title: Hong Kong, Australia markets closed
summary: Hong Kong and Australia's financial markets are closed on December 26, 2014, due to a public holiday. No relevant market news is provided in the article.

site_title: Surprise 2.8% fall in S'pore Nov factory output
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector experienced a 2.8% year-on-year decline in November, contrary to expectations of a 0.3% rise. Output fell in all clusters except electronics and precision engineering, with the biomedical sector contracting 1.1% in October. The electronics cluster saw a 1.2% rise, but was not enough to offset declines in other sectors. The month-on-month contraction was 1.4%, and excluding biomedical manufacturing, output would have increased 1.6%. This marked a surprise to private-sector economists, who had expected a 0.4% rise.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.04 points to 1747.25. Volume reached 16.44 million lots worth RM3.91 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 48 to 47.

site_title: Santander expresses interest in Portugal's Novo Banco
summary: Spanish bank Santander has expressed interest in acquiring Portugal's Novo Banco, joining other potential bidders including Banco BPI and Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria. Novo Banco was capitalized with 4.9 billion euros after its predecessor Banco Espirito Santo collapsed under debt. The Bank of Portugal has launched the sale process, with potential bidders until December 31 to formally express interest. The actual bidding phase is expected to begin in the second quarter of 2015.

images.alt_text: Spanish bank Santander on Tuesday formalised its interest in acquiring Portugal's Novo Banco, with its Portuguese unit Santander-Totta saying: "Taking into account the reference terms of Novo Banco sale, Santander decided to present itself for the first phase of the process, which consists in the manifestation of interest."

site_title: China challenges India's polished diamond throne
summary: India's dominance in the world's diamond polishing market is being challenged by China's growing output. China's direct procurement of rough diamonds from African mines has boosted its net exports of polished diamonds by 72% to $8.9 billion, while India's exports rose 49% to $14 billion. In response, India is seeking help from Russia to defend its market share, with Russia's state-run diamond monopoly Alrosa signing deals to increase direct rough diamond deliveries to India. To compete, India is looking to streamline its tax and import rules, and build special notified zones for importing and re-exporting rough diamonds.

images.alt_text: India's long-held position as the world's top diamond polisher is being challenged by soaring output from China, compelling the south Asian country to seek help from ally and top rough diamond supplier Russia to defend its market share.

site_title: DBS, OCBC the main pillars as STI rises for sixth consecutive day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 13.4 points to 3,345.91, its sixth consecutive day, driven by DBS Group Holdings and Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation (OCBC). The index's recovery follows a 79-point drop on Tuesday due to oil-related concerns. The US market reached new highs, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average surpassing 18,000 and the S&P 500 hitting its 51st all-time high. Brokers attribute the STI's rise to funds capitalizing on US market gains.

site_title: SCCCI's 5 recommendations based on its Singapore Pre-Budget 2015 Survey
summary: The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) released five recommendations based on its Pre-Budget 2015 Survey. The recommendations include widening coverage of productivity and innovation credit schemes, reducing foreign worker costs, and providing targeted funding for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to venture into the Asean market. The SCCCI also urged the government to engage in more consultation with trade associations and businesses before introducing new policies. The survey, conducted from September to November, received responses from 356 companies, with 96.7% being SMEs, and 92.6% being decision-makers.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
Mr Thomas Chua Kee Seng, president of Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

site_title: Sarine shares continue to rise after clarification on profit expectations
summary: Sarine Technologies shares rose 1.8% in early trading on Friday after the company clarified that fourth-quarter revenue is expected to be in line or better than the third quarter. This follows a 10-month low of S$2.17 on Dec 23. The stock traded at S$2.28 on a volume of 121,000 shares. The clarification has contributed to the uptick in shares, which continues the trend since the low on Dec 23.

site_title: Weak Japan wages bode ill for Abe's aim of reviving economy
summary: Japan's wage earners saw their total cash earnings drop 1.5% annually in November, the first decline in nine months, and real wages fell 4.3% year-on-year, the 17th straight month. This marks a blow to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policies aimed at reviving the economy. Regular pay rose 0.2% for the sixth month in a row, but special payments and overtime pay declined. Abe urges major firms to raise base pay starting next April, but business leaders have vowed to do so.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on December 26, 2014, due to a lack of trading due to the Christmas holiday. The Nikkei 225 index was at 17,799.49, down 0.05% or 9.26 points. Currency rates were stable, with the dollar at 120.36 yen and the euro at 146.94 yen. Analysts expect the Nikkei to rise in the new year due to a recovering Japanese economy and lower oil prices. Japan's industrial output and core consumer inflation data showed a surprise drop and continued slowdown, respectively.

site_title: Arrest warrant sought for 'nut rage' heiress
summary: South Korean prosecutors have sought an arrest warrant for Korean Air heiress Cho Hyun-Ah, 40, who delayed a flight in 2014 due to a tantrum over snacks, sparking a national uproar. Cho faces charges including aviation safety law violation, coercion, and interference in duty. The incident, known as "nut rage," has been widely criticized, and Cho's arrest warrant is the latest development in the case.

site_title: Arson attack on Swedish mosque injures five
summary: An arson attack on a mosque in Eskilstuna, Sweden, injured five people on December 25, 2014. The fire started after an object was thrown through a closed window, and police are investigating the incident as aggravated arson. The attack occurred in the wake of Sweden's growing political crisis, sparked by the rise of the extreme right, including the anti-immigration Sweden Democrats. This incident marks the latest in a series of hate crimes targeting Muslims in Sweden, including a previous attack on a Stockholm mosque in January.

images.alt_text: An arsonist set fire to a mosque in central Sweden on Thursday injuring five people, police said, as the country grapples with a political crisis caused by the rise of the extreme right.

site_title: Pacnet's Fitch ratings may be upgraded if Telstra deal closes
summary: Fitch Ratings has placed Pacnet Limited on "rating watch positive" following Telstra's acquisition announcement, indicating a possible upgrade of Pacnet ratings if the deal closes and credit support is available. Pacnet's ratings reflect its low profitability, strong competition, weak financial position, and high execution risk of its data centre strategy. Fitch expects further improvement in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) and a more meaningful contribution from core data centres in 2015. A "stable outlook" is likely to be assigned if the deal does not close, but a possible upgrade is possible if the deal closes.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sarine, Wee Hur, Perennial Real Estate Holdings
summary: Sarine Technologies expects Q4 2014 revenues to be in line with or slightly better than Q4 2013, and is likely to be profitable, allowing a final dividend recommendation. Wee Hur Holdings acquired a Brisbane land plot for A$51.3 million, with additional land acquisition required to complete the deal. Perennial Real Estate Holdings transferred to the SGX Main Board, with a temporary odd lot counter set up for trading in board lots.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: UBS warns of risks from China's unhedged debt
summary: UBS warns that China's $1 trillion of unhedged foreign debt poses significant risks as forecasters predict bets against the US dollar will unwind in 2015. The renminbi is forecast to drop 5.7% next year due to the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes and the People's Bank of China's borrowing cost cuts. This could lead to a financial crisis similar to the 1997 Asian financial crisis, where firms struggled to repay debt as currencies slumped.

site_title: Paris dresses up its windows for the season
summary: Paris' iconic department stores, Printemps and Galeries Lafayette, have transformed their holiday windows into spectacular displays, featuring animated figurines and elaborate shows. Jean-Claude Dehix, known as the "Geppetto of the Grands Magasins," has been responsible for designing these displays for over four decades. This year, Dehix has installed 200 animated puppets across 24 windows, drawing crowds and blending traditional fairy tales with modern consumer culture. The displays have become an integral part of Parisian holiday tradition, showcasing the city's creativity and festive spirit.

site_title: China to beat energy intensity target in 2014: Xinhua
summary: China is on track to meet its 2014 target for reducing energy intensity, with energy usage per yuan of GDP expected to be 4.9% less than the previous year. The country aims to reduce energy intensity to 16% below 2010 levels by 2015, a goal that could be achieved earlier than expected. China has already cut outdated production capacity by 75 million tonnes in the steel sector and 570 million tonnes of cement over the past three years. This is part of the country's efforts to reduce energy waste, cut pollution, and slow greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: E-tailing turns small companies into exporters
summary: Online shopping is turning small businesses into exporters, but they face issues such as duty free limits and customs duties. Retailer Colleen Rast was hit with a US$150 customs bill on a $1,000 shipment from New Zealand, affecting her 20-25% overseas sales. A Nielsen survey predicts international online shopping will reach $300 billion by 2018. Small firms, like eBay's cross-border holiday transactions, are pushing for issues such as duty free limits and open Internet access in upcoming trade deals, including the US-European Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership.

site_title: Industry very much in the pink
summary: The biomedical sciences industry in Singapore remains promising, with companies restructuring, consolidating, and entering new growth markets. Despite a cautious outlook for the 2015 economy, the industry continues to expand, contributing 4-5% to GDP and employing 23,000 people. Mergers and acquisitions are driving consolidation, with companies seeking to enter new markets, restructure, or acquire new capabilities. The government has invested in biologics, medical technology, and digital health, with a focus on value creation and commercialization. Companies are adopting innovative production methods, such as next-generation biomanufacturing and continuous manufacturing, to reduce waste and costs.

site_title: Ezra and Swiber upbeat despite bond price fall
summary: Ezra and Swiber, two offshore marine companies, remain upbeat despite a fall in bond prices due to declining crude oil prices. Ezra's perpetual bonds have fallen to 92.375 cents on the dollar, while Swiber's have plummeted to 89.665 cents. Despite the challenges, both companies are confident in their ability to refinance debt and are working closely with their banks. Industry observers believe the spillover effects on other corporate bonds will be negligible, and the companies' fundamentals are still sound.

site_title: Saudi projects huge deficit as oil price drop bites
summary: Saudi Arabia has announced a 2015 budget with a huge deficit of $38.6 billion, marking the first deficit since 2011 and the largest ever for the kingdom. The deficit is due to a 50% drop in oil prices, with revenues expected to be $190.7 billion and spending at $229.3 billion. The government plans to boost spending by tapping into its vast financial reserves, but analysts predict a potentially much higher deficit of $200 billion.

site_title: TripAdvisor fined in Italy for fake reviews
summary: TripAdvisor has been fined 500,000 euros (approximately S$806,267) by an Italian regulator for failing to prevent false reviews on its site. The regulator called on TripAdvisor to stop publishing misleading information and gave the company 90 days to comply. The fine is one of the first times a review site has faced financial penalties in Europe or the US for failing to address potentially false reviews. TripAdvisor rejected the decision and plans to appeal, citing its efforts to combat fraud and confidence in its review systems.

site_title: Homebuilders lag in US real estate recovery
summary: US homebuilders continue to struggle in the real estate recovery, with demand for office, retail, and apartment properties outpacing home buying. Institutional investors have poured $18.9 billion into real estate investment trusts (Reits) and $1.1 billion into homebuilder stocks over the last eight years, with Reits gaining 65% since the end of the recession. The homebuilding industry's troubles date back to the housing crash, with annual residential construction starts below 1 million since 2007, and new single-family homes sold at an annualized rate of 438,000 in November.

site_title: Huawei's smartphone sales soar after copying Xiaomi's online strategy
summary: Huawei's smartphone sales have surged to 20 million units in just one year, thanks to its low-price Honor brand, which adopted an online-only strategy similar to Xiaomi Inc. The brand now accounts for a quarter of Huawei's 2014 shipment goal, helping the company overtake Xiaomi in global market share. Analysts warn that this strategy may lead to price wars and thin profit margins, affecting all manufacturers. Huawei aims to replicate Xiaomi's phenomenal growth, but the low-cost approach may also impact its own profitability.

site_title: China adapting Fed swaps as power tool
summary: China is expanding its foreign-exchange swap lines, worth up to $500 billion, to boost the renminbi's global role in trade and finance. The People's Bank of China has signed agreements with dozens of central banks, including those in Europe, Asia, and the Americas, to lend and borrow currencies quickly. China's objectives are to promote the yuan's use in international trade, deepen financial-market ties with key partners, and increase its strategic influence through economic and geopolitical means. The move is seen as a way for China to play offense, rather than defense, in the global economy.

site_title: US economic growth at fastest in 10 years
summary: The US economy experienced its fastest growth in over a decade, with a 5% annual rate in the third quarter, according to the Commerce Department. Strong consumer spending and investment by businesses contributed to the growth, with higher healthcare outlays and a narrower trade balance also playing a role. The improved data suggests the economy is moving to a higher gear, with economists expecting growth to decelerate somewhat in the fourth quarter but still predicting a strong year.

site_title: Uber takes patent office for ride on surge pricing
summary: Uber is taking the US patent office to court over its surge pricing system, claiming it as its own idea. However, the company's previous patent applications have been largely rejected, with 11 out of 16 filings deemed obvious or covering abstract ideas. The US Supreme Court has also ruled that abstract ideas, such as surge pricing, are not patentable. Despite this, Uber's patent filings can temporarily slow rivals and may serve a strategic purpose, but the tactic risks fuelling patent wars and potential costly lawsuits.

images.alt_text: Uber is taking the US patent office for a ride on surge pricing.

site_title: We'll drink to that, and here's why
summary: Wine has been intimately connected to celebration and worship across cultures and religions for thousands of years. From ancient Egypt to modern-day Christianity, wine has played a significant role in spiritual and communal practices. The strategic location of the elbow on the arm, as noted by Benjamin Franklin, allows for easy drinking of wine, which has led to its association with festivities and communal bonding. The "cult of wine" has been a staple of many cultures, including Judaism and Christianity, and its production and consumption have been tied to religious and cultural practices for centuries.

site_title: Oil drop may lead to US real estate slowdown
summary: US real estate markets, particularly energy-driven areas like Houston and Calgary, may experience a slowdown due to the 45% drop in oil prices since June. This decline is expected to negatively impact leasing and construction demand. Real estate investment trusts with heavy energy-related holdings are also underperforming, indicating a potential downturn in these markets.

site_title: Traders likely to store crude in tankers next year
summary: Global oil traders are likely to store crude in tankers next year due to a widening contango, making sea storage profitable for the first time since the financial crisis. Oil prices have plunged nearly 50% since June, but the economics of storing crude at sea have remained favorable. This shift is attributed to the widening supply glut and the decline in oil prices.

images.alt_text: Global oil traders are likely to store crude in tankers next year, as a widening contango makes large-scale storage at sea profitable for the first time since the financial crisis more than five years ago, industry sources said.

site_title: Japan inflation continues to slow in November
summary: Japan's core consumer inflation slowed to 2.7% in November, down from 2.9% in October, according to the internal affairs ministry. Excluding volatile food prices, the adjusted core consumer-price index rose 0.7% from a year earlier, the lowest since September 2013. This reading fell short of the Bank of Japan's 2.0% inflation target, despite efforts to break from deflation. The increase was largely driven by the 8.0% sales tax rate introduced in April.

images.alt_text: Japanese core consumer inflation continued to slow in November, official data showed Friday despite efforts by the government and central bank to make a clear break from deflation.

site_title: GIC unit buys into Bombay-listed Nirlon
summary: GIC affiliate Reco Berry has acquired a stake of up to 39.2% in Bombay-listed Nirlon Ltd., with a cash offer of 222 rupees (S$4.63) per share for an additional 28.4%. Assuming full take-up, Reco Berry will hold 62.6% of Nirlon, which owns a large-scale IT office park in Mumbai. The deal is part of Reco Berry's expansion into the Indian real estate market.

site_title: How do I gift thee? Let me Google the ways
summary: Google analyzed top trending shopping queries in major US cities during the 2014 holiday season, revealing regional preferences and cultural influences. site_title: US airlines rush to cover costly hedges
summary: US airlines, including Delta and Southwest, are rushing to cover losses due to falling oil prices, which have halved to five-year lows. To address this, carriers are holding meetings with brokers and consultants to strategize and potentially sell assets or change hedging prices. Despite the losses, Delta expects a $1.7 billion gain from lower fuel prices in 2015, while Southwest expects to cover only 20% of its fuel consumption with hedge contracts.

site_title: Asian stocks up on strong US data; China shares take a breather

summary: UPS and FedEx have limited air express deliveries to retailers after a surge in shipped packages during the Christmas shopping season. FedEx cited changes in demand due to slowdowns at West Coast ports, while UPS said its operations were going as planned. Both companies had previously stated they would refuse deliveries if volumes threatened to overload their systems. The restrictions were made in response to unplanned package volumes.

site_title: Barcelona Xmas markets shine on bravely
summary: Barcelona's Christmas markets, including the oldest in the world, Santa Lucia, have faced a decline in visitor turnout due to the economic crisis and bad weather. Despite this, organizers remain optimistic, with sales expected to drop only 10-15% and the historical tradition of the market expected to endure. The markets, which date back to the 18th century, now feature imported goods from China, but organizers believe the market will still thrive.

site_title: Fresh G-7 currency accord possible: Trichet
summary: Former European Central Bank president Jean-Claude Trichet suggests a "window of opportunity" for the G-7 to agree on a fresh accord against competitive devaluations, citing a convergence of central banks' inflation targets and practices. site_title: Anti-terror police arrest 2 in Sydney a week after cafe siege

site_title: Bitcoin beats hryvnia, rouble as the worst currency

The article concludes that the value of money remains tied to confidence, and the fragility of the financial system could be exposed in times of crisis.

site_title: A quieter year ahead for the palm oil sector
summary: Analysts expect a relatively muted year ahead for the palm oil sector, with crude palm oil prices expected to remain under pressure in the first quarter of 2015 due to an edible oil glut. Lower soyabean oil prices and volatile crude oil prices are seen as key factors. Despite this, some analysts, such as CIMB and UOB Kay Hian, peg CPO prices at RM2,400-2,500 in 2015, expecting a gradual recovery in subsequent quarters. Mainboard-listed players with younger plantations and higher yield prospects, such as First Resources and Bumitama Agri, are preferred by analysts.

site_title: Re-elected Abe appoints hawkish defence minister
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was re-elected and retained his cabinet, except for outgoing Defense Minister Akinori Eto, who was replaced by Gen Nakatani. Nakatani favors giving Japan a pre-emptive military strike capability, potentially alarming China. The appointment sets a "hawkish" tone for Abe's new administration.

site_title: Consumer spending in US beats forecast as petrol prices drop
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.6% in November, beating forecasts, as incomes increased 0.4% and petrol prices dropped. This growth, driven by surging employment and confidence, indicates the US economy is strengthening as the year ends. The improving outlook for household spending will spur growth this quarter and into 2015, despite a cooling global economy. Lower energy expenses are also subduing inflation, with the price index tied to consumer spending dropping 0.2% in November.

site_title: Singapore Nov industrial output seen rising 1.2% year-on-year
summary: Singapore's industrial production is expected to rise 1.2% year-on-year in November, according to a Reuters survey. The manufacturing sector expanded in November, but at a slower pace than in October, which recorded its strongest expansion in 3.5 years.

site_title: Russians rushing to lock in mortgages

Despite higher mortgage rates, the real estate market is seeing a boost, with property developers raising prices. The central bank's rate increase has led to a 19% decline in the rouble's value, and economists predict a recession next year.

site_title: The missing dolls

site_title: Americans expect pay rise as economy grows

The expansion follows a series of public commitments to increase private capital participation in the financial sector.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices dropped 34 US cents to US$56.78 for West Texas Intermediate and 31 US cents to US$61.38 for Brent crude in mid-morning trade on Wednesday. The US economy grew at a 5% rate in the third quarter, beating estimates, boosting hopes for energy use to rise. Oil prices have fallen 50% since June due to increased production and lacklustre growth, but analysts expect the US economy to grow 2.5% in 2014 and 3% in 2015, potentially prompting the Federal Reserve to hike interest rates earlier than expected.

site_title: Indie cinemas play leading role in Sony's 'Interview' comeback
summary: Sony Pictures has allowed independent cinemas to screen its film "The Interview," a lowbrow satire about assassinating North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un, after major theater chains backed out due to security concerns. The film, starring Seth Rogen and James Franco, was initially pulled by the studio following a cyberattack blamed on North Korea. Independent cinemas, such as those in Oakland, California, convinced Sony to let them screen the film, marking an atypical move by the studio.

site_title: Mitani's exit means sayonara to old fund management style
summary: Takahiro Mitani's departure from the Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) marks the end of an era in Japanese pension management. The 65-year-old former Bank of Japan official oversaw a major overhaul under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics, shifting the fund's asset mix to include more equities and foreign bonds. The changes, which include a new board structure and a high-profile hire as chief investment officer, aim to boost returns and keep pace with inflation. Mitani, who resisted changes initially, now says he's ready to move on, citing his age and desire for a quieter life.

images.alt_text: MR MITANI: A panel has recommended that his role as sole decision-maker at the GPIF should be replaced with a board structure.

site_title: Coke to cut up to 2,000 jobs in coming weeks: WSJ
summary: Coca-Cola Co plans to cut 1,000-2,000 jobs globally as part of its $3 billion cost-cutting programme, following a 14% drop in third-quarter profit. Job-cut notices will be sent to North American and international employees in late January, with the impact expected to be significant at headquarters and regional offices. The cuts are aimed at reducing costs and improving profitability, following a disappointing quarterly earnings report.

site_title: Two airliners clip wings in New York's LaGuardia Airport, no one injured
summary: Two commercial airliners, Southwest Airlines flight 449 and American Airlines flight 1104, clipped each other's wings while taxiing at LaGuardia Airport on Tuesday, injuring no passengers but damaging both Boeing 737 aircraft. Each plane had 143 passengers on board. The cause of the collision is unclear. More than 280 travelers had to change their plans due to the incident.

site_title: South Korea Dec consumer sentiment, inflation expectation both fall
summary: South Korea's consumer sentiment index fell to 102, the lowest in 20 months, and inflation expectations dropped to 2.6% in December, a record low. This decline in consumer sentiment and inflation expectations adds to concerns that the country's economy may be cooling, despite recent stimulus measures and interest rate cuts. The Bank of Korea attributed the slowdown to plunging global oil prices. Deflationary risks to the economy are increasing, according to some analysts.

site_title: Outraging Russia, Ukraine takes big step toward Nato
summary: Ukraine's parliament adopted a bill dropping the country's non-aligned status, a move aimed at joining NATO, in a historic vote. The move stoked Russia's anger ahead of talks to end the separatist war in eastern Ukraine. President Petro Poroshenko had vowed to seek Western military protection after the February ouster of a Moscow-backed president. The decision marks a significant step toward Ukraine's integration with Western military alliances, despite potential backlash from Russia.

site_title: Dollar bulls get early Christmas present after strong US GDP
summary: The US dollar surged to its highest level in nearly nine years against a basket of major currencies on December 24, 2014, following strong US economic growth. The dollar index reached 120.82 yen, a 7-1/2 year high, while the euro sank to a 28-month low of $1.2165. This move was attributed to market expectations of an interest rate hike, sparked by the strong GDP growth.

site_title: China to crack down on pollution with tougher limits, heavier fines
summary: China plans to revise its air pollution law, imposing stricter limits and heavier fines. The revised law would set standards for vehicles, the coal industry, and heavy-polluting manufacturing, with fines of up to 1 million yuan (S$212 million) for exceeding emission limits. The law also includes an early-warning system and contingency procedures for pollution spikes in affected areas. The move aims to reduce smog that takes hundreds of thousands of lives each year, with the government battling to address the issue. The revised law is expected to come into force on January 1.

site_title: US: Dow ends above 18,000 for first time on strong GDP report
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Dow closing above 18,000 for the first time ever and the S&P 500 reaching a record high, following an unexpectedly strong third-quarter US economic growth report. The report showed a 5% annual GDP growth rate, its quickest in 11 years. The rally led to a broad market gain, with nine of the ten primary S&P 500 sectors higher, while the Nasdaq biotech index fell 4.6%.

site_title: France boosts security after spate of brutal attacks
summary: France has stepped up security nationwide after a series of brutal attacks, killing one man and injuring 25, in the past three days. The attacks, which included a knife assault on police and two car rampages, have raised concerns about the threat of Islamic extremism. Prime Minister Manuel Valls has increased security patrols and deployed 200-300 extra soldiers, while urging the French to remain calm. The motives behind the attacks remain unclear, with authorities suggesting they may be the work of unstable individuals rather than coordinated terrorist acts.

site_title: Oil up on stronger-than-expected US GDP growth data
summary: Oil prices surged by over $2 a barrel on Tuesday after the US GDP data showed the fastest rate of US economic growth in 11 years, bolstering expectations for crude demand. Oil rose 3% after the release of the data, with Brent settling up $1.58 to $61.69 a barrel. However, the gains were pared after preliminary data showed a build of over 5 million barrels in US crude stockpiles. The US Energy Information Administration will release official inventory data on Wednesday.

site_title: Australia: Shares slightly higher as iron ore slump offsets US fervour
summary: Australian shares edged higher on Christmas Eve, rising 0.2% as investors took a breather in a shortened session, despite falling iron ore prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 11.68 points higher after US stocks reached a record high, with insurers and mining giants leading gains. However, shares like Telstra slipped due to concerns over its purchase of Pacnet.

images.alt_text: Australian shares edged higher on Wednesday as investors took a breather in a shortened Christmas Eve session and falling iron ore prices undercut an upbeat lead from Wall St trading at a record high.

site_title: Pound falls on weak data, euro at 28-month low
summary: The pound fell to its weakest since September 2013 due to weak UK growth data, easing pressure on the Bank of England to raise interest rates. The euro dropped to a 28-month low of $1.2211 after Greek lawmakers failed to elect a president, potentially leading to early elections and a Syriza party takeover.

site_title: Consumers give UK 7th straight quarter of growth
summary: The UK economy experienced its seventh consecutive quarter of growth in the three months to end-September, driven by household spending that rose 0.9% and accounted for almost all of the 0.7% growth. This is the most significant increase in consumer spending in over four years. The growth was despite a slowdown in exports and a decline in investment.

images.alt_text: Falling oil prices and slowing inflation are helping to support domestic demand, the main driver of Britain's economy this year.

site_title: Moody's downgrades Met Opera's credit rating
summary: Moody's Investors Service downgraded the Metropolitan Opera's credit rating to Baa1 from A3, citing the company's weakened financial profile, including a $22 million deficit and low cash reserves. The downgrade was also influenced by the Met's decision to use its Chagall murals as collateral for loans, which gave Bank of America a secured interest in the paintings. The Met's general manager, Peter Gelb, said the company is implementing a plan to balance its budget and increase its endowment, but Moody's remains uncertain about the plan's success.

site_title: Australian government targeted as anti-terror police arrest two there
summary: Australian counter-terror police have arrested two men in Sydney, one allegedly in possession of documents related to a planned attack on government targets. The arrests follow a series of pre-dawn raids in September and come amid concerns about the radicalization of youths and the influx of Australians fighting with the Islamic State group. The 20-year-old is accused of possessing documents designed to facilitate a terrorist attack, while the 21-year-old breached a control order. The arrests follow warnings by Prime Minister Tony Abbott of heightened "terrorist chatter" after a fatal cafe siege in Sydney last week.

images.alt_text: Two men have been seized in Sydney with one allegedly in possession of documents connected to a planned terrorist attack on government targets, police said Wednesday.

site_title: Small is big for hedge funds in 2014 as Mumbai fund is top performer
summary: Small hedge funds outperformed their larger counterparts in 2014, with Mumbai-based Alchemy Capital Management's US$53 million fund gaining 63% through November. Other top performers included San Francisco-based funds EcoR1 Capital Fund and venBio Select Fund, as well as smaller funds managed by Paul Mulvaney and Darren Upton. In contrast, industry titans such as Paul Tudor Jones and John Paulson struggled to keep pace, with average returns through November at around 4%. The results highlight the potential benefits of smaller, more focused funds that take bigger risks.

site_title: Greek PM still short of votes in second round of presidential poll
summary: Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaras failed to secure the required votes in the second round of presidential polling, necessitating a final round next week. Samaras' nominee, Stavros Dimas, received 168 votes, in line with expectations. This outcome may prompt a snap general election unless Dimas secures the additional 12 votes needed.

site_title: Google self-driving car prototype ready to hit the road
summary: Google has announced that its first completed prototype of a self-driving car is ready for road testing in Northern California. The prototype, a battery-powered vehicle without a steering wheel, accelerator, or brake pedal, will be tested during the holidays. This marks a shift for Google away from adapting existing vehicles, with plans to pioneer individual transport. The top speed of the prototype is 40 kilometers per hour, and it is designed for utility, not luxury. This development comes as several carmakers work on autonomous or semi-autonomous features, with some predicting that self-driving cars could be as transformative as the smartphone.

site_title: Huawei's smartphone sales shoot up after copying Xiaomi's online strategy
summary: Huawei's smartphone sales surged to 20 million in just one year, thanks to its low-price Honor brand, which copied Xiaomi's online-only strategy. The brand, which was launched last December, has become a quarter of Huawei's 2014 shipment goal. Analysts warn that the low-cost strategy may lead to price wars and thin profit margins for all manufacturers, except Samsung and Apple. To widen its profit margin, Huawei plans to target wealthier consumers with high-spec products in developed markets like Europe.

images.alt_text: China's Huawei Technologies Co Ltd has taken sales of its low-price Honor brand of smartphones to 20 million from 1 million in just one year, hitting pay dirt with the disruptive online-only strategy it copied from smaller upstart Xiaomi Inc.

site_title: SGX seeking legal advice over market disruption, sources say
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is seeking legal advice over a recent market disruption linked to Keppel's data hub, which caused a three-hour shutdown of SGX's securities and derivatives trading systems in November. This is considered the most serious trading outage in recent years and the most widespread stoppage since 2007. The power outage at Keppel's data centre has raised concerns about the reliability of the country's financial infrastructure.

site_title: Maersk CEO: low oil price may lead to closures
summary: Maersk Oil CEO Nils Smedegaard Andersen warns that the current oil price of around $60 per barrel could lead to site closures and cost cuts, reducing revenue by a third from 2013 levels. Andersen aims to reduce operational costs and exploration costs, focusing on low-cost areas for new oil exploration. He believes the oil price will stabilize at $70-$80 per barrel by the end of next year, driven by a global economic recovery.

site_title: S'pore prices dip for first time in 5 yrs
summary: Singapore's headline inflation fell to -0.3% in November, marking the country's first technical deflation in five years. Economists describe this as a blip and do not expect it to last, citing stable core inflation and wage pressures. They attribute the decline to base effects and fluctuations in car Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums, rather than a lack of demand. Forecasts predict headline inflation to rise above 1% in Q2 2015 and core inflation to stay above 2% in the second half of next year.

site_title: Sony Pictures moves to release 'The Interview' in about-face
summary: Sony Pictures has decided to release its comedy film "The Interview" in some US theaters on Christmas Day, reversing its decision to cancel the film after a cyberattack was blamed on North Korea. The film, starring Seth Rogen and James Franco, was initially pulled from release due to threats from hackers who warned of a September 11-style attack. President Barack Obama and others praised Sony's decision, saying it allowed people to make their own choices about the film. The studio plans to screen the film in a limited number of theaters, with some theaters also offering video-on-demand.

site_title: Priceless: the inefficient, but merry economics of Christmas
summary: A Christmas gift is often more valuable when given freely, rather than bought and sold, as it reflects affection and worth, rather than mere self-interest. According to economist Joel Waldfogel, giving gifts can be inefficient due to the risk of not perfectly matching the recipient's preferences, but this overlooks the extra value added by the affection behind the gift. In reality, many human interactions, including Christmas giving, are motivated by higher goals than mere self-interest, and limiting consideration to market transactions can have detrimental effects on mental health and social trust.

site_title: Documenting change in China through art
summary: Chinese artist Yang Fudong's solo exhibition, Incidental Scripts, at the NTU Centre for Contemporary Art, showcases four key works, including a full-length feature film, "An Estranged Paradise" (2002). The exhibition blurs the lines between film, art, and documentation, exploring how a film can be a medium in the visual art world. Yang, trained in landscape painting, views his work as art rather than film, and his films often capture change in China, such as the lifting of the Bamboo Curtain in the 1990s.

site_title: Arms and the Man, led by technology
summary: US Defence Secretary nominee Ashton Carter's background in physics and technology highlights the shift from manpower to technology in modern warfare. This trend erodes the democratic check on government, as seen in the erosion of civil rights during wartime. Unlike past wars, where fighting men's contributions to collective defence shored up political rights, today's wars rely on a small number of specialised warriors, leaving a gap in the democratic system. This shift underscores the need for a re-evaluation of the role of technology and government in modern warfare.

site_title: Economists put a Happy New Year on their wishlists, eye optimistic forecasts
summary: Economists are optimistic about 2015, predicting a 3.5% global economic growth, the first increase in five years, driven by factors such as a 40% decline in oil prices, easing monetary policies, and improving consumer spending. The US is expected to experience its fastest growth in a decade, while the euro area may see a rebound in growth due to a weaker currency and aggressive ECB policies. Other countries, including China, India, and South Korea, are also expected to grow, with some economists predicting a 4% global growth rate.

site_title: Facebook accused of yielding to Moscow pressure for blocking page
summary: Facebook blocked an event page promoting a demonstration in support of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, citing Russia's Internet monitor, Roskomnadzor, as the reason. The page had gathered over 12,000 attendees before being deleted. Navalny faces up to 10 years in prison and has been under house arrest since February. Facebook's decision has sparked accusations of censorship and yielded to government pressure, raising concerns about the free flow of information and potential market-share loss.

site_title: China's shadow banking adapts and grows as rules tighten
summary: China's shadow banking sector continues to grow despite efforts to regulate it, with new players taking advantage of loopholes to prosper. The sector has expanded to roughly 45% of conventional banking loans, with brokerages and fund management companies pooling retail investor funds or investing bank funds. Authorities have tightened regulations, but the sector's rapid growth poses risks of debt buildup in the slowing economy. New statistics are needed to measure shadow banking, and experts warn of a build-up of risks in the banking system.

site_title: As oil gets cheap, gold loses its lustre as an inflation hedge
summary: Gold, once seen as a reliable hedge against inflation, has lost its allure as oil prices plummet and the US economy is "disinflating". Investors are shifting out of gold funds, with holdings at a 5-year low, and speculators remain bullish despite a 44% drop in oil prices this year. The US Federal Reserve's move to raise interest rates is also expected to pressure gold prices, with Goldman Sachs forecasting a drop to $1,050 by next December.

site_title: Director Tim Burton and actress Helena Bonham Carter split: People
summary: Movie director Tim Burton and actress Helena Bonham Carter have separated after 13 years together. The couple, who never married, have remained friends and co-parents to their children, Billy, 11, and Nell, 7. They met in 2001 when Burton directed her in "Planet of the Apes" and worked together on several movies, including "Sweeney Todd" and "Alice in Wonderland." The pair parted earlier this year, with Carter's representative requesting respect for their privacy and that of their children.

site_title: Tiny airport jostling for a sliver of Atlanta's air traffic
summary: The Paulding Northwest Atlanta Airport, a small two-lane airport 50 miles from Hartsfield-Jackson, is seeking to introduce commercial flights, but faces opposition from Delta Air Lines and the city of Atlanta. Despite the airport's supporters claiming a possible start of flights late next year, the Federal Aviation Administration's decision has been stalled due to objections from residents and environmental concerns. The airport's backers, Propeller Investments, are determined to push forward with their plans, but the challenges and lawsuits from Delta and residents may hinder their progress.

site_title: Informal capital controls stem rouble's slide
summary: Russia's rouble hit a two-week high against the dollar on Tuesday, reaching 52.88 to the dollar, amid informal capital control measures designed to prevent a repeat of the 1998 financial crisis. The government pressured state-owned exporters to sell dollars, while the central bank installed supervisors at major state banks. Analysts say the measures are a softer version of capital controls, but do not believe President Putin will break his pledge to avoid full-fledged controls. The rouble has recovered from an all-time low of 80 per dollar in December, but economists forecast a 3.6% economic shrinkage next year.

images.alt_text: Forex prices outside a Moscow currency exchange bureau on Dec 16. The rouble dived to an all-time low in mid-December.

site_title: Russian crisis makes East European companies fret over 1998 redux
summary: Eastern European companies are concerned about the economic impact of Russia's currency crisis, reminiscent of the 1998 default. With exports to Russia accounting for less than 5% of their total trade, companies are feeling the pinch. The rouble's decline has led to increased costs, reduced sales, and potential financial losses. Industries such as appliance makers, pharmaceutical companies, and machinery factories are hurting, with shares of major companies like Gorenje and Krka Group declining significantly. The crisis is expected to erase 0.3-1 percentage point from GDP growth across Central and Eastern Europe in 2015.

site_title: Can MTP work for Singapore's stock market?
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have decided to implement a minimum trading price (MTP) of 20 cents per share in March 2015 to address excessive speculation and market manipulation. However, critics argue that this could lead to more downside risks and difficulties for issuers to raise funds. The SGX and MAS have been advised to reconsider the implementation and consult other market players.

site_title: Front opens in US biotech price war
summary: Express Scripts, the largest US manager of prescription drug plans, has taken an aggressive stance in price negotiations with pharmaceutical firms, blocking Gilead's hepatitis C treatment and excluding it from its list of covered medicines. This move is seen as a sign that other major biotechnology players will face steeper US pricing pressure from insurers. The biotechnology industry's two-year run of riches may stall, with shares in Amgen, Biogen, and Celgene falling over 2% on the news. The move could lead to reduced profits at Gilead and other pharmaceutical companies, and may prompt other companies to discount their prices.

site_title: Jail for former HK chief secretary, Sun Hung Kai's Thomas Kwok
summary: Former Hong Kong Chief Secretary Rafael Hui was jailed for 7.5 years on five graft charges, including misconduct in a public office, making him the highest-ranking official in Hong Kong's history to be convicted of taking bribes. Hui was also ordered to pay a fine of HK$11.182 million. Joint chairman of Sun Hung Kai, Thomas Kwok, was sentenced to five years for conspiracy to commit misconduct in a public office, while his brother Raymond was cleared of all charges. The case has deepened anger at cosy ties between officialdom and big business in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: From left: Rafael Hui, Hong Kong's former chief secretary; Thomas Chan, former executive board member of Sun Hung Kai Properties (SHKP); and Thomas Kwok, former co-chairman of SHKP, arrive at the High Court in a prison van in Hong Kong on Monday.

site_title: Privately-owned Aussie firm eyes S'pore bus deal
summary: A privately-owned Australian firm, Busways, is eyeing Singapore's inaugural public bus contract, competing against 13 other companies. Busways, founded in 1942, is seeking to build a long-term presence in Singapore and is interested in the government's contracting model, which bears revenue risk. The company believes its corporate culture of efficiency and customer-centric approach will set it apart from larger rivals. Busways has a track record of delivering high-quality services, including a contract in Western Sydney, and is confident it can work effectively with the Singaporean authorities.

site_title: Time running out on mileage runs for fliers
summary: Airlines are shifting their frequent-flier programs to focus on minimum fare spending rather than flight distances, making it more difficult for travelers to accumulate miles through mileage runs. Starting next year, United and Delta will require customers to spend a minimum amount with the airline to achieve elite status, increasing the threshold from $2,500 to $3,000 for lower ranks and $15,000 for the highest. This change is expected to make mileage runs, which involve flying cheaply to accumulate miles, less effective.

site_title: S'pore VC firm invests US$3m in India startup
summary: Singapore-based venture capital firm BlueHill has invested US$3 million in Indian startup Triotech Solutions, boosting its remittance business by expanding its Mobile Money Transfer Service to 40,000 post offices across India. The investment will simplify the process of instant money transfer via an app, allowing those without bank accounts to use the service. This marks the first round of funding for Triotech and highlights BlueHill's interest in the rapidly growing Indian startup economy.

site_title: STI drifts sideways after 4-day climb
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended with a net gain of 1.55 points at 3,332.51 on Tuesday, after a 4-day climb of 115 points or 3.6%. Trading volume was low at 993 million units worth S$778 million, with most of the gains coming from bank stocks, particularly UOB. Analysts warn of a fragile market due to weak oil prices, economic sanctions, and high volatility in emerging markets.

site_title: Centurion, Lian Beng to build 7,900-bed workers dorm
summary: Centurion Corporation and Lian Beng Group have collaborated to develop a 7,900-bed workers' accommodation in Jalan Papan, catering to process industry workers. The facility will also feature a 3,000 sqm training centre and recreational facilities. The project, valued at an undisclosed amount, is expected to be completed by mid-2016 and will be operated by Centurion-Lian Beng (Papan). This marks the second joint venture between the two companies, following the completion of Westlite Mandai.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Dow hits historic high on strong Q3 GDP
summary: The Dow Jones index reached a historic high of 18,020.19 on Tuesday, driven by a stronger-than-expected 5% annual GDP growth rate for the third quarter. The report beat expectations, with consumer spending and business spending contributing to the growth. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with the S&P reaching its 50th record high of the year. The strong GDP growth and consumer spending could lead to the Federal Reserve raising interest rates in mid-2015, and economists may lift their GDP estimates for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Alibaba says it removed 90 million fake listings before IPO
summary: Alibaba removed 90 million fake product listings from its e-commerce platforms before its IPO, spending $160.7 million to block counterfeit goods. The company aims to build credibility and limit risks of lawsuits as it faces scrutiny for selling counterfeit goods. Alibaba has penalized 131,000 sellers and cooperated with Chinese law enforcement in over 1,000 counterfeiting cases, resulting in 400 suspect arrests. The company's efforts come as China is known for its extensive availability of counterfeit merchandise, and Alibaba seeks to maintain its reputation as a major player in the global e-commerce market.

site_title: Rouble swap signal shows China swooping in as emergency lender
summary: China is expanding its role as a lender of last resort, providing $24 billion in currency swaps to financially strapped countries, including Russia, Argentina, and Venezuela. The move aims to bolster China's influence in the global economy and cut into the IMF's traditional role. Analysts speculate that China's terms are focused on securing its interests in resource-rich countries, rather than solely on providing aid. China has provided billions in loans to these countries, including a $47 billion loan to Venezuela, and has signed currency-swap agreements with 28 other central banks.

site_title: Pace of property sales at auctions quickens in fourth quarter: JLL
summary: In the fourth quarter, the pace of property sales at auctions in Singapore quickened, with 90% of properties sold at their first listing, up from 54% in the second quarter. The total value of sold properties at auctions surged 251% year-over-year to S$13.7 million, driven by a narrowing expectation gap between buyers and sellers. Mortgagee sales made up half of total sales value, and experts expect a steady rise in mortgagee sales next year, contributing to a similar pace of sales at auctions.

site_title: Arab Opec sources see oil back above US$70 by end-2015
summary: Arab Opec members expect global oil prices to rebound to $70-$80 per barrel by the end of 2015 as a global economic recovery boosts demand, according to delegates. This indicates a potential stabilization in the oil market, with some speculating that a return to $100 may not be imminent. The forecast comes as the cartel assesses the medium-term outlook, with oil demand expected to remain trimmed for the next four years.

site_title: Volatility turns overseas investors off Shanghai-HK bourse link
summary: The Shanghai-HK bourse link has seen a 26% surge in the Shanghai Composite Index since China loosened access to its stocks in November, but overseas investors are turning away due to volatility. Professionals warn the advance has gone too far, too fast, making it hard to determine when to buy or sell. Foreigners have passed up on daily allowances to buy mainland shares, with gains accompanied by wild price swings in four years. The skepticism has led to a lacklustre interest in the bourse link, with gains exceeding double those of the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index in Hong Kong.

site_title: Telstra buys Pacnet for US$697m to boost expansion in Asia
summary: Telstra has acquired Pacnet Ltd for US$697 million, expanding its presence in Asia. The deal, expected to be completed by mid-2015, includes Pacnet's submarine cables, data centre network, and major customers. The acquisition will help Telstra become a leading provider of enterprise services to multinational companies and carriers in the region. This move follows Telstra's previous asset sales, including a Hong Kong wireless carrier and a domestic directory business. The deal gives Telstra ownership of over 46,000 kilometres of submarine cable from Asia to the US, boosting its growth strategy in the region.

site_title: Wanda chief may top Forbes China Rich List again
summary: Wang Jianlin, China's richest man, may regain his position at the top of Forbes China Rich List after Dalian Wanda Commercial Properties raised $3.7 billion in an IPO, valuing the firm at $28 billion and Wanda Group at $12.5 billion. Wang owns over 98% of Wanda Group, and his son, Wang Sicong, holds the remaining 2%. Wang's success is attributed to his business acumen, not government ties, despite being close to Beijing and holding multiple official titles.

site_title: Latin America's biggest carrier banks on new identity to save sales
summary: Latin America's largest carrier, Latam Airlines Group, is rebranding itself as a highly risky move to reverse its declining fortunes.
