site_title: FTSE China A50 Futures Index outperforms global indices in December
summary: The FTSE China A50 Futures Index outperformed global indices in December, with a 36.36% price change, surpassing the S&P 500 Index (0.98%) and the FTSE 100 Index (-3.09%). The index's daily turnover averaged US$4.6 billion, and its volatility jumped to over 60% in December. This is in contrast to the Hang Seng Index (-4.05%) and major international equity indices.

site_title: Tata, Singapore Air's full-service airline to take off on Jan 9
summary: Singapore Airlines' Indian joint venture, Vistara, will begin operations on January 9 with a fleet of new Airbus A320-200s. The full-service airline will initially offer flights to Mumbai and Ahmedabad. The launch comes as the Indian aviation sector faces challenges, with budget carrier SpiceJet struggling for survival. Vistara aims to add a deep-pocketed player to the competitive market, which sees most operators losing money.

site_title: Movie world fears for freedom of speech as North Korea parody pulled
summary: Sony cancelled the release of "The Interview" after hackers, believed to be linked to North Korea, threatened to harm moviegoers if the film was shown. The decision sparked concerns about freedom of speech, with some praising Sony's caution and others criticizing the studio for caving to threats. The US State Department defended the right to free expression, while President Barack Obama said there was no credible evidence of threats. The film's fate remains uncertain, with some predicting it may be released online despite the cancellation.

site_title: White House releases snapshot of plan to rate US colleges
summary: The White House has released a draft plan to rate US colleges based on performance, intake of low-income students, completion rates, affordability, employment prospects, and student loan repayment rates. The plan aims to improve job prospects for college students and curb rising student loan debt. Colleges will be classified as high-, low-, or middle-performing, and the Education Department will seek public comments on the plan. The final rating system is expected to be implemented by the 2015-2016 academic year.

site_title: PSA partners three firms to jointly construct and operate new Jakarta container terminal
summary: PSA International has partnered three firms to jointly construct and operate a new container terminal at Jakarta's Tanjung Priok Port. The new terminal, PT New Priok Container Terminal One, will have an annual handling capacity of 1.5 million TEUs and a 16-metre draft. The partnership includes Mitsui & Co, Nippon Yusen Kabushiki Kaisha (NYK Line), and PT Pelabuhan Indonesia II (Persero). The terminal aims to support Indonesia's growing economy and facilitate expanding maritime trade, leveraging PSA's global expertise and training skilled port professionals.

site_title: HKMA says probe found no evidence of FX rigging
summary: Hong Kong's de facto central bank, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), has concluded an 18-month investigation into 10 banks' foreign exchange trading operations, finding no evidence of FX rigging. However, individual traders at Standard Chartered and Deutsche Bank were identified as engaging in "inappropriate" behavior. The HKMA warned banks to ensure the integrity of the FX market in Hong Kong, despite a global investigation into the $5-trillion-a-day FX market resulting in $4.3 billion in penalties for six major banks last month.

site_title: Seoul: Shares power to 2-1/2 week high on Fed optimism; won flat
summary: South Korean shares surged 1.7% to a 2-1/2 week high on Friday, driven by the US Federal Reserve's optimistic economic assessment and pledge to be patient in raising interest rates. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 1,929.98 points. The won remained flat, closing at 1,102.0 to the dollar. The rally came after a four-day losing streak.

site_title: Japan govt raises view on capex, output; economy in recovery albeit weakness
summary: Japan's government has raised its view of business investment and factory output, citing moderate recovery despite some weakness. The Cabinet Office stated the economy is in a moderate recovery, with factory output bottoming out, and business investment largely flat. However, private consumption remains weak due to a declining consumer confidence. The Bank of Japan also reported a moderate recovery, with solid capital spending planned by big firms. The economic recovery remains a challenge for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's plans to pull Japan out of deflation.

site_title: Up to 11 dead in Japan snow storms: reports
summary: Up to 11 people have died in Japan due to a severe snow storm, with strong winds and heavy snowfall disrupting travel and cutting off isolated communities. The storm, caused by a powerful area of low pressure, has dumped over 200 centimeters of snow in some areas and is expected to continue. Hazardous driving conditions have led to hundreds of accidents, and public transport networks have been severely affected. The Japan Meteorological Agency warned of the risk of further avalanches and tidal surges, with people in coastal areas being warned of the danger of high waves.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end 2.39% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 2.39% on Friday, following sharp gains on Wall Street and support from the dollar's strength. The Nikkei 225 index climbed 411.35 points to 17,621.40, while the Topix index rose 2.42% to 1,409.61.

site_title: India's 2014/15 GDP growth seen at around 5.5%: finance ministry report
summary: India's economy is expected to grow at around 5.5% in the fiscal year to March 2015, according to a finance ministry report. This would mark an improvement from two consecutive years of below 5% growth. The country's economy grew 5.5% in the first six months of the fiscal year, surpassing the forecast. The growth is a positive indicator for the country's economic prospects.

site_title: India's Sonia Gandhi hospitalised for infection
summary: Sonia Gandhi, 68, India's opposition Congress party head, has been hospitalized for a respiratory infection. She was admitted to New Delhi's Ganga Ram Hospital on Thursday evening and her condition is now stable. This is the second time she has been hospitalized in recent years, following a similar illness in 2013. Gandhi's health and private life are closely guarded secrets, but her family's influence in Indian politics remains significant.

site_title: Australia: Shares post biggest one-day gain since July 2013
summary: Australian shares surged 2.5% on Friday, the largest one-day gain since July 2013, following the Federal Reserve's promise of patience in raising US interest rates. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 127.8 points to 5,338.6, with all sectors advancing. This two-day rally resulted in the index's best weekly performance in eight weeks, rising 2.3%.

site_title: Japan finance minister: hope Russia to prevent recurrence of 1998 crisis
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso expressed hope that Russia will prevent a financial crisis similar to the 1998 crisis by addressing sharp falls in the rouble. Aso stated that despite a significant drop in oil prices, they are still high compared to the past. He anticipated that the Russian government would take measures to avoid turmoil, unlike in 1998.

site_title: Mermaid Maritime secures new 2-year contract worth US$50 million
summary: Mermaid Maritime secured a 2-year contract worth US$50 million with an international fabrication and installation contractor for subsea construction support in the Gulf of Thailand, starting in April 2015. The contract is valued at US$50 million and spans over 130 days per year for 2015 and 2016, serving a major international upstream oil and gas operator.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of a subsea construction vessel.

site_title: Thai economic recovery may not be as strong as expected: central bank
summary: Thailand's central bank expects the economy to recover next year, driven by government spending, but growth might not be as strong as anticipated. The Bank of Thailand cut its economic growth forecasts, now predicting 1.5% expansion this year and 4.8% in 2015. The central bank maintained its key interest rate at 2.0% and reserves "space" for a potential rate change. The baht's value is stable, but the central bank has measures in place to curb any excessive movements.

site_title: China pilot jailed over crash that killed 44: report
summary: A Chinese court sentenced pilot Qi Quanjun to three years in prison for causing the 2010 Henan Airlines crash that killed 44 people in heavy fog. Qi was found guilty of "causing a major airline accident" after deciding to land without proper visibility. The crash was China's worst since 2004 and highlighted safety concerns in the country's rapidly expanding airline market. Qi survived with severe facial injuries but was unable to speak.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 1.43% higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.43% at the open on Friday, adding to the previous day's advance, following a strong lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index increased 326.06 points to 23,158.27. This follows a rally in US stocks, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Russia's parliament rushes through bill boosting banking capital
summary: Russia's lower house of parliament passed a draft law boosting the banking sector's capital by up to 1 trillion roubles (S$21.7 billion) in response to a dramatic slide in the rouble and Western sanctions over the Ukraine crisis. The bill now needs to be passed by the upper house and signed into law by President Vladimir Putin. The move aims to increase banks' capital adequacy ratios and reduce their cost of funding.

site_title: BOJ stands pat, offers brighter view on economy
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary settings unchanged, sticking to its pledge to increase base money at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen ($673 billion). The decision was seen as a sign that no immediate expansion of stimulus is expected. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda offered a more upbeat view on the economy, citing moderate recovery trends despite the effect of the April sales tax hike waning. The decision reverses the unexpected expansion of monetary stimulus in October, which was seen as a response to slower-than-expected economic growth.

site_title: Uber driver in Boston charged with kidnapping and rape
summary: A Boston Uber driver, Alejandro Done, has been charged with kidnapping and rape of a woman who used the service on Dec 6. Done, who passed a background check, pleaded not guilty in Cambridge District Court. Uber has been working closely with law enforcement and will assist the investigation. This incident follows an alleged rape of a passenger in New Delhi, India, where Uber has been banned in several cities.

site_title: Singapore companies may miss corporate governance compliance deadlines
summary: Singapore-listed companies may miss corporate governance compliance deadlines, particularly in board independence. Only 41.6% of firms have met the requirements, with 376 firms still to comply. Companies have also been slow to disclose executive directors' exact remuneration. The latest Governance and Transparency Index (GTI) 2014 analysis found room for improvement in areas such as director independence and executive pay disclosure. Companies have until 2020 to comply fully with board independence guidelines, despite being required to align with the Code by the end of 2017.

site_title: Apple co-founder Wozniak sceptical on smartwatches, Google Glass
summary: Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak expressed skepticism about smartwatches and Google Glass, cautioning that no company can guarantee their success. He believes smartwatches are disappointing and should not replace smartphones, and thinks Google Glass is a great product that will not succeed due to its high cost and unclear benefits. Wozniak praises Apple CEO Tim Cook for breaking away from Steve Jobs' "dogma" and allowing innovation, but expects Apple to enter new markets late, unlike in the past.

site_title: Lower oil prices expected to boost Asian demand growth in 2015
summary: Lower oil prices are expected to boost Asian demand growth in 2015, with spot interest for diesel picking up in countries like Vietnam, Philippines, and Indonesia. Asia's oil demand is forecast to grow 660,000 barrels per day to 31.11 million bpd, driven by refining capacity additions and low oil prices. Demand growth is expected to outpace supply, with refining margins projected to improve to US$4.50 a barrel next year.

images.alt_text: Lower oil prices could boost demand in Asia in 2015, with spot interest for diesel, Asia's most widely used fuel, picking up in countries like Vietnam, Philippines and Indonesia, traders and analysts said.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 6.54 points to 1706.47. Gainers outnumbered losers 221 to 27, with a total trading volume of 81.61 million lots worth RM19.53 million.

site_title: For North Korea's cyber army, long-term target may be telecoms, utility grids
summary: North Korea's elite cyber-army is believed to be training for a long-term goal of crippling telecoms and energy grids in rival nations, according to defectors. The hacking attack on Sony Pictures may have been a practice run for this goal. North Korea has been working on cyber-warfare and nuclear technology to match its main enemies, South Korea and the US. The country's cyber-warfare unit, Bureau 121, has been pouring resources into sophisticated cyber-attacks, including crippling cyber-attacks on South Korean banks and broadcasters in 2013. Experts warn that North Korea's vulnerability to hacking poses a significant threat to its infrastructure and national security.

site_title: Oil rebounds in volatile year-end trade
summary: Oil prices rebounded in Asia on Friday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising 63 cents to $54.74 and Brent crude gaining 16 cents to $59.43. This follows a sharp decline in the previous session, with WTI falling to its lowest since May 2009 and Brent tumbling to its lowest since November 2008. Analysts predict continued market volatility until the issue of low global demand and oversupply is resolved, with the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) declining to cut output to curb the price plunge.

site_title: US officials see progress in China trade talks
summary: US officials reported progress in China trade talks, citing agreements on medicines, intellectual property rights, and agriculture. The 25th US-China Joint Commission on Commerce and Trade, led by Secretary of Commerce Penny Pritzker, resulted in agreements on pharmaceutical and medical device imports, anti-competition laws, and intellectual property treatment. China also agreed to ease requirements for US agriculture imports, benefiting corn and soybean farmers. While not all outcomes were perfect, US officials described the talks as "productive" and "renewed spirit and effort."

site_title: UK consumer confidence slides to nine-month low in December: GfK
summary: UK consumer confidence fell to a nine-month low in December, reaching -4, down from -2 in November, according to a GfK survey. This is the weakest level since March and a 17-month low in economic optimism. Despite the UK's strong economic growth, worries about the euro zone economy and geopolitical turmoil have likely curbed consumer morale. The index is still above its long-run average, but prospects for the coming year have dimmed.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index rising 16.77 points to 3,260.42. Gainers outnumbered losers 102 to 30. Volume was 33.3 million shares worth S$49.9 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks jump 1.75% at open
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.75% at the open on Friday, driven by sharp gains on Wall Street and a stronger dollar against the yen. The Nikkei 225 index climbed 300.96 points to 17,511.01. US stocks surged, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 reaching new highs. The dollar's firmness since the US Federal Reserve's interest rate announcement signalled a steady move towards more normal monetary policy. A weak yen is a positive for Japanese exporters, making them more competitive abroad.

site_title: Asian markets extend gains after Fed statement
summary: Asian markets continued their gains on Friday, with Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, and Hong Kong rising 1.59%, 1.66%, 1.29%, and 1.43% respectively. The rally followed a strong performance on Wall Street, where the Dow surged 2.43% and the S&P 500 rose 2.40%. The Federal Reserve's statement that interest rates would be hiked no sooner than mid-2015 brought relief to emerging markets and helped push the dollar back towards the 100 yen mark, boosting currency traders. Oil prices also rose after plumbing new five-and-a-half-year lows.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rally on Fed comments; won flat
summary: South Korean shares rallied on Friday, up 1.58% at 1,927.50 points, snapping a four-day losing streak. The rally followed the US Federal Reserve's comments on interest rate hikes, which were seen as reassuring. Samsung Electronics and Cheil Industries led the gains, with Samsung rising 4% and Cheil Industries surging 11%. The won remained nearly flat, and energy counters underperformed the market. The rally was attributed to a shift in the Fed's policy statement to a more data-dependent approach.

site_title: EBay CEO to get US$23m exit package after PayPal split
summary: eBay CEO John Donahoe will receive an exit package worth approximately US$23 million after the company splits from PayPal next year, according to an agreement. CFO Bob Swan will receive about US$12 million. The terms were approved by eBay's board on December 15, and other executives may also step down with benefits including a cash payment equivalent to 1.5 times their annual base salary. The packages are tied to the performance of eBay's share price during the separation period.

site_title: China 2013 GDP revision won't affect growth this year
summary: China has revised up its 2013 GDP to 58.8 trillion yuan (US$9.5 trillion), a 3.4% increase from the initial estimate. The revision, mainly due to an upward revision of the services sector, will not affect economic growth this year. China's economic growth weakened to 7.3% in the third quarter, and full-year growth is expected to miss the government's 7.5% target, marking the weakest expansion in 24 years.

site_title: China oil giant probes 'worthless' deals in Indonesia
summary: China's state-owned oil giant, CNPC, is investigating two suspect oil deals in Indonesia worth US$350 million, with one deal deemed "worthless" and causing heavy losses for the state. The deals include a 2009 purchase of a 80% stake in the Madura block for US$120 million, with no significant reserves found, and a 2009 acquisition of an exploration contract in Sumatra for US$230 million. These probes follow a separate investigation into a "worthless" deal in Indonesia, as officials highlight the challenges in monitoring smaller offshore investments in high-risk oil and gas exploration.

site_title: Plunging oil price to reset global defence budgets: IHS
summary: Global defence spending is expected to remain stable for the next two years due to plummeting oil prices. Middle East exporters' budgets are likely to decrease, while Asia-Pacific importers' budgets will increase. Oil prices have fallen 50% since mid-June, affecting defence budgets. Defence spending growth in China, India, and Indonesia is expected to continue at rates above five percent. NATO's share of global defence expenditure is predicted to decline by 2019, with the US no longer accounting for two-thirds of worldwide spending.

images.alt_text: Global defence spending is likely to remain constant for the next two years as tumbling oil prices cut the budgets of Middle East exporters, but swell the coffers of Asia-Pacific importers, defence analysts IHS said Friday.

site_title: China official who spoke out on graft faces corruption inquiry
summary: A senior Chinese official, Wang Min, Communist Party boss of Jinan city, is under investigation for suspected corruption, according to the party's graft watchdog. Wang had previously vigorously backed President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign, but now faces allegations of "serious breaches of the law and discipline". The investigation marks the latest victim of Xi's high-profile anti-corruption campaign, which has targeted officials across China.

site_title: SingTel's Australian subsidiary to acquire cloud-computing services firm Ensyst (Amended)
summary: SingTel's Australian subsidiary, Alphawest, agreed to acquire cloud-computing services firm Ensyst for A$13.0 million. Ensyst, with net assets of A$208,000, provides cloud-based professional and managed services in Australia. The acquisition will help Alphawest expand its cloud services offerings. Ensyst has approximately 80 employees and offices in Sydney and Melbourne. The deal is conditional upon regulatory approvals.

site_title: Brent steady below US$60, heads for 4th weekly decline as oversupply persists
summary: Oil prices continued to decline, with Brent crude holding below US$60 a barrel for a fourth straight week. The global oversupply persists, despite Opec's decision not to cut production. Companies are cutting upstream investments due to the decline in prices, and oil companies will need to reduce spending by US$170 billion next year to maintain debt levels. Only three of the top 40 international oil companies generate sufficient free cash flow to cover spending. Saudi Arabia's oil minister stated that Opec cannot cut output alone to reverse the oil price slump.

images.alt_text: Brent crude held below US$60 a barrel near a 5-1/2-year low on Friday as a global oversupply of oil showed little sign of receding, even as companies cut upstream investments next year.

site_title: Negative Swiss rates may not take much shine off franc as safe-haven
summary: The Swiss National Bank's decision to push interest rates into negative territory may not significantly impact the value of the Swiss franc, which is seen as a safe-haven asset. Despite this, analysts predict that low-risk assets such as German bunds, US Treasuries, and the yen may gain at the expense of the franc. The introduction of negative rates is likely to make Swiss assets less attractive to long-term investors, including pension funds, which hold significant amounts of Swiss franc assets. The Swiss franc is also expected to face prolonged weakness against the US dollar as the Federal Reserve prepares to tighten policy next year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingTel, Keppel Land, Keppel Corp, ST Engineering
summary: SingTel's Australian subsidiary Alphawest Pty Limited has agreed to acquire Ensyst Pty Limited, a cloud computing services company, for A$13.0 million. Keppel Land will acquire a 75% stake in Hong Kong's Array Real Estate for an undisclosed sum. Keppel Corporation rebounded 2.68% on Thursday following positive language from the US Fed. Meanwhile, oil prices fell below US$60 per barrel.

images.alt_text: SingTel announced on Friday that its Australian subsidiary, Alphawest Pty Limited (Alpha), has entered into a conditional agreement to fully acquire Ensyst Pty Limited (Ensyst).

site_title: Kraft Foods CEO to retire; chairman steps into role
summary: Kraft Foods Group Inc announced that CEO Tony Vernon will retire on December 27, with Chairman John Cahill succeeding him. Cahill will focus on accelerating change and growing Kraft's brand portfolio. Vernon's departure comes after Kraft reported an 11% drop in third-quarter profit due to higher commodity costs. Shares rose 6.4% to an all-time high as investors speculate about potential changes to the company's portfolio, including its Oscar Mayer and Maxwell House brands. Cahill has experience from his time at PepsiCo and aims to take Kraft to greater heights.

site_title: EU leaders seek to overcome hostility to US trade deal
summary: EU leaders defended plans for the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) deal with the US, aiming to conclude negotiations by the end of 2015. Despite campaigns by activists, EU leaders said the deal would not compromise food, labor, or environmental standards. British Prime Minister David Cameron, Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi, and German Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed support for the deal, which would create a market of 800 million people and encompass almost half the world economy. EU leaders emphasized the need for a mutually beneficial agreement, dismissing concerns about the deal's impact on public services.

site_title: Germany says will probably take on less net new debt than planned in 2014
summary: Germany's finance ministry says the country will likely take on less net new debt in 2014 than planned, with a current assessment suggesting a full balanced budget might be achievable this year. The reduction is attributed to historically low interest rates and rising tax revenues. The government's net new borrowing target of 6.5 billion euros remains unchanged, but the ministry's report suggests a possible achievement of a balanced budget in 2014, potentially beating the 2015 target.

site_title: US-Cuba ties thaw, White House open to Castro visit
summary: US President Barack Obama announced a historic bilateral rapprochement with Cuba, paving the way for improved relations. The White House is open to a visit by Cuban President Raul Castro, and Assistant Secretary of State Roberta Jacobson will travel to Havana in late January for direct talks. However, the trade embargo imposed in 1960 is unlikely to be lifted by the incoming Republican Congress, with lawmakers expressing opposition to repealing the Helms-Burton Act. The US and Cuba have agreed to release jailed US contractors and Cuban spies, and the US has begun re-examining its designation of Cuba as a state sponsor of terrorism.

site_title: US Secret Service too insular, needs outside leader, more agents: review
summary: The US Secret Service needs an outsider to lead the agency, improve training, and increase staffing, according to a highly classified review. The review, prompted by the September White House intrusion by an Iraq war veteran, recommended building a better fence, hiring more agents, and shortening long shifts. The agency's training regimen is also deemed unacceptable, with the average special agent receiving only 42 hours of training. The review's findings have raised concerns about the agency's culture and accountability, and an independent congressional review is promised.

site_title: EU leaders press Russia, urge new investment
summary: EU leaders urged Russian President Vladimir Putin to make a "radical change" in his stance on Ukraine, boosting sanctions against Crimea despite fears of economic blowback. The EU also agreed on a 315-billion-euro investment plan to kickstart Europe's moribund economy, with no specific pledges of money. Sanctions against Russia will continue until Moscow stops backing rebels in eastern Ukraine, with Foreign Policy Chief Federica Mogherini calling for a "cooperative mode."

site_title: UK house prices growth to slow in 2015: RICS
summary: British house prices are expected to slow in 2015, with a 3% average growth forecast, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS). This is due to tighter mortgage rules and affordability constraints. Despite this, a recent decision to cut transaction taxes may boost demand, particularly for first-time buyers. Housing market activity has been slowing since mid-2014, and the supply pipeline of new homes needs to be sped up to address affordability issues.

site_title: US banks to move cautiously into Cuba, trade groups say
summary: US banks will cautiously expand operations in Cuba after the US and Cuba re-established diplomatic ties. Banks will find it easier to process money transfers and US travelers can use their credit and debit cards. However, trade groups warn that banks will be slow to ramp up due to severe penalties for mistakes and a relatively small Cuban economy. Regulators have cracked down on sanctions violations in recent years, with BNP Paribas paying nearly $9 billion for breaking embargoes, including against Cuba. A year is expected to pass before significant movement is seen in banking operations.

site_title: EU leaders agree investment package to boost economy
summary: EU leaders agreed on a new investment package to boost the economy, with a focus on strategic investments, structural reforms, and sound public finances. The package includes a European fund for investments and allows governments to contribute to it without breaching EU budget rules. The agreement was reached at a Brussels summit, with European Council President Donald Tusk stating it will help speed up the economic recovery.

site_title: LMIR Trust gets S$180m term loan facility
summary: LMIR Trust has secured an S$180 million term loan facility from BNP Paribas, CIMB Bank, and Standard Chartered Bank. The loan will be used for working capital and general corporate funding purposes, including investments and acquisitions. The facility bears an interest margin of 3% per annum and has a 48-month tenor with an option to extend up to 84 months. This follows the announcement by LMIRT Management on December 16, 2024.

site_title: Professional help is at hand for stumped US gifters
summary: Penguin Random House has launched a "hotline" to provide book recommendations to stumped gifters, fielding over 2,800 requests since its launch on December 1. The hotline, which offers personalized suggestions from Penguin staff and competitors, aims to provide a human touch in a crowded holiday market. The program's success highlights the value of expert advice, with personal shoppers, concierges, and advisers stepping in to help with last-minute gift requests.

site_title: US: Wall St has best 2-day gain since 2011 on Fed optimism
summary: US stocks surged on a two-day gain, with the S&P 500 closing its biggest advance since 2011, driven by the Federal Reserve's optimistic assessment of the US economy and a "patient" approach to raising interest rates. The Dow industrials recorded its best one-day percentage gain since 2011, while tech shares jumped following Oracle's results. The rally extended from the previous session, with the S&P 500 up 4.5% in the last two sessions.

site_title: US considers 'proportional' response to Sony hacking attack
summary: The US government is considering a "proportional" response to the Sony Pictures hacking attack, which it has deemed a serious national security matter. Investigators believe the attack was state-sponsored and may have been carried out by North Korea, possibly with the assistance of Iran. Sony canceled the release of the film "The Interview," which was targeted by the hackers, in response to the threat of further attacks. US officials are exploring options for retaliation, including cyberattacks, financial sanctions, and increased military support to South Korea, but the effectiveness of any response is uncertain due to North Korea's isolation.

site_title: US holiday sales may recover with help of deep discounts
summary: US holiday sales may recover due to deep discounts, particularly in consumer electronics and home improvement segments. Despite a disappointing Thanksgiving weekend, last-minute shopping trips before Christmas could boost sales. Industry consultants expect retailers like Best Buy and Home Depot to benefit the most from discounts, which have been the strongest in these segments this year.

site_title: A year of flux
summary: In 2014, the music industry experienced significant changes with the release of U2's free album, a vinyl revival, and the rise of streaming services. Despite controversy over U2's album distribution, the year saw notable releases such as Taylor Swift's bestselling album "1989" and Pink Floyd's "The Endless River." Other notable mentions include Sam Smith's soulful debut "In The Lonely Hour" and The Observatory's experimental album "Oscilla." The year also saw a mix of successful marketing and artist resistance to streaming services, with Coldplay and Taylor Swift pulling their music from platforms.

site_title: Digital edge in validating art
summary: Professor John F. Asmus, a renowned art conservation expert, has pioneered laser techniques in restoring paintings and sculptures, as well as identifying the "digital fingerprint" of artists to test authenticity. He collaborated with George Stout, a physicist who helped George Clooney's character in the movie "The Monuments Men." Asmus's work has been applied to five major artists, including Leonardo da Vinci, and he hopes to continue his research with the help of Prof. Vadim Parfenov.

images.alt_text: Prof Asmus pioneered laser techniques which can be seeen in the Earlier Mona Lisa exhibition at The Arts House.
Prof Asmus (above) pioneered laser techniques which can be seeen in the Earlier Mona Lisa exhibition at The Arts House.

site_title: London home-price drop deepens as rules limit buyers
summary: London's housing market has seen a significant drop in home prices, with values falling 10% from their peak in the spring, according to the Bank of England and property researcher Hometrack. The drop is attributed to the Bank of England's restrictions on high loan-to-value mortgages and stricter affordability checks by the Financial Conduct Authority. Experts say the measures aim to stem rising household debt, which has reached 145% of gross disposable income. The impact is being felt more intensely in central, south-west, and west London districts, with prices declining 0.5-2.5% in October.

site_title: On the write trek
summary: Local books offer fresh perspectives on life in Singapore. Graphic novel "Last Train From Tanjong Pagar" by Koh Hong Teng and "A Certain Exposure" by Jolene Tan, a debut novel, challenge readers' views. Non-fiction essays in "Hard Choices: Challenging The Singapore Consensus" question the country's policy-making. Poetry collections, such as "One Thousand and One Nights: Love Poems" by Gwee Li Sui and "We Were Always Eating Expired Things" by Cheryl Julia Lee, showcase local talent. These books provide new insights into Singapore's history, culture, and identity.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Oil tumbles after brief rebound; Brent back below US$60
summary: Global crude oil prices slumped on Thursday, with benchmark Brent and US crude tumbling $2 a barrel each, after a brief rebound. The market is expected to resume its six-month rout due to concerns about a supply glut. Oil prices have lost about half their value since June, with Brent falling below $60 a barrel and US crude under $55. Analysts predict further selling, with some speculating another significant drop before the year-end.

site_title: Obama can loosen Cuban sanctions: experts
summary: US President Barack Obama has the power to further weaken sanctions against Cuba beyond the normalization of relations with Havana, experts say. Despite the Republican takeover of Congress in January, Obama can loosen trade bans with Cuba as long as at least one restriction remains on the books. The Obama administration plans to ease some restrictions on commerce, transportation, and banking, and may instruct the Treasury Department to soften its rules on Cuba. Sanctions may take years to lift fully, with the goal of lifting the embargo by 2017, when Obama leaves office.

site_title: SGX hopes for greater links with Shanghai
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is hopeful for a link with Shanghai, similar to the Shanghai-Hong Kong trading link, to further internationalize China's currency. SGX head of listings, Lawrence Wong, believes Shanghai may extend a similar link to Singapore, given Singapore's success in clearing the yuan. However, early results of the Shanghai-Hong Kong link have been muted, with only a small portion of the investment quota being used. SGX is also exploring crowdfunding, but notes that retail investors may not fully understand the platform, and is considering catering to accredited investors.

images.alt_text: "China would like to see more internationalisation of its currency. It goes hand in hand with the economic role it is playing." - Mr Wong

site_title: EU outlaws investment in Crimea; targets oil sector, cruises
summary: The European Union has banned investment in Crimea, targeting the oil sector and cruise ships. The measure, set to take effect on Saturday, prevents Europeans and EU-based companies from buying real estate or financing Crimean companies. EU companies are also prohibited from exporting goods and technology used in the exploration and production of oil, gas, and minerals in Crimea. The EU has reinforced its policy of not recognizing Moscow's annexation of Ukraine's Crimea region.

site_title: State of the art
summary: Singapore's visual art scene is thriving, with numerous exhibitions showcasing the work of top artists from the region. Notable shows include "Countershadows" at Lasalle College of the Arts, "Asia Pacific Breweries Foundation Signature Art Prize" at the Singapore Art Museum, and "Yang Fudong: Incidental Scripts" at the Centre for Contemporary Art. Other notable exhibitions include "Rirkrit Tiravanija: Time Travelers Chronicle" at the Singapore Tyler Print Institute, "Flux Realities: A Showcase of Chinese Contemporary Photography" at the ArtScience Museum, and "Zai Kuning: We Are Home & Everywhere" at Ota Fine Arts.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Wiggle room for possible Fed rate surprises
summary: The Federal Reserve has introduced "patience" as a guiding principle for monetary policy decisions, shifting focus from a set timeline to data-driven evaluations. This move may allow for unexpected interest rate hikes, as suggested by Chairwoman Janet Yellen, who noted a potential rate increase as soon as April. The Fed's economists have revised their GDP and unemployment predictions, indicating a strong economy, which could prompt rate hikes sooner rather than later. However, this change also introduces more interpretation and potential disagreements among committee members.

site_title: The art of pro-active disclosures
summary: A recent incident involving Keppel DC Reit on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) mainboard highlights the need for improved disclosure standards. A power outage at one of the data centres may have caused a system failure, disrupting trading for several hours in November. This incident, along with another at a different SGX-listed company, underscores the importance of transparency in corporate reporting. Both cases demonstrate a need for better adherence to disclosure standards in the SGX.

site_title: Project sukuk plan sees fivefold rise in Indonesian development programme
summary: Indonesia plans to increase sales of project sukuk by almost fivefold to 7.14 trillion rupiah (S$732 million) in 2015, aiming to diversify financing and attract more varied investors. The country aims to raise 7.14 trillion rupiah from notes to fund construction ventures, including roads, railways, and power plants, as part of President Joko Widodo's US$439 billion development programme. This increase is expected to help finance its estimated spending of about 5,519 trillion rupiah from 2015-19, with sukuk investors having long-term views despite the weakening rupiah.

site_title: Oil slump leads to fast investor exit from weakened commodities
summary: Investors are rapidly exiting commodities due to a slump in prices, with open interest in raw-material futures and options down 5.9% since June. The Bloomberg Commodity Index has slumped 13% this year, with Brent crude tumbling 45% and gasoline prices down 32% since June. Investors are betting that prices won't recover, citing low inflation, higher interest rates, and weaker currencies. While some industrial metals may rally in 2015, gold prices are expected to slide to $1,100 an ounce.

site_title: Fresh hope for regional M&As, caution over listings
summary: Singapore's mergers and acquisitions (M&As) are expected to increase in 2015, driven by stability and reduced political risks. The total value of completed M&As in Southeast Asia decreased 5% to US$84.9 billion, while Singapore's total value rose 75% to US$64.7 billion, its highest since 2008. Consolidation in the banking industry is challenging due to high acquisition costs. The real estate space also sees potential for mergers, with a landmark union between two Temasek-linked infrastructure trusts. In contrast, the IPO market is expected to remain cautious, with concerns over rising interest rates and decreased investor interest in yield products.

site_title: SpiceJet flies again amid government flip-flop over rescue package
summary: SpiceJet, an Indian budget airline, has resumed flights after a government flip-flop over a rescue package. The airline had missed salary payments and cancelled 2,000 flights this month. State oil companies initially rebuffed a request to offer fuel on credit, but a token payment by SpiceJet has helped buy time. Oil companies now demand more, but SpiceJet is operating normally. This development comes amid uncertainty over the airline's financial situation.

site_title: Management reshuffle prepares Airbus for record jet output
summary: Airbus has announced a management reshuffle, with British aerospace veteran Tom Williams appointed as chief operating officer and a seat on the group executive committee. This marks the first time a Briton has reached the No 2 slot, previously reserved for French or German executives. Williams' appointment is seen as a step towards focusing on industrial performance rather than national interests. The reshuffle also includes the promotion of Didier Evrard and Klaus Richter, with Richter becoming the chief Airbus representative for Germany, reflecting a focus on supplier risks and standardized carmaking strategies.

site_title: Oracle's Q2 earnings surge on cloud growth
summary: Oracle's Q2 earnings surged, surpassing analyst estimates with a profit of 69 cents a share and $9.6 billion in revenue. The company's cloud growth, driven by new software and acquisitions, is paying off. Oracle's cloud software, platform, and infrastructure businesses saw a 45% increase in revenue from a year earlier. Despite a 2% decline in net income, Oracle forecasts flat to 4% higher sales for the third quarter. The company is on track to sell over $1 billion in new cloud subscriptions next fiscal year.

site_title: US crude set for record output despite price trend
summary: US crude oil production is set to reach a 42-year record in 2015, despite a decline in global oil prices, as drilling costs and efficiency increase. Energy producers plan to pump more oil with fewer rigs, with Exxon Mobil expected to boost production by 2.8% next year. Despite benchmark crude prices near $55, existing wells remain profitable due to low operating costs of $25 or less, allowing companies to continue extracting oil with minimal disruption. This trend is expected to continue, with US oil production reaching 9.42 million barrels per day in May.

site_title: City Buzz
summary:

Singapore's Gillman Barracks art cluster is showcasing an impressive collection of art pieces, including works by Yang Fudong, Hahan, and Yayoi Kusama. The Local People's Christmas night market offers a unique shopping experience with art, food, and retail vendors. Meanwhile, TripList is a free app that helps users create customized packing lists for holidays. Veteran singer-songwriter Kevin Mathews will perform a unique musical concept, 20 Originals, at Artistry Cafe. The Stellar restaurant has debuted a special Krug pairing menu to celebrate its appointment as a Krug ambassador restaurant in Singapore.

site_title: 2015 could be a year of policy divergence and currency volatility
summary: US Federal Reserve's monetary policy statement reassured market players that interest rates would remain lower for some time, despite potential rate hikes. The Fed lowered its unemployment forecast for 2015 to 5.25%, and inflation forecasts were also lowered. This suggests the Fed is willing to slow its march towards tightening, allowing inflation to move back up. The policy divergence between the US, Europe, and Japan could lead to currency volatility, with the dollar strengthening against other currencies, potentially creating new vulnerabilities for companies with dollar-denominated debts.

site_title: Fed keeps favourite phrase of markets
summary: The Federal Reserve, led by Janet Yellen, has reaffirmed its plan to keep interest rates low for a "considerable time," sparking a surge in US stocks and boosting European and Asian markets. The decision was seen as a postponement of rate hikes, with traders interpreting the statement as a dovish move. The Fed's statement also highlighted its patient approach to "normalizing policy," which was a significant factor in the market's reaction. Despite some dissent from Fed officials, the decision was seen as a positive for the market, with energy and mining stocks leading the gains.

images.alt_text: Ms Yellen warned that the Fed could raise rates at any time after its March 2015 meeting.

site_title: Jokowi govt plans to cut budget deficit to 1% of GDP by 2019
summary: Indonesia's new government plans to cut its budget deficit to 1% of GDP by 2019, primarily through tax reforms. Finance Minister Bambang Brodjonegoro aims to curb the deficit, which threatens to push the country's largest economy to breach a legally binding limit of 3% of GDP. The government plans to reform the tax system, reduce fuel subsidies, and increase tax collections to achieve this goal. Lowering the budget deficit is expected to benefit Indonesia's economic fundamentals and reduce borrowing costs, as interest rates are expected to rise next year.

site_title: Cuban cigars will still remain a rarity in US
summary: US President Barack Obama plans to resume diplomatic relations with Cuba, but initial restrictions will remain in place. American visitors will be allowed to bring back only US$100 worth of Cuban cigars for personal use, and plain tourism is still banned. Genuine Cuban cigars are rare due to counterfeits and limited imports from Canada and Switzerland. Prices can be inflated, with some cigars selling for as much as US$1,000. The rarity and hype surrounding Cuban cigars may outweigh their actual quality, according to tobacconists.

site_title: Asia's transport sustainability dilemma
summary: Asia's transport sector faces a significant sustainability dilemma due to rampant air pollution from vehicles. Many countries, such as India, China, and Indonesia, struggle with outdated and poorly maintained vehicles that emit high levels of smog, contributing to climate change. To address this issue, experts suggest implementing low-carbon transport systems, increasing funding for environmentally friendly alternatives, and enforcing stricter smog laws. A "Bottom of the Pyramid" approach, providing financing for modern vehicles, could be a key solution.

site_title: Fall in oil prices likely to widen divergence in monetary policies
summary: Central banks worldwide are grappling with the implications of the near-halving of oil prices in 2014, leading to divergent monetary policy stances. The US Federal Reserve and Bank of England expect a boost to growth, while the European Central Bank worries about possible deflation. The ECB is considering bond-buying, while the Fed is likely to raise interest rates next year. The Bank of Japan is also debating its inflation target due to lower oil prices. This divergence in monetary policies is expected to continue into next year, with the ECB potentially taking a more aggressive stance to revive the eurozone economy.

site_title: Seck Wai Kwong moves up to State Street's top committee
summary: State Street Corporation has appointed Seck Wai Kwong, 59, to its management committee, the company's senior-most strategy and policy-making group. Kwong, a Hong Kong-based executive, is the only Singaporean now to sit at the top management level of a G-20 bank. Gunjan Kedia, head of investment servicing capabilities in the Americas, has also been promoted to the committee. The appointments reflect the contributions of both executives to the company's success, with diverse backgrounds and global expertise.

images.alt_text: Mr Seck is probably the only Singaporean now to sit at the most senior management level of a G-20 bank

site_title: The year of spectacle
summary: Singapore theatre companies delivered high-quality spectacles in 2014, showcasing top-notch production designs and performances. The year saw a mix of intense character-driven dramas and theatrical stunners, with the rebooted Singapore International Festival of Arts also bringing notable productions. This marked a notable shift from previous years, where intimate theatre dominated the scene. The success of these spectacles highlighted the growth and improvement of local theatre companies, solidifying Singapore's reputation for delivering powerful and engaging performances.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Obama buys a Cuban cigar
summary: US President Barack Obama announced major changes in American policy towards Cuba, restoring full diplomatic relations with the country and opening an embassy in Havana for the first time in over 50 years. The policy shift aims to normalize relations between the US and Cuba, with the goal of engaging the government and people of the island. The move is seen as a response to the failure of previous policies, which had isolated Cuba and hurt American standing in Latin America. The US and Cuba will work to ease restrictions on travel and trade, and lift the economic embargo, which has been a major obstacle to restoring relations.

images.alt_text: The Cubans agreed to release USAID contractor Alan Gross and another American spy in exchange for the US release of three Cubans convicted of spying in 2001.

site_title: Chevron puts on ice plans to drill in Arctic
summary: Chevron has indefinitely put on hold plans to drill for oil in the Beaufort Sea in Canada's Arctic due to economic uncertainty in the industry caused by falling oil prices. The company withdrew from a hearing on Arctic drilling rules after announcing it would not proceed with its plans for the EL 481 block, 250 km north-west of Tuktoyaktuk, Northwest Territories. Chevron had planned to drill the prospect in the 2020s and had previously outlined expectations for "highly significant" capital outlays in the area.

site_title: Genting M'sia not on NY casino shortlist, share price down 3%
summary: Genting Malaysia's share price dropped 3% after being excluded from a list of candidates for a commercial casino licence in New York. The New York Gaming Facility Location Board selected three companies, Empire Resorts, Capital Region Gaming, and Wilmorite Inc., for consideration. Despite this, Genting's parent company, Genting, remained unaffected, ending 0.8% higher. Analysts expect investors to react negatively to the news, but Genting's long-term plans, including a casino expansion in Malaysia, remain on track.

site_title: Rupiah, RM, rupee rise on upbeat Fed report
summary: The Indonesian rupiah, Malaysian ringgit, and Indian rupee rose on Thursday after an upbeat US Federal Reserve report, calming market nerves. The rupiah overperformed, pulling away from a 16-year low, while the Indian rupee clawed away from a 13-month low. The South Korean won fell against the US dollar after the Fed signalled interest rate hikes next year. Foreign funds and suspected central bank intervention also supported the rupiah's rise.

site_title: Russia prepares US$17b capital boost for banking sector
summary: Russia is preparing a US$17 billion capital boost for its banking sector to support struggling banks under Western sanctions and an economic slowdown. The government is considering a draft law allowing up to one trillion roubles to be invested in subordinated loans and bonds for state-owned banks, including Sberbank and VTB. The move aims to stabilize the rouble and support banks' profitability. The central bank has already introduced measures to support banks, including temporarily allowing them to use a third-quarter exchange rate to value their assets.

site_title: Modi moves in to speed up US$300b stuck projects
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has taken control of a project-monitoring body to fast-track investments worth nearly US$300 billion, aiming to revive manufacturing in the country. The move comes as industrial output contracted in October, its worst performance in three years, despite Modi's "Make in India" campaign. The Project Monitoring Group, previously in the Cabinet Secretariat, will now be overseen by the Prime Minister's office to cut through the complex clearance process, expected to boost business confidence and kick-start investment cycles.

site_title: US shipping lines cite wide gap in talks with W Coast dockworkers
summary: US shipping lines and terminal operators remain far from a deal with union dockworkers after seven months of contract talks, citing a wide gap in negotiations. The Pacific Maritime Association blames the International Longshore and Warehouse Union for waterfront cargo slowdowns, while the union disputes this, citing a shortage of tractor-trailer chassis as a main cause of gridlock. Talks are set to resume with face-to-face bargaining on Thursday.

site_title: Cerebral time-travel tale springs a few surprises
summary: The sci-fi thriller Predestination, based on Robert Anson Heinlein's 1958 short story All You Zombies, follows an unnamed bartender who leads a double life as a Temporal Agent, jumping back and forth in time to prevent certain events from occurring. Ethan Hawke stars as the agent, who becomes embroiled in a complex plot involving time travel and a mysterious bomber targeting New York City. With a modest budget and clunky CGI, the film is a trippy, if occasionally bumpy, ride that keeps viewers engaged with its multiple twists and turns.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: World investors cut back stocks as risk aversion reigns
summary: World investors cut back on stocks, lifting exposure to bonds as a Russian currency crisis, uncertain growth outlook, and declining energy prices heighten risk aversion. A Reuters poll found average allocations to stocks in balanced portfolios fell nearly a percentage point to 48.2% for the third consecutive month, while bond allocations rose to 38.2% for the fifth month running. Investors cited risks such as oil price instability and political tensions, but some saw declining oil prices as an economic stimulus and a buying opportunity for equities.

site_title: Casino resorts plan approved by New York state board
summary: New York state's board recommended the approval of Las Vegas-style casino resorts in the Catskill Mountains, near Albany, and on the northern end of the Finger Lakes, generating over $300 million in new tax revenues. The three resorts, including a $630 million Empire Resorts project, are expected to provide thousands of jobs and boost local economies. The decision comes after years of lobbying and comes as the Northeast's competitive gambling industry faces lagging returns. The governor's signature initiative aims to revitalize the region's economic woes, but faces opposition from local groups and environmentalists.

site_title: Ballsier Dollies
summary: The Dim Sum Dollies' new show, "The History of Singapore Part 2," tackles sensitive topics such as Operation Coldstore, Marxist Conspiracy, and Mas Selamat's escape, using humor to address issues that Singaporeans rarely discuss. The show features satirical skits, including a parody of The Lion King and a tribute to late opposition leader JB Jeyaretnam. While some jokes fall flat, the show's attempt to tackle politics with humor is seen as a reflection of the changing mindsets in Singapore. The show is currently running at the Esplanade Theatre until Dec 23.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: ST Index's rebound moves into 2nd day
summary: The Straits Times Index rebounded for a second consecutive day, gaining 16.42 points to 3,243.65, with a two-day gain of 28 points, following a 110-point decline on Monday and Tuesday. The recovery was driven by a strong Wall Street session, fueled by a bounce in European markets and the US Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee's statement that it can be "patient in beginning to normalize monetary policy."

site_title: RadioShack kept alive via US$25b credit-default swaps
summary: RadioShack, the struggling electronics retailer, has secured a US$25 billion credit-default swaps (CDS) deal to stay out of bankruptcy. The company's debt is 28 times the amount of swaps tied to it, making it the most heavily insured US company. The deals were arranged by hedge funds such as DW Investment Management and Saba Capital Management, which wagered on RadioShack's ability to avoid default. This has allowed the company to receive funding from its biggest shareholder, Standard General, and delay a potential bankruptcy.

site_title: Asia will be silver lining within emerging markets in 2015
summary: Asian emerging markets are expected to remain relatively strong in 2015, driven by lower commodity prices and improved policy flexibility, despite slower economic growth and tighter funding conditions. The decline in soft commodity and energy prices will boost corporate profit margins and support current account balances, while structural trends and targeted reforms across the region will continue to unfold. Valuations in Asian stocks are reasonable, and investors should pay attention to these trends as they head into 2015.

site_title: Santa is now big business in Shanghai, Dubai malls
summary: Christmas shopping is becoming increasingly popular in non-Christian countries, with major malls in Shanghai and Dubai hosting festive events and promotions. Global brands are targeting Chinese and Middle Eastern consumers, with sales, tinsel, and events aimed at getting them to catch the holiday spirit. In Dubai, the Dubai Christmas Fest attracts over 30,000 visitors annually, while in Shanghai, malls are expanding their holiday offerings, including Christmas markets and live entertainment. The trend is driven by younger consumers who are shopping more frequently and modestly, and by the growing influence of Western culture in non-Western countries.

site_title: Putin puts on brave face, promises rapid recovery
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin attempted to reassure the public about the country's economic crisis, promising a rapid recovery and stating that the downturn will last two years at most. However, his economy minister acknowledged that there was no coherent plan to tackle the crisis if oil prices don't rebound. The rouble has fallen to record lows, and real wages have declined for the first time in years. Markets reacted negatively to Putin's press conference, with the rouble falling 1.6% to 61 roubles to the dollar.

site_title: In Brief
summary: Global Tech posts a loss of HK$15.99 million for FY2014 due to lower revenue from repair services and a one-off gain in 2013. The company's turnover decreased by 18.78% to HK$89.79 million. Perennial China Retail Trust's trading will be suspended from Dec 23 due to the offeror acquiring 90.64% of its issued units. Leighton Holdings is forming a 50:50 services investment partnership with Apollo Global Management for A$1.075 billion.

site_title: BlackBerry faces turnaround test
summary: BlackBerry Ltd unveiled a new "Classic" phone, reminiscent of its glory days as the world's leading smartphone maker. The company aims to stabilize finances and win back investor confidence after a year of turnaround efforts. Earnings on Friday will shed light on the success of the strategy, which includes new devices and software sales. Analysts expect revenue to drop 22% and a narrower loss, with hardware revenue rising 8.8% due to the Passport phone's sales. However, experts question whether blockbuster sales of the Classic can turn the company around without significant device sales.

site_title: Boeing to deliver record 754 jets in 2015: trade group
summary: Boeing is expected to deliver a record 754 commercial aircraft in 2015, a 5.5% increase from the previous year, according to the US Aerospace Industries Association. This forecast aligns with Boeing's current production plans and suggests no major changes in production levels. However, Boeing plans to cut production of the 747-8 jumbo jet and may also reduce production of the 777 "mini-jumbo" jetliner to keep assembly lines running.

site_title: China's agriculture goes global
summary: China, the world's second-largest economy, is turning to overseas agriculture to address its food security concerns due to shrinking arable land and rising food demand. The country has invested in farmland in Africa, Brazil, and other countries, with plans to expand further. While the overseas option carries risks, such as land disputes and cultural concerns, it also offers opportunities for mutually beneficial partnerships and can help China and host countries address chronic food shortages and boost agricultural surpluses. China's investments in agriculture research centers and expertise can also alleviate food shortages and improve crop production.

site_title: Primer on whiskies
summary: Whisky sales have seen a surge in popularity among women, contributing to record sales in recent years. However, the classification and production rules for whisky vary by country, making it difficult for consumers to understand the different forms of whisky. Scotland's classification system is considered the most robust, with distinct styles emerging from single malt and blended whiskies. Single malts can be peated or unpeated, with distinct smoke flavor intensities, but commercialization is clouding traditional styles. Blended whiskies, made from a mix of malt and grain whiskies, are also becoming increasingly popular.

site_title: The year in cinema
summary: The 2014 film year was marked by a mix of forgettable and standout movies. Notable events included a cyber-attack on Sony Pictures, which cancelled the release of Seth Rogen's The Interview about assassinating North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. The year also featured typical Hollywood fare, including Marvel blockbusters, animation, and young adult films. Despite a few notable releases, 2014 was a year of standard cinema, with several films vying for the title of worst of the year, including Dumb and Dumber To and Horrible Bosses 2.

site_title: Greater retail rental transparency soon
summary: Singapore retailers and landlords will soon benefit from greater retail rental transparency under the Fair Tenancy Consideration Framework. The framework, set to be unveiled this month, consists of three components: data transparency, education and awareness, and a mediation process. Data transparency will involve making rent data available, including rent per square foot, while contract templates and guides will be provided for education and awareness. A mediation process will also be established to handle disputes between landlords and tenants. The framework aims to create a more sustainable relationship between the two parties, with the goal of moderating excessive behavior and protecting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Top 20 global bond funds in Japan decline on Russia crisis
summary: Japan's top 20 global bond funds declined on Wednesday due to Russia's crisis, with funds invested in Russia losing at least 15% of their value. High-yield funds not directly exposed to Russia also fell, including the Fidelity US High Yield Fund. The crisis has raised doubts about the funds' ability to raise cash in the near term, with analysts saying emerging bond funds may struggle to attract investors. The decline in emerging nation bonds and currencies has also hurt other high-yield funds, including those from Nomura Holdings and Goldman Sachs.

site_title: Olam sees further rise in cocoa prices next year
summary: Cocoa prices are expected to rise for a fourth consecutive year in 2015 due to a global shortage, driven by lower output in West Africa. A global demand-supply gap of 120,000 tonnes is forecast, with prices potentially increasing to £2,200-£2,400 per tonne to boost production. Olam International Ltd. predicts a deficit of good-quality cocoa, while other companies, such as Sucres et Denrees SA and Ecom Agroindustrial Corp, forecast different market scenarios.

site_title: UK to sell more shares in Lloyds, recoup more taxpayer cash
summary: The UK plans to sell an additional £3 billion worth of shares in Lloyds Banking Group, reducing its stake from 25% to around 19.5%. The shares will be sold through a "dribble-out offer" by Morgan Stanley, allowing for greater flexibility in size and timing. This is part of the UK's efforts to reduce its national debt and recoup taxpayer cash, with the government initially investing £20.5 billion in the bank during the 2007-2009 financial crisis. The sale is expected to be completed within the next six months.

site_title: Croesus trust raises hedge as yen falls
summary: Croesus Retail Trust (CRT), a Singapore-based retail trust with assets in Japan, has increased its hedge against foreign exchange risks to 100% for the period up to Dec 31, 2015, amid the weakening yen against the Singapore dollar. This move aims to mitigate forex risks and ensure steady returns for investors. The trust, which distributes 100% of its distributable income, has extended its hedges to cover approximately 100% of its income to better manage foreign exchange risks. The yen has declined about 9.3% against the Singapore dollar in the past four months.

site_title: UK Nov car production seen flat as exports weaken
summary: British car production remained flat in November, with overall output falling 0.2% year-on-year to 137,347 cars, due to weak exports and changes in models. Domestic demand rose by nearly a third, but exports dropped 6% due to economic uncertainty in foreign markets. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) now expects production to remain unchanged in 2014, despite forecasts of 1.59 million cars. However, the industry remains optimistic, with growth expected to return next year and production reaching an all-time high of over 2 million by 2017.

site_title: UOB launches online property loan calculator
summary: UNITED Overseas Bank (UOB) has launched a free online property loan calculator to help homeowners determine their total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) for mortgage loan applications. The calculator covers various types of properties, including private residences, HDB flats, and commercial properties. UOB's calculator is the most comprehensive one in the market, offering customers the option to pledge financial assets as additional income streams. The tool aims to educate customers about their personal financial situation and make informed decisions about buying or refinancing a property, with the goal of ensuring their TDSR or mortgage servicing ratio is within limits.

site_title: Analysts say 'sell' as Skymark surges 105% in a month
summary: Skymark Airlines Inc's share price surged 105% in a month after reports of a potential code-sharing agreement with Japan Airlines Co, optimism that cooperation may keep the airline from going broke. Analysts, including Mikey Hsia, recommend a "sell" due to technical indicators and high trading volume. Skymark's shares have risen despite the airline's prediction of a 13.7 billion yen loss for the year. The airline's cooperation with ANA and retention of Haneda airport flight slots also support the rally, with some analysts attributing gains to the slump in oil prices and tourism growth.

site_title: Pimco's emerging market funds post record U$5.8b outflow
summary: Pimco's emerging market funds have experienced a record $5.8 billion outflow in the first 11 months of 2014, nearly three times the total 2013 outflow. The outflows are attributed to ill-timed investment bets in Russia, Ukraine, Brazil, and Venezuela, as well as the ongoing flight from emerging markets. The funds' performance has been hindered by the management shake-up following Bill Gross and Mohamed El-Erian's departures. Law firms are investigating potential claims against Pimco, citing possible violations of securities laws.

site_title: Takata has sufficient funds to deal with global recall: report
summary: Takata Corp, the air bag maker, has sufficient funds to deal with its global recall of about 21 million vehicles, according to a company executive. The recall is linked to five deaths and excessive force from exploding air bags. CEO Shigehisa Takada stated that the company has set aside $774 million and is not concerned about capitalizing. Takata is analyzing inflators to determine the cause of defects and ramping up production of replacement parts. The company faces lawsuits and a US criminal investigation, but has identified and corrected manufacturing problems.

site_title: US leading economic indicator rises in November
summary: The US Leading Economic Index rose 0.6% in November, outperforming expectations, indicating underlying economic strength. This increase follows a 0.6% revision in October. Economists attribute the growth to tightening labor market conditions and the first signs of wage growth. The Conference Board's Ken Goldstein notes that income growth remains a challenge, but the rising index suggests a positive outlook for the economy.

site_title: All lights are green for BOJ now
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) continues its aggressive monetary policy, aiming to achieve a 2% inflation target and end deflation. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has been pushing for more quantitative easing, doubling Japan's monetary base, which is the largest in GDP-relative terms among central banks. The BOJ's policy has led to a sharp yen depreciation, potentially reaching 140 to the dollar, and has sparked concerns about the risks of a "train crash." Critics argue that the BOJ's focus on inflation targets has distracted from structural reforms, which are crucial for Japan's long-term economic growth.

site_title: Pimco expects global growth to accelerate in 2015 between 2.5-3%
summary: Bond giant Pimco expects global growth to accelerate in 2015 to around 2.75% due to supply-driven declines in oil prices. Former Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke supports Pimco's view, stating monetary policymakers will remain focused on real growth and core inflation. Bernanke's participation in Pimco's Cyclical Forum suggests the US economy is on track to support interest rate hikes in 2015, a move of confidence in the US economy.

site_title: China's Nov home prices down for 3rd straight month
summary: China's home prices fell 3.7% in November, marking the third consecutive month of decline compared to the same period last year. This is the largest drop since Reuters started tracking housing prices. The decline is attributed to an intractable property downturn, despite government efforts to energize the market.

site_title: Oil rises 2% to US$62 as energy firms slash investments
summary: Oil prices rose 2% to $62 a barrel as energy firms cut investments in new production due to the six-month price rout. Brent crude rebounded from five-year lows this week, while US crude rose 45 cents to $56.92 a barrel. Energy firms such as Chevron and Marathon Oil cut investments, citing lower prices threatening future production. Saudi Arabia's oil minister believes the price drop is temporary, and OPEC members are focusing on market share.

site_title: EU adopts tighter investment sanctions on Crimea
summary: The European Union has adopted tighter investment sanctions on Crimea, targeting Russian Black Sea oil and gas exploration and tourism. The restrictions, approved by EU governments, will take effect on Saturday and aim to limit European investment in the region. The move comes as the EU's leaders prepare to discuss the Ukraine crisis and relations with Russia at a Brussels summit. The new sanctions are part of efforts to pressure Russia over its actions in Crimea.

site_title: Abe to tackle corporate sector opposition to basic wage hike
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe faces corporate sector opposition to raising basic wages, a key component of his Abenomics agenda, following the recent election victory. The Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association's chairman, Fumihiko Ike, expressed opposition to increasing basic pay scales, suggesting that a one-off bonus may be more likely. This contradicts Abe's plea to industrialists to raise basic pay to boost consumption and economic growth. Corporate cash hoarding in Japan has reached record levels, with companies holding around half of the country's GDP in cash reserves.

site_title: UK air traffic group to compensate airlines for travel chaos
summary: The UK's National Air Traffic Service (NATS) will compensate airlines for a computer failure that disrupted hundreds of flights at London's Heathrow airport last week. The incident, which occurred during a switchover of air controllers' workstations, caused thousands of passengers to suffer cancellations and delays. The compensation, which is being calculated, will be notified to customers in due course. This is the second major incident at NATS in two years, following a 2013 glitch that cost the service £7.4 million. British Transport Secretary Patrick McLoughlin described the incident as "simply unacceptable".

site_title: Sanofi signs lease for 40,000 sq ft office space at South Beach
summary: Sanofi has signed a lease for approximately 40,000 sq ft of office space at South Beach Tower in Singapore. The 34-storey tower, part of the S$3 billion mixed development, has secured 80-90% of its 500,000 sq ft net lettable area. The 654-room hip hotel is expected to soft open in April 2015, with the official opening planned for September 2015. The residential component, comprising 190 units, is still pending pricing, with the consortium considering benchmarking prices similar to Ion The Orchard Residences at around S$4,000 psf.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: S$180m term loan facility granted to LMIR Trust
summary: LIPPO Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIR Trust) has secured a S$180 million term loan facility from BNP Paribas, CIMB Bank, and Standard Chartered Bank. The loan will be used for working capital, general corporate funding, and investments. The interest margin is 3% per annum. The first drawdown is expected by the end of this year.

site_title: Russian firms explore ways to ease pain of foreign debt payments
summary: Russian firms are exploring ways to ease the burden of foreign debt payments amid the rouble's decline and interest rate hike. With over $600 billion in foreign currency debt, companies are looking for alternatives, such as refinancing or converting roubles to dollars. Exporters like Norilsk Nickel are likely to have sufficient funds, but those with foreign debts and revenues in roubles may struggle. The central bank has announced plans to provide additional foreign currency funds, but analysts warn that a massive default is unlikely.

site_title: Putin promises economic recovery, digs in on Ukraine
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin vowed to rapidly recover from the economic crisis, promising support for the poorest section of the population. He indicated that the economic downturn will last two years at most, despite Western sanctions and a record fall in the ruble's value. Putin dug in on his stance on Ukraine, accusing the West of behaving like an "empire" and comparing Russia to a bear fighting for survival. He assured Russians that his position on Ukraine has not shifted, and warned that Western sanctions could lead to a "palace coup" against him.

site_title: Pre-Christmas wine thoughts
summary: A middle ground approach to celebrating Christmas sensibly is to focus on good wine pairing rather than extravagant spending. Traditional Christmas dinner wine pairings often begin with champagne, followed by white and red wines before the main course. White wine is typically preferred before red to avoid overpowering the palate. For a budget-friendly option, consider non-vintage and non-deluxe champagnes like Laurent Perrier Vintage 2004 or Pol Roger 2002. When selecting dinner wines, consider the sequence and budget, as high-end wines like Romanee Conti and Lafite Rothschild are best saved for special occasions.

site_title: Final resolution to an epic adventure
summary: The Hobbit: Battle of the Five Armies concludes the epic adventure of Bilbo Baggins, 15 years after its inception. The film, directed by Peter Jackson, brings closure to the trilogy, which has garnered numerous awards and box-office success. The battle between Elves, Orcs, dwarves, and humans at Erebor is depicted, with Bilbo and his allies thwarting Thorin's greed and saving the day. While the level of suspense is somewhat muted due to hobbit fatigue, the storytelling remains consistently good, marking the end of Middle-earth for now.

images.alt_text: Luke Evans helps the hobbits end the tyranny in the last instalment with all its twists and turns

site_title: Oil jumps 3% to US$63 as energy firms slash investments
summary: Oil prices surged 3% to US$63 a barrel, rebounding from five-year lows this week. The price increase came as energy firms cut investments in new production due to the six-month price rout. Oil has almost halved since June, driven by fast-growing US shale output overwhelming demand. The rebound has raised concerns about future production, causing volatility in oil prices.

site_title: Hello Kitty
summary: Singapore has welcomed its first cat museum, Lion City Kitty - The Cat Museum, Muses & Mansion, which opened earlier this week. Located on Purvis Street, the three-storey space features a cat museum, play area, and adoption facility. The museum showcases the history of cats, curated cat photographs, and art, while the play area and adoption facility allow visitors to interact with cats. The museum aims to change the community's mindset towards cats and animals, with founder Jessica Seet hoping to find homes for 50 cats by National Day next year. Admission costs S$9 per entry, and visitors can stay as long as they like.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Silverlake forms unit to launch bid for NZ firm
summary: Silverlake Axis, a Singapore-based company, has formed Silverlake HGH to launch a NZ$3 per share takeover offer for Finzsoft Solutions, an Auckland-based financial technology company. The acquisition aims to expand Silverlake's portfolio and deliver new digital economy offerings in the Asia Pacific region. The majority shareholder has committed to accepting the offer, with 51% held by Silverlake and 49% held by interests associated with Andrew Holliday, Finzsoft's managing director. The deal is seen as a strategic move to leverage Finzsoft's products and solutions.

site_title: US: Wall St climbs at open as oil rises
