summary: US stocks rose at the open on Thursday, driven by a 0.75% gain in the Dow Jones and 1.36% increase in the Nasdaq Composite, as oil prices steadied. The S&P 500 also rose 0.8%, reaching a fresh record. The gains followed a previous day's increase, as investors continued to look past uncertainty surrounding US-China trade tensions.

site_title: 'Impossible' for Saudi to reduce oil output: minister
summary: Saudi Arabia's oil minister Ali al-Nuaimi stated that reducing the kingdom's oil output is "difficult or even impossible" due to global supply glut and a strong dollar. Despite a 50% drop in crude prices since June, the minister expressed optimism for the future, citing the temporary nature of the current situation. Opec's production ceiling remains at 30 million barrels per day, with Saudi Arabia pumping 9.6 million barrels per day. The kingdom's decision to continue massive public spending in its 2015 budget suggests it can withstand lower oil prices.

site_title: Keppel Land to acquire 75% stake in Array Real Estate (Amended)
summary: Keppel Land will acquire a 75% stake in retail management company Array Real Estate for an undisclosed sum. The remaining 25% stake will be held by Array Holdings, a Hong Kong-incorporated company. The transaction is expected to take place in January 2025 and is not expected to impact Keppel Land's net tangible asset per share or earnings per share for the current financial year. Array Real Estate has a strong track record in developing and managing retail malls in Singapore and the region.

site_title: South Beach Tower 80-90 per cent leased: CEO of consortium developing project
summary: South Beach Tower, a mixed development in Singapore, is 80-90% leased with rents ranging from S$9 to S$12 per square foot. The project, developed by City Developments and IOI Group, is expected to achieve Temporary Occupation Permit by the end of this year and will feature a hotel and residential components. The retail component is slated for completion in Q4 2015, with the hotel and residential components expected to open in April and September 2015, respectively. The project's CEO, Aloysius Lee, is optimistic about the development's prospects.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: US Dec services sector activity growth slowest since Feb: Markit
summary: The US services sector expanded at its slowest rate since February in December, according to Markit's "flash" services Purchasing Managers Index, which hit 53.6. Growth in employment and new business slowed, with the services sector new business subindex falling to 53.1 and the employment subindex slipping to its lowest since April. This marks the weakest expansion rate since October 2013, with economists expecting a 2% growth rate in the fourth quarter, the worst performance in two years.

site_title: Oil at US$60 per barrel challenges biofuels: Brazil's Unica
summary: Brazil's Unica president, Elizabeth Farina, warns that oil prices at US$60 per barrel pose a challenge to the biofuels industry. Brazil is the largest producer of cane-based ethanol, but Farina questions whether consumers will opt for cheaper oil instead. This shift could impact the industry's growth and ethanol production.

site_title: The 12 daze of Christmas
summary: In 2014, Singapore experienced a year of quirky events, including politicians entering showbiz, elite schoolchildren using public transport, and an anti-gambling ad that generated wealth. The year saw various celebrities, such as Lawrence Wong and Nicole Seah, starring in plays and films. Notable incidents included a viral tourism video, the World Cup's financial struggles, and a screening of a banned documentary. The year concluded with the announcement of the SG50 Jubilee Baby Gift set, featuring 12 collectibles for newborns.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Singapore Airlines' profitability may be impacted by lower oil prices, but the effects are expected to be visible only in the long term. Analysts expect the airline's profit to increase by 19% in FY2016, but note several factors that could offset the positive impact. Meanwhile, analysts have mixed views on the consumer sector, with some recommending defensive plays like Sheng Siong and Thai Beverage, while others prefer to avoid stocks like Petra due to high valuations and earnings risks. The offshore and marine sector is also vulnerable to a lower oil price environment, but well-positioned players like Cosco and Swiber may benefit from attractive valuations.

site_title: US jobless claims point to firmer labour market
summary: US jobless claims unexpectedly fell to 289,000 for the week ended Dec 13, suggesting a strengthening labour market. This drop was below economists' forecasts of 295,000 claims. The four-week moving average of claims also decreased, indicating a step back in job growth after a surge in November. Despite this, December payrolls are still expected to exceed 200,000. The decline in initial claims was attributed to no special factors influencing the data, with the number of people receiving benefits after an initial week of aid also decreasing.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end 1.09% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.09% on Thursday, driven by bargain-buying and a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike delay until mid-2015. The Hang Seng Index reached 22,832.21 with HK$99.64 billion in turnover. In contrast, mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.11% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.58%.

site_title: Chinese billionaire gets first regulatory approval for Australia casino
summary: Chinese billionaire Tony Fung's Aquis Great Barrier Reef Resort has received regulatory approval from a Queensland state planning department, clearing the first hurdle for its proposed A$8 billion project. The resort, which includes a Macau-style casino and 7,500 hotel rooms, has been deemed unlikely to pose an unacceptable risk to the Great Barrier Reef. The project still needs to secure a casino license and clear other regulatory hurdles.

site_title: Hong Kong jobless rate steady at 3.3% in Sep-Nov
summary: Hong Kong's jobless rate remains steady at 3.3% for the fifth consecutive period in September-November, according to the Secretary for Labour and Welfare Matthew Cheung. Labour demand is expected to remain buoyant in the run-up to Christmas and the New Year, but the potential impact of the "Occupy Movement" on the domestic economy needs to be closely monitored.

site_title: Oil price fluctuations 'normal': Saudi minister
summary: Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister Ali al-Nuaimi expressed optimism about the future of the oil industry, stating that price fluctuations, which have plunged 50% this year, are normal. He attributed the current situation to being temporary, amid global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Indonesia to cut budget deficit to 1% of GDP in 2019
summary: Indonesia's new government plans to cut its budget deficit to 1% of GDP by 2019, primarily through tax system reform, to curb borrowing costs and improve economic fundamentals. Finance Minister Bambang Brodjonegoro aims to reduce the 2014 budget deficit to 2.4% of GDP and lower the current account deficit to 2% of GDP. The government will also cut fuel subsidies, linking domestic prices to global oil prices, and raise tax collections to achieve the target.

site_title: German business confidence grows in December
summary: German business confidence rose to 105.5 points in December, according to the Ifo economic institute, with current business holding steady and the outlook improving. The increase is attributed to dropping oil prices and a falling euro exchange rate. Analysts welcome the turnaround but note potential risks, including complacency, Russia's economic woes, and Germany's reliance on exports. The improved index follows a positive November and suggests a decent rebound for the economy in the final quarter of the year.

site_title: Oil price, euro fall spur German business confidence
summary: German business confidence rose to 105.5 points in December, driven by the falling price of oil and weak euro, according to the Ifo economic institute. This marked a second consecutive month of improvement, following a decline in previous months. Analysts attributed the boost to reduced uncertainty, resilient export expectations, and cheap oil, but noted that risks include complacency, over-reliance on exports, and concerns about Russia and Greece.

site_title: State Street appoints Seck Wai Kwong to its global management committee
summary: State Street has appointed Seck Wai Kwong, 59, to its global management committee, marking the first time a Singaporean has reached a senior management level at a G-20 bank. Kwong, who heads global services and global markets businesses in Asia Pacific, joins Gunjan Kedia, who heads investment servicing capabilities in the Americas. The promotions reflect the contributions of both individuals to the company's success, according to Chairman and CEO Jay Hooley.

site_title: Russia to give US$500m in state support to sanctioned bank VEB
summary: Russia's government is providing US$505 million in state support to Vneshekonombank (VEB), a sanctioned state development bank, as part of measures to shield banks from Western economic sanctions. The 30 billion rouble (US$505 million) capital boost is part of efforts to alleviate funding costs and loan-loss provisions for the sector. The government has also submitted a draft law to parliament that could grant the wider banking sector a capital boost of up to one trillion roubles. This move aims to support the financial sector, which has been reeling from the sharp slide of the rouble against the dollar.

site_title: Obesity can be deemed a disability at work: EU court
summary: The European Union's top court ruled that obese individuals can be considered disabled, allowing them to be protected under EU law against workplace discrimination. The decision, made in response to a Danish court's review of a complaint, found that obesity can be a disability if it hinders an employee's full participation in professional life. This ruling applies to EU employment law and covers roughly 23% of European women and 20% of European men who were obese in 2008 estimates.

site_title: French parliament passes deficit-cutting 2015 budget
summary: The French parliament approved President Francois Hollande's revised 2015 budget, which includes 21 billion euros in deficit-cutting measures to bring the country's public deficit down from 4.4% to 4.1% of GDP. The budget was passed with a majority of votes from Socialist Party lawmakers, despite some abstentions. The European Commission will rule in March 2015 on whether France has implemented necessary economic reforms to improve public finances.

site_title: Oil drop sends major central banks in different directions
summary: The world's major central banks are grappling with the implications of the near halving of oil prices in 2014, with differing conclusions. Policymakers in the US and UK see lower oil prices as a boost to growth and consumption, while the European Central Bank (ECB) worries it could tip the eurozone into deflation. The ECB is considering quantitative easing, while the Federal Reserve is set to raise interest rates next year. Oil-producing countries, such as Russia, face negative impacts, with interest rates rising to combat currency devaluation.

site_title: Brent oil rises above US$62 as energy firms slash investments
summary: Brent crude oil prices surged 2% to above $62 a barrel, as energy firms cut investment budgets amid signs that lower prices may threaten future production. The price hit a five-year low of $58.50 this week, but some traders are betting that a six-month price rout could be ending. Chevron and Marathon Oil have put drilling plans on hold, while Canadian oil producers have cut spending by 20%. Analysts believe the 25% fall in prices over the past month may be overdone, with some positioning for a rebound.

site_title: Leighton and certain Apollo funds agree to form 50:50 Services investment partnership
summary: Leighton Holdings, the parent company of Leighton Finance, has agreed to form a 50:50 services investment partnership with funds managed by Apollo Global Management. The partnership, valued at A$1.075 billion, will combine the operations of Thiess Services and Leighton Contractors Services, creating one of Australia's largest services firms. The deal will reduce Leighton Holdings' gearing by 10 percentage points and provide access to Apollo's expertise in creating a single, integrated business. The partnership will have combined 2014 revenue of over A$2.2 billion and approximately 6,400 skilled employees.

site_title: India launches its biggest ever rocket into space
summary: India successfully launched its largest rocket, the Geostationary Satellite Launch Vehicle Mk-III, on December 18, 2014. The 630-tonne rocket, capable of carrying 4 tonnes, blasted off from Sriharikota, Andhra Pradesh, and carried an unmanned crew capsule designed to send astronauts into space. The capsule successfully separated from the rocket and splashed down in the Bay of Bengal. The launch marks a significant milestone for India's ambitious space program, which aims to tap into the $300-billion global space market.

site_title: Japan PM expected to tip BOJ board closer to his views in 2015
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is expected to tip the Bank of Japan's board closer to his views, potentially leading to further monetary stimulus, as two board members' five-year terms expire in 2015. Abe may choose candidates supportive of reflationary policies, which could ease the task of Governor Haruhiko Kuroda. However, the BOJ board remains divided, with some members skeptical of expanding quantitative and qualitative easing, a policy that has been criticized for its limited success in boosting the economy.

site_title: Ruble rallies in early trading on day of Putin press conference
summary: The Russian ruble rallied in early trading ahead of President Vladimir Putin's annual press conference, trading at 58 to the dollar and 72 to the euro. The ruble had crashed to historic lows of 80 to the dollar and 100 to the euro due to the financial crisis, which the Kremlin has attributed to a "perfect storm" of global and domestic factors. Economy Minister Alexei Ulyukayev warned of recession next year, with a contraction of up to 4.8% expected, and officials have called on Russians to bear the economic burden for the annexation of Crimea.

site_title: Chinese shopping "agents" cash in on Russian currency slide
summary: Chinese shoppers are taking advantage of Russia's declining rouble rate by buying luxury goods at discounted prices, which are then resold online or in person back in China. Known as "daigou," these shopping agents stockpile products such as iPhones, handbags, and watches before selling them at a profit. The rouble's 45% decline this year has made it cheaper for Chinese buyers to purchase luxury items, with some items costing up to half the price in China. However, firms are now hiking prices or halting sales, and consumers must act quickly to avoid missing out on deals.

site_title: Airports of Thailand sees passengers rising 6% to 10% in 2014/15
summary: Airports of Thailand expects a 6-10% rise in total passenger numbers in the 2014/15 financial year, driven by the recovery of tourism from months of political unrest. The firm reported a 1.67% increase in total passengers to 87.57 million in the previous year. Foreign tourist numbers rose for the second consecutive month in November but still dropped 8.61% in the first 11 months of 2014. The army's seizure of power in May helped restore stability, boosting confidence among tourists.

site_title: Indonesia says considering removing government subsidies for gasoline next year
summary: Indonesia's Chief Economics Minister Sofyan Djalil announced plans to remove government subsidies for gasoline next year, but maintain subsidies for diesel. The policy change, which would not require parliamentary approval, aims to reduce fuel subsidies by half, following a recent 30% hike in fuel prices. The move is part of Indonesia's efforts to reduce its massive fuel subsidy budget of $19.63 billion.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's Chief Economics Minister Sofyan Djalil on Thursday said the government is considering removing subsidies for gasoline next year, but would maintain subsidies for diesel.

site_title: Fed eyes audit push as key political challenge in 2015
summary: The US Federal Reserve is intensifying its lobbying efforts to maintain its independence amid growing calls for an audit of its monetary policy decisions. The "Audit the Fed" movement, which gained momentum in 2015, has the potential to impact the Fed's ability to make decisions without political interference. Fed Chair Janet Yellen has reiterated the importance of keeping short-term political interests out of policy decisions, while officials acknowledge that boosting transparency has broad support. The Fed is expected to intensify its outreach to lawmakers, with Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester already meeting with lawmakers to discuss independence and other topics.

site_title: Global Tech reports FY2014 loss as mobile phone repair revenue falls
summary: Global Tech reported a FY2014 loss of HK$15.99 million, down from a HK$12.88 million net profit in FY2013, due to lower revenue of HK$89.79 million, a 18.78% decrease from the previous year's HK$110.55 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 2.32% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 2.32% on Thursday, driven by a rally on Wall Street and a weaker yen. The Nikkei 225 index ended at 17,210.05, while the Topix index climbed 1.80%. The move followed the US Federal Reserve's indication of interest rate hikes by mid-2015.

site_title: Olam's cocoa purchase raises supply, price volatility concerns
summary: Olam International has acquired Archer Daniels Midland's (ADM) cocoa processing business for $1.3 billion, increasing its processing capacity to over 700,000 tonnes and giving it more control over cocoa bean prices. The deal may reduce liquidity in the cocoa market, raising concerns about volatile prices and potential disruptions to customer relationships. While Olam's acquisition could create opportunities for new dealers, it also increases the risk for suppliers, who may face larger quantities of beans to purchase from smaller firms.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares ended higher on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 18.05 points to close at 1,699.95. The index saw 1.91 billion lots traded, with 761 gainers and 180 losers.

site_title: Oil prices up in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia on Thursday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate increasing 8 cents to $56.55 and Brent crude gaining 18 cents to $61.36. The gains follow a decline in US oil reserves and a statement from the Federal Reserve indicating interest rates will not be hiked until mid-2015. The news adds to a recent advance in prices, which have fallen 50% from their 2014 highs due to a global supply glut and a strong dollar.

site_title: Rouble steady in Asia after Russia measures to halt collapse
summary: The Russian rouble recovered in Asia after Russia launched measures to halt its collapse, including selling $7 billion in foreign reserves and implementing other currency-stabilizing measures. The rouble rose to 61.20 to the dollar and 74.92 against the euro. The Federal Reserve indicated it will not raise interest rates until mid-2015, supporting the dollar's rally. Slumping oil prices and punitive sanctions have contributed to the rouble's decline, but the recent measures and Fed's stance have helped stabilize the currency.

site_title: UK says phone firms to spend 5 bln stg on tackling mobile "hot spots"
summary: Britain's mobile phone network operators have agreed to spend £5 billion (US$8 billion) improving rural coverage by 2017, aiming for 90% guaranteed voice and text coverage. This pledge follows a government promise to tackle patchy coverage, with two-thirds of "not-spots" (no mobile coverage) expected to be cut. The deal replaces a proposed legislative change to force operators to share networks, which was opposed by the companies. Communications regulator Ofcom will monitor progress, and the investment may influence licence fees.

site_title: Silverlake Axis plots takeover bid for NZ-based Fintech Solutions
summary: Silverlake Axis has formed a company, Silverlake HGH, to launch a NZ$3 per share takeover bid for Finzsoft Solutions, an Auckland-based financial technology company. The acquisition will expand Silverlake's portfolio and deliver new offerings in the Asia-Pacific region. 51% of Silverlake HGH is held by Silverlake, with 49% held by interests associated with Finzsoft's managing director, Andrew Holliday. The deal aims to leverage Silverlake's product and service offering to access opportunities in the Asia-Pacific market, with Finzsoft benefiting from a committed cornerstone shareholder with industry knowledge and global reach.

site_title: China money rates rise sharply as mini-crunch anniversary approaches
summary: China's money rates surged to 8.5% on Thursday, the highest level since January, amid a lack of interbank market activity. The People's Bank of China has not injected or drained funds in seven consecutive sessions, sparking concerns of a mini-money crunch. Traders expect intense pressure on liquidity near year-end due to cash demands from companies and speculators seeking cash for IPOs. The central bank may issue backdoor liquidity injections to selected banks to mitigate the risk of a repeat of last December's mini-crunch.

site_title: The oil puzzle
summary: US$60 per barrel Brent crude has reached a high not seen since the Global Financial Crisis. Experts disagree on the implications, with optimists seeing a contained Russian currency crisis and lower oil prices as supportive of economic growth. However, pessimists warn of a full-blown crisis that could trigger a global or regional economic downturn, affecting oil-dependent economies and leading to widening credit spreads and reduced access to capital. Economists now temper 2015 growth expectations for Singapore due to the uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher, with the Straits Times Index gaining 16.42 points to 3,243.65. The market traded 1.17 billion shares valued at S$1.23 billion, with 220 gainers and 169 losers. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: EU summit to discuss crisis-hit Russia, economic plan
summary: EU leaders gathered in Brussels to discuss crisis-hit Russia and an economic plan, led by Poland's former premier Donald Tusk. The 315-billion-euro investment plan, proposed by Jean-Claude Juncker, aims to revive Europe's economy, but hard cash is expected to be lacking. No new sanctions on Russia will be decided, as EU leaders want to maintain dialogue with Moscow. The summit will focus on Ukraine, where peace talks are set to resume, and the EU will reiterate its readiness to do more in return for reforms.

site_title: Heavy snow kills 3, disrupts travel in Japan
summary: Heavy snow in Japan has killed at least three people, with two elderly women killed on Hokkaido and a man killed in a traffic accident on snow-bound roads in Hiroshima. Widespread disruption to travel has occurred, with over 550 flights cancelled, including some international routes. The famous bullet train network has also struggled to stick to its timetables. Forecasters warn of more snow and strong winds, with up to 80 centimeters expected in parts of northern Honshu by Friday morning.

site_title: Indonesia says will cut budget deficit target to 1% of GDP in 2019
summary: Indonesia plans to cut its budget deficit target to 1% of GDP in 2019 by reforming the tax system, aiming to avoid breaching the 3% limit. The country is also cracking down on tax evasion, imposing a temporary travel ban on individuals with outstanding tax bills. Finance Minister Bambang Brodjonegoro announced the plan to address a shortfall in tax revenue estimated at $6.15 billion. This move is part of Indonesia's efforts to stabilize its economy and meet its fiscal targets.

site_title: US determines North Korea behind Sony attack as studio pulls movie
summary: The US government has determined that North Korea was behind a cyberattack on Sony Pictures, which led to the cancellation of the release of the comedy film "The Interview." The hackers, who claimed to be incensed by the film, had threatened attacks on movie theaters showing the film, prompting several theater chains to drop plans for the release. Sony has pulled all plans to release the film, citing decisions by theater chains to hold off showing the film. The US government is expected to officially announce its findings in the near future.

site_title: Perennial China Retail Trust to suspend trading of units from Dec 23
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings completed the purchase of 90.64% of Perennial China Retail Trust (PCRT) units, reducing its free float to less than 10%. In accordance with SGX rules, PCRT will suspend trading of its units from December 23, as the trust no longer meets the 10% public float requirement. The offer will close on December 22, and trading will resume once the trust regains the required public float.

site_title: Japan auto lobby sounds alarm over weak domestic sales
summary: Japan's auto lobby is sounding the alarm over weak domestic sales, with Chairman Fumihiko Ike citing a "sense of crisis" due to government stimulus policies' failure to boost consumption. Domestic new car sales are down by double digits after the April sales tax hike, and the industry is also concerned about the impact of plunging emerging-market currencies, particularly in Russia. Automakers are discussing whether to replace Takata Corp's potentially defective air bags, which have been recalled worldwide.

site_title: China to push forward with capital account convertibility: forex regulator
summary: China plans to push forward with reforms to allow for full capital account convertibility, a move to circumvent controls on speculative capital flows. The reform aims to prevent methods like overinvoicing exports to Hong Kong to sneak money into the country. China's recent surge in precious metals exports, not linked to speculative capital flows, prompted regulators to investigate. The move is part of China's efforts to increase trade and investment, and may signal the end of deflationary price wars.

site_title: Fed's rate-hike guidance
summary: The US Federal Reserve has released its last statement for 2014, providing guidance on future rate hikes. The "Dot Chart" shows a distribution of views among Fed governors, with median interest rate targets decreasing for 2015 and 2016, indicating concerns about US economic growth. This decrease may signal a slower pace of rate hikes in 2015, contrary to previous expectations. The Fed's stance on rate hikes is expected to continue in 2015, but the timing and pace remain uncertain.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain 1% as positive Fed talk sparks relief
summary: Australian shares rose 1% on Thursday, their largest one-day gain since 2013, following upbeat comments from the Federal Reserve. The S&P/ASX 200 index increased 48.94 points to 5210.80, while New Zealand's NZX 50 index rose 0.4% to 5518.48. The relief rally came after a tumultuous week, marked by Russian financial turmoil and tumbling oil prices, and amid uncertainty over US-EU trade talks.

site_title: India's Modi moves in to speed up US$300b stuck projects
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has taken control of a project-monitoring body to accelerate investments worth nearly US$300 billion, aiming to revive manufacturing and boost the economy. This move comes as the country faces criticism for failing to deliver on its "Make in India" campaign, which aims to make India a manufacturing powerhouse. Industrial output contracted in October, its worst performance in three years, highlighting the need for Modi's efforts to spur investment and re-energise the economy.

site_title: UK sold Royal Mail too cheaply, but not by much: official report
summary: A UK government-commissioned report found that Royal Mail shares were sold too cheaply, but not by as much as previously estimated. The report estimated an additional 120-180 million pounds in revenue for the government if the price had been increased by 20-30 pence per share. The shares were sold at 330p in 2013, but rose to 618p before falling back to around 400p. The sale raised 2 billion pounds, with critics arguing it was rushed and the price was too low.

site_title: South Korea prosecutors say arrest warrant issued for KOGAS CEO over suspected bribery
summary: South Korean prosecutors have issued an arrest warrant for KOGAS CEO Jang Seok-hyo on suspicion of bribery worth hundreds of thousands of dollars. Jang is suspected of receiving bribes and breach of trust while heading an LNG tanker tugboat company before becoming KOGAS CEO in 2013. A court review of the warrant is ongoing, with the decision expected late Thursday.

site_title: Japan to provide US$25b stimulus to support regional economies: media
summary: Japan plans to spend over $25 billion in a stimulus package to revive regional economies affected by slumping household spending after a sales tax hike in April. The package, set to be finalized on Dec 27, will mainly consist of payouts to local governments to subsidize household purchases. The government will fund the package with extra tax revenues and leftover budget money, aiming to boost regional economies and garner votes in nationwide regional elections in April next year.

images.alt_text: Japan will spend over 3 trillion yen (US$25 billion) in a stimulus package aimed at reviving regional economies hit by slumping household spending after a sales tax hike in April, the Asahi newspaper said on Thursday.

site_title: China's November home prices fall for third straight month
summary: China's home prices fell 3.7% in November for the third consecutive month, with 68 of 70 major cities experiencing year-on-year declines. This marks the largest drop since 2011 and is attributed to a persistent property downturn. The decline is expected to intensify concerns about economic growth, with GDP growth projected to cool to 6.8% in 2015. Despite a slight increase in property sales, the market is expected to remain weak, with policy easing by the central bank potentially providing a boost.

images.alt_text: China's home prices fell in November for a third consecutive month versus year-ago levels, pointing to a persistent property downturn despite efforts by authorities to energise the market.

site_title: Slumping oil won't derail US$500b Gulf infrastructure plan
summary: Gulf countries are unlikely to be deterred from their massive infrastructure spending plans, despite the impact of lower oil prices. The US$500 billion Gulf infrastructure plan is expected to be funded through a combination of government reserves, self-financing, and private sector funding. Rich nations are prioritizing infrastructure spending to maintain economic growth, while states are urged to consider effective funding mixes. Despite concerns about reducing public spending and burning through savings, governments are prioritizing infrastructure projects, with some using savings to fund projects off-budget.

site_title: Australia's NSW state to sell or lease electricity network for US$16b
summary: Australia's New South Wales state plans to sell or lease 49% of its electricity network for $16.24 billion, raising $20 billion to fund infrastructure projects. The move is expected to create over 100,000 jobs and boost the economy by $300 billion over two decades. The sale is part of the state's efforts to attract revenue and pay for capital works, following the end of a mining investment boom.

site_title: Uber fights French ban at EU
summary: Uber has filed an EU complaint against a French ban on amateur drivers doubling as chauffeurs, which could limit the company's business model. The ban, implemented earlier this year, is aimed at taxi drivers, but Uber operates by connecting drivers and passengers through a cellphone application. The EU complaint follows similar opposition from taxi companies and lawsuits in other countries, where Uber has been accused of unfair competition and unvetted drivers.

site_title: Australian PM says cafe siege 'horrific wake-up call'
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott has described the Sydney cafe siege as an "horrific wake-up call" after two hostages and the gunman were killed. An urgent inquiry has been ordered to investigate the circumstances surrounding the tragedy, including why the gunman, Man Haron Monis, was not under surveillance given his history of extremism and violence. Monis, who was on bail for multiple charges, took 17 hostages at a cafe in Sydney's heart before being killed in a police operation.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 1.92% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.92% on Thursday, driven by a stronger US dollar against the yen and gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index opened at 17,142.95, following a 323.22-point gain. The US Federal Reserve signaled no interest rate hike in 2015, boosting the dollar. Japanese exporters benefited from a weak yen, while Sony rose 2.15% after canceling a North Korea-themed film release.

site_title: Croesus Retail Trust increases hedging to protect it from falling yen
summary: Croesus Retail Trust (CRT) has increased its hedging to approximately 100% to protect against a falling Japanese yen, which has declined 9.3% against the Singapore dollar in the past four months. The move aims to ensure steady returns to investors. CRT's CEO, Jim Chang, stated that the decision is a response to the weakening yen and aims to insulate distributable income from forex risks. The trust distributes 100% of its income up to Dec 31, 2015, and 90% thereafter, with assets and liabilities denominated in Japanese yen.

site_title: New York bans fracking after health report
summary: New York state will ban hydraulic fracturing, also known as fracking, after a health report concluded that the process poses significant health risks. The ban, which will be issued early next year, makes New York the only state to completely prohibit fracking. The decision was met with opposition from the oil and gas industry, which claims it will deprive the state of jobs and revenue. Environmental groups hailed the move as a national leadership stance, citing the potential health risks of fracking.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore share prices opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 9.07 points to 3,236.30. Gainers outnumbered losers 104 to 32, with volume reaching 66.9 million shares worth S$87.0 million. This follows a 0.4% increase on Wednesday. The rally was driven by investors staying positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Italy arrest 18 over China bank transfers via British company
summary: Italy's financial police arrested 18 suspects, mostly Rome-based ethnic Chinese, over alleged money laundering of profits from importing counterfeit goods made in China. The suspects used British cash transfer company Sigue Global Services Ltd to move funds, avoiding declaration requirements under international money-laundering rules. Assets worth 13 million euros have been frozen pending the outcome of the inquiry. The suspects are accused of defrauding tax authorities and laundering over a billion euros.

site_title: China shows stabilisation in Q4, but investment sliding: business survey
summary: China's economy showed mild stabilisation in the fourth quarter, with sales, profits, and employment improving slightly, but corporate investment intentions declined for the fourth straight quarter, with 47% of respondents planning to decrease capital expenditure. The China Beige Book highlighted stubborn resistance to efforts to reinvigorate growth, citing weak internal demand despite strong service performance. The report challenges assumptions about the effectiveness of monetary easing measures, suggesting they may not lead to fresh productive investment.

site_title: Asian markets up after Fed meeting
summary: Asian markets rallied on Thursday after the US Federal Reserve indicated that interest rates may not rise until mid-2015, sparking a Wall Street recovery. The news boosted the dollar, with Asian markets surging 2-3% and US shares jumping 1.5-2%. Oil prices also rose, and concerns about Russia's economy eased after the country implemented measures to stabilize its currency. The Fed's change in language suggested a possible rate hike in the first half of 2015, lifting investor sentiment.

site_title: White House says FBI leading probe of cyber attack on Sony Pictures
summary: The White House announced that the FBI is leading the investigation into the cyber attack on Sony Pictures, stating that the US government is investigating attribution and will provide an update at an appropriate time. The US government has offered Sony Pictures support and assistance. A source suggests that the US may soon officially attribute the attack to the North Korean government.

site_title: Oil surges in about-face as some bet sub-US$60 Brent won't last
summary: Oil prices surged 6% on Wednesday before closing off their peaks, halting a nearly non-stop selling trend. The sudden spike was attributed to a big build in crude stockpiles at Cushing, with traders buying up contracts or taking profits on short positions. The rally caught traders by surprise, with speculation ranging from the Russian rouble's surge to US-Cuba diplomatic relations. The market is now looking for reasons to spike up, with volatility expected.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Silverlake, Perennial Real Estate, Oxley, Oil & Gas
summary: Silverlake Axis formed a company to launch a NZ$3 per share takeover offer for Finzsoft Solutions. Perennial Real Estate Holding completed the purchase of 90.64% of Perennial China Retail Trust's units. Oxley Holdings emerged as the preferred bidder for a 2.35 hectare commercial site in Dublin. Stocks in the Oil & Gas sector bounced back due to short-covering ahead of a likely interest rate hike, with Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine leading the gains.

site_title: Uber plans tighter screening for drivers
summary: Uber is expanding its driver screening process, exploring biometrics and voice verification to enhance safety. The company aims to build tools for enhanced driver screening, including polygraph tests, and will add its own processes on top of commercial license verifications. Uber's international background-verification process varies, with some countries' records being less rigorous and more prone to manipulation. The company is also building safety incident response teams to provide round-the-clock support, following controversies over its business practices and rapid expansion.

images.alt_text: Online taxi service Uber Technologies Inc, which had a driver was accused of rape in New Delhi, said it was exploring adding new methods to verify drivers'credentials and make its service safer.

site_title: US retailers curb holiday borrowing, avoid inventory glut
summary: US retailers are not borrowing heavily this holiday season, according to Wells Fargo Capital Finance. The credit utilization for inventory is near its lowest level since the 2008 financial crisis, suggesting retailers may not be stuck with massive inventories. This trend contrasts with last year's severe winter that kept shoppers away, causing retailers to struggle with bloated inventories. As a result, retailers are avoiding inventory glut and discounting, which may indicate a more manageable holiday borrowing situation.

site_title: UN chief to visit Ebola-hit countries
summary: UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon is visiting Ebola-hit countries in West Africa to assess international efforts to combat the epidemic. He will travel to Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone, Mali, and Ghana, where the UN is leading the response. Ban emphasizes the need for more financial help and health workers, citing the need to "get to zero" cases. The visit comes a year after the outbreak began and follows criticism of the UN's initial response. Ban has previously stated that the outbreak could be brought under control in 2015 with increased international mobilization.

site_title: American Air flight hit by storm, diverts to Tokyo
summary: A US-bound American Airlines flight, American Airlines Flight 280, was diverted to Tokyo's Narita airport after hitting severe turbulence created by a strong winter storm. The Boeing 777-200, carrying 240 passengers and 15 crew, dropped suddenly and was rocked for 30-40 seconds, resulting in minor injuries to four passengers and one crew member. The flight will continue to Dallas/Fort Worth airport on Wednesday, and none of the injuries were life-threatening. The storm slammed Japan's northernmost main island of Hokkaido and forced the cancellation of over 100 flights.

site_title: EU steps up trade dispute with Brazil at WTO
summary: The World Trade Organization has agreed to set up a panel to rule on European Union complaints that Brazil unfairly raised import duties on cars and other goods. The EU accuses Brazil of adopting protectionist measures to favor local producers. The dispute escalates differences between the two sides as they try to reach a long-delayed trade pact. Brazil claims its industrial policies comply with WTO regulations and aim to promote technological development. The dispute may not affect ongoing trade negotiations between Brazil and the EU, which have been stalled for two decades.

site_title: India property fund plans to raise US$500m
summary: India's HDFC Property Fund plans to raise US$500 million to invest in residential real estate projects in western and southern India. The fund, which expects to generate 21% returns over seven years, aims to secure funding from investors such as GIC, Temasek, and Oman's State General Reserve Fund. The move comes as India's debt-laden property developers face slow home sales and high interest costs, with analysts predicting a potential interest rate cut by the central bank early next year.

site_title: CEO of Brazil's Petrobras says he will not resign
summary: Brazil's Petrobras CEO Graca Foster refuses to resign amid corruption scandal, citing President Dilma Rousseff's trust. Foster outlines plan to reverse company's fortunes by investing less and saving more in 2015. An independent audit will investigate Petrobras directors and subsidiaries, with 66 management measures to improve corporate governance. The company faces financial challenges, including a 50% decline in oil prices and a weakening real. Petrobras shares have lost half their value in three months, and the company has delayed releasing third quarter financial results.

images.alt_text: The chief executive of Brazil's state oil giant Petrobras said Wednesday that she will not resign despite the corruption scandal shaking the company and the ruling Workers' Party.

site_title: November exports miss forecasts
summary: Singapore's November exports rose 1.6% from a weak base, missing market expectations, as shipments to key markets like the US, EU, and China dropped by double digits. Non-oil domestic exports fell 0.5% in October, but rebounded in November with a 7.5% increase, driven by a 26.8% jump in pharmaceuticals exports. Economists warn that this weak performance may dent the economy's growth in the fourth quarter, with some forecasting GDP growth of less than 3.0% for 2014.

images.alt_text: Singapore exports recovered in November - but only just - on a weak base a year ago. In fact, non-oil domestic exports (NODX) to some of the Republic's key markets suffered double-digit drops.

site_title: IMF disburses US$1 billion to Pakistan under loan programme
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has disbursed $1.05 billion to Pakistan as part of a $6.8 billion loan programme. This is the second installment, following a $1 billion loan released in April. Pakistan must meet conditions, including cracking down on tax evasion and privatising loss-making state companies, to receive further funds. The loan will be released in increments, and default is possible if conditions are not met.

site_title: Fed confident on US growth, opens door wider to rate hike
summary: The Federal Reserve expressed confidence in the US economy, signaling a potential interest rate hike in 2015. Fed Chair Janet Yellen stated that the committee would take a "patient" approach, likely not raising rates until at least April 2015. The Fed projects 2.6-3.0% economic growth, a 5.2-5.3% unemployment rate, and 1.0-1.6% inflation next year, with core inflation expected to turn higher by 2016.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve on Wednesday offered a strong signal that it was on track to raise interest rates sometime next year, altering a pledge to keep them near zero for a "considerable time" in a show of confidence in the US economy.

site_title: New e-book subscription service enters fraught market
summary: Bookmate, a new e-book subscription service, launched in Singapore in partnership with StarHub, offering a social media-friendly platform and 500,000 e-book titles. Users can access the e-books for $9.98/month and share their reading history and reviews on Facebook or Twitter. Bookmate aims to differentiate itself from competitors like Amazon and Google Play Books by integrating social media features. Despite the closure of two major e-book players last year, Bookmate plans to expand into Malaysia, Indonesia, and the Philippines, with a focus on showcasing local authors, including Singaporean comics.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 6.82 points to 1688.03. The index saw a 197-33 gain-to-lose ratio. Volume reached 59.71 million lots worth RM24.46 million.

site_title: Russia spends billions to prop up rouble
summary: Russia has intervened to prop up its struggling rouble, spending billions to halt a currency crisis and prevent a financial meltdown. The rouble lost 60% of its value since the start of the year, and the government has sold around $7 billion to stabilize the currency. The central bank has also announced measures to ease access to foreign currency and protect banks from losses. The crisis threatens to push Russia into recession, with the economy expected to contract by 5% next year, and President Vladimir Putin's popularity may be affected by the economic turmoil.

site_title: German investor confidence gains in a sign of stronger growth
summary: German investor confidence rose for a second month, increasing to 34.9 in December, surpassing economists' forecasts of 20. The ZEW Centre for European Economic Research attributed the rise to initial signs of strengthened growth in the fourth quarter, despite a sluggish start. A Bundesbank report noted that German factory orders and industrial production gained in October, while business confidence climbed last month. The economic growth outlook has improved, with the ZEW assessment of the current situation rising to 10 in December from 3.3 the previous month.

site_title: Amid volatile markets, growth forecasts seen at risk
summary: Singapore's private sector economists have tempered their growth expectations for 2015, with a median forecast of 3.1% growth, slightly above 3% for this year. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's poll showed a probability distribution indicating a 2-2.9% growth slowdown next year, citing risks such as weak external demand, manpower constraints, and elevated costs. The forecast cuts come amid volatile markets, low oil prices, and weak economic data from China, Japan, and Europe.

site_title: Global life expectancy rises: study
summary: Global life expectancy rose to 71.5 years in 2013, a 5.8-year increase for men and 6.6-year increase for women since 1990, according to a study. The gains were attributed to declining death rates from cancers and cardiovascular disease in high-income regions, and rapidly declining death rates for diarrhoea, lower respiratory tract infections, and neonatal disorders in less affluent regions. However, some chronic conditions, such as liver cancer and chronic kidney disease, saw significant increases.

site_title: US: Wall St rallies after Fed statement; S&P has best day this year
summary: US stocks rallied on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 scoring its best day since October 2013, driven by a 4.2% gain in the S&P energy index. The Federal Reserve gave an upbeat assessment of the economy and indicated it would take a patient approach to lifting interest rates, supporting the rally. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 288 points, while the Nasdaq Composite added 96.48 points, and all 10 S&P sectors ended higher.

site_title: Canada court orders Apple to hand over iPhone documents
summary: A Canadian Federal Court ordered Apple's Canadian subsidiary to hand over nearly three years' worth of documents related to iPhone sales as part of an anti-competition probe. The Competition Bureau is investigating whether Apple stifled competition by using its global clout to pressure local wireless carriers into not lowering the price of competing handsets. Apple must submit documents, including emails and contracts, dating back to 2012 and provide figures, analyses, and strategic plans for iPhone sales in Canada. The probe is ongoing, with Apple having 90 days to comply or appeal.

site_title: Japan banks to bulk up India presence on improving ties
summary: Japan's largest banks, including Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Mizuho Financial Group Inc, plan to expand their presence in India by opening new branches and offering services such as corporate deposits and debt capital market advisory. The move is driven by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's reform agenda and improving ties between the two countries. Japan aims to double investments in India within five years, and Indian banks are seen as inefficient and ripe for foreign competition. Japanese banks believe they can absorb lending exposure to Indian clients better than European and American banks.

site_title: Karl Pohl's guide to central banking
summary: Karl Otto Pöhl, the late president of the German Bundesbank, left a lasting legacy in central banking. Pöhl's spirit of nonchalant hedonism and adherence to price stability and independence guided his decisions, despite challenges from politicians. Key lessons from his tenure include upholding independence, avoiding monetary easing, and being cautious of rapid European integration. Pöhl's comments on East Germany's unpreparedness for monetary union also proved prescient. His legacy serves as a reminder that there are no easy answers in central banking, and his successors must navigate fraught balancing acts between in-house decision-making and international expectations.

site_title: Fewer presents under S'pore Christmas trees this year
summary: A survey by UOB found that Singaporeans have set aside a total festive shopping budget of S$709 for Christmas this year, a 20% decrease from last year. The majority of the budget (76%) will be spent on presents for family members, with the most expensive gift planned to be for a spouse or partner. This year's reduced budget is attributed to the cautious economic outlook for 2015, with consumers opting to spend less on non-essential items and getting the most bang for their buck.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Tag Heuer changes tune, now looking at smartwatches
summary: Tag Heuer's new CEO, Jean-Claude Biver, has changed his stance on smartwatches, acknowledging their potential place in the company's line-up. Biver insisted that any smartwatch would have to be unique and of high quality to maintain the brand's luxury reputation. The company plans to divide its research and development department to focus on technological innovation, possibly through partnerships with universities or specialist firms. This shift comes as Tag Heuer is undergoing changes, including layoffs and scrapping non-core products, in an effort to concentrate on its core business.

site_title: Update: US, Cuba move to end Cold War stand-off
summary: The US and Cuba announced a historic agreement to end five decades of Cold War hostility, with President Barack Obama and Cuban President Raul Castro re-establishing diplomatic ties and easing a crippling US trade embargo. The breakthrough came after a prisoner exchange and Havana's release of dozens of political prisoners. The US will re-establish its embassy in Havana and re-examine its designation of Cuba as a state sponsor of terrorism. Obama called the move a "new chapter" in relations with Cuba, while Castro urged the President to work around Congress to lift the embargo.

site_title: Consumer inflation posts largest drop in 6 years
summary: US consumer prices dropped 0.3% in November, the largest decline in nearly six years, as petrol prices plummeted. The core CPI rose 0.1%, while food prices increased 0.2%. Despite this, inflation remains below the Federal Reserve's target of 2%. Economists expect the Fed to signal interest rate hikes in mid-2015 due to job growth and accelerating economic slack absorption. The current account deficit rose 1.9% to $100.3 billion in Q3, driven by increased exports and a widening trade shortfall.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific to delever after jumbo LBO
summary: Del Monte Pacific Limited, a Philippine canned juice maker, plans to delever after a rare offshore preference share offering of $360m to pay off a $630m bridge loan backing its acquisition of US-based Del Monte Foods Inc. in 2014. The deal, which includes a $180m rights issue, aims to lower the company's net gearing to 1.7x-1.8x by April 2015. The offering will provide investors with access to a US consumer business contributing 80% of the company's turnover, but the high leverage may test investor appetite.

site_title: The transformation of Singapore banks
summary: Singapore's banking sector experienced significant growth in 2014, with local banks leading the charge and foreign banks expanding their presence. DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank made transformative acquisitions, with DBS acquiring Societe Generale Private Banking Asia and OCBC acquiring Hong Kong's Wing Hang Bank. Foreign banks, including HSBC and Morgan Stanley, also ramped up their operations in retail and private banking, while Japanese banks The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ and Mizuho Bank established their Asia and Oceania headquarters in Singapore. The sector is expected to continue growing in 2015, driven by the expected pick-up in external demand and the expansion of externally oriented sectors.

site_title: Watershed year as investment sales slump to S$17b-18b
summary: Singapore's investment sales have slumped to S$17b-18b this year, the lowest quarterly level since the global crisis. Despite this, the office sector remains resilient, with transactions reaching S$4.8 billion year-to-date. Bulk sales of high-end residential units have seen an uptick, with Blackstone completing the purchase of 18 units at Paterson Suites for S$2,100 psf. Experts expect 2015 to see an extension of the lacklustre performance, with forecasted investment sales ranging from S$12b-S$14b. However, the office sector and luxury residential market may present opportunities for investors.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Vanke plans onshore debt after rules eased
summary: China's largest listed property developer Vanke plans to sell 1.8 billion yuan (S$380 million) of three-year securities on December 24 to repay bank loans. This comes after regulators eased rules allowing more developers to access the onshore note market, supporting the slumping industry. The move follows China's central bank cutting its benchmark interest rate after housing sales slumped 10% this year. Vanke's bond is rated AAA, and the lead underwriter is Industrial & Commercial Bank of China.

site_title: Xi's visit to Macau deals cold deck to VIP gamblers
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Macau aims to diversify the region beyond its casino industry, which has faced a decline in VIP gamblers and a subsequent loss of market value. The government is cracking down on illicit money transfers, and Xi's visit is seen as a push for Macau to expand into family-friendly entertainment and non-gaming amenities. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to curb corrupt officials who have fled overseas, and casino moguls are under pressure to add non-gaming elements to secure their licenses.

images.alt_text: As Chinese President Xi Jinping arrives in Macau this weekend for his first official visit in five years, the message from Beijing is clear: the world's biggest gambling centre cannot remain a one-industry town.

site_title: SpiceJet rescue no fix for India's aviation woes
summary: India's second-largest single-brand carrier SpiceJet is facing financial woes and may receive a government-backed loan of up to $94 million. The airline needs more equity, but a comprehensive bankruptcy law is lacking, making it difficult to address financial troubles. Despite a rescue, exorbitant fuel taxes and industry constraints will continue to affect the aviation sector. The government is attempting to save jobs and prevent a repeat of the Kingfisher Airlines failure, but the rescue may not be a fix for India's broader aviation issues. SpiceJet's chairman, Kalanithi Maran, will determine the airline's future.

images.alt_text: Even after efforts to trim costs, SpiceJet made a net loss of US$49 million in the quarter ended Sept 30 and its net debt is almost five times as large

site_title: Barclays' CEO: funds set aside to settle forex probe not enough
summary: Barclays CEO Antony Jenkins stated that the $783.70 million set aside to settle allegations of foreign exchange market rigging is insufficient. He expressed hope for a settlement with regulators within the next year. Jenkins also mentioned that bonuses would be less controversial this season, as profits are expected to drop at the investment bank. Additionally, he signaled that the universal banking model is dead, and banks must selectively choose where to invest due to capital constraints and technological investments.

site_title: SGX clarifies issues about company announcements and StockFacts
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has clarified issues related to company announcements and its StockFacts portal. The exchange has defined "Company Name" and "Security Name" on its website to avoid confusion. For SGX StockFacts, the exchange displays company names in search results, allowing users to search by keywords or company names. Despite receiving over 1.7 million page visits since its launch, the exchange aims to improve its services to provide accurate and timely information to investors.

site_title: Oil prices: near-term stabilisation, long-term rebound seen
summary: Oil prices have declined by over 45% since the summer due to oversupply and disappointing economic data. Despite OPEC's decision to keep production levels unchanged, some oil suppliers have hinted at cuts, while others, such as Saudi Arabia, have maintained their quotas. The near-term outlook is uncertain, but the authors expect oil prices to stabilize and rebound within several weeks. In the medium term, production levels will become more visible, and the impact of low prices on oil demand and supply will be felt. The long-term outlook suggests a potential rebound in oil prices to around $80-$90/bbl in 2015, driven by a decline in investment in energy infrastructure.

site_title: Oil below US$59 as producers keep pumping
summary: Brent crude oil prices fell below $59 a barrel, reaching a 5 1/2-year low, as major oil producers signal they will maintain output despite a supply glut and faltering demand. Opec members, which had backed an output cut in November, are now prepared to wait for a year to see the market stabilize. US crude oil prices also dropped to their lowest since May 2009. Analysts say the lack of action from Opec members, combined with increasing US shale production, is adding to downward pressure on prices.

site_title: Rouble slide resumes as govt purchases fail to stem rout
summary: Russia's rouble plummeted, erasing an 8.4% rally within an hour after the Finance Ministry announced a failed attempt to stem the rout. The currency has lost 52% this year, its deepest decline since 1998. Emergency measures have failed for the second time this week, narrowing Vladimir Putin's options in addressing the country's financial crisis. The rouble's slide further complicates Putin's efforts to stabilize the economy and maintain investor confidence.

site_title: Taxi-Taxi@SG: LTA launches 'available cabs nearby' app
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore has launched "Taxi-Taxi@SG", a new app that allows commuters to broadcast their locations to nearby taxi drivers, reducing empty cruising and improving taxi availability. The app, available for download, complements existing third-party taxi-booking apps and provides commuters with more informed transport options. Industry players, including GrabTaxi and Easy Taxi, welcome the initiative, while Baidu's investment in Uber signals the global taxi app war continues.

site_title: Investors in troubled oil bonds leaning on banks for rescue
summary: US mutual funds holding junk-rated energy debt, totaling $30 billion, rely on bank credit lines to survive plummeting crude prices. The funds are forced to decide whether to sell their bonds at deep discounts or wait for a possible oil price recovery. Energy companies with distressed bonds, such as Quicksilver Resources and Sanchez Energy, have slashed exploration plans due to low oil prices. Banks are extending credit to these companies, but the lifeline is not unlimited, and the funds are vulnerable to default. The energy bond market has surged 155% since 2009, with some bonds selling at 30 cents to 40 cents on the dollar.

site_title: Car COEs mostly flat; Cat C slides 13%
summary: Singapore's COE premiums for passenger cars were largely flat, with Category A dropping to S$65,889 and Category B falling to S$74,000. Commercial vehicles saw a 13% decrease, with Category C dropping to S$52,100. The open category COE, which tracks Category B, fell by S$2,914 to S$73,990. The motor industry appears to be winding down as 2014 comes to an end, with fewer bids and lower premiums in recent tenders.

site_title: Rouble rousing
summary: Russia's ruble strengthened against the US dollar, amid low oil prices. Singapore stocks rose for the fifth consecutive day, ahead of GDP data, while traders in Asia continued to push stocks higher despite US President-elect Donald Trump's recent threats. Key takeaways include mandatory offers for Singapore companies PSC and others, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records in the US despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: RBS shrinks Irish arm with sale of £4.8b property debt
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) has sold £4.8 billion of Irish property loans to US private equity firm Cerberus, reducing its problem loans as part of its plan to shrink its business in Ireland. RBS will receive up to £1.1 billion in cash from the sale, with the remaining loans being placed in a "bad bank" to be sold or run down. The move follows RBS's decision to keep its Irish business after a five-month review, despite losses of billions of pounds in the Republic of Ireland since the property crash.

site_title: Rent-a-Christmas-tree firm lets Paris firs live on
summary: A French startup, Treezmas, is revolutionizing the Christmas tree industry by offering live trees for rent, which are collected and replanted after the holiday season. The company, founded by four school friends, aims to reduce waste and environmental damage by giving trees a second life. With 1,500 trees rented out this season, Treezmas joins a growing trend of home-delivery and replanting ventures in Europe and the US.

site_title: Offshore services firms fall victims to oil downturn
summary: Singapore-listed offshore support services companies have seen a 13.4% average decline in total returns for the year, with some stocks dropping over 50% due to falling oil prices. The 32 offshore support services stocks, valued at S$8 billion, have seen a combined market capitalisation drop, with the worst performer, Jasper Investments, losing 84.9% of its value. The exception was Pacific Radiance, which lost only 10.8%.

site_title: Chinese retail investors flocking back to stock market
summary: Chinese retail investors are flocking back to the stock market at the fastest pace in seven years, driven by President Xi Jinping's support for rising share prices and a maturing market. The Shanghai Composite Index has surged 22% in the past month, with record turnover and a growing buzz about the market. Despite state media warning of the risks of a reversal, experts predict an extended bull market, citing valuations still 70% below their 2007 peak. Investors are embracing leverage, with the outstanding value of equity purchases using borrowed money reaching a record 949.3 billion yuan.

site_title: EU says Ukraine needs US$15b, has limited ability to help
summary: The European Union has estimated that Ukraine needs an additional $15 billion in financing to withstand its economic crisis, but the EU has limited capacity to help. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) previously approved a $17 billion bailout package for Ukraine, but the country is at risk of defaulting due to ongoing economic disruption and pro-Russian rebellion in eastern territories, resulting in over 4,700 deaths. Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseny Yatseniuk has appealed for urgent financial aid from the EU.

site_title: Long-established Dutch flower auction faces competition
summary: The Dutch flower auction in Aalsmeer, Netherlands, is facing significant competition, with concerns over carbon emissions and rising costs of jet fuel impacting the global flower trade. The industry has adapted, with many growers moving to warmer climates, and the rise of presales and direct shipping. Despite this, the flower industry remains resilient, with big producers like Triflor doing well, while smaller growers have been pruned from the market. The auction's membership has decreased, but profits have grown, and the industry is exploring new ways to stay competitive, such as using digital photos and data to sell flowers before they are grown and harvested.

site_title: Russian situation may have its impact on global economy
summary: Russia's central bank raised interest rates by 6.5 percentage points to combat a falling rouble, which has lost half its value this year due to Western sanctions and plummeting oil prices. The move aims to prop up the currency, but it may not be enough to prevent an economic crisis. With $100 billion of debt due next year, Russia faces serious doubts over its ability to repay, echoing the 1998 default when interest rates rose to 100% and capital controls were introduced. The Fed's upcoming rate hike decision will also be closely watched, and investors are shifting capital to safe havens, affecting emerging markets like Indonesia and India.

site_title: Barclays dark-pool suits in US to be consolidated
summary: US District Judge Jesse Furman will oversee the consolidation of five cases alleging Barclays misrepresented its LX dark pool as being insulated from high-frequency traders. The cases, involving investors who claim the bank provided secret advantages to favored traders, will allow for quicker and less costly pre-trial information exchanges. The consolidation aims to eliminate duplicative discovery, prevent inconsistent pre-trial rulings, and conserve judicial resources. The cases, including those filed by the city of Providence and the Plumbers and Pipefitters National Pension Fund, seek to represent a nationwide class of traders who lost money due to Barclays' alleged misconduct.

site_title: HDB's deficit widens as it ramps up flat supply (Clarification)
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) of Singapore reported a net deficit of S$1.97 billion in its fiscal year ended March 2014, more than doubling from the previous year. The deficit was driven by a S$1.93 billion shortfall on its home ownership programme due to higher expected losses on flats under construction. HDB ramped up its supply of public flats, with 86,298 units under construction, and spent S$7.07 billion to buy land and S$4.11 billion on building public housing. The annual deficit is fully covered by government grants.

site_title: Swiss govt votes first woman onto SNB board
summary: The Swiss government has chosen Andrea Maechler to become the first female member of the Swiss National Bank's (SNB) governing board, a historic first in the central bank's 107-year history. Maechler, 45, will oversee the bank's $479 billion forex reserves and head the department responsible for the Swiss franc's cap against the euro. A native French speaker and economist with experience at the International Monetary Fund (IMF), Maechler will replace Fritz Zurbruegg, who will become vice-president next July.

site_title: EU to combat tax evasion with central registers
summary: The European Union has agreed to rules to combat tax evasion by setting up central registers of beneficial ownership. The registers will list the names, dates of birth, and nationalities of individuals who own and profit from companies, trusts, and other entities. Banks and financial institutions will be required to be more vigilant about suspicious transactions, and the registers will be open to national authorities and the public with certain restrictions. The changes are expected to come into force around 2017.

site_title: Fed rate rise won't stop gold's recovery next year: ANZ
summary: Gold prices are expected to recover next year due to improved demand in China and India, according to ANZ. The bank forecasts gold to reach US$1,280 an ounce by the end of 2015 and US$1,420 by the end of 2016, despite a Federal Reserve interest rate rise. Improved demand in key markets and a decrease in oil prices are cited as factors contributing to the forecast.

site_title: Germans spur price battles between British supermarkets
summary: British supermarkets are cutting prices ahead of Christmas in response to competition from German-owned discounters Lidl and Aldi, sparking "price battles" across the country. This has led to a drop in British food sales for the first time in 20 years, with prices contributing to 12-year lows in inflation. Major supermarket chains like Tesco, Asda, and Sainsbury's are slashing prices to regain lost market share, while Aldi and Lidl continue to gain ground with their low-price strategies and expanding job offerings.

site_title: Bonus pool for Citigroup traders likely to be unchanged from 2013: source
summary: Citigroup traders will likely receive unchanged year-end bonuses from 2013, despite a 9% decline in trading revenue. Investment bankers will see a 2-3% increase, while some may receive 5% increases. CEO Michael Corbat is under pressure to limit compensation costs amid a slump in trading revenue and rising legal expenses. The bank aims to reduce its efficiency ratio to the "mid-50 per cent" range by 2015, as predicted by Corbat.

site_title: EU fiscal deals probe extends to all member countries
summary: The European Union's competition regulator is expanding its probe into sweetheart fiscal deals, requesting all EU countries to provide information about tax accords with multinationals. The probe aims to identify if and where competition in the single market is being distorted through selective tax advantages. EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager is seeking lists of companies granted tax rulings between 2010 and 2013, including deals with Apple, Amazon, and Starbucks. The investigation will help combat tax avoidance and fight for fair tax competition, with Vestager stating that the information will be used to identify and combat illegal aid.

site_title: Vard wins deal to build Farstad offshore subsea construction vessel
summary: Vard Holdings secured a contract to build a 98-meter offshore subsea construction vessel for Farstad Shipping. The vessel, designed by Vard 3 17, will feature a 150-tonne active heave compensated offshore crane and be delivered in Q4 2016. The project is part of a five-year framework agreement between Farstad and Technip Norge. This contract win comes despite low oil prices, with Vard's orderbook valued at 20.1 billion kroner (S$3.5 billion) as of September 30, 2014.

site_title: Foreign condo owners scarce in Vancouver, Toronto
summary: Foreigners own a small percentage of condominiums in Vancouver and Toronto, with 2.4% in Toronto and 2.3% in Vancouver, according to a Canada Mortgage & Housing survey. This suggests that foreign investment is not a significant contributor to the Canadian housing market, reducing the risk of a housing-market crash. The survey found lower foreign ownership rates in other cities.

site_title: Dollar rebounds ahead of Fed policy statement
summary: The US dollar rebounded 0.6% on Wednesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy statement, reversing a day of losses amid a Russian currency crisis and declining oil prices. The rouble has lost 50% this year, and Brent crude fell to a 5½-year trough. The dollar recovered against the yen, euro, and a basket of major currencies, but emerging Asian currencies, such as Indonesia's rupiah and India's rupee, remained cautious. The Fed's policy statement is expected to be cautious, potentially slowing interest rate hikes.

site_title: Puma owner 'explored' sportswear firm's sale
summary: Kering, the parent company of Gucci, has explored the sale of German sportswear brand Puma, contacting potential buyers including Middle Eastern sovereign funds and Asian investors. The discussions have yet to lead to a takeover proposal, with Kering's stock falling 4.3% after the company announced the departure of top executives from Gucci. Analysts are skeptical about Kering's decision, citing the lower margins of the sporting goods market compared to luxury goods. Puma is revamping its athletic shoes and marketing efforts to reposition itself around performance gear.

site_title: Rise of Dubai property prices slow in H2; 2015 outlook stable
summary: Dubai property prices slowed in the second half of 2014, with valuations expected to remain steady in 2015 due to a glut of new units. The real estate sector, one of the most volatile globally, rebounded from a boom to bust to boom again, with residential property rental values rising 7% in 2014 and sales prices climbing 18% this year. A large number of new residential units are set to enter the market next year, which may impact prices. The major investors in Dubai's property market remain UAE nationals, Indians, and Pakistanis.

site_title: The economics of engaging India - risks and rewards
summary: India's economy is expected to grow by 6% in 2015, the second highest increase among larger economies, according to a UN report. The Modi government's initiatives, such as education reform and a "Make in India" campaign, are taking shape and gaining attention. Business leaders from Singapore believe the timing is good for expansion into India, citing a more positive outlook on the country's growth. However, they also caution that navigating India's complex bureaucracy and regulatory hurdles can be challenging. SMEs are encouraged to tap into India's growth story by linking up with established partners and leveraging local knowledge and expertise.

images.alt_text: R Theyvendran believes that the timing is very good now.
Chandra Das advises those heading for India to do their homework first.
Piyush Gupta says that the Modi government is taking steps in the right direction.
Jonathan Yap advises foreign companies to understand Indian culture.
Manaw Prasad's wish is for the new government's anti- corruption drive to succeed.
Mark Chong Chin Kok says first-mover advantage is in securing a good foothold.
Marcelo Wesseler notes that logistics and payment gateways are key challenges.

site_title: Co-Operative fails BOE stress test; RBS, Lloyds barely pass
summary: The Co-Operative Bank failed the Bank of England's (BOE) stress test, while Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) and Lloyds Banking Group barely passed. The test, which simulated a severe economic shock, aimed to revive investor confidence in lenders. RBS plans to sell £2 billion of notes to bolster capital, while Lloyds will cut assets. The BOE stated the core of the banking system is resilient, but shares of four of Britain's five largest banks trade for less than their book value.

site_title: Baidu to buy stake in Uber
summary: Chinese internet giant Baidu Inc agreed to buy a stake in Uber, valuing the online car-hailing service at $40 billion. The deal aims to expand Uber's presence in China, where it lags behind domestic rivals Kuaidi Dache and Didi Dache. Uber CEO Travis Kalanick said the company will integrate its service into Baidu Maps, a popular smartphone app. The investment is part of Uber's efforts to gain ground on rivals with powerful backers in the world's biggest transportation market.

images.alt_text: Uber's Mr Kalanick said his company will integrate its service into the popular Baidu Maps smartphone app

site_title: Russians go on shopping spree as rouble plunges
summary: Russians are taking advantage of the plummeting rouble, going on a shopping spree for imported items like electronics, furniture, and cars before prices increase due to the currency's decline. With inflation forecast to rise above 11% and interest rates soaring, consumers are trying to lock in the value of their rouble savings and invest them in luxury goods. This behavior is seen as a rational response to the economic crisis, with analysts noting that prices will rise anyway. The shopping spree is expected to continue for a few more months before the economy faces a more challenging period.

site_title: Oil-related stocks lead STI's rebound
summary: The Straits Times Index rebounded 12.14 points to 3,227.23 on Wednesday, following a 110-point drop in the previous two sessions. Oil-related stocks, such as Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine, led the recovery, driven by short-covering ahead of a possible US Federal Reserve interest rate decision. Markets are watching for clues on the future of interest rates, particularly the phrase "for a considerable time" related to depressed interest rates.

site_title: Apple wins decade-old iTunes antitrust lawsuit
summary: A US jury has unanimously ruled in favor of Apple in a decade-old antitrust lawsuit, finding that the company's update to the iTunes software was used for genuine improvements to older iPods. The plaintiffs, who sought at least $350 million in damages, alleged that Apple used the update to secure a monopoly over the digital music market. However, the jury rejected this claim, concluding that Apple's actions were not anti-competitive.
