The verdict is seen as a significant victory for Apple, which had maintained that its software updates were designed to improve the user experience.

site_title: Thai central bank holds key rate, agrees to cut growth forecasts
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 2% on December 17, 2014, as expected, citing low inflation and global risks to exports. The central bank reduced its economic growth forecasts, setting 1.5% growth for this year and 4.8% in 2015. The rate-hold means the benchmark rate has only changed once in 2014, amid rising political tension and government spending concerns. Economists expect the BOT to remain dovish, but not cut interest rates anytime soon to guard against excessive capital outflows.

site_title: Dutch privacy watchdog probes Facebook
summary: A Dutch government-affiliated watchdog is probing Facebook's changes to its privacy policy, which allows the sharing of personal details and pictures for commercial purposes. This comes after the watchdog warned Google it was breaching data protection laws by using personal details for targeted advertising. Facebook denies planned use of pictures for commercial purposes, but says it will not delay changes due to its headquarters being in Ireland. The investigation follows similar probes by other European regulators, with Google facing a 15 million-euro fine if it doesn't fix alleged breaches by February.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

CDL and Blackstone form a platform to acquire Quayside Collection's cashflows, raising S$1.5 billion through profit participation securities and debt facilities. This transaction is net positive for CDL, allowing it to extract value amidst weakening buyer sentiment and improving gearing. Olam International plans to acquire ADM's worldwide cocoa business for US$1.3 billion to establish itself among the world's top three cocoa processors. Hi-P International is expected to see profits from producing Xiaomi's metal casings, with the stock considered attractive at current levels. Analysts maintain buy recommendations for CDL, Olam, and Hi-P International.

site_title: US crude inventories fall in week: EIA
summary: US crude inventories fell by 847,000 barrels in the last week, below expectations. Gasoline stocks rose by 5.3 million barrels, while distillate inventories declined by 207,000 barrels. Refinery crude runs fell by 326,000 barrels per day, and US crude imports decreased by 564,000 barrels per day. These changes suggest a stable energy market, contrary to concerns fueled by recent Trump tariff announcements.

site_title: Global stock markets expected to rally in 2015 on more cheap cash: Reuters poll
summary: Global stock markets are expected to rally in 2015 due to central banks flooding markets with fresh liquidity, despite the US and UK starting to tighten monetary policy. Analysts polled by Reuters predict all 17 surveyed stock indexes will rise, with the eurozone, China, and emerging markets expected to outperform. The eurozone is forecast to reach a record high, while Chinese stocks are expected to surge 12% by the end of the year.

site_title: S'pore consumers still cautiously optimistic: survey
summary: Singapore consumers have become marginally more optimistic about the economy and their financial positions, with the latest ANZ-Roy Morgan Singapore Consumer Confidence Index rising to 121.8 in December. Despite this, consumer confidence has finished a year at average levels, and expectations of a rebound are still uncertain. Optimism about the next five years is higher, with 45% expecting good financial times, while 48% expect good economic times in the next 12 months. However, caution remains, with only 17% saying now is a good time to buy major household items.

site_title: EU agrees tougher money-laundering law
summary: The European Union has agreed on a tougher money-laundering law, creating a central register that will expose the ultimate ownership of all Europe-based companies or trusts. The registry will be accessible to those with a legitimate interest, but not the general public. The deal comes after the LuxLeaks scandal and aims to combat money laundering and tax evasion. EU leaders have also promised more proposals against tax fraud and evasion, including the automatic exchange of information on tax breaks handed to companies.

site_title: US mortgage applications fall in latest week: MBA
summary: US mortgage applications fell 3.3% in the latest week, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. Interest rates declined to 4.06%, the lowest level since May 2013. Refinancing applications remained unchanged, while home purchase demand dropped 6.9%. This marks the third consecutive week of decline in mortgage applications, indicating a slowdown in the housing market.

site_title: Russia to keep oil output steady, price will stabilise: minister
summary: Russia's Energy Minister Alexander Novak stated that the country will maintain its crude oil output at 10.6 million barrels per day in 2015, mirroring OPEC's strategy to combat a global surplus. This decision comes amid a 50% decline in Brent prices since 2013, exacerbating Russia's currency crisis. The nation relies on energy for half its budget, and Novak believes plunging prices will stabilize, despite a currency crisis.

site_title: Maximum public transport fare hike in 2015 will be 2.8%: Lui Tuck Yew
summary: Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew announced that public transport fares will increase by no more than 2.8% in 2015, lower than the original 3.4% roll-over figure. The decrease is attributed to a drop in energy costs.

images.alt_text: Public transport fares will not be increased by more than 2.8 per cent next year, said Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew in an interview with Channel NewsAsia.

site_title: Slumping oil won't derail US$500b Gulf infrastructure plan
summary: Slumping oil prices won't deter Gulf countries from spending up to $500 billion on infrastructure by 2020, according to the World Bank. Rich nations are deploying large reserves to maintain a development pace, while states are advised to consider the most effective funding mix for these projects. Gulf governments aim to improve citizens' lives and create jobs, despite lower oil prices.

site_title: Trade finance demand seen weakening for S'pore banks
summary: Singapore banks' trade finance demand is expected to weaken in 2015 due to weakening numbers out of China, with the gap between onshore and offshore yuan borrowing rates narrowing further. Despite this, analysts expect single-digit loan growth from banks, with regional markets, such as ASEAN, providing growth opportunities. The narrowing gap between onshore and offshore borrowing rates is seen as a natural progression, but may not benefit corporates. Experts also note that trade finance demand will not disappear overnight, taking time for corporates to unwind from offshore funding positions.

site_title: Europe's November car sales rise at slowest rate in a year
summary: European car sales rose 1.2% in November, the slowest pace in a year, due to waning economic growth. Registrations reached 989,457 vehicles, a 5.5% increase over the 11-month period. Carmakers, including Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, cut prices to boost sales, with discounts averaging 12.7% off the sticker price. Top carmakers, Nissan and BMW, posted gains, while Germany and France saw declines of 1.8% and 2.7%, respectively. Despite a rebound in car sales, economic concerns, including high unemployment, persist.

site_title: US stocks to rise again in 2015; oil, Fed moves loom large: Reuters poll
summary: US stocks are expected to rise in 2015, with the S&P 500 index predicted to reach 2,103 by mid-year and 2,200 at year-end, representing a 12% gain. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is expected to reach 18,500 by mid-year and 18,858 at year-end, up 8% and 10%, respectively. A Federal Reserve interest-rate hike in the middle of 2015 is anticipated, with strategists citing strong consumer spending and low oil prices as offsetting concerns. The healthcare, financial, technology, and consumer discretionary sectors are expected to drive market expansion.

site_title: Japan's November trade deficit shrinks 31.5%; exports stay weak
summary: Japan's trade deficit in November shrank 31.5% from the previous year, driven by a 4.9% increase in exports and a 1.7% decline in imports. Exports rose 4.9% despite weak volumes, while imports fell for the first time in three months due to lower oil costs. The trade deficit narrowed, but economists warn that growth remains uncertain due to tepid eurozone and Chinese growth, and a delayed consumption tax rise could impact Japan's national debt.

site_title: US and Cuba poised for historic thaw in ties
summary: US President Barack Obama and Cuban President Raul Castro are poised for a historic thaw in ties after a prisoner exchange cleared the way for talks on ending the five-decade-old US-Cuba standoff. US contractor Alan Gross was released in exchange for three Cubans held in the US for spying. The move has been hailed as a major breakthrough, with Obama set to make a major address on relations between the two countries, marking a potential resumption of diplomatic relations and easing of sanctions.

site_title: Asia central bankers on guard but feel safe from Russia currency crisis
summary: Asian central bankers remain vigilant but feel safe from a potential currency crisis triggered by Russia's rouble collapse, citing strong fundamentals and robust currency defenses. Despite Indonesia's rupiah hitting its weakest level since 1998, and Thailand's main stock index experiencing its largest intraday loss since 2008, the region's central banks have intervened to support their currencies. Experts warn that Russia's economic crisis could lead to global confidence shattering and increased risk aversion, but Asia's central banks are better equipped to handle exchange-rate pressures due to their built-up foreign exchange reserves and coordinated efforts.

site_title: Goodland eyes more overseas revenue and recurring income
summary: Goodland Group is shifting its revenue mix to focus on overseas markets, particularly in Malaysia, where it acquired a 51.33-acre land in T-City for commercial and residential development. The project, expected to generate rental income from fiscal 2018, will provide a long-term income stream. The company aims to diversify its revenue, with one-quarter of its revenue coming from regional projects by 2016, and has already entered Myanmar and Cambodia. Goodland's director, Raphael Wong, believes the project will capitalize on the region's growth and offer a buffer against economic downturns.

site_title: ADB shaves a bit off growth forecasts for Asian nations amid turbulence
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has downgraded its 2014 growth forecasts for many Asian nations due to the oil price slump and looming Russian financial crisis. The forecast for the developing Asia region is 6.1% for 2014, down from 6.2%, and for next year is 6.2%, down from 6.4%. China's growth forecast is revised downwards to 7.4% in 2014 and 7.2% for next year, while India is expected to reach its 5.5% growth forecast. The ADB also lowered its inflation forecast for the region to 3.2% in 2014 and 3.5% in 2015.

site_title: Despite pain, Opec hawks come round to merits of riding out oil slump
summary: OPEC members, including those who initially backed an output cut, are shifting their focus to market share, reducing the likelihood of price defense measures. Venezuela continues to advocate for output cuts, while other nations like Iran and African members remain silent. The producers are now watching the market and selling oil at the prevailing price, as stated by a delegate from an OPEC country. This shift in strategy may help stabilize oil prices in the face of global economic uncertainty.

site_title: World market shockwaves ripple far and wide from oil price epicentre
summary: A global financial contagion has begun, originating from the collapse of oil prices and Western disinflation, affecting investors' portfolios worldwide. The growing interdependency of world finance has led to a chain reaction of events, as fund managers sell profitable assets to cover losses. This phenomenon is reminiscent of previous global financial crises, such as the late 1990s and 2008-09. The ripple effects are far-reaching, impacting various markets, including gold, energy commodities, and emerging economies. The situation is being closely watched, with investors on edge due to ongoing trade tensions and market volatility.

site_title: 2015 shaping up as the year for even more quantitative easing
summary: The US Federal Reserve is considering returning quantitative easing (QE) in 2015 due to Europe's economic struggles and the global downturn. Europe, already experiencing disinflation, is expected to be severely affected by the drop in oil prices. The European Central Bank may need to increase QE, but its effectiveness is uncertain. Japan and China are also experiencing economic slowdowns, with Japan announcing a second round of QE and China's growth rate casting doubt on its 8% annual growth goal. Experts expect more rounds of QE to address these economic challenges.

site_title: China's central bank to provide short-term cash to some banks: sources
summary: China's central bank has issued short-term funds to some local banks to ease liquidity strains, providing liquidity operations and renewing medium-term lending facilities. This move aims to alleviate liquidity issues and maintain financial stability. The People's Bank of China did not comment on the matter.

site_title: US current account deficit widens in third quarter
summary: The US current account deficit widened in the third quarter to US$100.3 billion, exceeding expectations. The deficit rose 1.9% due to a decrease in secondary income receipts, which fell to US$27.8 billion, and an increase in primary income receipts, which rose to US$59.0 billion. Goods and services exports increased 0.9% to US$592.0 billion, while imports decreased 0.2% to US$716.3 billion. The current account deficit represented 2.3% of gross domestic product, unchanged from the previous quarter.

site_title: Oxley emerges as preferred bidder of 2.35ha commercial site in Dublin
summary: Oxley Holdings has emerged as the preferred bidder for a 2.35ha commercial site in Dublin, Ireland, after completing a competitive tendering process. The site, located next to the proposed Central Bank of Ireland headquarters, has the potential for over 60,000 square meters of Grade A office space and 200 apartments. If successful, Oxley will acquire a long leasehold interest with the right to develop, manage, and realize the site. The planning application stage is expected to commence in early 2015, with construction potentially starting in late 2015 or early 2016.

site_title: EU shines light on dirty money with central registers
summary: The European Union has agreed on rules to combat tax evasion and dirty money, including the creation of central registers listing beneficial owners of companies, trusts, and other entities. The registers will be open to national authorities and some journalists, but not the public. The aim is to stop anonymous companies from financing terrorism, laundering money, or evading taxes. The agreement, set to come into force around 2017, is seen as a landmark deal, but Transparency International says it still falls short of full transparency.

site_title: US consumer inflation posts largest decline in six years
summary: US consumer prices recorded their largest decline in nearly six years, falling 0.3% in November, with gasoline prices tumbling 6.6% and food prices rising 0.2%. The decline is expected to have little impact on the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates in mid-2015. Underlying price pressures are easing, with the core CPI increasing 0.1% after rising 0.2% in October. The Fed targets 2% inflation, which is currently running lower than the CPI.

site_title: Europe banks may feel profits squeeze after US raises capital bar
summary: US Federal Reserve proposes that eight major US banks hold an extra capital cushion, requiring a 12% core capital of risk-weighted assets, significantly above the global minimum. This could affect European banks, particularly Deutsche Bank, BNP Paribas, and Societe Generale, potentially depressing their profitability and forcing them to restrain dividends. The US move may prompt European regulators to raise capital requirements, potentially leveling the playing field for US and European banks.

site_title: Lower oil prices stoke demand from Vietnam
summary: Lower oil prices have boosted demand from Vietnam, with the country's top fuel importer seeking a spot cargo after buying diesel for December. Brent crude traded below $60 a barrel, near 5-1/2 year lows, as major oil producers signal maintaining output despite a supply glut. Vietnam's demand is returning, but end-users are waiting for prices to bottom before buying more volumes. Spot demand also emerged in Egypt, boosting sentiment among traders.

images.alt_text: Lower oil prices have stoked demand from Vietnam, with the country's top fuel importer seeking a spot cargo after earlier buying diesel for December, traders said.

site_title: Sony Pictures CEO consulted US State Dept on film, leaked emails show
summary: Sony Pictures CEO Michael Lynton consulted US Assistant Secretary of State Daniel Russel in June over concerns for American safety and North Korean relations amid threats to show a film featuring Kim Jong Un's assassination. Despite police taking extra precautions, Sony executives told theatres the film would not be pulled. Leaked emails from unidentified hackers revealed the consultation, which has cast doubt on US government claims of no threat. Sony has confirmed authenticity of some documents, but Reuters has not verified their accuracy.

site_title: British unemployment rate steady at 6.0%
summary: Britain's unemployment rate remains at a five-year low of 6.0% for the July-September period, according to the Office for National Statistics. The number of unemployed individuals decreased by 455,000 to 1.96 million. Wages are also rising, with the rate for the period unchanged from 6.2% for the three months to the end of October.

site_title: Public transport fare hike capped at 2.8% for 2015: Lui Tuck Yew
summary: Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew announced that public transport fares in Singapore will not increase by more than 2.8% for 2015, lower than the original 3.4% figure. This decision is attributed to a fall in energy costs, which is based on the four components of the fare formula: core CPI inflation, average wage increase, energy index, and productivity index. Public transport operators have until December 19 to submit their applications for a fare increase, subject to approval by the Public Transport Council.

images.alt_text: Public transport fares will not be increased by more than 2.8 per cent next year, said Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 12.14 points to 3,227.23. The 1.23 billion shares traded valued S$1.36 billion, with 189 gainers and 224 losers.

site_title: M&A, US surge to drive corporate bond market in 2015
summary: The European corporate bond market is expected to surge in 2015, driven by M&A-related financing and a US borrower surge. Euro-denominated issuance reached 234.5 billion in 2014, with hybrid issuance also on the rise. US corporates are expected to increase their presence in the European market, with 37 billion euros raised in 2014. Additionally, the European Central Bank's potential expansion of its asset buying program could boost the market, with tighter spreads and increased investor diversification.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares rose on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 7.96 points to close at 1,681.9. The index saw 1.94 billion lots traded, with 648 gainers and 257 losers.

site_title: US, China making progress on biotech crop talks: USDA's Vilsack
summary: US Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack stated that the US and China are making progress in talks over biotechnology crops, with a focus on establishing a strategic dialogue. China has rejected over one million tons of US corn containing genetically modified Agrisure Viptera due to its disapproval. The countries are moving towards an understanding on how to address this issue, which is a key trade concern.

site_title: Bank of England policymakers see oil price fall lowering short-term inflation
summary: Bank of England policymakers are considering keeping interest rates on hold due to falling oil prices, which have lowered inflation expectations. The majority of policymakers believe inflation will fall below 1% in December, and they are looking through the direct effect of the oil price drop on inflation. However, some members are concerned that spare capacity could be eliminated more quickly, potentially leading to faster wage growth and inflation. The BoE is expected to keep rates at 0.5% for now, but market investors are pricing in a possible rate hike late next year.

site_title: Buffett firm's smart-grid idea takes over your wash
summary: Warren Buffett's Northern Powergrid Holdings Co is testing a smart-grid system in the UK that can control when consumer appliances are used at home, aiming to reduce energy costs and better manage intermittent sources like wind and solar power. The pilot program, which involves 12,000 households, allows customers to choose when to use appliances or let the system decide for them. The technology complements Buffett's existing investments in wind and solar power and could be implemented on a broader scale in the UK next year, with potential interest from Berkshire Hathaway Inc.

site_title: Sharp fall in commercial-vehicle COE premium
summary: The latest Certificate of Entitlement (COE) bidding exercise saw a 13% drop in commercial-vehicle premiums, with Category C goods vehicles experiencing the largest decline of S$7,901 to S$52,100. Passenger-car premiums remained largely flat, with Category A and Cat B premiums decreasing by S$1,200 and S$389, respectively. Only the Cat D motorcycle premium rose, by S$102 to S$4,312, while the Cat E premium dropped by S$2,914 to S$73,990.

site_title: Airlines poised for US$12b windfall thanks to oil collapse
summary: Airlines worldwide are expected to receive a $12 billion windfall due to the global oil crash, which will lead to a 25% increase in profits to $25 billion in 2015. The savings will mainly benefit US carriers, which will save billions due to lower jet fuel costs. Industrywide fuel outlays are expected to drop to $192 billion, despite a 4.8% increase in consumption. European carriers, however, may see less benefit due to the weak euro, and analysts predict that oil prices may rebound, potentially hurting the industry in the long run.

site_title: Toyota-Peugeot Czech car plant cuts 2015 production targets
summary: Toyota-Peugeot Czech car plant TPCA reduced its 2015 production target by 10% to 220,000 vehicles. This marks a 10% increase from 2013, with output expected to rise to 200,000 units in 2015. The decrease in production targets is attributed to a slower European car market in 2015.

site_title: Rouble strengthens as Finance Ministry starts selling FX
summary: The Russian rouble strengthened by 3% against the dollar and 4.2% against the euro after the Finance Ministry began selling foreign currency from its leftover stock. The move came amid heavy selling pressure on the currency this week, prompting the central bank to raise its key interest rate by 650 basis points in an emergency move.

site_title: UK households' optimism over finances hits six-year high: Markit
summary: British households reached a six-year high in optimism over their finances in December, with a measure of financial well-being at 42.7, down from 42.8 the previous month. This is the highest level since the survey began six years ago. Reduced pressure on savings, growth in workplace activity, and falling inflation expectations contributed to the increase. However, income from employment fell in December, ending a four-month period of growth, while job security increased. More than half of households expect interest rates to remain at 0.5% over the next six months.

site_title: German business warns rouble plunge will 'affect us all'
summary: A German business group warned that Russia's currency woes, particularly the rouble's 60% drop in value, will affect not only Russia but also Germany, with a predicted 20% drop in German exports to Russia this year. The group cautioned against "Schadenfreude" and stated that a destabilization of Russia is not in anyone's interest, as it would harm trade and revenues of foreign companies operating in Russia. The situation is expected to worsen if the current decline in oil prices and Western sanctions continue.

site_title: Heavy snow hits northern Japan
summary: Heavy snow hit northern Japan on December 17, 2014, with over 70 centimeters of snow falling in 24 hours on parts of Hokkaido. The snowstorm forced the cancellation of 296 flights and trapped at least 50 vehicles. A rapidly developing low pressure system caused storm surges in coastal Hokkaido, with the blizzard expected to continue until Thursday.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares up 0.38% by close
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 rose 0.38% on Wednesday, rebounding from two days of heavy selling, as bargain hunting drove up the market. The benchmark index closed at 16,819.73, while the Topix index slipped 0.10%. Investors remained cautious due to the yen's strength, which erodes the value of Japanese exports and repatriated income. Despite this, strategists expect the Nikkei to continue its rebound, with some predicting a further increase by year-end. The outcome of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting is also expected to influence market sentiment.

site_title: IKEA concentrates ownership of shopping centres
summary: IKEA is consolidating ownership of its shopping centers, aiming to grow the operation more efficiently. The company will buy the remaining 51% of its European and Chinese mall business from Inter IKEA Group, simplifying its corporate structure. The new subsidiary, IKEA Centres, will own 31 malls in Europe and China, and 14 in Russia, with over 3 million square meters of retail space and 400 million visitors annually. The move is expected to improve procurement and facility management levels, and the shopping center business will continue to expand.

site_title: Oil prices sink further in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices dropped in Asian trade, reaching new multi-year lows, amid Russia's ruble crisis and US crude supply report uncertainty. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell $1.16 to $54.77 and Brent crude for February dropped 71 cents to $59.30. The slump is attributed to weak global demand and Opec's refusal to cut output, despite a global supply glut. Analysts warn that Russia may face a default on domestic bonds if oil prices continue to fall, and authorities may need to cap expectations of bank runs.

images.alt_text: Oil suffered fresh losses in Asia on Wednesday, sinking to new multi-year lows as dealers watch Russia's ruble crisis and await the latest US crude supply report, analysts said.

site_title: Japan govt panel sees fiscal goal 'hard to meet' without radical steps: draft
summary: Japan's finance ministry panel has expressed concerns that meeting the government's goal of halving the primary budget deficit by 2021 is "quite difficult" without drastic spending cuts and revenue increases. The panel's draft proposal highlights the need for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to restore Japan's finances, citing a revenue shortfall of $12.8 billion from a postponed sales tax hike. The panel urges the government to raise the sales tax to 10% by 2017 and present concrete steps to achieve a primary budget surplus by 2020/21.

site_title: Honda to recall almost 570,000 vehicles in China
summary: Honda is recalling approximately 570,000 vehicles in China due to potentially defective airbags. The recall affects 553,264 cars from 2002 to 2007, as well as 26,128 vehicles made between 2012 and 2014. A possibly defective front airbag could break its inflator casing, posing safety hazards. The recall is part of a global effort to address malfunctioning Takata airbags linked to five deaths and hundreds of injuries worldwide.

images.alt_text: Japanese carmaker Honda will recall almost 570,000 vehicles in China from February due to potentially defective airbags, China's quality watchdog said.

site_title: Indonesia central bank puts Q4 current account deficit at 2.8% of GDP, instead of 2.3%
summary: Indonesia's central bank has revised its estimate for the fourth quarter current account deficit to 2.8% of GDP, up from an earlier estimate of 2.3%. The revised deficit is expected to be $6.1 billion, equivalent to 2.8% of GDP. This is higher than the 3.07% deficit seen in the July-September quarter this year. The revised estimate reflects a stronger-than-expected current account gap, which could pose a challenge for the country's economic management.

images.alt_text: Indonesia central bank has raised its estimate for the fourth quarter current account deficit to 2.8 per cent of gross domestic product from an earlier figure of 2.3 per cent.

site_title: Key market inflation gauge falls to new low under 1.60%
summary: The European Central Bank's inflation gauge, the euro five-year five-year breakeven forward, fell below 1.60% for the first time, indicating lower-than-expected inflation expectations. This marks a significant drop from the ECB's target inflation rate of just below 2%. The decline may lead to further easing of monetary policy.

site_title: Bank of England's Cunliffe sees little direct exposure to UK from Russia
summary: Bank of England Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe stated that Britain has little direct exposure to economic turmoil in Russia, but policymakers should monitor the impact of investor sentiment and market volatility. He noted that a sharp fall in oil prices is a positive for the global economy, but cautioned that the core of the financial system is better equipped to handle situations like this.

site_title: US: Stocks rise as market awaits Fed announcement
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 44.80 points (0.26%) to 17,113.67, and the S&P 500 advancing 6.64 (0.34%) to 1,979.38. The market reacted positively to a weak US inflation report, which eased pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. The report showed US consumer prices fell 0.3% in November, partly due to a 3.8% drop in energy prices. The Fed's policy meeting is expected to update the outlook for monetary policy tightening later in the day.

site_title: Russians go on shopping splurge as rouble plunges
summary: Russians are taking advantage of the plunging rouble by going on a shopping spree, buying electronics, furniture, and cars before prices rise. With inflation forecast to exceed 11%, consumers are stocking up on imported items, driving sales at stores like Ikea and M.Video. Analysts say this behavior is "rational" as people anticipate price increases, and it may help soften the economic situation in Russia. The country's main holiday, New Year, is expected to boost shopping, and economists predict a consumer boom will last for another couple of months before the economic situation worsens.

site_title: UK earnings rise again, helping Cameron in election pitch
summary: British workers' earnings rose 1.8% in October, exceeding inflation and helping Prime Minister David Cameron's re-election pitch. The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 6.0% in the three months to October, while job creation slowed. The Bank of England is closely monitoring labour costs as it considers raising interest rates. A majority of policymakers believe wages need to grow faster to hit the 2% inflation target. This trend may extend into 2015, potentially benefiting the Conservatives, but economists caution that the past few years of economic pressure on consumers' budgets will not be easily erased.

site_title: Disasters cost US$113b damage in 2014: Swiss Re
summary: US$113 billion in economic losses were recorded in 2014 due to natural and man-made disasters, a 16% decrease from 2013. Insurers covered US$34 billion of the damage, down 24% from 2013. Natural catastrophes, such as extreme weather, accounted for US$106 billion of the total losses. This is significantly lower than the average annual figure of US$188 billion for the previous decade. The number of fatalities decreased to 11,000, down from over 27,000 in 2013.

site_title: Philippine Q4 growth will likely be better than Q3: official
summary: The Philippine economy is expected to experience better growth in the fourth quarter than the third quarter, according to Socioeconomic Planning Chief Arsenio Balisacan. This comes after positive results from business and consumer confidence surveys. The economic impact of typhoon Hagupit is expected to be negligible, with annual growth in the September quarter at 5.3%. Manila's growth target for the year is 6.5-7.5%.

site_title: ADB trims growth forecasts for developing Asia, says cheaper oil good for most
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has trimmed its growth forecast for developing Asia, expecting 6.1% growth in 2014 and 6.2% in 2015, down from previous estimates. Sliding oil prices are seen as a positive factor, helping economies push through with growth reforms. The ADB cut its forecasts for China, citing falling property prices and construction sector spillover effects. Reforms in India and Southeast Asia are also expected to boost growth, with Indonesia and India potentially reaping benefits from cheaper oil.

site_title: Russian ruble rebounds slightly after record plunge
summary: The Russian ruble rebounded slightly after plummeting 20% the previous day, its worst crisis under President Vladimir Putin. At 0800 GMT, the ruble traded at 66.80 to the dollar and 83.38 to the euro. The central bank spent $1.96 billion on Monday to prop up the currency, totaling over $10 billion since the start of the month. The regulator has faced criticism for its failure to halt the ruble's fall.

images.alt_text: The Russian ruble rebounded slightly as markets opened Wednesday, after the currency lost a fifth of its value in a single day in the worst crisis of President Vladimir Putin's 15 years in power.

site_title: China's Baidu confirms investment in online taxi service Uber
summary: Chinese internet giant Baidu confirmed a stake investment in international car-hailing service Uber, aiming to expand Uber's presence in China's large transportation market. The exact stake and payment amount were not disclosed. Baidu and Uber will collaborate to compete with domestic car-hailing apps Kuaidi Dache and Didi Dache in China. This move follows Baidu's rivalry with Alibaba Group and Tencent Holdings, which back Kuaidi Dache and Didi Dache, respectively.

site_title: India's SpiceJet says fleet grounded on lack of fuel
summary: India's budget carrier SpiceJet's aircraft are grounded due to oil companies not refueling its planes. The airline owes money to creditors, including oil companies. The civil aviation ministry has given airport operators 15 days to make payments to the airline, while state oil companies can offer credit for up to 15 days to avoid a collapse. The ministry aims to prevent a "major setback" for the civil aviation sector.

site_title: Korean Air heiress questioned over 'nut rage'
summary: Korean Air heiress Cho Hyun-Ah was questioned by prosecutors over her "nut rage" incident on December 5, where she forced a flight attendant and purser off a plane after being served macadamia nuts without her request. Cho, 40, has publicly apologized and resigned from her posts, but prosecutors will investigate whether she used violence against the crew members and if the airline's executives coerced them to give false testimony. The transportation ministry has sanctioned Korean Air with a possible flight ban and fined up to $2 million, and a criminal probe has been opened into the incident.

site_title: Australia: Shares rebound as energy stocks rally, NZ flat
summary: Australian shares rebounded 0.5% to 5,177.8, driven by a 3% gain in energy stocks, despite tumbling oil prices and concerns over the currency crisis in Russia. Gains were broad-based, with mining giants BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto jumping over 1% each. New Zealand's benchmark NZX50 index was fractionally firmer, supported by solid demand for telecommunications retailer Spark.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Vard, Straits Trading, Oil & Gas related
summary: Vard Holdings secured a contract for an offshore subsea construction vessel, set to deliver in Q4 2016. Straits Trading proposed acquiring Times Midtown in Chongqing, China for approximately S$141.65 million. Crude oil prices plummeted to new lows, potentially affecting oil & gas companies, while transportation businesses may benefit from lower fuel costs.

site_title: Australia: Shares show a rare gain, helped by energy bounce
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% on Wednesday, a rare gain, driven by a bounce in the energy and natural resources sectors. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 9.6 points to 5,161.9. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index remained unchanged.

site_title: British supermarket price wars rage before Christmas
summary: British supermarkets are engaging in intense price wars ahead of Christmas, driven by competition from German discounters Lidl and Aldi. The competition has led to a decline in mainstream retailers' market shares and a drop in British inflation to 12-year lows. Tesco, the market leader, has seen its share of the grocery business steadily decline, while Aldi and Lidl's market shares are steadily increasing. The price battles have also contributed to Britain's 110 billion-pound annual food sales market falling for the first time in at least 20 years.

site_title: Singapore's LTA launches new taxi location app
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) launched Taxi-Taxi@SG, a new taxi location app that shows the locations of all 28,000 registered taxis in the city-state. The app allows street-hail commuters to see if there are available taxis nearby, enabling them to decide whether to wait, walk, book a taxi, or make alternative arrangements. Unlike third-party apps, Taxi-Taxi@SG displays the locations of all available taxis, not just those signed up with the app. The app is available for download on Apple's App Store and Google's Play Store.

site_title: Tepco, Chubu to hold Japan's first joint LNG tender
summary: Tokyo Electric Power Co and Chubu Electric Power Co, two of Japan's largest LNG buyers, are holding a joint tender for LNG, marking the first time two Japanese companies have jointly requested bids. The exercise aims to reduce procurement costs as Japan replaces nuclear capacity shut down after the Fukushima crisis. About 60 LNG suppliers globally were invited to bid, with decisions expected in January. The utilities are seeking several hundred thousand tons of LNG for delivery after April, but volumes and price levels remain undisclosed.

site_title: Asian markets mixed ahead of Fed meeting
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Wednesday, with Tokyo rising 0.38% and Shanghai jumping 1.31% ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting. Oil prices extended their losses to fresh five-and-a-half-year lows, and the dollar recovered slightly against the yen. The Fed's meeting is being closely watched for clues about interest rate plans, with some analysts predicting a recession next year. Despite the uncertainty, some Asia investors took advantage of cheap valuations, with the Shanghai market surging by a quarter over the past month.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 1.43 points to 1673.04 on Wednesday, with volume reaching 20.47 million lots worth RM6.09 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 68 to 55.

site_title: Singapore's November NODX rises 1.6%, reversing October's dip
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 1.6% in November, reversing the 1.5% dip in October, according to International Enterprise Singapore. The electronics NODX dropped 10.2% year-on-year, while non-electronic NODX increased 7.5%. Non-oil re-exports rose 3.6% in November. NODX shipments to EU, US, China, Japan, and other top markets declined in November, except for Malaysia, Indonesia, and Thailand. The increase in NODX in November suggests a rebound from October's decline.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank says economic fundamentals 'sound'
summary: Indonesia's central bank deputy governor, Mirza Adityaswara, stated that the country's economic fundamentals are "sound" despite the recent depreciation of the rupiah. The rupiah strengthened 0.12% on Wednesday, closing at 12,655 to the dollar. Adityaswara attributed the depreciation to the rupiah being "undervalued," making Indonesia's exports competitive. Bank Indonesia will continue to stabilize the rupiah in foreign exchange markets and sovereign bond prices.

site_title: China's Dalian Wanda prepares for the end of urbanisation
summary: China's urbanisation era is expected to end within a decade, according to billionaire Wang Jianlin, founder of Dalian Wanda Commercial Properties. The company is shifting focus from urban development to tourism and entertainment, investing $53 billion in upscale facilities and expanding overseas to diversify its business. With 54% of China's population living in cities, urbanisation is nearing completion, and the government's restrictions on residency benefits are hindering rural migration. Dalian Wanda's IPO value is 8.6 times its 2015 earnings forecasts, reflecting investors' concerns over the commercial property sector's outlook.

site_title: Taiwan's ailing economy major challenge for leadership hopefuls
summary: Taiwan's struggling economy is a major challenge for leadership hopefuls ahead of presidential elections. The country's GDP growth has languished below 4% in recent years, and many voters are bitter about the lack of economic prosperity despite President Ma Ying-jeou's promises. Small business owners, like baker Lin Hsiao-an, are feeling the pinch, with rising prices and a lack of disposable income forcing them to close or relocate. Voters are calling for a new economic strategy to boost competitiveness and protect domestic industries, with some pushing for Taiwan to stand on its own two feet despite trade with China.

images.alt_text: A stagnant economy, as well as fears over China's growing influence, a string of food scandals and soaring housing prices saw the ruling Kuomintang party routed in local elections last month seen as a barometer for the 2016 presidential race.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.12% higher
summary: Hong Kong shares opened 0.12% higher on Wednesday, driven by bargain-buying, despite a sell-off on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 27.18 points to 22,697.68. This comes as traders brush off new Trump threats, extending the stocks rally.

site_title: Offshore support services firms' returns declined over the year: Singapore Exchange
summary: Offshore support services firms listed in Singapore have seen their returns decline by 13.4% over the year, with some companies losing more than half of their returns. The decline is attributed to falling oil prices, with WTI Crude Oil prices falling 43.2% and Brent Crude Oil prices falling 46.0% over the year. The largest companies, Ezion, POSH, Pacific Radiance, Ezra, and Mermaid, saw their returns wiped out by more than 40% except Pacific Radiance, which lost 10.8%.

site_title: HDB's FY13/14 deficit widens as it ramps up flat supply
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) reported a net deficit of S$1.97 billion in its fiscal year ended March 2014, more than doubling from the previous year's S$797 million. This was driven by a S$2.72 billion deficit from its 'Housing' activities, primarily due to increased spending on housing programmes to ramp up flat supply. The deficit was offset by a S$750 million surplus from its 'Other Activities', which are commercial in nature.

site_title: Olympics: US will bid for 2024 Olympics
summary: The US Olympic Committee announced it will bid for the 2024 Summer Olympics, with Los Angeles, Washington, Boston, and San Francisco as potential candidate cities. The USOC will select a city in early 2015 and submit its bid to the International Olympic Committee in May 2016. The bid is expected to be costly, with estimates ranging from $4 billion to $10 billion, and the USOC aims to pick a city that can launch a competitive bid while keeping costs under control.

images.alt_text: The United States Olympic Committee announced on Tuesday it will bid to host the 2024 Summer Games, but the candidate city won't be selected until early next year.

site_title: Japan nuclear watchdog greenlights more reactors
summary: Japan's nuclear watchdog, the Nuclear Regulation Authority (NRA), has approved the restart of two more atomic reactors at the Takahama nuclear power plant, with actual restarts delayed until a public consultation is held. The decision, made just days after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's election win, is seen as a step towards Japan's return to nuclear power. However, public opinion is divided, with around half of voters opposing the restarts. The NRA's approval comes after it granted safety clearance for two reactors at another site in September.

site_title: Hong Kong: Hang Seng index ends down slightly, H shares up
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng index ended down 0.4% to 22,585.84 points, despite a 1.2% gain in the China Enterprises Index. Financial firms saw a rally, but were offset by slumping service and IT shares. AVIC International Holding and Bank of China were among the most actively traded stocks, with AVIC down 3.0% and Bank of China up 2.7%.

site_title: American Airlines plane diverted to Tokyo after being hit by winter storm, several hurt
summary: A US-bound American Airlines flight from Incheon to Dallas/Fort Worth was diverted to Tokyo due to severe winter storm turbulence, resulting in minor injuries to 5 people, including a broken bone. The Boeing 777-200 aircraft made an emergency landing at Tokyo's Narita airport, with 240 passengers and 15 crew members on board. The flight will continue to the US on Wednesday, and the storm has caused disruptions across Japan, including flooding, road accidents, and flight cancellations.

site_title: Japan trade deficit shrinks 31.5% on-year in November: govt
summary: Japan's trade deficit in November decreased by 31.5% year-over-year to 891.9 billion yen, driven by higher exports and lower oil import costs. This is expected to be followed by a further narrowing of the deficit in coming months, as lower oil prices reduce import bills.

site_title: Japan banks to bulk up India presence on improving ties
summary: Japan's largest banks, including Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Mizuho Financial Group, plan to expand their presence in India, driven by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's reform agenda and improving ties between the two countries. The banks aim to grow their loan books through branch openings and new services, taking advantage of a sector dominated by inefficient state-owned banks and a relatively low market share for foreign lenders. Japan aims to double investments in India within five years, and the move is seen as a strategic move to tap into the country's growing economy.

site_title: EU wasted 38m euros on 'ghost airports'
summary: The European Union has wasted approximately 38 million euros on underused airports across 5 member states, according to an auditors' report. The report found that only half of the 20 airport projects were profitable, with 7 being financially unsustainable and requiring ongoing public funding. The European Commission acknowledged the waste, but stated that it will implement stricter investment terms to prevent a repeat of the issue, following a major investment plan worth 315 billion euros set to be greenlit by EU leaders.

site_title: EU to 'ban investment in Crimea'
summary: The European Union is set to ban all investment in Crimea, following Russia's annexation in March, to pressure Moscow and demonstrate the EU's continued opposition. The EU's 28 member states will formally endorse the measures on Thursday, which will halt the export of EU-made goods, ban tourism services, and bar cruise ships from Crimean ports. The move aims to keep up pressure on Russia and show that the issue is not being forgotten, despite growing concerns that Crimea may become a fait accompli.

site_title: White House: rouble plunge has Russia between 'rock and hard place'
summary: The Russian rouble has plummeted over 50% this year, mainly due to oil prices and Western sanctions, putting Moscow's economic policy in a difficult position. Chairman of Obama's Council of Economic Advisers, Jason Furman, stated that Russia is "between a rock and a hard place" with raised interest rates hurting the domestic economy and confidence. The US has limited exposure to the crisis, with exports to Russia accounting for only 0.1% of the US GDP, but other global economic slowdowns, such as in Europe and Japan, pose a challenge to the US.

site_title: Asian markets up ahead of Fed meeting
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, Seoul, and Shanghai gaining 0.49-0.35% due to bargain-hunting. Oil prices extended their losses to five-and-a-half-year lows, while the dollar dipped against the yen ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting. Investors await the Fed's interest rate plans, which may influence global markets. Despite expectations of higher US rates, the dollar continues to retreat against the yen, and gold prices fell.

site_title: Singapore consumer confidence inches upwards in December: ANZ-Roy Morgan
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence rose slightly in December, increasing to 121.8 points, just above the 2014 average. Despite this, the optimism is considered modest. About half of respondents (48%) expect good economic times over the next year, while 11% expect bad times. Personal finances also showed improvement, with 27% saying their families are better off and 31% expecting to be better off in a year. Long-term expectations remain positive, with 45% expecting good times over the next five years.

site_title: US urges caution as Palestinians bid for UN vote
summary: The US urges caution as Palestinians seek to push their hopes for statehood to the UN agenda ahead of Israeli elections. US Secretary of State John Kerry calls for lower tensions and cautions against any steps that could interfere with the Israeli polls. The Palestinians plan to submit a draft text to the UN Security Council, while France is preparing a more nuanced version. The US has traditionally used its veto power at the UN to block moves against Israel, but Kerry suggests a more constructive approach to finding a resolution that won't have unintended consequences.

site_title: After Google, Dutch privacy watchdog probes Facebook
summary: A Dutch government-affiliated watchdog, the Data Protection Agency, is probing Facebook's changes to its privacy policy, which allows the sharing of personal details for commercial purposes. The agency had asked Facebook to delay the changes, but the company said it would proceed despite the inquiry. Facebook denies planning to use user pictures for commercial purposes, but could use profile pictures in ads. The agency could fine Facebook up to $18.7 million if it doesn't fix the alleged breaches by the end of February. This is the latest in a wider fight over online personal data.

site_title: Alstom near US$700m US settlement in bribery case: source
summary: Alstom, a French industrial giant, has agreed to pay approximately US$700 million to settle US corruption charges related to bribes in Indonesia and other countries under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The US Department of Justice accused Alstom of bribing officials to win a US$118 million energy contract in the early 2000s. The settlement, to be announced next week, removes a hurdle for General Electric's deal to buy Alstom's energy assets, and at least four French Alstom officials have been indicted in relation to the case.

site_title: Australian PM says tough new national security laws failed hostages
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott said new national security laws failed to prevent a deadly hostage crisis in Sydney, where three people, including hostage-taker Man Haron Monis, were killed. Monis, a known extremist, was able to walk into a cafe with a shotgun despite not being on a security watchlist. The new laws, passed in October, aimed to prevent young people from becoming radicalized, but critics argue they do not account for individuals with "apparently deranged minds." Authorities are investigating the events leading up to the siege and how Monis obtained a gun.

images.alt_text: Tough new national security laws failed to prevent a deadly hostage crisis in the heart of Sydney this week, Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott said on Wednesday, raising questions about the usefulness of such measures.

site_title: Price plunge seen sparking tensions in 2015
summary: Global oil prices plummeted in 2015 due to oversupply, a stronger US dollar, and weak demand, sparking geopolitical tensions in key oil-producing nations. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) failed to cut output, leading to five-year lows in London and New York. Analysts disagree on the impact of low prices, with some wanting lower prices to counter US shale oil, while others, such as Venezuela and Russia, desire higher prices to balance their economies. The uncertainty has raised concerns about the economic stability of oil-dependent nations like Iraq and Iran.

site_title: Spanish regions likely to overshoot deficit targets: watchdog
summary: Spain's autonomous regions are likely to overshoot their budget deficit targets for 2014 and 2015, according to a fiscal watchdog. The 17 regions aim to end 2014 with a 1% deficit and cut it to 0.7% in 2015, but the watchdog says these goals are "very hard to achieve." Nine regions, including Madrid and Catalonia, are at risk of missing their targets. The central government is urged to act to prevent overspending, with potential solutions including mutualising debt and easing financing for the regions.

site_title: Brent falls, ends below US$60, US crude up near US$56
summary: Brent crude futures fell below US$60 a barrel for the fifth consecutive day, ending at US$59.86 a barrel. US crude rose slightly above US$55 a barrel after traders defended prices to avoid expiring options. Major oil producers said they have no rush to cut production, contributing to the glut. The market is considered possibly oversold, but a recovery is uncertain, with analysts predicting more volatility in the first half of 2015.

site_title: China steps up plan for new export corridor into Europe
summary: Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang has met with leaders from 16 central and eastern European countries to cement plans for a new export corridor into Europe. Beijing aims to expand its presence in the region through investments in infrastructure, including a high-speed rail link between Budapest and Belgrade. The project, set to be completed by 2017, will improve regional connectivity and benefit China's relations with the EU. Trade between China and the region is expected to exceed $60 billion this year, with China seeking to increase exports, particularly from Poland and other countries affected by Russia's food ban.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore share prices opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 5.29 points to 3,209.80. Volume was 60.0 million shares worth S$96.8 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 70 to 47. This marks a reversal from the 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, where the index rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: US prosecutor won't charge Cosby over decades-old sex claim
summary: US prosecutors declined to charge comedian Bill Cosby over allegations of sexually assaulting a 15-year-old girl at the Playboy mansion in 1974 due to the statute of limitations. Cosby, who has been accused by around 20 women of similar incidents, was only taken to court by former Playboy hostess Judy Huth. The decision was made by Deputy District Attorney Victor Rodriguez, citing the expiration of the statute of limitations for felony sex crimes in 1974.

site_title: Forced to pay for content, Google News closes in Spain
summary: Google News shut down in Spain due to a new law requiring news publishers to receive payment for content, even if they give it away for free. The law, dubbed the "Google tax," takes effect on January 1 and applies to other big web companies like Yahoo. Industry Minister Jose Maria Soria hinted at a possible compromise, while experts estimate a 10-30% drop in internet traffic to Spanish news media sites. Google cited the law's irreversibility as the reason for the closure, which is the first time the company has shut down a news service in a country.

site_title: Opec will not step in to support oil prices: Kuwait
summary: Kuwait's oil minister Ali al-Omair stated that Opec will not intervene in the oil market to support sagging crude prices, despite Brent crude breaching the $60 mark. The decision to maintain production levels remains unchanged, and Opec will discuss potential action when the situation warrants it. Excess oil supplies have increased to 1.8 million barrels per day, putting downward pressure on prices.

site_title: Tag Heuer changes tune, now looking at smartwatches
summary: Tag Heuer, a luxury Swiss watchmaker, is reconsidering its stance on smartwatches after initially dismissing the idea. New CEO Jean-Claude Biver acknowledged that smartwatches could have a place in the company's line-up, but emphasized that they would need to be unique and not dilute the brand's luxury reputation. Biver plans to divide the research and development department to focus on technological innovation, potentially through partnerships with universities or specialist firms. This shift comes after the company laid off employees and scaled back non-core products.

images.alt_text: Barely a few months after dismissing Apple's smartwatch, the new chief executive of luxury Swiss watchmaker Tag Heuer conceded Tuesday that such a hi-tech gadget might after all have a place in his firm's line-up.

site_title: Vard wins contract for an offshore subsea construction vessel for Farstad
summary: Vard Holdings Limited has secured a contract to design and build an offshore subsea construction vessel for Farstad Shipping. The 98-meter vessel, designed by Vard Design in Norway, will feature two ROVs, a 150-ton crane, and be delivered in Q4 2016. The vessel will support Farstad's five-year framework agreement with Technip Norge for subsea operations, including ROV support and construction work. This marks a long-term relationship between Vard and Farstad, with Vard CEO Roy Reite praising the cooperation.

site_title: US-China climate pact a good start, but not quite enough
summary: The US and China have agreed to a climate pact, with the US aiming to cut total emissions by over a quarter by 2025 and China to reach peak greenhouse gas emissions by 2030. While this deal is a step forward, it is deemed insufficient to combat global warming, which is exacerbated by the massive contributions of the two countries. The pact's success hinges on adherence to the deal, but experts warn that the world's leading emitters, including China and the US, will need to significantly reduce their carbon footprint to avoid catastrophic consequences, with a 2% global temperature rise potentially being irreversible.

site_title: Apple cleared in iPod antitrust suit
summary: A US jury has cleared Apple of abusing its dominant market position in an antitrust case over online music for the iPod, dismissing a $350-million lawsuit. The class-action case, which featured Steve Jobs' videotaped testimony, accused Apple of forcing iPod users to purchase music on its iTunes service. The jury's verdict marks a victory for Apple, which had argued that its iTunes service was a natural extension of its iPod product. The decision comes after Jobs' death in 2011.

site_title: US: Wall St falls 3rd session, led by tech, discretionaries
summary: US stocks fell for a third consecutive day, led by declines in consumer discretionary and technology shares, while energy shares rebounded to keep the S&P 500 and Dow mostly in positive territory. The Russian rouble hit new lows against the dollar due to oil's extended selloff, sparking concerns about the global economy. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 111.97 points, the S&P 500 lost 16.89 points, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 57.32 points.

site_title: Tata-SIA carrier gets air operator permit
summary: Vistara, a joint venture between Singapore Airlines and India's Tata Sons, has been granted the Air Operator Permit by India's Directorate General of Civil Aviation. The airline, which began applying for the licence nine months ago, will start operations with brand new Airbus A320-200s and plans to connect 11 cities in India. Vistara is poised to be the third full-service carrier in India after state-run Air India and Jet Airways, and will focus on customer service excellence and unique product offerings. The airline's CEO expressed gratitude to the Ministry of Civil Aviation for their support.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: US workers struggle to keep up as robots grow smarter
summary: US workers are struggling to keep up with increasingly intelligent robots, which are taking over knowledge and service jobs. Despite technological advancements, the job market has fallen into a long malaise, with the share of working-age adults in the workforce lower than a decade ago. Economists, including Lawrence Summers and Erik Brynjolfsson, warn that automation may not always create new jobs, and that society must adapt to the challenge. While machines will likely replace some jobs, they will also complement human skills, enabling workers to be more productive and earn more money, according to Marc Andreessen.

site_title: No reprieve for US orange juice rout
summary: US orange juice consumption has reached its lowest point in at least 18 years, with annual sales declining by a third since 2004. Despite a 55% production decline in Florida, the largest US citrus grower, demand has suffered due to increased beverage options and high sugar content concerns. Sales of top brands Tropicana and Minute Maid have plummeted, with Tropicana's sales dropping 27% and Minute Maid's sales falling 35%. The decline has limited the impact of production losses, with futures surging in response to smaller orange crops in Florida and Brazil.

site_title: Geopolitical fallout from weak oil prices
summary: The recent 40% decline in Brent crude has significant geopolitical implications, reversing the post-1973 international system where Middle Eastern countries wielded "oil power" to pressure the West. As the US economy becomes less dependent on Middle Eastern oil, Western governments are reassessing their interests in the region, potentially reducing the pressure on Israel-Palestine. Iran, however, faces economic hardship due to falling oil prices and international sanctions, weakening its position in regional politics. Other oil-producing countries like Russia and Venezuela also face economic challenges, potentially undermining their leaders' power.

site_title: Straits Trading unit to buy Chongqing development
summary: Straits Trading's subsidiary, Straits Real Estate, has agreed to acquire Times Midtown in Chongqing, China for approximately 668.4 million yuan (S$141.65 million). The 24,652 sq m property has a land use right tenure ending in 2050 and will be enhanced at a cost of about 100 million yuan. The acquisition is not expected to impact Straits Trading's earnings per share or net tangible asset per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Share buybacks pick up momentum in second week of December
summary: In the second week of December, Singapore's share buybacks accelerated, with a total value of S$91.1 million, up 3.52% from the previous week. Oil-related companies, including Keppel Corporation and Genting Singapore, made two of the top five largest purchases. Pacific Century Regional Developments topped the list with S$30.8 million spent on 118 million shares, while Keppel Corporation bought back S$12.9 million worth of its own stock. The move is seen as a response to tumbling oil prices, with Brent oil hitting a new five-year low below US$60 per barrel.

site_title: KL current account seen slipping to deficit as early as this quarter
summary: Malaysia's current account may slip into a slight deficit as early as the current quarter, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch. The warning comes amid sharply lower oil prices, which have already affected the country's equities and currency. Economists predict a twin deficit and lower growth, with GDP growth projected at 4.6-5.5% for 2015. The government has declined to revise its 2015 budget and GDP growth projections, despite economists warning of a potential sovereign rating downgrade due to the fiscal deficit.

site_title: Cheaper oil seen a boon for US banks
summary: US banks are expected to benefit from cheaper oil, with trading volumes and volatility increasing and consumers having more money to spend. The price of crude has plummeted over 45% in the past six months, drawing hedgers and speculators back into the market. This is expected to lead to the first annual jump in revenue for commodities trading desks in three years. However, some banks' credit-trading businesses may suffer due to increased corporate bond yields. Despite this, executives believe the benefits will outweigh the costs, with some seeing the recent surge as a net positive for the banking industry.

site_title: Italy's president hints at possible retirement date
summary: Italy's President Giorgio Napolitano, 89, hinted at possible early retirement in 2015, amid speculation he may step down after Italy's presidency of the European Union ends on December 31. Napolitano, who has been in office since 2006, had previously signaled he wouldn't serve a full seven-year term. The choice of his successor will be closely watched, as it may indicate the strength of Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's grip on the ruling Democratic Party.

images.alt_text: Giorgio Napolitano (right), Italy's 89-year-old president who helped to guarantee the country's political stability during a period of upheaval, hinted on Tuesday he might retire early next year.

site_title: McDonald's Japan rations fries as US port jams delay imports
summary: McDonald's Japan has rationed small-sized fries due to long delays in US port imports, caused by a labour dispute and other factors. The company is importing 1,000 tonnes of frozen fries by air and 1,600 tonnes by sea, but a shortage is still expected. The shortage could have occurred by the end of the year or beginning of the new year if not for the sales restriction. Japan is the largest Asian market for US-made frozen potato products, importing $336 million worth last year.

site_title: Uber could pay dearly for brazen behaviour
summary: Uber's aggressive expansion strategy, which involves disregarding local laws and regulations, could lead to significant financial costs for the company. Despite its rapid growth and popularity among investors, Uber is facing mounting legal, lobbying, and public relations expenses. The company has raised over $2 billion from investors and has hired lobbyists in 50 US cities and states. Governments have banned Uber services in several countries and cities, and the company's actions have sparked criticism. Uber's approach may eventually backfire, as it prioritizes short-term gains over long-term responsibility.

site_title: Hacked e-mail shows Sony received US$7b proposal
summary: Sony received a US$7 billion proposal from unidentified investors, believed to be linked to Middle Eastern princes, to fund film production and buy company stock. The proposal included US$6 billion in debt and equity financing and US$1 billion in Sony stock. However, Sony executives expressed concerns about the anonymity of the investors and the unusual structure of the deal, leading to the proposal's rejection. The hackers, known as Guardians of Peace, had released the emails as part of their hacking spree, which also revealed sensitive information about Sony employees and movie stars.

site_title: After record year, Australia IPO market seen slowing in 2015
summary: Australia's initial public offering (IPO) market is expected to slow down in 2015 due to a record-breaking year in 2014, with a total of US$14.67 billion raised. Recent listings have been met with mixed performance, and investor enthusiasm has been cooled by a slump in commodities prices. Investment banks in Australia can expect their equity markets fees to drop, with some firms, such as Macquarie Group, seeing a decline in their market share.

site_title: Economists see wage gains as US recovery spreads to more workers
summary: US economists see a nascent uptick in wages, with a 0.4% increase in average hourly earnings in November, prompting warnings from hawkish Fed officials to ward off potential inflation. Despite this, Fed Chair Janet Yellen and a majority of policymakers prefer to keep interest rates low until the trend is better established. The wage gains are seen as a sign of a broader economic recovery, but experts caution that lower-paid workers may not see significant gains, and that higher-paid workers with specialized skills are still getting the majority of raises.

images.alt_text: Overall wages in the US went up 0.4 per cent in November, but the gain for lower-paid workers increased only 0.2 per cent.

site_title: Oil falls through another support
summary: Oil prices plummeted below $60 a barrel, breaching a psychological support level for the first time in five years, as Brent fell to $59.02 and US crude dipped to $53.80. Analysts warn of more price volatility, citing a supply glut and weakening demand, with some predicting prices could drop to $50 for Brent and $40 for US crude. The decline could impact capital markets, with some investors facing risks of default from shale producers, while others see a boost in growth for Asia-Pacific economies if the savings are spent.

site_title: Tanker markets to gain from oil stockpiling due to price fall
summary: Oil prices have dropped, benefiting tanker markets, with supertanker rates nearing five-year highs. The drop in shipping fuel prices and receding overcapacity are contributing factors. As oil prices fall, demand for oil storage at sea is expected to increase, particularly in distant eastern markets. The International Energy Agency forecasts global oil stocks will build, potentially leading to floating storage and a contango in the oil market. This could lead to increased earnings for tanker owners, with average earnings potentially exceeding $120,000 per day.

images.alt_text: Supertanker rates are already close to five-year highs of over US$83,000 a day, helped by a drop in shipping fuel bunker prices, while overcapacity is also receding.

site_title: FedEx to buy reverse logistics company Genco
summary: FedEx has agreed to buy reverse logistics firm Genco, handling over 600 million returned items annually, for an estimated $2 billion, according to research estimates. The acquisition aims to capitalize on the growing e-commerce market, with FedEx expecting record shipments during the holiday season. Genco will continue to operate as a separate company until the acquisition closes in 2015, with its CEO Todd Peters remaining in position. The deal is expected to broaden FedEx's capabilities and services, benefiting both FedEx and its customers.

site_title: Maserati moves to prime motor belt
summary: Maserati has relocated its Singapore distributor, Hong Seh Motors, to a larger showroom in the prime motor belt, expanding its 6,000 square foot space from its previous location. The move aims to boost "higher automotive visibility" and support the company's goal of more than doubling production by 2017, targeting 75,000 cars worldwide. The new showroom features a more extensive display of Maserati models, including the Levante SUV and Alfieri sports cars, set to be unveiled in the coming years.

site_title: Weak PMI data pushes eurozone yields to new lows
summary: Weak private sector growth data in the eurozone, as indicated by the Markit flash composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 51.4 in December, pushed eurozone bond yields to new lows. The data reinforces bets that the European Central Bank (ECB) may soon start buying sovereign bonds to inject money into the economy. Oil price falls, which had previously offered little support to the region's economy, are having a more significant impact on dampening inflation expectations, with eurozone bond yields reaching record lows.

site_title: UK exec barred from financial industry
summary: A former managing director at BlackRock Asset Management in London, Jonathan Paul Burrows, has been barred from the financial industry for life after evading train fares over five years. He was fined £43,000 and ordered to pay the maximum fare for a trip within London. Regulators found that Burrows lacked honesty and integrity, and his conduct fell short of the standards expected of a senior financial services professional. The decision was made by the Financial Conduct Authority after Burrows admitted to evading fares and failed to report the incidents to his employer.

site_title: Getting ahead in Islamic finance
summary: Singapore must leverage its position as a global banking hub to tap the growing Islamic finance market, but lacks domestic appetite for Syariah-compliant products. Islamic finance assets are estimated to be around US$1.8 trillion, with a 19.7% year-on-year growth rate through 2018. To become a competitive Islamic financial centre, Singapore must adopt breakthrough strategies, despite its current status as a gateway to South-east Asia and a top international financial centre.

site_title: Property disposal doesn't signal London market exit: Sinarmas
summary: Sinarmas Land, a Singapore-based property developer, has sold its London office building, New Brook Buildings, for £113.4 million (S$233.4 million), despite the London market's expected appreciation in 2015. The sale was an opportunistic move, taking advantage of the property's high rental yield. The proceeds will be used to repay bank loans, boost working capital, and fund future London acquisitions. Sinarmas plans to increase its recurring income from 20% to 25% and balance its exposure to its volatile property development business.

site_title: ADB okays US$100m loan to Yoma
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has approved a US$100 million loan to Singapore-listed Yoma Strategic Holdings for infrastructure connectivity projects in Myanmar. The loan will be disbursed in two tranches to support telecommunication towers, cold storage logistics, and transportation subprojects. This investment aims to enhance connectivity, reduce costs, and promote trade in Myanmar, one of the least-connected countries in the world. The loan is seen as a key step in accelerating Myanmar's growth and improving its infrastructure, with Yoma Strategic executive chairman Serge Pun praising the ADB's support.

site_title: Rouble down more than 11% after rate hike
summary: The Russian rouble plummeted over 11% against the dollar on Tuesday, reaching a record low of 72.80, and has fallen nearly 20% this week, taking its losses against the US dollar to over 50% this year. The central bank's rate hike of 650 basis points was seen as a sign of desperation, and analysts say Russia is on the brink of a full-blown currency crisis. The rouble's decline is attributed to the slump in oil prices and Western sanctions, and has sparked concerns about capital controls and the stability of the Russian economy.

site_title: Housing starts decline for third straight month
summary: Housing starts declined 1.6% to a 1.03 million annualized rate in November, marking a third consecutive month of decline, according to the Commerce Department. Single-family house construction decreased to a 677,000 rate, while multifamily home construction rose 6.7%. Total housing starts were down 7.5% from the same month in 2013. The decline is attributed to the South region, while job gains and lower mortgage rates are expected to support demand in the housing market.

site_title: Employers get a guide on spelling out employment terms in writing
summary: Singapore employers will be required by law to spell out employment terms in writing, starting by the first half of 2016, alongside itemised payslips. The Tripartite Guidelines, drawn by the Ministry of Manpower, employers, and unions, outline who should receive written terms, when they should be given, and what should be included. Employers must provide written key employment terms (KETs) to workers employed continuously for at least 14 days, including job details, salary, and benefits. The guidelines aim to increase transparency and better protect workers.

site_title: Marijuana enjoys a legal high in 2014
summary: In 2014, Uruguay became the first country to fully legalize marijuana, allowing citizens to grow, buy, and consume it. The policy, implemented by President Jose Mujica, aims to combat illicit trafficking. Meanwhile, US states like Washington, Colorado, Alaska, and Oregon legalized marijuana for recreational and medical purposes, with the District of Columbia also approving a legalization initiative. The cannabis industry is booming, with estimates ranging from $10 billion to $40 billion, and campaigners see 2014 as a breakthrough year for marijuana's growing acceptance.

site_title: China FDI up 22.2% in November despite economic slowdown
summary: Foreign investment into China surged 22.2% in November to US$10.36 billion, defying expectations of a slowdown in the economy. This marks a significant increase from October, which saw a 1.3% rise. However, the overall trend for the year remains mixed, with FDI falling 0.7% and ODI rising 11.9%. Despite concerns over business risks and declining investment from major countries, British and South Korean investments jumped 28% and 22.9% respectively in November.

site_title: China's factory activity shrinks in December
summary: China's manufacturing sector contracted in December for the first time in seven months, with the HSBC/Markit manufacturing PMI falling to 49.5. This marks a slowdown in the sector, which has been attributed to weak demand and rising disinflationary pressures.
