The deal aims to help Chinese banks gain European banking licenses and expertise, and is part of China's efforts to build up overseas bank outlets as the yuan gains a greater share of global trade.

site_title: Net long positions on US crude climb to 2-month high
summary: Speculators increased their net-long position in US crude to a two-month high, with money managers adding to their bets that the oil slump is ending. Despite this, prices continued to fall, reaching a five-year low, as OPEC producers reduced prices and the International Energy Agency cut its global demand estimate for the fourth time in five months. The US pumped a record 9.12 million barrels a day, and investors added $264.5 million to oil funds in December, indicating a growing sense of optimism about a price rebound.

site_title: Police storm Sydney cafe to end hostage siege, three dead
summary: Police stormed a Sydney cafe early Tuesday morning, ending a 16-hour hostage siege that killed three people, including the attacker, Man Haron Monis. The gunman, an Iranian refugee and self-styled sheikh, was known for sending hate mail to Australian soldiers' families. Monis, also charged with sexual assault, was armed with a sawn-off shotgun and was killed during the raid. Four hostages were wounded, and 17 were accounted for, including those who escaped on Monday. The incident highlights the dangers of "lone wolf terrorism" and underscores Australia's efforts to combat Islamic State.

images.alt_text: Heavily armed Australian police stormed a Sydney cafe early on Tuesday morning and freed a number of hostages being held there at gunpoint, in a dramatic end to a 16-hour siege in which three people including the attacker were killed.

site_title: New economic census likely to show that China will meet 7.5% growth target
summary: China is predicted to meet its 2014 economic growth target of 7.5% after the release of its third national economic census this month. The census, conducted after a year of interviews and data collection from millions of businesses, may revise the value of services higher, prompting additions to gross domestic product estimates. The announcement comes after a year of economic growth, with China's economy showing resilience despite global economic uncertainty. The results will provide insight into China's economic performance and its ability to meet growth targets.

site_title: America's oil states show early signs of slowdown
summary: The US oil-producing states, including Texas, North Dakota, Alaska, Oklahoma, and New Mexico, are showing early signs of a slowdown due to the sharp drop in crude prices. Companies have announced layoffs, and spending plans have been cut, with a 40% decline in crude prices since June. This is expected to widen budget gaps in these states, particularly Alaska, where the forecast crude price is expected to drop by almost $2 billion. The slowdown is also expected to affect related industries such as transportation and cement, with some firms planning to cut the number of rigs they operate by over 50 in 2015.

site_title: Gearing up for big events in 2017
summary: Kazakhstan is gearing up for two major international events in 2017: Expo 2017 in Astana and the 28th Winter Universiade in Almaty. The Winter Universiade, a biennial international sporting and cultural festival, will bring together university student-athletes worldwide, promoting friendship and sportsmanship. The event is expected to have a positive impact on Almaty, fostering future leaders and inspiring sustainable development. Additionally, Expo 2017 will showcase Kazakhstan's investment opportunities in alternative energy and promote regional development.

site_title: Obama vows no safe haven for Islamic State
summary: President Barack Obama vowed to destroy the Islamic State group, stating that a US-led coalition will permit no safe haven to the militants. During a visit to a US military base, Obama expressed confidence in the coalition's efforts, citing successes in taking out hundreds of vehicles and tanks, as well as over 1,000 fighting positions. He emphasized that the US will find and destroy the group, warning that those who threaten America will have no safe haven. Obama also confirmed plans to end the US combat mission in Afghanistan by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: President Barack Obama used a holiday season visit to a US military base on Monday to issue a tough warning to Islamic State militants, saying a US-led coalition will permit no safe haven to the group and will destroy it eventually.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines shares suspended
summary: Malaysia Airlines suspended its shares from the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange on December 15, 2014, under a government rescue plan. The airline, struggling with losses after the disappearance of MH370 and the downing of MH17, will be taken private by state investment fund Khazanah Nasional, which owns 70% of the carrier. The plan includes a $1.73 billion investment, 6,000 job cuts, and route network trimming. The airline's CEO position will be filled by Christoph Mueller, previously head of Aer Lingus, in the middle of 2015.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ezion and Pacific Radiance, two offshore oil services companies, are trading at 26% and 7% above recommended entry points, respectively, according to CIMB Research. The companies are expected to benefit from a rebound in oil prices in the second half of 2015. In contrast, PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) is being downgraded to "hold" due to reduced demand for its services. Meanwhile, Sheng Siong Group is upgraded to "neutral" due to improved regional consumption growth and consumer confidence.

site_title: GIC and Vatika to develop residential projects in India
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and Indian property developer Vatika Group have established two joint ventures for residential projects on Dwarka Expressway in Gurgaon, India. The projects, called Sovereign Park and Seven Elements, will be developed by Vatika and expected to be completed by 2018-19, generating revenues in excess of 20 billion rupees. The projects, with 2.3 million square feet of development potential, will meet India's demand for high-quality residential units, with GIC confident of India's long-term growth potential.

images.alt_text: Sovereign Park (above) and Seven Elements are expected to be completed by the 2018-19 financial year and generate revenues in excess of 20 billion rupees

site_title: Smithsonian completes digitising job
summary: The Smithsonian has completed a multi-year effort to digitize its 40,000-item collection, making it the first of the franchise to share its entire collection with a global audience. The digitization process, which began with a 400-year-old painting, will include at least one image of each work, with the majority in high-resolution, and will be searchable and downloadable for non-commercial use. The collection will be available online starting January 1, and museum officials predict it will increase interest and attract more visitors.

site_title: Going from strength to strength
summary: Kazakhstan celebrates its 23rd anniversary of independence on December 16, marking a significant milestone in the country's journey from the Soviet era. With abundant natural resources and a strong economy, Kazakhstan has emerged as one of the region's leading nations. The country's key values, including its multi-vector foreign policy and anti-nuclear weapons movement, have contributed to its success. President Nursultan Nazarbayev highlighted seven assets gained upon independence, including a strong sense of global responsibility and a unified culture and language. Kazakhstan looks to the future with confidence and new hope.

site_title: In brief
summary: Yongnam Holdings secured two contracts worth S$22.8 million, one in Hong Kong and one in Singapore. Sysma Construction secured a S$13.5 million contract for a detached house in Singapore. A Leader Environmental Technologies subsidiary renewed its loan facilities for S$23.3 million. Meanwhile, other news includes Tesla's robotaxi expansion, FedEx's robot delivery partnership, and a mandatory offer for PSC shares.

site_title: Direct poll vote: Joko may win support from opposition
summary: Indonesia's President Joko "Jokowi" Widodo's ruling party is in talks with opposition parties to ensure the passage of a bill re-establishing direct elections for regional heads, a potential stepping stone to broader cooperation. The Democratic Party, led by former President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, may support the bill, while the National Mandate Party is also in talks. This cooperation could lead to a 307-seat majority for Jokowi's party in parliament, allowing him to push through his legislative agenda. The opposition vows to remain a potent force, holding the government accountable.

site_title: SGX should be more proactive in its response to feedback
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has been criticized for its new website, with users expressing frustration over information gaps and confusing layout. The website's company disclosures page is particularly problematic, with company names listed under "managers" rather than the actual company name, making it difficult for investors to find relevant announcements. Despite numerous complaints, SGX has shown inaction in addressing these issues, prompting calls for the company to be more proactive in responding to feedback from the investing public.

site_title: Uber offers free rides in Sydney following flak over siege-linked price surge
summary: Uber offers free rides in Sydney after a surge in prices amid a hostage drama in a city cafe, sparking public backlash. Fares initially rose to A$100, following the company's automatic surge pricing. After criticism, Uber announced free rides from Sydney's central business district to help passengers get home safely. This move comes amid controversy surrounding Uber's aggressive approach to local governments and traditional taxi services.

site_title: G-Global tackles international issues
summary: Kazakhstan's G-Global platform held an international conference in Almaty, focusing on a new paradigm for solving global challenges. The conference, titled "A new paradigm of sustainable human development," aimed to improve global dialogue and address current issues. Speaker Kassym-Jomart Tokayev emphasized the importance of sustainable human development and security, highlighting the role of G-Global in this process. The platform, a unique global dialogue among intellectuals and experts, seeks to promote equal dialogue and cooperation among nations to address global challenges.

site_title: Greenland biding its time to enter Singapore market
summary: Greenland Holding Group, a Chinese state-owned developer, plans to enter Singapore's market next year, after deciding not to bid for a land parcel in Singapore this year due to intense competition. The company aims to undertake large-scale iconic projects in Singapore and Malaysia, focusing on mixed-use developments with homes, offices, hotels, and retail malls. Greenland has already identified potential projects in Kuala Lumpur and is in mature talks with investors in Seoul and Paris. The company's internationalization strategy has led to its aggressive overseas moves in recent years, with notable projects in Sydney, Los Angeles, and London.

site_title: Yen strengthens despite Abe win; euro down
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe won the general election, boosting his reflationary economic policies but leading to a rise in the yen. The euro fell against the yen as investors anticipated the European Central Bank's aggressive policy easing. The dollar also declined, reaching 118.38 yen, while eurozone inflation expectations hit a new low. The Federal Reserve's last policy meeting of 2014 is expected to be dovish, with Fed chief Janet Yellen seen as hesitant to signal a premature interest rate hike.

site_title: Colliers sees jump in Asian property transactions in 2015
summary: Colliers predicts a jump in Asian property transactions in 2015 due to increased supply meeting strong demand. Pent-up demand from real-estate occupiers and investors, driven by expiring property funds and new developments, is expected to be satisfied by growing supply. Capital will likely be put to work in Asia, with investors raising asset allocations to the region, and GDP growth is forecast to pick up in most cities. The consultancy expects Singapore's capital market to see more transactions in 2015, with private-equity groups and institutional investors from Europe and North Asia driving demand.

site_title: Peace Centre/Mansion make third en bloc attempt
summary: The Peace Centre/Mansion in Singapore's District 9 is up for collective sale by tender for the third time, with an indicative price of S$680 million, or S$1,125 per square foot per plot ratio. The 76,617 sq ft site has about 54.5 years left on its leasehold tenure and can be redeveloped into a mixed-use development. The successful buyer can potentially redevelop the property into a mixed-use development with an allowable gross floor area of 604,578 sq ft.

site_title: New momentum needed to secure global climate treaty in 2015
summary: The 2014 United Nations climate summit in Peru concluded with a modest agreement, averting a potential collapse, but leaving many hard issues unresolved. Despite this, domestic climate change legislation is advancing rapidly, with almost 500 laws passed globally covering 90% of greenhouse emissions. Developing countries are recognizing the benefits of reducing emissions, and many have made significant progress in drafting climate change laws. A comprehensive global treaty in 2015 is still uncertain, but the momentum for action is growing, with a better response to climate change needed to address increasing urgency and physical impacts of global warming.

site_title: Asia-style regionalism works well
summary: Asia's regionalism has been market-driven and substantially successful, with trade within the region increasing to 40% of East Asian trade, up from 30% two decades ago. This growth is driven by the rising purchasing power of Asia's middle class and the continent's value chains servicing Asian consumers. Asian countries, despite their diversity in level of development, politics, economics, and religion, have worked together for prosperity and peace. The model for Asian regionalism is Europe's, where trade has led to better neighborly relations and spillover effects into other fields. Asian governments can further promote regionalism by pursuing free trade agreements and fostering cross-cultural understanding.

site_title: US magazine gets circulation boost from gift subscriptions
summary: The Week magazine has seen a significant boost in circulation due to gift subscriptions, with 110,000 subscribers purchasing 165,000 subscriptions in 2014. This accounts for over a quarter of the magazine's total circulation of 579,291. Gift subscriptions have become a major driver of circulation growth, increasing by 12% from 2010. The magazine has also raised its subscription price 30% and increased gift subscriptions by 35% over the last five years, making subscribers advocates for the publication.

site_title: Seige ends after police storm Sydney cafe
summary: Australian police stormed a Sydney cafe, ending a dramatic 8-hour siege that left two dead, three seriously injured, and possibly up to 15 hostages still held. The gunman, identified as Iranian self-described cleric Man Haron Monis, had taken several hostages and displayed a black flag with Arabic lettering. The siege occurred three months after Australia raised its terrorism alert to the highest level, prompting a nationwide lockdown and economic disruption.

site_title: Yuan won't be as volatile as other EM currencies, says PBOC
summary: China's yuan is expected to remain relatively stable despite recent volatility in emerging market currencies, according to PBOC chief economist Ma Jun. China's economic growth outpaces developed countries, its capital account is not fully open, and it has recorded trade surpluses, limiting the impact of international exchange rate changes. The yuan has been in a slight downtrend due to the US dollar's strength and interest rate cut by the People's Bank of China. Ma Jun expects the yuan to not fluctuate as sharply as other emerging market currencies.

site_title: Nov industrial production up the most since May 2010
summary: US industrial production surged 1.3% in November, the largest gain since May 2010, driven by a 1.1% rise in manufacturing and a 0.5% gain in output at manufacturers. Rising car sales, retail purchases, and hiring are boosting economic growth. Consumer-goods production saw its largest gain in 16 years, while the Fed's report indicates sustained production growth and improving household demand.

site_title: Passenger carriage in November down at SIA, up at SilkAir
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) adjusted capacity to match market demand in November, with a 3.8% drop in passenger carriage and 1.6% decline in passengers carried. The airline's passenger load factor (PLF) fell 1.3 percentage points to 75.7%. In contrast, SilkAir's systemwide passenger carriage increased 5.8% year-over-year. Cargo load factor improved by 3.8 points, driven by a 1.7% rise in cargo traffic. SIA's shares closed trading at S$11.58, down five cents.

site_title: Developer sales in 2014 likely to be about half of last year's
summary: Developers' private condominium sales in Singapore are expected to be about half of last year's, following a 48% decline in November sales to 412 units. However, executive condominium sales have been brisk, indicating a mixed market. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's data shows a contrast between weak private condo sales and strong EC sales, suggesting a potential shift in the market.

site_title: Rising salaries a welcome sign for industrial world
summary: Japan's Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda is receiving a pay raise, and workers in the US, Japan, UK, and Germany are seeing rising salaries due to tightening job markets. This indicates the world economy is on the mend and potentially poised for faster growth. The news is a welcome sign for households benefiting from low oil prices.

site_title: India prices unexpectedly stagnate amid calls for rate cut
summary: India's wholesale prices unexpectedly stagnated in November, the first time since July 2009, with all 34 analysts predicting an increase. This adds pressure on central bank governor Raghuram Rajan to cut interest rates, which he has left unchanged for a fifth straight meeting. The stagnation comes amid calls from Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government for lower borrowing costs to boost the economy, which saw a 4.2% industrial output fall in October.

site_title: Canberra sees wider deficit as commodities slide
summary: Australia's government expects a budget deficit of A$40.4 billion in the year to June, due to falling commodity prices and sluggish wage growth. The economy is forecast to grow 2.5% in 2014/15 and 3.5% in subsequent years, with unemployment peaking at 6.5%. Treasurer Joe Hockey attributed the deficit to a slide in iron ore prices and difficulties in implementing cost-cutting measures. Despite this, the budget deficit is relatively small by international standards, and the government's AAA rating remains unchanged.

site_title: SocGen betting on corporate, investment banking
summary: Societe Generale, a French bank, is investing heavily in corporate and investment banking, shifting 3,000 employees to five large trading floors. CEO Frederic Oudea aims to drive profit growth as economic growth falters in France and Russia. The corporate finance and capital-markets businesses generated almost half of the firm's profit in the first nine months of the year, the highest level since 2006. This shift reflects the bank's reliance on these areas to counter declining revenues from traditional securities businesses.

site_title: The importance of being earnest
summary: Ernestine Fu, the youngest venture capitalist in Silicon Valley at 20, shares her secrets to success. She emphasizes the importance of a strong team and market in funding startups. Her own startup, HelloWorld, was sold to Life360 for an undisclosed seven-figure sum after being created in just two months. Fu credits her experience in non-profit work and having a supportive network for her success. She advises fostering entrepreneurship conversations and notes Singapore's supportive government and DBS backing. Looking ahead, Fu predicts growth in 3D printing and wearable technology, with user-friendly devices being key to success in the latter space.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Nurturing a partnership
summary: Singapore and Kazakhstan have strengthened economic ties, with Singapore companies investing in Kazakhstan's economy and Kazakhstan's business community exploring opportunities in Singapore. The two countries have organized business forums, signed treaties, and established special economic zones to enhance cooperation. Kazakhstan has become a preferred investment destination, with a stable investment climate and favorable policies. The country aims to become one of the top 30 most competitive economies in the world and is set to join the World Trade Organization.

site_title: Eurasian economic union to break new ground
summary: The Eurasian Economic Union, formed by Kazakhstan, Belarus, and Russia, will come into force on January 1, 2015. The union aims to promote trade and economic integration among its member states, with the goal of creating a common market of 170 million people. Experts predict a significant boost to economic growth, with a total GDP of $400 billion by 2015, and lower costs for goods and increased trade volume. President Nursultan Nazarbayev's vision for Eurasian integration began in the early 1990s and has been driven by Kazakhstan's efforts to promote regional cooperation.

site_title: Abenomics gets benefit of the doubt - and a second wind
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has been re-elected, retaining his coalition's majority in the lower house of parliament until 2018. His decision to call a snap election was seen as both opportunistic and pragmatic, allowing him to push through policies such as Abenomics, which aims to combat deflation and promote economic growth. Despite concerns over the economy's sluggish performance, Abe's win gives him more time to execute his agenda and a strong parliamentary majority to back him. However, his nationalistic foreign policy approach may face scrutiny from Japan's neighbors, particularly China and South Korea.

site_title: Sony Pictures warns media outlets against using hacked data
summary: Sony Pictures Entertainment warned media outlets against using hacked data, characterizing it as "stolen information" and demanding its destruction. The warning comes 20 days after hackers infiltrated the studio's computer systems and amid public silence from peer studios. The hackers have threatened to dump more data by Christmas, including information on Sony's salaries and private e-mail conversations. Sony representatives have acknowledged the authenticity of the e-mail and data, while other major studios and the Motion Picture Association of America have offered little public backing, citing concerns about potential backlash.

site_title: Yummi Media inks exclusive deal with China cinema chain
summary: Yummi Media, a Singapore-based digital media company, has inked an exclusive licensing and partnership agreement with China's cinema chain Wanda, the world's largest cinema chain. The deal will allow China cinema-goers to access Yummi's app, WeDong, which offers movie trailers, games, and rewards before and after a movie. This partnership aims to provide a more immersive and social cinema experience, complementing the actual movie experience. Yummi plans to expand into Western Europe, India, and South America, and has over one million active users globally.

site_title: Layoffs rise in Q3 but workers find jobs fast (Amended)
summary: Singapore's labour market remained tight in Q3, with the overall unemployment rate staying "low and steady" at 2.0% in September. However, 55% of retrenched workers found employment within six months, an improvement from 53% in the previous quarter. Layoffs rose to 3,500, with 58% in the services sector and 36% in manufacturing. Job vacancies dipped 5.9% to 60,700, with a seasonally adjusted ratio of 142 job openings per 100 job-seekers.

site_title: 2014: one of the safest years for flying despite MAS tragedies
summary: In 2014, one of the safest years for flying occurred despite tragic incidents involving Malaysia Airlines, which garnered global attention due to their disappearance and being shot down. This year marked a stark contrast to the fears surrounding modern jet travel, highlighting the resilience of the aviation industry.

site_title: Teo Soon Hoe lauded for his loyalty and commitment to Keppel
summary: Keppel Corporation's senior executive director Teo Soon Hoe, who died on Sunday, was lauded for his loyalty and commitment to the company. Described as having rendered "distinguished service" over 40 years, Teo rose from a management assistant in 1975 to group finance director and senior executive director. Tributes from Keppel's leaders praised his focus on the company's interests, commitment to execution excellence, and devotion to Keppel. He will be remembered as a visionary entrepreneur, good friend, and capable colleague.

site_title: Kori, Ryobi Kiso bag huge government building contracts
summary: Two Singaporean construction and engineering firms, Kori Holdings and Ryobi Kiso Holdings, have secured large government project contracts totaling S$109.2 million. Kori won S$52.9 million in contracts related to the Thomson Line MRT extension, while Ryobi secured S$56.3 million in contracts for the Thomson Line, a NEWater plant, and Project Jewel. The projects are expected to start in 2015 and be completed in 24 months. The awards reflect the government's projected S$31 billion to S$38 billion in construction demand for 2014.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of the entrance of Upper Thomson Station of the Thomson Line, which will be located near Thomson Plaza shopping centre

site_title: Putin effect gives Chilean salmon farming short-lived boost
summary: Russia's retaliatory sanctions against EU and US imports, including salmon, led to a temporary boost in Chilean salmon farming. However, a slump in the rouble against the dollar reduced Russian demand, causing prices to drop. Despite global shortages and rising demand, Chilean salmon farmers are expanding production to meet demand, with Japanese companies such as Nippon Suisan and Mitsubishi Corp investing in the industry. The industry is expected to see further consolidation, with mergers and acquisitions expected to occur in response to the growing demand for salmon.

site_title: Vallianz clinches US$97m contract
summary: Vallianz Holdings secured a US$97 million time charter contract with a national oil company in the Middle East for up to five years. The contract, subject to formalization, adds to the company's existing contracts in the region, strengthening its order book to US$626.4 million. CEO Darren Yeo said the award reflects the company's execution capabilities and demonstrates its status as a key offshore support vessel provider in the Middle East. The contract is part of Vallianz's plans to expand its fleet size and diversify its current fleet of 34 OSVs.

site_title: Food Empire's early mover advantage
summary: Food Empire, a Singapore company, is the leading brand in the coffee-mix industry in Kazakhstan, having been one of the earliest to enter the market. The company exports its proprietary brands, including MacCoffee and Hyson, to over 60 countries worldwide, showcasing its global reach and early mover advantage in the industry.

site_title: Lower prices needed to revive demand for top Bordeaux
summary: Bordeaux wine producers face a challenge to revive demand for their top vintages, with growers needing to price 2014 wines lower than mature vintages to attract buyers. Chairman of London merchant Berry Bros & Rudd, Simon Berry, warns that if prices remain too high, people may swing away from Bordeaux and not return. The market has struggled to find buyers for the past three vintages, with prices for leading wines slumping 40% from their peak in 2011. The Bordeaux 2014 vintage is set to be presented in late March and early April next year, with Berry emphasizing that prices must be sensible to attract investors and collectors.

site_title: Iata calls on govts to help deal with new security threats
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) is calling on governments to collaborate in addressing security threats to the aviation industry, citing the recent disappearance of a Malaysian airliner and the Ebola crisis as examples. IATA head Tony Tyler wants governments to work together to find solutions, but also seeks a quicker relaxation of economic controls. This comes after a turbulent year for commercial aviation, marked by several major incidents.

site_title: S$2.5m scheme launched to upskill taxi drivers, raise service standards
summary: A new S$2.52 million training program has been launched in Singapore to upskill 4,000 taxi drivers over two years, aiming to improve service and safety standards. The program, in partnership with the Devan Nair Institute of Employment and Employability and the National Taxi Association, will provide subsidies of up to 90% in course fees and pay drivers S$7.50 per hour as absentee payroll. The initiative comes amid increased competition from third-party taxi-booking apps and changes to taxi availability standards, requiring taxi drivers to work longer hours.

site_title: Keppel Corp buys back more shares amid stock price drop
summary: Keppel Corp, a Singapore-based offshore and marine company, bought back 1 million shares for S$7.97 million, its fourth and biggest daily share buyback in less than a week. The total consideration since Dec 11 is S$20.87 million for 2.56 million shares. The company's share price has dropped due to lower oil prices, wiping off nearly S$5.77 billion from the market capitalisation of O&M companies listed on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Staying relevant to be future-ready
summary: Singaporean human resources manager Tay Beng Koon emphasizes the importance of lifelong learning to stay relevant in the industry. As director of the Shangri-La Academy, she ensures her staff receive meaningful training to fulfill their personal and career goals. William Thien, a company director and consultancy owner, also stresses the need for continuous skills upgrading due to a complex workplace environment. The Institute of Adult Learning (IAL) plans to roll out a new voluntary scheme to recognize adult educators, aiming to reach 3,000 by 2020, to support their career progression.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Ms Tay (right) ensures that the academy's learning activities are meaningful and relevant for employees in terms of fulfilling their personal and career goals

site_title: Many at ECB support containing deflation risk as oil falls: ECB's Visco
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) governing council member Ignazio Visco stated that oil price declines will negatively impact euro area inflation, with many ECB members supporting measures to contain deflation risks. The ECB previously lowered inflation forecasts due to lower oil prices, and President Mario Draghi is considering buying sovereign debt to prevent a deflationary spiral.

site_title: Profiling customers can well unmask money launderers
summary: A money launderer can often be identified through customer profiling, which involves verifying a customer's identity and identifying who ultimately controls them. This information, such as business and risk profiles, can help detect suspicious activities in a business relationship. Profiling can be used to spot bad apples in a portfolio of customers, and it is especially effective in cases where money laundering has occurred, as seen in the case of Mr. Tan, who was convicted of money laundering through the sale and purchase of his company's properties in Singapore and overseas.

site_title: No debt disaster for Singapore
summary: Singapore's households do not face a debt disaster, contrary to concerns raised by media. The country's gross debt-to-GDP ratio, currently at 75%, is comparable to that of other countries like the US at 100% in 2007. Despite rising personal debts and increasing loan defaults, Singapore's overall economic health remains stable. Experts attribute the concerns to flawed debt measurement methods, emphasizing the need for more accurate assessments.

site_title: A step nearer to WTO entry
summary: Kazakhstan gains US support for WTO membership, a significant step towards its accession to the global trade body. The US will provide assistance to Kazakhstan to join the WTO as soon as possible. Kazakhstan has been negotiating its accession since 1996 and has a strong position due to its close relations with the European Union, its largest trade partner. The country's accession is expected to bring gains of up to 6.7% of GDP in the medium term.

site_title: Giving everyday objects a fresh spin
summary: The National Heritage Board has launched "Everyday Objects," a series of lifestyle products featuring 40 distinctive designs by 40 Singaporean talents, including local designers and artists. The collection includes items such as T-shirts, timepieces, bags, and plush toys, all created in collaboration with design firm Farm Studio. The objects were chosen from an open call and showcase a mix of authentic local flavour and culturally neutral designs. The collection is available for sale at the National Museum of Singapore and the Asian Civilisations Museum, with the public able to vote for their favourite prototypes to be considered for future productions.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Alibaba boss woos Taiwan youth to start businesses on mainland
summary: Alibaba founder Jack Ma called on Taiwan's youth to start businesses on the mainland, urging them to "reach out" and join Alibaba's ecosystem. The move comes amid growing tensions over China's increased influence on Taiwan, which contributed to the ruling party's worst-ever polls defeat. Ma encouraged young people to sell their products to the mainland using Alibaba as a platform, despite concerns over trade deals being agreed in secret and not benefiting the Taiwanese public. The meeting was attended by top business figures from China and Taiwan.

site_title: EU aims to keep Greece 'firmly' in eurozone
summary: The European Union aims to keep Greece firmly in the eurozone, amid concerns of early elections that could force Athens out of the single currency bloc. EU Economic Affairs Commissioner Pierre Moscovici visited Greece to review progress on austerity measures, as Prime Minister Antonis Samaras' coalition government faces intense pressure. The EU maintains neutrality in Greek politics, but Commissioner Moscovici expressed concerns about the potential consequences of a Syriza victory, which is opposed to austerity policies.

site_title: Wall Street sell-off finally takes its toll
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 29.99 points or 0.9% to 3,294.14 on Monday, following a large US selloff on Friday. Banks led the losses, with oil-price sensitive stocks such as Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Industries also dragging down the index. Trading volume was low at 994.8 million units worth S$881.1 million, with 111 rises versus 321 falls, excluding warrants. Analysts predict a turnaround in revenue trends for the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and a potential QE from the European Central Bank due to low oil prices.

site_title: Malaysia market dives as foreigners trim holdings
summary: Malaysia's stock market plummeted 2% due to foreigners trimming their holdings amid concerns over the country's fiscal position, particularly the impact of low oil prices on government revenue. The government's budget was based on $100 per barrel oil, but prices have dropped to $62, raising doubts about meeting fiscal deficit targets. Foreign investors have large positions in Malaysian Government Securities and local equities, contributing to the outflow of $17.5 billion so far this year.

images.alt_text: Analysts say the economy is resilient enough to weather the drop in oil prices and a reduction in fuel subsidies could offset the fall in oil revenue.

site_title: Retail sales up 8.1% in October, revved by vehicle sales
summary: Retail sales in Singapore increased 8.1% in October, driven by a 44.1% surge in motor vehicle sales, reaching an estimated S$3.2 billion. Excluding motor vehicles, retail sales rose 1.9%. Key sectors such as telecommunications, medical goods, and food and beverages also saw significant growth, while furniture, household equipment, and petrol service stations declined. The increase was largely attributed to the sales of newly launched mobile phones.

images.alt_text: Retail sales in Singapore increased 8.1 per cent year on year in October, boosted by motor vehicle sales. Excluding motor vehicles, retail sales rose a mere 1.9 per cent during the month.

site_title: Grammys to pay tribute to Stevie Wonder
summary: The Grammys will pay tribute to Stevie Wonder with a special performance on February 16, two days after the music industry's annual award night. The two-hour show will be recorded at the Nokia Theatre in Los Angeles and will celebrate Wonder's 64-year career, including his 25 Grammy wins. The tribute is similar to the 2014 special that honored the Beatles' 50th anniversary in the US, featuring a reunion of the Fab Four. Performers have not been announced, but the event aims to show esteem for Wonder's music and its ability to illustrate the world in every note.

site_title: Homebuilder sentiment edges lower in December: NAHB
summary: US homebuilder sentiment declined to 57 in December, down one point from November, but remained above the 50 threshold for the sixth consecutive month. The NAHB/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index is still stronger than the first half of 2014. Builders remain optimistic, with a gauge of single-family home sales sentiment at 61 and a six-month outlook at 65. NAHB Chairman Kevin Kelly expects builders to remain confident in 2015, citing improved businesses in many markets.

site_title: Markets give cautious verdict on Abe's "landslide" election victory
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's ruling coalition secured a fourth term in power after a record-low turnout, but markets reacted cautiously, with Tokyo stocks plummeting to a four-week low and the yen rising. The benchmark Nikkei 225 fell 1.6% to 17,099.40, reflecting concerns over plummeting oil prices and a weak global economy. Abe insisted that his "Abenomics" policies were endorsed by voters, but experts argue that the election was more about rejecting the opposition. The Bank of Japan's latest tankan survey showed a slight deterioration in business sentiment, and analysts expect the central bank to reassess its monetary policy.

site_title: Police storm Sydney cafe, more hostages freed
summary: Heavily armed police stormed the Sydney cafe, ending a 16-hour siege by a gunman holding around 15 hostages. The gunman, identified as Iranian-born Man Haron Monis, was shot dead in a volley of explosions and flashes. Several hostages were freed, with five more escaping earlier in the day. At least one more woman was carried out by paramedics. The pre-Christmas siege began on Monday morning, triggering a massive security lockdown in Sydney. Monis was on bail for violent offences and had raised concerns of radicalized citizens returning home.

site_title: Swiber enters West African market with US$710m deal
summary: Swiber Holdings has secured a US$710 million award from a Houston-based oil and gas company to provide EPCIC services for an offshore field development project in West Africa. The project award includes the provision of an offshore processing facility and associated subsea infrastructure developments. Swiber expects to start work in Q1 2015 and complete the project by mid-2017, broadening its experience and knowledge base in the offshore oil and gas industry. This marks Swiber's entry into the lucrative West African market, with the company having clinched contracts totaling US$1.03 billion year-to-date.

site_title: Kori Holdings wins S$52.9m Thomson Line MRT work contracts
summary: Kori Holdings announced it has won S$52.9 million contracts for construction works on the Thomson Line MRT. The projects are expected to start in Q1 2015 and be completed within 24 months.

site_title: German cities line up for bigger slice of capital markets action
summary: German cities are expected to increase their capital market activities as they face funding needs and regulatory changes. Despite a small market, German cities have raised less than 2 billion euros since 2009. The leverage ratio introduced by regulators may encourage banks to shift away from funding local authorities, prompting cities to develop their own capital markets funding. Funding needs are growing, with municipalities needing around 120 billion euros, and cities are exploring options such as bond markets, syndicate financing, and Schuldscheine markets to tackle these needs.

site_title: Big Data startups having to build up commercial user market
summary: Big Data startups are struggling to build commercial user markets, requiring agility and patience. Many are shifting from proprietary products to open-source software, focusing on technical support and consulting to generate revenue. Despite the challenges, the market is expected to grow to $41.5 billion by 2018, with companies like Hortonworks experiencing rapid growth but also significant losses. Startups must find sustainable business models to succeed, as the cost of chasing the big data opportunity can be daunting, with investors bidding up Hortonworks' stock after its initial public offering.

site_title: India's inflation rate flat, raising rate cut hopes
summary: India's wholesale inflation fell to a 5.5-year low of 0% in November, driven by declining fuel and food prices. This marks the lowest rate since July 2009 and is below analysts' estimates. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is expected to cut interest rates due to the fall in inflation, which is a three-year low. The RBI has resisted pressure to loosen monetary policy despite a faltering economy and a population struggling with rising food prices.

site_title: Afghan dilemma for China, India
summary: China and India are expected to play a major role in Afghanistan as Western forces withdraw. Despite months of negotiations, the two regional giants have yet to cooperate substantively on the issue. China has reached out to the new Afghan government, urging groups to "lay aside former enmity" and join the political reconciliation process. China has also proposed a peace and reconciliation committee to help the new government bring the Taliban to the negotiating table. India, meanwhile, has reaffirmed its commitment to supporting Afghanistan, with the Modi government investing $85.21 million in developing the strategic Chabahar port.

images.alt_text: Mr Ghani and Chinese Premier Li Keqiang at the 4th Ministerial Conference of Istanbul Process of Afghanistan in Beijing in October. China seems ready to play a larger role in Afghanistan than before.

site_title: India's Maruti to raise car prices by 2-4% from Jan
summary: Maruti Suzuki India Ltd, the country's largest carmaker, plans to raise car prices by 2-4% from January due to increased input costs. This decision follows similar price hikes by other carmakers, including Indian units of BMW AG and General Motors Co, which will raise prices by up to 5%. The move comes despite slowing sales of passenger vehicles, expected to grow at less than 4% this fiscal year.

site_title: Airbus says AirAsiaX places firm order for 55 A330neo
summary: AirAsiaX placed a firm order for 55 Airbus A330neo passenger jets, worth $15 billion at list prices. This order confirms a provisional order of 50 A330neo jets placed in July and adds 5 more, bringing the total to 55. The purchase also includes engines from Rolls-Royce, and the expanded order is expected to boost AirAsia's long-haul capabilities.

site_title: Indonesian rupiah weakest since Asian financial crisis
summary: The Indonesian rupiah has fallen to its lowest level since the Asian financial crisis in 1998, losing 2% to 12,713.5 against the dollar. The decline is attributed to signs of US recovery, leading investors to pull out of emerging markets and redirect funds to developed markets. This has resulted in a strengthening US economy, causing investor risk aversion and affecting Indonesian government bonds. The Jakarta benchmark stock market also lost 1% on Monday, with economists warning of another bout of risk aversion on the global stage.

site_title: India strikes balanced deal with former close friend Russia
summary: India has struck a balanced deal with Russia, with both countries agreeing to supply and build 12 new nuclear reactors over 20 years. The deal includes the supply of oil for 10 years and the extension of a proposed gas supply line to China. Russia needs to develop and sell its nuclear technology, while India gains access to a large market and some local manufacturing. The agreement comes despite India's growing anti-nuclear movement and Russia's dependence on Western markets. The deal is seen as a strategic partnership between the two countries, despite a decline in Russia's national income and India's increasing dependence on other countries for defence and technology.

site_title: EU says working to keep Greece 'firmly' in the eurozone
summary: The European Union stated its sole goal for Greece is to keep the country firmly in the eurozone, amid market turmoil sparked by the possibility of early elections. The EU Commission is working to prevent Greece's exit from the single currency bloc, following two previous bailouts. The EU's aim is to maintain stability and prevent economic disruption, as hostile financial markets pose a significant threat to the country's financial stability.

site_title: Singapore Airlines India joint venture gets flying permit
summary: Singapore Airlines' Indian joint venture, Vistara, has received a flying permit, paving the way for its operations. The joint venture with Tata conglomerate plans to announce sales, routes, and schedules soon. Vistara will operate Airbus A320-200 planes, and its launch is expected to be announced shortly.

site_title: India's Nov trade deficit hits 18-month high of US$16.86b
summary: India's trade deficit reached an 18-month high of $16.86 billion in November, driven by a 26.79% year-on-year increase in merchandise imports to $42.82 billion. Exports grew 7.27% to $25.96 billion. This widening deficit is a concern for the Indian economy, which is heavily reliant on imports to meet its growing demand for goods. The data suggests that India's trade imbalance is unlikely to improve in the near future.

site_title: Oil price slide roils emerging markets, yen rises
summary: Oil prices plummeted to fresh 5-1/2-year lows, sparking a sell-off in emerging markets and driving up the yen. Indonesia's rupiah hit a 16-year low, while Russia's rouble reached record lows due to US sanctions concerns. European stocks stabilized after a weak week, and US stock index futures pointed to a Wall Street recovery. Oil prices have fallen over 40% this year, and investors remain cautious ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting, where interest rate hikes are expected.

site_title: Bundesbank backs ECB line on possible further measures
summary: The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, has expressed support for the European Central Bank's (ECB) possible deployment of further stimulus measures to support the eurozone economy. The Bundesbank's stance, echoed by ECB President Mario Draghi, is significant as it contrasts with the hawkish views of its own chief, Jens Weidmann, who has been reluctant to endorse quantitative easing. This alignment suggests a unified front in addressing economic concerns, with the ECB potentially considering additional measures to stimulate growth.

site_title: US: Energy, tech shares lead Wall St higher at open
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Monday, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 0.66%, the S&P 500 gaining 0.76%, and the Nasdaq Composite adding 0.69%. Gains in Apple and Oracle shares boosted the technology sector, while investors focused on crude oil prices, which hit a fresh 5-1/2-year low earlier.

site_title: Ryobi Kiso wins contracts worth S$56.3m
summary: Ryobi Kiso Holdings secured contracts worth S$56.3 million for projects including the Thomson Line MRT, Changi's second NEWater Plant, and Project Jewel at Changi Airport. This brings the total new contracts awarded to the company since the start of the year to S$235.5 million.

site_title: China says to build US$31b worth of new infrastructure
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission has approved a $31 billion infrastructure project, including roads and a third airport in Beijing, to boost investment and support a slowing economy. The 192 billion yuan (US$31 billion) project aims to increase investment, which has slowed to 15.8% growth in the first nine months of the year, its slowest pace in nearly 13 years. This move is part of China's efforts to re-engineer its growth model by reducing inefficient state spending and encouraging domestic consumption.

site_title: US manufacturing output surges in November
summary: US manufacturing output surged 1.1% in November, the largest increase in nine months, driven by production gains across the board. This follows a revised 0.1% increase in October, beating economists' forecasts of a 0.5% rise. Utilities production jumped 5.1% due to a cold snap, contributing to a 1.3% overall industrial production gain, the largest since May 2010. Capacity use rose to 80.1%, the highest since March 2008, indicating underlying strength in the economy.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific profit plunges 97.9%
summary: Del Monte Pacific Limited (DMPL) reported a 97.9% plunge in net profits for the second quarter of FY2015, primarily due to the $20.5 million expenses from its acquisition of US packaged food producer Del Monte Foods, Inc in February 2014. Revenues tripled to $548 million, while net profits slumped to $185,000. The company expects FY2015 to be a business in transition, with FY2016 expected to return to normalcy. DMPL plans to deleverage by raising $515 million in equity to bring gearing down from 906% to 170-180%.

site_title: Oil rebounds from new five-year lows, boosting stocks
summary: World oil prices rebounded slightly on Monday, rising 26 cents to $58.07 a barrel for Brent North Sea crude and 55 cents to $62.40 a barrel for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate, after hitting fresh five-year lows. The modest rebound boosted European stocks, with the FTSE 100 index up 0.33% and the CAC 40 in Paris up 0.42%. Analysts attribute the rebound to fresh unrest in crude producer Libya and the weakening dollar, despite warnings that the slide in oil prices may be protracted.

site_title: Old hyperinflation days recalled at Russian shop pricing in 'units'
summary: A small shop near Moscow has started pricing items in "Uslovniye Yedintsy" (UY), an unofficial unit pegged to foreign currency, amid Russia's economic crisis. The unit allows for relatively constant prices while adjusting the equivalent rouble value according to import costs. This practice has been revived, 15 years after its last appearance, due to the rouble's 40% decline against the dollar. The Art Real Company shop in Khimki suburb, which sells imported ceramic tiles, has been using the unit to protect against inflation.

site_title: Keppel Corp buys back one million shares for S$7.97m
summary: Keppel Corp has bought back 1 million shares worth S$7.97 million, increasing its treasury shares to 2.56 million. This move comes as the company's share price has dropped 10 cents or 1.235% to S$8 per share since late November. The shares were purchased under the company's authorised share buyback plan of 90.78 million shares.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end lower
summary: Singapore shares ended 0.90% lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index falling 29.99 points to 3,294.14. 994.8 million shares valued at S$881.1 million were traded, with 111 gains and 321 losses.

site_title: New York state manufacturing index lowest in two years: NY Fed
summary: New York state's manufacturing activity contracted for the first time in nearly two years, according to the New York Federal Reserve's Empire State general business conditions index. The index fell to -3.58 in December from 10.16 in November, entering negative territory for the first time since January 2013. Economists had expected a reading of 12.4 this month, indicating expansion. This marks the lowest level in two years, signaling a decline in manufacturing activity in the state.

images.alt_text: Manufacturing activity in New York state contracted for the first time in nearly two years, a New York Federal Reserve survey showed on Monday.

site_title: Truffles and turkeys await Christmas tables at "Belly of Paris"
summary: Rungis market in Paris, the world's largest fresh food market, is bustling with activity as Christmas approaches. Wholesalers sell a variety of items, including truffles, oysters, and turkeys, to restaurants and retailers. The market, which generates 9 billion euros in sales annually, employs 12,000 people and supports an estimated 102,000 jobs nationwide. With three thousand restaurants buying directly from the market and 30,000 receiving deliveries from abroad, prices are expected to rise for popular holiday items like lobster and turkeys.

images.alt_text: At the temple to gastronomy outside Paris, Rungis market, Marinette shows off a tray of fat white truffles from Italy, at 1,800 euros a kilo (US$1,000 per pound).

site_title: Indonesia, Singapore agree to step up sharing of tax information
summary: Indonesia and Singapore have agreed to automatically share tax-related information starting in 2017 to combat tax evasion. The move is part of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) standards for automatic exchange of information. The agreement aims to strengthen tax collection and comply with the OECD standards. Indonesia's new president Joko Widodo has made improving tax collection a priority, with a goal of increasing the tax ratio to 16% of gross domestic product. The automatic exchange of information will help close loopholes and reveal hidden assets.

site_title: Malaysia's Supermax CEO charged with insider trading
summary: Malaysia's Securities Commission has charged Supermax Corporation Bhd CEO Stanley Thai with insider trading for passing on non-public information about an unexpected loss at glove maker APL Industries. Thai handed the information to a broker between Oct 26, 2007 and Oct 29, 2007, who sold shares in APL through family accounts. Thai faces up to 10 years in jail and a fine of US$286,123. The charges led to a 16.5% drop in Supermax shares, the lowest since October 2011.

site_title: LifeBrandz's Q1 loss widens to S$871,000
summary: LifeBrandz, a club operator, reported a widening first-quarter loss of S$871,000, down from S$188,000 a year ago, due to lower revenue (29% decrease to S$4.73 million) and higher costs. Total expenses dropped 17% to S$5.79 million, easing slower than sales. The company's loss was attributed to the decline in revenue and persistent high costs.

site_title: Japan firms promise Abe 'utmost efforts' to lift wages, urge reforms
summary: Japanese business leaders have agreed to make "utmost efforts" to raise wages and pass on higher costs to suppliers, in a draft agreement with the government and labour groups. The plan, to be announced by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, aims to address Japan's stagnant wages and labour market. The agreement was reached ahead of Abe's election landslide and labour reforms are expected to be part of the plan.

site_title: Philippines to seek investors for airport projects worth US$2.6b
summary: The Philippines plans to tender six airport projects worth US$2.6 billion under a public-private partnership scheme. The projects, worth 116 billion pesos, aim to upgrade the country's aging infrastructure and cater to growing passenger numbers. The Department of Transportation and Communications has invited investors to pre-qualify and bid for contracts to develop, operate, and maintain airports in key cities and tourist hubs. The development is crucial to address traffic congestion and anticipated passenger growth.

site_title: US industrial output rises in November
summary: US industrial production rose 1.3% in November, exceeding its average monthly pace of 0.3% over the prior five months. Manufacturing production increased 1.1%, driven by a 5.1% jump in electric and gas utilities output, boosted by cold weather. Consumer goods production jumped 2.5%, with motor vehicles and parts production surging 5.1%. The increase in industrial output was higher than the Fed's average monthly pace, and capacity utilization rose to 80.1%, in line with its long-run average rate.

site_title: Indonesia central bank supports currency, bonds as rupiah at lowest since 1998
summary: The Indonesian rupiah fell to its lowest level since 1998, reaching 12,695 rupiah per dollar, due to declining risk appetites and increased demand for dollars to settle foreign loan payments. Bank Indonesia intervened in the foreign exchange and bond markets to stabilize prices, while emerging markets experienced sharp outflows of capital. Analysts attributed the fall to factors such as declining oil prices, rising dollar expectations, and high foreign ownership of Indonesian bonds, which made the currency vulnerable to a strengthening dollar.

site_title: Olympics: Rome to lead Italy bid for 2024 Games
summary: Rome will lead Italy's bid for the 2024 Olympic Games, with Prime Minister Matteo Renzi vowing a strong campaign to win the event. Italy became the first to announce a bid, taking advantage of new International Olympic Committee rules allowing events to be staged in more than one city. The bid will be officially presented in September 2015.

images.alt_text: Rome will spearhead an Italian bid for the 2024 Olympic Games, Prime Minister Matteo Renzi said on Monday vowing a strong campaign to win the event.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's stock market ended lower on Monday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 31.17 points to close at 1,701.82. The index saw 2.06 billion lots traded, with 66 gainers and 1,010 losers.

site_title: Investment proposals in Thailand to exceed US$24.3b this year: PM
summary: Thailand's proposed investment value is expected to exceed US$24.3 billion this year, surpassing the government's target of 800 billion baht. The country's economy is recovering after a May coup, with Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha predicting 3.5-4.5% growth next year. Tax incentives, including exemptions on machinery and raw materials, will be offered to encourage investors, particularly in provinces with low per capita income and special economic zones. This growth is a significant improvement from the 0.2% growth in the first nine months of the year.

site_title: Ahead of taxi protest, France says UberPop to be banned
summary: France will ban UberPop, a car-sharing service, on January 1, citing inadequate insurance for drivers and unfair competition. The ban follows a law regulating the taxi industry and chauffeured cars that took effect in 2015. Taxi unions plan a one-day protest in Paris, blocking roads during the morning rush hour. Uber has faced regulatory hurdles in France, including a fine of 100,000 euros for fraudulent business practices. The ban is the latest challenge to Uber's expansion in the country.

site_title: SIA reports lower passenger carriage in November; cargo improves
summary: Singapore Airlines reported a 3.8% year-on-year decline in systemwide passenger carriage in November, with a 1.6% drop in passengers carried to 1.52 million. The passenger load factor fell 1.3 percentage points to 75.7%. Demand improved in East Asia and South West Pacific, but weakened in Americas and Europe.

site_title: Viscous oil
summary: Singapore's motorists have not benefited from the decline in oil prices this year, with pump prices remaining relatively unchanged. Wholesale prices account for part of the cost, but duties and taxes, charged by volume, contribute a fixed amount to pump prices regardless of Brent crude prices. According to JP Morgan, Singapore's October-to-June decline in pump prices was in the middle of regional pack, with the country's subsidies and taxes slowing the passthrough of lower oil prices. This windfall is instead being passed onto cost recovery.

site_title: Five hostages run out of Sydney siege cafe
summary: A gunman took hostages at a Sydney cafe, displaying an Islamic flag, and five people were rescued after a six-hour standoff. Three men and two women were freed, with the status of the remaining hostages unknown. Police confirmed they had contact with the hostage-taker, but the motivation behind the siege remained unclear. No one was harmed at the time of the rescue.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close down on weakness in financials, property
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 1.0% to 23,027.85, as investors sold off China-related financials and real estate names. The China Enterprises Index lost 0.2% to 11,212.65 points. CCT Land rose 5.9%, while Wai Yuen Tong Medicine Holdings and Renhe Commercial Holdings declined 15.6% and remained unchanged, respectively. The decline was attributed to weakness in Hong Kong's financials and property sectors.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end 1.57% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 1.57% lower on Monday, despite Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's expected election win, due to drops on Wall Street and lower oil prices. The Nikkei 225 index fell 272.18 points to 17,099.40, while the Topix index dropped 1.45% to 1,379.29.

site_title: Australia: Shares dips 0.6% on oil woes & hostage incident
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Monday, marking a fifth consecutive session of decline, due to a drop in oil prices and a hostage incident in Sydney. The S&P/ASX 200 index eased to 5,186.1.

site_title: VW's Bentley raises car sales target on new models: report
summary: Bentley, Volkswagen's ultra-luxury brand, has raised its annual sales target to 20,000 deliveries by 2020, doubling its 2013 sales. The brand's CEO, Wolfgang Duerheimer, attributes the increase to new models, including a sport-utility vehicle, and plans to expand its model line-up by next autumn. Bentley's revenue and operating profit rose to 1.68 billion euros (US$2.1 billion) and 168 million euros, respectively, in 2013, with potential further growth expected in 2025.

site_title: Alibaba boss taps up Taiwan youth amid protests
summary: Alibaba founder Jack Ma has encouraged Taiwan's youth to start businesses on the mainland, amid anti-Beijing protests. Ma's comments came during a high-level business meeting in Taiwan, where trade with China is a sensitive topic due to fears of the mainland's increased influence on the island. The meeting was attended by business leaders from China and Taiwan, and Ma urged young people to "reach out" to the mainland and Alibaba, offering them a platform to sell their products. The move has been met with criticism from pro-independence activists, who claim the summit is a joint effort by Beijing to decide Taiwan's future.

site_title: Sony hacking highlights challenge to CEO Hirai's 'One Sony' vision
summary: Sony's hacking incident highlights the challenge to CEO Kazuo Hirai's "One Sony" vision, which aims to turn around the money-losing company. Leaked emails reveal tension between Hirai and Sony Pictures executives, including racial jokes and disparaging remarks about top actors. The hack, which targeted the company's computer systems, also shows that North Korea is a principal suspect. Despite Hirai's efforts to prove the benefits of keeping all businesses under one roof, investors and analysts now believe drastic cuts are needed in the electronics arm, particularly in weak product lines like TVs and smartphones.

site_title: Seoul: Shares pare losses after dipping to 2-mth low; won firmer
summary: South Korean shares rose slightly after falling to a 2-month low, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closing at 1,920.36 points. The won strengthened against the dollar, closing at 1,099.1 to the dollar. The gains came after a volatile trading session, with oil prices plummeting and triggering risk aversion. The US Federal Reserve's expected rate hike was also a factor, with safe-haven bids in the yen outweighing dollar bulls.

site_title: Three hostages run out of Sydney siege cafe: police
summary: A gunman took hostages at a Sydney cafe, displaying an Islamic State flag. Three people escaped through a side door, with police saying no one has been harmed. The remaining hostages are believed to be fewer than 30, according to police deputy commissioner Catherine Burn. Negotiators are in contact with the person holding the hostages, but the motivation behind the siege remains unclear.

images.alt_text: Two hostages (left) run for cover behind a policeman (right) during a hostage siege in the central business district of Sydney on December 15, 2014.

site_title: SGX issues trading caution on Tritech
summary: SGX issues a trading caution on Tritech Group's shares after the regulator queried the company about substantial trading volume increases on Monday. Tritech responded, stating it was unaware of any reasons for the trading activity. The SGX advises investors to exercise caution and will investigate possible transgressions to maintain a fair market.

site_title: India to boost women taxi drivers, spurred by Uber rape claim
summary: India aims to boost women taxi drivers nationwide after an alleged Uber rape claim, following the success of Kerala's 'She Taxis' service, which has ferried 24,000 people since 2013. The model is being replicated by the government, with plans to expand to Delhi and other cities. Critics argue that better security measures are needed, but supporters say that women drivers provide a safer option for female commuters. The move comes as India struggles with rising sex crimes and poor public transport safety for women.

site_title: Worker layoffs in Singapore rise to 3,500 in Q3
summary: Worker layoffs in Singapore rose to 3,500 in Q3, up from 2,410 in Q2, according to the Ministry of Manpower. Despite this, the jobless found employment quickly, with a second consecutive quarter of improved re-entry into employment within six months of redundancy. Unemployment remained low at 2% seasonally adjusted in September. Total employment increased by 33,400 in Q3, higher than the 27,700 increase in the preceding quarter.

site_title: India's Nov wholesale price inflation at near 5-1/2-year low
summary: India's wholesale price inflation eased to its lowest in nearly 5-1/2 years in November, driven by a sharp fall in fuel prices. The wholesale price index (WPI) was flat against a year earlier, contrasting economists' forecast of a 1.41% year-on-year jump. This marks the sixth consecutive month of decline in WPI inflation, with the September reading remaining unchanged at 2.38%. The decline is attributed to the sharp decrease in fuel prices.

site_title: Oil hits new five-year low before rallying to US$63
summary: Brent crude oil hit a five-year low of nearly US$60 a barrel on December 15, 2014, before rallying to around US$63. Oil producer group Opec reaffirmed its refusal to cut output, citing a global fuel glut. The collapse in oil prices was attributed to high-quality, light crude from North America overwhelming demand during lacklustre global economic growth. Market analysts predicted oil could fall further before a sustained recovery.

site_title: Uber in damage control after Sydney siege price hike
summary: Uber faced backlash after implementing surge pricing during the Sydney hostage siege, charging passengers up to four times regular fares with a minimum of A$100 to leave the area. The company later apologized and offered free rides to passengers fleeing the scene. Uber will also refund fares to those affected. The incident highlights concerns over the company's pricing strategy during emergency situations.

site_title: Asian stocks slump, Tokyo leads losses
summary: Asian markets declined on Monday, with Tokyo leading losses, as investors focused on the faltering economy and oil prices near five-year lows. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.57% in Tokyo, while Sydney dropped 0.64% amid a hostage crisis. Oil prices rebounded somewhat but remained low, and investors were also cautious about the Bank of Japan's quarterly survey showing a decline in manufacturing confidence. The decline in Asian markets follows a similar drop in US stocks on Friday.

site_title: Xiaomi made US$56m profit in 2013: filing
summary: Xiaomi Technology Ltd Co reported a US$56.15 million profit in 2013, with revenue of US$4.30 billion, according to Chinese securities filings. Chairman Lei Jun owns 77.8% of the company, while unnamed shareholders hold the remaining shares. This financial disclosure sheds light on Xiaomi's margins and business model, which has contributed to its success as the most popular smartphone vendor in China and the third-largest globally.

site_title: Update: Hostages held in Sydney cafe, forced to hold Islamic flag in window
summary: A gunman took hostages at a central Sydney cafe, forcing them to hold an Islamic flag in the window. The situation was deemed a terrorist event, with police surrounding the cafe and evacuating nearby buildings. Five hostages were freed, and the situation remains under control. The incident is being investigated as potentially politically motivated, with Prime Minister Tony Abbott warning of militant plans to strike Australian targets.

site_title: Australian police say contact made with Sydney siege gunman
summary: Australian police have established contact with the gunman holding hostages in a Sydney cafe, where five hostages have already escaped. The situation remains tense, with the remaining hostages believed to be fewer than 30. The gunman's demands include an Islamic State (IS) flag and the presence of four bombs in the city. Police Commissioner Catherine Burn stated that there is no indication of harm to the remaining hostages, but negotiations are ongoing to resolve the crisis.

site_title: Oil prices plunge to fresh five-year low in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices plummeted to a fresh five-year low in Asian trade, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling 25 cents to $57.56 and Brent crude down one cent to $61.84. OPEC Secretary General Abdalla Salem el-Badri attributed the price drop to speculation, contradicting the common view that it's solely due to a global supply glut. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries maintained its production level despite pleas to cut output, and a two-day US Federal Reserve meeting is expected to be in focus, potentially affecting interest rates and market sentiment.

site_title: Australia revises budget deficit sharply higher
summary: Australia's government revised its budget deficit forecast sharply higher, now predicting a deficit of A$40.4 billion (US$33.2 billion) in the year to June. This is due to falling prices for key resource exports and reduced tax revenue. The revised forecast is A$11.6 billion higher than the May budget, with the 2015/16 shortfall predicted at A$31.2 billion. The delay in releasing the midyear economic and fiscal outlook was caused by a hostage siege in Sydney.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines shares suspended as part of rescue plan
summary: Malaysia Airlines suspended its shares from the Kuala Lumpur stock exchange on December 15, 2014, as part of a government rescue plan. The airline, struggling with losses and two major tragedies (MH370 and MH17) this year, will be taken private by state investment fund Khazanah Nasional, which owns 70% of the carrier. The plan includes a $1.73 billion investment, 6,000 job cuts, and route network reductions. The airline's new CEO, Christoph Mueller, will oversee a turnaround strategy similar to Aer Lingus' under his previous role.

site_title: Singapore November exports seen expanding from year earlier
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports are expected to have grown 3.7% in November from a year earlier, following a 1.5% annual contraction in October. November's forecast is based on a low base, with pharmaceuticals exports recovering from a poor performance in the same month last year. Overseas shipments rose 1.1% seasonally adjusted in October, while manufacturing activity growth slowed in November after a 3-1/2 year expansion.

site_title: Singapore new private home sales fall 48% in November
summary: Singapore's private home sales plummeted 48% in November, with only 412 condominiums sold, compared to October's 412 units. However, executive condominium (EC) sales rose 45% to 1,267 units, driven by new launches such as Lakelife, Bellewaters, and Bellewoods. Chinese developer MCC Land's TRE Residences saw only 52 units sold. The decline in private home sales is attributed to the EC market's growth, with top-selling projects achieving high median prices, exceeding the S$3,000 psf benchmark.

site_title: Hong Kong leader declares Occupy protest 'over' as last site cleared
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam declared an end to the 11-week Occupy protest after police cleared the last remaining camp in Causeway Bay. The protest, which began in September, aimed for universal suffrage in the territory's electoral system. The clearance led to the arrest of a handful of peaceful protesters, causing "serious loss" to the local economy and damaging the rule of law. The episode of illegal occupation activities is now over, according to Lam.

site_title: Japan economy key after Abe landslide: analysts
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe secured a second consecutive term in office after his ruling Liberal Democratic Party and its junior partner Komeito swept the ballot, winning 326 of 475 seats in the lower house of parliament. Analysts warn that Abe must fulfill his promise to fix Japan's economy, which has been a major concern. The coalition's two-thirds majority in the lower house gives them the power to override the upper chamber, allowing them to implement policies without opposition. The outcome is seen as a significant boost to Abe's economic agenda.

site_title: Hong Kong police clear last pro-democracy protest site in retail hub
summary: Hong Kong authorities cleared the last pro-democracy protest site in Causeway Bay, marking the end of demonstration camps that blocked streets for over two months. Police removed barricades, and protesters scrambled to pack up belongings as about 10 people sat in the front line waiting to be arrested. The mainly peaceful protests, which began in November, aimed to demand open nominations in the city's next election for chief executive in 2017. Beijing has refused to grant concessions, and protesters have vowed to consider other forms of civil disobedience.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall for 5th session as oil slumps
summary: Australian shares fell 1% on Monday, led by resources and financials, due to oil price slumps and a hostage siege in Sydney. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 49.9 points to 5,169.60, its fifth straight session of losses. Miners, including Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton, declined as iron ore prices hit five-year lows. Qantas tumbled 6% to A$2.255, while Recall Holdings surged 19% after rejecting a takeover offer.

site_title: Oil slump drags Asian stocks lower, Tokyo leads losses
summary: Asian markets fell Monday as oil prices plummeted, dragging US stocks to their worst losses of the year. Tokyo's Nikkei dropped 1.31% despite Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's re-election, with investors focusing on the faltering Japanese economy. Sydney lost 0.89% amid a hostage crisis, while Shanghai and Seoul also declined. Oil prices sank to a five-year low, benefiting consumers but posing risks to energy companies and banks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 18.85 points to 1715.87, with volume reaching 51.02 million lots. Losers outnumbered gainers 250 to 25.

site_title: Japan big manufacturers' mood worsens slightly in Q4: BOJ tankan
summary: Japanese big manufacturers' sentiment worsened slightly in Q4, with the headline index decreasing by 1 point to plus 12 in December, according to the Bank of Japan's quarterly "tankan" survey. Despite this, corporate spending plans remained strong, with a 8.9% increase in capital spending for the current fiscal year. The survey highlights the uneven recovery brought by Shinzo Abe's stimulus policies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 1.37% lower
summary: Hong Kong shares opened 1.37% lower on Monday, following sharp losses on Wall Street and in Europe. The benchmark Hang Seng Index lost 318.67 points to 22,930.53. This decline is attributed to global market volatility.

site_title: Australia govt postpones budget update amid security scare
summary: Australia's conservative government has postponed the release of a mid-year budget update due to a security alert in Sydney, where hostages are being held in a cafe. The update, scheduled for Monday, will instead be delayed. Treasurer Joe Hockey and Prime Minister Tony Abbott were set to discuss the situation at a news conference. The delay comes amid a hostage crisis in the city's central business district.

images.alt_text: Australia's conservative government said on Monday it had postponed the release of a mid-year budget update due to a security alert in Sydney, where hostages are being held in a cafe in the central business district.

site_title: Singapore's October retail sales up 8.1% driven by motor vehicles
summary: Singapore's retail sales increased 8.1% year-over-year in October, driven by a 44.1% surge in motor vehicle sales. Total retail sales reached S$3.2 billion, up from S$3 billion in October 2013. Motor vehicle sales declined 7.7% from September, but motor vehicle retailers saw a 44.1% increase in sales.

images.alt_text: Retail sales in Singapore increased 8.1 per cent year on year in October, boosted by motor vehicle sales.

site_title: Japan's inbound tourism growth boosts retailers, railroad operators
summary: Japan's inbound tourism has reached a record 11 million from January to October, with tourists spending 1.468 trillion yen, surpassing last year's full-year figure. The weak yen has made Japan cheaper for tourists, boosting companies such as railway operators and retailers like Keisei Electric Railway Co and Oriental Land Co. This trend is expected to continue, with double-digit growth in tourism spending predicted.
