The government's expansion of tax-free items for foreign tourists has also encouraged foreign shoppers, with retailers like Bic Camera Inc. seeing significant sales growth.

images.alt_text: Investors are snapping up Japanese stocks in the retail and transportation sectors, thanks to a weaker yen that has lured a record number of foreign visitors in one of the few bright spots for the economy.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore share prices opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index down 21.87 points to 3,272.27. Volume was 35.6 million shares worth S$51.3 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 81 to 38.

site_title: M1 expresses condolences on death of chairman Teo Soon Hoe
summary: M1 has expressed condolences on the death of its chairman, Teo Soon Hoe, who passed away after nearly two decades of service on the board. Low Huan Ping will serve as acting chairman until a formal appointment is made. M1 praised Teo's 18-year dedication and commitment, citing his instrumental role in the company's growth and transformation into a full-service quad-play provider. The company thanked Teo for his strong leadership and invaluable contributions, describing him as a key figure in charting its strategic directions and business.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Oil & gas-related counters, XMH
summary: Oil prices plummeted to new lows, with Brent crude falling to US$62.75 and US WTI at US$58.80 per barrel, due to lower demand predictions and weaker economic data from China. Oil and gas stocks declined, while transportation-related counters rose due to cheaper fuel costs. XMH Holdings saw a 64.9% decline in Q2 net profit to S$711,000, citing slower sales in the distribution business.

site_title: Vallianz wins US$97m Mid-East charter contract
summary: Vallianz Holdings has secured a US$97 million time charter contract with a Middle Eastern national oil company for a specialized vessel to support oil and gas production from 2015 to 2020. This award strengthens the company's order book to US$626.4 million and reaffirms the oil company's confidence in Vallianz's execution capabilities. CEO Darren Yeo stated that the successful deployment of this vessel will place Vallianz in a favorable position for future contract bids.

site_title: Australia's major banks close Sydney CBD branches due to hostage crisis
summary: Australia's major banks, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Westpac Banking Corp, and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, closed their Sydney CBD branches on December 15, 2014, due to a hostage crisis at a cafe in Martin Place. Police surrounded the cafe, and several people were seen standing with their hands pressed against the windows. The banks cited the police operation as the reason for the closures, which affected 12 Westpac branches in the Sydney CBD.

site_title: Del Monte Q2 profit slumps on acquisition expenses
summary: Del Monte Pacific Limited reported a Q2 net profit of US$185,000, down from US$8.9 million a year ago, due to acquisition-related expenses. The company's turnover reached US$548 million, with US$435.1 million generated by Del Monte Foods, Inc. Acquisition expenses and interest expenses from a long-term loan impacted the bottom line. The company plans to refinance the loan with equity.

site_title: Seoul: Shares hit 2-month low on extended oil plunge; won edges down
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.6% to a 2-month low, driven by a prolonged oil price decline and concerns over deflation risks. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) hit 1,909.99 points, its lowest level since October 17. Investors are cautious ahead of the US Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting, which may signal a potential interest rate hike. The won currency also edged lower, trading at 1,104.3 to the dollar.

site_title: Oil slump drives US drillers to idle the most rigs in 2 years
summary: US oil drillers have idled the most rigs in almost two years due to oil prices below $60 a barrel, with 29 rigs dropped last week to 1,546. Major US producers such as ConocoPhillips and Chevron have curbed spending, deferring investments in North American plays. Domestic production is surging, with new wells in shale formations projected to reach records next month, despite potential delays in major effects until mid-2015.

site_title: Central banks, oil price rout to rule markets in 2015
summary: Global markets are expected to be influenced by differing monetary policies from central banks in 2015, including the US Fed, ECB, and China. The US and Britain are likely to begin raising interest rates, while Japan and China are injecting liquidity to stimulate their economies. A rout in oil prices, which has nearly halved since June, may also impact markets, particularly for European economies struggling with deflation. The divergence in central bank policies could introduce more volatility, and a stronger dollar could hurt emerging markets.

site_title: Australia dollar battered by oil dip, hostage incident, NZ dollar softer
summary: The Australian dollar dropped to 4-1/2-year lows, reaching US$0.8214, due to falling commodity prices and concerns about global growth. A hostage incident in Sydney further weakened sentiment. The New Zealand dollar also edged down to US$0.7754. The Reserve Bank of Australia's mid-year budget update showed a deficit expected to balloon to A$40 billion, while global dairy prices continued to fall.

site_title: Critics, defenders clash over US 'torture report'
summary: The US Senate released a report on the CIA's torture of Al-Qaeda suspects, revealing brutal methods including beatings, waterboarding, and sleep deprivation, which were far more extreme than acknowledged. Former Vice President Dick Cheney defended the program, calling its operators heroes, while critics like Senator John McCain condemned the treatment as wrong. The report questioned the effectiveness of torture methods, concluding they were counterproductive, and raised concerns about the CIA's deliberate misrepresentation of its practices to Congress and the White House.

images.alt_text: Senate Intelligence Chairwoman Dianne Feinstein (center), a Democrat from California, speaks to reporters about the committee's report on CIA interrogations at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, on Dec 9, 2014.Defenders and critics locked horns Sunday over last week's release of a US report that aired harrowing new details of America's torture of "war on terror" detainees, and opened fresh political wounds.

site_title: Kerry, Lavrov meet as tensions soar over Ukraine
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry met with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov in Rome amid tensions over Ukraine, following the passage of a bill authorizing lethal military aid to Ukraine. The meeting came after US lawmakers passed the Ukraine Freedom Support Act, which calls for additional sanctions against Russia and $350 million in military aid to Ukraine. Kerry reiterated the importance of fully implementing the Minsk agreement and de-escalating the situation in Ukraine, while Lavrov warned of a response to US actions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks drop 1.5% after Japan PM secures re-election
summary: Tokyo stocks dropped 1.5% on Monday after Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe secured re-election in a snap poll. The Nikkei 225 index lost 260.09 points to 17,111.49 following sharp drops on Wall Street and the dollar's fall against the yen due to weak US inflation data. Abe's ruling coalition won a major victory, but analysts expect limited market impact. Overseas markets will set the tone for Japanese equities, with US stocks tumbling 1.79% on Friday.

site_title: Air, train links cut as national strike begins in Belgium
summary: A national strike in Belgium began Sunday, affecting air and train links. Both international and domestic flights were cancelled, and train services were suspended from 2100 GMT Sunday through Monday. The strike, which began with a 100,000-person march, is against the government's austerity policies, including plans to scrap a cost-of-living raise and raise the retirement age. The strike will expand to bus, tram, and metro services, as well as schools and government offices, on Monday.

images.alt_text: Both international and domestic air and train links were cut late Sunday in Belgium as a national strike began against the new government's austerity policies, official sources said.

site_title: Swiber makes foray into West African market with US$710m contract
summary: Swiber Holdings has secured a US$710 million contract from a Houston-based oil and gas company to provide EPCIC services for an offshore field development project in West Africa. The project award marks a major leap forward for the group, demonstrating its success in penetrating a new growth market and raising its capabilities to higher-value EPCIC services. Swiber expects completion of the project in the middle of 2017, with the group having clinched contracts totaling US$1.03 billion year-to-date.

images.alt_text: Swiber Holdings has broken into the lucrative West African oil market through a field development award, the group announced on Monday.

site_title: Carlyle, Warburg Pincus in lead to acquire DBRS
summary: A private equity consortium of Carlyle Group LP and Warburg Pincus LLC is in advanced talks to acquire DBRS Ltd, a Canadian credit rating agency, for over $500 million. Carlyle and Warburg Pincus have prevailed in the auction, with a global footprint that could help DBRS expand internationally. DBRS, the world's fourth-largest credit rating agency, rates debt, structured finance products, and financial institutions, and its owner, Walter Schroeder, has hired investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners LP to run the auction.

site_title: Study: China targeting Japan for investments
summary: China has become the world's third largest foreign investor, with its outward investment set to exceed inward investment this year for the first time. China is targeting Japan, acquiring strategic assets and technology to enhance its capabilities. The country's growing investment in Japan comes despite deteriorating diplomatic relations, with Chinese firms seeking to acquire Japanese technology and intellectual property. Experts attribute the surge in Chinese investment in Japan to the government's strategic objectives, with a focus on acquiring technology and intellectual property.

site_title: Eyeing 2015 election, Cameron unveils new house buying scheme
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron unveils the Starter Home initiative, offering 20% discounts to first-time buyers under 40 on 100,000 new homes built on under-used land. The scheme aims to boost economic recovery and increase living standards ahead of the 2015 election, with Cameron citing his government's responsible stewardship of the economy as a key factor. The move is seen as a vote winner, similar to previous Conservative leaders who used home ownership as a key campaign promise.

site_title: Japan short-term home rental market shows promise but rewards slow to come
summary: Japan's short-term home rental market is gaining momentum, driven by a rapidly growing tourism industry, a cheap currency, and 8 million vacant homes. Despite strict current rules, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's reforms aim to loosen curbs, targeting 20 million tourists by the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. Home rental websites like Airbnb have listed thousands of properties, with estimates suggesting the market could be worth around $840 million annually. However, local governments' opposition and vested interests hinder progress, with some businesses already scrapping plans for a short-term rental business.

site_title: Amex renews exclusive deal with Delta Air
summary: American Express has renewed its six-year deal with Delta Air Lines as the carrier's exclusive credit-card issuer, extending the relationship. The agreement, which began in 1996, generates about $2 billion in annual revenue for Delta and accounts for about 5% of Amex's customer card spending. The deal will double benefits to Delta over the next five years and includes removing annual limits on transferring points. This renewal secures Amex's largest airline partnership amid increasing competition among banks and payment networks.

site_title: Pay for top UBS advisers could hit all-time high
summary: UBS Wealth Management America has introduced a revised compensation package that could boost top advisers' overall pay to an all-time high. Advisers who bring in $1 million in assets from one new client or $10 million in net new assets are eligible for a bonus. The revised package also increases the payout for long-term employees, with those who generate $3.5 million or more in revenue able to take home up to 62% of their earnings. The new package is designed to incentivize top advisers to continue producing high revenue.

site_title: Iran hackers may target US energy, defence firms: FBI
summary: The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has warned US businesses to be vigilant for a sophisticated Iranian hacking operation targeting defence contractors, energy firms, and educational institutions. The operation, dubbed Operation Cleaver, has been linked to over 50 victims worldwide, including the US, and may have been larger than initially reported. The hackers typically launch attacks from two IP addresses in Iran, but the FBI did not attribute the attacks to the Tehran government. Iran has denied involvement, but cyber security experts believe the government may be behind the campaign.

site_title: Christmas - a time for giving
summary: Charities in Singapore are actively collecting soft toy donations as Christmas approaches. Food From The Heart, a local charity, is seeking donations to be matched by Ikea, which will double the donation and give out the soft toys as birthday presents. Ikea Singapore is also donating S$2,000 to the charity.

site_title: Oil price slump hurting ECB's stable price plan
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is struggling to achieve stable prices in the eurozone due to a slump in oil prices. The collapse of crude prices to five-year lows will curb inflation in the short term, but in the long term, it could boost growth and reverse stubbornly low inflation. Economists warn that the ECB faces a looming deflation crisis, making it challenging to maintain its core mission of price stability.

site_title: Spain not sliding into deflation: economy minister
summary: Spain's economy minister, Luis de Guindos, stated that the country is not at risk of deflation, despite five consecutive months of falling consumer prices. Falling prices have increased consumption and investment, aiding Spain's economic recovery. The move contrasts with the eurozone's chronically low inflation, which has fueled concerns of deflation. The European Central Bank (ECB) has cut interest rates and offered special measures to combat the risk, with an annual inflation target of 2.0%.

site_title: Hostages held in Sydney cafe, Islamic flag seen in window: local TV
summary: Hostages were being held in a central Sydney cafe, with a black flag with Arabic writing visible in the window, raising fears of an attack linked to Islamic militants. The area was closed off by armed police, with dozens of officers and a SWAT team setting up. Trains and buses were stopped, and roads were blocked as a precaution. The incident occurred in Martin Place, near the Reserve Bank of Australia and commercial banks, and was seen as a high alert situation due to Australia's involvement in the US-led action against Islamic State in Syria and Iraq.

site_title: French mall battered by consumer spending crisis
summary: A French mall, Le Millenaire, faced significant financial struggles due to the 2008 US credit and housing crisis. Construction began in 2008, but the project was severely impacted, with the mall eventually being completed at a lower cost than initially planned.

site_title: Thai academic sees GE in mid-2016
summary: A Thai academic, Pornchai Trakulwaranont, suggests that Thailand may not have a new general election until mid-2016 due to a possible referendum on a new constitution. The drafting of the constitution is expected to be completed by mid-2015, with a potential three-month referendum followed by three to four months of reviewing and modifying the draft charter. This timeline could delay the general election, potentially pushing it to mid-2016.

site_title: Italy's family firms endure crisis better, but governance remains a challenge
summary: Italian family firms proved more resilient to the economic crisis, with a 58% decrease in number compared to non-family businesses, and a higher propensity for internationalisation processes, providing over 75% of all foreign direct investment (FDI) by Italian large and medium-sized companies. However, despite their resilience, family firms showed a high turnover rate, with 60% of businesses having been on the market since 2007. Governance remains a challenge, with concentrated ownership and limited leadership structure hindering expansion and integration of non-family managers.

site_title: United Technologies seeking largest deal yet to spur sales
summary: United Technologies CEO Gregory Hayes is seeking the largest deal in the company's history, considering acquisitions over $20 billion, to boost share value despite a challenging growth environment. Hayes also plans to increase share repurchases by up to $3 billion and review portfolio changes, including selling off key business units. The company's lagging performance in 2014, with a 1.4% stock decline, is attributed to headwinds in several business units, including a slowdown in China's Otis elevator business and commercial-building sales in Europe.

site_title: Where's the price floor? Check the contango
summary: Traders are shifting focus from Opec policy and interest rates to a potential price floor in the oil market. A deep contango, where immediate delivery prices are cheaper than futures, is seen as a leading indicator of a price floor. This could provide support to the market as traders buy crude to put into storage, potentially stabilizing prices. However, the contango is not a guarantee, and its sustainability is uncertain.

images.alt_text: Oil traders searching frantically for an end to the deepest price rout since the 2008 financial crisis should forget about Opec policy, US drilling rigs or interest rates. At least for the moment.

site_title: Facebook dumps Bing search results
summary: Facebook has stopped including search results from Microsoft's Bing search engine on its social networking site, as part of a revamped search tool that focuses on helping users find information shared within the platform. This move comes as Facebook prioritizes its own search technology and follows the company's increasing emphasis on web search technology. The decision may reflect Facebook's growing importance in the market, with over 1.35 billion users, and its efforts to replace the need to search the web for answers.

site_title: Conglomerate Libra bets on upturn, ramps up purchases of boxships
summary: Global conglomerate Libra is increasing its purchase of container ships, betting on a sector recovery and lower oil prices. CEO George Logothetis said the drop in marine fuel prices will save owners millions of dollars annually. Libra's shipping arm, Lomar, has been buying small container ships, while leading container groups replace older vessels with mega-ships. The company expects to end 2014 with 74 vessels, including 50 container ships, and plans to buy more in 2015.

site_title: Companies Act reform - impact on directors
summary: The Companies (Amendment) Act 2014 has introduced amendments affecting directors' appointment, scope, and disqualification. The aim is to improve corporate governance and promote business flexibility. Key changes include changes to directors' life cycle, duties, and financial dealings. The reforms also provide more flexibility for companies to appoint and manage directors, with a focus on improving overall corporate governance.

site_title: Most Germans think govt not taking immigration concerns seriously enough
summary: Most Germans, 65%, believe Chancellor Angela Merkel's government is not taking sufficient action on immigration and asylum-seekers, despite record levels of immigration. The concern has led to weekly marches in Dresden under the slogan Pegida, with some participants believing Germany is undergoing a process of "Islamisation". Merkel has condemned the marches and recent arson attacks, stating there's "no place in Germany" for hatred of Muslims or any other group. The government argues that immigration is necessary to address a chronic shortage of skilled labor, but local officials struggle to cope with the influx of asylum-seekers.

site_title: US rate hike not all bad for Singapore
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates in 2015, which may benefit Singapore's economy due to stronger US demand. However, domestic constraints, sluggish growth in the EU and China, and a potential property market slowdown may offset these benefits. Economists predict a rapid transmission of US rate hikes to Singapore, with a possible increase in the 3-month SIBOR rate, but some experts believe the impact will be moderate and limited to the property market. Singapore's services activity and non-oil domestic exports are expected to grow, despite the potential challenges posed by higher interest rates.

site_title: Aggressive lobbying of state and local officials pays off for Uber
summary: Uber successfully lobbied state and local officials in Virginia, resulting in a reprieve from a cease-and-desist order. The company mobilized thousands of supporters to pressure government officials, and its high-powered lobbyists influenced lawmakers. This approach has been repeated in 17 cities and states across the US, allowing Uber to expand its operations and upend traditional taxi regulations. The company has also assembled a lobbying empire, employing 161 registered lobbyists and spending millions on lobbying efforts. Uber's CEO Travis Kalanick has praised the company's ability to inspire its base and shape new regulations, with former White House adviser David Plouffe leading the effort.

images.alt_text: Uber has asserted its strength in recent months through a combination of new-age tactics that portray the company as a social movement to be embraced by its faithful and old-school lobbying more typical for a business seeking to avoid government interference.

site_title: After a tragic year, can Malaysia Airlines get its act together?
summary: Malaysia Airlines has exited the Malaysian stock market after 30 years, citing financial struggles and a painful downward spiral since the Asian financial crisis. The carrier's exit is attributed to the loss of 537 lives in two recent tragedies and years of losses. A 12-point "recovery plan" has been implemented, involving RM6 billion in funding and the privatization of the airline. A new company, Malaysia Airlines Berhad, will be established, with Christoph Mueller as CEO, aiming to return to profitability within three years and relist on the stock market within three to five years.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: China's trust insurance fund to start with 40b yuan
summary: China is set to launch a 40 billion yuan ($8.5 billion) trust insurance fund, the first of its kind, aimed at reducing risk in the country's shadow banking sector. The fund, managed by the China Banking and Regulatory Commission, will require trust firms to contribute 1% of their net assets and trust products to pay 1% of raised money. The fund will be used for liquidation and restructuring of companies, not compensation for investors. It will also help separate risk in the industry from the government and digest individual trust risks.

site_title: New FAA rules may hit recreational drone flyers
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is expected to propose new rules governing small unmanned aircraft systems, including restrictions on hundreds of thousands of recreational drone flyers. The new regulations, which could take a year to implement, may require flyers to join a community-based model aircraft organization or obtain FAA authorization. The rules are aimed at addressing concerns about reckless drone flying near airports and military bases, with the FAA documenting over 190 close calls. Experts predict that the new regulations will require hobbyists to follow safety guidelines and may require a license to fly.

site_title: Investors see better private equity returns, shun hedge funds: survey
summary: Investors are becoming increasingly optimistic about private equity, with 93% expecting annual net returns of over 11% from their portfolios over 3-5 years. In contrast, 33% plan to decrease hedge fund allocations following poor performance. The survey also shows investors are shifting focus to Asia, particularly excluding Japan and India, and Latin America for returns. This optimism contrasts with concerns about a major economic downturn within five years and deflation in the euro zone, with half of investors expecting a downturn.

images.alt_text: Investors are optimistic about private equity, but reconsidering their allocations to hedge funds, a survey showed on Monday.

site_title: Rising market drives Chinese investors into a frenzy despite many warnings
summary: Hundreds of thousands of Chinese investors are investing in the stock market, driving up prices in a borrowing-fueled frenzy despite warnings of heightened risks. The Shanghai Composite Index has soared 20% since a surprise interest rate cut in November, its biggest one-day fall in five years. Despite the market's volatility, investors are piling in, fueled by the rally.

site_title: US corporate leaders defend Treasury nominee against congressional critics
summary: US corporate leaders, including Morgan Stanley's James Gorman and BlackRock's Laurence Fink, have endorsed Antonio Weiss, a Lazard banker, as the undersecretary for domestic finance. They argue that Weiss has deep financial expertise and will promote growth and shared prosperity. However, seven senators have criticized Weiss for his Wall Street experience and work on corporate tax inversions. The Treasury nominees' supporters, including four former undersecretaries, say Weiss's eight years of work in Europe and his experience negotiating complex financing deals make him qualified for the position.

site_title: What banks can find out from consumers' credit reports
summary: Credit Bureau Singapore executive director William Lim explains that banks can use credit reports to differentiate between payment oversights and distressed debt, as well as track credit enquiries and balance transfers. The reports also show secured and unsecured debts, and "needs-based" loans. However, banks calculate loan eligibility based on income, not credit reports alone. With 13,000 credit reports issued monthly, banks can monitor credit behavior and make informed lending decisions. A default on a credit report remains on a consumer's record forever unless negotiated, serving as an early warning of bankruptcy.

site_title: XMH Holdings' Q2 net down 65%, group upbeat on Vietnam
summary: XMH Holdings, a Singapore-based diesel engine provider, reported a 64.9% drop in net profit to S$711,000 for the second quarter, due to slower sales in the distribution business. Revenue slipped 28.9% to S$19.23 million. Despite this, the company sees positive trends in Vietnam, with increased deliveries and new orders, and expects the market to do well as the country expands its fishing fleet. The group's subsidiary MPG is on track to deliver its best year ever, driven by strong demand for standby generator sets.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: EU looks set to free up dairy sector amid greater demand
summary: The EU is poised to free up the dairy sector, 30 years after introducing quotas to combat overproduction. Global demand for milk products has driven this shift. To manage market fluctuations, Euronext plans to create futures contracts for several dairy products. The EU remains the world's top dairy producer and second-largest exporter, despite the quota system. This move aims to balance producer interests with growing global demand.

site_title: BT Group faces luxury of choice in mobile comeback
summary: BT Group is considering a mobile comeback with Britain's two biggest wireless providers competing for its attention. The company may reach exclusive talks with either Telefonica or a joint venture between Deutsche Telekom and Orange, potentially leading to lower prices and more favorable terms. BT's expansion plan could lead to consolidation in the UK market, with other carriers considering their options, including Vodafone's potential combination with Liberty Global. A deal could help BT sell fuller service packages and retain customers, while Telefonica seeks to repay debt and Orange aims to maintain its ratings.

site_title: Tories vow to create northern powerhouse ahead of polls
summary: The UK government, led by Chancellor George Osborne, aims to create a "northern powerhouse" by turning a string of cities in the north into economic hubs. This promise is seen as an effort to bridge the gap between the north and London, where the majority of Britain's economic prosperity is concentrated. The goal is to spread prosperity beyond the capital, creating jobs and stimulating growth in the region.

images.alt_text: Mr Osborne speaking at the opening of the Manchester City Football Academy in north England last week. The Conservative government is seen wooing northern voters by promising to spread prosperity far beyond London.

site_title: Unhedged US shale drillers bear brunt of oil slide
summary: US shale drillers who heavily hedged future production are bearing the brunt of the oil slide, with some companies, like Continental Resources, facing significant losses after lifting hedges at low prices. In contrast, more aggressive hedgers like Devon Energy Corp are better positioned, with the company potentially netting an extra $1.3 billion in revenue if oil prices remain at $65 a barrel. The industry's mid-sized producers, which often pursued varied hedging strategies, are now facing the prospect of lower revenues for months to come.

site_title: Re-hiring up to age 67 to be made law by 2017
summary: Singapore's Minister of Manpower Tan Chuan-Jin announced plans to re-employ workers up to age 67 by 2017, amid concerns that the local labor force participation rate will plateau due to demographic factors starting from 2020. The move aims to address productivity issues, as the retirement age will be extended and the labor force participation rate increases. Tan also discussed possible changes to the Central Provident Fund (CPF) system, including varying minimum sums for different groups and stream of payouts that increase with inflation.

images.alt_text: LEGISLATION on the re-employment of older workers up to the age of 67 will be introduced by 2017, said Minister of Manpower Tan Chuan-Jin, as reported by Channel News Asia.

site_title: 190 nations agree on building blocks for new 2015 climate deal
summary: 190 nations agreed on a new global climate deal in Lima, setting a March 2015 deadline for governments to submit plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The deal, part of a 2015 Paris summit, aims to combat climate change and limit global temperature increases. Emerging economies like China and India were appeased by the compromise, while rich nations like the US supported the move. The agreement marks a shift from the 1997 Kyoto Protocol, which only bound rich countries to cut emissions.

site_title: Ambitious Qatar Airways expands fleet, fuelling its push into Europe
summary: Qatar Airways is set to expand its fleet with the delivery of its first A350 XWB next-generation plane from Airbus on Dec 22, marking the airline's push into European markets. With orders for 80 of the planes, Qatar Airways is the largest single customer of the A350. The airline's expansion reflects the Gulf states' efforts to diversify their economies and reduce dependence on oil. Qatar Airways has also ordered 100 Boeing 777X aircraft and has total orders for over 340 aircraft worth US$70 billion, making it a major player in the airline industry.

site_title: US life insurers avoiding up to US$100b in federal taxes
summary: US life insurers are saving up to $100 billion in federal taxes by exploiting loopholes in state laws, which allow them to reduce sharply the reserves they are required to hold. Companies like TransAmerica Life Insurance Co. use complex accounting maneuvers to report their reserves as unchanged, avoiding federal taxes. This practice, known as "shadow insurance," has been criticized by New York's financial services superintendent, who is appealing to Washington to block the practice, citing financial risk and unfair tax avoidance.

site_title: Takata tightens screws on suppliers: sources
summary: Takata Corp has tightened quality controls on suppliers to boost production of airbags recalled for a potentially deadly defect. The company, under investigation by US regulators and lawmakers, has launched "urgent" inspections across its supply network and dispatched managers to parts makers in Japan and Asia. This move comes after millions of airbags were recalled globally due to exploding airbags causing five deaths.

site_title: Stay close to STI and its components for now
summary: Singapore stocks may be affected by the recent US market decline, as the correlation between local blue chips and the MSCI World Index was previously only 55%. The S&P 500 fell 3.5% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 3.8% last week, prompting concerns about a potential decoupling. Despite this, few US analysts are panicking, expecting a rebound soon, and Singapore's STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Thousands march to protest against killings of black men by police officers
summary: Thousands of demonstrators marched in Washington, New York, and Boston on December 14, 2014, to protest against the killings of unarmed black men by police officers. The marches, part of a global wave of protests, highlighted the issue of race relations in the US. The event drew attention to the deaths of black men, including Michael Brown in Ferguson and Eric Garner in New York, sparking widespread outrage and calls for reform. The marches were among the largest in recent times, demonstrating a growing movement against police brutality and racial inequality in the US.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators marching against police violence in Manhattan, New York on Saturday. The deaths of unarmed black men have cast a global spotlight on race relations in the United States.

site_title: Tips from financial veterans
summary:
Notable investment experts, including John Bogle, Burton Malkiel, Mark Mobius, Mario Gabelli, and others, shared their views on investing in the article. Key takeaways include: 

Investors should focus on the US market, which is the most productive and rapidly growing of industrialized nations, despite its problems. Emerging markets have great potential but come with fragile sovereigns and institutions. 

Bogle recommends investing in a broad market index, such as the S&P 500, and a bond index. Malkiel emphasizes the importance of low fees, as they directly impact investment returns. 

Mobius suggests diversifying into emerging markets, particularly those with strong companies, and avoiding the "home country bias." Gabelli advises against chasing fads and instead focuses on cash-generating companies. 

All experts agree that investors should adopt a long-term perspective, avoid making emotional decisions, and prioritize education on personal finance.

site_title: Homestyle cuisine in hipster haunts
summary: Two traditional Chinese eateries, Jing Hua Xiao Chi and Joyden Canton Kitchen, have successfully adapted to modern surroundings in upscale malls, offering homestyle cuisine to hipster crowds. Jing Hua Xiao Chi serves classic dishes like xiao long bao and guo tie, while Joyden Canton Kitchen offers a range of homey fare, including soya sauce chicken and Hakka braised pork belly. Despite not reaching high dining heights, the eateries' presence is a welcome one, providing a grounded and familiar dining experience. Both restaurants have received a rating of 6.5.

site_title: Bank of Singapore set to notch record growth of up to 15%
summary: Bank of Singapore is expected to post a record growth of up to 15% in 2014, with assets under management (AUM) reaching US$52-53 billion, according to outgoing CEO Renato de Guzman. This would be a significant increase from 2013's US$46 billion AUM. De Guzman attributed the strong growth to the bank's ability to "improvise" and upgrade service levels to clients, following the departure of key staff. The bank's profitability is also expected to be record-high, with a cost-to-income ratio below the industry average.

site_title: Badri says Opec has no target price, recommends more oil investment
summary: Opec Secretary-General Abdullah al-Badri said Gulf countries should continue to invest in oil exploration and production despite low oil prices to prevent future price hikes. He stated that Opec has no target price for crude, and the US will continue to rely on Middle East oil for years. Following an Opec meeting, the group left output ceilings unchanged. Badri's comments come as oil prices hit a five-year low.

site_title: Stock losses likely to mount this week
summary: Stocks have incurred their largest weekly loss since 2011 due to concerns over the US economy's response to low oil prices. Investors fear the oil bust could destabilize other sectors or trigger another financial crisis, similar to the 2008 US housing slump. The Federal Reserve's hints of rate hikes may further exacerbate losses, unless it retreats from its stance.

site_title: Telkom to lead US$24b broadband expansion in Indonesia
summary: State-owned telecom firm PT Telekomunikasi Indonesia Tbk will lead a $24 billion expansion of Indonesia's broadband capacity over the next five years. Only 12% of the population had access to mobile broadband last year, and fixed line broadband access was even lower at 5%. The government is considering incentives for Telkom to improve Internet access in South-east Asia's largest economy, which could boost the nascent e-commerce market. The government is also discussing new regulations for the telecom industry to deal with consolidation and expects the number of telecom operators to halve to four in the next decade.

site_title: Hailo sees its track record giving it an edge here
summary: Hailo, a London-based taxi-booking app, launched in Singapore in October, aiming to replicate its success in other cities. The company, which has carried over 30 million passengers worldwide, is banking on its track record to outcompete rivals Uber, GrabTaxi, and Easy Taxi. Hailo's strategy involves introducing its service and technical expertise to improve the taxi experience in Singapore. The company has already secured tie-ups with major fleets and plans to expand its service to other major cities in Southeast Asia, including Hong Kong and Seoul.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Buying among directors, companies soars, selling remains low
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

In Singapore, director buying surged in the past week, with 26 companies making 50 purchases worth S$6.5 million, while selling remained low for the sixth straight week. Notable buys include Keppel Corp's chairman Lee Boon Yang and SATS Limited's CEO Alexander Charles Hungate, while rare director purchases were made in Rotary Engineering, Oxley Holdings, Halcyon Agri Corp, and Ezion Holdings. Meanwhile, Jason Holdings' project director Nelson Sim Choon Joo sold shares, reducing his holdings by 19%. The buys and sells reflect market sentiment, with some companies benefiting from share price drops.

site_title: China, Kazakhstan to sign US$10b in deals including oil, infrastructure: Xinhua
summary: China and Kazakhstan are set to sign 30 cooperative agreements worth $10 billion, including oil and infrastructure deals, during Premier Li Keqiang's visit to Kazakhstan from December 14 to 20. The agreements aim to increase interconnectivity between the two countries and boost trade, with annual growth rates of 20%. China is Kazakhstan's second-largest trade partner, while Kazakhstan is China's second-largest in the Commonwealth of Independent States.

site_title: Keppel Corp stalwart Teo Soon Hoe, 65, dies
summary: Keppel Corp stalwart Teo Soon Hoe, 65, has died after a six-month battle with cancer. A long-time executive with nearly four decades of service, Teo spent his career with the conglomerate, rising through the ranks from 1975 to 2011 as group finance director. He continued to serve as a nominee director for various Keppel subsidiaries after his retirement in June.

site_title: Could 2015 see the end of Ebola as a killer?
summary: A global emergency in 2014 brought Ebola to the forefront, killing thousands and prompting a scramble for treatments and vaccines. Scientists are hopeful that experimental medications may prove effective, with a dozen candidates being developed. The World Health Organization expects the epidemic to be under control within a year, but warns that the virus will continue to survive in animal reservoirs. Experts emphasize that improvements in medical infrastructure and infection control measures are also crucial in preventing future outbreaks.

site_title: Abe secures extended mandate for policies in low turnout election
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe secured an extended mandate for his policies in a low-turnout election, with his ruling Liberal Democratic Party and coalition partner winning a commanding majority in the lower house of parliament. The coalition secured over 317 seats, giving them a joint two-thirds "super majority" to override opposition. Abe's victory will allow him to push ahead with his Abenomics policies without interruption until the next lower house election in 2018. The election saw a record low voter turnout, with only around 35% of voters casting ballots, nearly 7 percentage points below the previous record.

site_title: China's e-cigarette boom lacks oversight for safety
summary: China's e-cigarette industry lacks oversight, with hundreds of manufacturers operating with little regulation. The country produces about 90% of the world's e-cigarettes, with some factories producing components in just hours. Despite concerns over safety, some manufacturers claim to follow quality control standards, but experts say flawed or sloppy manufacturing could account for hazardous compounds. The US FDA has just begun to regulate e-cigarettes, but analysts say setting rules could take years, allowing Chinese factories to build profits before regulatory scrutiny arrives.

site_title: Pockets of risk - 1 in 5 cardholders in Singapore pays just the minimum sum
summary: In Singapore, 1 in 5 credit-cardholders pay only the minimum sum, while women aged 30 and above are more likely to miss payments than men, despite overall delinquency rates being lower than the Sars period in 2003. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) notes that while the consumer credit situation remains sound, a small group of borrowers have incurred unsustainable debts. Credit Counselling Singapore (CCS) expects more distressed debtors, with 64% of cardholders paying in full each month, and 22% revolving their debt.

site_title: Yen has best week in 16 months as oil slump fuels refuge demand
summary: The yen experienced its largest weekly gain in 16 months, rising 2.3% against the dollar, driven by the decline in oil prices and market contagion. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index fell 0.2% to 1,115.76, while the yen strengthened 0.5% to 118.05 per dollar, its highest level since August 2013. Investors are rethinking the Federal Reserve's possible interest rate hike amid declining inflation expectations.

site_title: Abe re-elected easily despite low turnout in Japan polls
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe won re-election with a comfortable majority, despite a low turnout, in a snap poll that may cast doubt on the endorsement of his economic policies, known as "Abenomics." Abe's ruling party secured a two-thirds majority, giving them the power to override the upper house. The election outcome follows the success of Abe's economic policies, including a plunge in the yen and rise in stocks, but also a recession triggered by a sales tax rise. The low turnout has raised questions about the legitimacy of the endorsement.

site_title: Alleged UK hacking of Belgian telco was far-reaching: reports
summary: Belgium's Belgacom telecoms firm was allegedly hacked by the British spy agency GCHQ in 2011, resulting in the interception of communications from clients of hundreds of international telecoms providers. The hack went undetected for over two years, with the malicious software, known as "Regin", being one of the most advanced spy tools identified by security researchers. The breach was discovered in 2013, when Belgacom improved security and removed a virus from its systems, but the full extent of the intrusion was only revealed through leaked documents and interviews with sources.

site_title: Xiaomi's India smartphone ban exposes wider patent risk
summary: A court order in India has banned Xiaomi from selling its smartphones in the country due to a patent infringement case filed by Ericsson. The ban, which will last until February 5, has halted Xiaomi's rapid expansion into the world's fastest-growing smartphone market. The decision could be the start of a string of patent challenges for Xiaomi, which has already acknowledged its vulnerability to intellectual property disputes. The ban is a setback for Xiaomi's growth prospects in India, where the smartphone market is expected to continue growing despite the ban.

site_title: Oil prices extend collapse; gold gains
summary: Global oil prices hit a five-year low, falling to $57.34 per barrel for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate and $61.35 per barrel for Brent North Sea crude. The decline is attributed to plentiful supplies, a stronger dollar, and weak demand due to the struggling global economy. In contrast, gold prices rose to $1,217 an ounce, supported by deteriorating risk appetite and a weaker US dollar. European stock markets also slumped due to the oil price collapse, while US retail sales data reinforced investor confidence in the US economy.

site_title: Wall St scores a win in Washington, eyes more victories
summary: Wall Street has secured several victories in its lobbying efforts against the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial reform law. The US House of Representatives included provisions easing a Dodd-Frank rule and exempting "end-user" businesses from collateral requirements for certain risky trades. The Senate is likely to pass these bills, despite opposition from Democrats who view the measures as bank handouts. The Dodd-Frank rollback is seen as a sign that Wall Street's lobbying efforts will continue, with potential future victories including changes to the asset threshold for big banks and the bankruptcy code.

site_title: Fund manager issues warning on surge in developed nation debt
summary: Developed economies' debt has surged by $66 trillion to $102.7 trillion between 2000 and 2013, outpacing GDP growth of $17 trillion. Emerging markets' debt has also increased, with outstanding government and corporate debt rising by $12 trillion to $14.5 trillion. Despite this, emerging market debt fears are overstated, with 86% of EM fixed income in local currency. However, experts warn that the shift to market financing and rising interest costs pose financial stability risks, particularly for countries like Russia and China, which are vulnerable to currency devaluation.

site_title: Sunseap wins biggest HDB solar leasing tender
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has awarded its largest solar leasing tender to Sunseap Leasing Pte Ltd, with 38 megawatts of solar energy to be installed at 680 HDB blocks and three HDB-owned commercial properties. The tender was announced on October 27 and attracted seven tenderers. This is the largest solar leasing tender awarded by HDB to date.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Eight dead, 100 missing in Indonesian landslide: official
summary: A landslide in Jemblung village, central Java, Indonesia, has killed at least eight people and left 100 missing. The landslide, triggered by torrential downpours, buried scores of houses and mud covered hillsides and roads. Rescuers are struggling to reach the area due to tough conditions and lack of phone signal. The national disaster agency is coordinating the search efforts, which involve 200 rescuers and 500 volunteers. Landslides are common in Indonesia during the rainy season, affecting around half of the country's 250 million population.

site_title: Gulf stocks reel on sliding oil prices
summary: Gulf stocks plummeted on Sunday, with Dubai's benchmark index slumping 7.6% and Abu Dhabi's down 3.6%, as oil prices hit new lows. The decline was attributed to a 50% drop in oil prices since June, with the International Energy Agency slashing its 2015 demand outlook. The region's energy-rich states, which rely heavily on oil revenues, saw market leaders such as Emaar Properties and Arabtec Properties shed significant value.

site_title: Dutchman tries to pop question, destroys house
summary: A Dutchman attempted to propose to his girlfriend by having a crane lower him into her garden. However, the crane fell through the neighbor's roof, causing damage to the house. Fortunately, the would-be groom escaped unharmed, and no one else was hurt. The girlfriend accepted the proposal despite the chaotic circumstances, and the couple went on holiday to Paris. Authorities will assess the damage to the house after the crane is lifted.

site_title: China's Tencent wins approval to start banking business
summary: China's Tencent Holdings Ltd has received approval to start its banking operations, becoming the first private bank to open to clients. As part of China's efforts to channel loans to small businesses, Tencent's private bank, Webank, will focus on loans to individuals and small enterprises. The bank has a registered capital of 3 billion yuan and will officially start operations on Dec. 28. This marks a gradual opening of China's banking sector, which is currently dominated by state giants, following the approval of over 10 private lenders in recent months.

site_title: Record number of China-bound supertankers hints of stockpiling
summary: A record 83 supertankers are bound for Chinese ports, transporting 166 million barrels of oil, amid signs of China stockpiling due to the oil-price crash. The International Energy Agency suggests China may have added to its strategic crude stockpiles last month. Daily shipping rates on the Middle East to Asia route have surged to $83,605, the highest since 2010, and analysts expect VLCC rates to rise to $35,000 a day in 2015. China's strategic petroleum reserve needs to buy at least 50 million barrels more crude in 2015, potentially raising total inventories to 100 million barrels.

site_title: US Senate passes spending bill, ends govt shutdown threat
summary: The US Senate passed a $1.1 trillion spending bill, ending the government shutdown threat. The 56-40 vote sends the measure to President Barack Obama, who is expected to sign it into law before federal spending authority expires. The bill funds most government agencies through September 2015, but Republicans insisted on a shorter funding extension for the Department of Homeland Security. The legislation also includes provisions that weaken the Dodd-Frank financial reform law and ease deportations for undocumented immigrants.

site_title: Changing semantics of a rate hike
summary: The US Federal Reserve is set to discuss a potential rate hike at its meeting this week, with officials hinting at a change in language from "considerable time" to convey a more patient approach. The Fed has been closely watched for guidance on future rate hikes, with some analysts predicting a rate increase as early as March. The change in language is seen as a key factor, with most expecting the Fed to adopt a more patient stance on rate hikes, similar to its approach in 2004. This shift could impact global markets and economies.

site_title: Hong Kong left deeply polarised by protests
summary: Hong Kong's two-month pro-democracy protest occupation ended with the demolition of the main protest camp, but the city remains deeply divided. The protests, which began in late September, called for free leadership elections in 2017 and were the biggest challenge to Beijing's authority since 1997. The protests have sparked a passionate and volatile polarisation, with analysts predicting future confrontations between pro-democracy activists and the city's leadership, who have refused to make concessions. Beijing is unlikely to employ harsh tactics, instead opting for a longer game through softer means, such as influencing education in the city.

site_title: XMH Holdings Q2 net profit down 64.9%
summary: XMH Holdings reported a 64.9% decline in net profit to S$711,000 for Q2 2014, driven by slower sales in its distribution business. Revenue dropped 28.9% to S$19.23 million. Earnings per share fell to 0.16 cents, while the net asset value per share decreased to 12.54 cents. The stock price closed at 27 cents, down 1.5 cents. The company attributed the decline to reduced sales.

site_title: Why US women are leaving their jobs for their families
summary: US women are leaving their jobs to care for their families, a trend that has led to a decline in workforce participation. Since 1999, the percentage of working women in the US has fallen from 74% to 69%. In contrast, many European countries have seen an increase in women's labor force participation. A recent poll found that 61% of non-working women cited family responsibilities as a reason for not working, while 37% of men did so. Women are more likely to want flexible work arrangements, such as working from home, and are more satisfied with not working. However, the US lacks family-friendly policies, which may contribute to the decline in women's workforce participation.

site_title: Canadian Christmas tree exports to rise: minister
summary: Canada's trade minister predicts a rise in Christmas tree exports this season due to a reported shortage in the US. The US National Christmas Tree Association reports a 38% increase in American Christmas tree purchases, with 33 million trees bought last year. Canada is the world's largest exporter of Christmas trees, shipping over 1.5 million worth C$28 million in 2013. The shortage in the US is attributed to dwindling tree farms, severe weather, and increased demand.

images.alt_text: Canada's trade minister on Friday predicted a rise in Christmas tree exports this season, amid reported shortages in the United States.

site_title: US: Oil slump leads Wall St to worst week in 2-1/2 years
summary: US stocks fell sharply on Friday, marking the worst weekly performance since May 2012, due to the oil slump and weak Chinese data. The S&P 500 dropped 3.5% for the week, with the energy sector down 2.2% and Exxon Mobil and Chevron Corp hitting 52-week lows. Despite strong US consumer sentiment, investors pulled back from the markets, with the CBOE Volatility Index rising 5% to 21.08.

site_title: Sunseap Leasing wins largest solar leasing tender from HDB
summary: Housing & Development Board (HDB) has awarded its largest solar leasing tender to Sunseap Leasing Pte Ltd, a 38-megawatt solar energy project. The tender, announced in October, attracted seven tenderers and will install solar photovoltaic systems at 680 HDB residential blocks and three commercial properties. This is the first tender with the full cost borne by the solar developer, with HDB funding no upfront costs. The project could generate enough electricity for 14,000 units of four-room flats and marks HDB's 54 MWp of solar PV procurement to date.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Korean Air chief purser in nut row says insulted, forced to kneel
summary: Korean Air Lines' chief purser, Park Chang-jin, claims he was insulted and forced to kneel by airline executive Heather Cho after she reprimanded him for serving her macadamia nuts on a flight. Cho, the daughter of the airline's chairman, allegedly swore at Park, jabbed him with a file case, and pointed a finger at him while he was kneeling. Cho has been stripped of titles and faces investigation for breaching aviation laws. The incident sparked public outrage and ridicule in South Korea, where powerful family-run conglomerates are common.

site_title: Job losses as 175 Australian govt agencies face scrap: reports
summary: Australia's government plans to scrap around 175 government agencies, including Antarctic science and drought-related services, as part of its efforts to reduce waste and size. The move is expected to lead to further job losses, with Finance Minister Mathias Cormann stating that the goal is to ensure the government is "as big as it needs to be but as small as it can be." The abolition of agencies is part of the government's broader efforts to sell off assets and reduce the deficit, with a potential blowout of A$5 billion in the mid-year economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Australia's government warned of further job losses Saturday as media reports said around 175 government agencies working in areas as diverse as Antarctic science and drought will be scrapped.

site_title: Thai flight forced to return by unruly Chinese passengers
summary: A Thai AirAsia flight was forced to return to Bangkok after a Chinese passenger threw hot water at a cabin attendant. The flight, carrying 174 passengers, was on a route from Bangkok to Nanjing when the incident occurred. The captain decided to return to Bangkok, where four Chinese passengers were detained and fined by police. The cabin attendant received first aid and was fine. The flight departed again and arrived in Nanjing the next day, with the Chinese passengers leaving the country on the same day.

site_title: Japan heads to polls with Abe on course to retain power
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is on course to retain power after a general election, with his ruling Liberal Democratic Party and junior partner Komeito expected to sweep the ballot. Opinion polls predict the coalition will secure over 300 of the 475 contested seats, giving them a super-majority needed to force through legislation. Abe's "Abenomics" economic policy is likely to be given a mandate, with polls showing the premier's coalition will add a couple of dozen more seats to its tally. Turnout is expected to be a record low due to heavy snow in some areas.

images.alt_text: Voters began casting ballots in Japan on Sunday for a general election likely to return Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to power, and billed as a referendum on his economic policy.

site_title: Kocherlakota to step down from Minneapolis Fed in 2016 Dec 12
summary: Narayana Kocherlakota, president of the Minneapolis Federal Reserve, announced his decision to step down in 2016, citing the "state of crisis" that faced the economy as having passed. He took the job in 2009 to help deal with the economic emergency and has been a strong advocate for accommodative policy. Kocherlakota dissented against the Fed's October policy decision and will not seek reappointment. His term expires on February 29, 2016, and his vote at the next policy meeting will be his last.

site_title: Belgium strike to ground all flights
summary: All flights to and from Belgium will be grounded for 24 hours starting from late Sunday due to a nationwide strike by air traffic controllers against the government's austerity policies. The strike, organized by the CSC union, aims to protest plans to save 11 billion euros over five years. The strike will affect flights at six airports, but planes flying over Belgium at high altitudes will not be impacted. The strike is part of a series of disturbances that began with a 100,000-person march in Brussels last month.

site_title: China's Xi says Nanjing Massacre undeniable on 77th anniversary
summary: President Xi Jinping marked the 77th anniversary of the Nanjing Massacre, stating that no one can deny the event. A national day of remembrance was held in Nanjing, with 10,000 people attending the ceremony, including survivors in their 90s. Xi called the massacre undeniable, warning those who deny it will be denied by history. China has officially recognized the anniversary, which was previously marked only by the Communist Party-controlled legislature. The "Rape of Nanking" remains a sensitive issue between China and Japan, with China accusing Japan of failing to atone for the atrocity.

site_title: US Senate delays vote on US$1.1 trillion spending bill
summary: The US Senate has delayed a vote on a $1.1 trillion spending bill, with a stop-gap measure expected to be passed on Saturday to temporarily extend government funding through next Wednesday. The House of Representatives has already passed a similar measure. The delay will keep federal agencies operating beyond midnight Saturday, when existing funds expire. The Senate aims to pass the spending bill on Monday.

site_title: Italy's Renzi proposes tougher corruption laws amid Rome scandal
summary: Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi proposed tougher corruption laws, extending minimum and maximum prison sentences by two years to six and 10 years, respectively. The measures aim to increase accountability for corruption, allowing for easier confiscation of assets and property from convicted individuals. The proposal follows a Rome scandal involving a mafia-like group offering bribes to officials, with 37 people arrested and dozens under investigation, including former officials from the ruling Democratic Party. The new laws aim to reduce the statute of limitations for corruption cases, increasing the likelihood of convictions and prison time for those found guilty.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Two Singapore-listed companies, Pacific Radiance and Cogent Holdings, have been recommended as top picks by brokers, citing their potential for long-term growth. Pacific Radiance's share price has been affected by falling oil prices, but its experienced management and strong correlation with oil prices make it an attractive investment. Cogent Holdings' new logistics hub is expected to improve operating efficiency and reduce costs, positioning the company for success in the upcoming supply of warehouse space.

site_title: Facebook dumps Microsoft Web search results
summary: Facebook has stopped including search results from Microsoft's Bing engine on its platform, following the introduction of its revamped search tool. The move may reflect Facebook's increasing emphasis on web search technology, as Google dominates the market. This change comes as Facebook focuses on its own search offerings, allowing users to quickly find past comments from friends.

site_title: Canada's competition watchdog probing Apple
summary: Canada's Competition Bureau is investigating Apple for allegedly stifling competition when the iPhone was first introduced in 2008. The investigation focuses on Apple's contracts with local wireless carriers, and the bureau has sought a court order to obtain records related to iPhone sales in Canada. No determination has been made yet as to whether any laws were broken, and Apple has declined to comment on the investigation.

site_title: S Korea, Asean to work to boost two-way trade by over 50% by 2020
summary: South Korea and the 10-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) have agreed to boost two-way trade by over 50% by 2020, aiming for $200 billion. The growth targets follow a 25-year diplomatic relationship, with trade increasing from $8 billion in 1989 to $135.3 billion in 2014. Korean President Park Geun-hye and Asean leaders also agreed to work towards further liberalizing the Korea-Asean free trade agreement and conclude the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) by the end of 2015.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: S&P doubts UK deficit target, says more tax revenue may be needed
summary: Standard & Poor's has expressed doubts about the UK's deficit target, suggesting that more tax revenue may be needed to balance the budget. The ratings agency expects Britain's economy to suffer if it leaves the European Union, and forecasts a slow decline in the deficit to 3% by 2017. Finance Minister George Osborne's pledge to balance the budget through spending cuts alone may be revised, with S&P considering the need for a wider tax base. The agency maintains a stable outlook for Britain's triple-A rating.

site_title: MIT study explains why stocks swoon when school vacation ends
summary: A new MIT study found that stock markets tend to decline after long school breaks due to investors being less focused on news and information being incorporated into stock prices more slowly. The study, which examined academic schedules in 47 countries, found that stock market returns average about 1% lower in months after major school holidays, particularly in September, the traditional start of the academic year. This effect is stronger for bad news due to the complexity of short-selling.

site_title: WTO talks on duty-free trade in IT goods collapse
summary: Talks on cutting trade tariffs on hundreds of information technology products collapsed at the World Trade Organization, delaying a deal estimated to be worth US$1 trillion to global trade. The failure was attributed to a deadlock between China and South Korea over liquid crystal display (LCD) screens. The talks aimed to update the WTO's 17-year-old Information Technology Agreement, which guarantees zero-tariff and duty-free trade on hundreds of products. The collapse has potentially scuppered the deal, leaving participants disappointed.

site_title: Obama hails US budget compromise, says it has funds needed for Ebola
summary: US President Barack Obama praised a budget compromise, saying it includes funds needed for the Ebola fight despite opposition from some Democrats. The $1.01 trillion legislation, passed by the House and likely to be approved by the Senate, includes funding for healthcare, climate change, early childhood education, and Ebola efforts. Obama acknowledged some provisions he dislikes, but emphasized the need for compromise and responsible governance. The compromise was seen as a result of divided government, and White House spokesman Josh Earnest sought to mend fences with Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi after strained talks.

site_title: Fitch downgrades France's credit rating
summary: Fitch downgraded France's credit rating to "AA" from "AAA" due to the country's failure to meet fiscal deficit reduction targets. Despite reducing its projected deficit to 4.1% of GDP, Fitch believes the government's debt dynamics will not significantly change, with the debt-to-GDP ratio expected to peak at 98% in 2016 and 100% by the end of the decade. The agency's outlook remains stable, but its projections for the French economy's growth and inflation are considered overoptimistic.

site_title: Falling oil prices will continue fuelling Turkish bourse: BlackRock
summary: BlackRock predicts Turkish stocks will continue to outperform due to falling oil prices, which have fueled a 13% return on the Istanbul stock index since September, surpassing all global gauges except the Shanghai and Venezuelan stock markets.

site_title: Wife of Thailand's Crown Prince 'relinquishes' royal status: palace
summary: Thailand's Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn's wife, Princess Srirasmi, has relinquished her royal title, according to the palace. The decision comes after a string of relatives were arrested in a police corruption scandal. Princess Srirasmi married the Crown Prince in 2001 and has a son who is thought to be Vajiralongkorn's most likely heir. The move is seen as a result of the Crown Prince's efforts to distance himself from his relatives, who were involved in the scandal. The palace statement confirms the king's permission for her resignation.

site_title: Lap of luxury
summary: Luxury furniture brands are revisiting classic designs with kid-friendly versions, such as B&B Italia's UPJ armchair and Sancal's Float couch. Meanwhile, Carlo Moretti's Murano Crystal objects and Magis's Traffic furniture showcase innovative designs. The Bentley Home Collection, in partnership with Club House Italia, offers handmade furniture inspired by Bentley car interiors. High-end brands like Poltrona Frau's Nivola armchair and sofa also cater to discerning tastes.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: US truckers eye rate hike as shippers save on cheaper oil
summary: US truckers are eyeing rate hikes amid a surge in cargo demand and declining diesel prices, which have saved shippers $24 billion in fuel surcharges next year. With fuel averaging $2.15 a gallon, down from $2.85, trucking companies aim to cover rising expenses for salaries, healthcare, and regulations. Industrywide fuel savings of $350 million per cent drop in fuel prices spur higher rates, with some large truckers boosting freight prices by 3-4% this year and potentially 5-6% in 2015.

site_title: Oil rout positive for global economy: IIF
summary: A decline in oil prices has a positive impact on the global economy, boosting demand and shifting purchasing power to consumers, according to the Institute of International Finance (IIF). The price drop is estimated to raise global GDP by 0.5% over a two-year period, benefiting countries like the US, China, and Japan. However, large oil exporters such as Saudi Arabia and other countries with thinner cushions will face pressures on their budgets and exchange rates. The impact on financial markets is also significant, with equity markets gaining and oil-related sectors underperforming.

site_title: Autonomerc mobility
summary: Mercedes-Benz is testing its autonomous S-Class on Californian roads, with a license granted by US authorities. The vehicle features advanced sensors, including eight radar sensors and three cameras, to navigate through urban traffic. The car's computer is isolated from external links for security purposes. Mercedes-Benz aims to retain the driving experience by including a steering wheel, throttle, and brake pedals. The company also envisions a future where the car's interior becomes a digital living space, with passengers interacting with the vehicle through gestures or touch displays.

site_title: Cisco makes big push into data analytics
summary: Cisco Systems Inc has introduced data-analytics software packages for various industries, aiming to reduce reliance on proprietary hardware. The company unveiled eight sets of programs, including those for retailers and sports venues, to help make informed decisions using vast amounts of data. Cisco predicts US$7.3 trillion in new profits and cost savings through analytics software in the next decade, with a focus on real-time information analysis. This push is expected to bolster growth in Cisco's services business, which now accounts for 23% of revenue.

site_title: PE industry change favours strongest firms
summary: The private equity industry is shifting in favor of stronger firms, with investors such as pension funds receiving significant cash back and investing more in the industry. This has led to more robust negotiations between firms and investors, with some offering discounts on fees. The strongest firms, including Apollo and Hellman & Friedman, are raising large amounts of capital, while others, like TPG, face skepticism from investors due to past performance. The rules of fund-raising are changing, with cash-rich investors able to compare and contrast managers' performance, making it harder for firms to hide.

images.alt_text: DIFFERENT STROKES: Beyond the ups and downs of performance, fund-raising rules are different for the biggest private equity firms such as Blackstone and their big investors.

site_title: Next GE may take place when Singaporeans least expect it
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the timing of the next general election (GE) depends on various factors, including global events and the state of preparations. He emphasized that the PAP is working hard to prepare for the election, which must be called by January 2017 at the latest. Meanwhile, the PAP is also involved in various activities, including a year-long celebration of Singapore's golden jubilee in 2015 and efforts to strengthen ties with the labor movement, with younger ministers becoming more involved in the NTUC.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
PM Lee Hsien Loong, the PAP Secretary General, gives his rally address at the PAP60 rally at Expo Hall 7 on Dec 7, 2014.

site_title: Style to the max
summary: Macsk, a luxury furniture store, opens in Singapore on Dec 15 with 11 brands, including Molteni&C, Patricia Urquiola, and Gio Ponti. The 8,600 sq ft showroom features a kinetic chandelier and will carry pieces from Louis Poulsen, Fendi Casa, and Murano glass artisan Carlo Moretti. Despite a tepid property market, Macsk's general manager Syddal Wee is confident in the high net worth crowd's willingness to buy, citing his 20+ years of experience in the industry. The luxury furniture market has changed, with consumers becoming more knowledgeable and younger, and stores must adapt with a more personalized shopping experience.
