Winkler was a dominant presence in the newsroom, favored by Bloomberg, and outlasted many of the most highly regarded editors in journalism. Winkler's departure marks a significant change in the company, which Bloomberg had reassumed control of in September. The reason for Winkler's departure is not specified, but it is seen as a significant move by Bloomberg.

site_title: Charoen planning to start due diligence on United Engineers: sources
summary: Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi, Thailand's richest man, is planning to start due diligence on Singapore's United Engineers Ltd, a move that could lead to a potential acquisition. TCC Top Enterprise Ltd, Charoen's company, will begin examining the company's finances and WBL Corp unit next week. Exclusive talks with minority shareholder Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp (OCBC) will expire six weeks after due diligence starts. The process is private, and the outcome is uncertain.

site_title: QT Vascular's US unit gets S'pore catheter patent
summary: QT Vascular's US unit, TriReme Medical LLC, has been granted a Singapore patent for its GliderXtreme PTA balloon catheter, featuring improved column strength and torque. The technology is used in the group's minimally invasive medical devices for vascular disease treatment. The patent is the latest in a series of grants in Japan and China, and is expected to contribute to company growth in Asia in 2015, particularly in sales of GliderXtreme PTA in the region.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: World Bank lowers Russia's economic forecast
summary: The World Bank has lowered Russia's economic forecast, predicting a 0.7% contraction in 2015 due to falling oil prices and sanctions over Ukraine. The bank's forecast is in line with Russia's Economic Development Ministry, which predicted a 0.8% contraction. Oil prices have fallen to five-year lows, averaging US$65, and the rouble has plummeted 40% against the US dollar. The central bank has intervened with billions to prop up the rouble, but it remains uncertain if the measures will be effective.

images.alt_text: Russia's central bank says it spent US$4.5 billion last week to prop up the rouble, which has fallen about 40 per cent against the US dollar and 32 per cent against the euro year to date.

site_title: Twitter drops out of Glassdoor's list of best places to work
summary: Twitter has dropped out of Glassdoor's list of best places to work, ranking second last year but failing to crack the top 50 this year. Employee reviews on Glassdoor cited complaints about leadership changes and a lack of long-term plans, with some describing the company as "chaotic". This follows a year of significant changes at Twitter, including CEO Dick Costolo's leadership shuffle and a 42% decline in stock price. Google takes the top spot, followed by Bain & Co, with technology companies dominating the top 50 list.

site_title: Citigroup to book US$2.7b in legal expenses for Q4
summary: Citigroup recorded $2.7 billion in litigation expenses and $800 million in repositioning charges for the fourth quarter, leaving the bank "marginally profitable." The costs stem from government investigations into foreign exchange market manipulation and money laundering rules. CEO Michael Corbat attributed the charges to "opportunities to go ahead and pull some restructuring and repositioning forward." The bank had previously reduced its payroll by 20,000 jobs and cut real estate by 10 million square feet. Despite the charges, Corbat expects the company to meet its profit and efficiency targets for next year.

site_title: Tony Abbott's "shirtfront" is Australia's word of the year
summary: Australia's National Dictionary Centre has chosen "shirtfront" as the country's word of the year, beating out "man-bun" and "Team Australia". The term, popularized by Prime Minister Tony Abbott, refers to an aggressive Australian sports term where a player charges an opponent. Abbott used the term to challenge Russia's Vladimir Putin over the Malaysia Airlines MH17 crash, which killed 298 people, including 38 Australians. The word's widespread discussion and adoption across Australia's social, cultural, and political spheres led to its selection as the word of the year.

site_title: iFast IPO 12.4 times subscribed, debuts Thursday
summary: iFast Corporation, an internet-based fund distribution company, has successfully completed its initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) mainboard, with the offer about 12.4 times subscribed. The company, which operates the popular online platform Fundsupermart.com, raised S$45 million and is expected to have a market value of S$243.4 million. Proceeds will be used for mergers and acquisitions, expanding into the Chinese market, and enhancing product capabilities. The IPO price valued the company at 24 times earnings, with revenue up 16% and net profit up 36% year-on-year.

site_title: A celebration of top Singapore SMEs
summary: The Enterprise 50 Awards, now in its 20th edition, honored top Singaporean SMEs, with Borden Company, a pharmaceutical manufacturer, taking the top spot. Sunray Woodcraft Construction and Vigcon Construction followed closely. The awards also recognized Wee Tiong's 10-year achievement, as well as Seiko Architectural Wall Systems and Aik Moh Paints & Chemicals for their 5-year success. Since its inception, over 120 SMEs have been listed on the local bourse and gained international recognition.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Draghi measures may test Denmark's euro peg
summary: Mario Draghi's unprecedented stimulus push to pump one trillion euros into the euro area may test Denmark's euro peg, where the benchmark interest rate is already below zero. Denmark's deputy governor, Per Callesen, says the country is willing to defend the krone's peg to the euro at all costs, citing past experience with extreme measures deterring speculators. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing package, set to be discussed on January 22, aims to boost the ECB's balance sheet, potentially impacting Denmark's currency rate.

site_title: New Syscon facility to double prefab output
summary: Syscon, a Singaporean prefabricated bathroom units manufacturer, is expanding its facility in Tuas to double its production capacity. The S$120 million plant will enable the firm to produce up to 3,000 prefabricated bathroom units per year, meeting demands from the Housing Development Board and private developments. The new facility is expected to be ready in 2017 or 2018 and will feature multiple loading bays and a dedicated worker dormitory, increasing productivity and land efficiency. This move aims to cater to the government's push for land intensification and the increasing demand for prefabricated bathroom units.

site_title: In an about-face, Australia joins UN climate fund
summary: Australia will contribute A$200 million (S$218.7 million) over four years to the UN Green Climate Fund to help poor nations cope with global warming, reversing a stance held by former climate-change sceptic Prime Minister Tony Abbott. This pledge, part of a plan to raise US$100 billion a year by 2020, aims to curb greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to climate change impacts. The move comes as the country faces record low approval ratings and follows a series of policy reversals.

site_title: Barclays prefers Reits with strong distribution buffer
summary: Barclays recommends holding Singapore-based real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) with high absolute dividend yields due to potential higher interest rates in the second half of next year. S-Reits currently offer the widest forward-yield spread against benchmark 10-year Treasuries, and office rents in Singapore have been recovering. However, the report warns that rising housing supply and weakening demand may impact Hong Kong property players, with Barclays expecting prices to fall.

site_title: China eyeing foreigners to tame equity volatility
summary: China is opening its $4.6 trillion stock market to foreign investors to tame volatility, which has surged 2.9% in recent days. Authorities aim to increase the role of professional money managers with longer-term investment horizons. Foreign investors can purchase up to $64 billion of mainland shares through the Shanghai-Hong Kong exchange link, with the quota potentially increasing over time. However, participation has been limited due to concerns over ownership rights and delivery requirements, with international investors using only 28% of daily quotas.

site_title: Abercrombie's next CEO will have to revamp outdated brand, again
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch Co, a teen clothing chain, is searching for a new CEO to revamp its outdated brand. Longtime CEO Mike Jeffries stepped down after the company's strategies failed to appeal to current shoppers, who prefer fast fashion and lower-key styles. The new CEO must understand operations and rebuild the brand, ideally from an innovative retailer like Hennes & Mauritz AB or Amazon.com. Abercrombie is considering internal candidates, including Jonathan Ramsden and Christos Angelides, and has already begun a transformation plan with looser-fitting styles and social media marketing.

site_title: Internet firms push to be left out of EU cyber security law
summary: Internet firms, including Cisco and Google, are opposing a new EU cyber security law that would require them to adopt security measures and report serious breaches. The law aims to cover only critical sectors like energy and finance, but the EU executive and some countries want to include cloud providers and social networks. The companies argue that this would incur extra costs and lead to fragmentation of security standards, undermining the digital single market. They claim that companies like themselves are already implicated in critical sectors as customers, and that duplicate incident reporting would be a problem.

site_title: Report on CIA may have biggest impact outside the US
summary: The US Senate Intelligence Committee released a redacted report on the CIA's post-9/11 interrogation techniques, sparking international controversy and anti-American sentiment in Muslim-majority countries. The report, part of a 6,000-page study, makes new claims that may contradict a 2012 Justice Department investigation. The publication is expected to inflame tensions and pose a significant public diplomacy challenge for President Barack Obama, potentially undermining US efforts against terrorism. The international fallout may also impact US foreign policy, particularly in Asia and Europe.

site_title: Spain builds again 6 yrs after property crash
summary: Spain has restarted home building six years after the property crash in 2008, despite a huge stock of unsold homes. The country built around 700,000 houses annually during the 2000s, but construction halted after the bubble burst. Now, building has resumed, with many empty dwellings located outside urban areas. This marks a significant recovery for Spain's economy, which was severely impacted by the crash, throwing millions of people out of work.

site_title: No rest for art collectors as they snap up pieces at Art Basel Miami
summary: Art collectors snapped up pieces at Art Basel Miami, with dealers reporting robust sales despite some prices being deemed overpriced. The fair, which drew 73,000 visitors, saw colourful mostly abstract paintings and sculptures sell for upwards of $100,000. Notable sales included a $3 million John Chamberlain sculpture and a $4 million Damien Hirst mirrored medicine cabinet. Collectors, including celebrities and hedge fund managers, toured the booths and made significant purchases, with some galleries reporting almost selling out their works at the preview.

site_title: Asian oil traders' move to Texas spells trouble for Opec
summary: Asian oil traders are positioning themselves to buy US oil as Congress is expected to lift export restrictions. Japan's Mitsui & Co, South Korea's SK Innovation, and Tokyo-based Cosmo Oil have doubled their employees in Houston to take advantage of the opportunity. The US is producing record volumes of light oil, making it more attractive to overseas processors. Opec members are offering deep discounts, sparking speculation of a price war. The ban on US crude exports, passed in 1975, is seen as an artifact of the 1970s, and its lifting could boost global supplies and reduce costs.

site_title: For sale: Thong Sia Building at S$400-420m
summary: The Thong Sia Building in Singapore's Orchard Road area is up for sale with a price tag of S$400-420 million, translating to S$2,559-2,687 per square foot. Over 80% of owners have consented to the collective sale of the 26-storey building, which has a land area of 21,600 sq ft. The sale could be completed with the government allowing the sale of an adjoining road, reducing costs to S$2,414-2,532 per square foot.

site_title: British royals crown New York visit with gala dinner
summary: Prince William and Kate Middleton hosted a gala dinner in New York to raise money for the University of St. Andrews, where they met. The event took place at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with the Duchess wearing a midnight blue evening gown by Jenny Packham. The dinner marked the end of the royal couple's whirlwind tour of the US.

site_title: Japan's looming benefit cuts an undercurrent in Sunday's polls
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is facing pressure to address the country's looming benefit cuts, which could impact millions of people due to rising social welfare spending and a rapidly aging population. The government's public debt tops a quadrillion yen, and even a planned 10% national sales tax increase may not be enough to balance the budget. Abe has promised to formulate specific plans for welfare spending cuts by the summer of 2025, but critics argue that his economic policies have contributed to the country's deflationary mindset.

site_title: More negative news on the economy surfaces in Tokyo
summary: Japan's economy faces challenges ahead of the snap election, with Fitch casting doubts on the sovereign debt standing, wholesale prices falling, and a deteriorating business survey. This news comes after the Japanese economy's recession in the third quarter of 2014 was steeper than estimated. The negative economic indicators may make Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics strategy a tougher sell. The timing of the election adds to the pressure on Abe to deliver economic growth.

site_title: Popular posts S$1.25m Q2 profit; warns of property blues
summary: Popular Holdings reported a second-quarter net profit of S$1.25 million, up from a net loss of S$52,000 in the same period last year. However, the company warned of difficulties in selling its property units due to property cooling measures and potential extension charges if it fails to sell remaining units by May 2015. Despite a 8% year-on-year drop in turnover, the company's gross profit rose 1.3% to $19.4 million, and its shares closed at 23.5 Singapore cents, down 4.08%.

site_title: US manufacturers group opposes stricter Internet regulations
summary: The US National Association of Manufacturers opposes stricter Internet regulations, urging Congress and the Federal Communications Commission to oppose any efforts to regulate the Internet like a utility. The group, which represents over 14,000 members, including major companies like Verizon and AT&T, argues that such regulations would slow down business growth and investment. The opposition comes despite President Barack Obama's call for strict rules to protect net neutrality, and the FCC's plans to set new rules aimed at ensuring equal treatment of all Internet traffic.

site_title: HSBC dismisses head of FX trading for EMEA: source
summary: HSBC has dismissed Stuart Scott, head of foreign exchange trading for Europe, Middle East, and Africa, amid a global investigation into currency market manipulation. Scott's departure follows the firings of two London-based currency traders in October. The bank has paid $618 million in FX settlements with regulatory authorities. The move comes as US officials interview current or former HSBC employees in London as part of their investigations.

site_title: Institutional investors see more activism, but question its long-term value
summary: Institutional investors see shareholder activism on the rise, with 77% predicting a growth in the next three years, but also believe it may compromise long-term value creation, with 81% agreeing that short-term gains can come at the expense of longer-term value. Management quality and corporate strategy are key factors in valuing an investment, according to a poll of 500 institutional investors and sell-side analysts. Asian investors are less concerned about the potential impact of activism on long-term value, with only 25% strongly agreeing.

images.alt_text: Singapore skyline.

site_title: Afghanistan's own 'Bruce Lee' a big hit on the Internet
summary: A 20-year-old Afghan man, Abbas Alizada, has gained internet fame by performing kung fu moves and poses reminiscent of Bruce Lee, with the goal of promoting national unity in war-weary Afghanistan. Alizada, from a poor family, trained in wushu and now performs at a ruined palace in Kabul, where he hopes to become a champion and Hollywood star. His recent success reflects changes in the country since the US-led intervention and the rise of interest in sports under the government.

site_title: Report recommends flight tracking, airlines balk at deadline
summary: A report recommends that airlines install available flight-tracking systems within 12 months following the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370. However, the International Air Transport Association (IATA) has expressed concerns that the deadline is impractical due to varying airline performance. IATA representatives say some airlines already exceed the recommended performance criteria, but others may need more time to upgrade their equipment. The industry will monitor new satellite-based systems and explore making tracking systems tamper-proof, but this is not feasible in the short term.

site_title: Sustaining the Himalayas
summary: The Himalayas play a vital role in providing water resources and energy to over 1.3 billion people, with the region's 10 rivers supplying fresh water to the area. The Himalayas also serve as a food source for more than three billion people, feeding the agricultural output of Asia's breadbaskets. Sustainably tapping the region's hydropower potential is crucial to fuel growing economies, highlighting the importance of conservation and sustainable management of the Himalayan region.

site_title: Aussie banks urged to curb growth in home loans to investors
summary: The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) has urged banks to limit home loan growth to investors to 10% annually, citing surging house prices in Sydney and Melbourne. APRA also recommends adding a 2% buffer to home-loan rates and an interest-rate floor of at least 7% when assessing borrowers' ability to repay mortgages. The regulator will review lending practices in 2015 to assess if further action is needed, potentially including increases in capital requirements.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:

Even with 190% tariffs, a US shoemaker remains reliant on China. Japan's elevator empire saw a 6,000% stock gain due to the country's succession crisis. Singapore's top companies paid CEOs an average of S$1.2 million in salaries.

site_title: US financiers' nostalgia for Timothy Geithner
summary: Wall Street's top executives showed surprise nostalgia for former US Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner, receiving a warm welcome at a Manhattan hotel event. The gesture suggests bankers feel the current regulatory regime lacks commitment to financial regulation. Geithner's lenient approach during his tenure as watchdog may be seen as a factor, implying that bankers believe the current administration is not prioritizing their oversight. This perception is a departure from Geithner's tough stance during his time in office.

site_title: Eurozone fiscal stance appropriate, reform needed: ECB's Coeure
summary: European Central Bank Executive Board member Benoit Coeure stated that the eurozone's fiscal stance is appropriate, but structural reforms are needed to avoid low growth and low inflation. Coeure warned that the eurozone economy could become stuck on a "one per cent economics" path, where both growth and inflation remain around that level, making it unsustainable. He emphasized the importance of interdependent EU institutions and governments in implementing fiscal, monetary, and structural policies to achieve a medium-term inflation target of below, but close to, 2%.

site_title: China on the horns of a volatility dilemma
summary: China's stock markets are experiencing increased volatility, with prices jumping to levels last seen in 2009. Despite the yuan's fluctuation to drive away speculators, the trend is unsustainable, and the ruling Communist Party seeks to avoid political volatility. Market gyrations can benefit speculators but harm companies, as seen with China Development Bank's cancelled bond issue. The central bank's inability to control the currency's value may lead to capital flight, undermining the notion of government control over asset prices. China's economy may face long-term consequences from this volatility.

images.alt_text: China's gyrating stock markets are a reminder that movement matters. Volatility is increasing in the People's Republic, and fighting it is a losing battle.

site_title: Airlines body calls for UN to regulate anti-aircraft weaponry
summary: Global airlines body IATA has called on the UN to regulate anti-aircraft weaponry, following the downing of Malaysia Airlines MH17 over Ukraine in July. IATA Director General Tony Tyler described the incident as an "outrage" and urged the UN to establish international law for the responsible design, manufacture, and deployment of anti-aircraft weapons, similar to existing regulations for chemical weapons and landmines. The move aims to address the threat posed by powerful anti-aircraft weapons in the hands of non-state entities.

site_title: UBS eyes a tripling of assets with 'super-teams'
summary: UBS aims to triple its US wealth management clients' assets in fee-based accounts within 7-10 years, moving from mass affluent to ultra-high-net-worth clients. The company plans to create 100 "super-teams" with up to 20 brokers and specialists, each with discretion to invest over $1 billion in client assets. UBS currently holds about 33% of client assets in fee-based accounts, aiming to grow this to 50% within the same timeframe.

site_title: BP to cut jobs amid falling oil prices
summary: BP is cutting hundreds of jobs globally, a result of falling oil prices, as part of a US$1 billion restructuring program. The company will incur non-operating restructuring charges of circa US$1 billion over the next five quarters. The restructuring charge is part of BP's cost-cutting drive, which includes selling assets to cover the cost of the 2010 oil spill and rising oil sector costs. The company also considers further cuts to its 2015 spending program.

site_title: Iata forecasts record profits for airlines as fuel costs dive
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) forecasts a record net profit of $19.9 billion for airlines in 2014, driven by 20% lower oil prices. US carriers are expected to lead the industry, with a net profit of $11.9 billion, followed by Asia-Pacific airlines with $3.5 billion. The projected profit margin of 2.7% is slightly lower than expected due to fuel hedging. Despite lower fuel prices, airfares are expected to dip 5.1% and cargo rates decline 5.8%.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: SGX-TWSE cross-trading could start in July: report
summary: Singapore's SGX and Taiwan's TWSE may start cross-trading as early as July 2015, according to TWSE president Michael Lin. The partnership aims to allow investors to trade a range of listed stocks in each other's markets at a lower cost. This move could boost foreign participation in Taiwan's markets and provide Singapore investors with increased exposure to Taiwan equities. The development follows the success of Shanghai-Hong Kong's link and could inject liquidity into SGX's lull market.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee had said that the channel will allow investors to trade a range of stocks at a lower overall cost.

site_title: US: Energy stocks lead Wall St lower at the open
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday, led by a fourth consecutive day of declines in energy stocks, with crude prices hitting fresh five-year lows. The Dow Jones fell 0.41%, the S&P 500 lost 0.39%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.22%.

site_title: 'We were slow': WHO admits mistakes in Ebola response
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) admitted to mistakes in its response to the Ebola outbreak in west Africa, which has killed over 6,300 people. Director-General Margaret Chan acknowledged that the global health body was slow to respond due to its bureaucratic and politicized nature. The WHO initially misdiagnosed the outbreak, thinking it was cholera or Lassa fever, and by the time it was correctly identified, the virus had spread far and been deadly. The organization is now seeking to improve healthcare systems in affected countries, including boosting medical staff and supplies.

site_title: Glencore oil chief sees "good chance" crude price keeps falling
summary: Glencore's oil chief, Alex Beard, predicts a "good chance" of crude prices continuing their 43% fall since June. He expects few oil projects to be shut over the next 6-9 months, but notes that lower prices may lead to steeper price rebounds. Beard also believes many planned oil projects will be abandoned or reduced if prices stay low.

images.alt_text: Glencore's oil chief said on Wednesday there was a "good chance" of crude prices extending their 43 per cent fall since June, as he did not expect many oil projects to be shut over the next 6-9 months.

site_title: Asean corporate chiefs discuss building more effective trade ties with South Korea
summary: Business leaders from 10 Asean countries met with South Korea's largest private economic organization to boost trade ties and address barriers to business activities. The Asean-Korea Business Council aims to help SMEs penetrate markets in South-east Asia and South Korea. The meeting, held on the sidelines of a commemorative summit, focused on expanding trade and investment through the existing Korea-Asean FTA, which has seen trade increase to $135.3 billion. The goal is to increase trade volume to $200 billion by 2020, with Singapore companies expected to enter joint ventures with South Korean counterparts and attract higher-value partners.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Opec cuts 2015 demand forecast for its oil as shale boom persists
summary: Opec lowered its 2015 oil demand forecast to 28.92 million barrels per day, down 280,000 bpd from its previous estimate, citing weaker consumption growth and the US shale boom. The group had previously refused to cut output, with Saudi Arabia urging members to combat the US shale oil boom eroding Opec's market share. The new forecast indicates an increasing supply surplus in 2015.

site_title: BMW outsells Audi and Mercedes but lead narrows
summary: BMW achieved its highest-ever November sales with 158,953 deliveries, surpassing Audi's 146,250 models and Mercedes-Benz's 150,742. The sales growth was driven by strong demand in core European markets and China. Despite the narrow lead, Audi and Mercedes-Benz are expected to narrow BMW's gap in the global luxury car market.

site_title: UK trade deficit hits seven-month low in Oct, helped by slower oil imports
summary: Britain's goods trade deficit narrowed in October to 9.620 billion pounds, its lowest level in seven months, thanks to lower fuel imports and a slight rise in exports. This was slightly less than the expected 9.5 billion pound deficit. Economists had forecast a wider gap due to a rise in oil imports in September. The improvement in the trade deficit is seen as a positive sign for the UK economy.

images.alt_text: Britain's goods trade deficit narrowed in October to its lowest level in seven months, helped by lower fuel imports and a slight rise in exports, official data showed on Wednesday.

site_title: ECB to begin buying sovereign bonds early next year: Reuters poll
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to begin buying sovereign bonds early next year, amid growing concerns about deflation in the eurozone. A Reuters poll found that 25 of 27 economists believe the ECB will start buying sovereign debt, with March likely being the announcement month. The median probability of full quantitative easing increased to 70%, driven by low inflation and plunging oil prices. Despite the ECB's efforts to boost inflation, economists predict a 0.8% GDP growth this year and 1.5% in 2016, lower than forecasts for other major economies.

site_title: Update: BP to spend US$1b on hundreds of job cuts, restructuring
summary: BP will cut hundreds of jobs globally in a US$1 billion restructuring program, primarily staff redundancies, to increase efficiency. The cost-cutting drive follows steep oil price falls, with revenues slumping. The restructuring charge will be incurred over five quarters, including a first charge in the fourth quarter of 2014. BP's 2015 spending program is also being reviewed, with potential further cuts to US$1-US$2 billion.

images.alt_text: BP will cut hundreds of jobs cut across its global oil and gas business by the end of next year in a US$1 billion restructuring programme announced on Wednesday following steep falls in oil prices.

site_title: US mortgage applications rise in latest week: MBA
summary: US mortgage applications increased by 7.3% in the week ended Dec 5, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. Refinancing applications rose 13.2%, while purchase demand rose 1.3%. This marks a reversal of the previous five weeks of declines in mortgage rates. The increase in mortgage applications suggests a potential boost to the US housing market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares rose on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 27.42 points to close at 1,765.52. Trading volume reached 1.21 billion lots, valued at RM1.61 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 502-281.

site_title: Oil prices drop before US data
summary: Oil prices dropped before US data, with US$62.76 per barrel for West Texas Intermediate and US$66.04 for Brent North Sea crude. The decline occurred as dealers awaited US stockpiles data for an indication of demand in the world's largest crude consumer. The move came amid bearish market sentiment, potentially linked to US President Trump's tariff outlook.

site_title: Play on banks continues to drive STI
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 5.97 points to 3,325.81 on Wednesday, recovering from Monday's 27-point loss, following a rebound in Hong Kong and gains in bank stocks. UOB and DBS led the rally, with UOB reaching an all-time high of S$24.68. Despite a heavy reliance on a small number of stocks, analysts expect caution in the new year due to rich valuations and a potential interest rate hike.

site_title: Hong Kong protest leaders will 'stay to end' as police swoop looms
summary: Hong Kong's student protest leaders have vowed to "stay to the end" as police prepare to clear the city's main rally site, where thousands have gathered for a final mass rally. The protest, which began in September, demands fully free leadership elections, with China's communist authorities saying candidates will be vetted by a loyalist committee. Authorities have warned of "resolute action" against those who resist the clearance, but protesters remain determined to fight on, with many saying the movement will continue despite the end of the occupation.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's student protest leaders said on Wednesday that they would "stay to the end" as police prepared to swoop on the city's main rally site after more than two months of mass pro-democracy demonstrations.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 5.97 points to 3,325.81. Traders brushed off US President Trump's new threats to extend the stocks rally, with some stocks, including Singtel and Sinarmas Land, showing significant gains. Despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views, investors remained positive, driving the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Thousands rally in Indonesia for higher pay
summary: Thousands of Indonesian workers rallied in Jakarta, demanding higher salaries after a recent fuel price increase led to inflation. The protesters, unhappy with the 2015 minimum wage increase, marched to the presidential palace and major roundabouts. Strikes were also held in other cities across the country. The protesters cited the higher cost of transporting goods due to the fuel price hike as a major concern. The rally is part of two days of strikes, with workers calling for better compensation to offset the rising costs of living.

site_title: China needs more than 5,300 new aircraft through 2033: Airbus
summary: China is expected to require more than 5,300 new aircraft through 2033, according to Airbus' 2014-2033 Global Market Forecast. The demand for domestic air travel is mounting, driving the need for additional aircraft. This forecast surpasses previous estimates, indicating a significant increase in China's air travel needs. Airbus competes with Boeing for orders, with both companies vying for a share of the growing Chinese market.

site_title: China auto sales up 2.3% in November: industry group
summary: China's auto sales expanded 2.3% year-on-year in November, reaching 2.09 million units, according to the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers. This marked the slowest growth for any month this year, with production and sales remaining "relatively stable" compared to October and September, where sales were 1.99 and 1.98 million units respectively.

site_title: IATA ups global airlines' 2014 profit outlook, sees US$25b in 2015
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has revised its 2014 profit forecast, predicting US$19.9 billion in net profit, up from the previous estimate of US$18 billion, due to falling fuel prices and stronger economic growth. IATA expects this to rise to US$25 billion in 2015, driven by a decrease in fuel spend to US$192 billion. The organization attributes the improved outlook to the global economy's recovery and lower oil prices.

site_title: New ways to measure property prices
summary: The Housing Development Board (HDB) in Singapore will use a stratified hedonic method to measure property prices, controlling for "quality" characteristics such as the unit's storey. This new method replaces the current Housing Board resale price index, which excludes some estates. The HDB has decided not to recalculate old values to avoid confusion, sparking concerns about the lack of comparable past values. A comprehensive disclosure of the methodology and assumptions is recommended to improve the understanding and use of the index. The new method aims to provide a more accurate representation of the real estate market.

site_title: France unveils controversial plan to energise economy
summary: France has unveiled a plan to energize its crisis-hit economy, including expanding Sunday trading for shops and opening up traditionally closed sectors. The proposal, led by Economy Minister Emmanuel Macron, includes measures to boost growth, such as selling state-owned assets and opening inter-city coach travel. However, the plan to extend Sunday shopping has sparked outrage, with the left wing of the Socialist Party opposing it. The proposal aims to address France's stagnant economy, which has seen growth at 0.3% in the third quarter and a record-high 10.4% unemployment rate.

site_title: BP announces restructuring as oil prices plunge
summary: BP announces a major restructuring plan due to plunging oil prices, which have dropped by 40% since June. The company will take a $1.0 billion restructuring charge over the next year, simplifying its operations and corporate functions. Reports suggest job cuts are possible as part of the plan. BP has already sold off $43 billion in assets since 2010 to meet the clean-up bill from the Gulf of Mexico oil spill. The company aims to become a more focused and competitive business while maintaining safety and reliability.

site_title: UK pay growth may be at turning point: Bank of England's McCafferty
summary: Bank of England rate-setter Ian McCafferty says UK pay growth may be at a turning point, strengthening the case for higher interest rates now. The economy is running out of slack, despite a slight slowdown, and inflation could pick up more quickly than forecast. McCafferty believes there may not be much spare capacity left in the labor market, potentially leading to higher interest rates sooner than expected. This contradicts the Bank of England's previous forecast of a first rate hike deep into 2015.

site_title: QT Vascular unit granted Singapore patent for catheter
summary: QT Vascular's US subsidiary TriReme Medical LLC has been granted a Singapore patent for its GliderXtreme PTA balloon catheter, which features improved column strength and torque. This patent, along with previously granted patents in Japan and China, is expected to drive growth in Asia and contribute to the company's global value. The grant is seen as another milestone for QT Vascular, which is committed to delivering innovative solutions that improve patients' lives and reduce healthcare costs.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Taiwan Stock Exchange will start cross trading links with Singapore, Japan: president
summary: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TWSE) will start cross-trading links with Singapore and Japan in July 2015, aiming to boost its position after the successful Shanghai-Hong Kong trading link. TWSE president Michael Lin announced the plans, which include allowing investors to trade stocks and exchange-traded funds (ETFs) on both markets. This move follows the success of the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect and is expected to bolster Taiwan's position in the Asian market.

images.alt_text: The Taiwan Stock Exchange will kick off cross-trading with the Singapore and the Tokyo stock exchanges next year, the Taipei bourse's president said on Wednesday, in a bid to bolster its position after launch of the Shanghai-Hong Kong trading link.

site_title: Malaysia Oct factory output growth likely slowed to 4.1% year-on-year
summary: Malaysia's industrial output in October likely grew 4.1% year-on-year, slowing from September due to weaker commodity prices affecting mining production. Factory production declined, with exports 3.1% below a year earlier, following robust exports in the first half of the year. This slowdown reflects weaker demand, with the median forecast from 12 economists indicating a decline in factory production.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's industrial output in October probably grew 4.1 per cent from a year earlier, a Reuters poll showed, slowing from September as weaker commodity prices likely hurt mining production.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices in Asia decreased on Wednesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling 86 cents to $62.96 and Brent crude dropping 81 cents to $66.03. The decline was attributed to dealers waiting for the US supply report and weak trade data from China and Germany. Analysts also cited the global supply glut as a concern, particularly the level of US production.

site_title: Australia to crack down on online pirates
summary: Australia's government plans to crack down on online piracy by allowing copyright holders to apply for court orders to block access to infringing websites through internet service providers. ISPs will also be required to issue warnings to consumers who breach copyright laws. The move aims to reduce the country's position as a top illegal downloader of TV shows like "Game of Thrones." The government seeks a "least burdensome" approach, with a 120-day deadline for ISPs to develop an industry code.

site_title: Update: Airlines to post US$19.9b profit in 2014 and US$25b in 2015: Iata
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) predicts the world's airlines will post a collective net profit of US$19.9 billion in 2014 and US$25 billion in 2015, driven by lower oil prices and stronger global economic growth. The average jet fuel price is expected to decrease from US$116.60 per barrel in 2014 to US$99.90 per barrel in 2015, contributing to the higher profit forecast. Airlines are also expected to see increased revenues, with US$751 billion in 2014 and US$783 billion in 2015, leading to a 2.7% and 3.2% profit margin respectively.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 2.25%
summary: Tokyo shares closed down 2.25% on Wednesday, following a sell-off across global markets, due to a stronger yen that pressured exporters. The Nikkei 225 index tumbled 400.80 points to 17,412.58, its worst points loss in over three weeks.

site_title: Update: Asian shares mixed, Shanghai bounces back after slump
summary: Asian shares were mixed on Wednesday, with Shanghai rebounding after a slump, while Tokyo and Sydney fell. The yen strengthened against the dollar, and oil prices dropped due to a global supply glut. Greece brought forward a presidential election, raising fears of political instability, which affected European and US markets. Despite initial losses, the Dow and S&P 500 ended the day near record levels, and Shanghai's benchmark composite index surged 2.93%.

site_title: Japan budget carrier Skymark eyes joint support from ANA, JAL
summary: Japan's budget carrier Skymark Airlines is considering joint support from ANA and JAL, with code-sharing as a main pillar of assistance. Skymark shares surged 17.31% after the news, as the company seeks help to rehabilitate its management and reduce vacant seats. ANA has expressed interest in supporting Skymark but is hesitant about a joint tie-up that could benefit JAL. Skymark is also considering assistance from investment funds, with a formal request to ANA expected soon.

images.alt_text: Struggling Japanese budget carrier Skymark Airlines said Wednesday it was considering asking for help from domestic giant All Nippon Airways, even while eyeing a tie-up with ANA's rival Japan Airlines (JAL).

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares edge up after rebound on China markets
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.2% on Wednesday, erasing morning losses, following a rebound on mainland markets. The Hang Seng index closed at 23,527.43, while the China Enterprises Index gained 0.4%. Investors were cautious after Tuesday's sharp market drop, but the rebound helped to lift Hong Kong shares.

site_title: KFC calls on Chinese diners to inspect its kitchen
summary: KFC in China is offering tours of its kitchens and suppliers to reassure customers after a safety scare involving expired meat at a supplier. The tours, which began in 2013, allow customers to see how the food is prepared and inspect the facilities. The move aims to rebuild trust after sales slowed since a scandal was reported. KFC's parent company, Yum Brands, has also cut its profit forecast for the year. The company claims the tours demonstrate the safety and quality of its food, but critics say it's a desperate attempt to regain customer trust in a market where food safety scandals are common.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 3.08 points to 1735.02, with 63 losers outweighing 45 gainers. The article does not provide further details on the market's performance.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index losing 1.24 points to 3,318.60. Volume was 38.2 million shares worth S$55.0 million. Gainers beat losers 73 to 58.

site_title: Japan consumer mood worsens for 4th straight month in November
summary: Japan's consumer confidence index worsened for a fourth consecutive month in November, with a sentiment index of 37.7, the lowest since April. The Cabinet Office survey attributed the decline to the ongoing impact of the April sales tax hike. The general households' sentiment index, which includes views on incomes and jobs, has been in weak movement. This marks a continuation of the trend seen in previous months.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.18% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.18% in the opening exchanges on Wednesday, extending losses from the previous day's sell-off on Wall Street. The benchmark Hang Seng Index dropped 43.14 points to 23,442.69.

site_title: Some Asia-Pac CFOs not helping enough with business challenges: KPMG study
summary: A KPMG study surveyed 178 Asia-Pacific CEOs, finding that 70% see a "powerful future" for their CFOs, but 33% believe CFOs are not helping enough with business challenges. 58% of CEOs think CFOs should focus on growth, but CFOs are often mired in costs and compliance issues. The study suggests CFOs should shift their focus to growth, but currently are too focused on financials.

site_title: US spending bill would expand allowed donations to political parties
summary: The US House of Representatives has released a government spending bill that includes a provision allowing wealthy individuals to make larger donations to political parties. The current limit of $32,400 per year would be increased to $324,000 annually, as individuals could donate three times the limit to each of the national parties' earmarked efforts, such as conventions, buildings, and recounts. This change would significantly expand the ability of wealthy individuals to influence party politics.

site_title: DreamWorks to launch family TV channel in Asia
summary: DreamWorks Animation plans to launch a 24/7 family-oriented TV channel in Asia during 2015, featuring popular shows like All Hail King Julien, The Adventures Of Puss In Boots, and How To Train Your Dragon. The channel will be managed by Singapore-based HBO Asia, which will handle affiliate sales, marketing, and technical services.

site_title: China: Shares up in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares rose in morning trade on Wednesday, driven by hefty losses in the previous session and weak inflation data for November. The Shanghai Composite Index increased 0.51% to 2,870.95, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.47% to 1,409.98. China's consumer inflation fell to a five-year low of 1.4% in November, providing a positive boost to market sentiment.

site_title: Help for British house buyers could end up hurting building stocks
summary: The UK government's plan to help British homebuyers by cutting taxes on property purchases has boosted housebuilding stocks, such as Barratt Developments and Taylor Wimpey, extending a multi-month rally. However, brokers warn that the impact of the reforms, including higher taxes on high-end properties, could soon sink in, potentially hindering sales of expensive new developments in London. The reforms could also make existing houses more affordable, reducing demand for new developments. Analysts predict a net-net negative impact on the sector.

site_title: Little Christmas cheer in economies shattered by Ebola
summary: Ebola's devastating impact on Liberia and Sierra Leone has shattered the Christmas spirit, with thousands of traders struggling to stay afloat. The outbreak, which has claimed over 6,000 lives, has also killed off manufacturing and agriculture, with the World Bank predicting a regional growth rate below four percent and recession in Sierra Leone and Guinea next year. The economic cost is estimated to be over $2 billion, with food prices soaring and buying power decreasing by a fifth in Sierra Leone and over a quarter in Liberia.

site_title: Condo rents in Singapore down for 10th consecutive month: SRX
summary: Condo rental prices in Singapore fell 0.8% in November, marking the 10th consecutive month of decline. Year-over-year, rents dropped 5.3%. Suburban private apartments saw the largest drop, with city and city fringe apartments experiencing smaller declines. The number of units rented also decreased by 11% from October, but remains 9.8% higher than a year ago.

site_title: Asian shares mostly down, Shanghai recovers slightly
summary: Asian markets were mostly lower on Wednesday due to a sell-off in New York and Europe, with fears of Greece's return to instability. Shanghai's benchmark index recovered slightly after a 5.43% drop on Tuesday, while Tokyo fell 1.38% and Sydney shed 0.68%. Greek stocks plummeted 12.8% amid concerns over the country's fiscal reforms and potential snap general elections. Oil prices fell due to a global supply glut, while the dollar strengthened against the yen and euro.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 1.07%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 1.07% lower on Wednesday, following a global downtrend due to tightened Chinese lending rules and Greek political uncertainty. The Nikkei 225 index fell 190.03 points to 17,623.35. However, Skymark shares rose 9.09% after media reports suggested the airline may seek assistance from All Nippon Airways. Global equities markets were down, with Shanghai shares plummeting 5% and Greek stocks diving 12.78%.

site_title: Oil pares gains after industry data shows weekly US crude build
summary: US crude oil inventories rose 4.4 million barrels in the week to 377.4 million, exceeding analyst expectations for a decrease. Benchmark Brent crude was up 30 cents at $66.49 a barrel, while US crude was 33 cents higher at $63.38. The strong build in crude stocks pared gains after the data was released, with oil prices later settling.

site_title: Under pressure Swiss banks eye Chinese wealth
summary: Swiss banks are seeking new markets, particularly China, as they face the end of banking secrecy in 2017. The country has drawn closer to China, with a free-trade agreement and bilateral currency swap agreement in place. Swiss banks are looking to capitalize on China's growing wealth and establish Switzerland as an international hub for the renminbi. The sector aims to adapt to the loss of lucrative revenue from banking secrecy and mitigate the impact of probes and fines from countries accusing them of tax dodging.

site_title: US$100m China media fund launched in Singapore
summary: A US$100 million closed-end fund has been launched in Singapore to invest in China's media and entertainment industry. The five- to seven-year fund, backed by anchor investors Bona Film Group and Chia Tai Group, aims to generate returns of 20-30% annually. Yu Dong, a Chinese film producer, and Calvin Cheng, a former Nominated Member of Parliament, co-founded the fund with Tembusu Partners. The fund will be formalized on March 31, 2015, with fund-raising to begin after.

site_title: New woes may put brakes on Uber, ride-share growth
summary: Uber faces regulatory roadblocks worldwide, threatening its growth. The ride-sharing service has been banned or restricted in several cities, including Spain, India, Thailand, and the US, due to concerns over safety, competition, and consumer protection. Authorities have also filed complaints against Uber, citing issues with insurance, liability, and driver background checks. Despite its valuation of $40 billion, Uber's growth is being hindered by regulatory hurdles, with some advocates arguing that the system is self-regulating through user reviews.

images.alt_text: Uber, the ride-sharing service and Silicon Valley superstar startup, has hit problems around the world which threaten to put the brakes on its spectacular growth.

site_title: Climate funds exceed US$10b at Lima talks
summary: Rich countries at the UN global warming talks in Lima have pledged over $10 billion in climate aid for poor economies, exceeding the initial target of $10 billion. The pledges are for the Green Climate Fund, which will help vulnerable countries reduce carbon emissions. The US has contributed $3 billion, while Japan and France have pledged $1.5 billion and $1 billion respectively. However, some critics argue that Australia's pledge falls short of its fair share, and developing countries are seeking more predictable and robust information on public aid.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall to 3-week low, won erases gain on China data
summary: South Korea's won fell to a 3-week low against the dollar, erasing gains after China's November inflation pace was lower than expected, adding to concerns of a slowdown in South Korea's largest export destination. The won was quoted at 1,108.0 to the dollar, down from a peak of 1,103.0 earlier in the session. South Korean shares also slumped to a three-week low, with the main bourse down 0.91% due to worries over slowing Chinese growth and falling oil prices.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments, Huan Hsin
summary: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments acquired a 22.3% stake in Silvermane Investments for S$6 million, with S$2 million paid in cash and the balance in promissory notes when the Amayapampa Gold Project starts production.

site_title: Update: China's November inflation falls to 1.4%: govt
summary: China's consumer inflation fell to a five-year low of 1.4% in November, below the government's 2014 target of 3.5%. This marks a slowdown in the economy, which has been hit by disappointing manufacturing activity, tumbling property prices, and concerns over corporate and local government debt. Economists expect further policy easing measures, including interest rate cuts and reserve requirement ratio reductions, to stimulate the economy and mitigate the risk of deflation.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on Greek unrest, China slide, commodities drop
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% on Wednesday due to concerns over Greek unrest, China's economic slowdown, and weak commodities prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 27.17 points to 5256.40. Global banks led the decline, with Macquarie Group and QBE falling 1.7% and 2% respectively. Resources majors BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto gained 1% and 0.8% after iron ore prices fell.

site_title: Tencent CEO sells shares worth US$387m in the China internet firm
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd CEO Pony Ma sold 25 million shares worth HK$3 billion (US$387 million) between Dec 2 and Dec 5, citing personal wealth management. The sale, which accounted for less than 0.5% of the company's outstanding stock, leaves Ma as Tencent's largest individual shareholder with a 9.87% stake. Ma, 43, was reported to have recently bought into China's Ping An Insurance Group. The sale follows a 2011 sale of smaller Tencent shares.

site_title: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments buys into LionGold's former asset (Amended)
summary: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments acquired a 22.3% stake in Silvermane Investments, buying into LionGold's former Amayapampa Gold Project in Bolivia for S$6 million. The firm will pay the remaining balance through promissory notes, maturing within two years. The acquisition is expected to enable the firm to invest in the "highly prospective" mineral mining business, owning assets worth US$42 million to US$77 million.

site_title: MH17 wreckage arrives at Dutch base
summary: A convoy carrying wreckage from Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 arrived at a Dutch airbase, where it will be pieced together as part of a probe into its shooting down over Ukraine. The 298 people killed, mostly Dutch nationals, were victims of a missile attack on July 17. The Dutch Safety Board, leading the investigation, aims to establish the cause and identify culprits, with a reconstruction of the aircraft expected to take several months. The investigation seeks a criminal prosecution if the culprits can be identified, amid accusations of Russian involvement.

site_title: US extends scrutiny of Standard Chartered on sanctions compliance
summary: Standard Chartered will face three more years of scrutiny from US prosecutors for compliance with government sanctions against certain countries, following the expiration of its original deferred prosecution agreements. The bank agreed to extend the deals, which could result in harsher penalties if violations are found. The investigation is ongoing, with the bank hiring new staff and improving its compliance program. The bank paid $667 million in 2012 for violating US sanctions and faces another fine after a monitor uncovered shortcomings in its computers.

site_title: Judge bans Uber in Spain
summary: A Spanish judge has banned Uber from operating in Spain, citing lack of administrative authorization and unfair competition. The ruling also orders telecom companies and payment service providers to block Uber. Uber plans to review its options, but vows to respect Spanish law. Similar bans have been imposed in the Netherlands, France, and other countries, amidst growing controversy over the company's business practices.

site_title: New 'LuxLeaks' release drags Disney, Microsoft into tax scandal
summary: Luxembourg's tax avoidance "LuxLeaks" scandal expanded on Tuesday with the release of 28,000 pages of documents, revealing tax strategies used by multinationals such as Microsoft and Disney. The revelations, obtained by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, increase pressure on former Luxembourg prime minister Jean-Claude Juncker ahead of his swearing-in as European Commission president. The documents also shed light on the country's tax policies, fueling criticism of Juncker's tenure. The scandal has sparked renewed calls for greater transparency in tax practices across the EU.

site_title: Huan Hsin sells 51 per cent stake in JV to partner
summary: Huan Hsin Holdings, a Singapore-based contract manufacturer, sold its 51% stake in Hefei Baolong Hsin Technology to joint venture partner Shenzhen Bitland Information Technology for 6.19 million yuan (S$1.3 million). The sale is part of Huan Hsin's strategy to monetize non-yielding assets and increase working capital. The disposal was made after the company was placed on the Singapore Exchange's watchlist due to consecutive losses.

site_title: US Congress reaches deal for US$1.1t spending bill
summary: US Congress has reached a deal for a $1.1 trillion spending bill, resolving policy disputes and clearing final hurdles. The measure funds government agencies through September 2015, except for the Department of Homeland Security, which will be extended through late February. A bipartisan provision on distressed pension plans was removed and proposed as an amendment. The bill includes emergency funds for the Ebola outbreak and keeps domestic spending flat with last year. A stop-gap extension is expected to be passed to avoid a government shutdown at midnight on Thursday.

site_title: Time running out fast in climate fight: UN's Ban
summary: UN Secretary-General Ban Ki Moon urged nations to seize the shrinking opportunity to curb global warming, warning that the window of opportunity is fast narrowing. He called for progress on climate finance, adaptation support, and loss and damage mechanisms, as the Lima climate talks aim to draft a negotiating outline for the Paris deal. Despite optimism, key divisions remain, including climate financing and differentiation, with developing countries seeking a bigger share of the burden and developed nations focusing on mitigation efforts.

site_title: More gains ahead for China stocks: APS
summary: APS Asset Management expects China's stock markets to continue their rally, potentially gaining 20% over the next 12 months, despite no additional government stimulus. The firm's assets under management have returned 315% since its inception, outperforming the CSI 300 Index. APS's founder, Wong Kok Hoi, attributes the market's bullishness to China's restructuring and reform efforts, rather than a lack of liquidity. The company expects to raise about $1 billion in inflows next year, following a $100 million collection this year.

site_title: US class-action lawsuit adds to Petrobras woes
summary: A US class-action lawsuit was filed against Petrobras, accusing the Brazilian state oil giant of failing to disclose a "culture of corruption" that has led to plummeting shares. The lawsuit claims Petrobras issued false statements and overstated its value to hide a multi-billion dollar money-laundering and bribery scheme. The plaintiffs seek unspecified damages for losses suffered by investors who bought Petrobras ADS between May 2010 and November 2014, when shares lost 40% of their value.

site_title: EU states, parliament reach 2015 budget deal
summary: EU member states and the European parliament have reached a 2015 budget deal, agreeing to 141.2 billion euros in payments. The agreement includes an increase of 3.5 billion euros for the 2014 budget to address unpaid debts. The budget also includes 8 billion euros in seed money to support the EU economy. Finance ministers have urged France and Italy to reduce their deficits, threatening disciplinary action but offering wiggle room. The deal must be confirmed by the parliament's budgets committee by Thursday.

images.alt_text: Italy Finance Minister Pier Carlo Padoan welcomed the agreement, saying it tackles the "need to address the backlog of payments"

site_title: Qantas chief defends airline on three unscheduled landings
summary: Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce defended the airline after three unscheduled landings on Monday, citing its lower turn-back rate compared to the industry average. The incidents involved a Qantas A380 with a malfunctioning air-conditioning system, a Boeing 737 with a technical issue, and a 737 with an unusual odor. Joyce said Qantas' reliability record is better than most, with a turn-back rate of one per 18,000 sectors, compared to an industry average of one per 9,000 sectors.

site_title: Japan business mood sours as economy struggles with recession
summary: Japan's business mood has soured due to a struggling economy, with big manufacturers growing less optimistic in the October-December quarter. The business sentiment index fell to 8.1, down from 12.7 in the prior quarter, and is expected to slide further to 6.1 in the following quarter. The decline suggests a domestic demand-led recovery may not materialize, casting doubt on Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's pro-growth policies, known as "Abenomics." The economy slipped into recession in the third quarter after a sales tax hike in April.

images.alt_text: Big Japanese manufacturers grew less optimistic in October-December and they see conditions worsening further in the following quarter, a government survey showed on Wednesday, suggesting that the economy is slow to recover from a recession.

site_title: Barclays Capital upgrades NOL rating
summary: Barclays Capital upgraded its rating for Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) to 'overweight' due to a decline in stock price following the potential sale of its logistics unit. Analysts expect a sequential earnings recovery driven by cost reductions, but lowered the 12-month price target by 8% to S$0.95. A better-than-expected global economy in 2015-16 could see NOL shares appreciate to S$1.30, while a sustained economic recession could cause cash flow tightness. NOL shares closed at 82 Singapore cents.

site_title: World Bank lowers Russia's economic forecast as ruble falls
summary: The World Bank has lowered its economic forecast for Russia, predicting a 0.7% contraction in 2015 due to falling oil prices and sanctions over the Ukraine crisis. The ruble has fallen 40% against the dollar and 32% against the euro, prompting price rises and reduced spending. The central bank has intervened with billions of dollars to prop up the currency, but the ruble still fell on Tuesday. A best-case scenario sees the economy avoid recession if oil prices average $85, while a worst-case scenario predicts a 1.5% contraction and households in "a crisis mode" for 2015 and 2016.

site_title: OCBC tops buy volume with S$490.6m
summary: Global mutual funds were net buyers of Singapore stocks in the three months to Dec 3, with net buys totaling S$1.77 billion. The largest buy volume was in OCBC with S$490.6 million, while Ascendas Reit had the largest sell volume with S$72.4 million. This data, provided by ShareInvestor and Ipreo, offers insight into fund managers' market focus, but may not reflect the entire trading picture, as other investors may be trading without disclosing their trades.

site_title: Global sukuk record unlikely as 1Malaysia delays US$2.4b sale
summary: Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Bhd has delayed the sale of $2.4 billion in Islamic bonds, known as sukuk, until the first half of 2015, potentially missing the record-breaking year of 2012. This delay, combined with a slump in crude oil prices, may deter issuance and lead to a challenging year for sukuk sales. Global issuance is expected to be the worst quarter since 2013, with sales so far totaling $7.8 billion.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as European, Asian markets sink
summary: US stocks ended the day mixed, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 51.28 points (0.29%) to 17,801.20, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.49 (0.02%) to 2,059.82. Despite negative momentum from Asian and European markets, the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 25.77 (0.54%) to 4,766.47. The rally was attributed to analysts citing reports that the US Federal Reserve may move up its interest rate timeline, but Verizon's earnings warning and other company losses contributed to the mixed result.

site_title: Citigroup to post US$2.7b in added legal costs in Q4: CEO
summary: Citigroup will record $2.7 billion in litigation expenses and $800 million in repositioning charges in the fourth quarter, leaving the bank "marginally profitable." The costs stem from government investigations into foreign exchange markets and money laundering rules. CEO Mike Corbat has been trying to meet profit and efficiency targets, and the bank has reduced payroll by 20,000 jobs and real estate by 10 million square feet since he became CEO in 2012. The bank's stock closed down 1% to $55.85 following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Citigroup Inc will record US$2.7 billion in litigation expenses and another US$800 million in repositioning charges, leaving the third-largest US bank "marginally profitable" in the fourth quarter, its chief executive officer said on Tuesday.

site_title: Taxi app users boosting demand for limo service
summary: Taxi app users in Singapore are increasingly opting for higher-end limousine rides, with demand for Uber Black and GrabTaxi's premium services growing significantly. Prime Group, which supplies vehicles for Uber Black, has seen a 2-3 fold increase in demand since partnering with the service in March. The company's drivers now complete 10-15 trips per day, up from 5-6 daily previously. Meanwhile, GrabTaxi's GrabCar limousine service has also seen a rise in demand, particularly for larger vehicles. The growth is attributed to the "mismatch" between demand for and supply of taxis, as well as the convenience and appeal of booking on-demand.

site_title: Abbott drops plan for healthcare co-payment
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Tony Abbott has abandoned his plan to charge patients a fee to see their doctor as part of a revised healthcare system. The A$7 co-payment was heavily criticized by opposition and healthcare groups, and instead, the government will cut doctor rebates and encourage them to charge adults an A$5 fee, exempting children, the elderly, and those on state allowances. The policy change aims to save A$3.5 billion over four years, a decrease of A$100 million from the original budget proposal.

site_title: Cyber-attacks will worsen in 2015, warns McAfee
summary: McAfee warns that cyber-attacks will worsen in 2015, with hackers using advanced techniques to infiltrate networks, steal sensitive data, and target more connected devices such as healthcare IoT systems and industrial control systems. The report predicts an increase in cyber-warfare and espionage, as well as new strategies to hide tracks and steal money. Cyber-criminals will use better methods to remain hidden and carry out long-term theft of data without detection, making them more sophisticated nation-state cyber-espionage actors.

site_title: OECD: Income inequality slows growth significantly
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has found that income inequality significantly slows economic growth, particularly for the bottom 40% of society. The study, which analyzed the impact of inequality on US GDP growth between 1990 and 2010, found that it knocked about 6-7 percentage points off growth. To counteract this, policymakers should focus on the general welfare of the bottom 40%, not just poverty of the lowest 10%. The OECD recommends redistributive policies, such as tax changes targeting high earners and government transfers, to address inequality and promote strong and sustained growth.

site_title: JPMorgan cuts iron ore price forecasts on growth in supply
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has cut its iron ore price forecasts through 2017 due to growth in low-cost supply from the world's largest producers. The bank now expects prices to average US$67 a tonne next year, down 24% from previous forecasts, and US$65 in 2016, down 23%. Prices will average US$69 a tonne in 2017, 16% less. This reduction follows the current average price of US$98.95 a tonne this year.

site_title: Triumphant Merkel re-elected party chief with 97 per cent
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel was re-elected unopposed as the chief of her conservative party, the Christian Democratic Union (CDU), with 96.7% of the vote, marking her eighth term as party leader. Merkel emphasized her commitment to economic growth, budget discipline, and environmental standards, while warning against complacency in the face of future challenges. She also expressed confidence in resolving the Ukraine conflict diplomatically, citing her frequent contact with Russian President Vladimir Putin. Merkel's approval rating remains high at 67%, with 56% of Germans supporting her for a fourth term as chancellor.

site_title: RBS said to be seeking Coutts bids as early as this week
summary: RBS is seeking offers for its international private bank, Coutts, with about a dozen potential bidders signing confidentiality agreements. First-round offers are due by Dec 12, and the unit could fetch US$600-900 million.

site_title: Hybrid to remain core automobile technology: Lexus official
summary: Lexus remains confident that hybrid technology will be the core technology for automobiles in the future, despite the growing trend of electric mobility. Executive Vice President Mark Templin believes that current batteries are not capable of meeting the demands of electrification, and that a next-generation battery is needed. With 10 hybrid products globally, Lexus is well-positioned to capitalize on the growing demand for hybrids, particularly in Europe, where 90% of sales are hybrids. The company plans to continue expanding its global portfolio of products, including the popular NX compact crossover, which has brought in younger buyers to the luxury brand.

site_title: Export more diamonds to us, India to ask Russia
summary: India is set to persuade Russia to increase its diamond exports directly to the country, aiming to boost ties and the Indian gemstone industry. Russian state-controlled mining group Alrosa is due to sign long-term contracts with Indian companies during the World Diamond Conference in Delhi. Currently, only about a fifth of rough diamonds are sold directly from Russian mines to India, with the rest passing through diamond hubs such as Antwerp and Dubai. The move could help India's stuttering economy and boost bilateral trade.

site_title: Resales of apartments, condos up 6.6% in Nov
summary: Singapore's resale market saw a 6.6% year-over-year increase in November, with 388 non-landed private homes transacted. The median Transaction Over X-value (TOX) turned non-negative for the first time since October 2013, indicating buyers are paying above market value in some areas. Experts predict continued anaemic demand and stubborn prices until significant changes occur, with forecasted price declines ranging from 5-8% for non-landed private homes in 2015.

site_title: Honda to expand airbag recall globally
summary: Honda expands global recall for potentially lethal Takata airbag inflators, affecting over 19 million vehicles since 2008. The recall, initially limited to 11 US states, now covers an additional 2.6 million US vehicles and 200,000 in Japan. Honda is investigating which models and vehicles will be covered in other markets. The US NHTSA and Japan's transport ministry are reviewing their recall processes amid the crisis.

site_title: Banks, SGX prop up STI in weak session
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 22 points or 0.67% to 3,319.84, driven by a surge in bank shares, including SingTel and the Singapore Exchange (SGX), which jumped 0.25 to S$7.60 after Goldman Sachs raised its "buy" call on the stock. Despite a weak session, the market still recorded 156 gains versus 263 declines excluding warrants. The rest of the region was affected by a decline in China's Shanghai Composite, which ended 5% lower after a previous 2% gain.

site_title: Cheaper oil could continue into 2015, to global benefit
summary: Global oil prices have plummeted, losing over one-third of their market value in 2014, with crude oil falling 36% to below $70 a barrel. While some economists warn of potential budgetary and balance-of-payments deficits, cheaper oil could stimulate economic growth, particularly for large energy importers like India, China, Indonesia, and Japan. These countries could benefit from reduced fuel costs, boosting consumption and economic development. However, countries like Malaysia, a net oil exporter, may struggle to maintain budget deficit targets with falling oil prices.

site_title: Paris cleans up its act to draw more visitors
summary: Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo has unveiled an ambitious plan to reduce pollution and improve tourist experience. The plan includes banning diesel cars within five years, making central four districts pedestrian-only, and banning wood burning in the capital. The city aims to extend Sunday shopping rights to 12 times a year, including special exemptions for international tourist areas. While some Parisians oppose the measures, tourists welcome the changes, citing improved air quality and reduced traffic congestion. The city hopes to cement its position as one of the world's most visited cities.

site_title: Banks swap tips to deal with Fed stress tests
summary: US bank executives are sharing notes on the Federal Reserve's stress tests, which measure lenders' performance during economic downturns. The Fed keeps its methods secret to prevent banks from finding loopholes, but this lack of transparency frustrates banks, which often have different results. Executives have met in informal forums to discuss how to effectively communicate with regulators and improve their reports. The Fed will likely use stress tests to pressure banks to make their balance sheets safer, with capital requirements potentially increasing. The stress test process has been criticized for its opacity, with banks struggling to understand the Fed's expectations.

site_title: US port congestion hits cotton shipments
summary: US port congestion is causing delays of up to a week in shipping cotton to China, threatening exports ahead of a key Chinese deadline at the end of the month. The delays at Los Angeles and Long Beach ports, the two busiest container ports, are due to equipment shortages and increased container sizes, affecting both imports and exports. The US cotton industry is struggling with low prices and weakening demand, and some $1.56 billion in cotton was exported to China through September. Merchants are seeking alternative routes to meet the deadline, potentially increasing costs.

site_title: McDonald's tests customised menu to counter worst US sales slump since 2001
summary: McDonald's is testing a customized menu to boost US sales, which have slumped since 2001. The "Create Your Taste" program allows customers to pick toppings using a touch screen, with options including jalapenos and tortilla strips. The concept is expanding to five more states, including chicken, to appeal to millennials. This move aims to shake off McDonald's reputation for outdated fast food and offer more choice to customers.

site_title: Malaysia's 26,000 millionaires held US$151b last year
summary: Malaysia has approximately 26,000 millionaires with combined wealth of US$151 billion, with about three-quarters of their wealth invested overseas. The country's wealth is comparable to that of Argentina and Colombia, despite having a smaller population. WealthInsight analyst Tom Carlisle notes that Malaysia has "big potential for billionaire growth," highlighting the country's wealth disparity and limited success in policies to close the gap between the haves and have-nots.

site_title: Market cap of 23 O&M firms falls 15.7% in a month amid oil rout
summary: The market capitalization of 23 offshore and marine (O&M) firms in Singapore has declined 15.7% in a month due to declining oil prices. The industry is feeling the impact, with Keppel Corporation and Sembcorp Marine losing S$2.3 billion and S$1.5 billion respectively. Companies such as Swiber Holdings and Ezra Holdings have lost significant proportions of their market cap. Analysts predict a slowdown in oil and gas projects, with some firms like Nam Cheong seeing downgraded estimates due to lower oil prices.

site_title: Australian business confidence down in November
summary: Australia's business confidence fell to +1 in November, down four points from the previous month, according to a National Australia Bank survey. The decline in confidence is attributed to weaker commodities and labor market outlook, leading NAB to predict two interest rate cuts in 2015. Financial markets have already priced in at least one more rate cut, with commodity prices falling heavily in recent months. The decline in confidence also led to a drop in consumer sentiment, with the ANZ Roy Morgan index of consumer confidence falling 3.1% to its lowest in four months.

site_title: Bangladesh's 'mystic minstrels' soldier on with pipes of peace
summary: Bangladesh's "mystic minstrels," known as Bauls, continue to spread their message of peace and love despite attacks and persecution. Originating in the 17th century, the sect combines elements of Hinduism and Sufism, rejecting consumerism and promoting humanism. Their popularity is growing, attracting members of the rising middle class. Bauls renounce worldly possessions and travel on foot, singing and begging for alms. The sect's philosophy is gaining traction, with some Islamic hardliners opposing its blend of faiths. Bauls face daily humiliation and violence, but their message of inclusivity endures.

site_title: Treasuries record shows bears will lose
summary: Treasuries' yields are expected to rise as the Federal Reserve prepares to raise interest rates, according to economists and strategists.
