Despite a 5.1% rally in US government debt this year, yields on 30-year bonds have fallen to 2.97%, in line with historical norms. Experts attribute this to lackluster demand and low inflation, with forecasts predicting yields will reach 3.88% next year. The US economy's slow growth and global slowdown may also contribute to higher borrowing costs, with the Fed expected to raise rates in the second quarter of 2015.

site_title: China stocks correct 5.4% after Monday's steep rally
summary: China's stock market corrected 5.4% on Tuesday after a 6.5% surge on Monday, its highest level in three years. Despite the correction, some analysts, including Credit Suisse's Fan Cheuk Wan, expect the rally to continue due to relatively cheap valuations. The Shanghai Stock Exchange Composite Index is now trading at 9.6 times next year's earnings, compared to a 10-year average of 14.1 times. China's stock market remains the world's best performer this year, up 40% year-to-date.

site_title: PM Lee heads to S Korea for 3-day trip
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will visit South Korea for a 3-day trip, starting Wednesday, to attend a summit in Busan marking 25 years of Asean-Seoul dialogue. He will meet with South Korean President Park Geun-hye, review cooperation, and discuss regional issues. The summit will also focus on climate change, natural disasters, and security. This trip comes as trade between the two sides has grown from $8 billion in 1989 to $135 billion last year, with South Korea investing $3.8 billion in Asean last year.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Mr Lee will hold bilateral talks with South Korea's Ms Park in Busan. The leaders also met at the presidential Blue House in Seoul in December last year.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust's closing price on Dec 9, 2014, was S$0.315, with a target price of S$0.37.

site_title: SGX shares perk up amid broker's upbeat report
summary: SGX shares rose 3.4% on Tuesday after Goldman Sachs upgraded its 12-month target price to S$9.50, citing solid, sustained earnings growth over the next two years. The broker attributed this growth to the potential boom in China, which saw a year-on-year doubling of volumes in SGX's China A50 index futures. SGX stated it was unaware of any undisclosed information that might explain the unusual trading activity, which was the highest single-day volume in the past 12 months.

site_title: Haitong buys Novo Banco investment banking unit
summary: Haitong Securities Co, China's second-largest brokerage, will buy Novo Banco's investment banking unit for 379 million euros (S$618 million). The deal aims to expand outside China, improve client service capabilities, and share resources. The sale is dependent on regulatory approval from the Bank of Portugal and European Commission. This move follows a 22% increase in China's outbound investments in the nine months through September, with US$75 billion spent abroad. The acquisition will help Haitong develop cross-border operations and diversify its income geographically.

site_title: US dollar softens but fresh rises tipped
summary: The US dollar edged down against the yen on Tuesday, but analysts expect further advances as monetary policy in Japan and the US diverges. The dollar bought 120.18 yen in Tokyo, down from 120.78 yen in US trade on Monday. Experts expect the dollar to continue appreciating against the yen through 2015, with some predicting a level beyond 124.14 yen. The dollar also fell against other Asia-Pacific currencies, showing signs of overheating and prompting some traders to adjust positions.

site_title: SIAS president earns recognition for shareholder advocacy
summary: SIAS president David Gerald received the Investor Watchdog Peer Recognition 2014 award from the Minority Shareholders Watchdog Group (MSWG) in Malaysia for his contributions to corporate governance and investors' rights. Gerald co-founded and leads the Singapore investors' rights organisation, SIAS, which has almost 70,000 members. He helped establish SIAS in 1999 to address issues stemming from the Clob crisis, and expressed hope that his work will encourage responsible shareholder activism in Asean to push for better corporate governance.

site_title: Three New York airports set to get US$8b facelift over 10 years
summary: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey plans to spend approximately $8 billion over 10 years to improve the three major airports in the metropolitan area, including La Guardia, Kennedy International, and Newark Liberty International. The project aims to address the perception that the airports are "third-world" and to modernize their terminals. Delta Air Lines and JetBlue have already invested billions of dollars in improving their terminals, and the Port Authority is conducting design competitions to re-envision the airports for the 21st century. However, the congested airspace remains a significant obstacle to improving air travel in the area.

site_title: World central banks' stimulus could well accelerate next year
summary: Global central banks are set to add almost three times more liquidity in 2015 than they did in 2014, with a projected 13% expansion in their balance sheets. The US Federal Reserve and Bank of England will continue to hold onto their assets, while the Bank of Japan and European Central Bank will increase their assets through quantitative easing. This could lead to a global injection of $1.9 trillion in stimulus, with experts warning that the "QE infinity" trap may hinder growth. Policymakers aim to boost spending and risk-taking, but critics argue that the strategy may not be effective.

site_title: Mall in Little India offered for sale at S$320-350 million
summary: A Singapore mall, THE Verge, located in Little India, is being offered for sale with an indicative price of S$320-350 million. The six-storey mall and eight-storey building, anchored by supermarket Sheng Siong, offer 238,527 sq ft of retail space and are connected by link bridges. The sale comes as the surrounding area is set to undergo significant infrastructure improvements, including road widening and new MRT stations, which could enhance the property's value and potential for refurbishment or re-positioning.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Bipartisan proposal on US govt spending in the works
summary: US Congressional negotiators plan to release a bipartisan government spending proposal, resolving disputes over Republican policy proposals. The bill, set to fund most government operations through September 2015, includes renewal of a terrorism insurance program and repeal of part of the Dodd-Frank law. However, Senate Democrats aim to strip out the Republican provisions, and the Department of Homeland Security's funding will only last through February. The agreement is seen as a victory for Republican leaders seeking to clear their agenda.

site_title: Surprising rise in Oct wholesale inventories augurs well for Q4
summary: US wholesale inventories rose 0.4% in October, exceeding expectations, which could boost fourth-quarter growth forecasts. The increase in inventories, excluding autos, was 0.6%, and auto inventories fell 1.4% due to strong sales. Job openings reached 4.83 million, the second-highest level in 14 years, as companies seek to boost headcount amid accelerating growth. Economists expect the manufacturing sector to continue growing next year, with revenue and investment increasing.

site_title: Global pharma firms interested in local startup's new glaucoma treatment
summary: A local Singaporean biotech startup, Peregrine Ophthalmic, has attracted interest from the world's top five pharmaceutical companies with its new glaucoma treatment, liposomal latanoprost. The treatment, a sustained release nanomedicine product, has shown promising results in clinical trials and aims to improve patient compliance and reduce healthcare costs. The company, founded by Prof Tina Wong and two NTU researchers, plans to conduct a multi-center trial on at least 300 patients in 2015 and is seeking FDA approval to accelerate commercialization.

site_title: Hollande's 'Tartuffe' Syndrome
summary: France is at risk of a catastrophe due to President François Hollande's inability to honor his political pledges, mainly due to factors beyond his control, such as the European Monetary Union. His approach is likened to Molière's "Tartuffe", where pride and reason dictate actions, leading to disastrous consequences. Hollande's failures risk miring the economy in stagnation and driving an angry French public to elect the far-right National Front party's Marine Le Pen as his successor, potentially leading to a dramatic shift in the country's politics.

site_title: Tanker rates rise as US refiners boost shipments to Latin America
summary: US refiners are boosting shipments to Latin America, driving up tanker rates to the highest level in at least three years. Refined fuels are in high demand, with vessels carrying 38,000 tonnes earning an average of $31,050 a day. This surge underscores the US's increasing ability to process crude into fuels, with record numbers of vessels hired to move oil products to the region. The export market has strengthened, with traders booking record shipments to Latin America and the Caribbean, and shipments to Europe also increasing.

site_title: Transformation of GIC
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, GIC, has undergone a significant transformation under the leadership of Lim Chow Kiat, its group chief investment officer. GIC has shifted away from its traditional endowment model of strategic asset allocation, becoming one of the world's most aggressive sovereign wealth funds. The fund now takes a more active approach, deviating from its portfolio to beat the market. GIC's new strategy has led to direct investments in over 100 companies and a significant increase in real estate investments. The fund's performance has improved, with a 20-year nominal annual rate of return of 6.5%. GIC's strong reputation and leadership, exemplified by Lim Siong Guan and Lim Chow Kiat, have enabled it to capitalize on global opportunities and maintain its position as one of the world's top sovereign wealth funds.

site_title: 2015 positive for S'pore equity, debt markets: OCBC
summary: OCBC Bank predicts a positive 2015 for Singapore's equity and debt markets, driven by Asia's buoyant economies. The bank expects more companies to opt for corporate IPOs rather than Reits, which may take a backseat due to the impending tax exemption on foreign-sourced income. Meanwhile, the bond market is expected to remain strong, with a 20% increase in 2014 and potential growth in 2015, driven by Asia's need for funding and low interest rates.

site_title: Bond traders double down on non-inflation in US ETFs
summary: Bond traders are reducing their bets on inflation in the US, as weaker growth abroad and lower expectations for US consumer price gains. The iShares 20+ Year Treasury Bond ETF has seen a 22.6 percentage point drop in its share price since October, and short interest in the iShares 7-10 Year Treasury Bond ETF has increased by 6.5 percentage points. This suggests investors are becoming more cautious about inflation, which was a key concern earlier in the year.

site_title: Pension funds turn to shipping industry for better returns
summary: Pension funds are exploring investments in the shipping industry to generate higher returns, driven by a potential recovery in the market. Ship financier NordLB predicts a broad recovery by 2016, as signs of a gradual pick-up in world trade and ship values emerge. This shift comes as pension funds face low interest rates, making them seek alternative investment opportunities. The potential investment in shipping could provide a boost to the industry, which has been hit hard by the financial crisis.

site_title: US sues Deutsche Bank for fraud
summary: The US government has sued Deutsche Bank for allegedly creating shell companies to avoid paying tens of millions of dollars in taxes on a $100 million stock sale. The bank claims the issue was settled five years ago, but the US attorney says it's pursuing the case again. The US seeks $190 million in back taxes and penalties. Deutsche Bank plans to defend itself vigorously against the claims.

site_title: Hunger Games in pole position with US$258.2m in takings
summary: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1 remains the top-grossing film in North America for a third straight week, earning US$22 million and boosting its total to US$258.2 million. It took second place behind animated-animal film The Penguins of Madagascar, which earned US$10.9 million. Other notable films include Interstellar, Dumb and Dumber To, and The Theory of Everything, which rounded out the top 10.

site_title: China mulls tax cuts for iron ore miners
summary: China is considering tax cuts for domestic iron ore miners amid a global supply glut, tumbling prices, and increased imports. Current tax rates of 20-30% may be reduced to below 10% to improve competitiveness. Lower domestic prices would likely reduce China's reliance on imports, benefiting local firms and the economy. The move aims to create a "fair environment" for local and foreign miners, balancing the supply ratio between domestic and overseas supplies.

site_title: One in 4 views of digital video ads faked by bots: study
summary: A study by the Association of National Advertisers found that one in four views of digital video ads and 11% of other display ads are faked by bots, costing advertisers an estimated $6.3 billion globally in 2015. Hackers use malicious software to hijack computers, creating "botnets" that watch videos and click on ads, inflating viewership and prices for advertisers. The study's findings could undermine confidence in the online advertising industry, which is projected to nearly double in value by 2018.

site_title: Uber told to cease ops in Thailand, India
summary: Thailand has ordered Uber to cease operations, citing drivers' lack of registration and insurance, as well as non-compliance with regulations. This decision comes on the same day that taxi apps were banned in New Delhi, India, where an Uber driver is under arrest for suspected rape. Vietnam is set to discuss regulating online cab services, including Uber, after branding it illegal.

site_title: Rescuing refugees off the high seas
summary: Asylum seekers from war-torn Middle Eastern countries continue to attempt crossing the Mediterranean to reach Europe, despite rougher weather conditions. Merchant ships have been heavily involved in rescuing refugees, but some EU governments have expressed concerns that reducing search and rescue operations could lead to more deaths at sea. The Italian government's Mare Nostrum operation is ending and being replaced by the EU-funded 'Triton' operation, which will have a reduced scope and budget. International maritime law and humanitarian organizations emphasize the obligation to rescue those in distress at sea, regardless of policy changes.

site_title: Natas still holds out hope of making peace
summary: Natas, Singapore's National Association of Travel Agents, still hopes to reconcile with a group of travel agencies that broke away to organize a rival travel fair. The opposing camp has made "untrue" remarks about Natas, according to association president Devinder Ohri. Natas has brought forward its March 2015 fair to March 6-8, citing concerns about having two fairs on the same day. The rival fair will take place on March 27-29. Natas expects its fair to attract a 10-20% increase in visitors.

site_title: Beirut's "fairytale" villa comes back to life
summary: A 71-year-old Lebanese woman's brother, a painter, used Rose House as a meeting place for artists in the 1960s and 1970s. The villa, once a symbol of Beirut's romantic past, fell into disrepair but has been taken in by British painter Tom Young, who plans to use it as an art centre until the end of the year. Owner Hisham Jaroudi plans to renovate and turn it into a museum to preserve Beirut's history. The move aims to save the city's remaining old villas, which have dwindled from 1,200 to 400 since 1995.

site_title: China corporate debt yields hit by collateral rule
summary: China's clearing house disqualifies higher-risk corporate bonds from being used as collateral for bond repurchase agreements, a move that could exclude over $100 billion in bonds. The China Securities Depository and Clearing Corp (CSDC) tightened rules, citing rising yields and increased risks. The move is part of efforts to crack down on fixed income trade and push local governments away from opaque financing vehicles. Analysts predict the exclusion of lower-grade bonds will depress demand, put upward pressure on yields, and further spur the migration of capital into Chinese stock markets.

site_title: Season's readings
summary: A National Library of Singapore staff idea to create a 3.6-m Christmas tree using 2,000 donated used books has sprouted. The tree is on display at the NLB building's lobby and aims to promote the joy of reading. The initiative serves as a reminder that reading remains a worthwhile pursuit, regardless of the season. The books will be donated to charities later.

site_title: Tech leaders put money into petition site Change.org
summary: Tech leaders, including Bill Gates, Jerry Yang, Evan Williams, and Richard Branson, have invested $25 million in Change.org, a petition site that allows users to create online petitions calling on governments and companies to act on specific issues. The investment will be used to expand the company's engineering team, invest in mobile development, and engage with users. Change.org has already raised nearly $20 million and has over 80 million users worldwide, with a majority of new users coming from abroad. The company is a B corporation, allowing it to prioritize social and environmental performance over shareholder value.

site_title: How to restore confidence and take the local market forward
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) faces criticism for its handling of trading issues, including computer glitches and a decline in market confidence. Instead of debating blame, stakeholders should work together to tackle problems and take the market forward. The proposed starting point is to dismantle the dual-role, commercially-driven regulator model, which many believe is an anachronism. A new approach, similar to Australia's, where the exchange operator licence is granted to a non-profit regulator, could be considered. Addressing issues such as continuous all-day trading, clearing fee caps, and private placements is also crucial for market revival, and cooperation among stakeholders is essential.

site_title: Daughter of KAL's CEO quits over macadamia incident
summary: Korean Air's CEO Cho Hyun-Ah, daughter of the airline's CEO, resigned on December 9, 2014, after being criticized for kicking off a flight's chief purser due to the way macadamia nuts were served. The incident caused a 12-minute delay and sparked a state probe over possible aviation safety law breaches. Cho, 40, retained her vice-president title despite resigning from all posts, and apologized for the trouble caused. The incident drew widespread criticism in South Korea, with many calling for punishment and greater accountability.

site_title: Madison Avenue sees hard slog, but respectable growth
summary: Madison Avenue is expected to experience steady growth in worldwide advertising spending of 4.8 to 5 per cent in 2015, despite a tough economic climate. Industry leaders, including Martin Sorrell of WPP, predict that advertisers will continue to face pressure to reduce costs and that the industry will trudge ahead from the previous year. However, gains in digital ad sales and improving economic conditions in markets such as India and the US are expected to contribute to the steady growth. Despite the challenges, the industry is seen as being in reasonably good shape, with growth in digital and mobile ad spending expected to continue.

site_title: US: Wall St slides on growing global demand concerns
summary: US stocks fell sharply on Tuesday due to concerns about the impact of lower oil prices on the global economy and the effect of Greek political turmoil on the euro zone. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 139.81 points, the S&P 500 lost 16.9 points, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 51.08 points. Overnight, the Shanghai Composite Index dropped over 5%, its largest decline in five years, further weighing on investor sentiment.

site_title: Fed officials ponder pledge to keep interest rates low
summary: Federal Reserve officials are discussing the future of their vow to keep interest rates low for a "considerable time" ahead of a meeting next week. Fed officials, including President Dennis Lockhart and Vice-Chairman Stanley Fischer, are weighing the pledge against signs of economic strength, including strong job creation data. The decision comes as investors have bet on a rate hike as early as next June, citing a rise in the central bank's preferred gauge of price pressures. Officials are cautious, with Lockhart expressing concerns about raising rates too soon, and Fischer emphasizing the need for guidance.

site_title: More firms offer flexible work arrangements
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower released its latest Conditions of Employment report, showing that 47% of private sector establishments and 89% of employers offer flexible work arrangements. The most prevalent arrangements are part-time work (36%), flexi-time (12%), and staggered hours (11%). However, the proportion of establishments providing marriage and compassionate leave has declined slightly since 2012, with 71% of employers offering marriage leave and 89% offering compassionate leave.

site_title: Cheaper oil is a slippery business
summary: Global oil prices have declined by 40% since June, sparking concerns that this may be a sign of a new, cheaper source of crude or a collapse in demand. However, experts argue that the impact of lower oil prices is largely about shifting the distribution of income, with oil-exporting countries losing revenue and oil-importing countries gaining. The total global GDP impact is estimated to be less than 1%, with some countries, such as Europe and the US, gaining significant benefits, while others, like the Middle East and former Soviet Union, lose substantial revenue.

site_title: Financing and marketing needed to spur diamond market growth: Bain
summary: The diamond market is expected to experience growth due to rising demand in the US and limited supplies. According to consultancy Bain, the market grew 2-4% in 2013 and is expected to remain strong in the next decade if the industry focuses on driving demand and maintaining a positive image. However, challenges to growth include access to financing and increased marketing efforts.

site_title: Americans warm to wearable tech devices, Europeans cooler: Forrester
summary: Forrester Research predicts that wearable tech devices will see a significant increase in adoption in 2015, with the number of users tripling to 10 million, primarily driven by the release of the Apple Watch. The study suggests that Americans are warming up to the idea of wearing a computer on their wrists or clothing, while Europeans remain more skeptical. The report anticipates a breakout year for the trend, which was initially met with concerns about fashion and functionality.

site_title: India may change rules on gold imports for star trading houses: source
summary: India is set to announce changes to its gold import rules, potentially giving "star trading houses" more flexibility in their gold imports and exports. The changes, expected to be announced this week, may clarify the fate of these firms, which were previously mandated to export 100% of their imports. The moves follow India's easing of restrictions on gold imports, which were imposed in 2013 to address a trade deficit. The changes aim to provide a "free hand" to traders, allowing them to import and export gold without restrictions.

site_title: Financial watchdogs rethink plans to regulate big investment funds
summary: Financial watchdogs are revising plans to regulate the world's biggest investment funds due to concerns that original proposals would hinder infrastructure investments. The Financial Stability Board's (FSB) revised plans focus on activities rather than fund size, considering risks such as outflows of money in stressed markets and contagion. The move aims to balance the need to reduce risks with the importance of nurturing market-based finance, including fund investments in infrastructure projects. Revised plans are expected to be published by early 2015.

site_title: Dubai's world-beating skyscraper now in Google Street View
summary: Google has added Dubai to its Street View, allowing users to explore the city's landmarks, including the 830m-tall Burj Khalifa skyscraper and the Dubai Mall. The online pictorial map provides views of the city's pedestrian walkways, highways, beaches, and Dubai Creek. This is the first time a location from the United Arab Emirates has appeared on Google Street View. The addition offers armchair travelers a unique perspective on Dubai's architecture and daily life.

site_title: Investors must re-examine assumptions about India
summary: Investors should re-examine their assumptions about India, as the country's equity markets have outperformed China's despite an economic slowdown. India's business cycle is in an upturn, driven by a stabilizing macroeconomic outlook, business cycle turnaround, and political change. The new administration under Prime Minister Narendra Modi is focused on making existing things work better, with recent reforms such as simplifying labor laws and rolling back diesel subsidies. Foreign investors are cautious due to market volatility, but conditions in India are similar to those in 2004, which saw significant growth in the equity market.

site_title: US small business confidence jumps to near 8-year high
summary: US small business confidence reached a near 8-year high in November, increasing 2.0 points to 98.1, according to the National Federation of Independent Business. Business owners are optimistic about sales and earnings over the next six months, but remain cautious about capital spending and hiring. They expect strong sales growth through price cuts, while steadily raising wages for workers. This surge in optimism suggests the economy is poised for faster growth in 2015, despite expected slower growth in the fourth quarter.

site_title: UK bank credit ratings could be hurt by retail separation: S&P
summary: UK banks' credit ratings may be negatively affected by plans to separate their domestic retail banking operations, according to Standard & Poor's. The Bank of England requires lenders to ring-fence their retail businesses by 2019, which could lead to increased costs for customers and reduced credit supply. Ratings agency S&P warns that banks may pass on costs to customers, and that credit supply could be squeezed, potentially leading to lower credit ratings. The separation of functions could also disrupt economies of scale, negatively affecting earnings and bank funding.

site_title: Brent crude oil rebounds after hitting 5-year low
summary: Brent crude oil prices rebounded to near US$67 a barrel after hitting a 5-year low, as buyers emerged in anticipation of a price bottom following a 40% slide since June. The price drop is attributed to fast-growing US shale output, which has disrupted Opec's ability to manage supplies, leading to a large oil glut forecast for early next year.

site_title: China must honour joint declaration with Britain on HK
summary: China's refusal to grant visas to British MPs investigating the implementation of the Sino-British Joint Declaration on Hong Kong has raised concerns about China's commitment to the treaty, which allows Hong Kong a high degree of autonomy until 2047. China's deputy ambassador stated that the Joint Declaration is now void, contradicting the treaty's terms. This move has sparked debate about China's adherence to international treaties and its obligations to the UK and Hong Kong. The UK's Foreign Affairs Committee is set to conduct an inquiry into the UK's relations with Hong Kong, with the outcome potentially impacting China's international reputation.

site_title: Cheaper oil compounding protracted commodities slump
summary: Cheaper oil is exacerbating the longest commodity slump in a generation, with prices expected to drop further due to surpluses in copper and sugar, and a slowing Chinese economy. The Bloomberg Commodity Index is on track for a fourth consecutive annual decline, with Brent crude tumbling 41% since June to $66.19 a barrel. This will lead to lower costs for mining companies and farmers, potentially dropping corn, cotton, and gold prices, but may also hurt US farmers who have already bought inputs for the current season.

site_title: London police sell HQ for US$578.9m to Abu Dhabi investment firm
summary: London's Metropolitan Police Service sold its New Scotland Yard headquarters for £370 million (US$578.9 million) to Abu Dhabi Financial Group, exceeding the listed price by £120 million. The site, home to the police since 1967, will be redeveloped into luxury apartments and a new landmark. The sale is part of cost-saving measures and relocation efforts, which aim to reduce the force's running costs by £6 million annually. The funds will be used to balance the police's budget and invest in new equipment and technology.

site_title: China to simplify rules for interbank FX market
summary: China's State Administration of Foreign Exchange announced simplification of rules for the interbank foreign exchange market, effective January 1. This change allows financial companies to trade freely in the market, aiming to increase market efficiency. The move is part of China's efforts to liberalize its currency markets and promote financial innovation.

site_title: Singapore Exchange unaware of reason for 'unusual' trading in own shares
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) issued a statement regarding unusual trading activity in its own shares, with over 8 million shares changing hands, more than four times the 200-day daily average. The share price rose 3.4% to close at S$7.60, its highest since August 2013. The exchange stated it is unaware of any information that might explain the unusual activity, which comes amid pressure on its equity business due to falling volumes and technical problems.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 2.74 points to close at 1,738.1 on Wednesday, with 1.44 billion lots valued at RM1.70 billion traded. The market saw 647 losers and 216 gainers.

site_title: Singapore, US finalise agreement on tax evasion
summary: Singapore and the US have finalized an information-sharing agreement to combat offshore tax dodging. The deal allows financial institutions in Singapore to report US account holder information to the local tax authority, which will then send it to the US Internal Revenue Service. This simplifies the compliance process for US tax law and avoids the need for firms to deal directly with US tax authorities, thereby avoiding a 30% withholding tax on US investment income. The agreement comes into effect on January 1, 2015, under the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act of 2010.

site_title: French-American software start-up to launch automatic password changer
summary: A French-American software start-up, Dashlane.com, is launching the world's first mainstream automatic password changer to combat the issue of humans managing passwords. The company acquired PassOmatic, a New York start-up, and plans to incorporate the password changer into its products in the coming weeks. Dashlane has three million users and aims to counter hackers with its new offering, which aims to simplify password management.

site_title: EU states, parliament agree new 2015 budget
summary: EU member states and the European parliament have reached a deal on a new 2015 budget, worth 141.2 billion euros (US$174.5 billion). The agreement comes after a gap was bridged on a recalculation of member state contributions, with Britain paying an extra 2.1 billion euros. The budget includes 8 billion euros in seed money for the EU economy and aims to address unpaid debts totaling 25-30 billion euros. The agreement is expected to be formally confirmed on Thursday, with the European Council and parliament to take final decisions on Friday and December 17, respectively.

site_title: UAE to activate China currency swap soon: central banker
summary: The UAE central bank plans to activate its 35 billion yuan (US$5.7 billion) currency swap agreement with China soon, according to a senior official. The agreement, signed in 2012, aims to facilitate trade and investment between the two countries. However, the arrangement has seen little use in practice, with most UAE trade conducted in dollars. The UAE's central bank is now eager to activate the swap, with a possible yuan clearing centre also being considered, but no plans to diversify into the yuan for its foreign reserves.

site_title: Malala's blood-soaked uniform to go on show
summary: Malala Yousafzai, the 17-year-old Nobel Peace Prize laureate, will display her blood-soaked school uniform, which she wore when shot by the Taliban, at a Stockholm exhibition. The uniform is a memento from her traumatic experience and a reminder of her courageous fight for education and women's rights. Malala shares the peace prize with Kailash Satyarthi, an Indian campaigner who has fought for 35 years to free children from virtual slave labor. The display is part of Malala's ongoing efforts to raise awareness about the importance of education and her personal struggle for survival.

site_title: Reducing inequality would boost economic growth: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) reports that reducing income inequality between rich and poor citizens can boost economic growth. A 30-year study found that widening gaps between lower middle-class and poor households negatively impacted growth. Policies to reduce inequality, such as investing in education and redistributing wealth through taxes, are recommended. The OECD states that such policies would not harm growth if well-designed and implemented. This conclusion is supported by data from developed countries, where reduced inequality led to higher GDP per capita in Spain, France, and Ireland.

site_title: Trucks carrying MH17 wreckage arrive in the Netherlands
summary: Trucks carrying the wreckage of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17, which crashed in eastern Ukraine on July 17, 2014, arrived in the Netherlands. The Boeing 777, which killed all 298 people, was hit by a surface-to-air missile, with Washington attributing the strike to pro-Russian rebels. Relatives of victims waited outside a Dutch airbase, where investigators will attempt to rebuild the airliner. The Netherlands launched the largest criminal investigation in its history, and the wreckage was transferred under a deal with Ukrainian authorities. Experts will now photograph, scan, and categorize the debris to reconstruct the plane.

site_title: Lufthansa sees strike costs at around 200 mln euros
summary: Lufthansa estimates that strikes may have cost it around 200 million euros (US$247 million) this year, with the previous eight pilot strikes costing 160 million euros. The airline's Lufthansa German Airlines unit cited customer dissatisfaction after two recent walkouts by pilots led to the cancellation of thousands of flights. The strikes, which occurred in addition to other airport staff disruptions, significantly impacted the airline's operations.

site_title: UK Oct factory output slides, hit by electronics, after strong
summary: UK factory output fell 0.1% in October, with a 0.7% decline in manufacturing output, driven by a 4.5% drop in electronic products. This marks the biggest monthly decline since May. Despite this, there are signs that Britain's economy will avoid a sharp slowdown at the end of the year. The Bank of England has signaled it will keep interest rates low, and consumer spending has been the main driver of the recovery so far.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 22 points to 3,319.84. The trading volume was 1.58 billion shares, valued at S$1.18 billion. The market saw a mix of gainers and losers, with 156 stocks rising and 263 falling.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end lower on profit-taking, China slump
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 2.3% on Tuesday due to profit-taking and a slump in Chinese stocks. The China Enterprises index dropped 4.6% to its biggest single-day loss since 2011. Chinese shares listed on the Hong Kong bourse fell sharply, with the Hang Seng Index down 2.3% to 23,485.83 points. The slump was partly attributed to a reduction in Chinese investment in Hong Kong through the mutual market access pilot programme.

site_title: Japan's beef bowl - symbol of deflation - to get price hike
summary: Japan's Yoshinoya Holdings Co will raise the price of its signature beef bowl dish, "gyuudon," by 27% to 380 yen (S$4.17) due to higher import costs and the yen's depreciation. This marks the first price hike for the dish in 24 years, aimed at reversing Japan's deflationary economy and meeting the central bank's 2% inflation target. The move is a welcome boost for the Bank of Japan, which has been struggling to achieve its inflation target.

site_title: Indonesia's bad loans expected to rise by year end
summary: Indonesia's central bank expects bad loans to rise to 2.4% of outstanding loans by year-end, up from 1.8% in 2013, but still manageable. The bank forecasts annual loan growth at 11-12%, the slowest pace since 2010, due to tightened monetary policy. GDP growth is expected to slow, with a 5.01% growth in the third quarter, but is forecast to pick up to 5.1-5.8% next year. The bank aims to keep non-performing loans below 5%.

site_title: Amazon adds bidding option to site for fine art, collectables
summary: Amazon has added a bidding option to its website for fine art and collectibles, allowing customers to negotiate prices with third-party sellers. The new feature, called "make-an-offer," is distinct from an auction and allows customers to submit private offers that sellers can accept, reject, or counter. The option is expected to expand to hundreds of thousands of items in 2015, including rare items like a signed Babe Ruth baseball. The move represents Amazon's renewed attempt to move beyond its fixed-price model and increase sales.

site_title: Thailand rules Uber illegal, orders to halt taxi services
summary: Thai transport authorities have ordered Uber to halt its operations, deeming the ride-hailing service illegal due to unregistered drivers and non-compliant credit-card payment systems. The Department of Land Transport fined drivers who use personal vehicles for commercial use 2,000 baht (US$61) and plans to impose higher penalties. This decision comes after a passenger in New Delhi reported being raped by an Uber driver, prompting authorities to ban all unregistered internet taxi firms in the Indian capital.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 0.68% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.68% lower on Tuesday, marking the end of a seven-day winning streak. The Nikkei 225 index fell 122.26 points to 17,813.38, while the Topix index dropped 11.49 points to 1,436.09. A decline in crude prices and a strong yen weighed on Japanese shares, with the Bank of Japan's campaign to lift inflation also under threat. Analysts predicted further profit-taking and possible rounds of quantitative easing.

site_title: China: Shanghai stock exchange plunges 5.43% at close
summary: Shanghai shares plummeted 5.43% on Tuesday, the largest decline since August 2009, amid profit-taking following a surprise interest rate cut and new corporate bond rule that restricts short-term financing. The drop was driven by a surge in leverage among brokerages, which is expected to curb investors' ability to trade on margin. Heavyweight financial plays were heavily impacted, while firms in southern China, such as Xiamen XGMA Machinery, bucked the trend on hopes for a new free-trade zone.

site_title: India should allow banks to hold gold as reserves: WGC
summary: India should allow banks to hold gold as part of their liquidity reserves, reducing the need for imports and promoting domestic trade. The World Gold Council recommends setting up an exchange for transparent gold pricing and streamlining trade. This would motivate banks to introduce gold deposit schemes, circulating existing bullion within the country. The current re-export rule, which has been scrapped, had curbed gold supplies but failed to curb consumer demand. Allowing banks to hold gold as reserves could make India's gold a productive, fungible asset class like other financial savings.

site_title: Germany's BMW appoints new chief from 2015
summary: BMW appoints Harald Krueger, 49, as new chief executive, replacing Norbert Reithofer, who will be put forward for election to the supervisory board in 2015. The company aims to maintain its leading role in the premium segment by handing over responsibility to the next generation. Krueger will take over in May, and Klaus Froehlich has been named as a new board member responsible for development to replace Herbert Diess, who joined rival Volkswagen.

images.alt_text: German top-of-the-range carmaker BMW announced a shake-up at its helm Tuesday, appointing a new chief executive and proposing a new head of the supervisory board.

site_title: Cargill may invest US$1b in Indonesia over next four years
summary: Cargill Inc plans to invest US$1 billion in Indonesia over the next four years, with a focus on expanding its cocoa processing facilities and entering the poultry sector. CEO David MacLennan aims to increase cocoa grinding capacity to above 70,000 tonnes per year. The company also plans to explore opportunities in the poultry sector, citing its potential as a "good place for us to play." This investment is part of Cargill's efforts to strengthen its presence in the Indonesian market.

site_title: Australia regulator calls on banks to curb investor mortgage growth
summary: Australia's prudential regulator, APRA, has asked banks to limit investor mortgage growth to 10% per year and add a 2% interest rate buffer to assess borrowers' ability to repay. APRA aims to address risks in the frothy housing market, where lending to investors has surged to its highest since 1991. The regulator will review banks' lending practices in 2015 and may take supervisory actions, including raising capital levels for erring lenders. APRA Chairman Wayne Byres described the measures as a "measured and targeted response" to emerging pressures in the housing market.

site_title: Indonesia October retail sales up 17.6% year-on-year
summary: Indonesia's October retail sales rose 17.6% year-on-year, a slower pace than the 17.9% growth in September. This slowdown is attributed to weaker demand for cultural and recreational goods. Retailers expect sales growth to continue slowing until November, with concerns over increasing fuel prices and distributor goods. Businesses also anticipate a slowdown in annual sales growth in April due to softer demand.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's annual retail sales in October grew at a slightly slower pace of 17.6 per cent compared with 17.9 per cent in September, due to weaker demand for cultural and recreational goods, a Bank Indonesia survey showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Asian shares retreat on profit-taking, oil slump
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday, with Shanghai plummeting 5% and Tokyo falling 0.68% after a week of gains. Energy firms, including Santos and BHP Billiton, were heavily impacted by oil prices hitting 5-year lows. The Nikkei dropped 122.26 points to 17,813.38, snapping a 7-session winning streak. Profit-taking and oil slump were the main drivers behind the retreat.

site_title: China's yuan set for largest single-day loss since 2008
summary: China's yuan dropped to 6.2059 per dollar by midday Tuesday, marking its largest single-day loss since 2008. The currency slid over half a percent in morning trade, following a surprise interest rate cut by China's central bank, seen as bearish for the yuan. The yuan's slide accelerated on Monday, when it lost 0.37% by market close.

site_title: HDB gives its resale price index more oomph
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has revised its resale price index (RPI) to better reflect market changes. The revised approach will cover all towns and flat models, excluding 12 previously excluded towns. The new method, stratified hedonic regression, aims to screen out "noises" in measuring price changes, providing a more comprehensive and robust index. This change is intended to make the RPI more reflective of market dynamics, allowing for more accurate analysis of property prices. The revised RPI is expected to be more representative of the market.

site_title: Jurong Aromatics to shut Singapore plant mid-Dec for maintenance
summary: Jurong Aromatics Corporation plans to shut its 100,000 barrels per day petrochemical complex in Singapore from mid-December for maintenance. The company cited an unfavorable market for petrochemicals to re-calibrate production and improve efficiency. The plant has been experiencing issues that reduced production, and no details on the shutdown duration are available. SK Group and Jiangsu Sanfangxiang Group are the largest shareholders of Jac.

site_title: German labour costs increase at sharpest rate since early 2013
summary: German labour costs rose 2.3% in the third quarter, the sharpest rate since early 2013, with employers spending 2.0% more on gross earnings and 3.4% more on non-wage labour costs. This increase is likely to boost eurozone neighbours' competitiveness, making German goods more attractive.

site_title: Korean Air apologises over VP's nuts incident
summary: Korean Air has apologized for an incident in which its executive vice-president, Cho Hyun-Ah, had a chief purser ejected from a plane after being served macadamia nuts incorrectly. The airline acknowledged that forcing the plane to return to the gate caused an unreasonable delay. Cho Hyun-Ah, 40, was criticized for her behavior, described as heavy-handed and imperious. The incident is being investigated by South Korea's Transport Minister, who vowed to handle any regulatory breach "sternly."

images.alt_text: Korean Air has apologised over an incident in which the daughter of the airline's CEO had a chief purser ejected from a plane in a furious reaction to being incorrectly served some macadamia nuts.

site_title: Natas urges 'breakaway group' to make peace
summary: The National Association of Travel Agents Singapore (Natas) has urged the "breakaway group" of 24 travel agencies to resolve their differences and make peace. Natas president Devinder Ohri expressed hope that the group would re-join, stating it would benefit everyone involved. The group had announced they were pulling out of the Natas Fair due to concerns over transparency and sponsorship. Natas has proposed alternative dates for its fair, which will now be held from March 6-8, and expects an equal number of visitors or a 10-20% increase.

site_title: Condo resale prices down 1.1% in November on sharply lower volumes: SRX
summary: Condo resale prices in Singapore dropped 1.1% in November, the second consecutive decline, with 22.4% fewer units sold. This follows a 0.4% price increase in October. The drop was more pronounced in city fringe and suburbs, with city apartments experiencing only a 0.1% decrease. The CEO of SRX Property attributes the decline to low sales volume, stating that demand remains anaemic and prices will be relatively stubborn until a significant change occurs.

images.alt_text: Condominum resale prices fell again by 1.1 per cent in November, compared to the month before, while resale volumes tumbled 22.4 per cent, said SRX Property on Tuesday.

site_title: US city of Portland sues Uber
summary: Portland, Oregon, has sued ride-sharing startup Uber, alleging it's operating illegally and violating city rules. The city seeks a court order to stop Uber from operating in Portland until it complies. Mayor Charlie Hales expressed concerns over public health and safety, citing the lack of regulations in the industry. Uber claims widespread public support, with nearly 7,000 residents signing a petition in favor of the company. The lawsuit follows Uber's rapid expansion and scrutiny over its business practices and data collection.

site_title: Honda expanding airbag recall, could help Takata: report
summary: Honda is expanding its global recall of cars fitted with potentially defective Takata airbags, affecting 13 million vehicles worldwide. The recall, initiated by Honda, aims to determine the cause of the issue, which could lead to excessive explosive power and fatal shrapnel. If Takata faces financial difficulties, Honda may step in to ensure the parts maker can continue supplying airbags to automakers, including itself. The expansion could help Takata and mitigate further industry-wide recalls affecting an estimated 20 million vehicles.

site_title: US consumers warm to wearable technology, Europeans cooler: study
summary: A new study by Forrester Research predicts the wearable technology market will triple in 2015, driven by the expected release of the Apple Watch, which is expected to draw 10 million users. US consumers are more willing to wear wearable devices, with 45% willing compared to 32% of European consumers. Businesses are also driving demand, with 68% of business decision-makers considering wearables a priority. The market is expected to grow rapidly, with Morgan Stanley predicting over 1 billion devices by 2020.

site_title: HDB revises way it computes resale price index
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has revised its method for computing the resale price index (RPI), which will take effect from the fourth quarter of this year. The new approach, using the "stratified hedonic regression" model, shows that resale prices fell by a bigger magnitude over the past three quarters. This change aims to expand data coverage to newer towns and flat models. The revised RPI would have fallen 1.8% in the third quarter, compared to 1.7% under the previous method.

site_title: Australia and New Zealand dollars slip to multi-year lows, bonds in demand
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars plummeted to multi-year lows on Tuesday, with the Aussie dropping half a US cent to US$0.8247, its weakest in over four years. The decline was fueled by a slide in oil prices and global growth concerns, as well as a change in interest rate forecasts by National Australia Bank. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to ease interest rates, with markets pricing in a cut to 2.25% by mid-2015. The currencies also fell against the safe-haven yen, with the New Zealand dollar reaching a two-and-a-half year low of US$0.7624.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars dropped to multi-year lows on Tuesday as another slide in oil prices and global growth concerns fuelled a flight to safety.

site_title: Hong Kong protest sites to be cleared: court
summary: Hong Kong's High Court has ordered the clearing of main protest sites, building up to a final showdown between pro-democracy activists and authorities. Student groups have been calling for a free vote through peaceful demonstrations, known as the "Umbrella Movement." The clearance order comes after a local bus company received an injunction against street blockades at the site in Admiralty. The move is seen as a precursor to a confrontation between protesters and authorities, with Beijing backing the government. The protests have been ongoing for months, with protesters seeking greater democracy in the Chinese-controlled city.

site_title: Paris bids to clean up City of Light
summary: Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo unveiled a plan to ban diesel cars within five years and pedestrianize the central four districts, aiming to improve air quality and tourist experience. The city aims to become one of the world's most visited destinations. The plan also includes making the inner city open all hours, with a few exceptions. The move is part of Paris' efforts to address pollution and traffic issues, making it a cleaner and more livable city.

site_title: Australian government drops universal healthcare changes
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Tony Abbott has dropped plans to charge patients a fee to see their doctor as part of a universal healthcare overhaul. The A$7 co-payment, which was included in the 2014-15 budget, was heavily criticized and would have saved A$3.5 billion over four years. Instead, the government will cut the rebate paid to doctors and encourage them to charge adults a A$5 fee, while exempting children, the elderly, and those on state allowances. The decision is seen as a major backflip for the struggling conservative government.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 0.64% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.64% lower on Tuesday, amid a strong yen and losses on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 115.40 points to 17,820.24, despite shares in Takata jumping 6.29% after Honda's president expressed willingness to assist the struggling auto parts maker. The dollar fell to 120.66 yen, eroding Japanese exporters' competitiveness.

site_title: Facebook boosts search on mobile, desktop
summary: Facebook has rolled out upgraded search capabilities for mobile and desktop users, allowing them to find favourite posts from friends on the social network. The new search feature, which was tested in August, enables users to quickly search for posts such as videos, news articles, and photos. Users can only see search results that have been shared with them, and the results are personalised and unique to each individual. The upgrade is part of Facebook's long-term effort to help users tap into the experiences and perspectives of their friends.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 11.80 points to 3,309.64. Volume was 63.4 million shares worth S$108.3 million. Losers beat gainers 79 to 49.

site_title: Amazon warns it could take drones testing elsewhere
summary: Amazon is moving its drone delivery research outside the US due to regulatory delays. The company's vice president, Paul Misener, stated that Amazon is using non-US facilities for testing and development. Amazon founder Jeff Bezos expressed concerns that the US could be late in adopting drone delivery, potentially allowing other countries to get ahead. The company had previously tested in Washington state but has now shifted its focus to other locations. Amazon plans to use drones for fast delivery of small packages, but regulatory hurdles may delay the project.

site_title: Delhi bans all Internet taxi firms after Uber rape claim: report
summary: Delhi has banned all internet-based taxi firms, including Uber, after a female passenger reported being raped by a driver contracted to the US company. The Delhi transport department issued an order allowing only six registered radio taxi companies to operate, effectively shutting down Uber and other similar services. The ban was implemented after police found Uber had failed to run background checks on the driver, who was acquitted in a similar case three years ago. The move aims to improve safety and accountability in the city's taxi services.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.57% lower
summary: Hong Kong shares opened 0.57% lower on Tuesday, following a three-day rally that saw the Hang Seng Index rise over two percent. The benchmark index dropped 137.26 points to 23,910.41. This decline comes as investors reassess the market amid uncertainty from US trade policies.

site_title: Zero carbon emission goal not 'realistic': Saudi Arabia
summary: Saudi Arabia's chief negotiator at UN climate talks has stated that setting a zero carbon emissions goal by 2050 is not realistic due to the lack of clear technology diffusion and international cooperation programs. The country's envoy, Khalid Abuleif, expressed concerns that such a target would be "very challenging to the future sustainable development of oil exporters." Developing countries want rich nations to bear a bigger share of the burden, while developed nations point to major developing emitters as the primary polluters.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 4.10 points to 1736.74 on Tuesday, with 144 losers outnumbering 62 gainers. The decline followed a mixed global market trend. Meanwhile, the Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday despite US tariff uncertainty. In other news, Airalo raised US$220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion, and a Dutch firm moved to privatise Grand Venture Technology at S$0.94 per share.

site_title: Merkel suffers dizzy spell but recovers for TV interviews
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel experienced a dizzy spell during a TV interview on Monday evening, but quickly recovered after taking a break and finishing the interview. Merkel, 60, was in the midst of a series of media interviews ahead of her party's congress. She later attended the annual media gathering, unaffected by the brief incident.

site_title: Internet overload? No, survey says
summary: A survey of US internet users found that 72% are happy with the internet's resources, while 26% feel overwhelmed by information. Despite concerns, 87% of adults say the internet has improved their ability to learn new things, and 77% believe today's students are better informed due to online access. However, younger respondents (under 30) are less convinced of the internet's value, with 19% saying it has had little impact.

site_title: EU announces 61 million-euro Ebola package for west Africa
summary: The European Union has pledged an additional 61 million euros (S$99.1 million) to aid efforts to combat the Ebola crisis in west Africa. The EU's total contribution to the crisis is around 1 billion euros, focusing on epidemic surveillance, medical supplies, and training of health workers. The donation aims to help countries affected by Ebola, particularly Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone, which have seen over 6,300 deaths. The EU Commissioner for International Cooperation and Development, Neven Mimica, emphasized the EU's commitment to supporting the affected regions in the short and long term.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Hiap Hoe, Spackman, Stamford Tyres
summary: Hiap Hoe Group sold 48 units in its District 10 project to its controlling shareholder Hiap Hoe Holdings for S$72.83 million, avoiding further extension fees. Spackman Entertainment Group and Stamford Tyres were also mentioned as stocks to watch.

site_title: More firms offering flexible work arrangements: MOM survey
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) reported that 47% of establishments in Singapore offered flexible work arrangements in 2014, up from 38% in 2011. The most common arrangements were part-time work (36%), flexi-time (12%), and staggered hours (11%). Employers are also providing additional leave benefits, such as compassionate and marriage leave, to support employees with family commitments. Absenteeism due to illness remained stable.

site_title: Spackman buys 51% stake in Korean theatrical film company for S$2.53m
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group has acquired a 51% stake in Novus Mediacorp, a Korean theatrical film company, for S$2.53 million. Novus has a revenue of S$5.39 million and a net profit of S$1.26 million for 2013. The acquisition will allow Spackman to tap into Korea's fastest-growing film industry segment and expand its production slate to 10 films, with at least seven set for release next year, making it one of Korea's largest theatrical film production companies.

site_title: US$ hits 2-year high against euro ahead of data reports
summary: The US dollar has reached its strongest level in two years against the euro, rising 0.3% to US$1.2248 per euro, driven by improved US consumer confidence and retail sales data. The dollar has also gained against the yen and other currencies, with the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index reaching its highest close since 2009. The euro has fallen 0.8% and the yen has strengthened 0.5% in the past week. The US dollar has jumped 12% in the past six months, outperforming other developed-nation currencies.

site_title: Huffington Post launches in India, eyes China edition
summary: The Huffington Post launched its Indian version, HuffPost India, in partnership with The Times of India Group, aiming to tap into the country's growing internet users. The website, featuring news, entertainment, health, and blogs, is its 13th edition worldwide. Editor-in-chief Arianna Huffington sees this as an opportunity to tell India's stories and expand to China in the near future, despite fierce competition in the crowded online media scene. India's 1.25 billion population is expected to drive growth, with internet penetration still limited to 25%.

site_title: Inequality worst in decades in range of countries: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has reported that the gap between the rich and poor in 34 member countries has reached its widest in 30 years. The richest 10% of the population now earn 9.5 times the income of the poorest 10%, up from 7:1 in the 1980s. This widening income inequality has harmed growth, with the OECD estimating that it has knocked more than 10 percentage points off growth in some countries, including Mexico and New Zealand. The report calls for anti-poverty programs and increased access to education, training, and healthcare.

images.alt_text: The gap between the rich and poor in a range of countries has reached its widest in 30 years and the trend has harmed growth, the OECD said Tuesday.

site_title: Christmas comes early for some SIA passengers
summary: SINGAPORE AIRLINES (SIA) has reversed its decision to force 400 Australian passengers to downsize to Economy Class or pay the fare difference after a computer glitch sold Business Class tickets at Economy fares. The glitch, discovered on November 29, affected flights from December 8 onwards. SIA will honour the tickets and avoid financial losses, despite estimates suggesting the airline could have lost over US$1 million. The airline's shares closed 2 cents higher after the announcement, which also alleviated concerns among travel agents in Australia.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US concert promoter accused of US$300m Ponzi scheme
summary: US concert promoter John Utsick, 72, has been extradited to the US after being charged with a $300 million Ponzi scheme. Utsick defrauded 3,300 investors, using their money to fund luxury items like condos, stocks, and a yacht. The scheme, considered one of the largest in Florida, involved him paying off previous investors while producing concerts by notable artists like Coldplay and Elton John. Utsick was ordered extradited by Brazil's Supreme Court in August and made his initial appearance before a US judge in Miami.

site_title: Indonesia plans management shake-up at state power utility
summary: Indonesia plans a management shake-up at state power utility Perusahaan Listrik Negara (PLN) as part of a series of reforms aimed at boosting confidence in the country's economy. The move is part of a broader review of state-owned enterprises (SOEs) to enhance efficiency and confidence. The reforms follow a series of other changes, including those at Pertamina, Indonesia's state oil company. The shake-up is expected to boost investor confidence in the country's largest economy in Southeast Asia.

site_title: British MP's Candy Crush Saga turns sour
summary: British MP Nigel Mills apologized for playing Candy Crush Saga on his tablet during a pensions debate, saying his conduct was unbecoming for a member of parliament. The incident sparked controversy after a photo was published, with critics accusing Mills of not taking the debate seriously. Prime Minister David Cameron also weighed in, saying Mills would be "embarrassed" by the incident. Mills later tweeted an apology, promising it would not happen again, and parliamentary officials launched an investigation into the photos.

site_title: US: Energy, tech sell-offs lead stocks lower
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 103.23 points (0.57%) to 17,855.56, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index down 14.77 (0.71%) and 40.06 (0.84%), respectively. Weak Chinese and Japanese data, as well as a supply glut in oil, led to declines in energy and tech stocks. Chevron fell 3.7% and Apache Corp. 6.9%, while tech stocks like Apple and Netflix declined 2.4% and 3.3%, respectively.

site_title: Property taxes on HDB flats to be lower in 2015
summary: HDB flat owners in Singapore will pay lower property taxes next year due to a 3% reduction in annual values. This decrease, combined with more progressive taxes, will result in savings of S$42 to S$54 in taxes for HDB residents compared to two years ago.

site_title: SMEs that tap Machine to Machine tech will punch above their weight
summary: M2M technology, which connects devices to the internet, is poised to change the way people live and companies operate, particularly in Asia. The technology is expected to grow 162% globally from 2014 to 2019, with Asia and Oceania leading the way. Small to medium enterprises (SMEs) are set to benefit from M2M, with declining costs and tangible benefits making it a compelling proposition. By 2016, SMEs are expected to edge ahead of enterprises in M2M adoption, with the number of SMEs implementing M2M growing by 6% between 2013 and 2014.

site_title: Cyberattacks to worsen in 2015: McAfee researchers
summary: Cyberattacks are expected to worsen in 2015, with hackers using advanced techniques to infiltrate networks, according to McAfee researchers. The 2015 Threats Predictions report predicts increased cyber-warfare and espionage, with small nations and terror groups launching crippling attacks on networks. Hackers will target more connected devices, including healthcare and industrial control systems, and use methods to remain hidden and steal sensitive data. The report also warns of increased threats from ransomware, attacks on mobile phone operating systems, and exploitation of wireless systems.

site_title: Temasek to take minority stake in Virtu: sources
summary: Temasek Holdings Pte is set to acquire a minority stake in Virtu Financial Inc for approximately US$180 million. The deal comes after Virtu postponed its initial public offering. Temasek will purchase a portion of the equity investment held by Silver Lake Partners LP. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

site_title: US Republicans should stop pushback against climate change
summary: US Republicans are denouncing the US-China climate change agreement, despite its significance in setting a precedent for future international negotiations. The deal aims to curb carbon emissions, with the US pledging to double its pace and China committing to peak emissions by 2030. Republican lawmakers, including Senator Jim Inhofe, claim the accord is a "non-binding charade" and a distraction from their concerns. However, experts argue that accepting the conventional wisdom on climate change is crucial for addressing global warming and that Republicans' opposition will harm US interests and the planet.

site_title: Pele to leave hospital on Tuesday: clinic
summary: Brazilian soccer legend Pele is set to leave the hospital on Tuesday after recovering well from a two-week kidney ailment. He is in good clinical condition and does not show signs of infection. Pele's medical team has scheduled his departure, and he is expected to speak to reporters at 12:30 pm on Tuesday. This comes after a video posted on Facebook showed Pele thanking supporters and playing his guitar with family and friends.

site_title: Interest rate hike will hit Britons with big mortgages
summary: The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates in the second half of 2015, impacting British consumers with large mortgages. With debt levels reaching 140% of income, a rate hike could exacerbate the impact on consumer spending. A quarter-point rise would add £16 to average mortgage payments, but some borrowers may struggle to afford repayments, particularly those in low-paid, insecure work. The BOE expects an impact in line with previous cycles, but economists warn that the effects could be more severe due to stagnant earnings and high debt levels.

site_title: Taiwan against IOI Properties' purchase of Taipei 101
summary: Taiwan has expressed opposition to Malaysia's IOI Properties Group's attempt to buy a 37.17% stake in the iconic Taipei 101, citing concerns that foreigners should not control a national landmark. Finance Minister Chang Sheng-ford stated that the deal would be subject to a "strict review" by the Taiwan Investment Commission, which could potentially block the deal. The move could impact IOIPG's plans to diversify and grow its assets, with analysts predicting the deal would be completed in the first quarter if approved.

site_title: CME Group offers new iron ore contract
summary: CME Group has introduced a new iron ore contract with 58% content, trading on the Globex platform and open outcry in New York. The contract, set to be listed in January 2015, aims to provide a more efficient hedge for lower-grade ore. The move comes as the global iron ore market faces a glut, with prices slumping to a five-year low. The introduction of the new contract is seen as a positive development by analysts, who expect it to provide more flexibility for traders.

site_title: Commodity benchmarks vulnerable to manipulation: study
summary: A new study by UK law firm Clyde & Co found that 64% of commodity market participants believe benchmarks for setting prices of commodities such as crude oil and zinc are vulnerable to manipulation. Concerns include small sample groups, lack of independent oversight, and traders influencing prices. The study also found that over 70% of participants think overly burdensome regulation could deter participation in the price-setting process. The European Commission has proposed new regulations for financial benchmarks, including authorizing and supervising benchmark administrators and using actual transaction data.

site_title: Why was Chuck Hagel let go?
summary: Chuck Hagel, the US Secretary of Defense under President Barack Obama, was let go in a move seen as a political response to the Democratic Party's losses in the 2014 mid-term elections. The decision was made by President Obama, who had previously shared a common national security agenda with Hagel. The exit of Hagel, who had been in the role since 2011, was seen as a change in US strategy in the Middle East, similar to how President George W. Bush had fired Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld in 2006.

site_title: The happiness curve
summary: A study of happiness across 80 countries reveals that happiness follows a "U-curve" pattern, peaking in the late years of life. According to researchers, people tend to be happier as they age, with 40% of Americans 65 and older rating themselves "very happy" compared to 33% of those 35-49. This trend is not unique to the US, with similar patterns found in other advanced countries. Experts attribute the U-curve to life-cycle rhythms, including declining responsibilities and increasing acceptance of one's limits, which can lead to a reappraisal of life's purpose and meaning.

site_title: Thai rubber farmers to take to the streets as prices slump
summary: Thai rubber farmers plan protests this week, defying martial law, to demand government support for falling rubber prices. The slump in prices has led to suicidal deaths among farmers, with some selling at 40 baht per kilogram, despite production costs of 65 baht. The government has promised measures, including direct buying and handouts, but farmers want prices to reach 80 baht per kilogram. Protests are planned in the south and at Government House in Bangkok, with calls for the removal of ministers blamed for the price slump.

site_title: Joyce plans to stay on as Qantas shares double from record low
summary: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce plans to remain at the helm despite the airline's shares doubling from a record low, as he aims to see through a A$2 billion cost-cutting programme. The airline is experiencing strong market momentum, with its international unit set to post its first profit since 2011, according to analysts. Joyce, 48, has no plans to move, indicating his commitment to the airline's future.

site_title: Web publishers wage war on pop-up ad blockers
summary: Web publishers are waging war on ad blockers, threatening legal action against software developers to protect their advertising revenue. Ad blockers have nearly 144 million active users worldwide, with 20-40% of publishers losing advertising revenue due to the software. To combat this, publishers are experimenting with strategies such as using carrots-and-sticks approaches, devising ads that respect users' privacy, and exploring alternative revenue models. The move is reminiscent of the music industry's takedown of Napster, with some experts advising publishers to learn from this approach.

site_title: Oil prices drop to 5-year low on oversupply
summary: Oil prices have dropped to a 5-year low due to predictions of oversupply, with Brent crude falling over $2 a barrel to $66.85 a barrel. Opec's decision not to cut output has contributed to the decline. US investment bank Morgan Stanley predicts oil prices could fall as low as $43 a barrel next year. The US shale industry has yet to be impacted by the slump, with new oil-drilling rigs being added.

site_title: WEF on impact investing: Do your homework first
summary: The World Economic Forum warns wealthy families considering impact investing to "do their homework" before making a decision. Impact investing, popularized in 2007, has attracted $50 billion in assets, but experts emphasize the need for a multistep process to evaluate goals, risks, and social impact. Family offices should start with lower-risk asset classes and monitor financial and social results. The Forum aims to moderate the hype surrounding impact investing and provide guidance for those seeking to balance profit and social responsibility.

site_title: Hotel booking site eyes growth surge
summary: Journeyful.com, a Singapore-based hotel booking platform, expects bookings to surge after a recent revamp, with a goal of reaching $150-200 million in annualized gross bookings within the next 2-3 years. The company, founded by Moe Ibrahim, has seen double-digit monthly growth and now boasts over 40,000 registered users, mainly from South-east Asia. Journeyful.com aims to reduce dependence on online travel agencies and offers a 10% commission or a 5% commission for powering hotel websites. The company is also developing a software tool to give hoteliers greater visibility into bookings and access to transaction data.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
journeyful.com is expecting bookings to pick up strongly on the hotel booking platform after having gone through a revamp in recent weeks.

site_title: Insiders snap up energy stocks as valuations fall
summary: Energy executives are buying stocks amid the lowest valuations in a decade, as oil prices hit a 10-year low. Industry insiders, including Ring Energy's Tim Rochford and Chesapeake Energy's Archie Dunham, are snapping up shares after a US$300 billion loss in share values. Valuations are at a 37% discount to the market, with the S&P 500 Energy Index down 21% this year. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) kept its production ceiling unchanged, underscoring the price war in the crude market. Experts predict earnings in the industry will drop 15% in the fourth quarter and 9.8% in 2015.

site_title: Japan bank loans in November up 2.8%, fastest since 2009
summary: Japan's bank lending rose 2.8% in November, the fastest pace since 2009, according to data. This growth is a positive sign for the economy, led by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who is trying to steer the country out of a recession. Lending by local banks also increased, a good sign that the benefits of Abe's economic policies, known as Abenomics, are expanding to regional economies. However, economists caution that the growth may be premature and that the fundamentals of the economy remain unstable.

site_title: Japan's recession deeper than expected
summary: Japan's economy contracted 1.9% in Q3, worse than the estimated 1.6%, due to a sharp decline in corporate capital spending. The service sector sentiment index fell to 41.5 in November, reflecting concerns over the economic outlook. The country is now officially in recession, with two consecutive quarters of negative growth. Despite this, analysts expect a relatively strong rebound in the fourth quarter, driven by a recovery in private consumption and exports. The government maintains that the economy is on a moderate recovery track, but the news may impact Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's snap election.

site_title: Managing risks when using the cloud
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can enjoy the benefits of cloud-based services while minimizing risks by using the right tools and outsourced IT security experts. However, SMEs must protect themselves from privileged account security threats, which have become a significant dark spot in the cloud computing landscape. Recent cases of hacking and data breaches have highlighted the need for SMEs to secure their privileged accounts and credentials to prevent unwanted access into critical assets. By taking proactive measures, SMEs can ensure the security of their data and maintain confidence among their customer base.

site_title: From well to pump
summary: Oil prices have fallen amid bearish expectations of US President Trump's tariffs on Canada and other countries. The OPEC trimmed its oil demand forecast for the next four years, contributing to the decline. Gold prices rose after Trump's tariff announcement. In other news, a Chinese tycoon is reportedly in talks to buy Exxon's Singapore stations. Solar stocks in China surged as Beijing sought to calm price wars, while a major energy company, Aster, is set to acquire Exxon's stations in Singapore. Oil prices fell amid a bearish outlook.

site_title: US economy picking up steam but many buy Republican spiel
summary: The US economy is showing signs of improvement, with the Labor Department reporting 321,000 jobs added in November, marking 10 consecutive months of growth. Average hourly earnings rose 0.4% and the unemployment rate declined 0.9 percentage point this year. Despite these positive indicators, many Americans still feel the economy is not recovering as quickly as they had hoped. A Gallup poll found 52% of Americans believe the economy is getting worse, while the White House acknowledges the need for more workers to benefit from the recovery.
