The airline, which recorded its worst quarterly loss since 2011, plans to take itself private with a 6-billion-ringgit (US$1.8 billion) restructuring aimed at returning the carrier to profit within three years. The restructuring includes replacing MAS with a new company, Malaysia Airlines Bhd, and making a key announcement on leadership by this month.

site_title: Indonesia 2015 fuel subsidy spending may be below 140t rupiah
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Bambang Brodjonegoro said the country's fuel subsidy spending may drop below 140 trillion rupiah (S$14.4 billion) in 2015, about half the budgeted amount. The 2015 budget sets the spending at 276 trillion rupiah, down from this year's target of 246 trillion rupiah. The move comes as the government seeks to divert funding to other sectors amid budget and current account deficits. In June, President Joko Widodo raised subsidized fuel prices to help fund his reform agenda.

site_title: GIC affiliate completes US$395m investment in Emperador: Manila Bulletin
summary: Arran Investment Private, an affiliate of Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC, has completed a US$1.63 billion investment in Emperador Inc, a Philippine cigarette manufacturer. The initial investment is valued at 17.6 billion pesos, with an option to invest an additional 4.4 billion pesos over a 13-month period at 11 pesos per share. This marks a significant investment in the Philippine market, with Emperador Inc being one of the country's largest cigarette manufacturers.

site_title: DeClout unit buys web, mobile business from JV partner for US$1 million
summary: DeClout, an ICT provider, has acquired a web and mobile business, Playworks, from its joint venture partner for US$1 million in cash. The acquisition is expected to boost DeClout's vertical domain clouds business, accelerate gaming platform development, and enhance consumer marketing capabilities. Playworks' net tangible asset value was estimated at S$273,000 as of October 13, and the deal is not expected to significantly impact DeClout's net tangible assets or earnings per share in 2014.

images.alt_text: A DeClout joint venture has bought a web and mobile business from its partner for US$1 million in cash.

site_title: Hot stock: SIIC drops 10.5% after director pares stake
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings shares dropped 10.5% after executive director Yang Changmin sold about two-fifths of his shares, reducing his stake to 0.79%. The shares fell to 14.5 Singapore cents after 660 million shares changed hands at 14.9 Singapore cents apiece. The sale was part of a sale and purchase agreement made on November 26.

site_title: Philippines' November inflation slows to one-year low
summary: The Philippines' annual inflation rate slowed to a one-year low of 3.7% in November, beating economists' forecasts of 4.0%. Core inflation, excluding volatile items, was 2.7% from last year, down from a forecast of 2.9%. The central bank's policy meeting next week is expected to keep interest rates on hold, as the economy showed signs of slowing down. The latest data also showed a decline in public spending and farm output in the third quarter, signaling a longer-than-expected pause in the central bank's tightening cycle.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, Yuuzoo, DeClout
summary: Olam International acquired US peanut sheller McCleskey Mills for $176 million, aiming for "farm gate to factory gate" capabilities in the world's lowest-cost peanut market. Yuuzoo Corp saw two key officers leave, with new hires announced to replace them. DeClout Ltd bought a web and mobile business for $1 million, funded internally.

site_title: Indonesia to ease dividend payment requirement for state firms
summary: Indonesia's new government plans to ease dividend payment requirements for state-owned firms, allowing them to use profits for capital expenditure instead of sharing with the government. The move aims to support President Joko Widodo's goal of investing $450 billion in infrastructure by 2019. State firms will be required to use dividends for infrastructure projects, with Finance Minister Bambang Brodjenogoro supporting the initiative. The policy change is expected to contribute 40 trillion rupiah (US$3.25 billion) in dividends this year, or 2.44% of state revenue.

site_title: Olam buys US peanut sheller for US$176m
summary: Olam International has agreed to purchase US peanut sheller McCleskey Mills for $176 million, gaining a foothold in the US peanut supply chain. The acquisition will be funded by internal funds and debt facilities, with completion targeted for the third quarter of 2015. This move aims to capitalize on the US's competitive peanut industry and expanding production to meet growing demand in emerging markets such as China and India.

site_title: Work starts on Project Jewel, expansion of Changi's Terminal 1
summary: Work has begun on Changi Airport's Project Jewel, a $1.7 billion expansion of Terminal 1, which will increase the terminal's capacity to 24 million passengers annually. The project, set to be completed in 2018, will feature 22,000 square meters of gardens, a 40-meter high waterfall, and a 130-room hotel. Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew emphasized the need to differentiate Changi Airport from others by maintaining high standards of service and making it an attractive destination.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: SGX to offer MSCI Malaysia futures from Feb 9
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will begin trading a new futures contract linked to the MSCI Malaysia Index on February 9, offering a direct trading option in the US. The contract tracks 43 Kuala Lumpur-listed stocks, adding to SGX's existing suite of South-east Asian index futures.

site_title: Starbucks eyes booze, food and technology to boost US growth
summary: Starbucks plans to boost US growth by expanding its offerings to include beer, wine, and evening snacks at thousands of domestic cafes, widening lunch options, and introducing mobile ordering. The company aims to double US food revenue to over $4 billion by 2019, with a focus on evening menus and mobile ordering. The efforts are part of a broader strategy to attract consumers who prefer online shopping over in-store experiences, with plans also to double its China cafe count to 3,000 by 2019.

site_title: Thousands evacuate as Philippines braces for typhoon Hagupit
summary: Thousands of people in the central Philippines evacuated their homes as Typhoon Hagupit approached, with tens of thousands fleeing coastal villages and landslide-prone areas. The typhoon, expected to make landfall on Saturday, is packing winds of up to 215 kph and 4- to 5-metre high storm surges, putting 10 million residents at risk of flooding and strong winds. The Philippines is still recovering from last year's devastating Super Typhoon Haiyan, which killed over 7,000 people and left 4 million homeless.

images.alt_text: Tens of thousands of people fled coastal villages and landslide-prone areas in the central Philippines on Friday, as typhoon Hagupit bore down on eastern coasts of the island nation where thousands were killed in a devastating storm last year.

site_title: In a Home Fix
summary: A homeowner remodels their space, realizing the complexities of DIY projects, particularly with appliances like air conditioners and refrigerators. The author's research and interactions with online forums reveal numerous potential pitfalls and a growing trend of homeowners becoming experts in these areas. This phenomenon may be a response to the trauma of the Great Financial Crisis and a desire to rebuild control over their lives, with some opting for a more low-key approach, such as using IKEA products.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.37% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.37% lower on Friday, following the European Central Bank's decision not to expand its stimulus. The Nikkei 225 index fell 65.36 points to 17,821.85. Market participants are cautious ahead of US jobs data and reluctant to trade aggressively. The dollar rose past 120 yen for the first time since 2007, while the euro rebounded against the US dollar. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.07% to 17,900.10 on Thursday.

site_title: Australia: Shares subdued, weekly gains expected
summary: Australian shares fell 0.8% on Friday, weighed down by losses in the resources sector. Despite the decline, shares are still on track to post weekly gains. Mining shares, particularly Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton, dropped 2.6% and 1.3%, respectively, amid concerns over global demand for commodities. In contrast, industrial stocks rose 1%, with Bradken Ltd up 27% after receiving a takeover approach.

site_title: Asian shares edge up, dollar awaits US jobs report
summary: Asian shares rose 0.1% in early trade, tracking a weekly loss of 0.7%, while the dollar remained steady ahead of the US jobs report. The US nonfarm payrolls report is expected to show 230,000 new jobs and an unchanged 5.8% unemployment rate. The euro rose to a two-year high against the dollar, and oil prices fell after Saudi Arabia cut prices. The US dollar and euro will likely influence Asian markets, with the US jobs report expected to impact the dollar's trajectory.

site_title: North Korea still a suspect in Sony attack despite denial
summary: North Korea remains a suspect in the Sony Pictures cyber attack, despite the country's denial, according to a US national security source. The investigation, led by the FBI's Los Angeles Field Office, has found connections to North Korea in hacking tools used in previous attacks on South Korea. The attack, which exposed internal data and shut down Sony's computer systems, was linked to the film "The Interview," which mocks North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Sony has cooperated with the investigation and released the film on schedule, but still struggles to recover from the breach.

site_title: JPMorgan continues run as top ranked investment bank
summary: JPMorgan retained its position as the top-ranked investment bank in the first nine months of the year, with revenue of $17.1 billion. Goldman Sachs came in second, while Deutsche Bank and Citigroup shared third place. Investment bank revenue declined 6% compared to the previous year, primarily due to a downturn in fixed income, currencies, and commodities divisions. Equities divisions, however, saw a 15% increase in revenue, with Morgan Stanley leading the way.

site_title: Holland Rd mixed-use site available for application on reserve list
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has made a 99-year leasehold mixed-use site in Holland Road available for application on the reserve list. The site, with a maximum gross floor area of 59,715 square meters, can yield approximately 570 homes. The project will feature varying height zones, ranging from three to 35 storeys, and a network of pedestrianized streets and public spaces. The site is the first sale site under the Holland Village Extension plans, aiming to enhance the area's buzz and provide more residences.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Brainard says Fed lacks complete data on financial system
summary: Federal Reserve official Lael Brainard stated that the central bank lacks complete data on various parts of the financial system, hindering its ability to implement financial stability tools. Brainard emphasized the need for more data and research to provide targeted recommendations for financial stability measures. This incomplete data poses a challenge as the Fed ramps up its efforts to ensure financial stability.

site_title: Massive white truffle to be sold at New York auction
summary: An Italian white truffle, weighing 4.16 lbs, is set to be sold at a New York auction on Saturday, with bidding starting at $50,000. The truffle, nearly twice the size of a 2010 record sale, is one of the largest in the world and is expected to fetch a high price. The proceeds from the sale will be donated to several charities by the truffle's supplier, the Balestra family. The truffle was discovered in Italy last week and has already generated interest from buyers in Latin America, Asia, and North America.

site_title: Universal Terminal delays IPO plans: report
summary: Universal Terminal, Singapore's largest independent petroleum storage terminal, has postponed its initial public offering (IPO) to February 2015 due to bearish market sentiments on oil-related assets, following a plunge in crude oil prices. The IPO was expected to raise up to S$1 billion and was likely to be the largest on the Singapore Exchange since April 2013. Market analysts attribute the delay to caution in the oil industry, with many investors adopting a wait-and-see attitude amidst significant falls in oil stocks over the past six months.

site_title: Mickey & math: Disney unveils learning apps
summary: Disney has unveiled "Disney Imagicademy," a learning app for children aged 3-8 that incorporates iconic characters like Mickey Mouse to teach math, science, creative arts, and languages. The app, developed in collaboration with education experts, includes 30 app-based experiences, with five new ones launching on December 11. The program also includes books and physical products, aiming to expose young children to core educational concepts and make learning fun.

site_title: Petition against huge US-EU trade deal passes key threshold
summary: A petition against the proposed Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) between the EU and US has reached one million signatures, forcing the European Commission to review the policy. The deal, which aims to create a single market of one billion consumers, has drawn criticism over concerns it may override local laws and benefit corporate interests. Negotiations continue despite opposition from NGOs and activists, with the EU's trade commissioner promising to address fears and concerns.

site_title: Samsung asks appeals court to throw out US$930m damages in Apple infringement case
summary: Samsung Electronics has asked a US appeals court to overturn a $930 million verdict that found the company infringed on Apple patents in making its Galaxy line of smartphones and tablets. The decision, made by a US District Court in California, was based on design and trade dress patents, which Samsung claims were incorrectly decided. Samsung argues that the verdict is "absurd" and that the court erred in awarding Samsung's total profits on the infringing products. The appeals court will review the decision and decide whether to uphold or overturn the verdict.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics asked a US appeals court on Thursday to toss out an order that it pay Apple US$930 million for infringing on iPhone patents to make its Galaxy line of smartphones and tablets.

site_title: Blame your boss, not China, for stagnant wage growth: ILO
summary: The International Labour Organization (ILO) says stagnant wage growth in rich countries is due to corporate penny-pinching, not competition from cheap Chinese labor. Despite a 5.3% increase in workers' productivity, average wages in developed countries have grown only 0.4% since 2009. ILO Deputy Director Sandra Polaski attributes the stagnation to retained profitability not being reinvested in wages, reducing household demand and overall aggregate demand.

images.alt_text: It is not cheap labour competition that is causing wages to stagnate in more advanced economies, said Sandra Polaski, the ILO's deputy director for policy.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters weigh next move as one suggests blocking govt, not roads
summary: Hong Kong pro-democracy protesters are weighing their options after nearly two months of street demonstrations. The Hong Kong Federation of Students is set to decide whether to call off the protests or change tactics, with one leader suggesting a campaign of withholding tax to "block government." Protesters are expected to retreat from camps in the Admiralty area, but some may stay due to the sense of home and lack of progress. The Umbrella Movement has achieved its goal of awakening democratic aspirations in Hong Kong, despite the government not meeting its demands for a free vote.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong pro-democracy protesters were weighing their options on Friday, whether to call off more than two months of street demonstrations or change tactics, as one leader suggested a campaign of withholding tax to "block government".

site_title: Australia's Abbott risks recession as infrastructure pledge falters
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Tony Abbott risks presiding over a recession due to the slow pace of new infrastructure projects, despite his promise to be an "infrastructure prime minister" a year ago. Public spending on capital works has shrunk in each of the past three quarters, contributing to economic growth slowing and the mining industry's spending set to plummet. This could be a critical factor in preventing a contraction, but Abbott's pledge to accelerate infrastructure projects remains unfulfilled.

site_title: Audi to take on Tesla with a high-end electric car
summary: Audi plans to launch a high-end electric car in 2017 to challenge Tesla Motors, marking the brand's first mainstream all-electric vehicle. The new model, a crossover, will be part of Audi's push to roll out greener cars, following the introduction of a battery-powered variant of the R8 sports car and the plug-in hybrid A3 E-Tron hatchback. Audi aims to surpass BMW in US sales by the end of the decade, with growth in the US expected to continue, targeting 200,000 cars by 2020.

site_title: Silicon Valley clears out homeless 'Jungle' camp
summary: Authorities in San Jose, California, have begun dismantling "The Jungle," a notorious homeless camp in the heart of Silicon Valley, home to approximately 300 people. The encampment, near the city's downtown district, was formed due to the rising cost of housing as tech companies moved in. The camp's residents were forced out of the rental market, with many unable to afford the increasing prices. The operation, led by municipal workers, aims to relocate the camp's residents to more suitable accommodations.

site_title: UK permanent hiring slows to 18-month low, recruiters say
summary: The UK's permanent hiring rate slowed to its lowest level in 18 months in November, according to a survey by the Recruitment and Employment Confederation. Despite this, starting salaries rose due to staff shortages in many sectors, with hourly rates for temporary workers also increasing. The slowdown in hiring is attributed to political uncertainty ahead of the national election and the risk of a Brexit referendum. Salaries are expected to continue rising, driven by business confidence and skills shortages, particularly in IT, engineering, and medicine.

images.alt_text: Office workers walk in the precinct of the The Canary Wharf development. British firms hired permanent employees at the slowest rate in 18 months in November, although starting salaries rose faster due to staff shortages in many sectors, a survey showed on Friday.

site_title: US: Wall St ends with slight losses, energy weighs again
summary: US stocks ended slightly lower on Thursday due to broad losses across the S&P 500 sectors, with seven out of ten sectors ending in negative territory. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi reassured investors that the ECB will reassess its stimulus early in 2015 and take further action if necessary, but didn't provide a specific timeline.

site_title: Euro gains as ECB holds off on fresh easing
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) held off on implementing fresh stimulus measures, including quantitative easing, due to German opposition. The euro strengthened against the dollar and yen after the announcement. ECB President Mario Draghi stated that the bank will assess the impact of existing easing efforts to boost growth, and that the possibility of additional measures remains open for early 2015. The ECB cut its growth and inflation forecasts for the eurozone, citing concerns over falling economic growth and inflation expectations.

site_title: Mazda expands recall for US cars with Takata passenger air bags
summary: Mazda Motor Corp is expanding its recall for US cars with Takata passenger air bags, adding Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia, Guam, Saipan, and American Samoa to the initial affected areas. The recall, which covers about 87,000 vehicles, follows a request from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Defective Takata air bags have been linked to five deaths globally, and Mazda will replace the air bags at its dealerships. The expansion is part of a growing global recall effort, with over 16 million cars recalled since 2008.

site_title: BMW tries to succeed where Daimler failed with London car-share scheme
summary: BMW launched its DriveNow car-sharing service in London, competing with Zipcar and 24/7, six months after Daimler shut down its equivalent initiative in Britain. The service operates in partnership with Sixt and allows users to locate and return cars via app or card. BMW's initial launch will be in three North London boroughs, with a focus on proving the concept before expanding. The company aims to capitalize on the growing demand for flexible, short-term car use, particularly among younger people.

site_title: Impressive Asian fare at film festival
summary: The Singapore International Film Festival featured a diverse lineup of Asian movies, including "The Obs: A Singapore Story," "Stray Dogs" by Tsai Ming-liang, "Chiang Khan Story" by Yuthlert Sippapak, "Meeting Dr. Sun" by Yee Chih-yen, and "Forma" by Ayumi Sakamoto. The festival showcased a range of genres, from rockumentaries to comedies, dramas, and arthouse films. Notable winners include "Stray Dogs," which won the Grand Jury Prize at the Venice International Film Festival, and "Meeting Dr. Sun," which earned a Golden Horse award for Best Original Screenplay.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Environment plays a profitability role
summary: UES Holdings, an environmental engineering solutions provider in Singapore, is motivated to maximize profits while prioritizing environmental well-being. The company, led by Managing Director Johnson Tang, has become a key player in water and waste treatment sectors, serving clients including the Public Utilities Board and Changi Airport Group. Tang emphasizes the importance of having an "irrepressible passion" for one's job and advises budding entrepreneurs to find a business they can relate to, rather than focusing solely on profit. He also stresses the value of perseverance and being a visionary leader.

site_title: 50-year Honda-Takata ties on the rocks
summary: Honda Motor is severing ties with airbag supplier Takata Corp due to the company's safety crisis, which has killed five motorists in its cars. Honda is turning to alternative suppliers, including Autoliv Inc, and is negotiating with Daicel Corp to secure more components. The crisis has led to a nationwide recall of over 13 million vehicles worldwide, with Honda expanding its US recall. Industry analysts predict that carmakers may need to shoulder some of the costs of repairing airbags, potentially leading to a shift in supplier contracts and a boost in market share for alternative suppliers.

site_title: Unusual faces of rock triumph on stage
summary: Unlikely rock frontmen Wayne Coyne and Jack Black of The Flaming Lips and Tenacious D, respectively, wowed audiences in Singapore with their high-energy performances. Coyne's eccentric stage presence and colorful outfits, including a neon-green dinosaur jumper, set the tone for The Flaming Lips' psychedelic show. In contrast, Tenacious D's no-frills, comedy-driven performance featured Black and Kyle Gass poking fun at rock cliches. Both bands delivered energetic and entertaining shows, showcasing the importance of showmanship over physical appearance.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Green company of the year
summary: Tetra Pak (Thailand) Limited has been named Green Company of the Year for its sustainable carton collection and recycling efforts, promoting environmental awareness and social responsibility. Founded in 1975, Tetra Pak is part of the world's leading food processing and packaging solutions company. The company's "Green Roof Project for Princess Pa Foundation" aims to protect the environment and people. Meanwhile, entrepreneur Kang Puay Seng was named Entrepreneur Of The Year, while Pat Liew was named Woman Entrepreneur Of The Year, and Seah Kian Hoe was named Young Entrepreneur Of The Year for their dedication and leadership.

site_title: UK budget plan could change state beyond recognition: think tank
summary: A leading economic think tank warns that the UK's public sector could undergo significant changes by 2020 due to deep spending cuts planned by Finance Minister George Osborne. Cuts to public services could be 41% lower than 2010 levels, with spending adjusted for inflation in areas like defence, policing, and transport. This could lead to a "state beyond recognition" according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies.

site_title: Uber now valued at US$40b
summary: Uber has raised US$1.2 billion in funding, valuing the company at US$40 billion, more than double its worth six months ago. The funding will fuel expansion, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region, where Uber now operates in over 250 cities across 50 countries. Founded in 2009, Uber has faced controversy and criticism, but its rapid growth has also created jobs and potentially reduced congestion. The company plans to invest in data privacy, city services, and carpooling systems, aiming to set new standards and become a positive force globally.

site_title: Twitter CEO's trusts cut holdings further
summary: Twitter CEO Dick Costolo's family trusts have sold 141,730 shares in the social network for $5.68 million, halving their stake to a quarter of their initial holdings. This sale is part of a larger effort to diversify Costolo's investments, which he began after the initial public offering. Despite the sale, Costolo still owns 36,028 shares and 509,828 unvested restricted stock units. Twitter's stock has declined 39% this year, but the company has been working to improve its product and rally investors.

site_title: Japan Opposition too divided, says Ozawa
summary: Japan's opposition parties are unlikely to make significant inroads into the power of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's ruling coalition due to internal and group divisions, according to former political heavyweight Ichiro Ozawa. Media polls suggest the coalition may maintain its two-thirds majority in the lower house of Parliament. Ozawa criticized the current opposition's focus on party interests, stating they can't regain control while divided. He also expressed concerns about Japan's relations with China and criticized Abenomics, which he believes could lead to a system of "market fundamentalism" and "unfettered capitalism".

site_title: Executives at higher levels got bigger pay raise
summary: Executives at higher levels received bigger pay raises, with nearly half of CEOs (44%) and two-thirds of lower-ranked directors and executives (66%) receiving increases in the last financial year. Total compensation is on the rise for most executives, with 17% of CEOs experiencing a 16% or more increase. The report suggests "pay for performance" is working, but CEOs still earn significantly more than other executives, with 45.6% earning $251,000 to $400,000 per year in base salary.

site_title: Microsoft CEO stresses importance of diversity
summary: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella emphasized the importance of diversity in his first shareholder meeting, stating that the company is working to promote a more varied workforce. This includes providing training to alert employees to their unconscious biases and implementing strategies to hire, retain, and promote diverse talent. Nadella's message highlights Microsoft's commitment to creating a more inclusive workplace.

site_title: Leadership culture
summary: MORS Group organized The Gray Affair forum on November 25, focusing on leadership, innovation, and sustainability. The event featured a keynote address by Andrew Bryant, who discussed new ways of looking at leadership and development. The forum aimed to promote a culture of progressive learning and knowledge sharing among C-suite executives and function heads across the Asia region. The event highlighted the importance of innovation and sustainability as a strategic business plan for organizations to compete effectively.

site_title: France calls for end to French bashing as it fights moroseness
summary: France is experiencing negative international views, with publications like The Economist and Newsweek labeling it a "time bomb" and "finished". The country's economic growth is stalling, and this has led to a questioning of its way of life. France's President Francois Hollande has been in office since 2012, and the negative perceptions are attributed to his administration. The country's 35-hour workweek, generous holidays, and long lunches are seen as contributing factors to its perceived decline. France is now calling for an end to negative views and a reevaluation of its reputation.

site_title: China mulls easing of controls on gold imports: sources
summary: China's central bank is considering a draft plan to ease restrictions on gold imports, potentially lowering prices in the world's biggest gold market. The plan would open up imports to qualified miners and banks, and could benefit Chinese consumers who buy gold. The move is part of China's efforts to link the mainland to global markets and may erode the premium Chinese buyers pay for gold. The change may also spur higher global prices, following eased import restrictions in India and Switzerland.

site_title: Educating the young
summary: Hemas Holdings, a Sri Lankan conglomerate, has established 39 pre-schools across the country, enriching the lives of over 3,000 children. Launched in 2002, the Piyawara project aims to promote early childhood care and development, aligning with the United Nations Millennium Development Goal 2. The company has spent $2.5 million on the project over 12 years and has received recognition from the Sri Lankan Parliament and the country's President.

site_title: Returning to its rightful place
summary: Chateau Rauzan-Segla, a Second Growth wine in Bordeaux, has regained its former glory under the management of John Kolasa since 1994. After languishing in the shade, the Chateau's wines have shown significant improvement, with the 2006 vintage being the most promising, displaying a youthful black color and fruity scents. The 2004 and 2001 vintages also showed great quality, with the 2001 exhibiting a Margaux-style wine. The estate's restoration is complete, with Rauzan-Segla now back at the top of the list of Seconds, and some speculating it may one day be elevated to First Growth.

images.alt_text: Perhaps history will repeat itself, and Rauzan-Segla will like Mouton Rothschild in time be elevated to First Growth!

site_title: Myanmar mine workers search for jade, find misery
summary: Myanmar's jade industry, driven by China's insatiable demand for the gemstone, has become a lucrative but corrupt trade marred by violence, heroin addiction, and HIV infections. The industry, controlled by elite members of the military and rebel leaders, fuels a bloody ethnic conflict and profits from the suffering of thousands of miners, many of whom are addicted to heroin. The trade has been described as a "toxic mix" of jade and heroin, with Chinese companies and traders colluding with the military and rebels to smuggle billions of dollars' worth of jade into China. Despite the government's claims, the majority of jade mined in the country disappears into the black market, with billions of dollars lost to corruption and smuggling each year.

images.alt_text: As Myanmar experiments with democratic governance after almost 50 years of dictatorship, its handling of the jade industry has become a test of the new leaders.

site_title: ACES Awards category
summary: The Aces Awards honored an illustrious entrepreneur for their ability to communicate their vision and lead their company to a megabrand status. The award recipient is described as displaying strong entrepreneurial passion, flair, perseverance, and standing out as a grand example of a remarkable entrepreneur. However, no name or details about the award recipient are provided in the given article.

site_title: British chancellor's crowd-pleasing measures may backfire
summary: British Chancellor George Osborne has introduced crowd-pleasing economic measures ahead of the May UK general election. Critics argue that the measures, which include giveaways, may backfire and hinder the UK's recovery from a high government debt of 80% of GDP. Osborne's strategy is seen as a gamble, as the UK economy remains bogged down by debt. The outcome of the election will determine the future of the Conservative Party and Osborne's economic policies.

site_title: Thailand, Myanmar to revive industrial zone project
summary: Thailand and Myanmar are set to sign a pact in January 2015 to revive the Dawei industrial zone, a multi-billion dollar project that has been stuck in a quagmire. The complex, a 250 square kilometer deep-sea port and petrochemical hub, was seized by Thailand and Myanmar from Italian Thai Development in 2013. The Thai government hopes Italian Thai Development and Rojana Industrial Park will play a role in the first phase of the project, which aims to become South-east Asia's largest industrial complex. The move is seen as a potential boon for firms relying on the Malacca Strait shipping lane.

site_title: Make room for Japan in SGX's hook-up party
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Japan Exchange Group Inc (JPX) have signed a letter of intent to collaborate on various market development initiatives, including new derivatives products, commodities markets, and promotional activities. The joint effort aims to benefit both markets and prove that collaborations can be mutually beneficial, even among rivals. This move comes after SGX's Nikkei 225 Index contract saw a 9% year-on-year growth in trading volume in November.

site_title: Luxottica inks deal with Intel to develop hi-tech glasses
summary: Luxottica, the world's largest eyewear maker, has partnered with Intel to develop high-tech glasses that combine fashion with technology. The first glasses are expected to launch in 2015. The frames will feature Intel's chips and Luxottica's top fashion brands, such as Ray Ban and Oakley, without competing with Google's Internet-connected glasses. Intel aims to expand into wearable devices and is also involved in the Google Glass project. The partnership will involve joint research and development teams, but no financial details were disclosed.

site_title: Struggling China coal miners try to boost prices for 2015 contracts
summary: Chinese coal miners are raising spot prices in a domestic market struggling to recover from seven-year lows, with discussions on annual 2015 contracts being closely watched abroad. Benchmark prices have risen around 8% from lows in August, but are still down nearly 20% from the start of the year. Industry experts predict benchmark prices could drop again next year due to swollen stockpiles and tepid demand, with utilities holding strong bargaining power in negotiations. Top producers have suggested a 2015 contract price of 510-520 yuan, and the National Development and Reform Commission has urged multi-year contracts at 550 yuan a tonne.

site_title: EU launches antitrust probe into France's Orange bid for Jazztel
summary: The EU has launched an antitrust probe into Orange's $4.2 billion acquisition of Jazztel, a Spanish telecom company, citing concerns it would reduce competition and lead to higher prices for customers. The deal would cut the number of telecom companies in Spain to three from four, potentially harming customer choice. The 90-day probe aims to assess whether the acquisition distorts the market and undercuts competition. Analysts say the move reflects the consolidation of Europe's crowded telecom markets, where major companies are acquiring smaller rivals to offer a full range of services.

site_title: Time is not on South Asian nations' side
summary: South Asian nations face significant challenges in achieving regional integration due to ongoing tensions between nuclear-armed India and Pakistan. Despite Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to reinvigorate relations, the 18th SAARC Summit in Kathmandu failed to yield substantial results. Modi's bilateral meetings with neighboring countries did not lead to significant breakthroughs, and the summit's progress was hindered by the continued India-Pakistan tensions. SAARC's effectiveness has been questioned since its inception in 1985, and bilateral, sub-regional arrangements may be a more viable path to regional integration.

site_title: Going back to her classical roots
summary: British mezzo soprano Katherine Jenkins is releasing her 10th album, "Home Sweet Home," after a decade of platinum-selling albums and touring worldwide. Recorded at Abbey Road Studios, the album marks a return to her classical roots. Jenkins aims to showcase the fun and lovely side of classical music, featuring well-known songs and arias. The album is accompanied by a desire to settle down and take a break from touring, with her recently getting married and potentially starting a family.

images.alt_text: Mezzo soprano Katherine Jenkins recently released her 10th album, Home Sweet Home

site_title: Petronas defers decision to build C$36b LNG terminal in Canada
summary: Petronas, a Malaysian state-owned energy company, has deferred a decision to build a liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminal in Canada due to plunging oil prices. The $36 billion project, which was scheduled to start operating by 2019, now faces reduced costs and competition from US LNG suppliers. The deferral may lower expectations for LNG exports from Canada by 2020, and the company is considering exporting gas from Canada in liquid form to meet rising demand in Asia.

site_title: SGX, 'sorry' isn't good enough; let's have an independent review
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has faced its second major market disruption in less than a month, prompting criticism of the exchange's handling of the situation. The incident has led to a significant loss of confidence in the market, with many retail investors withdrawing their funds to overseas markets. The author, S Nallakaruppan, calls for a thorough investigation and an independent review to address the issues, including a lack of consultation with market players and a lack of confidence in the exchange's ability to provide a level playing field for all market participants.

site_title: Late weakness erodes STI gains
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 19 points to an intraday high of 3,322 on Thursday, driven by gains in Jardine Matheson, UOB, DBS, and Thai Beverage. However, late weakness eroded the gains, resulting in a net gain of only 1.43 points at 3,304.82. The broad market was weak, with an advance-decline score of 167-230 excluding warrants. Analysts predict a 10-15% dip in residential home prices over 2015-2016 due to a heavy physical oversupply and anticipated interest rate hikes.

site_title: Richest UK homebuyers to face big tax rise; others to get relief
summary: The UK's Chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, has revamped the stamp duty system, increasing taxes for the wealthiest homebuyers while reducing taxes for most others. The new system, which went into effect at midnight on Wednesday, will see buyers pay no tax on the first £125,000 of a home's price and 2% on the portion up to £250,000, with incremental increases up to 12% for homes above £1.5 million. This change is expected to affect London particularly, with the average house valued at over £6 million in areas like Mayfair and Knightsbridge.

site_title: Most socially responsible company in Asia
summary: Manila Electric Company (Meralco) has been named the most socially responsible company in Asia. The company serves over 5 million customers and has implemented thousands of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) activities since 2003, benefiting almost 50,000 marginalized families. Meralco's One Meralco Foundation invested 114.8 million pesos in CSR in 2013, providing safe, reliable, and affordable electricity to underserved communities. This recognition highlights Meralco's commitment to CSR and sustainability.

site_title: Achieving excellence and sustainability
summary: The Asia Corporate Excellence & Sustainability Awards (ACES) was held in Singapore, recognizing companies and individuals for their leadership and social responsibility. The inaugural awards ceremony honored over 50 winners, including Colin Tan of the Hatten Group, Mencast Holdings, and Globe Telecom, for their contributions to community care, sustainability, and diversity. The event aimed to promote excellence and sustainability in Asia, with the MORS Group's CEO stating that corporate sustainability is crucial for a better future. The awards also recognized outstanding leaders, entrepreneurs, and companies in various categories.

images.alt_text: Winners all demonstrated strong leadership skills, responsible business traits such as incorporation of ethical values, innovation in community impact as well as a commitment to protect the environment.

site_title: MORS Group - organiser of ACES Awards
summary: MORS Group, a leading Asia-focused organisation, aims to promote leadership and sustainability excellence through various programmes. Founded in 2012, the group's research team focuses on boosting the region's business prominence. MORS Group's mission is to unite and resilient Asia by providing a platform for companies, corporate leaders, and industrialists to share knowledge and engage stakeholders. The group's differentiated value lies in its research and development efforts, which have sustained and substantial impacts since its inception.

site_title: Looking at the world through posters
summary: French artist Jacques Villegle, 88, has had a unique career collecting and re-appropriating posters from the streets of Paris, creating a form of collective appropriation art. From 1948 to 2000, he would tear down posters and reassemble them on canvas, capturing moments in history stacked on top of one another. His work is now on display at the Partners & Mucciaccia Gallery until February, with prices ranging from S$13,000 to S$128,000. Curator Dominique Stella calls Villegle a "social artist" who seeks to share a message, rather than create aesthetically pleasing art.

site_title: Singapore stock market's malaise runs deep and is multi-fold
summary: The Singapore stock market is experiencing a prolonged slump, with a 21% decline in turnover to S$286 billion in the financial year ended June 30, 2014. Average daily turnover fell 29.8% to S$1.06 billion, and nearly 200 trading representatives quit the business annually. Factors contributing to the malaise include global financial crisis-induced low volumes, regulatory changes, and the shift to algorithmic trading. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and brokerage firms are exploring solutions, including new rules, market maker liquidity, and commission structures to incentivize trading representatives.

site_title: Meet the man who's making waves with advocacy for bitcoin in Japan
summary: Japanese lawmaker Mineyuki Fukuda has been instrumental in shaping the country's bitcoin policy, despite initial reluctance from the government. After the Mt Gox hack, Fukuda embarked on a listening tour to understand bitcoin, meeting traders and programmers. He then pushed for industry-led regulation, persuading his party to adopt a hands-off approach. Fukuda's efforts have led to the establishment of the Japan Authority of Digital Assets, which aims to set standards for bitcoin businesses, including the use of cold wallets and identity verification. His vision for bitcoin is not just as a form of money, but as a platform for blockchain technology, with potential applications in property registration and other areas.

site_title: Industrial S-Reits lagging regional peers in total returns
summary: Singapore-listed industrial Reits (S-Reits) lagged their regional peers in total returns this year, with year-to-date average and median returns of 11.5% and 12.2%, respectively, compared to 16.3% and 17.2% for the 25 industrial Reits in Asia-Pacific. Despite this, some S-Reits, such as Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) and Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT), offered the best year-to-date returns, with MIT maintaining its BBB+ rating from Fitch Ratings. The sector faces risks from a supply glut in Singapore, which may affect some industrial Reits.

site_title: Woodlands, Holland Rd sites take spotlight in H1 GLS slate
summary: The Singapore government has announced its latest Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme for the first half of 2015, featuring four new sites on the confirmed and reserve lists. The Woodlands site will be sold through a dual-envelope system, allowing for concept proposals and tender prices to be submitted separately. Three predominantly office sites on the reserve list will be available for application, including a site in Woodlands Square to sustain the development momentum of the Woodlands Regional Centre. The government has trimmed the total supply of private homes, including ECs, on the confirmed list to 3,020 units, 9.4% lower than the previous half-year supply.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: A luxe route to health
summary: The Luxe House, a two-month-old Dempsey Road spa, offers a unique concept that combines social space and spa services at affordable prices. Founder Chris Tan aims to provide straightforward, effective treatments in a plush setting, catering to condominium dwellers and busy individuals seeking regular spa treatments. Unlike other spas with numerous facilities, The Luxe House focuses on providing simple yet effective treatments at reasonable prices, making it an attractive option for those seeking a luxurious yet affordable spa experience.

site_title: Chrysler widens recall over air bags to just pickups
summary: Chrysler is expanding a US recall of vehicles with Takata Corp passenger-side air bags, but only for 2003 model year Ram pickup trucks. The recall now affects 149,150 pickup trucks, primarily in the southern US. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) had requested a broader recall, but Chrysler stopped short of including all models. The recall is due to defective Takata air bag inflators that can rupture and spray metal shards, particularly in humid areas. Chrysler claims it has not received any injury reports or laboratory test failures.

site_title: Fung Choi Media can be saved
summary: Fung Choi Media Group, a Hong Kong-based media conglomerate, is facing significant challenges. Its main subsidiary is in receivership, and the CEO, who is also the husband of the executive chairman, is in trouble over unreported transactions. The CEO's passport has been impounded in China, preventing her from attending the delayed AGM. The company's financial situation and leadership issues have raised concerns among shareholders, but a rescue plan may be possible, leaving the future of the company uncertain.

site_title: Human stories amid a sweep of history
summary: John Woo returns to the big screen with "The Crossing (Part One)", a two-part war-and-romance epic set in modern Chinese history. The film, based on the real-life sinking of a passenger ship in 1949, follows three couples as they navigate love and war amidst turmoil. The narrative is uneven, with a melodrama-laced script and visually connected storylines. The film focuses on General Lei Yifang's story, which is linked to major historical events, but the overall impact is marred by a lack of depth, leaving viewers with a nagging feeling that something is missing.

site_title: Vatican discovers undisclosed millions of euros in line accounts
summary: The Vatican has discovered hundreds of millions of euros in undisclosed accounts, significantly improving its financial situation. According to Australian Cardinal George Pell, the funds were "tucked away" in Holy See departments without appearing on the balance sheet. Pell stated that the discovery indicates the Vatican's finances are in better shape than previously believed.

site_title: Blackrock's China fund losing shine
summary: BlackRock's US$10.1 billion iShares FTSE A50 China Index ETF, the pioneer of tracking mainland Chinese shares, is at risk of losing its market-leading status due to underperformance. The fund has trailed its benchmark index by 4.6 percentage points this year, mainly due to its decade-long strategy of using derivatives proving more expensive for investors. This trend is attributed to reduced government curbs on foreign investors, allowing competitors to gain an advantage.

site_title: ARA-CWT takes prudent path in capital, risk management
summary: ARA-CWT Trust Management has refinance its S$375 million loan facilities to a new S$400 million facility agreement with a four-year term loan of S$185 million and a five-year term loan of S$150 million. The new refinancing includes a four-year revolving credit facility of S$65 million, spreading out the debt maturity profile and reducing interest rate volatility risk. The manager adopts a prudent approach to capital and risk management, maintaining a robust balance sheet and providing financial flexibility to meet its needs.

site_title: Gyllenhaal delivers as repulsive antihero
summary: Jake Gyllenhaal delivers a chilling performance as Louis Bloom, a morally bankrupt LA lowlife who becomes a freelance film crew member, capturing gruesome accidents for the 24-hour news cycle. As Bloom's skills improve, he manipulates crash scenes to get more graphic footage, benefiting under-pressure producer Nina Romina. The film, written and directed by Dan Gilroy, is a satirical commentary on society's obsession with sensationalized news. While Gyllenhaal's intense performance is impressive, the film lacks depth and soul, leaving a lasting impression of Bloom's repulsive character.

site_title: Putin orders use of cash from wealth funds to support banks
summary: President Vladimir Putin has ordered the use of Russia's National Wealth Fund to support domestic banks, aiming to counteract Western sanctions and economic woes. The fund, valued at $81.7 billion, will be used to recapitalize leading banks, such as VTB and Gazprombank, to help them meet loan demand. The move aims to bolster the Russian economy, which has been hit by sanctions and falling oil prices, and to promote infrastructure projects.

site_title: Mitsui bags gas-fired engine job from Japan shipbuilder
summary: Mitsui Engineering & Shipbuilding Co. has won an order to supply four gas-fired engines to Japan's Imabari Shipbuilding Co. for use in two liquefied natural gas (LNG) carriers. The order highlights growing interest in switching to cleaner-burning fuel due to lower gas prices. Mitsui has secured separate orders for engines to burn ethane, marking the world's first such engines. The orders aim to help shipbuilders comply with environmental regulations while capitalizing on the shale boom in the US, with 1,000 LNG-fuelled ships expected to be delivered globally by 2020.

site_title: Caring for children
summary: Great Eastern Life has donated over RM2 million to more than 180 children's charities in Malaysia, part of its long-term community project, ChildrenCare, launched in 1995. The project, in collaboration with government ministries and NGOs, focuses on education, health, and personal development for underprivileged children. With over 10,000 children helped so far, the project aims to inspire potential and promote corporate citizenship, supporting the government's goal of fostering a caring society.

images.alt_text: Great Eastern Life's ChildrenCare is a long-term community project that aims to address and resolve the ongoing struggles of the underprivileged children
Great Eastern Life's ChildrenCare is a long-term community project that aims to address and resolve the ongoing struggles of the underprivileged children

site_title: ECB will reassess stimulus measures early next year
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) announced plans to reassess stimulus measures early next year, with President Mario Draghi unveiling "substantially" lower forecasts for inflation and growth. The central bank cut its forecasts for gross domestic product and price gains through 2016. The ECB left the main refinancing rate at a record-low 0.05%. This move aims to gauge the need for further stimulus amid a sluggish economy.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank (ECB) policymakers will gauge the need for further stimulus at the beginning of 2015, President Mario Draghi said as he unveiled "substantially" lower forecasts for inflation and growth.

site_title: Thai consumer confidence falls in Nov; consumption may stay weak: survey
summary: Thailand's consumer confidence index fell to 79.4 in November, down from 80.1 in October, due to concerns over high living costs and a delayed government subsidy for farmers. Despite low inflation and efforts to boost the economy, consumption may remain weak due to high household debt. The junta has cut its GDP growth outlook, citing sluggish sectors like tourism, which saw a 8.7% decline in visitors for the first 10 months of 2014 compared to 2013.

site_title: Three's a company
summary: Three contemporary Singapore artists, Genevieve Chua, Jason Wee, and Eugene Soh, are showcasing their solo works at top galleries, demonstrating the diversity of local art. Genevieve Chua's "Parabola" features shaped canvases transformed into freestanding sculptures, while Jason Wee's "Requiem" explores the concept of monuments and memorials for the dead. Eugene Soh's "Renaissance City" reimagines famous artworks in a local context, using photography and digital manipulation to comment on Singaporean life.

images.alt_text: Chua, who has been working on shaped canvases for the past three years, says she intends her paintings to eventually be independent of the wall.
Chua, who has been working on shaped canvases for the past three years, says she intends her paintings to eventually be independent of the wall.
Wee's show includes watercolour paintings, paper sculptures, cloth sculptures, also a funerary wreath and granite sculptures
Soh's Hawker Philosophy, which was shot at Lau Pa Sat over six sessions since October, is a re-imagination of Raphael's School of Athens mural at the Vatican

site_title: Have-nots of oil world scramble for cover after Opec decision
summary: OPEC's decision to maintain production levels has sent oil prices plummeting to five-year lows, affecting struggling oil-producing countries like Venezuela, Nigeria, Iran, and Russia. These countries rely heavily on oil revenues, with budgets built around a price scenario now unrealistic. Venezuela, in particular, is facing a crisis, with President Nicolas Maduro's government announcing budget cuts and the risk of default. Analysts warn that the oil price pain could rekindle violent protests in Venezuela and exacerbate economic instability in other countries, including Nigeria and Iran.

site_title: Asian units weaker on strong US jobs data
summary: Asian currencies weakened on Thursday as the US dollar remained at multi-year highs due to solid US jobs data and an upcoming European Central Bank policy decision. South Korea's won slid to a 7-year low against the yen, while Indonesia's rupiah hit a 6-year low. Malaysia's ringgit fell to its weakest since 2010, and the euro sank to a 2-year low against the dollar. Despite expectations of an ECB hold, economists believe the euro will signal a move towards easing in the new year.

site_title: Famous Boston shopping spot getting a makeover
summary: Faneuil Hall Marketplace in Boston is undergoing its first major overhaul since the 1970s in an effort to attract more local visitors. The historic shopping and dining destination, which attracts 20 million tourists annually, has seen a decline in Bostonian visitors in recent years. The renovation aims to revitalize the area and make it more appealing to locals, following comments from former Mayor Thomas Menino that the market was the only place he could have lunch without being recognized.

site_title: Fed survey shows more broad-based hiring
summary: The Federal Reserve's Beige Book report shows widespread hiring across industries, with employment gains reported in all 12 Fed districts. Consumer spending improved due to falling petrol prices, and business contacts remained optimistic about the outlook. The report confirms positive momentum ahead of key jobs data on Friday, with economists expecting a 230,000 job increase and a six-year low unemployment rate of 5.8%. Despite strong hiring, overall price and wage inflation remained subdued.

site_title: Miyoshi ups stake in electric vehicle maker
summary: MAINBOARD-listed Miyoshi Precision Ltd has raised its stake in light electric vehicle (LEV) maker Green Galaxy from 5.13% to 55% in a bid to diversify into a higher-margin business. The company's CEO, Andrew Sin, attributes the investment to strong demand for cheaper alternative modes of transport in China's emerging cities, driven by the Chinese government's push for green technology. Green Galaxy manufactures three models of LEVs, including the supermini-sized Nebula with a maximum range of 120km, priced at S$12,000 in China.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Boustead Singapore's re-branding of its 4-star hotel offering Amba is progressing well. The company also completed a refinancing of its expiring £138 million bond debentures at below 4% interest, saving US$14 million annually. In contrast, Genting Singapore's VIP volumes have declined 14% in 2014, with analysts predicting a hit to profitability in the mature market. Boustead Singapore's energy infrastructure division may be impacted by low oil prices, but its high-quality management and growth strategy remain a positive factor.

site_title: Cathay pilots to work contractual hours only as pay talks break down
summary: Cathay Pacific pilots, representing over 2,000 pilots, have started a work-to-rule action, refusing to work additional shifts, amid ongoing pay talks with the airline. The move, which will see pilots work only contractual hours, raises concerns of delays and cancellations in the run-up to the busy Christmas season. The pilots' union, Hong Kong Aircrew Officers Association, claims a lack of pilots has led to excessive workload, with some pilots forced to work twice a month on their rostered days off.

site_title: Sustainability starts with us all
summary: The ACES Awards 2014, honoring corporate excellence and sustainability, received 140-plus nominations from across Asia. The jury, comprising experts, praised the nominees' efforts in sustainable business approaches. Winners were recognized for their strategic CSR efforts and inclusive business understanding. The organizers hope that the winners will continue to scale their efforts, with a focus on small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and collective action for the common good. The awards aim to inspire greater collaboration and promote sustainable practices in the region.

site_title: Trade finance to be wild card for banks in 2015
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), warns that the trade finance business will be a "wild card" for banks in 2015 due to a weakening economic prognosis for the region. Banks' cross-border exposures are healthy overall, but MAS cautions that higher exposure could pose risks to the banking system. The MAS notes that the banking system has evolved from being a net lender to advanced economies to a conduit of funds to emerging Asia since 2008.

site_title: Environment crusaders
summary: The Beacons of Asia publication honors business leaders and sustainability advocates in Asia, recognizing those who have implemented responsible practices and generated returns beyond financial gains. The ACES Awards, organized by MORS Group, identifies the selected individuals and companies. The publication aims to promote responsible best practices and encourage industry peers to follow suit, serving as a beacon of leadership excellence in Asia. Companies featured in the publication can use the ACES emblem on their marketing materials, representing their commitment to sustainability and leadership.

site_title: Weaker ringgit may mean good time for foreigners to pick up Malaysian property
summary: Malaysia's weaker ringgit is seen as a potential boon for foreigners looking to buy property, with some realtors predicting a pick-up in interest. The currency has slipped 2.34% against the Singapore dollar and 3.3% against the US dollar, with the ringgit hitting a five-year low. While some Malaysians may struggle with imported inflation, those earning other currencies like the Singapore dollar can benefit from the exchange rate. Realtors advise that investors consider the long-term growth and stability of the economy, as well as the property market, before making a decision.

site_title: In brief
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) constituents will remain unchanged following its quarterly review. The STI reserve list, comprising Keppel Land, UOL Group, CapitaCommercial Trust, Suntec Reit, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings, will be reviewed again on March 5 next year. Meanwhile, other indices in the FTSE ST Index Series will undergo changes effective December 22.

site_title: The big oil bust of 2014 may be even bigger in 2015
summary: Crude oil prices have dropped 40% since June, from $115 to $70 a barrel, resulting in a massive transfer of wealth from producers to consumers, estimated at $1.5 trillion annually. This decline is expected to boost the global economic recovery and cause strain on major exporters such as Nigeria, Venezuela, Russia, and Iran.

site_title: China builders seize window for bond issues
summary: China's property developers seized the opportunity to tap the US dollar high-yield bond market after the central bank's interest rate cut, raising a combined $900 million. The issuers, including Logan Property, Yuzhou Properties, and Sunac China Holdings, plan to use the funds to repay debt and replenish land banks amid a slowdown in China's property market. The sector has seen improved sentiment following the rate cut, with analysts expecting the central government to adjust policies to maintain momentum.

site_title: CapitaLand's Ascott buys Jakarta serviced residence for S$90m
summary: CapitaLand's Ascott Limited has signed a conditional agreement to buy a 185-unit serviced residence in Jakarta, Indonesia for S$90 million. The acquisition will take Ascott's brand to Vietnam and mark its first property in Laos. Ascott expects the Jakarta property to be handed over in the second quarter of 2015 and will also manage a 222-unit property in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. The company aims to expand its presence in South-east Asia, with plans for more openings in 2015.

site_title: US: Wall St dips at open after Draghi comments
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday after European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that the bank would reassess the impact of its monetary policy stimulus early next year and take further action if necessary. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 21.32 points, or 0.12%, to 17,891.3, while the S&P 500 lost 2.8 points, or 0.13%, to 2,071.53.

site_title: ECB holds key rate steady at 0.05%
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained its key interest rates unchanged at its monthly policy meeting, holding the main "refinancing" rate at 0.05% and the marginal lending and deposit rates at 0.30% and minus 0.20% respectively.

site_title: Offshore & marine sector: five ways to identify bright spots
summary: The offshore and marine (O&M) sector in Singapore is facing challenges due to the decline in oil prices, which has led to a decline in stocks in the industry. However, sector analysts suggest that not all O&M companies will be negatively impacted, and some may even be undervalued. Five key factors to identify bright spots in the O&M industry include: 1) the segment of oil and gas activities the company is involved in, 2) the order book of companies, 3) the quality of contracts, 4) exposure to regional and cabotage markets, and 5) a strong balance sheet. Companies with a strong order book, quality contracts, and exposure to protected markets may be better positioned to weather the storm.

site_title: China drives third straight record year for emerging market bond issuance
summary: China drove a record third year of emerging market bond issuance, with over $525 billion in bonds underwritten this year, up from $473.3 billion last year. Chinese issuance surged 123% while India and Brazil saw 52% and 21% increases, respectively. Strong demand for higher-yielding assets from investors, combined with central banks cutting interest rates, fueled the growth. In contrast, Russian firms were largely excluded from international bond markets due to sanctions, with issuance plummeting 80% compared to last year.

site_title: Barnes & Noble to buy Microsoft's stake in Nook business
summary: Barnes & Noble to buy Microsoft's 17% stake in Nook business, a unit comprising e-readers, e-books, and college bookstores. The company's revenue fell 2.6% to $1.69 billion in the second quarter, mainly due to the Nook business. Net income also declined to $12.3 million. Pearson Plc owns 5% of the Nook business.

site_title: GrabTaxi books US$250m in benchmark funding
summary: GrabTaxi, a Malaysia-based taxi-booking platform, has secured US$250 million in Series D funding from Japan's Softbank, bringing its total funding to US$340 million. Industry observers warn that the company faces long-term sustainability challenges, as it competes with larger players like Uber, which has raised over US$1.5 billion in funding. To maintain its lead, GrabTaxi needs to expand into new markets, such as India, China, and South America, and find a balance between charging commuters and taxi drivers. The company plans to focus on growth and expansion within the region, with a goal of becoming the dominant player in South-east Asia.

site_title: Encore for ChildAid's finest performers
summary: The 10th anniversary of ChildAid, a charity concert, will feature a star-studded lineup of performers, including alumni from previous shows. At 24, soprano Janani Sridhar, who sang Puccini's O Mio Babbino Caro, will make a special appearance. Other returning performers include piano prodigy Abigail Sin, popstar Farisha Ishak, and YouTube sensation Clarence Liew. The concert will also include foreign talent from Japan and Thailand, celebrating the charity's decade-long mission to support children's welfare.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: ECB's Draghi concern about some impacts of lower oil price on eurozone economy
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi expressed concern over the mixed impact of lower oil prices on the eurozone economy, which could boost costs but also drag down inflation. The estimated direct and indirect impact of falling oil on inflation is 0.4% next year and 0.1% the year after. Draghi noted that the lower price may alter the profile of inflation rates over the coming months, particularly in the next few months, as eurozone inflation is below the ECB's target.

site_title: Indie scene rocks
summary: Singapore's indie music scene thrives despite limited airplay, thanks to passionate fans and musicians organizing unconventional shows. The Diarists, a local collective, organizes rooftop, flyover, and living room concerts, creating a unique connection between artists and audiences. The group aims to promote folk-inspired singer-songwriters and has achieved a milestone of three years of operation. Meanwhile, a Museum of Independent Music is being established in Kampong Glam to preserve the history of local music, featuring memorabilia, posters, and live performances. Local music scene veteran Kevin Matthews promotes original music through events at Artistry cafe, providing a platform for indie bands to showcase their work.

site_title: Top companies to work for in Asia
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Top companies to work for in Asia include Mencast Holdings, Leeden National Oxygen, and Asiatic Group (Holdings) Limited. Mencast emphasizes treating employees with respect and investing in their development, while Leeden prioritizes product positioning and quality. Asiatic Group has expanded into the energy sector with significant investments. Panaflo Controls, a SME, attributes its success to finding and retaining talented employees, with a focus on teamwork and perseverance. These companies have been recognized for their leadership and commitment to employee development, making them attractive workplaces in the region. They have also been featured in the ACES Awards.

site_title: 3 Samsung senior execs to go: source
summary: Samsung Electronics is facing a rapid decline in profit due to soft sales, with the company's smartphone market share falling year on year for the last three quarters. Three senior executives are leaving the mobile division, including global marketing chief DJ Lee, directly reporting to division chief JK Shin. Despite retaining his post, Shin will face pressure as the company prepares to announce its annual business reorganisation plan, which may include reducing executive-level positions by 25% and potentially hiving off its medical equipment business. Samsung's annual profit is expected to be its worst in three years in 2014.

site_title: US financial firms need more top women managers: study
summary: A report from Oliver Wyman found that US financial firms are not promoting women to top management positions quickly enough, despite increasing female representation on boards. In 2013, women made up 13% of executive committees and 20% of directors, but more than a third of companies had no females in top management. The study suggests that the industry needs to improve its pipeline of top female managers to achieve greater diversity and representation.

site_title: Australians defy income fears and keep shopping
summary: Australian shoppers defied income fears and kept spending in October, with retail sales rising 0.4% and trade deficit shrinking by more than expected. The data, released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, is a hopeful sign that consumers are weathering a slowing economy. The upbeat news comes after the economy grew just 0.3% in the third quarter, less than half the pace analysts expected. The increase in exports, particularly to China, contributed to the improved trade data.

site_title: Early next year for reassessment of ECB policies' impact: Draghi
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi announced that the ECB will reassess the impact of its monetary policy stimulus early next year and consider further measures if necessary. The bank has already cut borrowing costs to record lows and started buying repackaged debt to boost growth. Draghi stated that the ECB will evaluate the impact of recent oil price developments on inflation trends and remains committed to using unconventional instruments to address low inflation risks. The Governing Council will reassess the monetary stimulus and balance sheet expansion in early 2015.

site_title: International air passenger demand up 5.7% in October: IATA
summary: International air passenger demand rose 5.7% in October, according to IATA, building on a 5.2% increase in September. Capacity grew 5.5%, leading to a 0.1 percentage point increase in load factors to 79.1%. The positive outlook for air travel is attributed to improving economies in Asia-Pacific and the US, offsetting weakness in the Eurozone and China. IATA Director General Tony Tyler noted that falling oil prices have boosted airline stocks but may signal a broader economic slowdown.

site_title: Micron to inject US$4b into expansion of Woodlands fabrication plant
summary: Micron Technology plans to invest approximately US$4 billion in expanding its fabrication plant in Woodlands, Singapore, one of the largest investments in the country's semiconductor industry in a decade. The expansion will add 255,000 square feet of clean room space and help implement the production of 3D Nand, an advanced type of flash memory. Construction is expected to begin in 2015, with initial manufacturing output likely to take place in 2017. The move is seen as a testament to Singapore's competitiveness in wafer fabrication, with the Singapore Economic Development Board welcoming the new investment.

site_title: ACES Awards design crafted by Royal Selangor
summary: Royal Selangor has designed the ACES Awards using pewter, featuring a freestanding frieze on a solid wood base with gold plating on a matt black background. The design symbolizes Asia's finest responsible corporate leaders. With over 250 skilled craftsmen, Royal Selangor continuously pushes the envelope in pewter design while staying true to its heritage. This design is part of the company's expansion into gifting, corporate mementos, and awards.

site_title: EU grants Vietnam US$633m in aid for energy, development
summary: The European Union has granted Vietnam a non-refundable aid package worth US$633 million to strengthen its energy and health sectors, as well as boost governance and its legal system. The 400 million euro aid will focus on sustainable energy and democracy, while a 114 million euro aid will support health sector reform. The agreement is part of Vietnam's major funding sources for infrastructure and socio-economic development, with the EU being Vietnam's second-largest trade partner, worth 24.2 billion euro last year.

site_title: US jobless claims fall, unwind prior week's increase
summary: US jobless claims fell last week, decreasing by 17,000 to 297,000, following a prior week's increase. The four-week moving average of claims remained below 300,000 for 12 straight weeks, indicating labor market strength. Economists expect nonfarm payrolls to increase by 230,000 in November, marking the 10th consecutive month of gains above 200,000. The unemployment rate is forecast to remain steady at a six-year low of 5.8%.

site_title: Indonesia to lead S-E Asian online shopping boom
summary: Indonesia is poised to lead a boom in online shopping across South-east Asia as internet access expands and investors pour into the region's growing retail startups. The country's middle class is expected to drive the growth, with business-to-consumer e-commerce projected to increase five-fold by 2020. Indonesia's e-commerce sector is expected to reach $35 billion by 2020, with Tokopedia, a popular marketplace, securing a $100 million investment from SoftBank and Sequoia Capital. Despite challenges, analysts believe the country's e-commerce sector has huge potential, with the government taking steps to support the sector.

site_title: India to press G20 for deadline to cut remittance costs: sources
summary: India is set to push the G20 to establish a two-year deadline to reduce remittance costs, aiming to save over $20 billion for developing countries. The move comes after G20 leaders last month pledged to cut the average cost of sending money home to 5% by 2014, but that deadline has been missed. India, the world's largest recipient of remittances, plans to attend a G20 meeting in Istanbul and will demand a deadline, with some countries already reducing costs to near 3%.

site_title: Euro hits new dollar-low before ECB meeting
summary: The euro hit a two-year low against the dollar at US$1.2296 before the European Central Bank's key policy meeting. European stock markets rose, with London's FTSE 100 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 edging up. The Bank of England is expected to keep its interest rate at 0.50%, while the ECB may announce anti-deflation measures. The euro has been sold ahead of the meeting but is expected to signal a move in the new year, with additional easing likely in the first quarter of 2015.

site_title: City Buzz
summary: Casio introduces next-generation smart analogue watches with Bluetooth and GPS technologies, aiming to achieve high accuracy. The G-Shock GPW-1000 and Oceanus OCW-G1000 feature hybrid timekeeping systems, while the Edifice collection uses Bluetooth for smart phone linking and inbuilt e-mail notifications. Meanwhile, a new New York-style deli, Sacha & Sons, opens in Singapore, offering traditional Jewish-inspired dishes. A Christmas market, Dream Christmas Market, will be held at Dream furniture store, featuring designer furniture and gifts. An Android app, Whistle Phone Finder, helps users locate misplaced phones by whistling.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Thai Airways to seek government approval for restructuring plan in January
summary: Thai Airways International plans to seek government approval for its restructuring plan in January, according to its newly appointed president. The airline expects to raise fuel hedging amid declining global oil prices, which will improve its earnings performance next year. No further details were provided.

site_title: Oil forecasts dive after Opec keeps output target: Reuters poll
summary: Oil price forecasts have plummeted after Opec's decision not to cut output, with a Reuters poll showing a 23% drop in average forecasts for 2015, citing a global glut. North Sea Brent crude is now expected to average $82.50 a barrel, down $11.20 from last month's forecast. Analysts predict a surplus of 1.5-2 million barrels per day, with Brent averaging $87.40 in 2016.

site_title: SGX, Japan exchange ink pact to promote markets
summary: SGX and Japan Exchange Group Inc (JPX) signed a letter of intent to jointly develop and promote their markets. The partnership aims to create new derivatives products, collaborate on commodities markets, and enhance promotional activities. This move is seen as a way to deepen their relationship, particularly in the derivatives and IT areas, and contribute to the development of capital markets in Asia. The partnership follows SGX's success with its Nikkei 225 Index Futures product, which saw a 9% year-on-year growth in November.

site_title: China banks' wealth management products given bond, stock market entry: sources
summary: China is allowing commercial banks to sell wealth management products directly into the domestic bond and stock markets, aiming to boost direct investment. The move aims to curb the country's shadow banking sector, which has grown rapidly. Banks must set aside funds to guard against potential risks. This change follows a report showing China's shadow banking sector ranks as the third largest globally, with the sector continuing to grow at a breakneck pace.

site_title: Putin proposes amnesty for returning capital to Russia
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin proposed an amnesty for individuals returning capital to Russia, exempting them from tax penalties. This move comes as the country expects net capital outflows of over $100 billion, potentially leading to recession and a decline in the rouble against the dollar.
