Putin also called for measures to tackle speculators in the foreign exchange market. The proposal aims to encourage the return of capital and stabilize the economy.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher, with the Straits Times Index gaining 1.43 points to 3,304.82. Traders brushed off new US President Trump's threats to extend the stocks rally, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. Investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: UK house prices slow again in November, up 8.2% year-on-year: Halifax
summary: UK house prices rose 8.2% year-on-year in November, the smallest increase since February, according to Halifax. This marks a slowdown from the previous month's 0.4% fall. Economists had expected a 8.0% rise and 0.3% increase. November prices rose 0.4% month-over-month, recovering from the October decline.

site_title: UK new car registrations rise 8% in November
summary: British new car registrations rose 8% in November, reaching 172,327, with the year-to-date total exceeding 2.3 million, the highest level in seven years. This marks the 33rd consecutive month of growth. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders forecasts a total of 2.46 million new car sales for the year, the highest level in a decade, driven by cheap credit and economic recovery in Britain.

site_title: China denounces foreign influence in Hong Kong after US criticism
summary: China has reiterated its stance against foreign interference in Hong Kong affairs, following a top US official's backing of democracy protesters. China's foreign ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying stated that Hong Kong affairs are domestic affairs and that Beijing opposes outside interference. The US diplomat, Daniel Russel, called for "competitive" 2017 elections in Hong Kong, which China sees as a threat to its authority. China hopes other countries will match words with actions to promote Hong Kong's stability and prosperity. Tensions remain high between China and the US over the issue.

images.alt_text: China on Thursday reiterated that foreign countries should not stoke trouble in Hong Kong after a top US official gave Washington's strongest backing yet to democracy protesters in the Chinese territory.

site_title: Indonesia's current account deficit to fall below 3% of GDP this year
summary: Indonesia's current account deficit is expected to fall below 3% of GDP this year, driven by a sharp drop in global oil markets and higher domestic fuel prices. The deficit narrowed to 3.07% in the third quarter, compared to 4.07% in the previous quarter. Despite the improvement, it remains higher than the central bank's target of 2.5% of GDP. A decline in oil prices can narrow the deficit by around $170 million.

site_title: Toyota lessons lost on Takata as it resists US recall order
summary: Takata Corp has rejected a US order to expand its air bag inflator recall nationwide, citing uncertainty about the cause of the defective products. The Japanese firm's resistance to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration's demand is seen as driven by a need to protect itself from legal liability, but may harm its public image and long-term business. Experts warn that ignoring public opinion can lead to financial ruin, with one president stating that Takata's approach "can put you out of business long before a court of law decides about liability."

site_title: ECB sharply cuts inflation and growth forecasts
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has lowered its forecasts for growth and inflation in the eurozone, citing a deteriorated outlook. The bank now predicts 0.5% inflation in 2014, 0.7% in 2015, and 1.3% in 2016, down from previous forecasts. Economic output is expected to grow 0.8% this year, 1.0% in 2015, and 1.5% in 2016, down from previous predictions. The cuts in forecasts suggest the ECB may take further steps to bolster the eurozone economy, which has been struggling.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank slashed its forecasts on Thursday for growth and inflation over the next two years, saying the outlook had deteriorated since its last staff forecasts were published in September.

site_title: Struggling China coal producers try to boost prices for 2015 contracts
summary: Chinese coal producers are raising spot prices in a domestic market struggling to recover from seven-year lows. Benchmark prices for Chinese steam coal have increased by nearly 8% from lows in August, but remain down by nearly a fifth from the start of the year. Industry experts predict that benchmark prices could drop again next year due to swollen stockpiles and tepid demand. Top producers, including Shenhua Coal, have suggested a 2015 contract price of 510-520 yuan per tonne, while the National Development and Reform Commission has urged utilities to agree to a 2015 term price of 550 yuan per tonne.

site_title: Pilot strike grounds half of long-haul flights at Lufthansa
summary: Pilots at Lufthansa started a strike on Thursday, grounding about half of scheduled long-haul flights, as they dispute an early retirement scheme. The strike, the tenth this year, is over a demand to retain a scheme allowing pilots to retire at 55 with 60% of their pay. The strike, which will last until Friday, has already impacted the airline's operating profit, wiping 160 million euros off its earnings this year. Lufthansa's board has approved plans to expand low-cost operations to compete with budget carriers.

site_title: Tokyo stocks close up 0.94% to new seven-year high
summary: Tokyo stocks reached a seven-year high, closing 0.94% up, driven by a lower yen and record close on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index hit 17,887.21, its best finish since 2007, and the Topix index climbed 0.76%. This marks a five-day winning streak. The ruling coalition is expected to win upcoming elections, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: European shares edge higher, focus on ECB meeting
summary: European shares rose, reaching a 2-1/2-month high, driven by an improving US economic outlook and expectations of further stimulus from the European Central Bank. The FTSEurofirst 300 index edged up 0.1% to 1,401.67 points, with Ryanair jumping 8.7% after raising its full-year profit guidance. ECB President Mario Draghi is set to present updated forecasts, with investors awaiting potential announcements on stimulus measures.

site_title: Thai consumer confidence index falls in November
summary: Thailand's consumer confidence index dropped to 79.4 in November, the second decline since the May 22 army coup, amid concerns over high living costs and household debt. Despite low inflation, the economy has not fully recovered, with the central bank keeping interest rates low due to high debt levels. The junta has cut its GDP growth outlook, citing sluggish exports and domestic demand. Tourist arrivals rose in October, but overall economic growth remains sluggish, with the state planning agency estimating 1% growth for 2014.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.54% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.54% in the opening minutes of trade on Thursday, following a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index climbed 126.19 points to 23,554.81.

site_title: Hong Kong student leaders consider protest retreat
summary: Hong Kong student leaders consider ending a two-month protest occupation, following violent clashes with police. The decision will be made within a week. Public support for the movement has waned, and police violence has led to dozens of injuries. The protesters aim to force reform, with a demand for fully free leadership elections. China insists on vetting candidates, which demonstrators see as a pro-Beijing move. Washington backs the protesters, calling for competitive leadership elections, while the protesters plan to continue hunger strikes to pressure the government.

site_title: Gold eases on dollar strength ahead of ECB meet, US jobs data
summary: Gold prices edged lower in Asian trading on Thursday, falling 0.4% to $1,204.70 an ounce, ahead of the European Central Bank's policy decision and US weekly jobless claims data. The US dollar index reached a 5-1/2 year high, driven by optimism over the US economy. Gold prices have struggled to gain traction despite recent gains, with demand weakening due to a stronger dollar and softer oil prices. Investors await key events to determine the metal's trajectory.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close higher as China stocks sizzle
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.7% to 23,832.56 points on Thursday, driven by mainland China's blistering rally. Financial and energy stocks led the gains, with China's market reaching its highest level since mid-2011. Chinese investment flowed into Hong Kong, taking up 0.41 billion yuan of the daily quota. The China Enterprises Index gained 3.8% to 11,481.03 points.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on upbeat US outlook, domestic data
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to 5,360.5, driven by better-than-expected trade deficit and retail sales data, and positive US economic data. The S&P/ASX 200 index has gained for three consecutive sessions. Commodity-related shares led the gains, while Santos fell 10.5% after scrapping a plan to raise 1 billion euros. The US economy showed resilience with record highs in the Dow and S&P, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Cathay Pacific pilots in 'work-to-rule' over pay dispute
summary: Cathay Pacific pilots in Hong Kong went on a "work-to-rule" strike, starting Thursday, over a pay dispute that has been ongoing for a year. The Hong Kong Aircrew Officers Association (HKAOA) represents over 2,000 pilots and has received 92% approval for the action, which will limit pilots to their contractual hours. The strike comes despite a 4% pay hike announced in November. Cathay Pacific expressed disappointment and said talks would be put on hold, while the airline's CEO said pilots would continue to fulfill their duties despite the strike.

site_title: HDB resale prices down 0.8% in November to 40-month low: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore fell 0.8% month-on-month and 6.3% year-on-year to a 40-month low in November, according to SRX. The 1,350 HDB flats sold in November saw a 13.1% drop from October, but 11.4% more flats changed hands than in November 2013. Resale prices have dropped 9.8% since the April 2013 peak, while resale volume is 63% lower than the May 2010 peak.

site_title: ECB set to talk up stimulus measures but hold fire
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to announce stimulus measures to combat deflation, but will not act until early 2015. Inflation in the eurozone slowed to 0.3% in November, prompting concerns of imminent deflation. The ECB has already implemented rate cuts, cheap loans, and asset purchases, but is considering quantitative easing to stimulate the economy. Analysts expect the ECB to send a strong message that it will take action to raise inflation, with some speculating that QE could be announced as early as the first quarter of 2015.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.91% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.91% higher on Thursday, driven by a weakening yen that makes Japanese exporters more competitive abroad. The Nikkei 225 index rose 161.48 points to a fresh seven-year high of 17,881.91. This follows a record close on Wall Street, where the US economy was reported to be growing, leading to fresh record highs on the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500.

site_title: Gaylin COO Teo Bee Kheng dies
summary: Gaylin Holdings announced the death of Teo Bee Kheng, executive director and COO, who died on Dec 2 at 60. His brother Teo Bee Hoe has taken over as COO, and CEO Desmond Teo Bee Chiong stated that the company has a strong team in place for continued smooth operations.

site_title: Universal Terminal postpones up to S$1b IPO
summary: Universal Terminal has postponed its up to S$1 billion IPO due to uncertain market conditions, targeting a listing before the Chinese new year in February. The IPO was initially set to open on December 4 and list on December 18. The company, owned by Hin Leong Group and PetroChina, is one of the largest independent oil storage terminals in Asia.

site_title: Koh Boon Hwee named independent director of Pictet's private bank in Singapore
summary: Veteran investor Koh Boon Hwee has been appointed as an independent board director of Bank Pictet & Cie (Asia) Ltd, the Pictet Group's private banking entity in Singapore. In this role, he will advise and guide the wealth management team and its board, as well as Pictet's managing partners. Koh, currently managing partner of private equity firm Credence, brings experience from previous positions at Singapore's leading companies, including chairman of DBS Bank, Singapore Airlines, and SingTel.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 3.73 points to 1761.88. The market saw 79 gainers and 51 losers, with volume reaching 56.3 million lots worth RM20.89 million.

site_title: MND moves Holland Rd site to reserve list, adds Woodlands office site to reserve list
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) has moved the Holland Road site to the reserve list of the 1st half 2015 Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme, adopting a concept and price revenue tender to ensure the site's development enhances the unique charm of the Holland Village Identity Node. A second commercial site in Woodlands Regional Centre will also be released for sale via the reserve list. Two other predominantly office development sites at Marina View and Beach Road will be carried over from the H2 2014 reserve list.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Samsung mobile executives to leave after profit slide: source
summary: Samsung Electronics is experiencing a rapid decline in profit due to sagging smartphone sales. Three deputies to division chief J.K. Shin are leaving, including global marketing chief D.J. Lee, amidst a 25% reduction in executive-level positions for its mobile communications business. The company faces intense competition from Chinese rivals like Xiaomi and Apple's iPhones. Samsung is expected to announce its annual business reorganisation plan by next week, which may include hive-offs of its medical equipment and fibre optics businesses.

site_title: Google to introduce child-friendly versions of products
summary: Google plans to release child-friendly versions of its popular products, including search, YouTube, and Chrome, for users under 12 years old. The company aims to provide a "fun and safe" experience for children, giving parents tools to oversee their use of the products. No timeline has been announced for the rollout, but Google has confirmed the effort is underway.

site_title: Brent heads above US$70 after US crude stocks drop
summary: Brent crude oil prices rose above US$70 a barrel, gaining nearly 1% due to a drop in US crude stocks and refineries increasing output. US crude futures rose 64 cents to US$68.02 a barrel. Analysts expect prices to fall further, but a temporary reprieve is possible after "bearish exhaustion". Markets are watching US data for clues on demand strength, with investors focusing on the US economy's resilience.

site_title: Toyota to recall 190,000 cars in Japan, China over Takata air bags
summary: Toyota Motor Corp will recall 190,000 vehicles in Japan and China to replace potentially defective front passenger-side air bags made by Takata Corp. The recall follows an unusual deployment of a Takata-made air bag in a Toyota model at a scrapyard last month. Toyota says it's a precautionary measure, but the cause of the problem is unknown and no injuries or deaths have been reported. The recall affects 19 models, including the Corolla and Alphard, in Japan, and 5,000 cars in China.

site_title: Government trims land for private homes, ECs on H1 2015 confirmed list
summary: The Singapore government will offer land for approximately 3,020 private residential units, including 490 executive condominiums, through the confirmed list for the first half 2015 Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme. This is lower than the previous second half 2014 GLS programme. No commercial or hotel sites will be offered in the H1 2015 confirmed list.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Japan output gap widens in blow to BOJ inflation target
summary: Japan's output gap widened to minus 2.7% in the third quarter, exceeding the previous quarter's minus 2.2%, as the economy slipped into recession. The negative output gap indicates weak demand and deflationary pressure, making it challenging for the Bank of Japan to guide inflation to its 2% target.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, LionGold, NOL, SingPost
summary: Singapore Exchange delayed its market open by 3.5 hours due to a software glitch, its second major disruption in a month. LionGold Corp divested a 10% stake in the Amayapampa Gold Project for S$3.5 million. Neptune Orient Lines is seeking a buyer for its logistics unit APL Logistics at a price of US$1 billion. SingPost acquired Australia-based parcel delivery company Couriers Please Holdings for S$105 million.

site_title: LCD Global rebrands Laos serviced residence as Somerset Vientiane
summary: LCD Global Investments rebranded its serviced residence in Vientiane, Laos, as Somerset Vientiane, with 116 newly-upgraded apartments set to open on December 9. The service residence will be managed by The Ascott Limited for the first two years under an agreement signed in May 2014.

site_title: Boeing completes test flight with 'green diesel'
summary: Boeing successfully completed the first test flight with "green diesel," a biofuel made from vegetable oils, waste cooking oil, and waste animal fats, offering potential to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in aviation. The Boeing 787 ecoDemonstrator flew with 85% conventional fuel and 15% green diesel. The company aims to provide data to support commercial aviation approval and meet industry environmental goals. Green diesel could supply up to 1% of global jet fuel demand and is near price parity with conventional fuel, thanks to US government incentives.

site_title: US calls for 'competitive' Hong Kong polls
summary: The US has expressed strong backing for Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement, urging for "competitive" 2017 elections with a range of candidates. Top US diplomat Daniel Russel told lawmakers that a legitimate election would enhance the chief executive's legitimacy, but China has dismissed US concerns, calling the issue an internal matter. US rights activists have criticized the muted response, saying it undermines the US's commitment to democracy and human rights. The US has also been accused of prioritizing relations with China over supporting the protesters.

site_title: US healthcare spending registers smallest growth since 1960
summary: US healthcare spending increased 3.6% in 2013, the smallest rate of growth since 1960, with per capita growth slowing to 2.9%. This modest increase reflects pressure on providers and President Obama's healthcare reform, which put checks on provider charges. Healthcare spending accounted for 17.4% of GDP, with premiums for private insurance rising 2.8% and Medicare spending growing 3.4%. Despite aging and population growth, Americans used fewer medical services in 2013.

site_title: Credit Bureau Singapore to offer consumers enhanced debt reports
summary: Credit Bureau Singapore (CBS) launched an enhanced debt report, providing consumers with total credit limit and outstanding balances across financial institutions. The report is available online for S$6.42. The move aims to help consumers make better borrowing decisions and avoid deeper debt. It also benefits other borrowers at risk of credit problems, allowing them to take steps to reduce their outstanding debt. This information can aid in reducing the risk of credit problems and promote responsible borrowing practices.

site_title: Sony Pictures slams 'malicious' hack attack, mum on North Korea
summary: Sony Pictures has confirmed a "malicious" cyberattack that resulted in the theft of confidential information, including movies and personnel files. The company denies knowing the full extent of the attack, but notes it is "sophisticated" and "brazen." The investigation is ongoing, with the FBI also probing the breach. The attack may be linked to a comedy film about a CIA plot to assassinate North Korea's leader, but Sony Pictures has declined to comment on a report that North Korea was behind the attack, calling it "not accurate."

site_title: SoftBank to invest US$250m in taxi app firm GrabTaxi
summary: SoftBank Corp has invested US$250 million in GrabTaxi Holdings, becoming the top investor in the Southeast Asian mobile taxi-booking application. The funding will be used to accelerate GrabTaxi's expansion in the region, following similar investments in India's online retail market and Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. GrabTaxi has raised US$340 million in funding, with SoftBank's stake to be determined. The investment comes as taxi-hailing apps gain popularity in Southeast Asia, with GrabTaxi's user base increasing six-fold to half a million and its taxi drivers growing four-fold to 60,000 over the past year.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend gains, dollar approaches 120 yen
summary: Asian markets continued their upward trend, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, and Shanghai gaining 0.76%, 0.46%, 0.72%, and 0.27% respectively. The dollar approached 120 yen, a level not seen in over seven years, following a strong US economy report. The euro struggled ahead of the European Central Bank meeting. The Strait Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% despite US tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Britain launches new 'Google tax' on multinationals
summary: The British government has introduced a new tax rate of 25% on profits generated by multinational companies in the UK, aimed at preventing them from avoiding tax through complex corporate structures. The "Google tax" will come into force in April and is expected to raise over £1 billion in tax revenues over the next five years. The move is part of a broader crackdown on multinational firms and banks that use tax avoidance schemes to minimize their tax bills. Finance minister George Osborne said it's "not fair" to other British firms and the British people.

site_title: India to fast-track US investments
summary: India announced a move to fast-track US investments, following a global trade dispute settlement and President Barack Obama's visit. A new committee will identify and address regulatory bottlenecks, facilitating investment from US companies. This comes after the US invested $806 million in India in 2013-14, with two-way trade valued at $100 billion. The countries aim to boost trade to $500 billion, with relations recovering after a diplomatic incident last year under Prime Minister Narendra Modi's leadership. The move is part of efforts to boost US investments in India.

site_title: Opec chief says cartel facing 'challenging' time
summary: Opec's president and Nigeria's oil minister, Diezani Alison-Madueke, says the cartel is facing a challenging time due to falling oil prices. Many Opec and non-Opec countries are "suffering immensely" from the price drop, which has affected Venezuela, Angola, Algeria, Iran, and Nigeria. The cartel's crude oil prices are currently around $70 a barrel, and Alison-Madueke is monitoring the situation to determine if a special meeting is needed to discuss strategies. Nigeria is reviewing its fiscal and monetary policies to address the predicted revenue shortfall.

site_title: CapitaLand's Ascott acquires Jakarta serviced residence for S$90 million
summary: CapitaLand's serviced residence unit, The Ascott Limited, has acquired the 185-unit Ascott Kuningan Jakarta in Jakarta for S$90 million. The acquisition is part of a larger expansion strategy. Meanwhile, The Ascott Limited has also secured a contract to manage the 222-unit Ascott Waterfront Saigon in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, set to open in 2016 as the brand's 13th property in the country.

images.alt_text: CAPITALAND said on Thursday morning that its serviced residence unit The Ascott Limited is acquiring the Ascott Kuningan Jakarta for S$90 million.

site_title: IBM signs US$1.25b cloud deal with WPP
summary: IBM has signed a $1.25 billion cloud deal with WPP, the world's top advertising firm, in its third major billion-dollar-plus contract in the fourth quarter. The seven-year deal will run WPP operations in the cloud. This follows recent deals with Dutch bank ABN Amro and German airline Lufthansa, totaling over $3 billion. IBM's general manager, Bart Van den Daele, expects more technology outsourcing contracts from European clients ready to play catch-up after the euro crisis.

site_title: Takata rejects broader airbag recall
summary: Takata Corp. has rejected a nationwide US recall of its potentially deadly airbags, citing testing data that shows no necessity to expand the existing recall. The company's senior executive, Hiroshi Shimizu, defended the decision, stating that the problems persist mainly in passenger-side airbags in hot and humid climates. However, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) and some lawmakers express doubts about the company's arguments, warning that Takata and car makers could face court action and fines of up to $35 million if they do not address the issue.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 at records after upbeat Fed report
summary: US stocks reached record highs on Wednesday after a Federal Reserve report showed the US economy was growing, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 33.07 points (0.18%) to 17,912.62, and the S&P 500 gaining 7.78 (0.38%) to 2,074.33. The Fed's Beige Book reported that national economic activity continued to expand, and optimism about future growth increased. Banking and oil stocks gained, while Puma Biotechnology plummeted 12.2% after delaying a drug approval.

site_title: Iran hackers penetrate key world networks: researchers
summary: Iranian hackers, known as "Operation Cleaver," have infiltrated and stolen sensitive information from governments and companies worldwide since 2012. The hackers, believed to be based in Tehran with help from others in the Netherlands, Canada, and Britain, have targeted critical infrastructure sectors, including military, oil, and gas, energy, and telecommunications. Researchers have observed the group's technical capabilities rapidly evolve over the past 24 months, posing a significant global security threat.

site_title: Nomura to expand e-stock trading service
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc plans to expand its electronic stock trading service to cater to asset managers seeking to execute large transactions without disrupting the market. The service allows big trades of Japanese companies' shares outside the Tokyo Stock Exchange. Three Nomura officials will meet with hedge funds, pension funds, and asset managers in the US in January to pitch the service. This move follows Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund shifting assets to stocks to increase returns, and the Tokyo Stock Exchange's introduction of smaller price increments.

site_title: Year-end spike in big car COE premium
summary: Singapore's big car COE premium surged in the latest year-end bidding exercise, jumping to S$74,389, while the small car premium softened to S$67,089. Category E, the open category, rose S$3,004 to S$76,904, catching dealers off guard. The increases are attributed to the reduced COE supply due to the Early Turnover Scheme, with some speculating that dealers may be stocking up on transferable Cat E COEs.

site_title: 1MDB to woo investors for unit's US$3b IPO
summary: 1Malaysia Development Bhd plans to meet with potential investors in January for its US$3 billion IPO of 1MDB Energy, aiming to reduce its debt burden of over US$11 billion. The initial public offering had been delayed due to a lengthy due diligence process and debt refinancing negotiations. The sale is part of the state investor's efforts to reduce its debt and increase transparency.

site_title: Eurozone risks return to contraction
summary: The eurozone economy may face another contraction after business activity grew less than expected in November, despite heavy discounting, according to surveys. The Markit PMI index fell to 51.1, missing the growth threshold for the first time since mid-last year. Retail sales also picked up less than expected, and inflation dipped to 0.3%, deep into the European Central Bank's "danger zone" for price moves. The ECB is set to meet on Thursday, with a decision expected to be influenced by the eurozone's slow and fragile recovery.

site_title: Poland facing office space glut
summary: Poland's commercial property market faces a growing glut of office space, with prices continuing to decline and a vacancy rate increasing to almost 14% in Warsaw. Despite this, developers are adding new projects, further exacerbating the imbalance. The Polish central bank attributes the issue to a "boom in space growth" leading to a significant vacancy rate.

site_title: Tokyo real estate trading picks up
summary: Tokyo real estate trading has seen a significant surge in demand for office space, with major trades reaching their second-highest level since 2007. Foreign buyers and investors have been actively purchasing land and buildings, with some trades exceeding 100 billion yen. The recovery in trading is attributed to companies' earnings recovering, and the vacancy rate in central Tokyo has fallen to 5.65% for the first time in five years and seven months. However, experts have expressed concern that the recent recovery may lead to a real estate bubble, emphasizing the need for careful examination of the value of real estate.

site_title: Beijing's self-made islands and the law of the sea
summary: China is reclaiming land at Fiery Cross Reef in the South China Sea, transforming it into a large artificial island with an airstrip and harbour. This is the fourth such project in the Spratly Islands in the past year, with the goal of expanding China's territorial claims and exclusive economic zone. The US has urged China to stop the land reclamation program, while a Chinese military officer argued that the US is biased against China. China's moves could lead to the declaration of an air defence identification zone over the South China Sea, potentially overlapping with existing zones in Japan and South Korea.

site_title: Buyers bet on record corporate travel to snap up resort hotels
summary: Luxury resorts are experiencing a resurgence in demand as corporate travel spending rebounds, with investors seeking to capitalize on the economic recovery. Strategic Hotels & Resorts, DiamondRock Hospitality, and Hyatt Hotels have announced deals for high-end properties featuring amenities such as golf courses and conference facilities. The recovery of resort properties is attributed to higher group spending and a lack of new construction, with revenue per available room (RevPAR) reaching a record $340.90 this year. The trend is expected to continue, with corporate travel spending projected to increase 6.8% to $292.3 billion this year.

site_title: Greek PM denies planning tax hike to satisfy creditors
summary: Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaris has denied plans to hike taxes to satisfy creditors, rejecting calls from the EU and IMF to raise taxes to meet the country's bailout programme. Samaris criticized the "heavy pressure" exerted by the troika of creditors and insisted that Greece will meet its budget goals without new measures. The EU financing programme ends in December, and Greece is set to receive another 1.8 billion euros, with 12.6 billion euros remaining to be disbursed by the IMF by 2016.

site_title: Europe makes it easier to tap China stock link
summary: Europe's main funds regulator has introduced a "fast-track" procedure for approving mutual funds to participate in the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect scheme, a landmark equity trading link between China and Hong Kong. The move aims to address industry frustration over regulatory hurdles that have prevented many asset managers from participating. This change is expected to facilitate easier access to the Chinese market for European fund managers.

site_title: Lower jet fuel costs to bolster the bottom line of airlines
summary: Airlines can expect lower jet fuel costs to boost their bottom lines due to recent price drops. However, hedging strategies may mitigate some of the positive impact. Fuel surcharges, covering 30% of fuel costs, are not expected to decrease immediately, taking a month to 1.5 months to adjust.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US CEOs say having hard time finding workers with right skills
summary: US CEOs report significant problems in finding workers with the necessary skills, particularly in math and science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields. A survey of 126 companies found 46% of companies see a skills shortage as a problem, with 6% considering it very problematic. The shortage is attributed to a slowdown in US college enrollment since the 1980s, leading to rising income inequality. Two-fifths of job openings require advanced STEM knowledge, highlighting the need for improved education and training programs.

site_title: ICE to start Singapore operations with five contracts
summary: US energy markets operator IntercontinentalExchange (ICE) will launch five futures contracts, including one for Brent and gold, in Singapore starting in March. The contracts include mini ICE Brent crude, Chinese cotton, Chinese sugar, and renminbi, which will be cash settled, and 1kg gold futures, which will be physically settled in Singapore.

site_title: Occupy Central founders turn themselves in
summary: Hong Kong's Occupy Central movement leaders surrendered to police on December 3, 2014, after a day of calling for students to retreat from protest sites. The founders, who had deemed the protests illegal, filled out forms and were allowed to leave without facing charges. This marks a possible decline in the civil disobedience campaign, which had been ongoing since September. The surrender comes after student leader Joshua Wong called for supporters to regroup.

site_title: Brent rebounds to US$71 but downtrend seen continuing
summary: Brent oil rose to US$71 a barrel on Wednesday, rebounding from a near 40% fall since June. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) said it won't lower output, despite an oversupplied market. Analysts say a downtrend remains, with US crude potentially falling to US$50 per barrel if support levels are breached. Opec's oil supply fell by 340,000 barrels per day in November, but Saudi Arabia and other key members will only consider production cuts if other countries participate.

site_title: Second market stoppage in a month triggers SGX 'sorry' and MAS warning
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has delayed its market opening by 3.5 hours due to a software defect that resulted in erroneous reports being distributed for trades done on Monday and Tuesday. The incident, the second major disruption in a month, has prompted an apology from SGX CEO Magnus Bocker and a warning from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) that possible supervisory action may be taken. The delay has eroded confidence in the market, with industry players expressing concerns about the impact on retail investors and the exchange's reputation.

site_title: To get Lego's 'Frozen' set for X'mas in US, try Santa's homeland
summary: Lego will release its "Elsa's Sparkling Ice Castle" Frozen set in the US in January, after missing the holiday season. The set, featuring Elsa, Anna, and Olaf, will be available in Nordic and Baltic regions, as well as select northern European markets. The delay was attributed to Lego's focus on other holiday products, with the company generating half its revenue during this time. Despite the delay, demand for Frozen-themed products remains strong, with the film ranking as the top-grossing animated film of all time.

site_title: US regulator criticises Takata for shirking responsibility over air bags
summary: US vehicle safety regulators criticized Takata Corp for shirking responsibility over its potentially deadly air bags, which have been linked to at least five deaths. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) ordered Takata to expand a regional recall nationwide, but the company's response was deemed "disappointing." Takata's CEO, Shigehisa Takada, stated that the decision to recall would be up to carmakers, but did not admit to defective air bags. The NHTSA may fine Takata up to $7,000 per vehicle not recalled, and is reviewing the company's response.

site_title: Singapore is retailers' 3rd most popular Asia-Pac city
summary: Singapore is the third most popular city in the Asia-Pacific for international retailers, after Hong Kong and Shanghai, with over 50 new brands entering the market last year. Despite high rents, Hong Kong remains the top choice for expansion due to its affluent population and tourist base. Retailers are seeking to tap the growing consumer base in the Asia-Pacific region, which is expected to account for 54% of the world's population and 36% of the world's economy by 2020. Singapore's strong supply chains and strategic locations make it an attractive hub for expansion, but vacancy rates in prime locations are extremely low, creating hurdles for new entrants.

site_title: Singapore seen gaining from Asean Economic Community
summary: Singapore is expected to benefit from the establishment of the Asean Economic Community (AEC) due to its strong growth potential and strategic location. The AEC aims to create a free flow of goods, services, investment, and skilled labor, as well as a freer flow of capital. However, the report warns that the road to the AEC's fruition is fraught with challenges, including harmonizing regulations and standards, liberalizing flows of labor and capital, and addressing disparities in income and economic development between member states.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: A self-regulating banking sector is simply untenable
summary: A self-regulating banking sector is unworkable, according to the article, as bank brands have created consumer contempt. This shift occurred almost overnight, 25 years ago, with scandals and exceptionalism replacing trust. Bankers believe they can act with impunity, and this is partly due to the public's, regulators', and governments' failure to hold them accountable. The environment that allows this to happen is perpetuated by the general public as bank customers. The author argues that this is a result of the sector's perverse globalism and the lack of consequences for those involved.

images.alt_text: The latest infraction by HSBC in Brussels is only the latest example of the bad behaviour society continues to foot the bill for.

site_title: China's services sector growth up in November
summary: China's services sector experienced a slight increase in growth in November, with the official non-manufacturing PMI rising to 53.9 from 53.8 in October. A separate services PMI published by HSBC/Markit also showed growth, with new orders rising at their quickest pace in 2.5 years. However, the labour market continued to shrink for the fifth consecutive month, and business expectations softened. Despite the mixed data, economists predict further policy easing, with some expecting another interest rate cut to 5.25% in the first quarter to support growth.

site_title: Data loss and downtime cost Singapore firms over US$1b in 12-month span
summary: A survey by EMC Corporation found that data loss and downtime in Singapore cost firms over US$1 billion in a 12-month period. 66% of firms experienced data loss or downtime, with an average of 3 working days of unexpected downtime per year. Only 6% of respondents had a disaster recovery plan for big data, mobile, or hybrid cloud environments. The study also found global data loss to have increased by 400% since 2012, with the Asia-Pacific and Japan region experiencing an average loss of US$34 billion.

site_title: LionGold to sell remaining stake in Amayapampa Gold Project
summary: LionGold Corp is selling its remaining 10% stake in the Amayapampa Gold Project in Bolivia to Silvermane Investments for S$3.5 million. The project is a high-grade 1.8 million ounce open-pit gold resource. The directors consider the remaining stake non-strategic and will use the cash for working capital.

site_title: SGX must get out of its bizarre state of denial
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) CEO Magnus Bocker has apologized and accepted responsibility for the recent computer system breakdown, marking a shift from the exchange's previous denial of issues. The breakdown, which occurred twice in less than a month, has raised concerns over accountability and the exchange's reputation. The costs of the breakdowns include monetary losses and lost opportunities, with estimates ranging from millions to billions of dollars. To repair the damage, SGX must overcome its state of denial and acknowledge the need for fundamental changes to address the issues plaguing the local equities market.

site_title: Q3 productivity revised upwards, but Fed likely to keep rates low
summary: US non-farm productivity grew at a 2.3% annual rate in Q3, surpassing initial estimates of 2.0%. This upward revision, combined with downward revisions to compensation, suggests muted wage inflation and may keep interest rates low for a while. Productivity rose 1.0% compared to the same quarter in 2013, while unit labour costs fell at a 1.0% rate. This trend supports the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates low, easing concerns about wage growth and interest rate hikes.

site_title: AI could end humanity, warns Hawking
summary: British theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking has warned that the development of artificial intelligence could lead to its rapid evolution and ultimately, the end of humanity. Hawking stated that humans, limited by slow biological evolution, would be superseded by AI, which could re-design itself at an ever-increasing rate. He emphasized the need for caution and regulation to prevent this scenario, citing the dangers of the Internet and the need for balance between security and freedom.

site_title: Russian 10-yr bond yields rise above 11%, rouble volatility at record highs
summary: Russian 10-year bond yields surged above 11% for the first time since 2009, while rouble volatility reached record highs despite a brief currency boost. Emerging markets, including the Malaysian ringgit and Indonesian rupiah, were pressured by a stronger dollar. Analysts forecast 9.3% inflation for end-2014 and 11% for early 2015, driving bond yields up 350 basis points this year. Rouble volatility, a gauge of expected currency swings, hit new record highs, with Moody's warning that 36% of Russian companies carry negative ratings outlooks.

site_title: What Obama could pick up from Wilson
summary: US President Barack Obama may learn from former President Woodrow Wilson's mistakes in building a new world order and managing relationships with Republicans. Wilson's failure to pass the League of Nations and Versailles Treaty due to Republican opposition and his inflexibility led to the rejection of his vision for global peace. Similarly, Obama faces a challenge from Republicans opposing his healthcare law, the Affordable Care Act. Historians view both leaders as "dreamers" out of touch with reality, yet Wilson's legacy remains intact, and his ideas on globalisation and the UN have influenced subsequent US presidents. Obama can learn from Wilson's mistakes, including the importance of compromise and outreach to Republicans.

site_title: Osborne closes tax net on multinationals, banks
summary: UK Chancellor George Osborne closed the tax net on multinationals, introducing a 25% tax on UK profits. He also halved the bank tax loophole and reformed stamp duty on house purchases.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: SingPost's wholly owned subsidiary, Quantium Solutions, will acquire Couriers Please Holdings from New Zealand Post for A$95 million (~S$105 million) to expand its regional ecommerce delivery networks in Australia. This move aligns with SingPost's logistics growth objectives. Meanwhile, Nam Cheong Holdings' decline is attributed to Petronas cutting capital expenditure, but its fundamentals remain unchanged. Mermaid Maritime is expected to benefit from the oil-price slump due to stable demand from Middle East clients.

site_title: Lufthansa pilots union extends strike action
summary: Lufthansa pilots' union has extended strike action on long-haul and cargo flights, affecting thousands of travelers. The two-day stoppage, which began on Monday and Tuesday, will continue on Thursday. Short and medium-haul flights, as well as Germanwings flights, remain unaffected. The union stated that the strike is due to unresolved labor issues.

site_title: Swiss chocolatier chief upbeat about cocoa surplus
summary: Swiss chocolatier Barry Callebaut predicts a global cocoa surplus in 2014/15 and possibly the next year, contradicting some other forecasters. CEO Juergen Steinemann stated there will be more cocoa beans than needed, leading to a surplus. This differs from Olam International's forecast of a global cocoa deficit of over 120,000 tonnes in the same period. Steinemann sees growth opportunities in Latin America, particularly in Argentina, where consumer purchasing power is rising despite the country's structural crisis.

site_title: Broking houses upbeat on Singapore market, citing cheap valuations
summary: International broking houses UOB and OCBC are cautiously optimistic about the Singapore market, citing cheap valuations. They expect the Straits Times Index (STI) to rise 9% by the end of 2015, driven by sectors such as banks, telecommunications, and plantation. However, UBS and Goldman Sachs have taken a "underweight" stance on the market due to slow electronics exports and rising interest rates. UOB and OCBC favor blue-chip stocks and Reits, while UBS prefers telcos.

site_title: Sales of asset-backed debt in Europe set to jump 50% to 115b euros next year
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to boost sales of asset-backed debt in Europe by 50% to 115 billion euros next year, the largest increase since 2007. The ECB's purchases of asset-backed securities are part of its stimulus measures to revive the market and encourage banks to increase lending and boost economic growth. The sales of asset-backed securities are forecasted to be a fraction of their peak, with issuance totaling around 100 billion euros in 2015, according to Credit Suisse and Morgan Stanley.

site_title: India fast-tracking submarine upgrade to match China moves
summary: India is accelerating its submarine modernization program in response to China's growing naval presence in the Indian Ocean. Following a recent border stand-off, Chinese submarines have appeared in Sri Lanka and the Maldives, prompting India to seek support from its neighbors. India is speeding up its navy upgrades and leaning on regional nations to curb Chinese submarine activity, amid increasing regional unease over China's expanding undersea capabilities.

site_title: Shipping firms face tax, accounting challenges
summary: Shipping firms are forming alliances to reduce costs and increase efficiency in the container shipping industry. The G6 alliance, 2M alliance, and Ocean Three pact are among the recent agreements, which will pool ships and services on major trade routes. Despite a slow global recovery, freight rates remain depressed, and carriers are focusing on cost containment. Tax and accounting considerations, such as permanent establishment and income taxation, are also a concern. New accounting standards, including lease accounting, will impact the industry, requiring companies to renegotiate with lenders and reassess their strategies.

site_title: Next salary hike for Indonesia central bank's board in doubt
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, faces uncertainty over its next salary hike due to rising inflation. Inflation is projected to average 6.4% this year and 6.95% next year, exceeding the central bank's 3-5% target. The increase in fuel prices has put the governor's pay in doubt, as lawmakers consider inflation and macroeconomic assumptions when deciding on the board's salaries. A missed inflation target in 2013 led to no pay increase, and lawmakers may be less inclined to approve a salary hike if price gains stay elevated.

site_title: SingPost unit to buy Australia's Couriers Please for A$95m
summary: SingPost, a Singaporean parcel delivery firm, is acquiring Australia-based Couriers Please Holdings for A$95 million, strengthening its e-commerce logistics capabilities Down Under. Couriers Please has a network of 575 franchisees and handled nearly 11 million consignments in FY2014. The acquisition will be funded by SingPost's internal resources and is expected to raise SingPost's group net profit. The deal aims to tap into Australia's growing e-commerce market, with online purchases expected to reach A$36.8 billion by 2016.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Aussie consumers spent over A$10 billion on online purchases in 2012, and this might reach A$36.8 billion in 2016.

site_title: Blackstone seen making US$2b profit from IndCor deal
summary: Blackstone Group LP is set to make a profit of over US$2 billion by selling its majority stake in IndCor Properties Inc, a warehouse owner, to Singapore's GIC Pte Ltd for US$8.1 billion. This is Blackstone's largest-ever private sale of a property holding. IndCor, created by Blackstone in 2010, owns over 117 million square feet of warehouse buildings across the US, and the sale pre-empts a planned initial public offering.

site_title: A busy 2015 in deals seen for German property firms
summary: German property firms, including Patrizia Immobilien AG and Deutsche Office AG, may see a busy year for stock market deals in 2015 due to growing investor demand for real estate shares. Patrizia may sell shares in GBW Gruppe for the first time, while Deutsche Office and Alstria Office Reit AG could make good merger partners. The Deutsche Annington takeover bid and rising rents are driving consolidation and economies of scale in the market. German property companies sold a record 4.1 billion euros of shares in the first 10 months of 2014, with demand expected to weaken in 2015.

site_title: Sony Pictures struggles to recover after cyber attack
summary: The Sony Pictures Entertainment studio is struggling to recover from a massive cyber attack that occurred on November 24, with hackers using a rare data-wiping virus to steal confidential data, including personnel information and business documents. The attack, which affected computers with Microsoft Windows software, has forced employees to use paper and pen, and some systems have been restored, but the full scope of the breach is still unknown. Government investigators, led by the FBI, are considering multiple suspects, including North Korea, and have warned US businesses about hackers' use of malicious software.

site_title: US CEOs are gloomier on spending but more optimistic on hiring: survey
summary: US CEOs are more pessimistic about spending plans, with 36% expecting to decrease capital spending in the next six months, down from 39% in the third quarter. However, they are more optimistic about hiring prospects, with 40% expecting to add jobs. The Business Roundtable CEO Economic Outlook Index dropped to 85.1, below the long-term average of 80.3. CEOs call for temporary tax breaks, including R&D credits, to boost the economy and create more jobs. They forecast 2.4% US economic growth in 2015.

site_title: Saudi Star to invest US$100m in Ethiopia rice farm
summary: Saudi Star Agricultural Development, an Ethiopian company owned by billionaire Mohamed al-Amoudi, plans to invest US$100 million in a rice farm in western Ethiopia in 2015. The company will focus on building irrigation infrastructure, including a rice de-husking plant and land clearing, after delays caused by unsuitable design and contractor performance issues. The project aims to produce aromatic rice, with revenue forecasted to be US$60 million in 2016. The investment is part of a government plan to establish commercial farms in sparsely populated areas, with the goal of earning US$6.6 billion in agriculture exports annually.

site_title: Malaysia's hard-won fiscal progress falls victim to oil price rout
summary: Malaysia's fiscal progress is threatened by a sharp reduction in oil revenue due to a potential 37% decline in Petronas' contribution to the government's exchequer. This would undermine the government's target of reducing the budget deficit to 3% of GDP and could weaken the currency, which has already weakened by almost 3% against the dollar. The finance ministry is resisting the decline, but investors are concerned, and a weaker currency could lift prices of imported goods, providing relief to household debtors. The government's hard-won fiscal progress is at risk.

site_title: Japan's upcoming election is about more than just "Abenomics"
summary: Japan is set to hold a snap election on December 14, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government almost certain to remain in power. Despite a voter disapproval rate higher than support, the government's coalition is expected to win due to undecided voters favoring the governing coalition. The election outcome will significantly impact Japan's direction in the next four years, with debates centered on Abenomics, national security, foreign policy, personal freedoms, and constitutional issues. Voters must challenge Abe's stance on contentious issues, such as territorial disputes with China and South Korea, to prevent a one-party system.

site_title: Euro skids as investors bet on more ECB easing
summary: The euro plummeted to a 27-month low against the US dollar, falling to $1.2322, due to investors' expectations of further easing measures from the European Central Bank. The dollar reached a seven-year peak against the yen, boosted by upbeat comments from Federal Reserve officials. The eurozone's struggling economy and threat of deflation may lead to a rebound in the euro on Thursday if the ECB fails to deliver new measures, according to analysts.

site_title: Tokyo retains gourmet crown with most starred restaurants
summary: Tokyo retained its title as the Michelin guide's gourmet capital for the eighth consecutive year, with 267 restaurants gaining stars, including 12 three-star-rated establishments. Notable winners include Makimura, a traditional restaurant whose chef initially thought winning was a joke, and Usukifugu Yamadaya, which serves poisonous blowfish. The 2015 guide highlights Tokyo's diverse culinary scene, with eateries specializing in sumo stew and loach fish. The coveted three-star rating was down one from last year, with master chefs like Sukiyabashi Jiro Honten's chef in his late 80s continuing to impress.

site_title: UK retailers report first fall in food prices since 2006
summary: UK retailers report the first decline in food prices since 2006, with a 0.2% drop in November, according to the British Retail Consortium. This decline follows a 1.9% drop in shop prices for all goods. The drop is attributed to supermarkets cutting prices in response to competition from discounters Aldi and Lidl, and a decrease in oil prices. Bank of England governor Mark Carney expects overall consumer price inflation to fall below 1% in the coming months.

site_title: Europeans agree to build new-generation Ariane 6 rocket
summary: European nations have agreed to build a new-generation Ariane 6 rocket, replacing the Ariane 5, with a maiden flight scheduled for 2020. The 20-nation alliance has pledged 5.924 billion euros for operations, with four billion euros earmarked for the Ariane 6. The new rocket will incorporate existing designs from the Ariane 5 and ME, with two versions of the rocket expected to be developed. The agreement brings an end to months of behind-the-scenes negotiations between France and Germany over the successor to the Ariane 5.

site_title: Australia economic growth slows unexpectedly
summary: Australia's economic growth unexpectedly slowed to 0.3% in the third quarter, below expectations, due to sliding export prices and a rout in global commodity prices. This has raised concerns about the nation's economic outlook, with the annual growth rate at 2.7%, well short of forecast. The Australian dollar has fallen to four-year lows, and interest rates are expected to be cut by mid-2015, according to financial markets. The government's tax revenue is expected to be severely impacted, with Treasurer Joe Hockey warning of larger-than-expected budget deficits.

site_title: Graft schemes widespread in Brazil: former Petrobras exec
summary: A former Petrobras executive, Paulo Roberto Costa, claims widespread graft schemes in Brazilian public-infrastructure projects, including inflated contracts and bribes to politicians. Costa's testimony at a congressional hearing suggests the practice is not limited to Petrobras, but occurs in various state-run companies. Prosecutors estimate $5.1 billion was skimmed from overpriced contracts and distributed to politicians, including President Dilma Rousseff's Workers' Party. The case has sharpened Brazilian political divisions, with Rousseff denying involvement and dozens of construction executives arrested in relation to the scheme.

site_title: Patricia Barbizet to be Christie's first woman CEO
summary: Christie's International plc has named Patricia Barbizet as its first female CEO, succeeding Steven Murphy, who will step down at the end of the year. Barbizet, 59, is chairman of Christie's and CEO of Artemis SA, and will retain her chairman title. The announcement comes after Sotheby's head William Ruprecht also announced his resignation, citing a bitter proxy battle with activist investor Daniel Loeb. Christie's has seen record sales, including a $852.9 million postwar and contemporary art auction in November, and a 12% increase in sales from the same period in 2013.

site_title: UK district wins bid to limit basement sizes
summary: The Royal Borough of Kensington & Chelsea in London has won UK government backing to limit the size of basement extensions in response to complaints from residents. The new plan restricts basements to 50% of a property's backyard, down from 85%, and bans reconstruction under protected buildings. The move aims to address concerns about the lack of space and amenities in historic homes, with 450 basement planning applications in 2013 compared to 46 in 2001. The plan will be formally adopted on January 21.

site_title: Eat less meat, dairy to slow climate change: study
summary: A new survey by Chatham House found that meat and dairy consumption contribute as much to climate change as exhaust emissions from the transport sector, accounting for 14.5% of global total emissions. The survey of 12,000 people in 12 countries showed that consumers are unaware of the climate-changing impacts of their diet, with 40% of Russians and 25% of South Africans believing meat and dairy production causes "little or no" climate change. However, once aware, 20% of respondents were willing to change their diet, with women more likely to consider climate change when making food choices.

site_title: Fall in cocoa butter prices eases threat to chocolate consumption
summary: Cocoa butter prices have declined by 22% in two months, easing the threat to chocolate consumption. The decline has reduced the need for chocolate makers to raise prices, which had been announced due to soaring costs. AAK AB, a leading supplier of fats to the chocolate industry, has seen a 31% increase in operating profit from its chocolate and confectionery unit, but CEO Arne Frank remains cautious on the outlook for cocoa butter, which remains at historically high levels.

images.alt_text: At the moment, the cocoa butter spot price stands at US$6,681, down from more than US$8,500 earlier this year.

site_title: Britain cuts supplementary oil tax to help firms deal with low prices
summary: Britain's finance minister George Osborne announced a cut in the supplementary tax charge on oil companies to 30% from 32%, helping the industry cope with low oil prices and high production costs. The move aims to support the industry faced with weak oil prices and high production costs.

site_title: US financial sector risks on the rise
summary: The US financial sector is at risk due to excessive risk-taking fueled by low interest rates. A report by the US Treasury's Office of Financial Research found that investors are increasingly leveraging to achieve better returns, with money flowing into areas with less oversight. This has raised concerns about financial stability, as demonstrated by the unexplained bond market swing in October. The report warns that investors are not taking these risks seriously, leaving markets increasingly on edge.

site_title: KKR among 3 in final race for NOL's APL Logistics: report
summary: KKR & Co, CJ Korea Express, and XPO Logistics are among the three companies selected to make final bids for NOL's APL Logistics, with a reported price of about US$1 billion. NOL has short-listed these companies after conducting due diligence on its logistics business, which contributed 18% of its sales in the last quarter. The sale of APL Logistics may be part of NOL's plan to wind down the group and sell off its other assets, following a disappointing quarterly performance.

site_title: Britain targets multinationals who try to dodge taxes
summary: Britain plans to introduce a 25% tax on profits generated by multinationals that shift revenue to low-cost tax jurisdictions, targeting tech companies like Google and Amazon. Finance Minister George Osborne stated that big multinational businesses will pay their fair share, aiming to raise over $1.6 billion in revenue over the next five years. However, tax experts caution that enforcing global tax norms unilaterally will be challenging, and many multinationals may find ways to sidestep the new rules.

site_title: Fostering a culture of transparency
summary: A panel discussion on corporate governance highlighted the need for transparency and stakeholder involvement to prevent financial scandals. The ACCA-KPMG report found that corporate governance frameworks alone are insufficient to prevent crises, and that the "tone from the top" regarding transparency and good governance is critical. Experts emphasized the importance of actively engaging shareholders and directors to ensure compliance with governance standards. While rules and regulations can incentivize good behavior, they cannot guarantee prevention of all scandals. A balance between rules and flexibility is necessary to promote a culture of transparency and good governance.

images.alt_text: Debating that fine balance between corporate governance rules and flexibility at a panel discussion are (from left) ACCA's Asia-Pacific head for policy and panel moderator Chiew Chun Wee, MAS executive director of the market conduct department Paul Yuen, Stamford Law Corporation director Elizabeth Kong, NUS associate professor Lawrence Loh and KPMG head of risk consulting Irving Low.

site_title: US service sector growth at 3-month high: ISM
summary: The US services sector experienced a 3-month high growth rate in November, according to the Institute for Supply Management. The services index rose to 59.3, surpassing economists' forecasts of 57.5. While employment and imports fell, the business activity component, new orders index, and prices paid index all increased. The US economy is expected to have added 230,000 jobs in November, and a reading above 50 indicates expansion in economic activity.

site_title: India eases FDI rules for construction sector
summary: India has eased foreign direct investment (FDI) rules for the construction sector, allowing foreign investment in projects with a minimum built area of 20,000 square meters, down from 50,000 sq m. This move aims to attract more foreign investment in building new hotels, housing, and townships. The change is part of efforts to boost the country's construction sector and increase economic growth.

images.alt_text: Under the new rules, foreign investment is now allowed in projects with a minimum built area of 20,000 square metres.

site_title: Tennis stars raise S$122,000 for charity
summary: Tennis stars Andre Agassi, Ana Ivanovic, and Gael Monfils participated in a charity event at the Winchester Tennis Arena, raising S$122,000 for the building fund of the Rainbow Centre. Over 120 tennis fans, who had pledged at least S$100, hit rallies with the tennis players. The event, organized by the DBS Singapore Slammers, aimed to support a good cause while promoting tennis in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Keppel, Sembcorp take another hit
summary: Keppel Corporation and Sembcorp Marine, two Singaporean rigbuilding giants, have lost nearly S$2 billion in market capitalization each over a month as oil and gas stocks tumbled on the Singapore Exchange. The decline follows a rebound in Brent crude oil prices, with oil falling to just above US$70 a barrel. The companies' market values have dropped by 11.5% and 22% respectively, with Keppel Corporation hitting a new three-year low and Sembcorp Marine reaching a 22-month low. Analysts predict potential bargain hunts for some of these counters.

site_title: Oil whipsaw leaves gold investors in a tizzy
summary: Gold prices have experienced significant price swings due to the recent oil price fluctuations, with prices surging on Dec 1 before resuming declines. The dollar rally has also contributed to the volatility, curbing demand for alternative assets. US inflation expectations have fallen, further negatively impacting gold prices. Experts predict a bearish outlook for gold, with prices potentially dropping to around $1,085 in three months if they don't rise above $1,225-$1,240.

site_title: HK reversal hits STI in shortened session
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 11.7% on Wednesday due to a 3½-hour trading delay caused by a software glitch, resulting in a net loss of 18.93 points to 3,303.39. Turnover was S$875.4 million, lower than the S$1 billion average of the past couple of weeks. Banks, offshore oil, and energy sectors were hit hard, with OCBC, Keppel Corp, and Sembcorp Marine experiencing significant losses.

site_title: US calls on Europe, Japan to do more for global recovery
summary: US Treasury Undersecretary Nathan Sheets urged Europe and Japan to boost the global recovery, citing a fragile and uneven European economy and Japan's need to aid expansion. Sheets called on countries with large external surpluses, such as Germany and the Netherlands, to pursue demand-boosting policies. The US economy is one of the few bright spots in the global recovery, which has been cut by the International Monetary Fund for the sixth time since 2013. Sheets also emphasized the importance of Japan's sustained recovery and escape from deflation for the global economy.

site_title: Jailed owner tries to mortgage iconic hotels
summary: Sahara India Pariwar, an Indian financial-services group, sought court permission to mortgage two iconic hotels, New York's Plaza and London's Grosvenor House, to pay the 100-billion-rupee (S$2.12 billion) bail for its owner, Subrata Roy. The group aims to raise 30.7 billion rupees through the mortgage. This move is part of Sahara's efforts to settle its debt and avoid a potential bankruptcy.

site_title: Britain to review business rates system
summary: Britain's finance minister George Osborne announced a review of the country's business rates system, aiming to provide relief to traditional retailers battling online competitors. The review will examine the structure of business rates, currently calculated by rental property value. Osborne also increased a discount for retail premises in England with a rateable value of up to 50,000 pounds to 1,500 pounds from next year. The move aims to address concerns that the tax unfairly benefits online retailers.

site_title: US consumers to get more secure credit card
summary: US consumers will receive more secure credit cards with EMV technology, a chip embedded in cards that requires a PIN at checkout, starting next year. The upgrade aims to reduce card fraud, which has risen 30% annually in recent years. The technology, already widely used in Europe, will be introduced in stages, with 70% of credit cards and 40% of debit cards expected to use it by the end of 2015. The shift will cost billions of dollars and is seen as a significant improvement in security standards for the US.

site_title: Global economy to expand at solid pace in Q4: PMI
summary: The global economy is expected to expand at a solid pace in the final quarter, albeit less strongly than during the summer months, according to a survey by JPMorgan's Global All-Industry Output Index. The index fell to a seven-month low of 53.2 in November, indicating a gradual slowdown from the summer highs. Despite this, the survey suggests global GDP will still expand at a solid pace, with a global PMI covering the services industry also dipping to a seven-month low.

site_title: US: Chinese economy should wean from cheap labour model
summary: The US Treasury Under Secretary for International Affairs, Nathan Sheets, stated that China needs to move away from its cheap labor and export-focused economy to maintain growth. Europe and Japan also need to boost domestic demand to promote global rebalancing. Sheets noted that China's reliance on cheap labor and exports has been unsustainable, and its recent reforms aim to strengthen domestic household consumption and the services sector. The US emphasizes the need for countries with large external surpluses to pursue demand-boosting policies, such as infrastructure investment.

site_title: US mortgage applications fall in latest week: MBA
summary: US mortgage applications decreased 7.3% in the week ended Nov 28, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. Refinancing applications dropped 13.4%, while home purchase demand rose 2.5%. Fixed 30-year mortgage rates fell to 4.08%, the lowest level since May 2013. The survey covers over 75% of US retail residential mortgage applications.

site_title: Southern Europe gets unexpected lift from oil slide
summary: The plummeting oil price is providing an unexpected economic boost to Southern Europe, particularly Spain and Italy. Lower energy costs are increasing demand and contributing to growth. Spain's economy could add up to 1% to its annual growth with oil prices between $80 and $90 per barrel, while Italy's GDP could be boosted by 0.3 percentage points with a sustained $10 oil price drop. This unexpected lift is helping to alleviate the economic struggles faced by these crisis-battered countries.

site_title: Global gas price convergence shows shift to oversupply
summary: Global natural gas prices have narrowed to their narrowest since 2010, with prices in Asia, the Americas, and Europe converging due to faltering demand and rising supply. The convergence marks the end of a period of tightness in gas markets, with new LNG export projects set to start up next year. Mild winters and stockpiles further capped demand for LNG imports, leading to a global gas oversupply, similar to pre-Fukushima conditions. LNG prices are now trading within a $2/mmBtu range globally, down from peak spreads of $12/mmBtu.

site_title: Charities lose US$23.5m on foreign exchange
summary: Top global charities lost US$23.5 million on foreign exchange in 2014 due to difficulties in hedging international income or using obscure currencies of poor or war-torn nations. Greenpeace and Medecins Sans Frontieres suffered the most, losing 8.9 million euros and 7.9 million euros, respectively. Charities struggle to avoid costs associated with known currency risks, unlike companies that often hedge ahead of time. The issue highlights the challenges charities face in managing foreign exchange risks, despite the rise of cheaper non-bank currency providers.

site_title: Indian art has a long way to go even as China takes the big leap: Christie's official
summary: India is lagging behind China as a global art powerhouse due to its limited presence at international art fairs and lack of investment in new museums. Christie's International Director of Asian Art, Amin Jaffer, notes that China has taken a significant leap in promoting its artists and museums, creating a conducive environment for exhibitors. India's failure to attend major events like the Venice Biennale and its restrictive currency regulations and import duties hinder its art market growth. However, Jaffer remains optimistic about India's potential, citing the rise of art fairs, galleries, and global exhibitions featuring Indian artists.

site_title: Britain to scrap air travel taxes for children
summary: Britain's finance minister George Osborne announced plans to scrap air travel taxes for children under 12 and under-16s starting May 1, 2015, and 2016 respectively. The move aims to reduce the cost of family travel, with shares in airlines like easyJet and British Airways increasing in response. The change is seen as a boost to the airline industry, which claims the current tax has a negative impact on the economy.

site_title: Corruption worsening in Turkey, China: Transparency
summary: Corruption has worsened in China and Turkey, with China ranking 36 and Turkey 45 on Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index. The watchdog warned that the world's banking centers must help combat graft and money-laundering, citing examples of multinational banks facilitating illicit funds. The EU and US are urged to create public registers for companies, making it harder for corrupt officials to hide their wealth. The report highlights a link between corruption and economic growth, stating that no countries with long-term growth can have high levels of corruption.

site_title: Releasing India's telecom sector from its constraints
summary: India's telecom sector is expected to benefit from a resolution of the long-standing spectrum allocation issue, with the defence ministry set to give 15 MHz of spectrum in exchange for a similar amount in the 1,900 MHz band. This move could reduce pressure on the auction of the 900 MHz band and waive spectrum usage charges, saving the industry 470 billion rupees (S$9.9 billion) a year. The move comes as India's mobile phone market continues to grow, with the country adding 28 million new users in the first quarter of 2014, and overall mobile penetration reaching 90% in China.

site_title: Closely watched HDB resale price index up for revision
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) is revising its HDB Resale Price Index (RPI) methodology to better reflect the evolving HDB resale market in Singapore. The review aims to capture price changes over time, control for variations in attributes, and include newer towns such as Punggol, Sengkang, and Sembawang. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is also reviewing its private residential property price index (PPI) due to its complexity and the need for a more accurate representation of the market. The revised indices are expected to provide a clearer picture of price movements in the HDB and private residential markets.

site_title: UK banks to pay extra US$6.3b tax in next five years
summary: Britain's banks will pay an extra 4 billion pounds (US$6.3 billion) in taxes over the next five years due to changes announced by Finance Minister George Osborne. The changes limit the amount of profit that can be offset by losses carried forward to 50% and delay relief on bad debts. This move aims to encourage banks to "support the public in the recovery" after they received public support during the 2007-2009 financial crisis.

site_title: US Q3 productivity revised up, wages slashed
summary: US nonfarm productivity grew 2.3% in the third quarter, higher than the initial 2.0% estimate, but wages were revised downward, with hourly compensation increasing 1.3% instead of 2.3%. This muted wage inflation suggests the Federal Reserve may keep interest rates low for longer. Productivity remains relatively weak, with a 1.0% increase compared to the third quarter of 2013. The revisions ease concerns about wage growth, allowing the Fed to delay interest rate hikes.

site_title: Blackstone finds new asset exit - GIC's door
summary: Blackstone and GIC have struck a deal where GIC affiliates will purchase US industrial property rollup IndCor from Blackstone for $8.1 billion. This is the second major deal between the two, following a 2023 London office deal. The partnership suggests GIC's interest in buying from Blackstone, potentially benefiting both parties with divergent investment goals.

site_title: UK public spending to fall to lowest in 80 years: watchdog
summary: The UK's fiscal watchdog, the Office for Budget Responsibility, reported that public spending as a share of the economy is expected to fall to its lowest in 80 years due to the government's austerity plans. This is attributed to cyclical factors rather than long-run factors, and future growth is forecast to be lower than initially predicted. The government's policy assumption implies that the burden of consolidation will fall on day-to-day running costs of public services, particularly after the Autumn Statement.

site_title: UK to introduce cuts to stamp duty for nearly all homebuyers
summary: British finance minister George Osborne introduced sweeping cuts to stamp duty for nearly all property purchases, replacing the current system with a graduated rate similar to income tax. The tax will start at 2% on properties from £125,000 to £250,000, increasing to 12% above £1.5 million. This change benefits 98% of homebuyers, resulting in a £800 million annual tax cut. The reform aims to address long-standing grievances of homebuyers amid rising house prices, particularly in London.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as private-sector hiring slows
summary: US stocks opened mixed on Wednesday after a report showed private-sector hiring slowed in November, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 22.58 points (0.13%) to 17,856.97. The S&P 500 edged up 0.17 (0.01%) to 2,066.72, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 2.13 (0.04%) to 4,757.94. The private sector added 208,000 jobs, below the 225,000 projected by analysts, but above 200,000.

site_title: Intel, Luxottica team up for smart eyewear
summary: US tech giant Intel and Italy's Luxottica are partnering to develop connected eyewear, with the first products set to launch in 2015. The partnership aims to pioneer the development of smart, fashion-forward eyewear that combines Intel's leading-edge silicon and software technology with Luxottica's design innovation and consumer expertise. The collaboration is part of Intel's commitment to wearable technology, which CEO Brian Krzanich sees as creating a new playing field for innovation.

site_title: Global semiconductor outlook brightens, Microchip sees sales rebound
