summary: The global semiconductor industry is expected to experience modest growth in 2014, with a 9% increase in sales to $333 billion, driven by strong demand for smartphones and automotive electronics. Microchip Technology, which previously warned of an industry downturn, now expects a rebound in sales and predicts a return to quarterly sequential revenue growth. Industry associations World Semiconductor Trade Statistics and SEMI have revised their forecasts, with SEMI predicting 15.2% growth in chip equipment sales in 2015 and a flat 2016. The outlook suggests a brighter future for the industry, despite a dip in 2016 sales.

site_title: US private-sector hiring slows
summary: US private-sector hiring slowed in November, with 208,000 jobs added, below the October increase of 233,000. Despite the slowdown, the job growth remains above 200,000, indicating solid growth. Analysts expect the Labor Department's November report to show 230,000 jobs added, including 228,000 in the private sector, with the unemployment rate remaining at 5.8%. The steady job growth is expected to prompt acceleration in wage growth.

site_title: Indonesia to sign sales, refinery agreements with CNOOC, Saudi Aramco next week
summary: Indonesia is set to sign agreements with China's CNOOC, Saudi Aramco, and two other oil companies next week for direct oil sales and refinery investments. The deals aim to modernize the country's refineries, build new ones, and secure crude supplies, as part of President Joko Widodo's energy reforms. Indonesia needs up to $25 billion in investment to double its crude intake by 2025, with the goal of raising its refining capacity to 1.6 million barrels per day.

site_title: Palm rebounds to near 1-week high as soy, lower output estimates lift
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures rebounded to a near-weekly high, rising 1.4% to RM2,170 (US$631) per tonne, as gains in competing soyoil markets and lower output estimates lifted prices. The benchmark contract reversed intraday losses and pulled up from a low of RM2,102, with traders citing hopes for smaller December output and improved crude oil futures. Total traded volume was 57,888 lots, much higher than usual.

site_title: Air freight demand back at 2010 levels: IATA
summary: International air freight demand reached 2010 levels in October, growing 5.4% year-over-year, according to the International Air Transport Association. Europe, however, saw a 1.4% increase, hindered by economic uncertainty and sanctions due to the Russia-Ukraine crisis. IATA Director General Tony Tyler stated that the industry remains under pressure to improve its value offering despite the rebound in demand.

site_title: China bolsters support for farm sector with tax breaks
summary: China has renewed tax breaks for the farm sector, providing select financial companies and insurers with discounts on business taxes. The tax breaks, which were previously in place, will be reinstated until the end of 2016 and aim to boost lending to farmers and small-time borrowers. The move is part of China's efforts to support the real economy, which has been affected by a slowing housing market and domestic demand. The tax breaks are expected to help alleviate financial stress for banks, which have reduced lending to high-risk borrowers.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end lower
summary: Singapore shares ended 0.57% lower on Wednesday, closing at 3,303.39, after a trading volume of 1.19 billion shares valued at S$875.4 million. The Straits Times Index dropped 18.93 points.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Wednesday, closing at 1,758.15 after a 27.82-point drop. 1.56 billion lots valued at RM1.97 billion were traded, with 197 gains and 678 losses.

site_title: Oil producers pump more while urging Opec cut: Kuwait
summary: Kuwait's Oil Minister Ali al-Omair accused other Opec countries of increasing oil production despite urging the cartel to cut output to curb sliding prices. Kuwait maintains its production level to preserve its market share, while others have increased production to maintain their market share. Al-Omair said this is "unacceptable" to Kuwait and it will continue with its production level to meet its needs.

site_title: Taiwan names new premier in cabinet reshuffle following poll defeat
summary: Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou's ruling Kuomintang party lost key mayoral and local-level posts in local elections, leading to the resignation of Premier Jiang Yi-huah to take responsibility. Vice Premier Mao Chi-kuo was named as the new premier in a cabinet reshuffle. This shift in power comes less than two years ahead of the next presidential election, with Ma and his new premier facing a difficult task steering policy as he sees out his second and final four-year presidential term that ends in 2016.

site_title: UK's Osborne says to miss short-term budget targets, sticks to plan
summary: British finance minister George Osborne announced that the UK will miss its short-term target for cutting the budget deficit, with the deficit expected to fall to 5.0% of GDP in the 2014/15 financial year, surpassing the forecast of 4.9%. Osborne stuck to his plan to fix the public finances by the end of the decade, despite missing the target.

site_title: German private sector grows at slowest pace in 17 months in November: PMI
summary: Germany's private sector experienced its slowest growth in 17 months in November, according to the Markit PMI survey, with a composite index of 51.7. The services sector showed a 16-month low, while future business expectations rose. The German economy is expected to face marginal growth in the fourth quarter, with fears of a renewed downturn intensifying. Despite this, some improvement in business expectations suggests companies plan to boost investment in 2015. Germany's growth forecasts for this year and next have been cut to 1.2% and 1.3%, respectively.

site_title: India central bank says 'reasonably comfortable' with current account deficit
summary: India's central bank is "reasonably comfortable" with the current account deficit due to lower oil prices, according to Deputy Governor HR Khan. The bank has eased rules on gold imports, scrapping the 20% export mandate. This move comes ahead of the announcement of the current account deficit for the July-September quarter. Khan attributed the decision to the impact of lower oil prices on the country's finances.

site_title: Britain to pay back all WWI debts
summary: Britain is set to pay back its World War I debts of £1.9 billion (US$3 billion) through a refinancing deal involving the issuance of new bonds, capitalizing on low interest rates. The move also involves repaying debts dating back to the 18th century, including those from the South Sea Bubble. The government aims to settle the debts through this deal, which will help alleviate the country's historical financial burdens.

site_title: Asian markets boosted by US data
summary: Asian markets rose for a second consecutive day on December 3, 2014, driven by positive US economic data, including a 1.1% increase in construction spending and a 4.6% rise in car sales. The US dollar surged to a 7-year high against the yen, reaching 119.30 yen. Oil prices edged up after a deal was signed to boost Iraq's crude exports. The Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq all reached record highs, with the US economy seen as leading global growth momentum.

site_title: Hong Kong Occupy protest leaders turn themslves in to police
summary: Hong Kong's Occupy protest leaders, Benny Tai, Chan Kin-man, and Chu Yiu-ming, surrendered to police on December 3, 2014, amid violent clashes between protesters and authorities. The move comes after over two months of rallies demanding free leadership elections in the semi-autonomous city. The trio, who were not arrested, stated they would continue their pro-democracy movement through education and a new social charter, while Cardinal Joseph Zen, a prominent supporter, also surrendered. The Occupy movement will shift its approach, but student protesters remain on hunger strike, calling for dialogue with the government over political reform.

site_title: Eurozone economy looking set to contract in the new year: PMI
summary: The Eurozone economy is expected to contract in the new year, with a 0.1% GDP growth in the final quarter of 2014, according to a survey by Markit. The November Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 51.1, below the 50 level separating growth from contraction, indicating a further downturn in December. Heavy discounting failed to boost business activity, and firms have been cutting prices for three years to drum up business. The European Central Bank faces concerns over low inflation and is unlikely to alter its policy when it meets on Thursday.

site_title: Greece needs bailout extension as new credit line delayed: EU official
summary: Greece is unlikely to receive a new credit line by the end of the year, prompting the need for a bailout extension. The eurozone official stated that a final 1.8 billion euro payment must be made by December 15 for Greece's existing program to continue into January. Disagreement over Greece's funding needs for 2015 is the main sticking point, with lenders demanding additional measures to address a potential budget shortfall of over 2 billion euros. Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaras's government is under pressure to exit the bailout program by the end of the year.

site_title: Thailand's PM expects GDP growth of 2-3% next year
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister General Prayuth Chan-ocha expects the country's economic growth to reach 2-3% in 2015, lower than the 3.5-4.5% predicted by the state planning agency and 4.8% by the central bank. The economy is expected to grow around 1% this year, according to the planning agency. The lower growth projection is attributed to the global economic recovery.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares sink 0.95%
summary: Hong Kong shares dropped 0.95% on Wednesday, reversing gains from the previous day, amid investor skepticism over global market trends. The Hang Seng Index fell to 23,428.62 on turnover of HK$123.19 billion. In contrast, Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indexes rose 0.58% and 1.35%, respectively. The decline in Hong Kong shares was attributed to investors brushing off recent market rallies on Wall Street and the mainland.

site_title: Indonesia may disband or relocate state oil trader in corruption crackdown
summary: Indonesia may disband or relocate state oil trader Pertamina's Singapore trading unit to increase transparency, following President Joko Widodo's overhaul of the oil and gas sector. The move comes after Pertamina's Hong Kong-based unit, Petral, was implicated in corruption. An audit is planned, and relocation to Jakarta or disbandment are considered as options. The goal is to bring more transparency to operations that supply Indonesia with one-third of its daily oil needs.

site_title: Malaysia October exports seen falling 1.6% year-on-year as oil prices slide: Reuters poll
summary: Malaysia's exports in October are expected to fall 1.6% year-on-year due to declining oil prices, according to a Reuters poll. The median forecast predicts a trade surplus of RM8.9 billion (US$2.59 billion) for the month. This follows a 2% increase in September exports and a 1.1% rise in imports, resulting in a trade balance of RM9.3 billion.

site_title: UOB Kay Hian has end-2015 STI target of 3,600 points
summary: UOB Kay Hian predicts the Straits Times Index will reach 3,600 points by the end of 2015, a 8% gain from current levels. This target is based on a 10% discount to long-term valuations due to below-trend economic growth. The brokerage expects corporate earnings to rise 9.2% in 2015, driven by sectors such as banks, telecommunications, and plantation. Key "buy" calls include DBS and OCBC banks, SingTel, and CapitaLand, while SIA Engineering Company and IHH Healthcare Berhad are recommended for sale.

site_title: IntercontinentalExchange to launch 5 contracts at March opening of Singapore exchange
summary: IntercontinentalExchange (ICE) will launch five new contracts in Singapore in March, including one-kilo gold futures and four other commodities such as Brent crude, Chinese cotton, and sugar. The contracts will be physically settled for gold and cash settled for the other four. This expansion complements ICE's existing portfolio of benchmark contracts, including Brent crude, and will be part of its new exchange and clearing house in Singapore.

site_title: UK services sector expands faster than expected in November: PMI
summary: Britain's services sector expanded faster than expected in November, beating forecasts and suggesting the economy may be slowing less than thought. The Markit/CIPS services PMI rose to 58.6, exceeding the 50 level that represents growth for nearly two years. This increase is attributed to firm demand and increased new business, and may lead to a revised estimate of 0.6% economic growth for the final three months of 2014. The news is expected to be welcomed by finance minister George Osborne and may support the Bank of England's forecast of 3.5% economic growth this year.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 10.07 points to 3,332.39. Volume was 68.6 million shares worth S$116 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 72-59.

site_title: China rolls ahead with merger of train makers: report
summary: China is moving forward with the merger of its two top train makers, China CNR Corp. and CSR Corp., to create a massive group to export high-speed railway technology. The merger, which has been submitted to policymakers, aims to prevent "cut-throat" competition and put the combined entity in a stronger position to compete with foreign companies like Siemens and Bombardier. CSR will take the lead in the all-share deal, absorbing CNR's business, employees, assets, and debts. The new entity will be named "China Railway Rolling Stock Group."

site_title: Big car COE premium up, small car premium falls
summary: COE premiums for cars above 1,600cc and 130hp surged to S$74,389 in Wednesday's bidding exercise, while those for smaller cars below 1,600cc or 130hp dropped to S$67,089. Motorcycle premiums rose by S$21 to S$4,210, and goods vehicle premiums fell by S$5,000 to S$60,001. The open category, Cat E, also saw a significant increase to S$76,904.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.43% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.43% higher on Wednesday following strong US economic data and a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 101.75 points to 23,756.05.

site_title: Singapore's small, mid-cap companies association calls for independent probe into disruptions
summary: Singapore's Small and Middle Capitalisation Companies Association (SMCCA) has called for an independent probe into recent disruptions of the Singapore stock market, citing the need for a "totally independent" inquiry to establish the root of the operational failures. The disruptions, including a delayed market open due to a software glitch, have drawn criticism and warnings from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), which may take supervisory action against the Singapore Exchange (SGX) if necessary.

site_title: HDB to revise resale price index: Khaw Boon Wan
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) plans to revise its resale price index (RPI) due to significant changes in the HDB resale market. The current RPI methodology may not accurately reflect market movements, and the board will review and update the index to better capture price changes and control for variations in flat attributes and locations. The revision aims to provide more reliable information on resale market movements.

site_title: MAS warns of supervisory action against SGX, says market disruption 'unacceptable'
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) expressed disappointment and concern over the software bug that delayed Wednesday's stock market opening, calling it "unacceptable". The delay, which occurred just weeks after a power breakdown on November 5, was attributed to a software defect affecting post-trade processing. MAS warned that supervisory action against the Singapore Exchange (SGX) could be taken if necessary, following a thorough review of the shortcomings that led to the delay.

site_title: Asia: Markets climb after US data
summary: Asian markets rose for the second consecutive day following strong US data, including a 1.1% increase in construction spending and a 4.6% increase in car sales. The dollar surged to 119.41 yen, its highest since 2007, as the US economy appears to be on track. Oil prices edged up after Iraq signed a deal to export more crude to a saturated market. The Dow and S&P 500 also reached new records, with US online sales rising 16% year-over-year.

site_title: SGX CEO apologises for disruption, says rebuilding trust a priority
summary: SGX CEO Magnus Bocker apologized for the market disruption caused by the delay in market open, taking full responsibility and acknowledging the frustration caused by the power breakdown on Nov 5. The market operator is reviewing its processes to prevent recurrence and prioritizes rebuilding trust with members and customers.

site_title: Hong Kong protest founders prepare to surrender
summary: The original founders of Hong Kong's Occupy movement prepared to surrender to police on December 3, 2014, to show their commitment to the rule of law. However, student protesters who launched a hunger strike vowed to continue their struggle for justice. The protest leaders read an emotional letter to the city's leader Leung Chun-ying, expressing their determination to fight for democracy. The surrender marked a significant end to the 79-day occupation, which began in September 2014.

site_title: Oil rebounds 1 per cent after sharp losses; US data supports
summary: Oil prices rebounded 1% on Wednesday, with Brent crude rising above $71 a barrel, as a turbulent market struggled to find a price floor. The rebound came after US data showed a bigger-than-expected fall in crude inventories, supporting prices. OPEC maintained steady output in November, defending market share, and Saudi Arabia and other key members kept output stable. This move recouped some losses from the previous session, which saw Brent and US crude drop over 30% since June.

images.alt_text: Oil rebounded more than 1 per cent on Wednesday, with Brent rising above US$71 a barrel, recouping some of its losses from the previous session as a turbulent market struggled to find a price floor.

site_title: Indonesia to lead SE Asian online shopping boom
summary: Indonesia is poised to lead a significant online shopping boom in Southeast Asia, driven by rapid internet access and growing consumer spending. The region's e-commerce market is expected to increase five-fold by 2020, reaching $35 billion annually, with Indonesia being the most promising market. With 125 million people expected to be online by 2015, the country's middle class is driving the growth, with analysts citing the increasing affordability of smartphones as a key factor.

site_title: SingPost buys Couriers Please for A$95m to boost Aussie e-commerce business
summary: SingPost is acquiring Australian parcel service Couriers Please for A$95m (S$104.7m) to boost its e-commerce business in Australia. The acquisition, funded internally, will give SingPost a network of 575 franchisees and 11 million consignments handled in 2014. The deal is expected to raise earnings per share and reduce net tangible assets per share. The purchase is seen as an opportunity to tap into Australia's advanced e-commerce market and emerging regional markets.

site_title: Singapore firms lost over US$1b from data loss, downtime in last 12 months: study
summary: Singapore firms experienced significant financial losses due to data loss and downtime, totaling over US$1 billion in the last 12 months, according to a study by EMC Corporation. The Asia-Pacific region and Japan saw an average cost of US$34 billion, with global data loss rising 400% since 2012. Singapore ranks fourth on the EMC Global Data Protection Index, behind China, Hong Kong, and the Netherlands, highlighting the need for improved data protection measures.

images.alt_text: Singapore ranks fourth on the EMC Global Data Protection Index, which rates "protection readiness" for 24 countries.

site_title: Greek PM denies planning tax rises to satisfy creditors
summary: Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaras denied plans to raise taxes to satisfy creditors, rejecting calls from the EU and IMF. He criticized "heavy pressure" from the troika, saying Greece will meet its budget goals without new measures. The denial comes as Greece faces a crucial audit that determines the future of its bailout program, which expires at the end of December. The government may consider "extraordinary measures" if there is a fiscal shortage in 2015.

site_title: SGX delays Wednesday market opening to 12:30pm
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has delayed the opening of its stock market on Wednesday to 12:30pm to allow members to rectify errors from a software defect. The delay is to enable member firms to complete client position reconciliations and rectify end-of-day processing errors. The market will remain open until 5pm and close as normal. The software defect has been rectified, and the delay is a precautionary measure to ensure accuracy.

site_title: SGX: Weekend programming changes caused bug that delayed Wed's market open
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) experienced a software error caused by weekend programming changes, delaying the market open on Wednesday, December 3, 2014. Post-trade online systems were restored at 6am, and the market resumed normal operations. The pre-open routine began at noon, with the open at 12:30pm, and the market closed as scheduled at 5pm.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange (SGX) said programming changes over the weekend led to a software error that affected end-of-day processing on Dec 1.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 2.39 points to 1788.36. Gainers outnumbered losers 117 to 46, with a total volume of 44.68 million lots worth RM20.89 million.

site_title: Facebook Argentina fined over fake profiles
summary: Facebook Argentina was ordered to pay a firefighter $232,100 for failing to delete insulting fake profiles. The case, which began in 2013, involved a labor dispute and the plaintiff's repeated requests to Facebook to remove the offending profiles. The court initially ruled in favor of the firefighter a year ago, but the profiles remained active. The company was fined $1 million and ordered to pay a monthly penalty of $50,000. The decision was made by Judge Carlos Cadierno and notification was sent to Facebook's offices in Argentina and the US.

site_title: Another disruption at SGX
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) delayed its market opening on December 3 due to a software glitch that appeared on December 1. The glitch, which has yet to be resolved, prompted the exchange to postpone the opening. The incident has raised concerns about the exchange's operational reliability. Meanwhile, other news includes China urging Southeast Asian countries to support openness amid US tariffs, and Reliance Jio's India IPO being delayed beyond this year.

site_title: US: Dow hits record on construction spending, auto sales
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a fresh record close of 17,879.55, gaining 102.75 points (0.58%) on a rise in US construction spending and encouraging auto sales data. Construction spending rose 1.1% in September, exceeding analyst projections. General Motors and Chrysler exceeded forecasts for November US sales. US online sales on Cyber Monday rose 16% from 2013, offsetting disappointing Black Friday sales. The US economy appears to be leading global growth, according to market strategist Art Hogan.

site_title: Takata hires top US ex-officials amid recall pressure
summary: Takata Corp, a Japanese auto parts manufacturer, has hired three former US transportation secretaries to advise on manufacturing reforms and addressing airbag issues. The move comes amid pressure to implement a nationwide recall of its faulty airbags, blamed for several deaths and injuries. The company has also appointed an independent panel to audit its manufacturing procedures. Despite a demand for a national recall, Takata has not met the deadline, and the US auto safety regulator is considering further action, including a potential $35 million fine.

site_title: Former Petrobras director says graft scheme widespread in Brazil
summary: A former Petrobras executive, Paulo Roberto Costa, claims widespread graft schemes in Brazil's public-infrastructure projects, including roads, railways, and hydroelectric dams. Costa, who helped uncover a multibillion-dollar scheme, said similar practices occur beyond Petrobras. Prosecutors have already arrested dozens of construction and engineering firm executives and are probing other state-run companies. An estimated 10 billion reais (S$5.11 billion) was allegedly skimmed from inflated contracts and distributed to politicians. The case is further dividing Brazilian politics, with President Dilma Rousseff denying involvement despite her role on Petrobras' board of directors from 2003-2010.

site_title: US CEOs see dimmer economic growth in 2015
summary: US CEOs are less optimistic about the economy, with the Economic Outlook Index falling to 85.1 in the fourth quarter from 86.4 in the third quarter. Expectations for capital spending and sales have also decreased, with projections for 2.4% economic growth next year, lower than the Federal Reserve's and International Monetary Fund's forecasts. CEOs cited US tax policy and regulatory issues as major cost pressures, with 39% of respondents naming regulatory costs as their largest concern.

site_title: China official services PMI edges up to 53.9 in November
summary: China's services sector grew slightly faster in November, with the official non-manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 53.9 from October's 53.8. This marks a welcome respite to the country's slowdown, which is its worst in at least six years. The slight increase above the 50-point line separating growth from contraction indicates a continued expansion in the services sector, providing a positive note to China's economic outlook.

site_title: Australia's economy slows as private investment weakens
summary: Australia's economy slowed to 0.3% growth in the third quarter, below expectations, due to weak private investment. The annual rate of growth is 2.7%, down from 3.1% in the previous quarter. Exports expanded, but private capital spending declined, while consumption spending rose. The economy is transitioning towards non-resources driven growth, with the Reserve Bank keeping interest rates low amid expected mining investment decline. The decline in commodity prices and rising unemployment rate (over 6%) also contributed to the slowdown.

site_title: Major power outage hits Detroit
summary: A major power outage hit Detroit on Tuesday, cutting off electricity to all government buildings, including jails and police stations. The outage, which started 45 minutes ago, is currently being investigated by DTE Energy. The city, which declared bankruptcy in 2013, is in the process of exiting bankruptcy with a plan approved by a judge last month. Buildings in the downtown area are being evacuated as a precaution. The cause of the outage is not yet known.

images.alt_text: A major power outage hit the US city of Detroit on Tuesday, cutting off electricity to all government buildings, including the city's jails and police stations.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.62% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.62% higher on Wednesday, driven by a dollar's rise to a fresh seven-year high against the yen and a new record close on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 108.93 points to 17,772.15, boosted by encouraging US data and a weak yen, which makes Japanese exporters more competitive abroad. The dollar reached 119.18 yen, its highest level since August 2007, while the euro strengthened against the yen.

site_title: Ebola-hit nations' GDP to fall: World Bank
summary: The World Bank predicts a significant economic decline in West Africa, particularly in Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Guinea, due to the ongoing Ebola outbreak. The bank forecasts a shrinking gross domestic product in 2014 for two of the three countries, with Liberia being the only one expected to expand next year. Investors are fleeing, construction projects are halted, and agricultural production is declining, exacerbating the economic devastation.

site_title: US financial sector risks on the rise: Treasury
summary: The US Treasury's Office of Financial Research has warned of rising risks in the financial sector, citing excessive risk-taking and low interest rates. A report to Congress stated that investors are taking on too much leverage, increasing the dangers to financial stability. The report also expressed concerns about the potential for asset fire sales and runs in short-term funding markets, particularly as the Federal Reserve tightens monetary policy. Despite a reduced risk of contagion, the Treasury warned that markets are increasingly on edge and that complacency is unwarranted.

images.alt_text: Low interest rates are feeding a surge in excessive risk-taking in more murky corners of the finance industry and leaving markets increasingly on edge

site_title: Australia's Ten Network confirms numerous takeover approaches
summary: Australian television broadcaster Ten Network Holdings Ltd has received non-binding, conditional proposals from multiple parties, including Discovery Communications and Foxtel, to acquire the company. The proposals value Ten at A$510 million-A$664 million, following a decline in ratings and advertising revenue. A board committee will consider the proposals with Citigroup, which was hired to advise on the company's future ownership. A sale of Ten would be a significant sign of pressure on Australia's free-to-air broadcasters, which are facing declining audiences and revenue.

site_title: Lack of rainfall could drive Brazil into recession in 2015
summary: Brazil faces the risk of recession in 2015 due to a severe drought that may lead to energy rationing, according to BNP Paribas and energy consultant Thymos Energia. A drought of 7.6 cm in the south-east and mid-west regions, where hydroelectric dams are located, could shave two percentage points from gross domestic product, pushing Brazil into recession. Economists forecast 0.77% growth, which would be enough to trigger a recession.

site_title: Warm food with a warm heart
summary: Alfred Chua, managing director of The Wok People Pte Ltd, has been awarded EY Entrepreneur of the Year for Food and Beverage. The company, a Singapore-based institutional caterer, has grown from a small operation in 2010 to 450 employees and 50 outlets islandwide. Chua emphasizes the importance of serving nutritious meals with personalized customer service, and attributes his success to the firm's "people-first" mindset and resilience in the face of challenges. He believes that innovation, courage, and agility are key qualities for entrepreneurs to thrive in the business climate.

site_title: Turner's Rome piece up for auction
summary: A 1835 oil painting by JMW Turner, Rome, from Mount Aventine, is up for auction in London, estimated to sell for £15 million to £20 million. The painting, considered one of Britain's greatest masterpieces, is in exceptional condition, with every brushstroke and fingerprint of the artist still visible. The sale comes after a biopic about Turner's life was released, sparking renewed interest in the artist. Turner's work challenged 19th-century conventions, foreshadowing Impressionists, and its sister painting, Modern Rome - Campo Vaccino, sold for £29.7 million in 2010.

site_title: Packing it green & keeping it lean
summary: Susan Chong, CEO of Greenpac, has been named EY Entrepreneur of the Year for Sustainable Packaging Solutions. Greenpac is a knowledge-based company specializing in environmentally friendly packaging products and solutions. Chong developed a special cold-chain packing solution in collaboration with a US partner, enabling vaccines and medical samples to be airlifted to the US within 7-8 days. This innovation aims to reduce the carbon footprint of medical shipments, marking a significant step forward in sustainable packaging.

site_title: Most automakers see higher US sales in November
summary: US auto giants General Motors and Chrysler reported higher November sales, driven by lower gasoline prices and holiday promotions. GM sold 225,818 cars, up 6% from last year, while Chrysler sold 184,142 vehicles, a 4.4% increase. The industry as a whole sold 1.3 million vehicles, a 4.6% rise from the previous year. Ford Motor reported another decline in sales.

site_title: Building Colombia with trade initiatives and peace
summary: Colombia is at a crossroads, with the country's economy thriving due to trade initiatives and the presence of multinational companies, yet a decades-long civil war with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc) remains unresolved. The country's mayor's office promotes emerging industrial parks and new technology firms, while guerrillas continue to kidnap citizens and wreak havoc. Despite the progress in some areas, the country's dual nature – with citizens facing violence and economic opportunities – highlights the need for a lasting peace agreement. Negotiations with Farc have stalled, leaving the country's future uncertain.

site_title: Russia predicts recession in 2015 on sanctions, oil slump
summary: Russia's economy ministry predicted a 0.8% contraction in 2015 due to Western sanctions and falling oil prices, slashing its previous forecast of 1.2% growth. The sanctions, combined with weakening consumer spending, led to the revision. Oil prices also contributed to the decline, with a weakening ruble and rising inflation. The ministry cited a "more conservative" assumption that sanctions would remain through 2015 as the reason for the revised forecast. The move is attributed to worsening economic indicators.

site_title: Australian landlords take record debt as rental yields fall
summary: Australian landlords have taken record debt as rental yields fall, with home loans to investors accounting for over half of all mortgages. The Reserve Bank of Australia warns of speculative excess, as investors seek income yields in a low-interest-rate environment. Home prices rose 8.5% in the year through November, but rental yields dropped to 3.7% for houses and 4.5% for apartments. This has boosted total returns on residential property investments to 13.3%, prompting landlords to boost borrowing and take on more debt.

site_title: Irish artist Campbell wins coveted Turner Prize
summary: Irish-born artist Duncan Campbell has won Britain's prestigious Turner Prize for his "essay film" that draws on sources including African art, the Irish Republican Army, dance, and Marxism. The award was presented by actor Chiwetel Ejiofor at Tate Britain on Monday. Campbell's film explores a range of themes, showcasing his unique approach to contemporary art.

site_title: Noble Group top stock among buys at S$177.4m
summary: Global mutual funds were net buyers of Singapore stocks in the three months to Nov 26, with a total of S$2 billion invested. The top stock among buys was Noble Group, with a volume of S$177.4 million, while Genting Singapore was the top stock among sells, with S$87.8 million shares traded. This highlights the focus of fund managers on consumer services stocks, with Noble Group being the top pick. The data provides insight into the investment strategies of mutual funds and can help identify market trends.

site_title: Singapore safe from deflation danger, for now
summary: Singapore's inflation rate may see its first negative reading in five years with November's consumer price index (CPI), but economists do not expect damaging deflation. Recent disinflationary factors include a softening property market, lower home rentals, and healthcare subsidies. While some experts, such as Manu Bhaskaran, suggest the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) should loosen monetary policy, most economists believe the central bank will maintain its current policy stance due to tight labour market conditions and core inflation remaining stable at 1.5-2%. The government projects core inflation of 2-3% in 2015.

site_title: Dreamliner battery fire caused by 'inadequate design'
summary: A battery fire on a Boeing 787 Dreamliner in 2013 was caused by inadequate design and testing, investigators concluded. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) found that Boeing and the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) failed to anticipate how the power packs might fail, and that battery maker GS Yuasa Corp was responsible for poor manufacturing. The NTSB issued 16 new recommendations to improve safety, and Boeing redesigned the battery to include more protection and ventilation. The incident highlighted the dangers of lithium-ion power packs and led to a re-examination of their use in aircraft design.

site_title: US peer-to-peer lending firm seeks to raise US$692m in IPO
summary: Lending Club, a US peer-to-peer lending firm, is set to raise up to $692.4 million in its initial public offering (IPO) with a stock price of $10 to $12 per share. The company aims to convince Wall Street investors that the prospects of the peer-to-peer lending industry are bright, potentially valuing it at $4 billion. Lending Club's business model matches borrowers with investors using advanced algorithms, and it has already attracted big-name investors such as Google and Silicon Valley venture capitalists.

site_title: Ashton Carter likely next Pentagon chief: reports
summary: Ashton Carter, the former US Deputy Secretary of Defense, is likely to be nominated by President Barack Obama as the next Pentagon chief, replacing outgoing Secretary Chuck Hagel. This decision is based on reports from unnamed administration officials and The Washington Post. Carter's nomination is seen as a move to stabilize the Pentagon following Hagel's resignation.

site_title: SGX's Nov glitch stemmed from data centre at Keppel Digihub: sources
summary: SGX's November trading glitch, which paralyzed the local bourse for over three hours, was caused by a power outage at the exchange's data centre in Keppel Digihub, according to sources. The incident is being investigated by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, and a board of inquiry has been set up to review the findings. The incident has raised concerns about the link between the glitch and Keppel DC Reit's listing, which is expected to raise up to S$513 million on December 5.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Moody's downgrade tripping up Abe
summary: Moody's downgraded Japan's credit rating from Aa3 to A1 due to concerns over the country's ability to regain fiscal health, coming at a bad time for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe ahead of a snap election. Abe promised to present a fiscal consolidation plan by next summer and aim for a primary budget balance by 2020, but other aspects of his Abenomics policies are already under fire. Tax revenue is expected to reach a 17-year high, but Moody's downgrade casts doubt on Abe's ability to repair Japan's fragile public finances.

site_title: Russia cancels new gas pipeline to Europe, will build one to Turkey
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has cancelled plans for a $19 billion natural gas pipeline to Europe, instead opting for a smaller pipeline to Turkey. The decision comes after the European Union intensified opposition to the project due to the conflict in Ukraine. The move caps seven years of planning and billions of dollars of Russian investment, which would have bypassed Ukraine. Putin cited the drop in oil prices and EU opposition as reasons for the cancellation, stating that Russia will refocus its energy resources on other parts of the world.

site_title: O&M stocks recover as oil rebounds
summary: Singapore's offshore and marine (O&M) stocks rebounded on Tuesday after falling oil prices led to a four-day losing streak. The FTSE ST Oil and Gas Index rose 0.5%, with stocks like Nam Cheong, Ezion Holdings, and Sembcorp Marine gaining up to 7.46% as analysts recommended investors look for bargains. Analysts warn of a potential 10-15% drop in oil prices but note that some O&M stocks remain profitable at current levels.

site_title: Perception of global imbalances as a problem way off base
summary: Global economic institutions have long focused on reducing imbalances between major economic powers, such as China's surplus and the US deficit. However, the article argues that this obsession is misplaced, as imbalances are not the primary cause of economic problems. Instead, domestic factors like asset inflation, debt, social welfare, and inequalities are more significant contributors to economic instability. The article suggests that global institutions should shift their focus to managing these domestic imbalances, rather than trying to eliminate external imbalances. This approach could help avoid potential negative consequences, such as trade diversion and lower productivity, and promote more effective global economic governance.

images.alt_text: The United States is running a deficit because, among other things, the households continue to spend more than their incomes warrant

site_title: OW Bunker creditors in Denmark may not have dibs on S'pore units' receivables
summary: Denmark's OW Bunker creditors may not automatically claim receivables from Singapore subsidiaries. KPMG, provisional liquidators, stated that Danish trustees and receivers do not have secured rights over all receivables of OW Bunker Far East (Singapore) and Dynamic Oil Trading (Singapore). This means creditors in Denmark may need to negotiate with Singapore-based units to recover debts. The decision could impact the distribution of assets and payouts to creditors in the case of the failed Singapore subsidiaries.

site_title: Goldman downgrades Singapore to "underweight"
summary: Goldman Sachs has downgraded Singapore's market to "underweight" due to muted or lower earnings from key sectors such as banks, energy, and property. The downgrade contrasts with an upgrade to "market weight" for Hong Kong and "overweight" for Indonesia. Goldman expects Singapore's banks to benefit from interest rate hikes, but only in 2016. Indonesia's consistently high corporate earnings and potential fiscal reform have led to an upgrade.

site_title: EU's Keynesian adventure may spark fresh recession
summary: The European Union is embarking on a Keynesian adventure to stimulate stagnant economies by borrowing to finance infrastructure projects. This approach, inspired by John Maynard Keynes' 1936 theory, aims to create jobs and boost growth through the multiplier effect. However, critics warn that bureaucratic meddling may hinder the plan, and its effectiveness remains uncertain. With 24.5 million unemployed in the EU, policymakers are seeking a fresh solution to revive economic growth.

site_title: Having that special fire in your belly
summary: EY Entrepreneur of the Year award winner Ong Tze Boon, 45, group executive chairman of environmental design solutions firm Ong & Ong, has been recognized for his entrepreneurial achievements. Under his leadership, the firm has grown from 62 employees to 1,000 and now operates in 12 cities globally. Ong attributes his success to having a "special fire in the belly" to make a difference, and emphasizes the importance of creativity, innovation, and collaboration in business. He believes that making a difference in society is more valuable than financial success.

images.alt_text: "To just make money should not be the sole objective of a real entrepreneur. If you are really able to make a difference to society through what you do, you will get satisfaction that is far more valuable than money. If you can make a difference, you will be successful and money will be there in any case."- Mr Ong Tze Boon (above), group executive chairman of Ong & Ong
SIA's Silver Kris Lounge in Sydney. Besides Singapore Airlines, Ong & Ong has done various projects for Singapore Exchange, the HDB, OCBC Bank and Salad Stop among others employing experience design.

site_title: Spanish tycoon pays S$4,100-plus psf for pair of Seven Palms Sentosa Cove units
summary: Spanish tycoon Ricardo Portabella Peralta has purchased two units at Seven Palms Sentosa Cove for S$4,100-plus per square foot, a record price in the waterfront housing district. The overall sale price is S$28.55 million. The units, valued at 3,400-plus sq ft each, are part of a four-storey condo project with 41 luxury beach-house apartments. The sale is seen as a highlight in a quiet year for Sentosa Cove properties, with transactions thinning drastically due to market conditions.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: US consumers spread out shopping beyond Cyber Monday
summary: US consumers are spreading out their holiday shopping, with online sales growth on Cyber Monday slowing to 8.1% compared to 17.5% last year, according to IBM. This shift towards online shopping is driven by convenience, with consumers opting to shop over multiple days rather than being lured by one-day sales.

site_title: SPH's digital push gains traction
summary: SPH's chairman Lee Boon Yang stated that the company's digital media efforts are bearing fruit, with a 1.7% increase in total newspaper circulation for print and digital editions to 1.07 million copies per day in FY2014. This growth is attributed to new online and mobile offerings to tackle the challenges faced by traditional media.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Coffee output in Vietnam seen falling after rain shortfall
summary: Vietnam's coffee production is expected to decline by 3.5% to 1.65 million tonnes in the upcoming year due to a lack of moisture and reduced yields from fatigued trees after a record harvest. This decrease comes as global demand is forecasted to exceed supply, with futures surging 23% in London. The drought in Brazil, the largest grower of arabica beans, also negatively impacted the crop.

site_title: Russia reeling from triple whammy
summary: Russia's economy is expected to enter recession in 2015, with a forecasted 0.8% decline in GDP, following a triple whammy of oil price collapse, sanctions, and a run on the rouble. The rouble has depreciated 36% against the US dollar in less than six months, and the country's external debt has reached $614 billion. The Russian central bank has raised interest rates to 9.5% to stabilize the currency, but this is weighing on the economy. The economy ministry predicts a decline in capital investment and consumption, with real disposable incomes expected to contract by 2.8% next year.

site_title: ICS puts on its gloves for the Lima climate change pow-wow
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) is attending the UNFCCC COP 20 in Lima, emphasizing the shipping industry's modest contribution to global CO2 emissions. ICS argues that any shipping-related funding to the Green Climate Fund should be decided by IMO member states, not the UNFCCC. The industry claims to have reduced its emissions by over 10% since 2007 and is on track to cut emissions by 20% by 2020. ICS also highlights the importance of maintaining IMO as the primary forum for addressing maritime emissions, which cannot be attributed to individual national economies.

site_title: Oil prices 'bound to rise to help oil producers manage reserves'
summary: Oil prices are expected to rise to help oil-producing countries manage their reserves due to unsustainable current prices. According to John Westwood, group chairman of Douglas-Westwood, key countries like Saudi Arabia and Russia need oil to be priced at US$99 and US$100 per barrel, respectively, to balance their budgets. A cyclical industry, with seven significant price cycles since 1970, will lead to another price increase, potentially in 2016. Falling oil prices may affect financing availability for small exploration and production companies, particularly in the US.

images.alt_text: Current oil prices are unsustainable for many key oil-producing countries for the long term and therefore they are bound to rise to help these economies manage their reserves.

site_title: US shale pioneer sees slowdown in drilling amid oil slide
summary: US shale pioneer Harold Hamm, CEO of Continental Resources Inc, expects a slowdown in US drilling amid falling oil prices. Despite concerns, Hamm believes declining activity won't harm the industry as much as thought, as US producers can outlast countries in OPEC that depend on higher oil prices. Hamm's personal fortune has fallen by more than half in the past three months.

site_title: Citi sees a doubling in its Asian digital users in 5 years
summary: Citi expects to double its Asian digital banking users from 7.5 million to 15 million by 2019, driven by rising affluence and a growing middle class. This growth will help the US lender boost client accounts and revenue without incurring branch setup costs. Jonathan Larsen, Asia-Pacific head of consumer banking, cited these factors in a Hong Kong interview. The growth is expected to occur over the next five years, marking a significant expansion for Citigroup in the region.

site_title: When some family businesses thrive and others don't
summary: Family businesses that survive beyond the second generation often possess robust governance, defined expectations, and transparent communication. Research indicates that many family businesses fail to survive beyond the second generation due to succession issues. Effective succession planning, considering both family and non-family succession options, is crucial for long-term viability. A family's unity, values, and vision are essential components of a successful governance model, which also includes forward planning, conflict management, and clear communication.

site_title: Oil-related selling eases - for now
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 16.68 points to 3322.32 on Tuesday, following Hong Kong's recovery from Monday's 45-point drop. The index was led by OCBC, ThaiBev, and SingTel. The offshore oil and gas sector showed a slight uptick, with marginal gains for Sembcorp Marine and Ezion. Analysts, including OSK-DMG and OCBC Investment Research, suggest that the market is experiencing a "fear-driven" sell-off, creating opportunities for investors to pick up quality stocks.

site_title: S'pore's November PMI bullish, but not convincing
summary: Singapore's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to 51.8 in November, beating expectations, but the electronics sector's PMI dropped to 50.6, a six-month low. Economists believe Singapore's manufacturing sector is still vulnerable to regional softness, with the country expected to catch up with weaker Asian economies. The electronics sector's decline suggests stagnant global demand, with new export orders contracting for the first time in over 22 months. Despite the overall PMI's expansion, economists warn that the growth signal is "hollow consolation" due to subdued global demand.

site_title: Aviva agrees to takeover terms for Friends Life
summary: British insurer Aviva has agreed to a £5.6 billion takeover of rival Friends Life, creating a market leader with 16 million life insurance customers. The deal, expected to generate £600 million in excess cash flow annually, includes job losses. Aviva shareholders will receive 0.74 new shares, valuing the company at £5.6 billion, while Friends Life shareholders will receive a second interim dividend and a final dividend of 12.25p per share. Analysts note the deal's potential cost savings, but Eamonn Flanagan at Shore Capital questions Aviva's strategic positioning and suggests it may be a "rights issue in disguise".

site_title: Innovation dictates future of companies and countries
summary: Innovation is accelerating globally, driven by exponential increases in computer power, machine learning, and data analysis, according to experts. This has led to a shift in competitive advantages, with emerging markets losing their cheap labor advantage and developed economies adopting automation and robotics. As a result, companies must invest in innovation to weather the disruptive effects and harvest its benefits. The focus is on investing in companies that can tap into data riches, with a key determinant of success being the quality of education. Innovation is also seen as a driver of productivity, but slowing growth rates and aging populations may pose challenges to sustainable long-term growth.

site_title: Corporate bribery extracting a huge cost globally, says OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has released a report revealing that corporate bribery costs the global economy millions of dollars. The report analyzed over 400 cases of foreign bribery, finding that most cases occur in extractive, construction, transport, and storage sectors, with bribes averaging 10.9% of total transaction value and 34.5% of profits. Bribes are often paid to win contracts from state-owned or controlled companies, and most bribe payers and takers are from wealthy countries. The OECD urges governments to strengthen sanctions and protect whistleblowers to tackle bribery and corruption.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Tesla plans to expand its robotaxi service to California and Arizona. FedEx partnered with Singapore's QuikBot to deploy robot deliveries in commercial areas. Popiah king Sam Goi made a mandatory offer for the rest of PSC at S$0.40 per share. Despite US President Trump's new threats, Asian traders are extending their stocks rally. Japan's elevator empire saw a 6,000% stock gain amid a succession crisis. The article also highlights rising CEO salaries in Singapore's top companies.

site_title: RBA keeps interest rate at record low
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) held interest rates at a record low 2.5% for the 15th consecutive meeting, signaling a continued accommodative monetary policy to support growth. A weaker Australian dollar is needed to achieve balanced growth, with the RBA citing a significant decline in commodity prices and a supply glut. Markets expect potential rate cuts next year, with Deutsche Bank pricing in 50 basis points of cuts. The RBA retains its view of moderate growth in the Australian economy, despite economic headwinds.

site_title: Grand ovation for Agassi; Williams returns
summary: Andre Agassi received a grand ovation at the Coca-Cola International Premier Tennis League (IPTL) in Singapore, marking his 44th birthday. Agassi, an eight-time grand slam champion, played for the DBS Singapore Slammers but lost to Australian Mark Philippoussis. Meanwhile, world's top-ranked female player Serena Williams returned to Kallang, winning the women's singles match against Kristen Flipkens. The IPTL, a four-city tour, continues until Dec 13, with teams competing for a US$1 million prize and a challenge trophy.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: HK protest founders to 'surrender', urge students to retreat
summary: The original founders of Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement, Benny Tai, Chan Kin-man, and Chu Yiu-ming, announced they would "surrender" by turning themselves in to police, urging protesters to retreat. The announcement came after clashes with police, leaving dozens injured. The trio cited a commitment to the rule of law and "the principle of peace and love." However, protesters rejected the call to retreat, saying they would not consider an end to the campaign until their demands for civil nomination and true democracy were met.

site_title: Don't let budget wishlists derail restructuring
summary: The Singapore government must balance its generosity with economic restructuring needs. Despite public wishlists for tax incentives and grants, the government should resist the temptation to deviate from the restructuring path. The economy is not yet at a stage requiring anti-cyclical intervention, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore noting high home prices and potential stress points in debt levels. The government must carefully distinguish between those who truly need help and those who do not, while also mitigating potential job losses in the construction industry.

site_title: Citi: GE may be held next year due to good economic window
summary: Singapore's ruling party, the People's Action Party (PAP), may hold the next General Election earlier than required in 2015, capitalizing on the perceived feel-good factor accompanying the 50th anniversary of independence. Recent easing of inflation rates, but not public perception, could play to the PAP's advantage. The party's share of the popular vote has been negatively correlated with growth and inflation. The PAP may use the economic window to focus on growth risks and set aside perception issues, but it's unclear if they will call for elections next year.

site_title: Oil rout leaves investors with outdated portfolios
summary: BlackRock's Sam Vecht warns that investors are missing emerging opportunities due to the rapid decline in oil prices, which has eased energy costs and boosted consumer spending. Many money managers have yet to adjust their portfolios, which were optimized for oil prices above $110. BlackRock has increased investments in net energy-importing countries and is bullish on eastern and western Europe, where cheaper oil will stimulate businesses serving consumers. Investors should prepare to increase investments in industrial-goods and consumer-products industries if oil falls further.

site_title: Tasmanian whisky makers make global waves
summary: Tasmanian whisky makers are making global waves with their unique, handcrafted spirits. Sullivans Cove, a 13-year-old single malt, was recently named the world's best whisky at the World Whisky Awards. The distillery's owner, Patrick Maguire, attributes the success to the use of traditional methods and high-quality ingredients, including second-hand casks. This approach is in contrast to mass-produced whiskies, which Maguire believes compromise on the natural flavors and craftsmanship. The success of Sullivans Cove has sparked a new wave of whisky producers in Tasmania, with many hoping to replicate the distillery's success and meet the growing demand for their products.

site_title: Dollar rises on upbeat remarks by Fed officials
summary: The US dollar rose against a basket of currencies on Tuesday, driven by upbeat comments from Federal Reserve officials on the positive impact of declining oil prices on the US economy. This move contrasts with the concerns of the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan, which are grappling with deflation and the sharp fall in oil prices. The dollar's rise suggests that the Fed may start to tighten policy in the middle of 2015, despite the uncertainty surrounding the timing of such a move.

site_title: Boustead plans demerger leading to listing of a unit
summary: Boustead Singapore, a technology and engineering group, proposes demerging its real estate solutions business to be listed on the Singapore Exchange under its wholly owned subsidiary Boustead Projects. The proposed restructuring would unlock value for shareholders and allow them to participate directly in the equity of Boustead Projects. The plan, which remains at a preliminary stage, has not been finalized and requires regulatory approvals. Boustead reported a 94% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$17.5 million for its second quarter ended Sept 30.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Outstanding entrepreneurship
summary: Advanced Holdings founder Dr. Kar Wong has been awarded the EY Entrepreneur of the Year Award for Engineering Services and Process Equipment. Wong founded the company in 1993 and it has since grown into a global organization with over 500 employees across Asia-Pacific, the Middle East, Europe, and the US. Wong attributes his success to a clear vision, resourcefulness, and a set of principles, citing examples such as Jeff Bezos of Amazon. He believes that entrepreneurship can thrive in Singapore, but requires a global mindset and a focus on innovation and quality.

site_title: Delta cuts down Ghana flights as Ebola damps travel demand
summary: Delta Air Lines is cutting 20% of its flights to Accra, Ghana, due to the Ebola outbreak in West Africa, despite not directly citing the virus as a reason. The airline reduced round-trip flights from 22 to 18 in November and plans to maintain the reduced schedule indefinitely. Delta's Africa flights have historically struggled with low demand, and the airline must be creative to make money in the region, which faces challenges such as high altitudes and theft of customer luggage.

site_title: Security firm claims cyber espionage to game US markets
summary: A cyber espionage ring, designated FIN4 by cybersecurity firm FireEye, has been targeting companies with access to highly insider data to profit on trades. Since mid-2013, the group has attacked over 100 firms, mostly pharmaceutical and healthcare companies, and corporate advisers. The hackers stole sensitive information, including draft SEC filings and medical research results, before making it public. FireEye believes the hackers are based in the US or Western Europe, and were likely trained at Western investment banks.

site_title: The importance of legacy planning
summary: Wealthy individuals and families are increasingly planning for the future, including succession planning, as inherited wealth declines and fortunes are made at a rapid rate. A key consideration is how to share wealth with friends, family, and charitable causes, with 49% of over-65s and 36% of those between 55-65 using their wealth in this way. There are three main models of legacy planning: conservative, philanthropic, and a balance between the two. Families must consider the timing of these decisions and allow members to flourish and develop at their own pace to create a successful legacy.

site_title: China to introduce property registration rules in March
summary: China plans to implement property registration rules from March, sharing information among government departments to prevent officials from hiding assets and curb speculation. The national registration system, approved by the State Council, aims to provide anti-graft tools and pave the way for nationwide real estate taxes. The rules were delayed due to sensitivity and complexity, but will take effect despite these challenges. The move could help address public outrage over corrupt officials and stabilize the market, which has seen house prices surge and then fall. The system is expected to be operational by 2016.

site_title: GIC beefs up real-estate portfolio with US$8.1b purchase of IndCor
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has agreed to buy US industrial property company IndCor Properties Inc from Blackstone Group LP for $8.1 billion. IndCor, with a portfolio of 117 million square feet of industrial real estate in 23 states, will give GIC a significant presence in the US warehousing space. The deal comes as demand for commercial real estate and warehouse properties increases due to global trade growth. The purchase is part of GIC's efforts to expand its global real-estate portfolio, which accounted for 7% of its assets in its most recent annual report.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Investing in the genius of art
summary: Fine art has become a significant asset class, with record-breaking sales at Christie's and Sotheby's auctions in New York, totaling over $2 billion. The sales of contemporary and post-war art have seen an average compound return of 20% annually, surpassing inflation and equities. Financial institutions are now treating art as an asset class, with banks lending against art and creating collateralized debt obligations. Experts attribute the surge in art prices to innovation by artists, with works from influential periods and styles commanding high prices. The art market's emergence as a legitimate asset class is seen as a significant shift.

site_title: FBI alerts US firms to malware used in Sony cyberattack
summary: The FBI has warned US businesses about a destructive malware used in a cyberattack on Sony Pictures Entertainment, the first major attack on US soil. The malware, described in a confidential FBI report, overrides hard drive data and makes it difficult to recover. The attack, which brought down corporate email and crippled systems, has been linked to North Korea as possible retribution for Sony's release of the comedy film "The Interview." The FBI is investigating with the Department of Homeland Security, and Sony has hired a team to clean up the attack.

site_title: Growing and transforming
summary: Four entrepreneurs from diverse industries have been named winners of the 13th Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year awards. Kar Wong, CEO of Advanced Holdings, was recognized for his customer-focused approach to business, which has grown the company into a global enterprise. Ong Tze Boon, CEO of Ong & Ong, was praised for transforming the local architecture firm into a global company. Susan Chong, CEO of Greenpac, was awarded for pioneering green solutions in sustainable packaging. Alfred Chua, co-founder of The Wok People, was recognized for his people-centric approach to business, which has helped the company thrive.

site_title: Update: Boustead Singapore looking at spinning off real estate solutions business
summary: BOUSTEAD Singapore is considering demerging its real estate solutions business, which would be consolidated under its wholly-owned subsidiary Boustead Projects and potentially listed on the Singapore Exchange. The proposed restructuring would unlock value for shareholders and allow them to participate directly in the equity of Boustead Projects. A decision on the proposed transactions has not been made, with the details remaining at a preliminary stage.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Innovation and the CFO
summary: Leading CFOs recognize innovation is not just an R&D department's responsibility, but a company-wide initiative. Innovation should drive business growth, not just product development. CFOs can champion innovation by collaborating with entrepreneurs, academics, and competitors, and by establishing a governance framework and measuring success. Successful collaborations require alignment of incentives, return on investment, and cultural fit. CFOs should lead in due diligence, governance, and long-term perspective to make these relationships fruitful, and ultimately drive growth and revenue increases.

images.alt_text: Mr Max Loh.

site_title: Takata recall may have to be expanded after latest explosion
summary: A recent explosion at a Japanese scrapyard involving a Toyota WiLL Cypha car model not subject to a Takata air bag recall has raised concerns about the scope of the safety campaign. The incident, which shattered the windshield and sprayed metal shards, is the seventh such rupture at Japanese scrapyards since 2012. Japan's transport ministry is investigating the cause, which could lead to the expansion of the recall, affecting more vehicles globally. The incident highlights the ongoing crisis surrounding Takata's air bags, linked to at least four US deaths, and the company's struggle to meet the demands of regulators.

site_title: Outgoing TSA chief reflects on 2014's airport security measures
summary: TSA Administrator John Pistole reflects on the agency's airport security measures in 2014. Over 45% of air travelers now use PreCheck or other risk-based programs, with 725,000 enrolled in the program. The TSA plans to expand PreCheck through partnerships with private companies, potentially increasing enrollment to millions. Pistole also discussed relaxed rules for carrying liquids, the return of small snow globes, and a record number of guns found at checkpoints, with over 1,900 discovered by mid-November.

site_title: Advanced Group MD crowned EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2014 Singapore
summary: Kar Wong, managing director of Advanced Group of Companies, was named EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2014 Singapore for his entrepreneurial spirit and ability to guide the company through crises. Wong also won awards for engineering services and process equipment, and will represent Singapore at the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year awards in Monaco next June. The EY Entrepreneur Of The Year award also recognized Greenpac CEO Susan Chong for sustainable packaging solutions and ONG&ONG's Ong Tze Boon for professional services.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: S'pore confident of long-term prospects for oil & gas industry: Iswaran
summary: Singapore remains optimistic about its oil and gas industry, despite short-term market volatility. Second Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran expressed confidence in the sector's long-term prospects, citing strong economic fundamentals in the Asia-Pacific region. The region's rapid population growth and development will continue to drive energy demand, supporting exploration and production activities. Singapore will invest in research and development and talent to support the growth of the offshore and marine sector, which currently employs over 20,000 Singaporeans in skilled jobs.

site_title: Investors hesitant about Malaysia, say analysts
summary: International portfolio investors are showing hesitation towards Malaysia due to its fiscal deficit, high household debt, and shrinking ringgit. Analysts attribute this to concerns about the country's ability to meet fiscal deficit targets and lower oil revenue. The benchmark KLCI and FBM70 indices experienced losses in November, and experts predict a continued decline in December despite window-dressing activities by funds.

images.alt_text: Analysts have observed that international portfolio investors are appearing hesitant about Malaysia, whether it is because of its high rate of household debt, or the belief that lower oil revenue will hurt the country's ability to meet its fiscal deficit targets, or a combination of other reasons.

site_title: RBI keeps rates on hold, says may ease in early 2015
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) kept interest rates steady at 8% amid concerns over India's weak economic recovery. Governor Raghuram Rajan stated that containing inflation is crucial for sustainable growth, and a change in monetary policy stance is premature. The RBI urged the government to meet fiscal deficit targets and revive capital investment. While inflation has slowed to 5.52%, the RBI expects it to rise in December and aims for a longer-term inflation target of 4% by 2016.

site_title: President Ma to step down as chairman of Taiwan ruling party: statement
summary: Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou announced he will step down as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang party on Wednesday, following heavy defeats in local elections. Ma expressed willingness to take responsibility and stated that his departure would mark a new beginning for the party, not an ending.

site_title: China to toughen stance on tax avoidance
summary: China plans to strengthen its stance against tax avoidance by foreign firms, closely monitoring their profit levels to prevent profits from being shifted to lower-tax regions. The move comes after Beijing levied $140 million in back taxes on US firm Microsoft. China will coordinate with other countries to clamp down on "base erosion and profit shifting" practices, a practice where companies shift profits to avoid taxes. This effort aims to prevent tax avoidance and boost revenue, following a pledge by Chinese President Xi Jinping to increase efforts to prevent tax avoidance.

site_title: In Brief
summary: JEP Precision Engineering, a subsidiary of JEP Holdings, signed a 30-year lease for an 18,500 square meter land in Seletar Aerospace Park, Singapore. The group plans to invest around S$28 million to build a new facility and purchase new machinery, relocating its manufacturing operations from Changi by end 2017.

site_title: Bridging the big corporate data skills gap
summary: Singapore leads the world as a digital society, with 85% smartphone adoption, and is one of only three countries ready to meet digital challenges. The country faces a skills gap in big data, with a need for digitally proficient and strategic executives, including chief digital officers, to lead digital transformation. These leaders must possess a range of skills, including business data analytics, digital risk management, and the ability to harness data to measure employee performance and engagement. With the war for digital leadership talent expected to intensify, companies in Singapore must invest in the right leadership skills to remain competitive.

site_title: Goldman Sachs downgrades Singapore to "underweight"
summary: Goldman Sachs downgraded Singapore's market to "underweight" due to muted or lower earnings from the energy and property sectors. The downgrade contrasts with upgrades to Hong Kong and Indonesia, which are expected to see more growth. Goldman's chief Asia-Pacific strategist cited macroeconomic factors and a challenging environment for sectors that make up 60% of Singapore's market capitalization, although some sectors like banks may benefit from interest rate hikes in the future.

site_title: IPOs won't draw retail investors to the market
summary: Recent initial public offerings (IPOs) have failed to attract retail investors, contrary to the notion that they can "strike the lottery" and make money. Companies price their IPOs high, while investors seek low prices, resulting in little upside or downside. Even if an IPO underpriced, investors are unlikely to return to the market solely for a chance to make money on a one-time win. Retail investors should be cautious and not rely on IPOs as a means to make consistent profits, as it is a flawed investment strategy.

site_title: Opec's latest move big shock for global system
summary: Opec's decision to maintain its stance of not reducing oil output has sent shockwaves to the global economy and political systems. The sharp decline in oil prices, resulting from increased production in the US and Iraq, has significant implications for countries reliant on oil exports, including Saudi Arabia, Iran, and the United Arab Emirates. The price drop may persuade Iran to agree with the West and abandon its nuclear ambitions, while also hurting the Islamic State and Japan's economy. The consequences for the global economy and politics are expected to be profound, with potential distributional effects including sharp declines in capital transfers between oil-importing and oil-exporting countries.

site_title: Oil falls below US$72 after sharp rally in volatile market
summary: Brent oil fell below US$72 a barrel on Tuesday, reversing gains from five-year lows, as traders expressed uncertainty over market direction. The price drop comes after new North American oil supplies overwhelmed demand, driven by slower economic growth in China and Europe. Analysts predict a volatile adjustment phase, with physical crude oil oversupply lasting into the second quarter of next year. Low prices may force some producers out of the market, with drillers considering temporarily idling rigs and unconventional producers threatening to exit the market.

site_title: Opec oil output drops in November as Libyan recovery falters
summary: Opec's oil supply dropped by 340,000 barrels per day in November to 30.30 million bpd, despite retaining its output target of 30 million bpd. The decline was attributed to a faltering Libyan recovery, with Libya's supply falling by 150,000 bpd, and maintenance at oilfields in Angola, Kuwait, and Qatar. Opec's decision not to cut production to support prices has led to a surplus, with prices falling below $68, the lowest since 2009.

site_title: Advanced Group's MD wins EY Entrepreneur Of The Year in Singapore
summary: Dr. Kar Wong, Managing Director of Advanced Group of Companies, was named EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2014 Singapore. He will represent Singapore at the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year in Monaco next year. Other winners included Susan Chong, Ong Tze Boon, and Alfred Chua, who won awards in various categories such as sustainable packaging, professional services, and food and beverage.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: GuocoLand ramps up marketing for new condo in Sims Drive (Amended)
summary: GuocoLand is set to launch its 1,024-unit condo project, Sims Urban Oasis, in Sims Drive, Singapore, early next year. The 2.4 ha project will feature a sky park, childcare centre, and various unit types. Pricing and initial unit release details have not been confirmed. GuocoLand aims to price the project competitively, targeting diverse owner-occupiers, including young couples, families, and multi-generational households. The project's proximity to Aljunied MRT station and amenities is expected to drive interest.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on upbeat 'Cyber Monday' sales
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, following upbeat data on "Cyber Monday" sales, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 39.23 points (0.22%) to 17,816.03. Online sales on Cyber Monday reached $2.65 billion, a 16% increase from 2013. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also advanced, driven by positive international markets, including a 3.1% surge in Shanghai.

site_title: S-Reits ratings to remain stable next year: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings expects Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) to maintain stable ratings in 2015, despite weak tourist arrivals due to economic growth in China and inflation in Indonesia. Hospitality Reits may face downside risks, while industrial S-Reits are expected to remain stable due to strong economic growth in Singapore and the US. Healthcare S-Reits are also expected to benefit from robust demand for healthcare services in key markets. Fitch maintains stable ratings for CDL Hospitality Trust, Far East Hospitality Trust, Mapletree Industrial Trust, and Parkway Life Reit.

site_title: Entrepreneurship - cradle to economic growth
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) recognizes the importance of mentorship programs to identify and groom promising young business leaders. The SBF-led Young Business Leaders Alliance (YBLA) aims to strengthen support for the community of young entrepreneurs, providing a platform for peer-learning, sharing experiences, and co-innovating. The YBLA has partnered with other ethnic chambers and organizations to launch mentorship programs, including the "Red Pill Programme" to equip aspiring and current Indian entrepreneurs with entrepreneurial knowledge. The initiative seeks to build a nurturing entrepreneurial culture and competitive business community, fostering relationships and learning from one another.

site_title: Total returns of IPOs this year average 3.3%
summary: Singapore's stocks averaged a 3.3% total return in the first 11 months of 2014, in line with last year's returns.
