The 24 IPOs this year had a mixed performance, with 10 stocks generating positive returns and 12 registering negative returns. Top performer IPS Securex Holdings saw its stock price more than double since its June IPO, while Terratech Group, a marble producer, had a negative 58.3% return. Funds raised by Catalist companies reached an all-time high of S$285 million as of November 27.

site_title: India hikes factory gate duties on diesel, petrol: government
summary: India has raised factory gate duties on petrol by 2.25 rupees (US$0.04) per litre and on diesel by one rupee per litre, effective immediately, to boost government revenues amid a slump in world oil prices. The measures aim to shore up revenue without stoking inflation, with expected additional income of 40 billion Indian rupees (US$650 million) in the remainder of the fiscal year to March 2015. This follows similar hikes in mid-November.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.7 points to close at 1,785.97 on Tuesday, driven by gains of 439 stocks and losses of 400. The index saw significant trading volume of 2.16 billion lots, valued at RM2.18 billion.

site_title: EU said to face Basel committee rebuke for banking rule shortfalls
summary: The European Union is set to face a rebuke from the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision for shortcomings in implementing its bank capital rules. A report found the EU to be "materially non-compliant" in areas such as the definition of capital and rules around banks' use of internal models. The Basel Committee, an international group of regulators, has no power to compel compliance but can name and shame non-compliant countries. The EU's European Central Bank's stance on the matter will be crucial in determining the outcome, with regulators suggesting that the ECB's attitude could bring the eurozone closer to Basel III compliance.

site_title: Don't look now, but Amazon is disrupting itself
summary: Amazon reported disappointing third-quarter results, with revenue falling short of forecasts by $250 million. The company's struggles may be attributed to intentional cannibalization of major product lines, including music, video, and e-books, to draw customers into its ecosystem. Analysts suggest Amazon's expansion into retail and entertainment could disrupt itself and other retailers. Despite increasing losses, Amazon aims to become a retail and entertainment colossus, with plans to leverage its e-commerce operation to sell devices, services, and basics like groceries.

site_title: US construction spending posts biggest gain in five months
summary: US construction spending rose 1.1% in October to an annual rate of $970.99 billion, the largest gain in five months. This increase in spending could ease concerns of a slowdown in fourth-quarter economic growth. The revision of September's construction outlays also showed a smaller decline, rather than the previously reported 0.4%. The stronger-than-expected increase in construction spending suggests a more robust economic growth outlook.

site_title: US to discuss possible new Russia sanctions with European allies
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry will discuss possible new sanctions on Russia with European allies over Ukraine violence. The US and EU have already imposed sanctions on Russia's financial, defense, and energy sectors due to its annexation of Crimea and support for separatists. However, EU diplomats express limited appetite for additional sanctions, fearing they could harm their economies as Russia is Europe's leading energy supplier. The talks aim to determine if further sanctions are necessary to halt violence in eastern Ukraine.

site_title: Company bosses often know of bribes to foreign public officials: OECD
summary: The OECD's first Foreign Bribery report found that corporate management was aware of bribes in over half of 427 enforcement actions taken since 2000. In 41% of cases, management-level staff knew bribes were being paid, and 12% involved company chief executives. Bribes were paid to officials in both poor and developed countries, with 43% of cases involving bribery in developed countries. The report aims to raise awareness about foreign bribery and identify areas for policy recommendations to combat the crime.

site_title: Volvo Car Group sales rise 2.6% year-on-year in November
summary: Volvo Car Group reported a 2.6% year-on-year increase in sales for November, driven by growth in China, Sweden, and Western Europe. However, US sales declined 14.4% due to recent struggles. Despite this, Volvo unveiled a model overhaul in October to revive its fortunes in the US market. The company's sales rose 15.6% in China, 6.5% in Sweden, and 3.4% in Western Europe.

site_title: UK construction sector expands at slowest pace in 13 months: PMI
summary: The UK construction sector expanded at its slowest pace in 13 months, with the Markit/CIPS construction PMI falling to 59.4 in November, below economists' expectations. Despite growth above the 50 threshold, optimism about the year ahead declined to its lowest level since October 2013. The slowdown was most pronounced in civil engineering, which relies heavily on government-backed projects. The sector's decline may be influenced by uncertainties ahead of the general election.

site_title: Boustead considers spinning off real estate solutions unit
summary: Boustead Singapore Ltd is considering spinning off its real estate solutions business, which could lead to a listing of the unit's shares. The proposed plan is at a preliminary stage. Boustead Projects, the company's industrial facilities arm, operates in Singapore, China, Malaysia, and Vietnam. No further details or timeline have been announced for the potential spin-off.

site_title: Joyas to issue warrants, convertibles to fund move into nickel trading
summary: Joyas International Holdings plans to expand into nickel trading by buying a 70% stake in Hong Kong Silver Basic Group for HK$700,000. The company will issue up to S$3.5 million of warrants and S$5.3 million of convertible bonds to fund its diversification plans, with 80% of proceeds going towards diversification and 20% for working capital. Global nickel demand is expected to outpace supply in the long term, according to managing director Peter Lau Chor Beng.

site_title: Singapore's November PMI slips to 51.8, electronics PMI drops to 50.6
summary: Singapore's November Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 51.8, down 0.1 from October's 51.9, marking a slight contraction. The electronics PMI dropped to 50.6, a significant decline from October's 52.5. New export orders in the electronics sector contracted for the first time in 22 months, while the overall PMI expanded due to increased new orders and export orders.

site_title: Malaysia's Asian Healthcare Group seeks US$219m IPO
summary: Malaysia's Asian Healthcare Group Bhd plans to raise up to S$286 million (750 million ringgit) through an initial public offering (IPO) to tap into the growing demand for private healthcare in Asia's middle class. The company, led by former banker Yvonne Chia, aims to acquire a hospital with 100-500 beds and initially focus on Malaysia before expanding into Indonesia, Thailand, and Singapore.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 16.68 points to 3,322.32. 1.18 billion shares were traded, with 219 gainers and 171 losers.

site_title: Taiwan's Ma to step down as ruling party head after polls defeat
summary: Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou announced his resignation as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) party after the party suffered massive losses in the island's biggest ever local elections. The KMT lost five of Taiwan's six large municipalities and retained control of only six out of 22 cities and counties. Ma attributed the defeat to his leadership and urged the party to remain calm and united, vowing to reflect and reform to regain the people's trust. The defeat marks a significant setback for Ma, who has faced mounting calls for his resignation.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close up 0.42% at fresh seven-year high
summary: Tokyo stocks reached a fresh seven-year high, closing 0.42% higher at 17,663.22. The Nikkei 225 index and Topix index rose 73.12 and 6.20 points, respectively. The gains came despite Moody's downgrading Japan's credit rating, as investors remained upbeat.

site_title: German car sales return to growth in 2014, grow further 2015: VDA
summary: Germany's auto market is expected to return to growth in 2014, with new car registrations growing about 2% to slightly more than 3 million. This growth is expected to continue in 2015, with volumes potentially rising by 1%. The VDA industry association attributes the improvement to a "better than sentiment" situation, with German auto sales experiencing a three-year growth pause.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close up on China rally
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.2% to 23,654.30 points, driven by a 2.8% gain in China's China Enterprises Index. Analysts attribute the rally to institutional investment in financial services stocks and speculation about a potential reduction in bank reserve requirements. The index measuring price differences between Shanghai and Hong Kong rose 2% to its highest level since July 2013.

site_title: US fed funds rate hit highest since April 2013
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised its interest rate to 0.13% on Monday, the highest level since April 2013, as part of a test program to tighten policy. The effective interest rate on federal funds rose from 0.08% on Friday, and the Fed set a new interest rate on reverse repurchase agreements at 0.10%. The move aims to drain cash from the banking system and keep the fed funds rate at the targeted level of 0.00-0.25%. The rate hike is part of the Fed's efforts to control inflation and stabilize the economy.

site_title: Australia's central bank holds interest rates at 2.5%
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, held interest rates at 2.5% for the 15th consecutive meeting, signaling an accommodative monetary policy to support growth. The decision was made despite a booming housing market and slumping commodity prices. Governor Glenn Stevens stated that a weaker Australian dollar is needed to achieve balanced growth and that a period of stability in interest rates is likely. The bank retains its view of moderate growth in the Australian economy, citing signs of improving non-mining private demand.

site_title: India's central bank keeps interest rates unchanged
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) kept interest rates unchanged at 8.0% during its policy review, as widely expected. The decision aimed to contain inflation while adopting a more dovish tone to support economic growth. 41 out of 45 economists polled by Reuters predicted the unchanged rate, with four expecting a 25 basis point reduction. The RBI's stance is in response to the government's call for help to revive economic growth.

site_title: Blackstone to sell IndCor Properties to GIC for US$8.1b
summary: Blackstone is selling its US industrial platform IndCor Properties to Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC for US$8.1 billion, canceling an initial public offering. IndCor, formed in 2010, owns warehouses and distribution centers across the US. The deal is expected to close in Q1 2015. This sale marks GIC's expansion into the US real estate market, following recent purchases in Tokyo and Australian student accommodation.

site_title: Japan kicks off election campaigning in 'Abenomics referendum'
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has kicked off election campaigning ahead of a December 14 national poll, describing it as a "referendum" on his "Abenomics" growth policies. The election will determine the composition of the lower house of parliament, with the ruling Liberal Democratic Party expected to secure a comfortable majority. Abe's popularity has taken a hit due to recent economic challenges and scandals, but the opposition lacks a strong contender. The election comes as the country grapples with high national debt, deflation, and a stalled sales tax hike.

site_title: Indonesia to boost oil reserves, refineries in bid to tackle graft
summary: Indonesia's new administration plans to expand oil storage and refineries as part of energy reforms aimed at reducing corruption in the state oil trader. The country aims to increase storage capacity by 40% by 2019, with a cost of $2.44 billion, and operational reserves to 30 days worth of fuel. The overhaul includes a comprehensive audit of Petral and the sacking of Pertamina's board, with the goal of shifting from spot market purchases to stable long-term contracts with foreign producers, reducing opportunities for graft.

site_title: Jaya faces S$15.6m claim from Mermaid Marine Australia
summary: Jaya Holdings has received a claim of S$15.6 million from Mermaid Marine Australia, alleging a breach of warranties under the sale and purchase agreement. Jaya is seeking further information to assess the claim and respond accordingly. As of Sept 30, Jaya had net current assets of S$19.7 million. The company's shares closed at 4.1 Singapore cents, down 2.4% due to the announcement.

site_title: Alibaba, Tencent chairmen invest in China's Ping An Insurance
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd and Tencent Holdings Ltd, led by founders Jack Ma and Pony Ma, respectively, invested in Ping An Insurance Group Co of China Ltd in a HK$36.5 billion (US$4.7 billion) deal. The three firms, collectively known as the "Three Mas", also collaborated on Zhong An Online Property Insurance and jointly invested in media production company Huayi Brothers Media Corp. This deal reinforces ties between China's second-largest insurance company and internet giants in finance.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.14% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.14% in the opening exchanges on December 2, 2014, after a heavy sell-off in the previous session. The Hang Seng Index climbed 32.66 points to 23,400.11.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.09 points to 1779.36 on Tuesday, with gains outnumbering losses 85 to 72. The market opened higher despite ongoing US tariff uncertainty and split Fed views. In other news, Airalo raised $220 million in funding, lifting its valuation to over $1 billion, while a Dutch firm made a mandatory offer for PSC at S$0.40 per share.

site_title: Hong Kong students on hunger strike want government to talk
summary: Hong Kong student leaders, including Joshua Wong, have gone on an indefinite hunger strike to force the government into further talks amid a pro-democracy movement crisis. The strike comes after violent clashes with police and a failed attempt to storm government headquarters. Wong hopes the hunger strike will allow for open dialogue with government officials, enabling a solution to the Hong Kong problem. The student group is demanding greater autonomy and democratic reforms.

images.alt_text: The student leaders are carrying out their hunger strike in tents outside government headquarters and were pictured shivering with cold as temperatures dropped in the city.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed, energy firms recover on oil bounce
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday, with energy firms recovering from losses as oil prices rebounded from multi-year lows. The Dow Jones eased 0.27%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.68% and the Nasdaq sank 1.34%. Energy giants BHP Billiton, Woodside, and Santos rose, while airlines such as Cathay Pacific and Korean Airlines fell. The Russian ruble strengthened against the dollar, while the yen edged up against the dollar, with analysts citing the Moody's downgrade of Japan's credit rating as having little impact.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open up on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 24.47 points to 3,330.11 on Tuesday, driven by a 0.4% gain from Thursday. The market saw a 101-46 gainer-to-loser ratio. Meanwhile, Airalo raised US$220 million in funding, lifting its valuation to over US$1 billion, and a Dutch firm made a mandatory offer for PSC shares at S$0.40 per share.

site_title: Obama expected to nominate Ashton Carter to lead Pentagon: CNN
summary: US President Barack Obama is expected to nominate former Pentagon official Ashton Carter as US defense secretary, replacing Chuck Hagel who is resigning. Carter, who previously served as deputy secretary at the Department of Defense, has been a leading candidate for the job. No official announcement has been made yet, but the nomination is seen as a likely move by Obama to fill the vacant position.

images.alt_text: US President Barack Obama is expected to nominate former Pentagon official Ashton Carter as US defense secretary, CNN reported on Tuesday.

site_title: China rate cut is cold comfort for struggling developers
summary: China's benchmark interest rate was cut by 40 basis points to 5.6% in November, providing a negligible relief to struggling property developers. Despite the rate cut, sales continue to slip, and banks are pulling back on lending to the sector due to mounting inventories and tight liquidity. Experts predict a 5% fall in average selling prices in 2015, and some developers are already increasing asset turnover to improve cash flows. The rate cut is unlikely to stimulate demand in cities with oversupply, and its impact will be limited due to poor access to borrowing for weaker players.

site_title: Malaysia says can meet 2015 budget deficit target despite slumping oil prices
summary: Malaysia is sticking to its target of reducing its budget deficit to 3.0% of GDP next year despite slumping oil prices, which could lead to a 37% decrease in Petronas' payments. State oil company Petronas warned that low oil prices could impact the government's revenue. However, Finance Minister Ahmad Husni Hanadzlah stated that the deficit targets remain in place, pending a final decision on Petronas' payments. The government aims to narrow the deficit further to 3.5% this year and 3% in 2015, with the goal of a balanced budget by 2020.

site_title: SGX hires TradingScreen to set up Asian bond trading platform
summary: SGX, a Singaporean exchange, has hired TradingScreen to create an over-the-counter Asian bond trading platform. The platform aims to concentrate liquidity for high-yield and investment-quality corporate bonds, initially focusing on G-3 currencies before incorporating local currency debt. The rollout is planned for mid-2015, with the goal of providing the best trading service for bonds in Asia.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 0.62%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.62% lower on Tuesday following early profit-taking, driven by a decline in US bourses and a stronger yen. Moody's downgraded Japan's sovereign debt rating to A1, but its impact appears limited. The Nikkei 225 index fell 109.04 points to 17,481.06.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL Hospitality Trusts, Jaya, Spackman
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts plans to spend $66.3 million to buy two Tokyo hotels, Hotel MyStays Asakusabashi and Hotel MyStays Kamata. The stapled group will acquire the 138-room and 116-room hotels, respectively.

site_title: Hong Kong braced for more violence as frustrations boil
summary: Hong Kong braces for further clashes as pro-democracy protests enter their third month. Demonstrators, frustrated by a lack of government compromise, are taking more radical action. Analysts warn that peaceful protests can turn violent if the government ignores or suppresses the issues. A law professor notes that history shows that protests become violent when the government fails to address problems. The protests, which have been largely peaceful, may escalate in the coming days, with analysts predicting more clashes.

site_title: China's fourth-richest man seeks expansion with US$6b IPO of Dalian Wanda property unit
summary: China's fourth-richest man, Wang Jianlin, plans to raise up to $6 billion through a Hong Kong IPO of Dalian Wanda Commercial Properties, his property unit. The IPO, the largest in Asia since 2010, aims to fund the expansion of the empire built on cheap government land. Despite an industry slump and rising debt, Wang believes the IPO will help lower funding costs and aid in the company's plans to enter the world's top 10 cities over the next decade.

site_title: Joyas eyes nickel trading, plans to issue warrants, convertibles
summary: Joyas International Holdings plans to expand into nickel trading by buying a 70% stake in a Hong Kong outfit for HK$700,000 (S$118,000) in cash. The company will also issue up to S$3.5 million of warrants and S$5.3 million of convertible bonds to fund its diversification plans. Managing director Peter Lau Chor Beng expects strong demand for nickel, driven by long-term supply shortages, providing a sustainable investment opportunity.

site_title: Spackman to buy 51% of post-production house
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group has agreed to buy 51% of post-production house Fireworks Co, a Korean entertainment production company, in a non-binding deal. The transaction is subject to due diligence and various approvals. Fireworks specializes in TV commercial picture editing services and has collaborated with Spackman's subsidiary Breakfastfilm Co for nearly 10 years. Spackman expects synergies with its theatrical film business, citing Fireworks' potential to expand into post-production for movies. The proposed value of the deal was not disclosed.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as oil, gold rebound drive resources up
summary: Australian shares rose 1% on Tuesday, driven by a rebound in oil and gold prices, which lifted resources firms. The S&P/ASX 200 index regained 52 points to 5259.4. Gold stocks surged 4-11%, while oil producers rose 2-3%. Iron ore stocks also recovered, with BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto gaining 3% each. The positive momentum followed a weak lead from Wall Street and encouraged investors despite weakening global growth.

site_title: Joshua Wong, two other HK student protesters on hunger strike
summary: Hong Kong pro-democracy protest leader Joshua Wong and two other members of his student group Scholarism announced an "indefinite" hunger strike to force the Hong Kong government to respond to their demands for free elections in 2017. The trio, including 18-year-old Wong and two female members, started their strike immediately, drinking only water and calling for the government to reopen stalled talks and withdraw its decision to vet candidates. The hunger strike comes as protests struggle to find new ways to push forward their demands, amid increasing violence and police action.

site_title: GLP: No deal with Blackstone, GIC on US industrial real estate
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) announced there is no agreement with Blackstone Group and GIC on a reported $8.1 billion US industrial property deal. The planned sale, involving 117 million square feet of assets held in IndCor Properties, was initially set to list in the first quarter of 2015. Blackstone instead opted for a trade sale, according to The Wall Street Journal. The deal's status remains uncertain, with no timeline for a potential closure.

images.alt_text: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) said there is no agreement on a reported US$8.1 billion deal for US industrial property between itself, GIC and Blackstone Group.

site_title: Microsoft buys email mobile app Accompli
summary: Microsoft has acquired mobile email management application Accompli for over $200 million. Accompli, which uses Google Android or Apple iOS operating systems, aims to provide innovative ways to manage email on mobile devices. The deal will help Microsoft reimagine productivity for the mobile era, with Accompli's founder stating the app will become part of Microsoft's effort to improve mobile email experiences.

site_title: Hot stock: Xpress falls after massive impairments
summary: Shares of Xpress Holdings plummeted by a third after the company reported significant impairments, resulting in a S$147 million loss for the year ended July 31. The company took a S$64.5 million impairment on goodwill and a S$63.9 million impairment on trade and project receivables due to struggles in the commercial printing industry. Trading was halted over the weekend and resumed on Tuesday, with the stock trading at 0.6 Singapore cent.

site_title: FBI says it is investigating cyber attack at Sony Pictures
summary: The FBI confirmed it is investigating the cyber attack on Sony Pictures Entertainment, which occurred last week. The FBI stated it is working with interagency partners to investigate the cyber intrusion. The incident was first reported by Reuters, which initially stated the FBI was probing the incident. Details of the attack and its cause are not yet available.

site_title: Report criticises Boeing, FAA over 787 battery woes
summary: US investigators say the 2013 grounding of Boeing 787 Dreamliners due to battery defects was due to a defect in the battery that was poorly addressed by manufacturers and regulators. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) found Boeing's management of contractors did not ensure consistent manufacturing practices, and the FAA failed to recognize the potential impact of internal short circuits. Boeing and the FAA were criticized for their handling of the issue, but the company maintains its battery system is safe and effective.

site_title: Taiwan cabinet quits following ruling party's dismal polls showing
summary: Taiwan's cabinet resigned en masse after the ruling Kuomintang party suffered a massive defeat in local elections, with Premier Jiang Yi-huah quitting hours after the result. The KMT lost five of Taiwan's six large municipalities, and its main rival, the Democratic Progressive Party, took 47.5% of the votes. The defeat is seen as a key barometer ahead of the 2016 presidential race, and President Ma Ying-jeou is expected to choose a new premier in the coming days.

site_title: Brazil posts worst November trade deficit in 20 years
summary: Brazil posted its worst November trade deficit in 20 years, totaling US$2.35 billion, with imports exceeding exports by US$2.4 billion. This marks the country's worst monthly result since 1998 and its worst year-to-date deficit since 1998, at US$4.2 billion. The country's economic crisis, recession, and low growth have contributed to the decline. Total imports reached US$18 billion, while exports fell to US$15.6 billion, mainly due to dropping prices in raw materials and the economic crisis in neighboring Argentina.

site_title: US car dealers also getting in on the Black Friday act
summary: US car dealers are joining the Black Friday shopping frenzy, offering discounts and promotions on new cars. Major manufacturers such as Volkswagen, General Motors, and Ford are providing zero-per cent financing and cash back deals to attract buyers. This trend is expected to continue through December, with some analysts suggesting it may pull sales forward from the month. The deals are seen as a way for carmakers to capitalize on robust demand and rising prices, with US car sales expected to reach a seasonally adjusted annualized rate of 16.8 million in November.

site_title: GM recalls 316,000 vehicles because of malfunctioning headlights
summary: General Motors is recalling 316,357 vehicles in North America due to malfunctioning low-beam headlights. The affected vehicles are from 2006-2009 model years, including Buick LaCrosse sedans, Chevrolet Trailblazer, GMC Envoy, and Isuzu Ascender SUVs. The recall does not affect high-beam headlights or other features. GM has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and this is the company's 30.4 millionth recall worldwide this year.

site_title: Venezuela faces hyperinflation threat
summary: Venezuela is facing a hyperinflation threat, with its economy struggling due to falling oil prices, shortages of food and medicine, and a lack of foreign currency. The country's inflation rate, once reported at 63.4%, has stopped being published by the central bank. Prices have continued to rise, with the value of the bolivar plummeting, as seen in the doubling of a Big Mac combo meal from 125 to 245 bolivars. The government has tried to boost buying power by raising the minimum wage, but this has only fueled inflation. Experts warn that Venezuela is not yet at the threshold of hyperinflation, but the monthly inflation rate is likely around 5%, putting pressure on the currency and fueling inflation.

site_title: SilverNeedle not eyeing Singapore hotel deals now
summary: Singapore-based SilverNeedle Hospitality CEO Iqbal Jumabhoy stated that the company is less keen on Singapore hotel deals due to higher costs and lower yields compared to other Asia-Pacific regions. He expressed interest in exploring opportunities in New Zealand and Australia instead.

site_title: Chow Tai Fook Enterprises eyes US$4b Vietnam casino project
summary: Chow Tai Fook Enterprises, a Hong Kong company, plans to invest US$4 billion in a casino project in Vietnam's Quang Nam province, aiming to tap into the growing gaming demand from Chinese travelers. The project, developed by VinaCapital Group, is still in negotiations with a foreign partner. Chow Tai Fook, controlled by Hong Kong's fourth richest man, Cheng Yu-Tung, also has separate investments in gaming in Macau, and plans to expand its gaming business in South Korea and Australia.

site_title: Smartphone expansion cooling, prices dropping: survey
summary: The global smartphone market is expected to experience slower growth, with sales of 1.5 billion units in 2015, a 12.2% increase from the current year's estimate. Smartphone prices are projected to drop from $297 in 2014 to $241 by 2018, with emerging markets like India seeing lower prices. Revenues are forecast to grow just 4.2% over the same period, with Android devices dominating the market and Apple's iPhones representing 13% of units sold and 34% of revenues.

site_title: More eurozone firms move back home as offshore costs rise
summary: Italian companies are shifting production back home as offshore costs rise, with 44 firms relocating to the country. Clothing, footwear, and electronics firms are leading the "reshoring" trend. This decision does not reverse the "off-shoring" phenomenon, which has dominated global business for two decades. The move is driven by increased production costs in Asia, with Italian firms seeking to reduce expenses and maintain competitiveness.

site_title: China's November PMIs slip further, jobs under stress
summary: China's manufacturing sector weakened further in November, with the official PMI falling to an eight-month low of 50.8 and the private HSBC/Markit PMI shrinking to 50. The economy is heading for its slowest annual growth rate since the financial crisis, despite targeted measures to boost investment and spur credit to small and medium enterprises. The central bank's recent rate cut is seen as insufficient to cause a rebound, with economists expecting more rate cuts and reductions to the reserve requirement ratio to stimulate growth.

site_title: Swissco, Sheng Siong among CIMB's top picks
summary: CIMB has named Swissco Holdings and Sheng Siong as its top picks for 2015, citing their potential for growth despite the low oil price environment. Swissco, an offshore and marine counter, is expected to continue shallow-water production and maintenance activities, while Sheng Siong, a supermarket operator, is seen as resilient in the consumer space. CIMB has upgraded the offshore marine sector to "neutral" and the property sector to "overweight", but warned that small-cap profitability will be challenging due to weak external demand and rising costs.

site_title: New US plea to China for restraint in Hong Kong
summary: The US State Department issued a fresh appeal to China to exercise restraint in Hong Kong, amid concerns over the city's pro-democracy protests. The US expressed concern over British MPs being barred from visiting Hong Kong, and warned that any increase in aggression would be a concern. Hundreds clashed with police on Sunday, resulting in dozens of injuries. The US also expressed concern over China's refusal to grant visas to the British MPs. The US calls for peaceful dialogue and restraint from both Hong Kong authorities and protesters, as the city approaches fully free leadership elections in 2017.

site_title: US: Retail, tech stocks lead equities lower
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, with retail and tech equities leading the decline. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 0.29% to 17,776.80, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.68% and 1.34%, respectively. Retailers suffered after the National Retail Federation estimated a 6.4% decline in holiday spending, and tech stocks like Apple, Facebook, and Tesla dropped 3.3%, 3.4%, and 5.3%, respectively. Oil prices rebounded, but bond prices fell, with the yield on the 10-year US Treasury rising to 2.22%.

site_title: Post-Opec bloodletting continues for SGX oil stocks
summary: The share prices of oil supply chain firms in Singapore plummeted on Monday, amid fears of lower crude prices following the Opec meeting last week. West Texas Intermediate crude oil fell 11.4% to a five-year low of US$66.15. Energy-related counters dominated the list of most heavily traded stocks. The decline in oil prices has further weakened the already struggling SGX oil stocks.

site_title: Oil's wild ride continues as volatility rises
summary: The oil market is experiencing high volatility, with prices struggling to find a floor. Brent crude oil hit a new four-year low of $67.53 a barrel on Monday, but rebounded later in the day. Producers' announcements in the coming months and global growth are expected to drive prices further. Despite OPEC's decision to trim oil demand for the next four years, prices remain uncertain, with warnings of yet further downside.

site_title: Cheaper oil points to lower growth, higher fiscal deficits for Malaysia
summary: Malaysia is facing lower growth and higher fiscal deficits due to cheaper oil prices. Petronas, the national oil company, warned that lower oil prices will result in a 37% decrease in government payments next year, totaling RM43 billion. This is a significant blow to the government's revenue, larger than the savings from scrapping fuel subsidies. Lower oil prices also mean less money for the government, which derives almost a third of its revenue from Petronas.

site_title: Oil & gas stocks take a hammering
summary: Oil and gas stocks plummeted on Monday, dragging the Straits Times Index down 44.86 points, or 1.3%, to 3,305.64. The sector's weakness was attributed to prolonged low oil prices and the surprise decision by Opec countries not to cut production. The bank sector also took a hit, with some analysts downgrading the sector to "neutral" due to spillover pressure from the oil and gas sell-off.

site_title: Wanda in talks to buy Lions Gate, MGM stakes
summary: DALIAN Wanda Group Co, controlled by billionaire chairman Wang Jianlin, is in talks to acquire a stake in film studio Lions Gate Entertainment Corp, the maker of Hunger Games films, for $4.7 billion. Wanda is also exploring investments in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc (MGM) and plans to acquire large theatre networks in Europe to control 20% of the global cinema market by 2020. This move is part of Wang's ambition to build a global movie empire, driven by China's booming film industry.

site_title: 'Internet of Things' chipmakers to merge in US$4b deal
summary: Chipmakers Cypress Semiconductor and Spansion announce a $4 billion merger to form a new company, Cypress Semiconductor Corporation, with headquarters in San Jose, California. The deal brings together two key makers of Internet of Things components, combining their expertise in touchscreen devices and automotive and industrial control markets. Spansion shareholders will receive 2.457 Cypress shares for each share, resulting in a 50-50 ownership split. The new company will have an eight-person board of directors and is expected to create a combined entity in the memory and embedded processing markets.

images.alt_text: The all-stock deal brings together Cypress, which is known for chips controlling touchscreen devices, and Spansion, a major maker of chips for the automotive and industrial control market.

site_title: Uber struggles to woo Germans spoiled by Mercedes E-Class taxis
summary: Uber struggles to gain traction in Germany, where Mercedes-Benz luxury sedans dominate the taxi market. The Daimler AG brand accounts for 60% of German taxis, with the average age of 3.5 years, compared to Uber's older fleet of up to 10 years. Despite offering cheaper rides in fancier cars, Uber is failing to win over German customers who are accustomed to Mercedes E-Class taxis. The company's strategy to offer luxury rides at a lower price is not working in Germany, where the market is highly competitive and loyal to established brands.

site_title: BTO project for Bidadari next year
summary: Minister for National Development Khaw Boon Wan announced the launch of a BTO project in Bidadari next year, featuring over 2,200 units. The project aims to support strong family formation by allowing extended families to live near one another. Additionally, parents or married children living in Toa Payoh will receive priority for the Bidadari project under the Married Child Priority Scheme. This follows a successful BTO exercise in which 5,941 applicants applied for the enhanced scheme and 123 multi-generation families applied for 3Gen flats in Tampines.

site_title: European banks lift Samurai bond sales to record levels
summary: European banks have increased Samurai bond sales to a record level, driven by Japan's low borrowing costs. This year's yen debt sales rose 57% to 1.16 trillion yen, contributing to total Samurai offerings of 2.4 trillion yen. The European Central Bank is pressuring lenders to bolster their balance sheets, while Japanese investors seek yield after the Bank of Japan expanded its bond buying. The Samurai market offers a premium of 43 basis points over government bonds, attracting investors seeking yield. This trend is expected to continue as lenders diversify their funding sources.

site_title: Singapore to adopt stricter emission standard in 2017
summary: Singapore will adopt the Euro VI emission standard for petrol vehicles from September 1, 2017, allowing Japanese carmakers to comply more easily. The National Environment Agency (NEA) has accepted the JPN 2009 standard as an equivalent to Euro VI, giving distributors and parallel importers more time to meet the deadline. This policy aims to reduce nitrogen oxides and fine particulate emissions, particularly PM2.5, and improve ambient air quality. The new standard will apply to vehicles sold in Singapore, while European brands have already been required to meet Euro VI since January 2014.

site_title: Eurozone manufacturing growth in Nov stalls; new orders sink
summary: Eurozone manufacturing growth stalled in November, with new orders falling at the fastest pace in 19 months. Factory activity declined in Germany, France, and Italy, raising concerns for policymakers at the European Central Bank. The situation is "worse than previously thought," according to Chris Williamson, chief economist at Markit, suggesting a risk of renewed economic decline across the region.

site_title: Malaysia O&G counters slump amid US crude price plunge
summary: Malaysia's oil and gas (O&G) counters saw significant losses amid a five-year low in US crude oil prices. The benchmark Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.03% at the start of trading, but oil and gas companies suffered double-digit losses, with UMW Oil & Gas experiencing an 18% decline. The plunge was triggered by bleak short-term prospects of a US oil price recovery, affecting Malaysia's economy, which has relied heavily on the O&G sector since 2009.

images.alt_text: THE plunge in US crude oil prices to a five-year low amid bleak short-term prospects of a recovery precipitated a rout of oil & gas companies in Malaysia on Monday as investors fled the sector that has been a mainstay of the country's economy since 2009.

site_title: Farewell to a movie franchise - and the 'soul' of the series
summary: The film "Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb" marks the end of a successful comedy franchise, with the third installment set for release on December 19. The film features an ensemble cast, including Robin Williams, who tragically passed away in August, and is dedicated to his memory. Director Shawn Levy and star Ben Stiller paid tribute to Williams on set, and the film's marketing strategy has contributed to its international appeal, with the series having grossed over $1 billion in global ticket sales. The film's farewell theme has added an emotional layer to the story, with some scenes written to honor Williams before his death.

site_title: Platform for growth
summary: Singapore hosts OSEA 2014, Asia's largest oil and gas industry event, featuring over 1,500 exhibitors from 49 countries. Despite volatile oil markets, companies remain optimistic about opportunities in the sector. The event showcases a broad range of products and services, including floating storage & offloading vessels, rigs, and platforms. Conference highlights include discussions on the future of oil & gas exploration and supply, as well as workshops on drilling & well design and asset integrity management. Keynote speakers include representatives from major oil companies and industry leaders.

site_title: Bordeaux prices expected to fall some more, says wine broker
summary: Bordeaux wine prices are expected to continue their decline, with leading brands still feeling the effects of the 2010 and 2011 Chinese demand surge. The Liv-ex Fine Wine 50 Index has fallen for its 18th consecutive month, while the Liv-ex Fine Wine 100 Index has gained for three months. Experts attribute the decline to over-supply and uncertainty about the 2014 vintage's presentation to the trade. Demand is currently at the middle and base of the pyramid, rather than the collectible top end, with many buyers discouraged by past price surges.

site_title: Companies too complacent about whistleblowing: Freshfields
summary: A global study by Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer found that many companies, particularly in Singapore, are still not taking adequate measures to encourage whistleblowing, despite its growing acceptance as a corporate risk management policy. The study surveyed over 2,500 senior and middle managers worldwide, revealing that 24.1% of companies do not have a whistleblowing policy in place, while 8.6% say it is never mentioned in the workplace. As a result, 37% believe their senior management would treat them less favorably if they blew the whistle, and 4 in 10 say their organization discourages or actively discourages whistleblowing.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Japan's recession less serious than thought
summary: Japan's economy, which plunged into recession in the third quarter, appears to be less severe than initially thought, according to official data. Corporate capital spending rose 5.5% in the third quarter, higher than the 3% rise in the second quarter, suggesting an annualized GDP contraction of around 0.4%, rather than the initially estimated 1.6%. This data may boost Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's prospects ahead of the December 14 snap election.

images.alt_text: Real GDP is likely to be upgraded to an annualised real 0.4 per cent decline from a 1.6 per cent drop.

site_title: Saudi regulator suspends Deloitte from auditing listed firms
summary: Saudi Arabia's market regulator suspended the local unit of Deloitte & Touche from auditing listed firms starting June 1, 2015, due to a case involving Mohammad al-Mojil Group, a contractor with debt problems. The decision could impact Saudi companies and the auditing market, coinciding with the opening of the Saudi Arabian stock market to foreign investors. Deloitte expressed surprise and respect for the regulator's role, stating it will engage in a satisfactory resolution. The probe will examine MMG's activities following its initial share sale in 2008.

site_title: Yen at 7-year low after Moody's cut
summary: The yen fell to a 7-year low against the US dollar after Moody's cut Japan's sovereign rating to "A1" from "AA3" with a stable outlook. The US dollar rose to 119.15 yen, its highest since July 2007, before easing to 118.35 yen. The euro also eased against the US dollar as investors expect the European Central Bank to ease policy to combat deflation. The downgrade underlines Japan's fiscal problems, creating opportunities for dollar and yen traders.

site_title: Easing of India rule seen boosting gold demand
summary: India's easing of gold import curbs is expected to boost demand as prices have fallen and may drop further. The move aims to remove the monopoly held by bigger traders and allow smaller jewellers to supply more gold, benefiting consumers. Retailer Aster plans to implement this change, making gold more accessible to buyers ahead of the main wedding season.

site_title: HK Oct retail sales dip as protests hit core shopping areas
summary: Hong Kong's October retail sales dipped 1.4% to HK$38.3 billion, the first broad look at the impact of pro-democracy protests on core shopping areas. Sales of luxury items like jewellery and watches dropped 11.6% and 8.8%, respectively, while consumer durable goods sales surged 23.6% due to new smartphone demand. The protests have disrupted business and scared off tourists, leading to a slowdown in economic growth, with Financial Secretary John Tsang warning of a possible 2.2% growth rate below the government's estimate.

site_title: Strong demand for Asian corporates' USD bonds
summary: Asian investors are snapping up US dollar bonds from regional corporates in search of yields, despite warnings of growing liquidity and currency risks. Two recent bond sales, one by China-based CDB Leasing and another by Beijing Capital Land, were met with strong demand, with orders reaching over $1.75 billion and $3.5 billion, respectively. Experts caution that currency risks, particularly in South-east Asia, could offset gains from low US dollar yields, with significant risks to currencies against the USD in countries like Indonesia and Malaysia.

site_title: Japan dairy producers hit by weak yen at a time of high demand
summary: Japan's dairy producers face increased costs due to a weak yen, which makes it expensive to import US corn for their cows. Despite record-high dairy prices in Japan, domestic production is at its lowest in three decades, contributing to a global surplus.

site_title: Postal service should use barcodes for normal mail too
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the establishment of a Smart Nation office to leverage IT and high-tech systems for productivity improvement. Tan Kok Tim suggested that the postal service adopt barcodes for normal mail, similar to its existing use for registered mail, to automate mail sorting and improve labor-saving. The implementation of such an IT application would have substantial benefits, including ease of adaptation for other countries, and is essential for sectors to enhance productivity. The investment in this system would be worthwhile, given its potential to drive economic growth.

site_title: White House holiday decor goes high-tech
summary: The White House has incorporated high-tech elements into its holiday decor, marking a shift towards digital age traditions. The 2014 holiday tour features infrared motion sensors, crowdsourced lighting patterns, and robot versions of the first family's dogs. The administration has also released an interactive holiday card and 3-D-printed ornaments. The digital additions reflect the administration's emphasis on innovation, manufacturing, and the Maker movement, which the President and his aides have enthusiastically supported.

site_title: Panasonic, Toshiba to acquire stakes in Cloud Stringers
summary: Panasonic and Toshiba are acquiring stakes in Cloud Stringers, a Singapore-based cloud-based digital marketplace. Panasonic will invest S$400,000 for a 15.34% stake, while Toshiba will invest S$398,000 for a 15.26% stake. Trek Technology, the parent company of Cloud Stringers, will retain 65.57% ownership after the investments. The partnership aims to integrate Cloud Stringers with Panasonic's professional cameras and Toshiba's new generation FlashAir SD cards, allowing for real-time content upload and management.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: UK mortgage approvals at year-low in October
summary: UK mortgage approvals fell to 59,426 in October, the lowest since June 2013, due to new curbs on risky lending and warnings of a property bubble. Net lending on homes rose 1.5 billion, the least in 11 months. The effective interest rate on new mortgages fell to 3.18%, while business lending declined £1.9 billion and loans to small and medium-sized companies dropped 2.1% annually. The cooling housing market adds to signs the UK economy is battling headwinds from the euro-area, with the Bank of England keeping interest rates at a record-low 0.5%.

site_title: Businesses hold key (and cash) to X'mas Good Cheer
summary: Tokyo's banks and firms are resisting central bank efforts to boost lending and wage growth, mirroring Ebenezer Scrooge's miserly ways. Despite trillions of dollars in quantitative easing (QE) pumped into economies, global growth remains modest, with widening income disparities. Wages have been declining relative to GDP, and consumers are unable to consume due to lack of financial wherewithal. Central banks, like the Bank of Japan, are urging firms to raise wages and increase spending to stimulate economic growth, but firms are hoarding cash instead. To break the vicious circle of low growth and deflation, putting more money into pay packets is key to injecting liquidity into the real economy.

site_title: Manufacturing in Nov up more than expected
summary: US manufacturing expanded in November at a faster pace than expected, with the Institute for Supply Management's factory index reaching 58.7, the second-strongest level since 2011. This growth signals the US economy is rising above a global slowdown, despite its global competitors experiencing contractions. The US expansion is a positive sign for the country's economy, but trade uncertainty remains high due to new US tariffs.

site_title: Surbana clinches Myanmar project
summary: Surbana International Consultants has secured a master-planning project in Myanmar's Bago region, focusing on industrial investors. The 400-acre i-Land Industrial Park project is the fourth-largest town's new development. This follows two major contracts secured earlier in 2014, and Surbana has upgraded its Yangon office to a full-fledged subsidiary. The company has also awarded US$10,000 scholarships to five students from Yangon Technological University.

site_title: Expiring tax break may keep new Reits away
summary: Singapore's Reit market may see fewer new listings in 2015 if a tax break for income from assets held abroad lapses. The country remains the largest Reit market in Asia, with two trusts raising funds via IPOs this year through assets in Japan and Germany. This tax break is crucial for Reits, as it helps offset costs associated with holding assets abroad. Lapse of the tax break could impact listings next year, affecting the market's growth and development.

images.alt_text: Concor Park (Munich), one of the four office properties that make up IReit Global's initial portfolio. The number of new S-Reit (Singapore real estate investment trust) listings next year could be affected if a tax break for income from assets held abroad by these trusts is allowed to lapse in 2015.

site_title: India's November factory growth fastest in 2 years
summary: India's manufacturing sector expanded at its fastest pace in nearly two years in November, with the HSBC Manufacturing PMI rising to 53.3, its highest since February 2013. The sector's expansion was driven by strong domestic demand for consumer goods and robust foreign orders, leading to a surge in new orders and output. This marked the 13th consecutive month of expansion in activity, encouraging manufacturers to add more jobs.

site_title: Weight-loss salon aims to be an oasis in the CBD
summary: Kris by MENCE, a weight-loss salon in Singapore's central business district, has signed over 100 clients since its launch in June. The salon uses MENCE's patented "passive exercise" concept, which simulates a gym workout to burn calories and improve circulation. The treatment, which can take two hours, is designed to be a relaxing experience, with VIP rooms available. Founders aim to expand into Malaysia and Indonesia, but first focus on stabilizing operations in Singapore. The center emphasizes a balanced diet and encourages clients to maintain a healthy lifestyle.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Gestation crates for pigs: New Jersey governor refuses to give in
summary: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie has vetoed a bill that would have banned the use of gestation crates for breeding pigs, citing it as unnecessary and a matter for state agriculture officials. The Humane Society of the US and several celebrities, including Martha Stewart and Bill Maher, urged Christie to sign the bill, calling it inhumane. Nine US states and the European Union have already phased out the use of gestation crates, which are used to prevent pig fighting. Christie described the bill as a "political movement masquerading as substantive policy."

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts enters Japan, acquires two hotels
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts, a Singapore-based stapled group, has acquired two hotels in Japan, Hotel MyStays Asakusabashi and Hotel MyStays Kamata, for a total cost of 6 billion yen (S$66.3 million). The acquisition marks CDLHT's entry into the Japanese market. Both hotels operate in the business economy segment, with 138 and 116 rooms respectively. The acquisition is expected to expand CDLHT's portfolio and increase its presence in the Asian hospitality market.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Interactive 3-D map of Singapore to be ready by 2017
summary: Singapore is set to launch an interactive 3-D map called Virtual Singapore by 2017, costing S$73 million. The map will display aboveground structures such as buildings and trees, and will also be used to develop solutions and simulations to address urban problems like crowd control and noise levels. The Singapore Land Authority is modeling the map, with technical expertise provided by the Infocomm Development Authority.

images.alt_text: Aw Cheng Wei

site_title: Fair value gains give Goodland FY14 boost
summary: Goodland Group's full-year net profit rose 24% to S$21.1 million, driven by fair-value gains of S$12.9 million and S$8.2 million on investment properties and derivatives, respectively. Revenue dropped 32% to S$25.3 million. The company recommended a final dividend of half a Singapore cent per share. Despite a negative working capital of S$22.8 million, Goodland has negotiated an extension on loan repayment until 2016, citing no impact on its viability.

site_title: Ageing Europe may well have to bite the immigration bullet
summary: Europe is ageing rapidly, with a projected 82 million residents in Germany declining to 74.7 million by 2050, and an average age of nearly 50. To sustain living standards, the EU needs significant skilled worker immigration, despite growing public opposition from populist anti-immigration parties. Experts warn that closing the door to immigration will lead to economic consequences, while countries like Britain and France can expect healthy expansion. The demographic shift also poses challenges for pension and healthcare funding, with the ratio of over-65-year-olds to working-age individuals projected to jump to 49.4 in 2050.

site_title: Mixed picture emerges for Aussie city home prices in November
summary: Australian home prices showed a mixed picture in November, with a 0.3% dip in national figures, but sharp falls in Melbourne (2.6%) and gains in Sydney (1.0%). The annual pace of price growth slowed to 8.5% in November, down from a peak of 11.5% in April. Despite a cooling market, policymakers have generally tolerated rising prices to encourage home building, which is underway.

site_title: Singapore developers on overseas buying spree
summary: Singaporean developers are investing heavily in overseas commercial property, with US$9.8 billion invested in the nine months to September, surpassing China's US$8.4 billion. This surge is driven by the cooling measures in Singapore's housing market, which have led to falling property prices and squeezed margins for developers. Companies like City Developments and Keppel Land are investing in markets such as Tokyo, New York City, and London, seeking higher yields and returns. The trend is expected to continue as developers seek to diversify their portfolios and capitalize on recovering markets.

site_title: Top 3 mining firms still banking on China demand despite cloudy outlook
summary: Top mining firms BHP Billiton, Vale SA, and Rio Tinto Group are optimistic about China's demand for commodities, despite a cloudy economic outlook. Despite China's slowdown, the companies expect China to remain a significant driver of demand for iron ore, copper, and other metals until at least the mid-2020s. However, analysts like Tao Dong from Credit Suisse Group AG warn of a potential substantial drop in commodities demand as China shifts to a consumer-led economy.

site_title: US climate change negotiators express optimism
summary: US climate change negotiators are expressing optimism about forging a global pact to halt climate change, with a landmark US-China agreement providing momentum. The Lima talks aim to produce a draft document committing nations to domestic plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, with the goal of signing a deal in Paris in 2015. However, scientists warn that even a deal to stop current emissions may not prevent a 3.6-degree Fahrenheit temperature increase, which could lead to severe consequences. The deadline for the deal is 2020, and the structure of the emerging agreement may not allow for stringent enough initial cuts.

site_title: Luggage for a cause
summary: Five young artists from The Little Arts Academy in Singapore spent their afternoon colouring luggage cases with local child artist Gelyn Ong's original artwork, "The Flying Elphy." The bags will be auctioned off with proceeds going to The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. One thousand limited-edition bags are being sold at Takashimaya Singapore for $99 each, with 80% of the net proceeds supporting the Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund and the BTBAF. The initiative supports growing talents and promotes environmental awareness through Gelyn's WWF Young Ambassadorship.

site_title: Deutsche Annington seeks to buy Gagfah in 3.9b euro deal
summary: Deutsche Annington Immobilien SE has offered to buy Gagfah SA in a 3.9 billion euro deal, becoming Germany's largest residential landlord. The offer values Gagfah at 18 euros per share, a 16% premium over its previous close. The combined company would have about 350,000 units and a portfolio valued at 21 billion euros. Deutsche Annington's CEO Rolf Buch will lead the firm, with Gagfah's CEO Thomas Zinnoecker as deputy CEO. The deal aims to expand market share amid rising rents and low interest rates in Germany.

site_title: Echoes from the 1920s
summary: The 1920-21 US economic depression, often overlooked, shares similarities with the 2007-09 Great Recession in its recovery patterns. The economy rebounded strongly due to the price mechanism, with falling prices and wages encouraging consumer spending, investment, and hiring. Historian James Grant argues that modern economic policies, which attempt to prop up the economy, may impede recovery. He suggests that a laissez-faire approach could produce stronger recoveries, contrasting with the prolonged collapse of the Great Depression. This counterintuitive proposition challenges conventional wisdom and warrants consideration in understanding economic downturns.

site_title: Sales slide shows Black Friday hype may be over
summary: US sales on Black Friday dropped 11% to $50.9 billion, a decline from $57.4 billion last year, according to the National Retail Federation. Online sales also fell, with an average person spending $159.55, down 10.2% from last year. The number of shoppers also decreased, with 133.7 million people shopping over the four-day weekend, a 5.2% drop from last year. Industry executives attributed the drop to consumers still feeling the effects of the recession, while those with better job prospects may have delayed their shopping.

site_title: Giving a boost to oil sector
summary: The Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) has made significant investments to boost industry-relevant R&D capabilities and talent in the oil and gas sector. This move aims to support the sector's growth, which has been impacted by falling oil prices. The EDB has launched initiatives such as the Petroleum Engineering Professorship programme and the multiphase flowloop facility at the National University of Singapore. The sector's importance to Singapore's economy is highlighted, with over 20,000 locals employed in skilled jobs, and OSEA 2014 serving as a platform to promote technology adoption and foster stronger relationships between the industry and academia.

site_title: Global investors cut stocks amid uncertainty: poll
summary: Global investors cut their exposure to stocks in November, citing uncertainty over divergent monetary policies and multi-speed growth paths among major economies. The average recommended exposure to stocks in global balanced portfolios eased to 49.1% from 49.5% in October. Investors also increased their allocations to bonds to 36.8%, seeking safe-haven assets amid market volatility. US fund managers cut their recommended equity allocation for the sixth consecutive month, while European investors built up holdings of cash. The global economy's growth prospects remain uncertain, with many investors concerned about the impact of monetary policy changes.

site_title: Chief of underperforming Samsung Electronics mobile unit keeps his job
summary: Samsung Electronics' heir apparent has decided to retain JK Shin as the head of its underperforming mobile division, despite weak smartphone sales and the worst earnings in three years. This decision was made after speculation that Shin would be dropped due to the division's poor performance. The move is seen as a sign that Samsung will continue to support its mobile unit, led by Shin, who was appointed by the company's ailing father. Shin's job security has been a subject of concern among Samsung staff.

site_title: Protecting PMEs against whimsical dismissals
summary: Singapore's Employment Act has been amended to protect Professionals, Managers, Executives, and Technicians (PMEs) with monthly salaries up to S$4,500, making them as good as statutory employees. PMEs are now entitled to general Employment Act protection, including Part II rights regulating contract of service and Part III rights for payment of salary. They also have the right to challenge unfair dismissals within a month of termination, with the option to seek reinstatement or compensation through the Minister for Manpower.

site_title: Indonesia inflation in Nov up more than expected
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate rose to 6.23% in November, exceeding expectations, but economists say the central bank doesn't need to raise interest rates again soon. Fuel price hikes in November contributed to the increase, but inflation is expected to peak at around 7.8% in January. The central bank predicted annual inflation of 7.9% and Finance Minister sees 7.3%. Economists agree a rate hike is possible, but a temporary spike in inflation is expected to lead to a moderate tightening of monetary policy.

site_title: Six S'pore startups win Red Herring global 100 award
summary: Six Singapore startups, BioSenze Life Science, Fastacash, Gumbuya, iAPPS, Sova, and ViSenze, have won the Red Herring Global Top 100 award, recognizing their innovative technology and global appeal. Fastacash, a social payments company, and iAPPS, a mobile app developer, expressed excitement about the win, with Fastacash citing its expansion plans and iAPPS highlighting the US startup ecosystem's innovative spirit. The award follows the startups' selection as among the 18 Singapore winners of the 2014 Red Herring Asia Top 100 Award.

site_title: Nestle puts robot in place of George Clooney
summary: Nestle has replaced George Clooney as the face of its coffee machines in Japan, introducing a robot named Pepper. The 120-centimeter tall robot can understand up to 80% of conversations and will be sold in 1,000 stores across Japan for 198,000 yen (S$2,183) plus monthly fees. The robot's artificial intelligence was developed by SoftBank's Aldebaran technology and will help Nestle discover consumer needs through conversations with customers.

images.alt_text: Pepper introducing Nestle's coffee machines at an electric shop in Tokyo on Monday.

site_title: CosmoSteel forms alliance with Japanese steel trader Hanwa
summary: CosmoSteel Holdings has entered into a subscription agreement with Japanese steel trader Hanwa to raise S$15.3 million. The two companies have formed a strategic alliance to reinforce business prospects, with CosmoSteel providing piping system components to the energy and marine sectors.

site_title: Smaller UK banks seen merging to gain scale
summary: UK's smaller banks are merging to gain scale, as they struggle to compete with the four largest banks controlling 80% of the market. Challenger banks, such as Virgin Money and TSB, may need to merge to challenge the dominance of Royal Bank of Scotland, HSBC, Lloyds, and Barclays. Lawmakers are pushing for these banks to grow their market share of personal current accounts to measure competition. TSB, valued at US$2 billion, may consider buying smaller banks or merging with Co-Operative Bank to achieve scale economies.

site_title: Discrimination in US goes beyond one race
summary: The US's affirmative action programs, designed to help racial minorities, are being used by Ivy League schools to discriminate against Asian-Americans. A "bamboo ceiling" exists for Asian applicants, with qualified individuals being denied admission due to their race. Critics argue that Harvard and other universities have quotas for Asian students, despite defending their policies by citing "intangible" criteria. The issue has sparked lawsuits, including a recent case challenging the use of race in college admissions. The phenomenon highlights the paradox of affirmative action programs creating conditions for racial discrimination, affecting not only African-Americans but also Asian-Americans.

site_title: Asia currencies hit new lows on oil slide
summary: Asia's emerging currencies, including Malaysia's ringgit and South Korea's won, hit new lows on Monday due to plummeting oil prices, which have sent the US dollar higher. Oil prices fell to a five-year low, hurting growth in Malaysia, a net oil exporter and major palm oil producer. The ringgit fell to around five-year lows, while other regional currencies also underperformed. The economic impact of oil price decline is evident, with investors worried about the impact on regional economies.

site_title: Huationg Global launches Catalist IPO
summary: Huationg Global, a Singapore-based civil engineering provider, has launched an initial public offering (IPO) for a Catalist listing on the Singapore Exchange, offering 27.5 million placement shares at 20 cents each. The IPO closes on Friday and trading is expected to commence on December 9.

site_title: Inequality and the Internet
summary: The US has become increasingly unequal over the past 35 years, with the rich becoming significantly wealthier, while the poor remain poor. However, the rapid technological change of the Information Age has provided inexpensive access to human knowledge and entertainment, potentially underestimating inequality. Investing time in information goods and services can increase wellbeing, equivalent to an extra 0.6% rise in standards of living per year. Despite this, the benefits may be neutralized by the envy and spite resulting from living in an increasingly unequal world.

site_title: CDLHT to acquire two hotels in Japan for 6b yen
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) is acquiring two hotels in Japan for 6 billion yen. The hotels, Hotel MyStays Asakusabashi and Hotel MyStays Kamata, will be acquired from AKH GK. The acquisition is expected to be completed by December 19. CEO Vincent Yeo believes the deal will benefit from Tokyo's strong growth potential and the weaker Japanese yen, which will lure more tourists. The acquisition is part of CDLHT's expansion into Japan, driven by the country's growing hospitality market and the Tokyo 2020 Olympics.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Sputtering manufacturing leaves Asian economies in the cold
summary: Asian economies, particularly Indonesia, South Korea, and China, experienced dismal manufacturing data in November, with PMI readings falling to record lows. Indonesia's PMI plummeted to 48.0, while South Korea's reading below 50 signaled a contraction in the manufacturing sector. China's official and private PMI surveys also showed a decline, with the official reading at 50.3 and the private reading at 50.0. This suggests a softer end to 2014 and a slow start to 2015, with global demand and growth weakening, according to economists.

site_title: Emerging market stocks in biggest fall in 7 weeks
summary: Emerging market stocks experienced their largest drop in seven weeks, with the MSCI Emerging Markets Index declining 1.5% to 990.06, as oil prices fell and energy shares lost 3.4%. The ruble weakened to a record, and the ruble slid 4.2% to 52.6120 per dollar, while the ringgit slid 4.1% to a 1998 low. Energy shares, including CNOOC and Sasol, tumbled 5.7% and 8.7%, respectively, while airlines rallied on optimism over lower fuel costs.

site_title: ECB set to debate impact of cheaper oil on stimulus
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to debate the impact of cheaper oil on its stimulus package. The plunge in oil prices, driven by Opec's decision not to reduce supply, puts downward pressure on consumer prices and could deliver a mini-stimulus. However, ECB officials, including Mario Draghi and Peter Praet, argue that temporary price shocks can cause lasting harm to the euro area economy. The ECB may consider expanding its quantitative easing measures, including sovereign debt purchases, to boost the economy, with some economists predicting a potential announcement by March 5.

site_title: Directors of UK business did not quit due to jail threat: HSBC chairman
summary: HSBC chairman Douglas Flint stated that two directors, Alan Thomson and John Trueman, did not resign due to jail threats from new senior manager's regime rules. Thomson resigned due to increased work demands, while Trueman expressed concerns over potential liabilities. According to Flint, Thomson's resignation was mainly caused by his workload, not the new rules. Regulators have warned of strong lobbying by banks against the new rules, and HSBC chairman Flint advised bankers to speak up when regulators are "getting it wrong" clearly and accurately.

site_title: IBM signs multi-billion dollar 10-year IT deal with ABN Amro
summary: IBM has signed a 10-year, multi-billion dollar deal with Dutch bank ABN Amro to provide cloud-based computer infrastructure services. The deal includes managed services for mainframe computers, servers, storage, and end-user computing, as well as technical support. This move aims to help IBM gain momentum in the cloud computing market, following ABN Amro's announcement of investing in online banking services.

site_title: Glaxo planning reorganisation: sources
summary: GlaxoSmithKline is planning a workforce restructuring in the US, which will include hundreds of job cuts, as the company struggles to sell respiratory medicines in its largest market. The changes are expected to be announced this week, with President of North American operations Deirdre Connelly addressing US employees on Wednesday. The reorganisation is part of a broader effort by the London-based drugmaker to adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: Huationg Global launches Catalist IPO to raise S$5.5m
summary: Huationg Global, a Singapore-based civil engineering provider, has launched an initial public offering (IPO) for a Catalist listing on the Singapore Exchange. The IPO will raise approximately S$5.5 million, with the company using S$1.5 million for mergers and acquisitions, joint ventures, and strategic alliances. Established in 1983, Huationg Global has seen its net profits jump 24.7% to S$4.96 million and revenues increase 17.6% to S$108.5 million for the year ended 31 Dec 2013. Trading of shares is expected to commence on Dec 9.

site_title: Raffles Hospital to receive non-critical patients sent by SCDF (Amended)
summary: Raffles Hospital has set aside 50 beds for non-critical patients sent by the Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) starting mid-2015. Patients with acute medical conditions such as fractures or minor injuries will receive subsidized care if eligible, with rates similar to public hospitals. This collaboration aims to improve access to care for SCDF patients. Specialized care, such as burns or gynaecological problems, will not be sent to the hospital. The arrangement is part of a first-of-its-kind collaboration between a private hospital and the SCDF for ambulatory care.

site_title: Turkey assumes G20 presidency, pledges to fight inequality
summary: Turkey has taken over the G20 presidency, with Deputy Prime Minister Ali Babacan pledging to fight global inequality during its turn at the helm. The 2015 G20 leaders' summit will focus on economic growth, climate change, and global development. Turkey aims to bridge the gap between developed and undeveloped countries, with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan seeking to turn Turkey into one of the world's top 10 economies by 2023. The move is seen as an opportunity for Turkey to showcase its economic and political power under Erdogan's rule.

site_title: Japan govt tax income seen at 17-year high of US$435b in FY2014/15
summary: Japan's tax revenue is expected to reach 51.5 trillion yen (US$435 billion) in the current fiscal year, surpassing the initial estimate of 50 trillion yen. This is the highest tax income in the government's general-account budget since 1997/98. The increased income will be used to support small firms and households affected by a sales tax hike and higher import costs. The government plans to craft an economic package worth 2-3 trillion yen to address these issues.

site_title: MH17 wreckage to be reassembled in Netherlands for investigation
summary: The wreckage of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 will be reassembled in the Netherlands for investigation. Collected from eastern Ukraine, the Boeing 777 debris was stored for months due to conflict in the area. Investigators believe the plane was likely shot down by a ground-to-air missile, but are open to Moscow's theory of a shootdown from the air. Over two-thirds of the 298 passengers were Dutch, with Dutch authorities leading the investigation into the downing of the airliner. The wreckage will be transported to a military base in the Netherlands for reassembly.

images.alt_text: Wreckage of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 recovered from its crash site in eastern Ukraine will be reassembled for an investigation at a military base in the Netherlands, Dutch authorities said on Monday.

site_title: EU truck safety and efficiency law faces delay as industry resists change
summary: The European Union is delaying a truck safety and efficiency law, which would have allowed trucks to have longer, more aerodynamic noses, due to industry resistance. The law, proposed by the European Commission, aims to improve safety, reduce emissions and fuel bills. However, truckmakers such as Volvo and Renault oppose the law, citing the long life cycle of trucks and the need for more time to develop new vehicles. A compromise position has been established, making the new cab designs voluntary and delaying full implementation to 2024.

site_title: French business owners protest taxes, red tape
summary: French business owners gathered in Paris to protest high taxes, charges, and regulations that they claim are suffocating their businesses. The rally, led by the CGPME, aimed to demonstrate frustration with decades of government policies. The protesters carried padlocks and banners, including "Taxes, levies, charges: enough is enough." The move follows stagnant growth, high unemployment, and EU demands to reduce France's budget deficit, with President Francois Hollande's re-election pledge hanging in the balance.

site_title: Oil hits five-year low in longest losing streak since 2008
summary: Brent crude oil fell to a five-year low below $68, its longest losing streak since 2008, after Opec's decision not to cut production last week. Oil prices have lost over 12% since the decision and more than 40% since June, impacting oil producers worldwide. Analysts expect prices to stabilize at around $65-80 a barrel in the short term, with China's slower-than-expected manufacturing growth and US Fed monetary stimulus phase-out adding downward pressure on oil markets.

site_title: Amazon rolls out Kiva robots for holiday season onslaught
summary: Amazon has installed over 15,000 Kiva robots across 10 US warehouses to boost holiday season efficiency, aiming to cut costs by one-fifth and speed up package delivery. The robots, acquired for $775 million in 2012, help streamline inventory management and reduce shipping times. With the robots, Amazon can hold 50% more items and offer same-day delivery in several areas, with some locations achieving delivery times of just 13 minutes. The move is part of Amazon's efforts to compete with brick-and-mortar stores and avoid last year's holiday season delays.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares tumble on worst trading day since February
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark share indexes plummeted 2.6% and 2.9% respectively on Monday, marking their worst single-day losses since February. Weak manufacturing surveys and unbalanced investment flows between Hong Kong and Shanghai contributed to the decline. The Hang Seng index fell to 23,367.45 points, while the China Enterprises Index dropped to 10,818.20 points.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals fall to lowest in more than a year: BoE
summary: The Bank of England reported that UK mortgage approvals fell to the lowest level in over a year in October, with 59,426 approvals, but consumer lending rose at its fastest annual rate since 2006. Despite this, household spending and private-sector surveys showed strong appetite for big purchases. The UK economy is experiencing some of its fastest growth in a decade, but Prime Minister David Cameron has warned of global dangers ahead.
