Mortgage lender Nationwide noted that house prices increased at the slowest rate since June 2013.

site_title: Europe needs a single energy market, not a buyers' cartel: IEA
summary: The European Union needs to avoid creating a buyers' cartel in its single energy market, the International Energy Agency (IEA) said. The EU should pool its resources to enhance energy security and competitiveness, but not restrict supply to certain countries. The EU relies on Russian gas, which supplies around a third of its energy, and needs to improve its supply security and integrate domestic renewable energy. The IEA also recommends rapid reform of the Emissions Trading System and greater energy savings to drive investment in lower-carbon energy.

images.alt_text: The European Union must not create a buyers' cartel in its bid to build a single energy market and curb reliance on Russian gas, the International Energy Agency (IEA) said on Monday.

site_title: Chairman of Harilela group dies
summary: Chairman of the Hong Kong-based Harilela Group, Hari Harilela, died at 92. He was the chairman for 67 years, overseeing 19 hotels worldwide, including the Holiday Inn in Singapore. Harilela was a significant patron of the arts in Singapore, donating $500,000 to the Indian Heritage Centre, and was known for his generosity, including giving $250,000 to various charities on his 65th wedding anniversary. His only son, Aron, now heads the company.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on soft global data
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Monday, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 44.31 points, or 0.25%, to 17,783.93. The S&P 500 lost 5.4 points, or 0.26%, to 2,062.16, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 14.15 points, or 0.3%, to 4,777.48. Soft global data, including eased manufacturing growth in Asia and Europe, contributed to the decline.

site_title: Vineyards: rich Chinese's new love
summary: China's ultra-high net worth individuals are increasingly investing in vineyard ownership, with 45% expressing interest, according to a Knight Frank survey. Chinese investors are the largest foreign buyers in the Barossa Valley, Bordeaux, and Napa Valley. China's wine consumption has risen 57% since 2000, and the country is now the second-largest wine importer in the world. Buyers face challenges in pinpointing the best locations, requiring local knowledge and research. This trend is part of a broader shift in Asian buyers, including Vietnamese, South Koreans, and Hong Kong residents.

site_title: German population drop spells skills shortage in Europe's powerhouse
summary: Germany's population is expected to shrink by 6.3 million by 2030, leading to a skills shortage and a blow to the country's economy. The working-age population is dwindling, and unemployment is at a record low, making it difficult for companies to find and retain skilled workers. Policymakers warn of a looming shortage costing €22 billion annually, with a particular deficit in math, computing, science, and technology skills. Companies are finding innovative solutions, such as hiring older workers and people with autism, but heavy immigration is needed to offset the burden, with annual net immigration required to be at least 300,000 until 2050.

site_title: Justice on two wheels in the heart of London
summary: A 49-year-old British cyclist, known as the "Traffic Droid", is patrolling London streets with a helmet-mounted camera to record reckless drivers. He hands over the footage to police, who use it to issue fines. This is part of a growing trend of cyclists taking matters into their own hands, with dozens of British cyclists documenting and reporting traffic offenses in their communities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 42.62 points to close at 1,778.27, with 2.76 billion lots valued at RM2.96 billion traded. The market saw 82 gains and 981 losses.

site_title: Thailand may raise VAT next year, have bigger budget deficit: finance minister
summary: Thailand's finance minister, Sommai Phasee, announced plans to raise the valued-added tax by at least one percentage point to 8% in the 2015/16 fiscal year. The government expects to spend around 2.88 trillion baht (US$87.5 billion) and will need a bigger budget deficit of at least 300 billion baht to cover these costs.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end lower
summary: Singapore shares ended 1.34% lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index slipping 44.86 points to 3,305.64. 1.72 billion shares were traded, with 84 gains and 400 losses.

site_title: China central bank says to maintain steady credit growth
summary: China's central bank announced it will maintain steady credit growth through various monetary tools, while continuing to implement prudent monetary policy and pushing ahead with interest rate and yuan exchange rate reforms. The bank stated that China's economic growth remained within a reasonable range. This move aims to ensure liquidity and reasonable growth in credit and social financing.

site_title: First BTO project to be launched next year in Bidadari
summary: Minister Khaw Boon Wan announced the launch of Singapore's first BTO project in Bidadari next year, offering over 2,200 units. The project prioritizes extended families, particularly those with parents or married children already living in Tampines. The initiative aims to support strong family formation and follows the success of the Married Child Priority Scheme, which saw a positive response from 1 in 3 family applicants and oversubscribed supply at Tampines North. The project is part of the Ministry of National Development's efforts to encourage extended families to live close to each other.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Things you should watch out for
summary: A global economic storm is predicted for 2015, with a 75% chance of occurrence due to persistent global imbalances. Key events that could trigger the storm include China's aggressive liberalization, military flashpoints escalating, and oil prices falling. The US economy is expected to continue recovering, but its oil demand will be steady. The article suggests that a "Black Swan" scenario, such as a significant economic downturn, could manifest if these events occur together.

site_title: UK manufacturing grows slightly faster in Nov despite lacklustre exports: PMI
summary: British manufacturing activity unexpectedly increased in November, with the PMI rising to 53.5 from 53.3 in October, marking its highest level in four months. Domestic demand offset falling exports, which were impacted by sluggish orders from the eurozone and emerging markets. Employment in the sector reached a four-month high, and inflation pressures remained subdued. The survey suggests the UK's economic recovery at the end of 2014 is unlikely to be sharp, providing a boost to finance minister George Osborne ahead of his half-yearly economic update.

site_title: Wee Hur trades flatly after acquisition of Brisbane plot for A$51 million
summary: Wee Hur Holdings acquired a plot of land in Brisbane, Australia for A$51.29 million (S$55.16 million). The 16,946 sq m land will be developed into a high-rise mixed development with residential, retail, office, and communal components. Construction is expected to start in the third quarter of 2015. The acquisition marks Wee Hur's first foray into property development in Australia, in line with its strategy to venture overseas.

site_title: Modi to pressure lawmakers on insurance
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is using an executive order to push through two key economic policy changes: allowing more foreign investment in the insurance sector and making coal mining more transparent. The ordinances, valid for six months, aim to increase foreign investment and boost the nation's insurance penetration, which is below the global average. The moves are seen as a bid to bolster India's economy, particularly to fund infrastructure upgrades. Modi's government faces opposition from the Congress Party, which has blocked the bills in the Upper House.

site_title: South Korea launches yuan/won trading
summary: South Korea launched direct trading between the Chinese yuan and won currencies on December 1, 2014. The move was aimed at increasing the use of the yuan in international trade, with China seeking to boost its currency's global presence and South Korea hoping to become a hub for yuan-related business. The trading session saw 5.395 billion yuan (US$877.29 million) in transactions, exceeding initial expectations. The yuan started trading at 180.30 won and finished at 180.77 won, with South Korea's finance ministry officials noting that the market needed to establish a firm footing before seeing significant growth.

site_title: The Interview to play on 200 US screens
summary: Sony Pictures will allow "The Interview" to play in over 200 US cinemas on Christmas Day, reversing its decision to pull the film after facing criticism from President Barack Obama and others for caving to North Korea's cyber threats. The film, starring Seth Rogen and James Franco, was initially pulled due to fears of a potential attack, but the studio has now secured a limited theatrical release. The White House praised the decision, with Eric Schultz stating that it allows people to make their own choices about the film.

site_title: Dalian Wanda buys control of China online payments firm
summary: Dalian Wanda Group Co, China's largest commercial property developer, has acquired a controlling stake in 99Bill Corp, a third-party payment processor similar to PayPal, in a deal worth over 2 billion yuan. This marks Dalian Wanda's first acquisition in the Internet finance sector, as the company seeks to diversify into e-commerce and maintain profitability. The move places property billionaire Wang Jianlin into direct competition with Alibaba Group's Alipay unit, which controls 80% of China's mobile payment market.

site_title: Oil prices continue to fall from five-year low
summary: Oil prices fell for a fourth day, extending losses from a five-year low, amid speculation that US crude inventories will stay at the highest level since June, contributing to a global glut. US production is at its highest in more than three decades, and hedge funds pared bullish bets on Brent crude. Oil futures dropped as much as 1.2% in New York, with stockpiles projected to remain at 387.2 million barrels. This move accelerated the market's collapse, driven by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries' decision to maintain output quotas.

site_title: North Korea's Internet down again: US experts
summary: North Korea's internet connections have been cut for the second consecutive day, according to US internet research group Dyn Research. The outage is believed to resemble a "denial of service" attack, potentially linked to a US cyber attack. The US has accused North Korea of being behind the hacking of Sony Pictures, and President Obama has promised a "proportionate response". The cause of the outages remains unclear, but experts speculate that China Unicom's networks may be the source of the issue.

site_title: SMBC to buy Citi Japan retail business in October: sources
summary: SMBC to acquire Citi Japan's retail banking operations in October for approximately 40 billion yen (US$332 million). The sale is attributed to Citi's Japan consumer banking business struggling with weak loan demand and falling interest margins. The acquisition will be announced on Thursday by SMBC, a unit of Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group Inc.

site_title: Taiwan launches its largest ever missile ship
summary: Taiwan has launched its largest ever missile ship, the 500-tonne corvette 'Tuo Chiang', in response to perceived threats from China. The ship, armed with 16 missiles, boasts stealth technology and a maximum speed of 38 knots per hour, making it difficult to intercept. Taiwan aims to modernize its armed forces to protect its defense capabilities and shipping lanes in the Taiwan Strait. The launch comes after the US Congress authorized the transfer of four Perry-class guided missile frigates to Taipei, which China has opposed.

site_title: Philippines' BOP swings back to a deficit in November
summary: The Philippines' balance of payments (BOP) swung back to a deficit in November, reaching US$3.72 billion for the 11 months. The central bank expects a year-end deficit of US$3.4 billion, with foreign investors shifting funds overseas. The forecast for this year's current account surplus was raised to US$6.6 billion, up from US$6 billion. The central bank lowered its foreign reserve estimate to US$79 billion from US$85.3 billion, and expects a 5% increase in cash remittances from overseas Filipinos this year.

site_title: BOJ chief says plenty of tools left to ease policy again: paper
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the bank has various tools to ease monetary policy again if needed to meet its 2% inflation target in the next fiscal year. He ruled out watering down the bank's commitment to hit the target, saying it would make achieving the goal impossible. The BOJ has various tools to adjust monetary policy, and Kuroda expressed confidence that Japan will see 2% inflation in 2015, despite recent slowing consumer inflation. Economists polled by Reuters believe the BOJ may fall short of its goal.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said the bank has various tools left if it were to ease monetary policy again, stressing its determination to hit its inflation target in the next fiscal year.

site_title: SBI Offshore bags procurement contract for semi-submersible rig to be built in China
summary: SBI Offshore has secured a procurement contract for a semi-submersible offshore rig to be built in China. The rig, set to be deployed in the North Sea at a depth of up to 3,600 meters, will be the largest of its kind built in China. Work on the rig is expected to begin in 2015 and be completed in 42 months. SBI will serve as the lead contractor, and the selected Chinese shipyard will enter into an engineering, procurement, and commissioning agreement with SBI. The contract's financial impact is not quantifiable, but SBI expects initial revenue in 2015 and project revenues over FY2016-2018.

site_title: Xiaomi raising over US$1b from investors including GIC: source
summary: Xiaomi is raising over $1 billion from investors including Singapore's GIC, valuing the company at over $45 billion. The funding round is led by tech fund All-Stars Investment and includes Russian tech fund DST Global and Alibaba Group's Yunfeng Capital. Xiaomi is using the funds to build an ecosystem of Internet-connected devices and appliances beyond smartphones. The company has invested in 43 companies across China's mobile Internet ecosystem, including smart device makers and network infrastructure firms.

site_title: Maersk CEO says low oil price may lead to closures: paper
summary: Maersk Oil's CEO, Nils Smedegaard Andersen, warns that the current low oil price may lead to site closures and cost cuts. If the oil price remains around $60 per barrel, it would reduce revenue by a third from 2013 levels. To mitigate this, Andersen plans to focus on reducing operational and exploration costs, primarily exploring for new oil in low-cost areas.

site_title: Share buybacks down last week at S$65m
summary: Share buybacks slowed down to S$65 million for the week of Dec 15-19, down from S$91 million the previous week, according to the Singapore Exchange. Keppel Corp, OCBC Bank, ST Engineering, Genting Singapore, and SATS were among companies that bought back shares, with ST Engineering purchasing 1.8 million shares for the first time since 1999. Pacific Century Regional Developments and Viking Offshore and Marine also ramped up their share buyback programs.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Malaysia extends crude palm oil export tax exemption to end-February 2015 to boost exports and reduce inventories, maintaining a neutral view on the sector. The move is unlikely to improve competitiveness against Indonesia, which is also expected to exempt CPO export taxes. CIMB Research maintains its Neutral rating and prefers stocks like First Resources, Astra Agro, and SIMP.

site_title: Canon inks 3-year sponsorship agreement with Singapore Sports Hub
summary: Canon Singapore has signed a three-year sponsorship agreement with the Singapore Sports Hub, becoming the official printing & imaging partner and founding partner. The company will receive branding, hospitality, and signage rights, and offer print and document management services. Canon celebrates its 35th year in Singapore, with CEO Kensaku Konishi stating that sports bring harmony and commitment to supporting local sports.

site_title: Political ground shifting in Taiwan against KMT
summary: Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has gained significant ground in local elections, potentially shifting the country's political landscape and paving the way for Tsai Ing-wen, the DPP's leader, to run for president in 2016. The DPP's victory marked a rejection of the Nationalist Party's (KMT) cross-strait policy, led by President Ma Ying-jeou, which has been a cornerstone of Taiwan's relations with China. Beijing has issued a cautionary note, but the outcome suggests a new era may be emerging in Taiwan, with implications for cross-strait relations.

site_title: BRICs' diverging outlooks spur stock split
summary: The BRIC grouping of Brazil, Russia, India, and China has experienced a significant divergence in their stock market performances in 2014. Chinese and Indian equity indices surged an average 40% year-over-year, while Russian and Brazilian gauges declined by 4.2%. This divergence is the largest since the term "BRIC" was coined in 2001, with Chinese and Indian stocks now accounting for a combined market capitalization of $5.2 trillion, surpassing Russia and Brazil's $1.2 trillion. The disparity is attributed to various factors, including economic slowdowns, sanctions, and corruption scandals in Russia and Brazil, as well as reforms and growth in China and India.

images.alt_text: WEAKENING LINK: More than 13 years after the BRIC moniker entered usage to characterise Brazil, Russia, India and China as a single economic concept, the connection is breaking down.

site_title: US casual-dining restaurants simplify menus to focus on strengths
summary: US casual-dining restaurants are simplifying their menus to focus on their strengths, aiming to win back customers from fast-casual eateries. Chains like Red Lobster, Chili's, and Olive Garden have removed non-essential items to speed up service and increase sales. Menu simplification is expected to continue, with sales projected to rise 1.9% in October and 3.4% in 2015. The improving labor market and lower petrol prices also contribute to the industry's growth.

site_title: A force for good
summary: Deloitte's global chairman Steve Almond advocates for measuring social progress comprehensively and rigorously to address economic and social ills. He believes the Social Progress Index, created by Harvard Business School's Michael E Porter, provides a better way to assess social progress by incorporating various indicators beyond traditional economic measures. Almond also supports the Integrated Reporting Framework, which aims to provide clearer reporting on companies' interactions with the external environment. He emphasizes the need for businesses to take ownership of social issues and for regulators to strike a balance between ensuring financial stability and promoting economic growth.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: More discounts at US retail Christmas sales
summary: US retailers are offering deep discounts for the holiday season, but the range of stock on offer has shrunk, according to analysts. This year, retailers vowed not to repeat their mistakes from last year, when they slashed prices to clear inventory. However, some analysts believe retailers may be pricing up initial prices to compensate for discounts, and consumers may struggle to find what's on their wish lists. Despite this, consumer sentiment has risen, and online shopping remains a significant competitor.

site_title: Currency troubles could undermine support for Putin
summary: Russia's currency, the rouble, hit record lows after a 6.5 percentage point interest rate rise to 17 percent, threatening President Vladimir Putin's financial stability and grip on power. The crisis comes amid low oil prices, looming recession, and Western sanctions over Ukraine. US Secretary of State John Kerry said sanctions could be lifted if Putin takes steps to ease tensions, while President Barack Obama is expected to sign legislation authorizing new sanctions. The currency crisis increases the risk of losing financial stability and prosperity, two key pillars of Putin's support, and brings an unwelcome policy headache at a time of strained relations with the West.

site_title: Singapore banks' exposure to oil firms manageable: report (Amended)
summary: Singapore banks' exposure to major oil-and-gas firms is manageable, according to a Maybank-Kim Eng Research report. Senior analyst Ng Wee Siang found that Singapore banks are exposed to several oil-and-gas companies, including Cosco Corporation and Swiber Holdings, but these exposures are not overly significant due to the companies' strong financial backing and limited gearing. The report maintains an "overweight" rating on the banking sector, suggesting that investors should not be overly pessimistic about the sector's prospects.

site_title: Failure is not an option, it's a must
summary: Author Nassim Taleb argues that over-education is detrimental to entrepreneurship in Singapore, where education is highly valued. He believes that too much emphasis on education leads to a reliance on school success, stifling the development of "street smarts" and risk-taking. Instead, Taleb advocates for a more balanced approach, prioritizing apprenticeship and experiential learning to foster a culture of antifragility, where failure and competition drive innovation. He also suggests that Singapore's focus on education may be hindering its ability to produce entrepreneurs and drive economic growth, citing examples such as Taiwan's rapid economic development despite lower literacy rates.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 0.39%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened down 0.39% on Wednesday, following a stronger yen that eroded income for Japanese exporters. The yen gained against the dollar and euro amid Russia's ruble crisis and investors' flight to safer assets. The Nikkei 225 index fell 65.98 points to 16,689.34. Investors also awaited the outcome of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting, which is expected to adjust its forecasting language on interest-rate hike plans.

site_title: Australia to take budget steps to absorb export shock: Treasurer
summary: Australia's Treasurer Joe Hockey announced budget measures to cushion the economy's decline, citing a 50% drop in iron ore prices and a forecast decline in terms of trade of 2.5% this year. The government will unveil large cuts to services and spending, including job losses, to absorb the shock. Economic growth is forecast to remain at 2.5% and rise to 3% over the next few years, while unemployment is expected to rise to levels "a tick higher" than forecast. The budget deficit is expected to blow out to nearly A$35 billion.

site_title: India central bank eases refinancing rules for infrastructure loans
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India, has eased refinancing rules for infrastructure loans, allowing for easier refinancing and flexible restructuring. The eased regulations apply to loans exceeding 5 billion rupees (US$79.40 million) per project, aimed at helping the government revive stalled infrastructure projects to boost the economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 1.30% higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.30% at the start of trade on Thursday, following a surge on Wall Street. The benchmark Hang Seng Index increased 292.50 points to 22,878.34. The move came after the US Federal Reserve dampened speculation of an interest rate hike at the start of next year.

site_title: US pet supplies retailer in largest PE deal of the year
summary: PetSmart agreed to a $8.7 billion buyout from a group led by BC Partners, the largest private equity deal of 2014. The US pet supplies retailer, with over 1,300 stores, will be financed primarily by borrowed money, despite having relatively strong cash flow and low debt. The deal follows pressure from activist investors Jana Partners and Longview Asset Management, and is expected to close in the first half of 2015.

images.alt_text: PetSmart has long been seen as a good target for private equity firms, given its relatively strong cash flow and low debt. It has over 1,300 stores in the US, Canada and Puerto Rico.

site_title: Firm bets on biometric scanning on mobile phones for IPO windfall
summary: Hector Hoyos' startup, Hoyos Labs, is planning an initial public offering (IPO) next year, betting on biometric scanning on mobile phones to replace passwords on websites and ATMs. The company has already released its consumer app, 1U, and is in trials with nine financial institutions worldwide. Biometric authentication is expected to become widespread, with 5.5 billion people using it by 2019, and is seen as a convenient and secure way to identify users on mobile devices. Hoyos Labs charges banks between 12 cents and 25 cents a customer per month for its technology, which uses an existing wireless company network to establish a secure communication between the phone and the bank.

images.alt_text: The scan of an eye is displayed on a computer screen during a demonstration at Hoyos Corp in New York and Mr Hoyos thinks the company will be valued at US$5 billion to US$10 billion if it goes public next year.

The scan of an eye is displayed on a computer screen during a demonstration at Hoyos Corp in New York and Mr Hoyos (above) thinks the company will be valued at US$5 billion to US$10 billion if it goes public next year.

site_title: Senate passes spending bill, avoiding govt shutdown
summary: The US Senate passed a $1.1 trillion spending bill, avoiding a government shutdown, with a 56-40 vote. The bill, sent to President Barack Obama, funds most government agencies through September 2015. The Department of Homeland Security received a shorter funding extension, allowing Republicans to potentially deny funds for implementing Obama's immigration order easing deportations. The bill marks a rare bipartisan effort amidst a two-year legislative session marked by partisanship and few major accomplishments.

site_title: Price caps imposed on 52 more essential drugs in India
summary: India's National Pharmaceutical Pricing Authority (NPPA) has extended price caps on 52 more essential drugs, including painkillers and antibiotics, bringing the total market size under price control to about $20 million. The move aims to improve affordability of medicines in the country, where most people live on less than $2 a day and health insurance is scarce. The price caps have been opposed by the pharmaceutical industry, which claims prices in India are already among the lowest in the world.

site_title: Debate shifts to how fast the Fed should move after first rate hike
summary: The Federal Reserve is shifting its focus from raising interest rates to determining how fast to move after the first rate hike, as stagnant US inflation becomes less of a concern with improving labor markets. The central bankers must navigate global growth and nervous markets to return to pre-crisis policies.

site_title: Google tries to undo US court ruling over YouTube trailer
summary: Google is trying to overturn a US court ruling that granted actress Cindy Lee Garcia a copyright interest in a YouTube trailer for the film "Innocence of Muslims", a film that sparked global controversy and riots. Garcia claimed she received death threats over her performance in the film, which was edited to include a fictional attack on a Christian family. The court's 2-1 ruling allowed Garcia to seek removal of the trailer from YouTube, which Google says would lead to "Swiss cheese" of US copyright law and open the floodgates to meritless copyright litigation. A hearing to reconsider the ruling is scheduled for Monday.

images.alt_text: Google is trying to undo a February ruling by a three-judge panel of the US Court of Appeals that concluded Ms Garcia's intellectual property interest in Innocence of Muslims gave her the right to seek removal of a 14-minute trailer for the film posted on Google's YouTube.

site_title: Sydney siege man demands IS flag, says 4 bombs in city: report
summary: A man is holding hostages in a Sydney cafe, demanding a flag of the Islamic State group be delivered to him and warning of four bombs planted around the city. The man, who has made demands for the flag and to speak to the Prime Minister, has also claimed that two of the hostages have escaped. Police are surrounding the cafe, a major square in the heart of Sydney, and have confirmed that five people have fled the scene. The Australian government has raised its terror threat level in response to concerns about citizens returning home radicalized.

site_title: Spain rebuilding again after housing crash of 2008
summary: Spain is rebuilding its construction sector after a seven-year downturn, with investment in house-building registering its first quarterly rise since 2008. The country is seeing a surge in new residential projects, particularly in Madrid and Barcelona, with developers focusing on high-end developments and obtaining financing through mortgages for buyers. However, construction accounts for only 5% of Spain's output, resulting in a 50 billion euro annual shortfall, and is unlikely to return to pre-crisis levels.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close down on China, global jitters
summary: Hong Kong shares closed down 0.9% on Thursday, weighed by weakness in China and overseas markets. Mainland China markets struggled due to concerns over speculation, while sliding oil prices affected energy producers and boosted fuel-sensitive stocks. The Hang Seng index fell to 23,312.54 points, and Chinese investment flowed into Hong Kong through the mutual market access pilot programme, taking up 0.48 billion yuan of the daily quota.

site_title: Korean Air CEO apologises for daughter's 'foolish act'
summary: Korean Air CEO Cho Yang-Ho publicly apologized for his daughter Cho Hyun-Ah's behavior on a flight, where she kicked the head of cabin crew off the plane due to unserved macadamia nuts. The incident sparked public anger and ridicule, prompting a state probe into a possible breach of aviation safety laws. Cho Hyun-Ah has been relieved of her official posts, including vice president of Korean Air, and will face questioning by Transport Ministry officials. The CEO acknowledged his daughter's "foolish act" and shared some blame for not bringing her up correctly.

site_title: Banks reassessing credit lines to some US energy firms
summary: US energy firms may face a cash crunch due to plummeting crude prices, which have fallen 40% since June. Banks are reassessing credit lines, potentially reducing the amount of credit available to highly leveraged companies, and may cut reserve valuations to around $60 per barrel, down from $77 per barrel. This could lead to a cash crunch for smaller oil companies with heavy debt and used-up credit lines, who may struggle to refinance debt or access new financing sources.

site_title: Singapore economists lower growth forecasts to 3% for 2014, 3.1% for 2015: MAS survey
summary: Singapore economists have lowered their growth forecasts for 2014 and 2015. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) quarterly poll of professional forecasters now expects 3% growth for 2014 and 3.1% for 2015. Inflation expectations have also been adjusted lower, with forecasters expecting 1.1% headline inflation for 2014 and 1.9% core inflation for 2015. The cuts in forecasts are attributed to a slowdown in the manufacturing and construction sectors, but the finance and insurance sector is expected to grow 7.3%.

images.alt_text: Singapore's economy watchers have tempered their expectations for GDP growth in 2014 from a quarter ago and are not expecting much improvement next year. Their inflation expectations too, have been adjusted lower.

site_title: iPod Nano user to represent US consumers in suit against Apple
summary: A 65-year-old amateur skater, Barbara Ragan Bennett, has been selected as the new lead plaintiff in a US$1 billion class-action lawsuit against Apple Inc. The lawsuit alleges that Apple maintained a monopoly on digital music from 2006 to 2009 by making it difficult for users to play music from rival providers on iPods. Bennett claims that buying her iPod Nano in 2006 made it hard for her to access "rare music" and that the changes were designed to lock users into iTunes. The case will decide whether Apple violated antitrust laws.

site_title: US services data point to upward revision to third-quarter GDP
summary: The US economy is likely to have grown at a stronger pace in the third quarter than initially reported, according to data from the Commerce Department's quarterly services survey. Services outlays increased more vigorously than expected, suggesting a possible revision to the third-quarter GDP growth rate from 3.9% to 4.4%. This upward revision could imply stronger momentum for services consumption in the fourth quarter, but is not expected to significantly impact fourth-quarter GDP growth forecasts.

site_title: Thai rubber farmers defy martial law with protest over low prices
summary: A small group of 50 rubber farmers in Thailand's Surat Thani province defied martial law to protest low rubber prices, handing in a petition to the governor. The farmers demand government intervention to support prices, citing a global supply glut and weak demand from top importer China, which has pushed prices down to five-year lows. The government has promised measures to push prices up to 60 baht per kg and direct handouts to farmers, but the farmers are threatening to escalate the protest if their demands are not met by the new year.

site_title: DBS cuts S'pore 2015 GDP growth forecast to 3.2%
summary: DBS has lowered its 2015 GDP growth forecast for Singapore to 3.2% from 3.6%, citing volatile global monetary policies and potential divergent growth rates in Asia. This is below the median forecast of 24 private-sector economists polled by Bloomberg, which stands at 3.35%. The bank's economist Irvin Seah warns that Singapore's small and open economy will be vulnerable to global economic fluctuations, with lower oil prices being the only potential upside.

site_title: Congress authorises US$577 billion in US defense spending
summary: The US Congress approved a defense policy bill authorizing $577 billion in defense spending, including $496 billion for the Pentagon's base budget and $64 billion for conflicts abroad. The bill also authorizes training and equipment for Iraqi and Syrian forces fighting Islamic State rebels and endorses the plan to vet, train, and equip a moderate Syrian opposition military force. The measure also includes steps to control personnel costs and rejects efforts to retire certain weapons systems, such as the A-10 Warthog and USS George Washington aircraft carrier.

site_title: China's falling inflation raises prospect of faster easing
summary: China's inflation rate fell to a five-year low in November, sparking expectations of faster monetary easing to combat deflation and slow economic growth. Consumer price inflation and the producer pricing index (PPI) are at their lowest levels in years, with the PPI having declined for 33 consecutive months. This has led to a surge in Chinese shares, with the SSE Composite index rising 3% on Wednesday, as investors anticipate the central bank will cut banks' reserve requirement ratios to inject more cash into the economy.

site_title: AP Strategic buys stake in LionGold's former gold project
summary: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments has acquired a 22.3% stake in Silvermane Investments, which owns LionGold's former Amayapampa Gold Project in Bolivia. The firm paid S$6 million and will pay the remaining balance through non-transferrable convertible notes. The acquisition allows Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments to invest in the "highly prospective" mineral mining business, with the potential to generate good cash flow and enhance shareholder value.

site_title: Seoul: Shares slide to 3-week low on China growth worries; won up
summary: South Korean shares fell 1.29% to a 3-week low, closing at 1,945.56 points, amid concerns of sluggish growth in China. China's consumer inflation eased to its lowest in five years, fueling worries about South Korea's largest export destination. The won strengthened against the dollar on short-covering, closing at 1,102.2 to the dollar.

site_title: Cambridge acquiring asset in business park
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) is acquiring a property in Singapore's International Business Park for S$28 million. The three-storey building has a gross floor area of 6,434 sqm and a 41.6-year land lease. CIT will lease the property back to the vendor for 11.6 years, with options to renew for two consecutive five-year terms. The acquisition is expected to enhance CIT's portfolio and will be funded through cash and existing debt facilities.

site_title: Revive those memories of much-loved musicals
summary: The Philharmonic Winds, a local wind orchestra, is set to hold its year-end concert, Circle Of Life: A Night Of Musicals, on December 21 at the Esplanade Concert Hall. The event will feature a mix of popular hits from musicals such as Phantom of the Opera and The Lion King, alongside local hits and performances by three local musicians, including Benjamin Kheng of The Sam Willows. The concert aims to bring together audiences from all walks of life and inspire them to attend other concerts by the orchestra.

site_title: Italy youth jobless rate risks social explosion: IMF chief
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde warns Italy is at risk of a social explosion due to its 43% youth unemployment rate, with emigration reaching a 10-year high. The IMF attributes the crisis to Italy's "toxic" economy, low growth, and restrictive labor market, which Lagarde says creates a vicious cycle of low investment and hiring. Lagarde urges Prime Minister Matteo Renzi to implement reforms, including boosting training and apprenticeships, cutting payroll taxes, and removing labor market restrictions.

site_title: Societe Generale pulls out of long-delayed Queensland project
summary: Societe Generale has suspended its involvement in financing a $10 billion coal mine, rail, and port project in Queensland, Australia, due to the project's years-long delay. The French bank cited the project's challenges from landowners and green groups, as well as falling coal prices. Developer GVK Hancock will focus on finalizing approvals and securing supply agreements before seeking financing again. This decision marks the latest twist for the project, which was originally scheduled to start producing coal in 2014. Green groups have welcomed the bank's withdrawal, calling it "good news".

site_title: Fugitive Thai millionaire protests his innocence
summary: Thai millionaire Nopporn Suppipat, 43, has denied helping orchestrate the kidnapping of a man who owed him money, claiming he fled to Cambodia after learning he'd be charged under Thailand's lese majeste law, which carries up to 15 years in prison. He was among 20 people arrested in a police corruption case, which has also led to the arrest of relatives of Princess Srirasmi, the wife of Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn.

site_title: Next year seen positive for Singapore equity and debt markets
summary: Singapore's equity and debt markets are expected to have a positive year in 2015, driven by Asia's buoyant economies. OCBC Bank officials predict more companies will opt for corporate IPOs rather than Reits, citing high property prices and the upcoming expiration of a foreign-sourced income tax exemption. The bond market is also expected to perform well, with volumes remaining strong despite low interest rates and inflation concerns. Foreign issuers are likely to increase their presence in the market, with Asia's US dollar bond market expected to reach over US$230-US$240 billion in 2015.

site_title: Global Logistic Properties partners GIC in US$8.1b acquisition
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has partnered Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC in a US$8.1 billion acquisition of a US warehouse and distribution center portfolio. GLP will initially hold a 55% stake, which will be reduced to 10% by August 2015 as part of its fund management strategy. The deal gives GLP "immediate scale" in the US logistics market and is expected to be completed in the first quarter of next year.

site_title: Foreign drug firms in China see approval delays
summary: Foreign pharmaceutical companies in China face delays in introducing new medicines due to changes in regulatory procedures. At least 34 applications from foreign multinationals have been or are set to be delayed after Chinese regulators began requiring an added procedure, potentially pushing back plans by up to 2 years. The changes highlight uncertainties for international drug manufacturers in China, where government scrutiny of sales practices has intensified, with the China FDA now requiring more rigorous examination of international clinical trials.

site_title: Italy, France hit back at Merkel (Amended)
summary: Italy and France have responded to Chancellor Angela Merkel's call for them to bring their budgets into line with EU rules by telling her to focus on Germany's own economic woes instead. Italian and French officials criticized Merkel's remarks, saying they were lecturing other EU nations without addressing Germany's own issues, such as low birth rates and crumbling infrastructure. France's Finance Minister Michel Sapin suggested Merkel should focus on her own country's problems before criticizing others, while an Italian official described her comments as "regrettable" and lacking respect.

site_title: Euro up but kept in check by Greece's situation
summary: The euro rose 0.15% against the US dollar, but was kept in check by concerns over Greece's uncertain political situation, which prompted investors to sell into any bounce. Greek bond yields rose, and the country's stocks fell to a quarter-century low. The European Central Bank conducts its second targeted long-term refinancing operation on Thursday, with expectations of a lower volume than desired. Meanwhile, the dollar fell 0.5% against the yen, and other currencies like the won and ringgit also gained as investors cut bearish bets.

images.alt_text: The euro was up 0.15 per cent against the dollar at US$1.2390 , having fallen to US$1.2365 earlier in European trade after Greek bond yields rose.

site_title: France's Total inaugurates major oil project off Angola
summary: France's Total has inaugurated a major oil project, CLOV, off Angola with a capacity of 160,000 barrels per day. The project, launched in 2010 at a cost of $8 billion, is part of Total's African investments despite falling oil prices. New CEO Patrick Pouyanne emphasized Total's strengths in ultra-deep water, liquefied natural gas, and Africa, stating the company will maintain long-term projects despite volatility. Total is the largest producer on the continent and in Angola, with a third of its production occurring in Africa.

site_title: HDB resale prices at 40-month low: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore have hit a 40-month low, with flash estimates showing a 0.8% decline in November. This marks a 6.3% year-on-year drop in HDB resale prices, according to SRX Property. Property consultants expect further softening of resale prices due to a large supply of homes entering the market from upgraders and new executive condominiums. The median price at which buyers snapped up HDB flats in November was S$3,000 below its computer-generated market value, with executive flats marking the steepest month-on-month decline.

site_title: Can you beat your 4+% CPF returns?
summary: Singapore's private pension plans can potentially beat the Central Provident Fund (CPF) rate of 4% per annum, but it depends on individual circumstances. Fund managers say yes, citing the ability to take calculated risks to achieve higher returns. Insurers say no, due to regulatory restrictions and the high administrative costs involved. Financial planners say it depends, requiring a case-by-case approach to determine what is "acceptably safe" and "unacceptably risky" for each individual. The government has also stated that higher returns do not necessarily come with higher risks.

site_title: Building of world's most powerful land-based telescope gets go-ahead
summary: The European Southern Observatory (ESO) has authorized the construction of the European Extremely Large Telescope (E-ELT), the world's most powerful land-based telescope, with funding exceeding 90% of the estimated $1.6 billion cost. The 39-meter-aperture telescope will be built in Chile's Atacama desert and is expected to start operations in 10 years. It will enable significant scientific discoveries in exoplanets, galaxy composition, and the deep universe. Poland's accession to the ESO has helped meet the 90% funding threshold, paving the way for the telescope's construction.

site_title: Lure of mass sports events is here to stay
summary: The running scene in Singapore remains popular, with numerous events drawing tens of thousands of participants. Despite concerns of saturation, event management company Spectrum Worldwide's managing director Chris Robb notes that new events, such as themed runs, are attracting new participants. These events are seen as opportunities for companies to build relationships with runners and their staff, rather than cannibalizing existing events. Robb also sees potential in swimming, citing successful mass swim events in Australia and South Africa, and believes Singapore is ready for a similar culture.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

SATURATION POINT? NOT QUITE: The Standard Chartered Marathon Singapore being flagged off last year. Of late, the Republic has been hosting a series of mass runs, drawing tens of thousands of participants.

site_title: China to deepen economic reforms in 2015
summary: China's ruling Communist Party has stated its intention to deepen economic reforms in 2015, aiming to boost domestic demand and further urbanize the country. The politburo acknowledged the risks faced by the economy, citing a cooling economy and challenging conditions, but emphasized the nation's growth engine remains in good shape. China will balance competing needs of stabilizing and reforming its economy, and is expected to adjust its annual growth target to 7% from 7.5% next year. The government will focus on reducing poverty, monitoring the labor market, and balancing imports and exports.

site_title: India's November services activity expands at fastest pace in five months: PMI
summary: India's services sector expanded at its fastest pace in five months in November, driven by rising new orders and falling raw material costs. The HSBC Services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to 52.6, up from 50 in October. However, business confidence plummeted to a seven-year low. Despite this, input costs for services firms fell for the first time in over five years, and consumer inflation eased to 5.52% in October. The Reserve Bank of India kept interest rates unchanged, hinting at a possible cut next year if inflation remains subdued.

site_title: Bank of England keeps rates on hold at record low
summary: The Bank of England maintained interest rates at a record low of 0.5% due to low inflation and a weak global economic outlook. Policymakers gave more weight to these risks than a strong domestic recovery, with no rate hike expected until 2016. The decision was influenced by weak pay growth, inflation below target, and a poor eurozone outlook. Britain is expected to experience more fiscal austerity, potentially keeping monetary policy loose. Financial markets anticipate a first rate hike in late 2015 or early 2016.

site_title: Distressed debt from emerging markets down the most since 2008
summary: Distressed debt in emerging markets has declined 9.8% this year, the largest drop since 2008, due to a glut in commodities, plummeting oil prices, and sanctions against Russia. Companies like Indonesian coal miner PT Bumi Resources and Russian Standard Bank are struggling to pay debts, with losses reaching record lows. Hedge funds are shutting down at a rate not seen since the credit crunch, and the International Monetary Fund forecasts a 3.8% global economic expansion in 2015, below pre-2007 growth rates.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 16.68 points to 3,320.07. Volume reached 24.8 million shares worth S$64.9 million, with 80 gainers and 35 losers. Investors remained positive despite US tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views, driving the STI up 0.4%.

site_title: Top outstanding leaders in Asia
summary: Colin Tan, Group Managing Director of Hatten Group Sdn Bhd, is featured as one of the top outstanding leaders in Asia. Hatten Group, a Malaysian property developer, has achieved success through innovation and a proven track record of success, winning 30 prestigious international awards. Tan emphasizes the importance of learning from industry trends and not being afraid to dream big. The company has successfully integrated core businesses in project development, construction, and asset management, and has made significant contributions to the community and conservation efforts.

site_title: China falls 20 spots in global graft perception ranking
summary: China has dropped 20 spots in the global graft perception ranking, falling to 91st place, following a decline in public perception of corruption among officials. Singapore remains the most highly ranked economy in Asia at No. 7. The decline in China's ranking is attributed to growing corruption concerns in the region, with Singapore also experiencing a slight drop in its ranking.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's stock market ended lower on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closing at 1,745.69, down 12.46 points. 1.88 billion lots worth RM2.26 billion were traded, with 519 stocks losing value and 286 gaining.

site_title: Full house expected for IPTL debut in Singapore
summary: The International Premier Tennis League (IPTL) is set to debut in Singapore with a full house expected at the 10,400-capacity Indoor Stadium. Over 9,000 tickets have been sold for the opening day, with top players like Serena Williams, Tomas Berdych, and Andre Agassi participating in the tournament. Despite being at the bottom of the table with three losses, head coach Josh Eagle is hopeful of a turn in fortunes over the next three days. The IPTL tour will move to New Delhi after Singapore, with a team format and quirky features such as a shot-clock and "happiness power point" opportunities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 3.78 points to 1745.59. The market saw 36.54 million lots traded worth RM15.43 million, with 82 gainers and 77 losers.

site_title: Value of shale boom junk bonds down nearly 10%
summary: US junk-rated energy bonds have plummeted nearly 10% since crude oil peaked in June, with potential losses of $8.5 billion. The decline is attributed to OPEC's refusal to ease a supply glut, pushing oil prices to a five-year low. Companies such as Halcon Resources, Sand-Ridge Energy, and Goodrich Petroleum Corp are among those facing significant losses, with some bonds down 26-34%. Experts warn of potential defaults and a downward spiral in production and cash flow as oil prices continue to fall.

site_title: Qatar's Mayhoola leads in bid to buy Pepe Jeans
summary: Qatar's Mayhoola for Investments SPC is leading the bid to buy Pepe Jeans, a Spanish fashion brand, with a bid of at least 700 million euros, surpassing the sellers' price expectation. Mayhoola, backed by the Qatari royal family, is the only bidder willing to pay a high price, according to sources. The company is majority-owned by private equity firms and has a 30% stake held by the management team. The luxury goods industry is experiencing a lower growth cycle due to economic weakness in Europe and international sanctions.

site_title: KepLand in JV to build office tower in Yangon
summary: Keppel Land, a Singapore-based property developer, has entered into a joint venture agreement with ShweTaung Group to build a 23-storey Grade-A office tower in Yangon, Myanmar. The US$47.4 million investment will provide approximately 33,400 square meters of net leasable space. Construction has begun and is expected to be completed in 2017, meeting the demand for high-quality office space in Yangon.

site_title: A new NY convention centre at no extra cost is possible
summary: A proposed new convention center in New York City, located at Sunnyside Yards in Queens, could address the city's lack of competitiveness in the conventions and conferences business without costing taxpayers a dime. The plan involves relocating the Javits Center, selling its property, and using the proceeds to finance the new center. The site would also enable the development of 14,000 new housing units, 2 million square feet of office and retail space, and a job-creating technology campus, making a significant contribution to Mayor Bill de Blasio's housing plan.

site_title: JLL buys Henry Butcher's international residential project sales business
summary: JLL has acquired Henry Butcher's international residential project sales business in Malaysia, expanding its presence in the country and enhancing its international residential sales base. The 13-strong team, led by Jazmine Goh, will join JLL's existing 17-strong Malaysian business, offering clients access to more global investment locations and market-leading intelligence. The acquisition reflects the strong appetite among Asian investors for overseas properties and JLL's efforts to cater to this demand.

site_title: Australia rules out open tender for subs: Japan likely beneficiary
summary: Australia has ruled out an open tender for its Collins-class submarine replacement, instead opting to consider a deal with Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and Kawasaki Heavy Industries. The decision bolsters Japan's position as the likely builder of the new multibillion-dollar fleet, which will be powered by a lithium-ion battery propulsion system. The Australian government has not yet chosen a manufacturer, with several European defense contractors expressing interest in the project. A final decision is expected in early 2015.

site_title: Plunging oil prices won't dent global clean power investment
summary: Global clean power investment is expected to reach $250 billion this year, despite plunging oil prices, with renewables accounting for 60% of new power plant investments over the next decade. The US, China, Japan, and the EU are driving the shift towards green energy, with policies and incentives supporting the industry. Oil prices have not affected countries' willingness to address climate change, with the US and other nations committed to reducing carbon emissions and transitioning to low-carbon economies.

images.alt_text: Renewables remain a tiny fraction of the world's power supply, accounting for about 5 per cent of the electricity generated, according to the most recent data from the IEA.

site_title: Qantas domestic, international heads out in management revamp
summary: Qantas has undergone a management revamp, with CEOs of its domestic and international full-service units, Simon Hickey and Lyell Strambi, leaving the company. Hickey will explore new opportunities, while Strambi will seek new challenges outside aviation. New CFO Tino La Spina will oversee the international and freight units, and Andrew David will lead the domestic unit. CEO Alan Joyce will remain in his position, overseeing a cost-cutting program aimed at reducing 5,000 jobs. The changes will take effect next year, with the transition finalized by March.

images.alt_text: MR JOYCE: Said there's still lots to do to build the foundation for a stronger and more sustainable Qantas

site_title: Next GE to be a deadly serious fight: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned that the next general election, set for 2017, will be a serious fight, with the outcome determining the government. The ruling People's Action Party has identified promising candidates, including potential office holders. Lee also hinted that his successor will likely come from a "renewed, strengthened and more seasoned" team of parliamentarians and ministers. He was re-elected to the party's central executive committee, alongside other key officials.

images.alt_text: THE next general election, which must be held by January 2017, will be a deadly serious fight, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong told members of his People's Action Party (PAP) on Sunday morning.
